DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, Aug. 1, or the 12th day of the sixth month of the Year of the Snake according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1774: British chemist Sir Joseph Priestley announces that he has discovered oxygen.
1834: Robert Morrison, the first English missionary to go to China and the translator of the Bible into Chinese, dies.
1894: War between China and Japan over the question of Korea breaks out. The Treaty of Shimonoseki was signed the next year, compelling the Ching court to pay a huge indemnity, open its seaports, recognize the independence of Korea, and cede the Liaotung Peninsula, Taiwan, and the Pescadores to Japan.
1915: The Peking government mints its silver coin, known as "Yuantatou," bearing the likeness of Yuan Shih-kai.
1926: Kwangtung University changes its name to National Sun Yat-sen University.
1927: The Chinese communists stage the Nanchang Uprising against the Nationalist government.
1928: The Central Broadcasting System is set up in Nanking by the Kuomintang.
1941: American volunteer aviators form the "Flying Tigers," with Brig. Gen. Claire L. Chennault as commander. They help China combat Japanese air superiority in the early stages of World War II.
1943: Lin Sen, chairman of the Nationalist government, dies at the age of 76.
1949: The Office of Tsungtsai (director general) of the Kuomintang is established in Taipei.
1958: An insurance program providing 180,000 government employees with coverage for maternity leave, illness, injury, disability and death is put into effect.
1966: The Chinese Communist Party opens a plenum meeting that declares the start of the 10-year Cultural Revolution.
1971: The Tainan Giants of the Republic of China win the Little League Asian and Pacific play-offs.
1973: The Economic Planning Council (EPC) of the Executive Yuan is inaugurated. The EPC replaces the Council for International Economic Cooperation and Development.
1973: General Kao Kuei-yuan takes over from General Cheng Ta-ching as the ROC's minister of national defense.
1974: Prof. Hsia Yuan-yu, a noted zoologist, dies of heart failure in Taipei at the age of 86.
1976: The National Reconstruction Seminar opens in Taipei with 130 local and overseas Chinese scholars participating.
1984: ROC athlete Tsai Wen-yee wins a bronze medal in weightlifting at the 1984 Olympic Games.
1986: The Executive Yuan approves a slight increase in the premium rate of laborers' occupational injury insurance. The rates for thirty-two occupations are raised.
1987: The Council of Labor Affairs is formally established under the Executive Yuan.
1989: A foreign currency call loan market designed to make the metropolis an international financial center is established in Taipei.
1992: The National Unification Council defines "one China" as "one country and two areas each ruled separately by a different political entity."
1992: The Taiwan Garrison General Headquarters, the ROC's highest security institution, is disbanded, and the Coastal Patrol General Headquarters is established under the Ministry of National Defense.
1999: The U.S. Defense Department announces the sale of two E-2T Hawkeye 2000E airborne early warning aircraft and related equipment and services to Taiwan.
2000: Ruling Democratic Progressive Party Chairman Frank Hsieh pays a visit to New Party leader Hau Lung-bin, a move Hsieh said is aimed at showing respect to the opposition.
2000: Taiwan resident Huang You-fu becomes the 10 millionth traveler to pass through Macau International Airport.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "By attending to the cleanliness and purity of his person and the propriety and dignity of his dress, and in every word and act permitting nothing which is contrary to good taste and decency, that is how the ruler puts in order his personal conduct."

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER EDUCATION MINISTER RELEASED ON NT$2 MILLION BAIL

TEXT.P: Former Education Minister Yang Chao-hsiang, who had been subpoenaed for questioning for alleged involvement in a bribery and corruption case, was released Wednesday morning on NT$2 million (US$57,637) bail, to Taipei law enforcement sources reported.

Yang was one of 14 people, including several former officials from the Ministry of Education (MOE), who were recently subpoenaed by Taipei district prosecutors for questioning about their suspected involvement in the notorious Jin Wen Academy bribery and corruption scandal that erupted last year.

Yang was questioned on charges of receiving bribes from board members of Jin Wen Academy so as to help smooth upgrading the former high school to an academy and an illegal development project of the Taipei County school, including the development of residential houses.

The former education minister was required by prosecutors to produce sufficient documents and related evidence in three days to prove that a luxurious residence he owns that was built by the Jin Wen Group was purchased at a justifiable price.
Also on Wednesday, Huang Cheng-chieh, a former MOE department director, was released on NT$300,000 (US$8,646) bail after an overnight questioning session, the sources said.
Former Vice Education Minister Lin Chao-hsien had been arrested in May on similar corruption charges. He was released later on NT$2 million bail.
Chairman and CEO of the Jin Wen Group, Chang Wan-li, who is also wanted by prosecutors for fraud and bribery charges, has reportedly fled to Canada.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK PRICES UP BY 1.54 POINTS

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) gained ground on Wednesday, with the benchmark weighted price index moving up 1.54 points to close at 4,354.52.
Market turnover amounted to NT$48.33 billion (US$1.39 billion).

DOC.HEADLINE: VILLAGERS IN DANGEROUS AREAS SHOULD CONSIDER RESETTLING: CEPD HEAD

TEXT.P: The chairman of the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) suggested on Wednesday that residents of villages in geologically unsafe areas around the island should consider moving permanently to different locations.
Chen Poh-chih said these residents should think about resettling so as to avoid being the victims of natural disasters such as that wrought by Typhoon Toraji which swept across the island Monday.

The chairman said a CEPD ad hoc task force will be established shortly in order to tackle geological and conservation issues, particularly resolving the problem of landslides and mud-flows on a permanent basis.

He quoted tallies compiled by the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture as indicating that there are more than 50 villages islandwide, most inhabited by aboriginal groups, located in geologically dangerous areas, such as along river banks, on mountainsides or at the mouths of rivers.

A comprehensive resettlement plan to be mapped out by the CEPD task force is expected to become available in a week, and the actual implementation of the plan should begin some time next year at the earliest, Chen noted.

He added that not all the villages' residents should move, saying that many of the villages will become safe to live in after work on reinforcing related facilities protecting against natural disasters is carried out.

Before any resettlement plan is carried out, Chen said, all relevant factors must first be considered and dealt with, including the villagers' feelings about resettling, their prospects for making an adequate living following resettlement, as well as other cultural and social issues.

The CEPD ad hoc task force will also solicit opinions and suggestions from specialists in the fields of geography and geology and from experts in the areas of local customs, practices and culture when drafting a resettlement plan, Chen noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices opened high but closed lower on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) on Wednesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 1.54 points to close at 4,354.52.

Encouraged by a rise in U.S. stock prices, the bourse opened at 4,402.71 but began to go down later due to profit-taking selling pressure. The index fluctuated between 4,411.92 and 4,328.53 during trading.

A total of 1.59 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$48.33 billion (US$1.39 billion), an increase from the previous trading session which saw 1.49 billion stocks change hands on a market turnover of NT$48.05 billion (US$1.38 billion).
Only one of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with electrical shares moving up 0.5 percent.

The other major categories posted losses, with construction stocks moving down the most at 2.3 percent, followed by bank and insurance shares and cement stocks, both at 1 percent, textile issues at 0.8 percent, plastics and chemical shares at 0.5 percent, foodstuff stocks at 0.4 percent, and pulp and paper issues at 0.2 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 343 to 140, with 102 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock index futures market were lower on Wednesday, as Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index futures for August moved down 24 points to close at 4,267, with 9,995 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for September lost 46 points to finish at 4,252, with 53 contracts traded. No transactions were reported for other months.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Wednesday at 4,291 for August, 4,298 for September, 4,254 for December, 4,240 for next March, and 4,283 for next June.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were generally lower.
August TE futures edged down 0.6 points to close at 226.9, with 1,802 contract transactions, while September TE futures rose 1.35 points to finish at 226.1, with seven contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for other months.
August TF futures moved down 4.8 points to finish at 507.2, with 551 contract transactions, while September TF futures decreased 15.2 points to close at 503.6, with four contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: LAWMAKERS LAUNCH NEW DRIVE TO HELP KIDS IN TYPHOON-STRICKEN AREAS

TEXT.P: Three opposition Kuomintang (KMT) legislators launched a campaign Wednesday to help children orphaned in the recent typhoon disaster.

Legislators Ting Shou-chung, Hung Hsiu-chu and Tina Wei-kang Pan urged candidates of all political stripes for the year-end elections for legislators and local government chiefs to cut spending on campaign literature and use the money instead to sponsor children in areas hardest-hit by Typhoon Toraji.
Ting pointed out that Toraji has inflicted heavy human casualties and property damage on Taiwan, particularly in the central county of Nantou and the eastern county of Hualien.

"In view of the government's limited financial and manpower resources, we have launched the drive to urge those who intend to run in the legislative and local government chief elections scheduled for December to reduce the number of their campaign posters, banners and other publicity materials and use the money to sponsor orphans in the typhoon-stricken areas until they can complete university education," Ting said.
Ting noted that candidates for public elections tend to spend hundreds of thousands, or even millions of new Taiwan dollars on campaign literature.
"We hope that all hopefuls in the December elections will spend less on campaign pamphlets and show more concern and offer more assistance to typhoon victims," Ting urged at a news conference.
Speaking on the same occasion, Hung said many local people have become fed up with the political wrangling and lip services of Taiwan's politicians.

"It's time for political figures to improve their public image," Hung said, adding that spending less on campaign vans and printed publicity materials and using the money saved to help young typhoon victims would be a good way to help politicians win popular support.
Pan echoed Hung's views, saying that money saved by reduced campaign literature could help finance living expenses and school tuition fees of children orphaned in the typhoon.

"We hope that all hopefuls intending to run in the year-end elections, regardless of their party affiliation or political stripes, can join our campaign to help more children in typhoon-stricken areas," Pan said.

The three lawmakers also announced that they would sponsor the children bereaved by firefighter Lee Chi-jung and police officer Lin Teh-fu, both of whom were killed in typhoon relief operations in the eastern county of Hualien, one of the hardest-hit regions.
Typhoon Toraji battered Taiwan with gusty winds and torrential rain Monday, leaving at least 69 people dead and 138 others missing, according to official tallies as of Wednesday morning.

DOC.HEADLINE: MACAU AIRLINES COOPERATES WITH FAR EAST AIR ON CROSS-STRAIT SERVICE
DOC.DATELINE: CKS International Airport, Aug. 1 (CNA) (By Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: A Macau Airlines Boeing 757 passenger liner leased from Taiwan's Far East Air Transport Corp. departed Taiwan for Macau Wednesday morning, marking the first joint-venture between airline companies from Taiwan and Macau.
The leased plane will carry Taiwan passengers to Macau, en route to mainland China.
Although the plane is liveried in the colors of Macau Airlines, it is piloted and crewed completely by a Far East crew, marking an unprecedented cooperation agreement between two airlines.

Pilot Kao Tse-li lauded the cooperative operation as a "right do," at a time when competition among rival airlines operating services between Taiwan and mainland China via "third places" such as Hong Kong and Macau have become increasingly cutthroat.

Chen Chih-ying, head of the plane's cabin crew, also welcomed the joint-venture operation, saying that it opens a new method for Far East to serve passengers from Taiwan who are heading to mainland China.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN EXPORTS TO JAPAN DIMINISH SLIGHTLY

TEXT.P: Taiwan exported US$6.85 billion-worth of products and services to Japan in the first five months of this year, a slight decrease of 2.36 percent from the same period of last year, sources from the Board of Foreign Trade (BOFT) reported Wednesday.
While almost all categories of Japan-bound Taiwan exports posted reductions in the January-May period, the exports of electrical machinery showed remarkable growth, BOFT officials noted.
The officials attributed the commendable growth in exports of electrical machinery mainly to growth in the export of integrated circuit (IC) products.
These exports, valued at US$1.91 billion in the first five months, represented an increase of 17.14 percent over the figure posted in the same period of the previous year, BOFT officials said.
They noted, however, that similar exports by Taiwan's major rival -- South Korea -- increased by 20.05 percent.

Taiwan exports of machine tools and optical instruments to Japan were down 10.87 percent and 14.96 percent year-on-year, respectively, in the five-month period, while exports of Taiwan-made fishery products, plastics and household products to Japan also diminished by a two-digit rate in the same period, the officials added.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT TO WATCH CLOSELY FORMER CHAIRMAN'S DEEDS

TEXT.P: The opposition Kuomintang (KMT) will watch closely the deeds of former KMT Chairman Lee Teng-hui when he attends the inauguration of a new political party, a KMT official said Wednesday.

Chao Shou-po, director general of the KMT's Organization and Development Committee, made the remarks one day after Konsin. C. Shah, a member of the KMT old guard, cut himself on the arm during a party meeting to demonstrate the strength of his desire to see Lee expelled from the party.
Chao said that when Lee attends the inauguration of the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU), the KMT will watch "what he does and what he says."

The TSU will be headed by former Minister of the Interior Huang Chu-wen, who is closely affiliated with Lee. The former chairman has raised the ire of KMT members by saying that he will help the minority government of President Chen Shui-bian gain a stable majority in the year-end legislative elections.

Chao said that the views on the matter within the party at present are polarized and that the KMT has to be careful how it handles the matter, adding that as long as there is substantial evidence against Lee, the KMT disciplinary committee will start an investigation.

Vice President of the Legislative Yuan Yao Eng-chi also said that the KMT must stress solidarity and tolerance at present. Only if Lee openly stumps for candidates of other political parties and jeopardizes the survival of the KMT, he said, will the party decide to take action.

Yao, who met with Chao Wednesday, said that any decision on whether to expel Lee will be left to the disciplinary committee. If Lee's deeds jeopardize the survival and development of the party, then the KMT will definitely take action, he added.

Yao said that the KMT is "still the center of political stability" in the nation and has made the greatest contribution to the country. He added his hope that those who have split from the KMT will come back to its fold.

According to Chao, the inauguration of the TSU is basically a "social event" in which Lee and figures from other political parties will participate. Lee's attendance therefore cannot be construed as stumping for TSU candidates, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: `NO MORE ROOM FOR TAX CUTS': DPP LEGISLATOR

TEXT.P: Legislator Chien Hsi-chieh of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) said Wednesday that "there is no more room for the government to cut taxes."

Chien made the remarks at a press conference in the wake of calls by industrial and business groups in the ongoing Economic Development Advisory Conference (EDAC) for the cutting or abolishment of six taxes.

According to Chien, Taiwan, with an average tax rate of 12.7 percent, is the "least burdened country in the world in terms of taxes," and with a government budget deficit of more than NT$400 billion (US$11.49 billion), there is no room for the government to further cut taxes.
The government should therefore silence interest groups that continue to suggest tax cuts, Chien went on.

He cited Lin Chuang, director-general of the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting & Statistics, who warned earlier that with a budget deficit of up to NT$400 billion, the government is not expected to be able to make ends meet for the next decade under the current tax system, let alone if further cuts are implemented.

Chien criticized the trade and industry groups for "only seeking their own interests" in proposing tax cuts, adding that the act would not benefit the general public and would not encourage consumption.
Professor Tseng Chu-wei of National Chengchi University opposed tax cuts, stressing that they should not be used to "bail out" the government.

Taipei University Professor Huang Shih-hsin also vehemently opposed the cuts, but said that the enterprises should not be criticized too heavily. He added that the social responsibility of Taiwan businesses lags behind developed countries and it is "a joke" for the government to let them play such a big role in its decision making process.

DOC.HEADLINE: PM ORDERS STUDY OF MEASURES TO PREVENT DEFECTION TO MAINLAND CHINA

TEXT.P: Premier Chang Chun-hsiung directed the Central Personnel Administration (CPA) Wednesday to discuss with relevant government agencies feasible measures to prevent military and civilian officials from defecting to mainland China.

Speaking at a weekly Cabinet meeting, Chang said the CPA should invite officials from the Ministry of National Defense (MND), the Ministry of Justice, the Mainland Affairs Council and the Veterans Affairs Commission (VAC) to carve out an effective mechanism to prevent retired and incumbent military officers and civil servants from defecting to work for the mainland government or its People's Liberation Army (PLA).

"We must formulate stringent regulations to block our career soldiers and civil servants from defecting to work for the mainland authorities," Chang said, adding that the CPA should produce a comprehensive report on possible measures in two weeks.

Chang's directive came after a local newspaper reported recently that mainland China is considering taking advantage of Taiwan's decision to reduce its troops by courting retired Republic of China military officers to work for the PLA. The report drew government attention and concern.

Noting that establishing a modern, elite deterrent force is one of the government's major policy goals, Chang said the ROC military will continue its personnel trimming and organization restructuring work.
Nevertheless, he went on, the military should refine its strategy and practice in carrying out the work.
The premier also asked the MND and the VAC to strengthen services, concern and care for all military servicemen to consolidate their loyalty to the country.
Meanwhile, Chief of the General Staff Tang Yao-ming also encouraged all military servicemen to dedicate themselves to serving the country during an inspection tour of the Navy General Headquarters.
Tang explained in a speech to all officers and men why the ROC must beep up its defense capabilities in the face of mainland China's ever-increasing military threat.

He also again debunked the recent newspaper report that had aroused so much concern, denying that a retired ROC army officer has defected to work for the PLA. Tang stressed that all ROC military servicemen must uphold their loyalty to the national cause.
Tang made a similar inspection tour of the Air Force General Headquarters last week and is scheduled to inspect the Army General Headquarters next week.
Military authorities said the tours are routine.

As for recent speculation about a possible reshuffle of military brass, the Ministry of National Defense said it is the ministry's established policy to refrain from commenting on military personnel changes before they are formally approved by relevant authorities.

DOC.HEADLINE: UMC TO SHIFT PRODUCTION TO 12-INCH WAFERS

TEXT.P: United Microelectronics (UMC) Chairman Robert Tsao said Tuesday that Taiwan's leading semiconductor foundry will shift the emphasis of its production capacity from 8-inch wafers to 12-inch wafers.
He added that 12-inch chips are expected to account for half of the corporation's chip output by 2003.

At an investor conference, Tsao said that for the first half of 2001, UMC posted net sales amounting to NT$38.596 billion, with net income totaling NT$4.62 billion and basic earnings per share reaching NT$0.4.
The corporation suffered a NT$3.05 billion loss before income tax in the second quarter. Tsao said that revenues in the third quarter will continue to decline from the level of the second quarter.
He added, however, that he expects revenues to bottom out in the third quarter and improvements will be seen in the fourth quarter.
Tsao pointed out that the semiconductor sector is facing the worst recession since 1985 and a speedy recovery before 2003 is very unlikely.

Due to the global over-capacity situation for 8-inch wafers, UMC plans to reduce the company's monthly 8-inch wafer capacity from 240,000 units to 160,000 units within the next six to eight months, said Tsao.
The company is planning to sell one-third of its 8-inch wafer production facilities and use the capital to expand its 12-inch production capacity, he added.
Tsao disclosed that UMC's NT$1.5 billion capital investment this year will be used to expand the production capacity of 12-inch wafers.

UMC now has three 12-inch fabs. Trecenti fab in Japan has monthly production capacity of 1,000 wafers; Fab 12A in Tainan, Taiwan, has a design capacity of 40,000 wafers and its production capacity by the end of this year will reach 10,000 wafers; and the Singapore UMCi fab will install its production equipment by the third quarter of 2002, according to Vice Chairman and CEO Peter Chang.
Chang said that the production costs of the 12-inch wafers will be reduced by up to 30 percent as compared to that of 8-inch wafers.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN INSPECTS NANTOU COUNTY IN WAKE OF TYPHOON TORAJI

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian on Wednesday inspected Nantou County, the area in Taiwan worst hit by Typhoon Toraji, in the aftermath of the typhoon that swept across the island Monday.
The streets of Chunkeng Village in Shuili Township, Nantou County, were literally buried by mudslides, and teary-eyed residents of the village asked the president to help them rebuild their homes.
The president said he had already instructed that an inter-government agency task force be formed to formulate an overall reconstruction plan.

In response to complaints that the military has not been doing enough in terms of relief and reconstruction work, Chen also instructed the Ministry of National Defense to send more personnel to join in the effort.
Meanwhile, Nantou County Magistrate Peng Pai-hsien also said that he had asked for more military personnel to help in clearing roads and highways to bring traffic back to normal.

Nantou County was the worst-hit county in Taiwan, with 25 residents being killed and 87 going missing, followed by Hualien County with 24 residents killed and 29 missing. As most of the those who went missing are believed to either have been swept away by floods or buried in landslides or mudflows triggered by torrential rains, the chances of finding them alive is considered slim.

While the president headed to Nantou County, Vice President Annette Lu inspected Hualien County Wednesday morning. Both the president and vice president have donated one-month's salary towards typhoon relief.
Meanwhile, Premier Chang Chun-hsiung has urged the Legislative Yuan to agree to the use of special funds to help in reconstruction efforts.
A Buddhist organization took the lead in extending help by donating NT$1 million (US$28,719) to the Ministry of the Interior.

Lin Chao, director general of Taiwan Sokagakkai, said that since the disastrous earthquake of Sept. 21, 1999, the organization has carried out spiritual reconstruction work in the quake-affected areas, and he urged the public not to give up hope in the wake of this new natural disaster.

Interior Minister Chang Po-ya, in accepting the check, noted that Typhoon Toraji wreaked severe havoc and that the situation in some areas is even worse than it was in the wake of the killer temblor of Sept. 21, 1991.
Premier Chang and another government agency chief donated one-day's salary toward typhoon relief, and both urged other civil servants to follow suit.
In addition to the heavy human casualties, agriculture, livestock, and fishery losses caused by the typhoon have been estimated to be NT$1.58 billion.
Taiwan Power Company said that as of 11 a.m. Wednesday, 15,575 households were still without electricity, adding that power should be restored to most by Wednesday night.
Some 2,000 of the worst hit households, located in the townships of Shuili and Hsinyi in Nantou County, will have to wait for roads to be cleared before work can commence on restoring their power.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN VISITORS TO TAIWAN TOP 1.38 MILLION IN JANUARY-JUNE PERIOD

TEXT.P: The number of foreign visitors to Taiwan in the first six months of this year totaled 1.38 million, the Cabinet-level Directorate-General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) said Wednesday.
The DGBAS statistics show that of this figure, 520,000 people came from Japan, 201,000 came from Hong Kong and 184,000 came from the United States.
Among the foreign visitors, 516,000 were tourists, up 38.5 percent over the same period of last year, while 452,000 came to Taiwan for business, down 0.1 percent.

Because of the increase in the number of foreign visitors, the DGBAS said that the occupancy rate of international tourist hotels in Taiwan averaged 63.6 percent between January-May, up 3.3 percent over the year-earlier level.
The statistics also indicate that 3.74 million Taiwan people visited foreign countries between January-June, up 3.7 percent over the corresponding period of 2000.

DOC.HEADLINE: GRENADA OFFERS SYMPATHY TO TAIWAN FOLLOWING TYPHOON TORAJI
DOC.DATELINE: Panama City, July 31 (CNA) (By Oscar Chung and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Grenada, one of the Republic of China's diplomatic allies in the Caribbean, has conveyed its condolences and concern to Taiwan for the country's huge losses and damage caused by Typhoon Toraji.

In a letter delivered to ROC Ambassador L.S. Chiang, Grenada Governor-General Sir Daniel Williams asked Chiang to pass on a letter to ROC President Chen Shui-bian to express his deepest condolences and grave concern over the havoc wrecked by the typhoon, Chiang said Tuesday.

Williams said it is regrettable that Taiwan was hit by the disaster at a time when the country was working at reconstruction following the Sept. 21 earthquake of 1999, the worst tremor to hit Taiwan in a century.

The Grenada government and people would like to extend their moral support and best wishes to the people of Taiwan at a time when they are suffering a great deal of pain, Chiang quoted Williams as saying.

Typhoon Toraji, which will go down in history as one of the island's most damaging storms, swept through eastern and southern Taiwan Monday, killing at least 72 people and leaving more than 134 still missing. The death toll is expected to climb higher as rescue workers continue to find the bodies of those missing and now believed killed.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI MAYOR MEETS CEO OF U.S. COMPUTER FIRM

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou met Wednesday with Echo Tsai, CEO of HiQ Computers in Sunnyvale, Calif. who has been working since 1998 on a "Technology Goes Home" project to help disadvantaged students learn how to use computers.
Tsai grew up in the eastern Taiwan city of Taitung before going to the United States and founding HiQ Computers in 1986, whose annual transactions hit US$80 million last year.

She started the "Technology Goes Home" project in Boston, providing computer lessons for the city's poor students and helping them gain basic computer skills. Those who finish all the courses receive a computer as a gift and so far 1,000 computers have been given out.

The project has been very successful and has won the support of both the mayor of Boston and former U.S. Vice President Al Gore. The city has even designated June 14 as "Echo Tsai Day" as a mark of respect for her contributions.
According to Tsai, computers are the easiest way to shorten the distance between people, while those who finish the courses and obtain a diploma can look forward to better-paying jobs, she told Ma.
Ma also expressed his respect for Tsai and said he hopes the project can be implemented in Taipei to help lessen the digital divide between Taiwan's citizens.

DOC.HEADLINE: OPTICS, TELECOMMUNICATIONS TO BECOME ROC INDUSTRY MAINSTREAM: POLL

TEXT.P: Local companies said in a poll conducted by Business Week magazine that optics and telecommunications are the next star industries of the coming decade, with the potential to duplicate the success of the personal computer industry.

The results of the survey, published in the most recent issue of the magazine, show that 34.4 percent of the 711 companies whose income last year exceeded NT$500 million (US$14.4 million) believe in the future of the optics industry. Another 24.2 percent of the companies cast their votes for the success of the telecommunications industry.
Only 31.3 percent of the same companies said that they look favorably on the future of Taiwan's computer industry in the next three years, and as high as 48.7 percent expressed a reserved attitude.

A total of 25.8 percent of the companies said that they believe the personal digital assistant, or PDA, will become the top-selling computer-related product over the next three years, followed by notebook computers at 17.8 percent and LCD display monitors at 17.4 percent.
The companies ranked Acer as the Taiwan computer brand name most likely to remain globally active and competitive in the next three years, followed by Asustek.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. THINK TANK FORESEES NO BREAKTHROUGH IN CROSS-STRAIT LIMBO
DOC.DATELINE: New York, July 31 (CNA) (By Jennifer Huang and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The lingering political stalemate between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait is not expected to see any major breakthrough this year, according to a report released Tuesday by a noted U.S. think tank.

The report prepared by the National Committee on American Foreign Policy, many of whose research fellows have offered counseling to the U.S. government, said mainland China will continue for the foreseeable future to pressure Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian to accept its "one China" principle.
The report said that as Chen's administration fails to control a majority in the legislature, it has met opposition at nearly every turn in carrying out its major policies.
Against this background, the report said, mainland China will shun any engagement with the Chen administration to avoid giving any credit to Chen's personal political clout.

Moreover, the report went on, mainland China will step up efforts to forge ties with Taiwan's opposition camp and businesspeople with a view to further weakening Chen's political clout and reputation.
According to the report, the mainland authorities think Taiwan's current political and economic doldrums are creating a favorable environment for their "united front tricks."
The report said Beijing seems to be waiting for the reshuffle of Taiwan's political map that will follow the island's year-end legislative elections and the 2004 presidential election.

The report pointed out that the number of Taiwan-targeting missiles deployed by mainland China has continued to increase, rising from 40-50 five years ago to 300 at present. Moreover, it said, the performance and accuracy of mainland China's newly deployed missiles are better than the old ones.
Even though mainland China has heightened its military threat to Taiwan, the report said, Beijing is unlikely to use force against Taiwan in the short term due to the following four reasons:
-- Mainland China must focus its energy on domestic economic modernization and partial political restructuring;

-- the mainland is seeking to forge better ties with its Asian neighbors with a view to offsetting the expansion of U.S. influence in the Asia-Pacific area. If Beijing attacks Taiwan at the moment, the report said, it will draw a backlash from its Asian neighbors; and

-- the mainland leaders believe that time is on their side, that Taiwan's politics will remain unstable due to wrangling between its ruling and opposition parties and that the island will become increasingly reliant on the mainland market along with growing cross-strait commercial exchanges and Taipei's and Beijing's WTO accession.

Another noteworthy development is that the balance of military power between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait will eventually tilt toward the mainland, no matter what kinds of advanced weapons the United States sells to Taiwan in the future, the report said.

As a result, the report continued, the mainland is expected to continue its "wait and see" strategy toward cross-strait relations. It will continue to watch whether Chen will compromise on the "one China" issue, the report said, adding that the mainland at the same time will avoid any unnecessary conflict with the United States.

The report suggested that the Bush administration should exercise prudence in dealing with cross-strait affairs. It said the best strategy for the United States is to continue its present efforts to cultivate a favorable atmosphere for the resumption of peaceful cross-strait dialogue, including selling Taiwan selected advanced weapons to help maintain the cross-strait balance of military power.

The think tank is also scheduled to organize a roundtable meeting in New York from Aug. 13-14. Scholars from Taiwan, mainland China and the United States, as well as U.S. officials in charge of China and Taiwan affairs, will attend the conference.
It will be the first meeting of its kind since U.S. President George W. Bush's inauguration early this year.

The Taipei delegation will be composed of representatives of Taiwan's three main political parties and several officials, including Antonio Chiang, deputy secretary-general of the National Security Council.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA VOWS TO PUSH FOR PRESIDENT CHEN'S VISIT TO DENMARK

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Wednesday it will continue its efforts to pave the way for President Chen Shui-bian to visit Denmark late this year to receive an award to be presented by an international alliance of liberal parties.
MOFA spokeswoman Chang Siao-yue said the Republic of China government appreciates the Liberal International's goodwill in deciding to present its 2001 Freedom Award to President Chen.
As the award marks an international recognition of Chen's contribution to promoting Taiwan's democratization, Chang said, the MOFA hopes that Chen can receive the prestigious award in person.

Chang said she cannot elaborate on relevant preparations for Chen's travel to Denmark at the moment. Despite the absence of formal diplomatic ties, the ROC and Denmark share common beliefs in freedom and democracy, Chang said.

Noting that boosting substantive ties with European countries has been one of MOFA's major work plans, Chang said the ministry will redouble its efforts to push for the realization of Chen's Denmark travel plan to receive the Freedom Award. Because of Beijing's diplomatic embargo against Taiwan, no ROC head of state has ever visited any European country so far.
Chang's remarks came after local news media reported that Chen's personal aides have held many rounds of discussion on his Denmark travel plan.
Commenting on the report, Presidential Office officials said whether Chen can visit Denmark to receive the award personally will hinge on the Danish government's attitude.

Therefore, the officials said, Chen has not yet filed a visa application. "We'll decide whether to apply for a Danish visa based on the developments in the general international situation in the coming months as well as on the Danish government's attitude," said a presidential aide.
If Denmark denies Chen's visa application, the aide said, the chairman of the Liberal International may travel to Taiwan to present the award to Chen.
The London-based Liberal International (LI) groups liberal parties in major countries around the world. Taiwan's current ruling Democratic Progressive Party has been its member.

The alliance decided at its executive commission meeting in February to present its 2001 Freedom Award to President Chen. The award is scheduled to be presented at the organization's annual congress to be held in Denmark Nov. 9-10.

In an interview with a Danish newspaper in March, Chen expressed his hope that the Danish government can grant him a visa so that he can receive the award at the LI's annual conference as the award marks a recognition of the 23 million Taiwan people's pursuit of freedom and democracy.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, Aug. 2, or the 13th day of the sixth month of the Year of the Snake according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1100: William II, known as "William Rufus," king of England from 1087, is slain by an arrow while hunting in New Forest. He was succeeded by his younger brother, who became Henry I.
1798: A 14-vessel naval squadron commanded by Rear Adm. Horatio Nelson scores a brilliant tactical victory over a French fleet of 17 vessels in the Mediterranean.
1918: British, French, and U.S. troops try to smash Lenin's communist revolution by supporting the White forces and seizing Archangel.
1921: Enrico Caruso, the Neapolitan with the golden voice known as the world's greatest tenor of his time, dies at the Hotel Vesuvio in Naples at the age of 48.
1922: Alexander Graham Bell, Scottish inventor of the telephone in 1876, dies at the age of 76.
1923: Warren G. Harding, the 29th president of the United States, dies in office at the age of 58. He made several misguided appointments that led to a corrupt administration.
1924: The Kwangchow government sets up the Central Bank of China with T.V. Soong (Soong Tzu-wen) as governor.
1934: Paul von Hindenburg, German general, politician, and president of the Weimar Republic, dies at the age of 86. He was succeeded by Adolf Hitler who declared himself "Der Fuhrer."
1938: Chinese troops blow up a bank along a section of the upper Yangtze River in an attempt to slow a Japanese advance.
1939: Albert Einstein, German-born American theoretical physicist, writes to U.S. President Roosevelt urging him to start an atomic project.
1944: Joseph P. Kennedy Jr., U.S. Navy pilot and elder brother of John F. Kennedy, is killed when his plane explodes over the Belgian coast.
1945: The Potsdam Conference, the final Allied summit of World War II, comes to an end.
1960: The Republic of China recognizes Dahomey, Niger and Upper Volta.
1961: President John F. Kennedy and visiting ROC Vice President Chen Cheng issue a joint statement in Washington D.C. opposing the admission of mainland China into the United Nations.
1964: President Lyndon B. Johnson orders a retaliatory strike after a torpedo attack on the U.S. Navy ship Maddox in the Gulf of Tonkin.
1974: The Babe Ruth junior boy's all-star baseball team of Washington State arrives in Taipei for a goodwill visit.
1980: The International Telecommunications Administration inaugurates direct dialing station-to-station telephone service between Taipei and major cities in Britain, France and West Germany.
1985: Kuo Yu-hsin, former member of the Taiwan Provincial Assembly, dies of illness in Washington, D.C., at the age of 77.
1986: The ROC delegation to the Aug. 4 ROC-U.S. trade talks, headed by Board of Foreign Trade Director-General Vincent C. Siew, leaves for Washington.
1990: Saddam Hussein makes good Iraq's claim to the oil-rich state of Kuwait by invading it. Thousands of heavily armed Iraqi troops quickly cut through the defenses of their tiny Gulf neighbor and gain firm control of the capital city of Kuwait City.
1996: Michel Debre, former French prime minister, dies at the age of 84. He was Charles de Gaulle's trusted aide and the architect of the Fifth Republic.
1997: Typhoon Victor injures 32 people in Hong Kong.
1999: Two trains collide head-on in eastern India, killing 226 people and injuring some 300 others.
1999: Republic of China Representative to Japan Chuang Ming-yao expresses his grave concern to his Japanese counterpart about a plan by a group of Japanese lawmakers to land on the Tiaoyutai Islands in the East China Sea.
2000: KMT Chairman Lien Chan leads a delegation of senior KMT officials to pay a courtesy call on ruling Democratic Progressive Party Chairman Frank Hsieh at the DPP headquarters in Taipei.
2000: The Asian Witness Center of the Guinness Book of World Records announces two of Taiwan's record-setting fathers as part of celebrations for Father's Day, which falls on Aug. 8. One of the record-breakers is Lo Tseng-wen, who has five children serving as police officers, and the other is Chang A-piao, a centenarian who is living with four generations of offspring under the same roof.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "By banishing all flatterers and keeping away from the society of women; holding in low estimation possession of worldly goods, but valuing moral qualities in men: that is how the ruler gives encouragement to worthy men."

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER CALLS FOR HALT TO EXCESSIVE DEVELOPMENT

TEXT.P: Premier Chang Chun-hsiung on Thursday called for an across-the-board halt to excessive development around the island as a means of preventing aggravating the effects of natural disasters.
Noting that floods and mudslides have become major killers in Taiwan, Chang said residents in mountainous and riverside areas are now so frightened that they dread the coming of rain.
Chang said that unrelenting and excessive development, which is taking Mother Nature and wildlife conservation hostage, must be stopped.

He urged all his compatriots and all the different levels of government in Taiwan to learn a lesson from Typhoon Toraji, which wreaked havoc across central and eastern Taiwan between Sunday and Monday, by respecting nature when seeking economic gain.
Chang said the central government will solicit ideas and plans to help Taiwan achieve sustainable development that is not at the cost of the natural environment.
The premier made the call during a meeting sponsored by the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture on Taiwan's agricultural development amidst the island's bid to join the World Trade Organization.

Toraji, one of the deadliest typhoons to strike the island in recent memory, killed 75 people, injured 36 and left 133 others unaccounted for. The death toll is expected to climb as rescue workers continue to find the bodies of those missing and now believed dead.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK PRICES UP BY 135.67 POINTS

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) gained ground on Thursday, with the benchmark weighted price index moving up 135.67 points to close at 4,490.19.
Market turnover amounted to NT$63.32 billion (US$1.84 billion).

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Shares prices opened high and closed even higher on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) on Thursday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 135.67 points to close at 4,490.19.

Encouraged by a surge in the U.S. semiconductor index, the bourse opened at 4,393.31 and continued to go up due to the good performance of electrical shares. The bourse fluctuated between 4,490.19 and 4,379.66 during trading.

A total of 2.13 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$63.32 billion (US$1.84 billion), an increase from the previous trading session which saw 1.59 billion stocks change hands on a market turnover of NT$48.33 billion (US$1.39 billion).

All of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with electrical shares moving up the most at 3.5 percent, followed by bank and insurance stocks at 3 percent, textile issues at 2.9 percent, plastics and chemical shares at 2.5 percent, pulp and paper issues at 2.3 percent, cement stocks at 2.1 percent, construction stocks at 1.8 percent, and foodstuff shares at 0.2 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 427 to 96, with 61 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock index futures market were higher on Thursday, as Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index futures for August moved up 188 points to close at 4,455, with 15,925 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for September rose 197 points to finish at 4,449, with 99 contract transactions, while December futures increased 46 points to close at 4,276, with two contracts traded.
Next March futures surged 195 points to finish at 4,411, with only one contract changing hands, while next June futures rose 143 points to close at 4,402, with eight contracts traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Thursday at 4,267 for August, 4,252 for September, 4,320 for December, 4,216 for next March, and 4,258 for next June.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were also higher.
August TE futures moved up 12.1 points to close at 239, with 2,790 contract transactions, while September TE futures rose 11.9 points to finish at 238, with 24 contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for other months.
August TF futures moved up 17.8 points to finish at 525, with 877 contract transactions, while September TF futures increased 17.8 points to close at 521.4, with only one contract traded.
No transactions were recorded for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: `HAVE YOU SEEN MY GRANDSON?'

TEXT.P: An elderly woman has combed the banks of typhoon-ravaged Fatsuchi Brook in Taichung County over the last two days trying to find her grandson who is believed to have been washed away by floods wrought by Typhoon Toraji earlier this week.
"Have you seen my grandson?" the 81-year-old grandmother of Taichung County resident Liao Chen-cheng asked of every person who appeared along the banks of the brook.

She also checked every body that was unearthed from the mud along the brook, which is now dry only three days after the typhoon swept across the island on Sunday and Monday, causing severe flooding, landslides and mudslides along rivers in eastern and central Taiwan, claiming 75 lives and leaving 133 others unaccounted for.
Between checking bodies that were unearthed and asking passersby about her grandson, the elderly woman sat on a rock on the banks of the brook and waited.

Liao was believed to have been washed away by floods Monday afternoon when he was trying to rush home by taking a short cut by riding his motorcycle along Fatsuchi Brook, which was dry prior to being inundated with surging water caused by heavy rains brought by the typhoon. His backpack was discovered later in the day on the banks of the brook.

In Hualien, eastern Taiwan, one of the two counties hardest hit by Typhoon Toraji, Chiang Chi-meng, the only survivor of a six-member family, didn't know what to say Wednesday when a body initially identified by rescue workers as his seven-year-old eldest daughter was found to be someone else.

While carrying the dead child's body in his arms and crying, he was told that it was in fact not his daughter but the six-year-old daughter from another family. The body, identified by the style and length of hair, was later retrieved by surviving members of the Chiu family.

Chiang, recalling the events of Monday night after Typhoon Toraji pounded Hualien County, said that the river's water level rose abruptly, whereupon he instructed all of his family members to climb onto the tin roof of their two-story home. Before he knew it, he said they were all swept away, including his elderly parents, wife and two daughters, despite his clutching onto his parents and his wife clutching onto the two children.

He said he later awoke and found himself stuck on a thick tree trunk lying in the river. He saw no trace of any of his family members, so he waited by the river and watched rescue workers comb the mud and rocks. As of Tuesday afternoon, none of his family members had been accounted for.

In Hsinyi Township in the central county of Nantou, the other of Taiwan's two hardest hit counties, an aboriginal man surnamed Liao walked for an entire day and night to reach his home in the mountainous village of Pishih to find his daughter.
Reaching Pishih after 34 hours of walking and climbing, Liao discovered that the entire village had been buried by landslides and falling rocks.
Liao said he reckons that more than 30 residents in some 20 households in the village went missing in the disaster, including his teenaged daughter, who was home alone when the typhoon struck.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA CONCERNED ABOUT CRASH IN BRAZIL OF BUS CARRYING ROC TOURISTS

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Thursday that the Republic of China representative office in Brazil has sent staff members to help handle the aftermath of the crash near Rio de Janeiro of a tourist bus carrying 41 ROC expatriates.

MOFA spokeswoman Chang Siao-yue said Huang Lien-sheng, chief of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in Rio de Janeiro, rushed to the crash site upon learning of the traffic mishap, in which five ROC expatriates were killed and 17 others injured.
Chang said the MOFA has formed a special task force to help deal with relevant affairs.

Among those killed was Chen Lung-hsing, president of the Taiwanese Association in Sao Paulo, Chang said, adding that the other four people who died were all ROC expatriates residing in the United States, including Tsai Chao-chia, Lee Yung-yi, Huang Hsiu-o and Cheng Yun-ju, president of the Taiwanese Women's Association in North America.

Chang noted that all of the injured have been sent to four nearby hospitals for emergency treatment. Five sustained serious but not life-threatening injuries, while the rest received only mild injuries in the accident, Chang said, quoting reports from Brazil.
All of the passengers aboard the ill-fated tour bus were participants in the 28th annual conference of the World Taiwanese Association (WTA) held in Sao Paulo July 28-29, Chang said.

More than 700 WTA members from North America, Latin America, Europe, Japan, Australia and Taiwan attended the two-day conference. After the meeting, the participants were divided into three groups to partake in sightseeing trips to Rio de Janeiro, Iguazu and the Amazon region, respectively.

Most of the 100-plus WTA members who joined the Rio de Janeiro tour group came from the United States. They took three separate buses. The accident only affected those aboard the ill-fated bus. No ROC diplomats stationed in Brazil accompanied the group on the sightseeing trip.
According to reports from Brazil, the accident occurred when the tour bus was returning from the historic city of Petropolis, located about 50 kilometers north of Rio de Janeiro.

Brazilian police authorities were quoted as having said that the bus driver seemed to be speeding as he was turning a sharp curve. The driver lost control of the bus which then overturned and plunged from the upper deck to the lower deck of the highway.
The highway was closed for several hours to facilitate relief operations.
Some Taiwan residents in the Rio de Janeiro area came to the hospitals where the injured WTA members are recuperating to offer necessary assistance.

The organizing committee of the 28th WTA conference commissioned one of the largest Brazilian travel agencies to arrange the post-meeting pleasure tour. The Brazilian travel agency reportedly purchased travel safety insurance policies for all tour group members.

The organizing committee had invited several ROC officials, including Chen Chu, chairwoman of the Council of Labor affairs, Tchen Yu-chiou, chairwoman of the Council of Cultural Affairs, and Yao Chia-wen, a senior adviser to the President, to attend the annual WTA congress.

None of them however managed to attend the meeting due to visa problems. The ROC does not maintain formal diplomatic ties with Brazil. About 20 WTA members, most of them pro-independence activists, traveled from Taiwan to Brazil to take part in the conference.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER CHANG SOLICITS DONATIONS TOWARD TYPHOON RELIEF

TEXT.P: Premier Chang Chun-hsiung donated one month of his salary toward typhoon relief Thursday and called for other civil servants around the country to follow suit.

Noting that it will take huge amounts of money to recover from the destruction of the typhoon, Chang said the Executive Yuan initiated a "one-day's salary donation campaign" Wednesday in the hope that more money will be collected shortly to expedite relief work in affected areas in the wake of Typhoon Toraji, which ravaged the island July 29-30.

Meanwhile, Executive Yuan officials said that people who intend to contribute cash to help accelerate relief work are welcome to send in money to the Ministry of the Interior (MOI), at postal account number 19595889.

MOI officials reported that as of noon Thursday, members of the generous Taiwan public have sent in nearly NT$20 million (US$576,370) over the past two days through the MOI postal account and two other bank accounts each offered by the Central Bank of China and the International Commercial Bank of China.

In related news, a Kuomintang sub-group at the Legislative Yuan on Thursday initiated a donation drive labeled as "casting a brick to attract jade," to collect donations from all sectors in Taiwan and overseas Chinese communities abroad.

To serve as the "brick," KMT Legislator Chen Hung-chi and Hu Yi-shou, chairman of the Taipei Chenghuang (town god) Temple, who is co-sponsoring the campaign with the KMT lawmakers, each donated NT$200,000 (US$5,764) in cash to facilitate the relief drive.

On the first day of the drive, a local dairy company promised to deliver 60,000 Tetra bags of milk worth approximately NT$700,000 (US$20,173) to Tahsin village in Kuangfu township in the eastern county of Hualien, one of the areas hardest-hit by Typhoon Toraji, which has claimed 75 lives, left 133 missing and 36 seriously injured as of Thursday.
Another Taipei household electrical appliances company offered to send 50 washing machines to Tahsin village Friday to show their support for relief efforts.
