DOC.HEADLINE: CHINESE TAIPEI TENPIN BOWLER WINS SILVER AT DEAF OLYMPIC GAMES

TEXT.P: Chinese Taipei athlete Chang Li-hsiao won a silver medal Wednesday in the tenpin bowling event at the 2001 Deaf Olympic Games in Rome.

In the preliminary round of the two-day bowling event, each athlete had to bowl 16 games, with the three bowlers with the best overall scores advancing to a round robin final. Chang made it to the final round and was able to bag a silver medal.

Meanwhile, the Chinese Taipei team won a total of four medals -- one gold, one silver and two bronzes -- at this year's Deaf Olympic Games, representing the team's best result since it began participating in the event.
The closing ceremony of the 19th Deaf Olympic Games took place in Rome's Olympic stadium on Wednesday night.

DOC.HEADLINE: OCAC MOURNS DEATH OF ADVISER'S SON

TEXT.P: The Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission (OCAC) expressed condolences Thursday for the death of the only son of one of its U.S.-based advisers.
OCAC officials said they feel deep regret over the murder in Orange County, California Monday of Kenneth Chiu, son of Christopher Chiu, an OCAC adviser.
The officials said Christopher Chiu is an unpaid OCAC adviser, not an OCAC commissioner as previously reported.
As the tragic incident was basically a private family affair, the officials said the OCAC was not in a position to make any further comment.
According to a Los Angeles Times report, Kenneth Chiu, 17, was allegedly stabbed to death by his next-door neighbor, 20-year-old Christopher Charles Hearn.

Hearn was later taken to a local jail on suspicion of murder and a large knife was recovered at his residence. Hearn, "a violent person" according to his neighbor, was questioned through sign language because he is deaf and unable to speak.
U.S. prosecutors alleged that Hearn waited for Kenneth to return home, and then attacked him with the large knife that was found with Hearn.

Hearn, held without bail, faces special-circumstance charges of lying-in-waiting and murder based on ethnicity, either of which would make him eligible for the death penalty if convicted, said the district attorney's office.

DOC.HEADLINE: OLYMPIC SPONSORS URGED TO PRESS CHINA TO LIFT INTERNET CONTROLS

TEXT.P: Human Rights Watch on Wednesday called on media and computer giants underwriting the 2008 Olympic Games as well as other Internet companies doing business in mainland China to work toward persuading the Chinese government to lift its restrictive regulations governing Internet use.
Sidney Jones, the Asia director of Human Rights Watch, said these tightening government controls "are having a chilling effect on academic freedom, commercial exchanges and ordinary communications."

"This is one area where human rights and corporate interests should coincide," he said, adding that "more people will use Internet services and related technologies if they don't have to worry about getting arrested."

In a report released Wednesday, titled "Freedom of Expression and the Internet in China," the New York-based human rights organization pointed out that Communist Chinese authorities have issued more than 60 sets of regulations governing Internet content since Beijing began permitting commercial Internet accounts in 1995.

The report details many of these regulations, describes recent Communist Chinese efforts to police Internet cafes, and summarizes the cases of several people put on trial or sentenced to prison terms for downloading or posting politically sensitive material on the Web.
It pointed out that as recently as July 11, mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin condemned the spread of "pernicious information" on the Internet and called existing legislation "inadequate."

"As the Olympic momentum builds, Chinese websites are going to proliferate," said Jones, noting that "corporate sponsors are going to have to choose between helping China open up by getting these controls removed or abetting repression by giving the government the technology for Internet censorship."
"China's entry into the World Trade Organization should also give companies an incentive to press to have these restrictions lifted," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. OFFICIAL REAFFIRMS SUPPORT FOR ROC'S WHO BID: HEALTH MINISTER

TEXT.P: U.S. Deputy Secretary of Health and Human Services Claude Allen says that the United States supports the Republic of China's participation in the activities of the World Health Organization (WHO), Taiwan's Minister of Health, Lee Ming-liang, said Thursday.
Lee, who is currently in the U.S. to solicit support for the ROC's WHO bid, made the remarks in a telephone interview with reporters in Taiwan.

Lee said that during his visit to Washington, D.C. last week he had met with Allen, several influential members of congress and officials of the American Institute in Taiwan, a quasi-official organization authorized to handle ROC-U.S. relations in the absence of diplomatic ties.

During their talks, Lee said Allen had told him that the U.S. government supports Taiwan's bid to participate in WHO activities. According to Allen, Lee said, U.S. President George W. Bush would also take pleasure in seeing Taiwan's participation in WHO activities.
However, Lee said, Allen did not directly refer to the term "observer status" in relation to Taiwan's participation in the WHO.

Lee further said many U.S. senators and congressmen had also voiced firm support for the ROC's WHO bid. "They assured me that they would introduce resolutions again demanding the U.S. executive branch take concrete steps to back Taiwan's WHO bid," he said.
Lee also met with Allen Jones, secretary-general of the World Federation of Public Health Associations and gave interviews to the Washington Post and the Los Angeles Times.
Both the Times and the Post have shown sympathy for Taiwan's stance in their coverage of the issue.

In an article appearing in its Aug. 1 issue, titled "Taiwan's lonely quest for help on health," the Post said the International Committee of the Red Cross, Rotary International, the Vatican, the Palestine Liberation Organization and Malta all enjoy observer status at the WHO's annual assembly.
In contrast, the U.S. paper said, five attempts by Taiwan to join the World Health Organization, not as a full member but as an observer, have been denied simply because of Beijing's opposition.
Lee said he hopes Taiwan's bid to join the WHO as an observer will make progress next year.

A pediatric geneticist and molecular biologist, Lee taught and conducted research in the United States for 30 years before returning to Taiwan a few years ago. He has visited the United States twice to enlist support for the ROC's WHO bid.
Lee said he would travel to Geneva to seek more international support for the ROC's cause when the next WHO assembly is held there in May 2002.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S 2001 ECONOMIC GROWTH TO BE BELOW 2 PERCENT: OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: Taiwan's economic growth rate for the whole of 2001 will fall below 2 percent, despite an optimistic outlook that business conditions will recover by the end of this year, an official with the Cabinet-level Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) said Thursday.

W. A. Yeh, an advisory member of a DGBAS committee and a former vice chairman of the Council of Economic Planning and Development, Taiwan's highest government agency in charge of drawing up the country's economic policies, said the low growth forecast is due to the fact that Taiwan's economy grew by only 1 percent in the second quarter and it will be hard to surpass 4 percent for the fourth quarter.
The DGBAS committee is slated to call a meeting Aug. 17 to officially adjust downward Taiwan's economic growth rate for the whole of 2001 from 4.20 percent forecast previously.

Although Taiwan's leading index for June rebounded, Yeh said it was only an initial good sign following a continued contraction over the past year. The leading index must rebound for three months in a row to indicate whether a country's economy has effectively regained momentum, Yeh said.

According to Yeh, it would be over optimistic to expect that Taiwan's export-oriented economy will be able to revive in the fourth quarter, despite the fact that the U. S. economy is very likely to rebound during the same time, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: RESUMING DIALOGUE KEY TO CROSS-STRAIT TIES: KMT CHAIRMAN

TEXT.P: Reopening channels for dialogue between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait is crucial to the development of cross-strait relations, opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan said Thursday.

"The two sides must renew their dialogue channels under the 1992 'one China, separate definitions' consensus to ensure that cross-strait relations move in a peaceful direction," Lien said while meeting with a delegation of former U.S. government officials.
Nevertheless, Lien told his guests that the KMT would never accept Beijing's claim that Taiwan is part of the People's Republic of China.
Touching on the possible U.S. role in cross-strait relations, Lien said he doesn't think that the United States needs to play the role of an "active promoter."
In his view, Lien said, cross-strait issues should be resolved by the people on both sides of the Taiwan Strait.
Lien further said Taiwan does not oppose U.S.-mainland China engagements and would never create any incident that may harm Washington-Beijing ties.

"Likewise, we hope that Taiwan-U.S. relations would never be affected by U.S.-mainalnd China interactions," Lien said, adding that the United States should forge a balanced, parallel triangular Taipei-Washington-Beijing relationship to maintain peace and security in the Taiwan Strait.

Turning to the domestic front, Lien said an intraparty split led to the KMT's embarrassing defeat in the 2000 presidential election. Nevertheless, Lien said, the KMT has no intention to ask members of its splinter groups to return to the party.
"We only hope to cooperate with them because the KMT and its splinter groups share common political concepts, goals and values," he noted.

Asked by some former Clinton administration officials whether he would visit mainland China, Lien said he does not reject such a proposal. "But I don't have any mainland travel plan at the moment," he said.
Lien said Taiwan's current woes result not only from economic problems but also from political instability.
Lien claimed that the current Democratic Progressive Party (DPP)-led government's failure to respect the ROC's "dual leadership" constitutional system has led to a constitutional crisis.

"While the KMT controls a majority in the legislature, it does not have a say in Cabinet formation and policy formulation. This is the root cause of political instability and uncertainty here," he said.

Lien said the KMT is now carrying out sweeping intraparty restructuring with a view to reinventing itself and to regaining power by doing well in the legislative elections scheduled for December and the next presidential election in 2004.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAYOR MA PITCHES FOR SUNGSHAN AIRPORT'S ROLE IN CROSS-STRAIT AIR LINKS

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou said Thursday the government should not rule out the possibility that Taipei's Sungshan Airport is used as a supplementary facility for direct flights services across the Taiwan Strait.
Ma said the city government's Bureau of Transportation has finalized a feasibility study which concludes that Sungshan Airport is fully equipped to operate direct cross-strait flight services.

Ma said although the Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) under the Ministry of Transportation and communication claimed that Sungshan Airport has reached its capacity in handling domestic flight services, the market situation would be different after the island's high-speed railway is inaugurated four to five years later.

"By then, the demand for domestic flight services would decline by an estimated 22 percent after the high-speed railway opens to traffic," Ma said, adding that Sungshan Airport would then have capacity to operate direct cross-strait flights.

Ma pointed out that Taipei residents account for 30 percent of cross-strait air traffic volume. If Sungshan Airport is allowed to operate direct cross-strait flights, he said, Taipei residents would no longer need to travel to Chiang Kai-shek International Airport in Taoyuan County, some 40 kilometers south of Taipei.

According to the city government's study, the best timing for opening direct cross-strait air links is around 2007 or 2008. Ma said he is convinced that direct cross-strait air traffic volume will be very large. "And we would need many airports to operate such flight services. Therefore, CAA officials should not rule out Sungshan Airport from the list of possible supplementary airports for direct cross-strait flights," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: COMMISSION HEAD URGES OVERSEAS CHINESE TO HELP TAIWAN'S WHO BID
DOC.DATELINE: Dallas, Aug.1 (CNA) (By Chang Hui-yen and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Chang Fu-mei, minister of the Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission (OCAC), urged overseas Chinese in Dallas, Texas to help Taiwan's bid to participate in activities of the World Health Organization (WHO).
Chang made the remarks when she met with overseas Chinese Wednesday. Edward Feng, director of Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in Houston, also took part in the meeting.

Chang said that U.S. officials had expressed support for Taiwan's participation in the WHO, and she asked the overseas Chinese to make use of their relations with U.S. congressmen to promote Taiwan's acceptance by the WHO.
She also said that it would be best to become a full member of the WHO, but that being granted observer status would be a good step in the right direction.

Feng also said that the governor of Texas and Texas senators and congressmen are good friends of U.S. President George W. Bush, and they have the potential to become part of Bush's team. He has therefore asked the overseas Chinese to help invite the rising political stars to visit Taiwan to witness its democracy, freedom and economic prosperity.

Given budget constraints, Chang also said that the future focus of the commission will be to put time, energy and money into Southeast Asia and central and south America where the overseas Chinese are not as well off as those in the United States.

Chang noted that the commission plans to communicate with and serve overseas Chinese groups, promote Chinese culture and Mandarin education, promote trade for Taiwan businessmen and enhance services to overseas Chinese students.
Chang has been traveling to meet with overseas Chinese since she took office last year. She left Taiwan July 18 for a visit to Europe before flying to Atlanta, Georgia, and later to Dallas.

DOC.HEADLINE: WINBOND, MACRONIX TO BUILD NEW PLANTS IN HSINCHU INDUSTRIAL PARK
DOC.DATELINE: Hsinchu, northern Taiwan, Aug. 2 (CNA) (By Fang Wen-hung)

TEXT.P: The Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park Administration agreed Thursday to grant Winbond Electronics Corp. and Macronix International a combined total of 17.3 hectares for the construction of 12-inch wafer plants.
The lots, located in the park's newest Duhsing Compound, are expected to be officially released to the two companies in April 2002.
The Macronix plant is expected to cost NT$207 billion (US$6 billion).
Winbond spokesman Hander Chang said that construction of his company's newest NT$120 billion (US$3.5 billion) DRAM wafer plant is expected to begin in June 2002.

After the necessary machinery is installed, he continued, the plant will begin partial production at 7,000 wafers per month by the end of 2004 and reach full capacity of 40,000 wafers per month by the end of 2007.
Chang said that the new plant will create 1,500 new jobs.

DOC.HEADLINE: SCHOLARS DIVIDED ON PROPOSED TAX CUTS

TEXT.P: Local economists and scholars on a symposium Thursday were divided on whether the government should adopt a tax cut to stimulate the sagging economy.

Academia Sinica member Yu Tzong-shian said a tax cut would not stimulate the economy at a time when the government is mired in financial woes, while Mai Chao-cheng, another Academia Sinica member, said the government should reduce its intervention in the market or keep out of the market completely.
The symposium were jointly sponsored by several business leaders who were invited to serve as members of the Presidential Economic Development Advisory Conference (EDAC).

Yeh Wan-an, an advisor at the Chung-Hua Institute for Economic Research, pointed out that there can be no economic development without a sound financial system. He suggested that now is not an appropriate time to consider tax cuts as a way to spur the economy.

National Chengchi University Professor Chang Chang-chi said that continued capital outflow from Taiwan will do no good to the country's economic development and suggested that the government establish clear industrial policies and focus on the information and related industries.
Chang added that the nation's labor policies should be adjusted and suggested that the government consider enacting legislation on unemployment insurance.

However, National Taiwan University Professor Liu Yi-ju said she is in favor of the scrapping of a 10 percent tax on corporations' surplus, adding that this would stimulate enterprises to retain their capital in order to expand their investments.
Liu added that every tax cut must be accompanied by supporting measures and suggested that the government also eliminate the stock transaction tax while reinstating the stock gain tax.
Liu Tai-ying, chairman of the China Development Industrial Bank, suggested that the government increase its debts to 48 percent of the gross national product in order to raise capital
EDAC, an advisory group set up by President Chen Shui-bian to spur the local economy, is scheduled to hold its first full meeting Aug. 24-26.

DOC.HEADLINE: ACER STARTS OUTSOURCING OPERATIONS

TEXT.P: Taiwan's leading computer firm, Acer Inc., has split its own brand name division and research and service units in an effort to create greater efficiency and profits for the business concern, an Acer executive said Thursday.

Acer Manager C.T. Wang said that the company divided its brand name operation unit -- ABO -- and its research and service division -- DMS -- in July in a move to draw a clear line between the two business departments.

From now on, the ABO division, which is now an Acer-affiliated group, will focus on a diversified outsourcing production of desktop home computers, including competing against other outsourcers to make Acer's own computers, while its DMS department will be retained within Acer Inc. to dedicate its energy to running own brand products, according to Wang.

Wang also said that Acer has set up R&D centers in Beijing and Italy and added that the company's head office in Taipei will dispatch a group of experts to Beijing to help carry out outsourcing tasks there.

He added that the Acer parent company hopes to lift the number of outsourced computer units in Beijing to more than 12,000 in the near future, while it is using its distribution network to expand Acer's presence in European markets by commissioning outsourcers from Taiwan to manufacture its brand name computers.

DOC.HEADLINE: BUDDHIST MASTER VISITS TYPHOON-STRICKEN AREAS IN CENTRAL TAIWAN
DOC.DATELINE: Nantou, central Taiwan, Aug. 2 (CNA) (By Edward Chen)

TEXT.P: Master Sheng Yen, founder of the Dharma Drum Mountain Buddhist Foundation, Thursday visited areas of central Taiwan ravaged by Typhoon Toraji.
The previous day, he went to Hualien in eastern Taiwan to visit typhoon victims in hospitals. The Buddhist Master also offered prayers at a funeral parlor for the dead.

Sheng Yen visited families of the victims in Chushan township, one of the areas most seriously affected by the typhoon in Nantou County and later visited Shuili township and nearby villages that also suffered heavy damage and casualties.

Followers of the Dharma Drum Mountain Buddhist Foundation went to typhoon-affected areas to offer help to the victims shortly after Toraji swept across Taiwan early this week and Sheng Yen also called on the people of Taiwan to render their assistance to help the families of the victims.
A disaster-relief coordination center was also set up at the foundation's Taichung branch.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAPANESE BASEBALL MANAGER HONORED BY ROC GOVERNMENT
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Aug. 2 (CNA) (By Mike Chang & Victor Lai)

TEXT.P: The Chinese manager of Japan's Daiei Hawks baseball team was awarded a medal by the Republic of China government Thursday for his contributions to the development of Taiwan baseball and the promotion of sports exchanges between Taiwan and Japan.
He received the Order of Brilliant Star with Grand Cordon from Lo Fu-chuan, representative of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Representative Office in Tokyo.
Known in Japan as Sadaharu Oh, Wang broke the world record of 756 home runs when he was a slugger for the Yomiuri Giants in 1977. He retired in 1980 after extending the record to 868.
After his retirement, he served as their manager before joining the Hawks several years ago. The Hawks have been the champions of the Pacific League for the past two consecutive seasons.

At the medal-presentation ceremony held at the ROC Mission in Tokyo, Lo lauded Wang for his career achievements, including rewriting the world's home-run record and being awarded the first "National Honor Award" by the Japanese government in 1977.
Lo also praised Wang for insisting on keeping his ROC citizenship despite his outstanding achievements in Japan.
In response, Wang described the ROC government's medal as a "top honor" for him.
He said that he has devoted himself to professional baseball for 40 years and added that the most important thing as a manager is to "let team members share the joy of victory."
Nevertheless, Wang stressed that no matter whether a game results in a win or a loss, "everyone must do his best."
In the past, Wang has received various medals from the ROC Ministry of Education, the Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission and the ROC Sports Federation.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. `YET TO RECEIVE' VISA REQUEST FROM ROC PRESIDENT
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Aug. 2 (CNA) (By Herman Pan and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: The United States has not received a visa application from Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian to enter the country to make a speech at the National Press Club, White House National Security Advisor Condoleezza Rice said Thursday.
Rice made the remarks in an interview with the Washington Times. She did not say what the U.S. response would be should such an application be received.

National Press Club Chairman Richard A. Ryan extended an invitation to Chen June 17 for a visit to the United States to deliver a luncheon speech there in September or October. Chen responded last week that he would be delighted to accept the invitation and asked to have further communication on the matter.

Chen's desire to visit the United States has become a thorny issue for the administration of U.S. President George Bush. Rice said at a press conference in June that Chen's transit stops in New York and Houston in May were courtesies accorded to an elected president of a democratic country.

Washington Times reporter Bill Gertz visited Taipei to interview Chen earlier this year during which Chen urged the United States, Japan and Taiwan to develop a missile defense system. Upon his return, Gertz asked Secretary of State Colin Powell and Rice about Chen's suggestion.

Rice said that U.S. Aegis-equipped warships could provide a shield against missile attack in Asia, but added that it is "premature to decide whether such a system could be deployed in a joint U.S.-Japan-Taiwan system as suggested by the ROC president."
"A lot frankly depends on what the (mainland) Chinese do with their missile capability across the Taiwan Strait," she said.

Rice also said that the administration's strategy regarding Beijing is to integrate mainland China's economy internationally with the goal of eventually causing its political dictatorship to enact reforms.

She said that "everyone would agree that China is a rising power in the Asia-Pacific and therefore we have a number of security issues in conflict with the Chinese," including mainland China's resentment of the U.S. presence in the region, differences over Taiwan and human rights, and Beijing's weapons and missile sales.

DOC.HEADLINE: LOCAL CURRENCY WILL NOT SLIDE FURTHER ON A WEAKER U.S. DOLLAR: CEPD

TEXT.P: Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) Vice Chairman Lee Kao-chao said Thursday that the local currency is not expected to further depreciate against a weaker U.S. dollar.

Lee said that the local unit will not continue to slide, due to the fact that other G8 member states have kept pressure on the United States on the grounds that a strong greenback is not good for the global financial situation. He predicted that the United States will soon adjust its strong currency policy.

CEPD Vice Secretary-General Thomas Ming-feng Yeh said the European Union is very likely to use the opportunity to ask the United States to allow its currency to depreciate, given the fact that the Euro has lost more than 30 percent of its value against the U.S. dollar since its inception two years ago.

In Asia, weakened Asian currencies have not helped boost regional countries' exports as a result of a sluggish world economy and a slumping U.S. market, he added, noting that a strong U.S. dollar has in turn had a negative effect in Asian countries' normal economic activities and foreign trade.
Yeh, however, pointed out that it remains to be seen whether the U.S. government will adopt a "weaker U.S. dollar" policy.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PRESIDENT INSPECTS NAVY, ARMY MISSILE UNITS

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Thursday during an inspection of navy and army missile units in northern Taiwan that air defense is the nation's first line of protection and the best guarantee of stability.

Accompanied by Chief of the General Staff Gen. Tang Yao-ming and Ministry of National Defense Political Warfare Department Director Gen. Teng Tzu-lin, Chen told the officers and soldiers manning the missile batteries that the key to the Republic of China's political and economic success over the past several decades lies in its "secure and stable" environment.
Without security, he said, there would be no stability. Without stability, the people would not have felt safe to carry out various nation-building projects, he added.
In modern warfare, the importance of air defense is greater than in the past, he continued, adding that whether missile forces can bring their strength into play depends on equipment availability.
Therefore, he instructed the officers and soldiers to operate and maintain their equipment in accordance with regulations in order to preserve an effective and high-availability air defense.

Chen said that the nation is building up a basic military force that is capable of meeting its self-defense needs and that Taiwan has no intention of starting an arms race with mainland China or provoking trouble.

DOC.HEADLINE: NANTOU COUNTY CHIEF COMPLAINS ABOUT LIMITED DISASTER AID

TEXT.P: Nantou County Magistrate Peng Pai-hsien complained Thursday that the central government has given too little assistance to his hard-hit county.

Peng said at a press conference that some of the areas in the wake of typhoon Toraji suffered as much as they did after the Sept. 21, 1999 earthquake, but rescue work is being hampered by road disruption and limited manpower and resources.

Peng took a helicopter to inspect affected areas of the central county's Hsinyi Township, where he encountered criticism from residents who said the rescuers came too late and the government did not understand their plight.

Peng said that he regretted that he did not have the authority to command airplanes to go to some townships still cut off from the outside world after typhoon Toraji swept across Taiwan Sunday and Monday.

He also questioned the central government's efforts in relief work, saying that after the Sept. 21 quake, military personnel could be seen everywhere helping the residents clear their land, and that the military personnel could clear roads in one day, compared with this time, when Shuili, Luku and Hsinyi townships are still closed to traffic.
Peng noted that 20,000 military personnel pitched in to the relief work after the quake, but only 2,000 were sent this time and even then, only after repeated requests.

Meanwhile, the 9-21 Earthquake Post Disaster Recovery Commission set up a command center for reconstruction work as a result of Toraji, which Executive Director Huang Jung-chun said will form a triangular system along with an army coordination center and the Nantou County disaster handling center.
Huang added that in the first stage of the operation, the center will compile requests from cities and counties on manpower and financial support so as to facilitate the relief work.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN BEING CAUGHT UP BY MAINLAND CHINA: IDB HEAD

TEXT.P: Taiwan industries should seek profound transformation or they will be caught up soon by their mainland Chinese competitors, Industrial Development Bureau (IDB) Director-General Shih Yen-shiang said Thursday.

Shih stressed that Taiwan businesses must shift to high value-added manufacturing and focus on R&D, design, marketing and creating own-brand names. He predicted that local industries will be outperformed by their mainland Chinese counterparts within five years should they fail to do so.

According to the IDB head, Taiwan industries are facing a historic challenge in that they must ride out the painful transformation period in order to survive at a time when globalization is sweeping the world and the mainland is quickly emerging as a strong rival.

He pointed out that those businesses that fail to achieve this objective will be eventually phased out, no matter whether they choose to relocate to mainland China or maintain their operations in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: ALLEGED ROC GANGSTER'S CASE DEPENDS ON PARAGUAYAN COURT: ROC ENVOY
DOC.DATELINE: Asuncion, Aug. 2 (CNA) (By Ramon Huang & Ed Chen)

TEXT.P: Republic of China Ambassador to Paraguay Yen Bing-fan said Thursday that a Taiwanese immigrant in Paraguay detained by the police July 21 was entering the judicial process and that the ROC Embassy can only await the court's verdict.

According to Paraguayan media Wu Wen-huan is a leader of the Fuching gang, a mainland Chinese criminal gang in Eastern City. He is accused of using threats and blackmail against Taiwan businessmen in the South American country.

The overseas Chinese community is said to be angry but too afraid of Wu to speak out, Yen went on, adding that the ROC government hopes that the Paraguayan police will eliminate gangsters and let overseas Chinese live peacefully in Paraguay.

Yen further pointed out that Wu's alleged threats have also affected Taiwan investor confidence, with "many" investors being reluctant to invest in Paraguay even though the country possesses good investment conditions.
Yen also ruled out the possibility of a Taiwan-financed industrial park being fully occupied within a year as local media have reported, which he said is also due to Wu's threats.

Wu was an adviser to the Foreign Relations Committee of the Lower House of Paraguay, with a three-month tenure that ended June 30 this year, an appointment the local media claimed was obtained through cronyism.

DOC.HEADLINE: US EXPERT URGES TAIWAN TO DIVERSIFY ENERGY SOURCES

TEXT.P: An expert from the United States recommended Thursday that Taiwan should diversify its energy sources, promote energy efficiency and take part in international large-scale energy research.

Ernest Moniz, undersecretary of the Department of Energy under the former Clinton administration, told a panel of science and technology advisers under the Executive Yuan that Taiwan is right in starting research into wind power, which has the potential to become a source of supplemental power within ten years.
Moniz also suggested studies in co-generation technology, which uses heat energy produced in industrial processes to generate electricity, and scattered small power generation stations.

Energy efficiency is a challenge facing the whole world, Moniz said while calling on the island to help heavy energy consumers such as steel mills to find ways of boosting energy efficiency during the manufacturing process and thereby boosting their competitiveness.
Noting that nuclear energy is a cheap source of electricity that does not produce any greenhouse gases, Moniz predicted that it will remain a major source of energy in the next one or two decades.

The U.S. energy expert said, however, that the permanent disposal of nuclear waste is a thorny problem and noted that no new nuclear plants are planned in the near future in the United States because of this.
He suggested that Taiwan should take part in international geological studies to seek ideal places for nuclear waste dumping sites.
These studies are sure to bear heavily on the worldwide nuclear power policy, Moniz added.

Automobile fuel is another subject of study he urged Taiwan to devoted itself to, saying that the government's automobile policy is poorly conceived because it fails to prod automobile manufacturers to use advanced technology to reduce the pollutants released by automobiles.
Moniz was invited to take part in a three-day energy conference organized by the Science and Technology Advisory Group under the Executive Yuan to help the government shape its energy policy.

Co-convenor Tsay Ching-yen said at the wrapping up of the conference Thursday that Moniz's suggestions will be translated into specific policy in a meeting between various ministries and government agencies next month.

DOC.HEADLINE: TYPHOON TORAJI RANKS 7TH-MOST LETHAL, CLAIMS 83 LIVES BY THURSDAY

TEXT.P: The death toll from Typhoon Toraji, which barreled across the island between Sunday and Monday, had risen to 83 by 9 p.m. Thursday, with another 130 people still unaccounted for, according to government statistics.
The heavy casualties make Toraji the 7th-most lethal typhoon since 1958, the year in which Taiwan authorities began collecting data on casualties caused by typhoons.

According to the statistics compiled by the National Fire Administration under the Ministry of the Interior, Typhoon Gloria in 1963 was the deadliest one, claiming 224 lives and leaving 88 people missing, followed by Typhoon Pamela in 1961, which caused 158 deaths and left 121 people missing.
Typhoon Shirley in 1950 came in third place with 108 deaths and 81 people missing.

From the fourth to the six places are: Typhoon Vera in 1977, with 104 deaths and 10 people missing; Typhoon Elsie in 1969, with 93 deaths and 12 people missing; and Typhoon Fran in 1970, with 89 deaths and 41 people missing.

Typhoon Opal in 1962, with 79 deaths and one person missing and Typhoon Flossie in 1968, which claimed 74 lives and left 31 people missing, were ranked seventh and eighth respectively before being overtaken by Toraji within only six hours on Thursday.
Meanwhile, the monetary cost of agricultural damage from Toraji had risen to NT$6.16 billion (us$181.17 million), according to the Council of Agriculture.

Nantou and Hualien counties, the two counties that bore the brunt of the havoc, suffered losses of NT$2.31 billion (US$68.05 million) and NT$990 million, respectively, to crops and agricultural facilities.
Other counties such as Ilan, Hsinchu, Miaoli, Taichung, Changhua, Yunlin, Chiayi, Tainan, Pingtung and Taitung also reported agricultural damage.

DOC.HEADLINE: MATSU RECEIVES FIRST DIRECT VOYAGE MAINLAND CHINESE VISITORS

TEXT.P: An 11-member delegation led by Mawei Special Economic Zone Secretary Zhang Jiu Thursday became the first mainland Chinese visitors to travel directly from Mawei to the Republic of China-controlled Matsu Island since the "three mini links" were inaugurated eight months ago.
The mainland visitors arrived aboard the Suguan at Fuao Port to be met by Lienchiang County Magistrate Liu Li-chun, County Council Speaker Chen Chen-ching and other local dignitaries.
During their three-day stay, they will visit economic and cultural establishments, as well as tourist attractions on the island.
They will also attend a symposium with Matsu government and civic leaders on future economic and cultural exchanges.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI MAYOR CALLS FOR CLOSER EXCHANGES WITH M'LAND

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou said Thursday that while Taipei City will respect the views of the central government concerning issues on cross-Taiwan Strait relations, it cannot rely on the central government to decide "on everything."

Ma, who has previously served as vice chairman of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council, said that cross-strait exchanges are very close, noting that cross-strait trade totaled more than US$30 billion last year, with Taiwan enjoying a trade surplus of US$10 billion.

In addition, he went on, a great number of 40,000 Taiwan businesses investing in the mainland come from Taipei City. "I cannot ignore the issue as the head of Taipei City Hall," Ma said, adding that the Taipei city government must also have a clear attitude toward cross-strait exchanges.

Ma said that the city cannot avoid such questions as "leaving roots in Taiwan," or a primary school for the children of Taiwan businessmen soon to open in Shanghai, or some mainland cities that desire to have exchanges with Taipei City.
Ma said that Taipei has to devise a policy that is the most beneficial to its residents and cannot wait for the central government to make the decisions.
The popular mayor said that Taipei will basically follow the regulations of the central government, but will also develop strategies and approaches that "the central government cannot."

Taipei's exchanges with other mainland cities, especially Shanghai, have been brisk, said Ma, adding that the exchanges focus on city administration, official and unofficial exchanges and substantial exchanges in trade and culture.

Looking ahead, Ma said that judging from present situation, whether or not both sides enter the World Trade Organization, Taiwan will have to engage in dialogue with the mainland. He added that a mechanism for the division of labor between Taiwan and the mainland that leaves R&D and high-technology in Taiwan would be most beneficial for Taiwan.

Ma also called for the central government not to restrict itself by banning local government heads from visiting the mainland and asked the central government to be "bolder and more far-sighted" so that cross-strait relations can be stabilized to a point acceptable to both sides.

He also expressed the hope that the ongoing Economic Development Advisory Conference will study all these questions so as to make the best use of Taiwan's advantages, otherwise, he warned, Taiwan could have less and less leverage in dealing with cross-strait relations.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S LONGEST RAILWAY TUNNEL FINALLY COMPLETED
DOC.DATELINE: Ilan County, northern Taiwan, Aug. 2 (CNA) (By Fang Wen-hung)

TEXT.P: The final section of the 11.307-kilometer New Kuanyin Tunnel of the North Link Railway was blasted through Thursday, making it the longest two-way railway tunnel in Taiwan.
Initial inspections showed that engineers on either side of the last section to be opened were off by less than 0.5 centimeters.
Construction of the NT$2.35 billion (US$67.7 million) tunnel began Oct. 31, 1996 and to speed up the drilling process, engineers worked on four separate sections that would later meet.
The south end section and the south adit section were blasted through Dec. 9 last year, while the north end section and the north adit section were similarly connected last Thursday.
The final blast bore through the north and south adit sections -- the two middle segments of the tunnel -- at a juncture point that is 6.31 km from the north end of the tunnel.

DOC.HEADLINE: SIX NOBEL WINNERS INVITED TO VISIT TAIWAN FOR THE CAUSE OF PEACE

TEXT.P: Six Nobel Peace Prize laureates have been invited to visit Taipei to attend activities organized by Republic of China Vice President Annette Lu "for world peace" on Aug. 15, the anniversary of the end of the Second World War.
The six Nobel laureates invited to Lu's Taiwan Alliance for Global Peace are Betty Williams, Jody Williams, Joseph Rotblat, Lech Walesa, Oscar Arias Sanchez and Frederik W. de Klerk.
Betty Williams, an Irishwoman who won the Nobel Peace Prize in 1976, is a pioneer in the Irish peace campaign.

Jody Williams of the United States, who won in 1997, is the leader of the International Campaign to Ban Landmines (ICBL). The ICBL helped draft a global anti-mine declaration that has been signed by 140 countries.
Rotblat, Britain but born in Poland in 1908, won in 1995. He insists that "scientists must take moral responsibility for their inventions" and dedicated himself to the scrapping of nuclear arms.
De Klerk, a former South African president who won the award in 1993, dedicated himself to eliminating apartheid and returning political power to the nation's black people.

Walesa, who established "Solidarity," the first independent labor union in the Eastern Bloc, won in 1983 for his efforts to prevent violence while trying to gain workers' rights. He was later elected president of Poland in 1990.

Arias Sanchez was elected Costa Rican president in 1986 and since then he has been dedicated to peace in Central America. During his tenure, he invited four other Central American countries to a summit in Costa Rica to discuss ways to promote peace in the region. He won the Nobel Peace Price in 1987.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP DEPUTY SECRETARY-GENERAL TO RUN FOR TAIPEI COUNTY MAGISTRATE

TEXT.P: The opposition People First Party (PFP) Thursday nominated the party's deputy secretary-general, Chin Chin-sheng, to run for the post of Taipei county magistrate in the December county chief and legislative elections.
After the nomination was announced, Chin and several PFP legislative candidates began visiting supporters in the Hsinchuang area, accompanied by PFP Vice Chairman Chang Chao-hsiung.
Noting that Taipei County has been ruled by the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) for 12 years, Chin said that "it is time for a change now."

If elected, Chin said, he will place greater focus on the improvement of the county's transportation system, environmental protection and illegal buildings to bring them up to the level of Taipei City.

Upon learning of Chin's nomination, Kuomintang (KMT) candidate Lin Chih-chia expressed the hope that the three main opposition parties -- the KMT, the PFP and the New Party -- will cooperate to support a single candidate so as to ensure victory in the election.
He said that he would agree to have the candidate selected through a public opinion survey.
As incumbent magistrate Su Chen-chang of the DPP will seek re-election in the election and Lin stated that Su's re-election will be a foregone conclusion if the opposition camp fails to cooperate.
He said that he would discuss the idea when he met with KMT Chairman Lien Chan Friday, and added that he would also confer with Chin and New Party leader Wang Chien-shien after his meeting with Lien.
Meanwhile, Wang did not exclude the possibility of running on the New Party ticket, but stressed that he wants to promote the cooperation of the opposition camp.
"If the opposition parties do not want to cooperate," he said, "their efforts will be in vain, and their budgets for the elections should be given to the victims of Typhoon Toraji."

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. SENATE AND CONGRESS LEADERS TO VISIT TAIWAN
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Aug. 2 (CNA) (By Jay Chen & Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: U.S. Senate Foreign Relations Committee Chairman Joseph Biden and Rep. Henry Hyde, Chairman of the House of Representatives Committee on International Relations, will visit Taiwan this month, Taipei's representative office to Washington said Thursday.

Biden, a Democrat from Delaware and Hyde, a Republican from Illinois, assumed their chairmanships earlier this year and their visits to Taiwan will provide local authorities with a valuable chance to exchange views with U.S. public officials, said a Taipei representative office spokesman.

The International Relations Committee holds great sway on the Congress' agenda and there is hardly a bill concerning Taiwan that can be sent to the full floor for debate without first passing through the committee, said the official.
Biden has never set foot on Taiwan during his 29 years as a senator, while Hyde visited the island 22 years ago.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies on Friday are as follows:
The China Times:
The government does not rule out the possibility of compulsory relocation of residents in mudslides-prone areas.
The United Daily News:
The New Taiwan dollar appreciates against the US dollar amid reports of the greenback's possible weakening.
The Liberty Times:
The U.S. naval fleet sails to the West Pacific to signify its security promise to Asian allies.
The Taiwan Daily:
Two veterans donate NT$1 million in cash each to help typhoon victims.
The Central Daily News:
NT$10 billion may be needed for post-typhoon reconstruction.

Premier Chang slams over-farming.
The Taiwan News:
Bush crash in Brazil kills five Taiwanese.

Rescuers battling against the clock.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, Aug. 3, or the 14th day of the sixth month of the Year of the Snake according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
216: An army led by Carthaginian General Hannibal defeats a huge Roman army, seizing its supply depot in the Battle of Cannae and killing some fifty thousand Roman soldiers.
1460: Scottish King James II is killed by the English during the siege of Roxburgh Castle.
1492: A flotilla of three ships, led by Christopher Columbus, sets sail from the Spanish port of Palos de la Frontera in search of a land called India.
1867: Stanley Baldwin, British Conservative prime minister three times between 1923 and 1937, is born.
1872: Haakon VII, Norwegian monarch who refused to surrender to the Germans in World War II, is born in Denmark.
1881: William George Fargo, American pioneer of long-distance express service, dies at his home in Buffalo, New York, at the age of 65.
1904: The Dalai Lama flees Lhasa as British troops invade Tibet. The Ching court on Aug. 26 orders the Pachen Lama to take over Tibetan affairs from the Dalai Lama.
1916: German troops launch a surprise attack on British forces in the Sinai in Egypt. Some 5,000 German soldiers are killed, while British loses amount to 1,100 men.
1929: Emile Berliner, German-born American inventor, dies in Washington D.C. at the age of 78. He greatly improved the telephone and invented the gramophone in 1887.
1940: Lithuania is formally incorporated into the Soviet Union as the Lithuanian Soviet Socialist Republic.
1958: Nautilus, the U.S. atomic submarine, becomes the first vessel to reach the North Pole under the ice.
1959: Japan Airlines formally inaugurates its Tokyo-Taipei route.
1967: The ROC Executive Yuan decides to extend the period of compulsory education from six to nine years beginning in 1968.
1969: Minister of Economic Affairs K.T. Li (Li Kuo-ting) receives the 1968 Ramon Magsaysay Award for government service.
1972: Sheng Chin-lai is appointed dean of the Engineering College at Chiaotung University.
1972: Brig. Gen. William C. Buttows, new chief of staff of the U.S. Taiwan Defense Command, arrives in Taipei.
1973: The Flying Tiger Line inaugurates air freight services between Kaohsiung and New York.
1974: Economics Minister Y.S. Sun and Paraguayan Minister of Industry and Commerce D. Ugarte Centurionuan sign an agreement in Taipei to boost economic cooperation between the Republic of China and Paraguay.
1976: President Yen Chia-kan receives eight members of the U.S. 14th Air Force Association, including Mrs. Anna Chennault, widow of the 14th Air Force's commander, Maj. Gen. Claire Lee Chennault.
1977: A US$100 million loan agreement is signed in Taipei between the Taiwan Power Company and 17 banks from five foreign nations.
1981: President Ronald Reagan orders the firing of 12,000 striking air traffic control workers.
1986: Construction of the Synchronous Radiation Research Center under the Executive Yuan is started at the Hsinchu Science-Based Industrial Park. It is scheduled for completion within five to six years.
1988: Mathias Rust, a West German youth who landed his light air plane near Moscow's Red Square in 1987, is released from prison and expelled from the Soviet Union.
1999: Nine renowned scientists and former intelligence and military officials send a letter to all 100 U.S. senators calling for the prompt ratification of the Comprehensive Test Ban Treaty to prevent the weaponization of stolen nuclear secrets by Communist China.
2000: President Chen Shui-bian directs the ROC Air Force to draw up a forward-looking blueprint for developing a new generation of warplanes to ensure supremacy in the skies over the Taiwan Strait.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "By extending the powers of their functions and allowing them discretion in the employment of their subordinates: that is how a ruler gives encouragement to the high ministers of state."

DOC.HEADLINE: LAWMAKER URGES SHELVING ARMS PURCHASE AND USING MONEY FOR RELIEF

TEXT.P: A lawmaker on Friday urged the Chen administration to postpone a US$4 billion arms purchase from the United States and use the money for reconstruction work in the aftermath of Typhoon Toraji that swept across Taiwan July 29-30.

Opposition Kuomintang Legislator Kuo Jung-chen submitted the emergency written appeal to the Executive Yuan Friday, asking that the money saved by shelving the purchase be used to help residents in areas battered by the typhoon recover from the disaster.
As of late Thursday, 83 people were confirmed dead and another 130 people were still missing as a result of Typhoon Toraji, the seventh most deadly typhoon to hit Taiwan in the last four decades.

In addition to the heavy human casualties, the typhoon also caused losses to agriculture totaling more than NT$6.2 billion (US$179 million) as well as immeasurable damage to the island's infrastructure, including roads and bridges, according to statistics compiled by the National Fire Administration under the Ministry of the Interior.

Kuo, a legislator representing Taichung County in central Taiwan, which was one of the areas seriously hit by floods, landslides and mudslides triggered by the typhoon, stressed that the Chen administration should put maintaining internal safety and security at the top of the list of its priorities and temporarily shelve defense expenditures.
He said the Republic of China government should refrain from incessantly increasing defense spending year by year and stop the meaningless arms race with mainland China.

Kuo urged the Ministry of National Defense to be "courageous" enough to say "no" to the Bush administration regarding the mammoth US$4 billion arms package, which includes four Kidd-class destroyers, eight diesel-powered submarines designed to counter blockades and invasions, 12 P-3 Orien Ai craft, and a Paladin self-propelled artillery system.

"A total of NT$140 billion would well be able to help the people in disaster areas stand up again from the ruins, and the money would definitely be better spent on this than on expensive weapons to be left idly in warehouses," he noted.

Meanwhile, Kuo called for President Chen Shui-bian to make genuine efforts toward generating funds for relief and rehabilitation work instead of taking whirlwind tours to disaster areas that Kuo said are designed and executed only as media events.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK PRICES UP BY 40.49 POINTS

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) gained ground on Friday, with the benchmark weighted price index moving up 40.49 points to close at 4,530.68.
Market turnover amounted to NT$71.57 billion (US$2.07 billion).

DOC.HEADLINE: EX-ENVIRONMENTAL CHIEF APPOINTED NEW ROC ENVOY TO GAMBIA

TEXT.P: Lin Chun-yi, a former administrator of the Cabinet-level Environmental Protection Administration (EPA), has been appointed the Republic of China's ambassador to the West African state of The Gambia.
Lin, 61, said in an interview with CNA that he takes great pleasure in accepting his new assignment to serve the country.

Lin, a biologist and environmental activist, said he will focus his efforts on further cementing bilateral relations after assuming his new post in the near future, particularly on promoting civilian, economic and cultural exchanges.

Lin said he is no stranger to Africa. During his service with a Christian church in the United States, Lin recalled, he had been assigned to Tanzania, Kenya and several other African states to assist in establishing their biology teaching systems.

"I also took the opportunity to conduct some biological and ecological research programs. I have many fond memories of my life and work in those countries. After leaving Africa, I still harbor a special affection for that continent," an emotional Lin said, adding that he was excited by his new mission.
Lin said that although he is a novice in the diplomatic world, he will devote his full energy to fulfilling his duty and contributing to the ROC's diplomatic cause.

He said he has been endeavoring to obtain more knowledge about Gambia through the Internet. Noting that Gambia upholds freedom and democracy and has a stable investment climate, Lin said he will push for increased Taiwan investment in the West African state after taking his new job.
In his view, Lin said, local entrepreneurs can consider investing in the electronics, power generation, agricultural, aquacultural and livestock industries in Gambia.

Touching on the heavy human casualties and property losses inflicted by Typhoon Toraji-triggered mudslides in Taiwan's mountainous regions in the central county of Nantou and the eastern county of Hualien, Lin said he was saddened by the typhoon tragedy.
Lin said he sounded warnings more than 10 years ago against the over exploitation of the island's mountainous regions and Taiwan's lax soil and water resources conservation efforts.

"We are now paying the price for our past mistakes. In the face of the recent disaster, we must from now on pay more heed to environmental protection and forestation. Otherwise, we will encounter even more adversities in the future," he noted.

Lin resigned from the top EPA post early this year to take the blame for the serious environmental pollution caused by oil slicks resulting from a grounded Greek cargo ship off the southern Taiwan coast.

The pollution -- caused by about 1,100 tons of fuel that leaked from Amorgos -- contaminated the pristine coral reef coastline of Kenting, part of a national park at Taiwan's southernmost tip. Environmentalists have said the affected area will take years to fully recover from the contamination.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Shares prices opened high and closed even higher on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) on Friday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 40.49 points to close at 4,530.68.

Encouraged by a rise in U.S. stock prices, the bourse opened at 4,499.68 and continued to go up due to the strong rebound in blue chip shares. The bourse fluctuated between 4,579.16 and 4,488.54 during trading.

A total of 2.74 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$71.57 billion (US$2.07 billion), an increase from the previous trading session which saw 2.13 billion stocks change hands on a market turnover of NT$63.32 billion (US$1.84 billion).

All of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with bank and insurance shares moving up the most at 3.4 percent, followed by pulp and paper issues at 3.2 percent, cement stocks at 2.7 percent, textile issues at 2.5 percent, plastics and chemical stocks at 1.6 percent, foodstuff shares at 1.5 percent, construction stocks at 0.9 percent, and electrical shares at 0.2 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 408 to 95, with 82 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP CAUTIONS TSU AGAINST COOPERATION WITH OTHER PARTIES

TEXT.P: An official of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) said Friday that if the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) chooses to cooperate with other opposition parties after the year-end legislative and county-head elections, then there will be "no more" political stability in Taiwan.

DPP Secretary-General Wu Nan-jen made the remarks one day after the TSU spokesman, Su Chin-chiang, said that the TSU advocates political stability but that this does not mean it will help the ruling party. Su added that the TSU does not exist for the purpose of opposing or helping any one political party.

The TSU, a party to be headed by former Minister of the Interior Huang Chu-wen, who is closely affiliated with Lee Teng-hui, the former ROC president and ex-chair of the Kuomintang, will be formally inaugurated Aug. 12. Lee had said earlier that he wants to help the minority government of President Chen Shui-bian gain a stable majority in the Legislature.
Wu said that the DPP is appreciative of Lee's help, but he noted that the deeds of the TSU head have departed from Lee's intentions.

He said that the TSU, as an independent party, will certainly not have to consider the views of any of the other political parties, but that it should definitely consider the intentions of Lee, its spiritual leader.

Wu stressed that DPP Chairman Frank Hsieh expressed his concerns about the nomination of TSU candidates for the year-end elections during his meeting with Lee earlier. DPP officials have estimated that one-fourth of the TSU candidates will have an affect on the election prospects of the DPP's own nominees.

Wu urged the TSU spokesman to show political sensibility, adding that if the TSU chooses to cooperate with other political parties after the election, then there will be "no more political stability" in Taiwan.

He also said that the DPP is not too worried about the TSU, adding that the DPP is not facing the problem of losing seats in the elections but instead the question of how many seats it can gain in the Legislature.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock index futures market were higher on Friday, as Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index futures for August moved up 40 points to close at 4,495, with 10,484 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index futures for September rose 41 points to finish at 4,490, with 91 contract transactions, while next March futures increased 5 points to finish at 4,425, with only one contract changing hands.
Next June futures gained 17 points to close at 4,437, with three contracts traded. No transactions were reported for other months.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Friday at 4,455 for August, 4,449 for September, 4,276 for December, 4,420 for next March, and 4,420 for next June.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were also higher.
August TE futures edged up 0.6 points to close at 239.6, with 1,859 contract transactions, while September TE futures rose 2.85 points to finish at 240.85, with 27 contracts traded.
December TE futures gained 0.6 points to close at 239.2, with 16 contract transactions, while next March TE futures rose 15.9 points to finish at 244.3, with 12 contracts changing hands.
No transactions were recorded for other months.
August TF futures moved up 20 points to finish at 545, with 1,097 contract transactions, while December TF futures increased 12.4 points to close at 535.4, with two contracts traded.
Next March TF futures rose 23 points to finish at 540, with 13 contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: CENTRAL SCIENCE PARK LOCATION TO BE DECIDED BY END OF YEAR: NSC

TEXT.P: The answer to the question of where exactly Taiwan's third "silicon valley" will be located is expected to be finalized by the Executive Yuan at the end of this year, an official in charge of science and technology development said Friday.

The exact location of the proposed Central Science-based Industrial Park (CSIP) -- Taiwan's third such park following the Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park (HSIP) in northern Taiwan and the Tainan Science-based Industrial Park (TSIP) in southern Taiwan -- is expected to be decided in five months, said Huang Wen-hsiung, vice chairman of the Cabinet-level National Science Council (NSC).
Ground-breaking and initial development are expected to kick off next year at the earliest, said Huang after presiding over the first NSC meeting on the CSIP development project.
According to Huang, a total of eight districts in five cities and counties in central Taiwan are aggressively bidding to be the site of the CSIP.

Related officials from Hsitun in Taichung City, Chinshui and Tahya in Taichung County, Changping and Erlin in Changhua County, Tuku and Paochung in Yunlin County, and Puli and Chushan in Nantou County attended the first NSC meeting exclusively at a CSIP location. The officials included Taichung County Chief Liao Yung-lai and Taichung City Mayor Chang Wen-ying, according to Huang.

After the location of the planned science park in central Taiwan is decided, Huang noted, actual development jobs are expected to begin around the middle of 2002 as land requisition is expected to take another half year to complete.

Taiwan's science-based industrial parks, particularly the first one located in Hsinchu, have been the cradle of the island's high-technology development and the "jewel in the crown" of its export-oriented industrial business.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER ORDERS REFORESTATON

TEXT.P: Saddened by the heavy casualties and property damage wrought by Typhoon Toraji, Premier Chang Chun-hsiung ordered a national reforestation campaign Friday to stabilize mountainous areas and restore a safe environment for the people.

Addressing a press conference dubbed "Clutching Taiwan's Land with the Roots of Trees" and hosted by the Government Information Office four days after the devastating typhoon ravaged Taiwan, Chang declared that the administration is determined to grapple with the problem of unrelenting farming and excessive development islandwide by carrying out widespread reforestation projects.

Harshly criticizing the exploitation of farmland and the relentless development for economic gains regardless of the negative effects, Chang said the soil and water conservation-depleting betel nut cultivation, which is one of Taiwan's worst "land killers" and the root cause of many otherwise preventable landslides and mudslides that occur when a typhoon strikes, must be ended once and for all.
Chang stressed that the government will ban betel nut cultivation and other "improper" farming methods and will "deal with them squarely" so as to help address the mudslide problem at its roots.

The national reforestation drive will begin in "geologically precarious" regions, which comprise around 10,000 hectares of hillside and slopeland that have become even more dangerous two years after the deadly Sept. 21 earthquake of 1999, Chang noted.
It is expected that reforestation will have been carried out on 5,600 hectares of this land by the end of 2004, with the planting of some 10 million new trees, Chang said.
The ambitious campaign is expected to create 400,000 work days for local residents, particularly aboriginal people, who have suffered high unemployment in recent years, the premier continued.

Pointing out that the geography of Taiwan features high peaks, steep slopes, rapidly flowing rivers and a fragile soil system, Chang said while accelerating reforestation in hilly regions continues, greening and forestation plans will also be carried out in some flat and low-lying areas.

It is expected that some 8,000 hectares of plains and low-lying areas -- mainly low-yield rice paddies -- will be the first targets of the forestation plan, Chang said, adding that by doing so, the "greened" areas will not only contribute to beautifying local communities but will also help reduce the greenhouse effect in cities caused by carbon dioxide discharged from factories and vehicles.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR UP ON TAIPEI FOREX MARKET

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar appreciated NT$0.03 against the greenback on the Taipei foreign exchange market Friday, closing at NT$34.669.
The local currency opened Friday at NT$34.669 and was traded between NT$34.510 and NT$34.669.
Interbank US dollar trading totaled US$943 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: TOP PRC NEGOTIATOR WITH TAIWAN `AT ODDS' WITH MAINLAND PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: Mainland China's top negotiator with Taiwan Wang Daohan no longer maintains close ties with mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin because of their different political concepts and Jiang's arrogance, according to a Hong Kong magazine report.

The report, carried in the latest issue of Open Magazine, said the first rift in the Wang-Jiang relationship occurred in September 1999 when Taiwan was rattled by a devastating earthquake that claimed more than 2,400 lives and left tens of thousands homeless.

At that time, the report said, Wang, a former Shanghai mayor and Jiang's mentor, had three times asked Jiang to allow him to head a delegation of Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) staff to visit Taiwan to show concern for its earthquake victims.
However, the report went on, Jiang repeatedly rejected Wang's requests, saying that mainland China "need not express regards for Taiwan's pro-independence government."
The report said that although Wang explained that his planned visit was not aimed at showing concern for the Taiwan government, but for the earthquake victims, Jiang still turned down Wang's request.

According to the report, Wang had even assured Jiang that he would not touch on any political issue during his stay in Taiwan. Wang reportedly had told Jiang that his planned visit could achieve political effects in winning Taiwan people's hearts during their time of hardship. But Jiang turned a deaf ear to Wang's advice, the report said.

The report further said Wang had suggested that mainland China should donate at least US$1 million to help Taiwan's earthquake victims. Jiang again rejected Wang's suggestion and Beijing later donated just US$100,000 toward Taiwan's post-quake relief programs.
The report continued that the final incident that led to the Wang-Jiang split occurred in March this year when they were discussing in private the Chinese Communist Party's (CCP's) transformation.

During their closed-door meeting, the report said, Wang advised Jiang to unveil an intraparty reform plan at the CCP's 16th national congress as a response to rising public calls for political modernization. In Wang's view, the report said, the CCP will be trapped in a very embarrassing position if it fails to accelerate its transformation from a revolutionary party into a socialist democratic party.
After Wang finished his speech, the report said, Jiang rudely told Wang that he did not think Wang was in a position to address the CCP's reform issue or its future prospects.

The report said Wang was caught off-guard by Jiang's remarks as the octogenarian party elder had never expected Jiang to made such a response. Wang later told his friends that he was deeply disappointed and embarrassed by Jiang's arrogance, the report said.

It further said that during his week-long stay in Shanghai in mid-June to attend a Beijing-initiated conference of the top leaders of mainland China and four Central Asian countries, Jiang met with all party elders in the Shanghai area except for Wang. The omission has since caused much speculation in mainland political circles, according to the report.

DOC.HEADLINE: SENATOR SAYS BUSH ADMINISTRATION SEEMS MORE WILLING TO ENGAGE BEIJING

TEXT.P: A senior U.S. senator said Thursday on the eve of his trip to East Asia that the Bush administration seems to have modified its attitude toward mainland China and now appears more willing to "engage and embrace" the country.

Joseph R. Biden, Jr., chairman of the powerful Senate Committee on Foreign Relations, also said that he does not expect administration officials to repeat President George W. Bush's statement that the United States will do whatever it takes to defend Taiwan.

The Delaware Democrat made the comments while talking to reporters before leaving for Taiwan, mainland China and South Korea on his first overseas trip since becoming committee chairman six weeks ago.

Biden said that the Bush administration, when it took office six months ago, "appeared to depart at least verbally, in body language, from the last administration in terms of how it dealt with China".
With Secretary of State Colin Powell's visit to Beijing in late July, Biden said, the administration" seems to have moved back in the direction of seeking to engage and embrace China".
The issue of weapons proliferation looks set to dominate Biden's discussions with the leadership in Beijing.

On cross-strait issues, Biden told reporters from South Korea, mainland China and Taiwan that the United States does not want to communicate to Taiwan that "we will be with it no matter what it does."
"We're not for your independence," he said, adding that "if you do that, you're on your own."

"Conversely, mainland China should not have any doubt that if they unilaterally decide to impose physical domination upon Taiwan, then anything could happen, the minimum of which would be us supplying the Taiwanese government with whatever it takes," he said.

Biden, along with Sen. Paul Sarbanes (D-Md.), Sen. Arlen Specter (R-Pa.) and Sen. Fred Thompson (R-Texas), is due to arrive in Taipei on August 6. The senators will then visit Shanghai and Beijing August 7-10 before heading to Seoul.

A liberal Democrat, Biden succeeded conservative Jesse Helms (R-N.C.) as chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee in June when the Democrats won control of the Senate because of the defection of a single Republican.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. SENATE COMMITTEE CHAIRMAN TO VISIT TAIWAN

TEXT.P: U.S. Senate Committee on Foreign Relations Chairman Joseph Biden is scheduled to arrive in Taiwan Aug. 6 at the head of a 21-member delegation for a two-day visit, the Republic of China Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) announced Friday.
While here, the delegation members are expected to meet with President Chen Shui-bian and Minister of Foreign Affairs Tien Hung-mao, according to a MOFA press release.

The delegation, which is making a tour of Asia in order to understand the situations in various potential regional flashpoints, will proceed to mainland China and the Korean peninsula after its Taipei visit, according to the press release.
The delegation is also scheduled to hold a press conference prior to its departure from Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: NANTOU COUNTY HEAD AGAIN APPEALS FOR MORE MILITARY ASSISTANCE

TEXT.P: Nantou County Magistrate Pang Pai-hsien appealed Friday for the military and civilians to help residents in his county, saying that typhoon Toraji wrecked more serious havoc to the county than earlier thought.

Pang, who has been inspecting the affected areas "day and night" since the typhoon swept across Taiwan Sunday and Monday, made a five-point suggestion after inspecting the affected areas in the central Taiwan county again Friday.

He first urged the military to speed up the construction of makeshift bridges, adding that the typhoon had destroyed 43 bridges in the county, rendering the delivery of goods and rescue services more difficult.

Pang also urged the military to increase its manpower support, saying that there are still residents trapped in affected areas and that more than 90 people are still unaccounted for. Nantou County desperately needs military support for traffic clearing, household cleaning and environmental disinfection, he said.

Saying that Luku and Hsinyi townships are still cut off from the outside world, Pang also asked for more airborne rescue efforts, adding that helicopters are in severe short supply, which is slowing down rescue efforts.
Pang also requested the support of heavy equipment and vehicles to help with rescues, goods deliveries and traffic clearing in the shortest possible time.
He also asked the military to provide support communications, as well as water and electricity equipment repairs so that daily necessities to the public can be resumed as soon as possible.

As it is already five days since Toraji swept across Nantou County leaving residents in the affected areas without water or electricity and with food running short, health officials are beginning to worry about the possibility of outbreaks of dysentery and chickenpox.

The health officials said that the elderly and the young are already suffering from colds and diarrhea, while patients with high blood pressure and asthma, as well as those who need dialysis, are having difficulty seeking medical treatment, despite the operations of airborne and land-based roving medical service units.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN WTO MEMBERSHIP `MOST LIKELY' BY YEAR-END

TEXT.P: Taiwan may join the World Trade Organization (WTO) in October at the earliest or next February at the latest, but most likely by the end of this year, Premier Chang Chun-hsiung said Friday.

He made the remarks during an inspection visit to the Fair Trade Commission, which he encouraged to set up a free and fair market in Taiwan to help the country lure greater foreign investment and transform the economy into one that will be knowledge-based, modern and globalized, following WTO entry.

In the face of robust international competition in the local market, mergers and acquisitions between multinational companies and market monopolies by large-scale business groups will be some of the major issues which the commission will need to handle in the future, the premier said, adding that the commission will also need to strengthen cooperation on information exchanges and law enforcement with other countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: SENATE BILL TO DENY BEIJING ACCESS TO U.S. CAPITAL MARKETS INTRODUCED

TEXT.P: U.S. Sen. Jesse Helms on Thursday introduced a bill in the Senate that if passed would deny companies owned by the mainland Chinese government access to American stock and bond markets.
The bill introduced by the North Carolina Republican is designed to encourage the full privatization of firms that are majority-owned by the Communist regime in Beijing.
The heavyweight senator emphasized that the United States "cannot and should not subsidize the barbarous Communist Chinese government when it tortures, imprisons and murders its own people."
He pointed out that Communist China ships missile technology and weapons of mass destruction to "terrorist nations" and is blatantly threatening democratic Taiwan.
At the same time, Helms added, Beijing is occupying Tibet and oppressing mainland China's minorities and people of faith.

The bill, which proposes to prohibit any government-owned mainland Chinese companies from listing stocks or issuing bonds on U.S. capital markets, is intended to deny the Chinese government access to billions of dollars without costing any American jobs, the senator explained.

"Simultaneously, the bill will promote economic reform in China by emphasizing that the United States favors privatized firms and real Chinese entrepreneurs, who will be free to utilize U.S. capital markets," he noted.
"That is a truly free market policy. The need to end this subsidy to the Chinese government is obvious," he emphasized.

"Today, two majority government-owned companies, PetroChina and Sinopec, do business with Sudan and Iran. The activities of these companies, both listed on the New York Stock Exchange, prop up two other governments that also abuse human rights and export terrorism and religious intolerance," Helms pointed out.
He stressed that the legislation he introduced "will help stave off potential financial disaster that could otherwise await American savers and investors."

"As China continues to partially privatize its economy, its government-owned companies are expected to dramatically increase listings and offerings on U.S. exchanges, meaning that more and more Americans would have Chinese government stocks and bonds in their portfolios," he said.

"Should there be a crisis in U.S.-China relations over Taiwan, for example, the value of those securities is certain to collapse. The savings of Americans must never be subjected to such a great political risk," he stressed.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC FREE TO NAME ENVOY TO APEC SUMMIT: MAC OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: The Republic of China is free to name any person as its representative at the annual informal leadership meeting of the Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum, a senior mainland China affairs official said Friday.

Chen Ming-tung, vice chairman of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), which charts Taiwan's policy toward mainland China, was responding to reports that Beijing will not allow Koo Chen-fu, chairman of the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), to attend this year's APEC summit to be held in Shanghai in October.
The SEF is a quasi-official intermediary body authorized by the ROC government to handle cross-Taiwan Strait exchanges in the absence of official ties.
Noting that APEC is a regional economic cooperation forum, Chen said Taiwan, as a full APEC member, has the right to freely name a delegate to attend the annual APEC summit.

"We hope mainland China can respect the international rules of the game and all APEC members' legitimate rights," Chen said, adding that mainland China, as the host country of this year's APEC ministerial and leadership meetings, should treat each member with respect and grace.
In his view, Chen said, mainland China should refrain from any name-calling and should instead extend a warm welcome to any delegate appointed by the ROC authorities.

APEC is one of the few international organizations that accept both Taiwan and mainland China as members. Due to Beijing's opposition, however, the ROC head of state has been barred from attending the annual APEC leadership meeting in person and must instead appoint a proxy to take part in the event on his behalf.
Koo, a veteran tycoon and Taiwan's top negotiator with mainland China, represented former ROC President Lee Teng-hui at the 1995, 1996 and 1997 APEC summit meetings.

But a local newspaper quoted mainland officials in charge of Taiwan affairs as having said recently that Taiwan should refrain from designating Koo to attend the upcoming summit and should instead appoint a delegate suitable for "the development of cross-strait relations" to participate in the Shanghai event.

According to mainland officials, Koo should not visit the mainland before the two sides of the Taiwan Strait resume dialogue.
