Mainland China has insisted that it will not resume regular dialogue between the SEF and its mainland counterpart -- the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) -- until after Taiwan accepts its "one China" principle, which downgrades the ROC to a local-level government under the People's Republic of China.

Commenting on the report, Presidential Office officials said they could not understand what mainland China means by saying that Taiwan should send "a person suitable for the development of cross-strait relations" to the summit.
In any case, the officials went on, President Chen Shui-bian has not yet decided who will represent him at the Shanghai summit.
"We hope mainland China will stop meddling in the purely economic APEC meeting based on its own ideological thinking," said a close aide to the president.

DOC.HEADLINE: LAWMAKERS DEBATE WHICH FUNDS TO USE FOR TYPHOON DISASTER RELIEF

TEXT.P: Ruling and opposition legislative caucuses agreed Friday to allow the Executive Yuan to make emergency use of what remains of the 2001 Tax Redistribution Fund if the money is to be spent on disaster relief in the wake of Typhoon Toraji.

With regard to a proposal by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) legislative caucus to convene an extraordinary legislative session to earmark additional budget toward disaster relief, Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng said that the Executive Yuan should use the available funds first.
He said that the Cabinet has approximately NT$6.3 billion (US$182 million) at its disposal for disaster relief.
If it were to be discovered that the allotted budget is insufficient to cover relief-related expenses, he continued, then the possibility of convening such a session could be discussed.
He added that the Legislative Yuan will try to quickly handle any proposal regarding the additional allocation of disaster relief money in order to facilitate the Executive Yuan's relief work.

Wang suggested that the Executive Yuan could also try to find a flexible way to use a NT$2.3 billion (US$66 million) portion of the Sept. 21 Earthquake Special Donation Fund and another NT$27.3 billion (US$787 million) portion of the NT$100 billion (US$2.9 billion) Sept. 21 Earthquake Special Budget.

DPP Legislative Whip Tsai Huang-lang expressed dissatisfaction with the agreement to use the Tax Redistribution Fund because it is meant to be allocated for the use of various local governments, not for disaster relief.

With regard to Wang's proposal to try to find a way to use the budgets earmarked for post-quake reconstruction on post-typhoon relief, Tsai said that those funds are meant for the rebuilding of various quake-affected counties and cities and should not be dipped into for typhoon relief.

Tsai noted that the passage of Typhoon Toraji on Monday has already caused estimated damage in excess of tens of billions of new Taiwan dollars and claimed that "a mere few billion" will not be enough to provide relief.

Meanwhile, in response to opposition Kuomintang lawmakers' comments that various government agencies have all earmarked budget that could be put toward disaster relief, DPP Legislator Chen Chin-jun claimed that these budgets are "not enough" to handle relief and reconstruction needs.

According to the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics, the combined allotted disaster relief budget of the Council of Agriculture, the Ministry of Transportation and Communications, the Ministry of Economic Affairs, the Ministry of the Interior and various county and city governments is approximately NT$4.7 billion (US$136 million).

DOC.HEADLINE: DONATIONS FOR TYPHOON RELIEF LESS FORTHCOMING THAN FOR 921 QUAKE

TEXT.P: Although the destruction wrought by Typhoon Toraji on Taiwan is almost as serious as the disastrous earthquake that hit Taiwan two years ago, public response toward relief efforts has been lukewarm compared to the spontaneous outpouring of help and sympathy after the quake, according to local newspaper reports Friday.

The mass-circulation United Daily News said that the lukewarm response may be the result of the economic sluggishness that has left people with less disposable income, or public mistrust due to the widespread government mismanagement and alleged theft of earthquake funds by the authorities.

The Ministry of the Interior set up three accounts to help post-typhoon reconstruction and had collected NT$113,374,870 (US$326,728) as of Friday following a NT$20 million donation by the Chi Mei Group.
To assuage the public fear about possible mismanagement of the donations, Minister of the Interior Chang Po-ya assured that "every dollar collected will be used for the affected residents."

Vice Interior Minister Lee Yi-yang also said that the use of Sept. 21 donations needs to be investigated and he gave his assurance that the ministry will monitor rigorously the use of the typhoon donations.
President Chen Shui-bian and Vice President Annette Lu had already donated one month of their salaries toward typhoon relief and they urged government chiefs and civil servants to donate generously.
It is expected that government agencies and political parties will launch a donation campaign in the next few days.
Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Corp. (TSMC) donated only a few million dollars this time, compared with NT$200 million donated in the wake of the Sept. 21 earthquake.
The Tzu Chi Buddhist Compassionate Relief Foundation, the largest charity organization in Taiwan, has been collecting donations and has begun distributing money to the needy.
Private charity organizations reported a sharp contrast to the wake of the Sept. 21 earthquake, for which private donations of NT$14.6 billion were collected.
The Chinese Fund for Children and Families Taiwan reported that they were deluged with calls for donations after the quake but have received far fewer calls this time.

World Vision Taiwan also said that although it received around 100 calls inquiring about donations, only about half of the callers actually remitted money. In the first month after the Sept. 21 earthquake, in contrast, it had collected NT$60 million.

Despite the lukewarm response, some heartening stories have surfaced, with one 82-year-old veteran who wished to remain anonymous donating NT$1 million (US$28,818). Another veteran gave a check for NT$1.2 million, allegedly his entire savings.

DOC.HEADLINE: RESETTLEMENT OF DEVASTATED VILLAGES HARD TO CARRY OUT

TEXT.P: Resettlement of villages devastated by mudslides will be a hard task, but there is no other option for some mountainous villages that are under constant threat of natural disasters, a Council of Agriculture (COA) official said Friday.

The official said that the council conducted a geological survey after the disastrous earthquake of Sept. 21, 1999 that shows that 65 villages on the island are located in dangerous areas vulnerable to landslides or debris and mudflows. The council suggested that at least 12 villages should be evacuated as soon as possible.
The torrential rainfall Monday brought by Typhoon Toraji caused large-scale floods of mud and debris to wipe out some mountainous villages, leaving many villagers buried alive.

Four villages in eastern Taiwan's Hualien County and in mountainous Nantou County in central Taiwan were reduced to wasteland, and the next torrential rainfall will very likely cause more hazardous landslides and debris flows, according to the COA official, who added that residents of these four villages should have priority for resettlement.

Most of the villagers are aboriginals reluctant to leave their own land and to give up their farms or trade, and the government has had difficulties carrying out similar resettlement plans in the wake of past disasters. The inhabitants of the aboriginal Hsinyi village in Nantou County, for instance, would flee the floods and landslides in times of danger and return to their damaged homes afterwards. The authorities have discussed permanent evacuation with the villagers for the last eight years, but no consensus has yet been reached.

Chairman Chen Po-chi of the Council for Economic Planning and Development said that an overall plan is necessary for the villager resettlement projects, while housing, education, job opportunities, customs and culture should all be considered.

Chen claimed that "budget constraints" will not allow the government to invest in developing new townships, but said that what the government can do at the moment is try to arrange for the villagers to move to safe areas in environments they are familiar with.

DOC.HEADLINE: MILITARY LAUNCHES FUNDRAISING DRIVE FOR TYPHOON VICTIMS

TEXT.P: Taiwan's military is launching a fundraising campaign for rescue and reconstruction work in the wake of Typhoon Toraji, a military spokesman announced Friday.

Typhoon Toraji, the 7th-most lethal to hit Taiwan since 1958, had claimed 86 lives as of Friday and had left 132 people missing. The typhoon also caused losses of some NT$6.16 billion (US$181 million) to the agricultural sector, as well as immeasurable damage to the country's infrastructure, including roads and bridges.
Nantou and Hualien counties, in central and eastern Taiwan, respectively, bore the brunt of the havoc.

Besides launching rescue efforts, the military also decided to launch the fund collecting campaign among officers and soldiers, some of whom have perceived at first hand the pain of the victims during their rescue work.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA PUSHING FOR PRESIDENTIAL VISIT TO DENMARK: FM

TEXT.P: Minister of Foreign Affairs Tien Hung-mao said Friday that the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) is making every possible effort to pave the way for President Chen Shui-bian to visit Denmark in November to receive an international award.
Tien said Liberal International's (LI's) decision to present its 2001 Freedom Award to Chen is an honor for both the president himself and for the Republic of China.

"We appreciate the LI's goodwill in presenting the award to our president, and MOFA certainly will enlist every possible means to have President Chen travel to Denmark to receive the prestigious award in person," Tien said.
Over the past few months, Tien said, the MOFA has used nearly every possible channel to push for the realization of Chen's Denmark travel plan.
Tien would not elaborate on MOFA's efforts, saying only: "We will continue our efforts."

MOFA officials said the ministry has been working to make Chen's Denmark visit happen ever since the LI, a London-based international alliance of liberal parties, decided to present its 2001 Freedom Award to him in February.

As the ROC does not maintain formal diplomatic ties with Denmark, MOFA officials have consistently kept a low profile in their work, but diplomatic sources said Denmark has already rejected MOFA's request for a Danish visa for Chen through official channels. Nevertheless, MOFA officials said they will continue trying other channels to push for Chen's visit.
MOFA spokeswoman Chang Siao-yue said earlier this week that despite the absence of formal diplomatic ties, the ROC and Denmark share common beliefs in freedom and democracy.

Noting that boosting substantive ties with European countries is one of MOFA's major goals, Chang said the ministry will redouble its efforts to push for the realization of Chen's Denmark travel plan. Because of Beijing's diplomatic embargo against Taiwan, no ROC head of state has ever been allowed to visit any European country so far.
Meanwhile, Presidential Office officials said that whether Chen can visit Denmark Nov. 9-10 to receive the award in person will hinge on the Danish government's attitude.

The officials said Chen has not yet filed a visa application. "We'll decide whether to apply for a Danish visa based on the developments in the general international situation in the coming months as well as on the Danish government's attitude," said a presidential aide.
If Denmark denies Chen's visa application, the aide said, the chairman of the Liberal International may travel to Taiwan to present the award to Chen.
The LI groups liberal political parties in major countries around the world. Taiwan's current ruling Democratic Progressive Party is a member.

In an interview with a Danish newspaper in March, Chen expressed his hope that the Danish government will grant him a visa so that he can receive the award at the LI annual conference, as the award represents recognition of the pursuit of freedom and democracy by the 23 million people of Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC TO LAUNCH 9TH BID FOR U.N. MEMBERSHIP

TEXT.P: Taipei's preparations to launch its ninth bid to join the United Nations have entered the final countdown, as the New York-based world body is to call its annual general assembly in mid-September.

Republic of China Foreign Affairs Minister Tien Hung-mao said Friday that the government has decided to rule out the possibility of joining the U.N. as an observer and also pointed out that it has no plans to join the international organization under a designation other than the ROC.

As the U.N. is a political and governmental body composed of sovereign states, Tien said, any change in the nation's formal title must be made in compliance with the ROC Constitution, a move which is out of the power of his ministry.

The foreign affairs minister made the remarks while answering questions from reporters following the swearing-in ceremony of the newly appointed representatives to France and Brazil -- Hsieh Hsin-ping and Chou Kuo-jui.

Tien revealed that the Executive Yuan will set up an inter-ministerial task force, to be led by himself and by Executive Yuan Secretary-General Chiou I-jen, to devise a more flexible, efficient and dignified strategy for this year's U.N. bid. Taipei will also coordinate with its diplomatic allies that traditionally raise the proposal in favor of Taiwan's membership at the U.N. assembly, he added.

According to Tien, the content of those allies' proposals will be quite similar to those put forward in the past and his ministry will call a news conference Tuesday to give an explanation of this year's proposal.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC HAS SOLE RIGHT TO DECIDE WHO TO SEND TO APEC FORUM: MOFA

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Friday that the Republic of China will decide who it will send to represent Taiwan at the annual informal leadership meeting of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum in Shanghai later this year. The ministry also said that mainland China has no right to interfere in the matter.

The MOFA was responding to media reports that mainland China will reject Koo Chen-fu, chairman of the Straits Exchange Foundation and Taiwan's top negotiator with the mainland, to attend the APEC meeting in October.

The MOFA said that to participate in APEC activities is the right and obligation of the members. As a full member and keen participant of APEC, the ROC government hopes to fulfill its duty and make contributions.

The MOFA said that past ROC presidents have wanted to participate in APEC meetings, but to preserve the harmonious operations of APEC and to fully participate in the functions of APEC, the ROC has sent envoys to represent its president each year.

The MOFA said that the ROC government is happy to see that mainland China is playing host to this year's event, but that the mainland has no right to interfere with the decisions of the ROC regarding its selection of its representative.
The Cabinet-level Mainalnd Affairs Council, echoed the same view earlier by saying that the ROC is free to name any person as its representative at the annual APEC meeting.
MAC Vice Chairman Chen Ming-tung said that APEC is a regional economic cooperation forum and the ROC has every right to participate in the meeting.

APEC is one of the few international organizations that accept both Taiwan and mainland China as members. Due to Beijing's opposition, however, the ROC state of head has been barred from attending past APEC leadership meetings in person and must instead appoint a proxy to take part in the event on his behalf.

DOC.HEADLINE: FM PRESIDES OVER OATH-TAKING CEREMONY FOR NEWLY APPOINTED ENVOYS

TEXT.P: Republic of China Foreign Minister Tien Hung-mao presided Friday over an oath-taking ceremony for newly appointed ROC Representative to France Hsieh Hsin-ping and Representative to Brazil Chou Kuo-jui.

Tien hailed Hsieh and Chou for their good performance and expressed hope that they will continue their efforts to promote foreign relations between the ROC and the nations in which they will be stationed.
Hsieh will replace Kuo Wei-fan, who is retiring from the foreign service, while Chou will replace Hou Ping-fu, who has been appointed new ROC envoy to El Salvador.

Hsieh, 59, a graduate of National Taiwan University (NTU), obtained a doctorate in law from France's Lyon University. He has held many important posts, including ROC representative to Czechoslovakia and secretary-general of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs.
Chou, 60, a graduate of National Taiwan University, obtained a Masters in politics from NTU. He has also held many important posts, including ROC ambassador to Burkina Faso.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOV'T CANNOT COPE WITH LARGE-SCALE REDUCTION IN TAX INCOME: OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: The Director General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics said Friday that the government would not be able to cope with a large-scale reduction in tax income as suggested by various industry groups.

Lin Chuan said at the third financial panel meeting of the Economic Development Advisory Conference slated to be held Aug. 24-26 that the government has already sold off all the state-owned company stocks that it could, so any imbalance in government finance might become more apparent in the next year or two.
He said that stock income cannot be considered routine income, and selling government bonds will produce negative effects and amount to spending government savings.
Lowering taxes will also cut into savings and reduce economic competitiveness, he said, warning that Japan and the United States ran into the same problem in the 1980s.

With the government's annual current tax income at NT$900 billion (US$26 billion) and its total annual budgeted expenditure at NT$1.6 trillion (US$46 billion), Lin said that Standard & Poor's has lowered Taiwan's credit rating because the government's current income from stocks alone amount to NT$200 billion (US$5.8 billion).
He went on to say that instead of simply giving a tax cut that would cause decreased tax income, the tax system should be adjusted and related measures planned.

There should be a period of transition from a reliance on stock income, he said, because if the budgeted income is lowered to NT$1.4 trillion (US$40 billion) immediately -- leading to a proportional reduction in the expenditure -- the economy would be "seriously hurt."

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN DIGNITARIES SEND MESSAGES OF CONCERN OVER TYPHOON TORAJI

TEXT.P: The international community has sent messages to the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and overseas diplomatic missions of the Republic of China to express their deep concern over the loss of lives and destruction of property caused by Typhoon Toraji which swept over Taiwan last weekend, a MOFA official said Friday.

The official said that as of Friday, MOFA had received letters or messages of condolence from political figures and friends from El Salvador, Paraguay, St. Vincent and the Grenadines, Grenada, the Commonwealth of Dominica, Belize, Saint Christopher and Nevis, Jordan, Swaziland, Japan, South Korea, France, the United States, the Vatican, the Marshall Islands, Argentina, Haiti, Burkina Faso and Gambia.
Condolence messages from other foreign nations are expected to continue to be received, the official said.

MOFA, on behalf of the ROC government and the people of Taiwan, has expressed its thanks to all who have shown their concern for the citizens of the country who were affected by Typhoon Toraji, the official added.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER HOPES TAIWAN CAN REACH 3 PERCENT ECONOMIC GROWTH THIS YEAR

TEXT.P: Republic of China Premier Chang Chun-hsiung said Friday that he hopes Taiwan can maintain an economic growth rate of 3 percent this year despite the global economic recession.
Chang made the remarks during a meeting with a Canadian parliamentary delegation, in which he also envisioned a 5 percent economic growth rate for next year.
The premier said Taiwan's economy is driven by foreign trade, and at a time when the world is mired in economic woes, the government will use huge public investments to prime the economy.
Taiwan's economic growth is not gained by luck, but by the nation's capacity to face challenges, Chang said, adding that now is the time to overcome difficulties.

In referring to the outflow of capital from Taiwan, Chang said that this was not unusual. He said that as Taiwan's living standard is rising, so are its labor costs. This being the case, it is natural that local enterprises should try to survive by finding opportunities abroad.
Chang went on to say that if these enterprises can base their headquarters in Taiwan, the island can serve as a global planning and management center.

However, Chang said, Taiwan's goal of being a regional operations hub has been hindered by the stalemate in its ties with mainland China. The premier emphasized that the government will do all it can to maintain peace between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.

For his part, Canadian congressman John McKay said the visit of his delegation, composed of 14 parliamentary members from Canada's four largest political parties, signaled Canada's friendship toward Taiwan.
McKay said the delegation appreciated the warmth and friendship from the people on Taiwan during their stay. He said they will continue promoting ties between the two countries when they return home.

DOC.HEADLINE: OVERSEAS CHINESE URGED TO BE ALERT TO BEIJING'S PLOT
DOC.DATELINE: Dallas, Texas Aug. 2 (CNA) (By Chang Hui-yen & Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: Republic of China Minister of Overseas Chinese Affairs Chang Fu-mei called on local ethnic Chinese in the United States Thursday not to support Beijing's "anti-Taiwan independence, promoting Chinese reunification" campaign.
Chang told local ethnic Chinese in Dallas, Texas that Beijing's campaign is a ploy to annex the Republic of China because Beijing equates the existence of the ROC with Taiwan independence.

She said Beijing has been following Taiwan's lead closely in trying to woo overseas Chinese to support their doctrine over the last decade but that China does not dare try to emulate Taiwan's democracy, freedom and respect for human rights.
Chang told local Chinese to meet Beijing's overtures on "anti-Taiwan independence, promoting Chinese reunification" with a "don't join, don't support, don't agree" campaign of their own.
Some 500 local Chinese listened to Chang's report on the conclusions reached at the Third Global Overseas Chinese Affairs Conference, which was held in Taipei May 17-18.

Noting that the overseas Chinese community is a powerful arm of Taiwan's diplomacy, Chang urged local Chinese to exercise their influence with U.S. congressmen to support Taiwan's bid to join the World Health Organization, and President Chen Shui-bian's desire to visit Denmark in November to collect the "Prize for Freedom" awarded to him by Liberal International, a group of the world's liberal parties.
Chang arrived in Dallas Wednesday on the second leg of her visit to the southern United States to canvass overseas Chinese support for Taiwan.
She will leave Dallas for Houston Friday.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER U.S. HOUSE SPEAKER CALLS ON ROC PREMIER

TEXT.P: Republic of China Premier Chang Chun-hsiung received visiting former U.S. House of Representatives Speaker Thomas S. Foley Friday and thanked him for his support of the 1979 Taiwan Relations Act that paved the foundation for regional stability.
Chang said that such security allowed Taiwan to develop its economy and create the "Taiwan economic miracle."

Facing global economic sluggishness, the ROC government is trying to create a good international investment environment, Chang said, adding that he hopes Foley can utilize his political influence and provide Taiwan with the necessary advisory services after the island joins the World Trade Organization.
Foley said that he would do his best to provide Taiwan with the necessary resources and assistance to respond to globalization issues.

Expressing admiration for Taiwan's political and economic progress over the years, he added that both Democrats and Republicans in the United States look upon relations with Taiwan with great importance.

Foley served 30 years in the House of Representatives, from 1965-1994. He was the U.S. Ambassador to Japan from 1997-2001. Having retired from government service earlier this year, he is currently a partner in a Washington, D.C. law firm, specializing in international affairs.
He is slated to call on Central Bank of China Governor Perng Fai-nan and Minister of Finance Yen Ching-chang during the course of his visit to exchange opinions regarding Taiwan's economic progress.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORESTRY OFFICIAL SAYS ILLEGAL BETEL NUT TREES TO BE UPROOTED BY 2004

TEXT.P: A senior official of the Forestry Bureau under the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture said Friday that all illegally planted betel nut trees found in national forests will be uprooted by 2004.
Illegally planted betel nut trees are a major contributor to soil erosion and mudslides as was clearly demonstrated during the last typhoon to pass over the island.

Lee Tao-sheng, deputy director of the bureau, said that the council has already removed many trees. At one point in the past, some 3,673 hectares of illegally planted betel nut trees were on national lands. Since the government has addressed the problem, there are now only 1,818 hectares affected. The trees in this area are expected to be removed by 2004, Lee said.

Lee pointed out that illegal betel nut plantations on private land totals 11,122 hectares. Nantou County has the most betel nut trees with 6,809 hectares, followed by Chiayi County with 5,662 hectares and Hualien County with 2,281 hectares.
Clearing lands of illegal trees is not as easy as planting new trees, Lee said, adding that the bureau expects to meet with resistance from plantation owners and workers over the plan.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S WIRELESS TELECOMMUNICATIONS OUTPUT TO HIT US$ 8.7 B. IN 2005

TEXT.P: The production value of Taiwan's wireless telecommunications industry will hit around NT$100 billion in 2001, and the figure is expected to reach NT$300 billion (about US$8.7 billion) in 2005, a trade official said Friday.
Vice Minister of Economic Affairs Yiin Chii-ming made the remarks at the establishment ceremony of the "3G Club" held at the Far Eastern Plaza Hotel in Taipei.

Expressing the hope that the formation of the business alliance will help pool the wisdom of the local telecommunications industry, and the academic and government sectors to create more advanced products to grab a larger slice of the mainland Chinese and global markets, Yiin said he believes that Taiwan's telecommunications industry will take off after the opening of its market.

Citing statistics compiled by the Industrial Technology Research Institute, Yiin said the output of Taiwan's wireless telecommunications industry totaled NT$31.9 billion in 2000, and the figure is expected to jump to NT$100 billion for this year and NT$140 billion and NT$300 billion for 2002 and 2005, respectively.

By 2005, Taiwan will emerge as one of the world's major suppliers of wireless LAN products, such as third-generation cellular phones, he predicted, adding that this will also lead to the innovation of the local semiconductor, telecommunications, and software industries to make them the locomotive of Taiwan's economy.

Yiin, however, pointed out that to achieve all these objectives, Taiwan must develop five strategic products -- cellular phones, blue tooth products, wireless Lan products, global positioning satellites and application and content services -- and further integrate cooperation in the local industries.

The "3G Club" hopes to create a wireless telecommunications application and invention center in Taiwan and cultivate local professional talent for those sectors by actively promoting those key strategies of the local third-generation wireless telecommunications industry, he added.
Leading local businesses, including Taiwan Cellular Phone Corp., Acer Communications and Multimedia Inc., Inventec Corporation, Asustek Computer and Quanta Computer are 3G members, among others.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT CONSIDERS ENTERING LAWSUIT BETWEEN RCA AND WORKERS

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) said Friday it was considering whether to serve as guarantor for former Taiwan workers of the U.S. company RCA in their lawsuit against the company for subjecting workers to occupational hazards.
CLA officials said they are studying the legality for the Cabinet-level agency to wade into civil disputes.
Former RCA Taiwan workers who claim the company exposed them to dangerous chemical solvents which predisposed them to various cancers are deciding whether to sue the company.

They plan to ask a court to temporarily impound RCA's assets in Taiwan as a safeguard against their damage claims pending the court's ruling, and thereby will be required to provide a deposit, usually one-third of the value of their claims, as a counter safeguard to compensate for any damage caused by the impound in case their claims are denied.
Since they intend to impound US$2.4 billion (US$69.76 million) worth of RCA assets, they need to post a deposit of NT$800 million (US$23.25 million).
They asked the CLA to serve as their guarantor in the proposed suit to persuade the court to waive the deposit requirement.

CLA Vice Chairman Kuo Chi-jen said Friday that a three-year study has failed so far to establish a link between the cancers suffered by RCA workers and their occupations while in the employ of the company.

Furthermore, Kuo said a government's written guarantee is rare in practice despite the fact that it is provided by law, and that the council will fully examine the legal consequences of such a move before making a decision.

However, Wang Shih-szu, a labor rights advocate who represents the RCA employees in the dispute, said the CLA has agreed to serve as guarantor in the lawsuit, and will certify in the suit that the RCA workers' diseases were related to their jobs.
Wang said RCA invested in Taiwan in 1969 and had three plants with about 30,000 employees at its peak until 1992 when it divested from Taiwan.

In 1994, the Environmental Protection Administration found that the company had dug wells at its Taoyuan plant to dispose of hazardous liquids and declared the plant site "a permanent pollution zone" in 1998.

In 1997, many former RCA workers were found to be suffering from various cancers. The number of RCA employees who developed cancer has risen to 1,375 by 2001, in addition to many others suffering from tumors. Among the cancer suffers, 216 have died already.
The former RCA employees have demanded damages from the company but have gotten no response thus far.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, Aug. 4, or the 15th day of the sixth month of the Year of the Snake according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1578: The Portuguese King Sebastian and his court are killed in a failed crusade to Morocco.
1875: Hans Christian Anderson, Danish writer famous the world over for his fairy tales and stories, including "The Princess and the Pea" and "The Ugly Duckling," dies in Copenhagen at the age of 70.
1906: The Education Ministry of the Ching court promulgates a set of "regulations on education for women" governing the establishment of schools for women.
1914: World War I breaks out when German troops invade Belgium. Britain declares war on Germany as the United States declares its neutrality.
1916: Denmark sells the Danish Virgin Islands to the United States for US$25 million.
1922: Fighting breaks out in Italy between the fascists and the socialists.
1938: The Nationalist government moves its offices from Wuchang and Hankow to Chungking in order to cope with the lengthy War of Resistance Against Japan.
1940: Italian troops invade the country of British Somaliland in East Africa.
1942: David Russel Lange, New Zealand Labor politician, is born. He served as prime minister from 1984 to 1989 and was controversial for his refusal to allow nuclear-armed ships to dock in New Zealand.
1944: Anne Frank, a 14-year-old German Jewish diarist, and seven other Jews in hiding in Amsterdam, are captured by the Gestapo and sent to concentration camps.
1950: Gen. Douglas MacArthur dispatches a high-ranking aide to Taipei as a liaison officer as the United States begins providing military aid to Taiwan.
1954: The P-1 English Electronic Lightning, Britain's first supersonic fighter plane, makes its maiden flight.
1960: Chung Li-ho, a noted Taiwanese folk tale author, dies at the age of 45.
1963: The Foreign Ministry declares that the Republic of China will not recognize the border treaty signed between the Peking regime and Afghanistan.
1967: Malawian President Dr. H. Kamuzu Banda arrives in Taipei for an eight-day state visit.
1972: Ugandan President Idi Amin declares that his country will expel 50,000 Asians with British passports within three months.
1976: The Central Standing Committee of the Kuomintang extends its "deepest sympathy" to victims of the earthquake that struck northern China.
1979: Ho Yen-sheng, former Saigon correspondent for the China Times of Taipei who had been stranded in Vietnam since 1975, arrives in Taipei from an isolated island in the South China Sea where he spent 70 days as a refugee.
1986: ROC-U.S. trade talks begin in Washington. During the five-day talks, the ROC agreed to abandon its use of duty tables as of Oct. 1, 1986.
1990: Iraq installs a nine-man puppet government in Kuwait and sets up a new "People's Army" to control the regime while 12 European Community nations ban oil imports from Iraq, impose an arms embargo on the country and suspend most trade with Iraq.
1993: Japan formally apologizes for the first time to women forced to serve as sex slaves for Japanese soldiers during World War II.
1993: The Japanese Cabinet resigns, ending 38 years of rule by the Liberal Democratic Party.
1999: British Defence Secretary George Robertson becomes the new secretary-general of NATO, succeeding Javier Solana.
1999: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou and Mayor Tarmile Ishoda of Majuro sign a pact of alliance in Taipei, making Majuro, capital of the Marshall Islands, the 44th sister city of Taiwan's capital.
2000: Government Information Office Director General Chung Chin says that the GIO is mapping out procedures for setting up exchanges across the Taiwan Strait of journalists for long-term postings.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "By dealing loyally and punctually with them in all engagements which he makes with them and allowing a liberal scale of pay: that is how the ruler gives encouragement to men in the public service."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies on Saturday are as follows:
The China Times:
Premier Chang orders crackdown on illegal betel nut plantations as part of efforts to combat soil erosion.
The United Daily News:
Yeh Sheng-mao promoted to head the Investigation Bureau.
The Liberty Times:
National reforestation campaign to be launched to combat soil erosion and curb landslides.
The Taiwan Daily:
Premier Chang vows to wipe out illegal betel nut plantations and speed up reforestation to prevent mudslides.
The Central Daily News:
Tax redistribution fund allowed to be spent on disaster relief.
The China Post:
Betel nut trees to be cleared for reforestation.
The Taiwan News:
Premier orders reforestation to curb erosion.
The Taipei Times:
Premier proposes reforestation.

DOC.HEADLINE: HOUSE RESOL'N FOR CONTINUED ENDORSEMENT OF ROC'S WHO BID INTRODUCED

TEXT.P: Two U.S. members of Congress have introduced a House resolution calling on the Bush administration to continue to endorse Taiwan's bid to obtain observer status at the 2002 annual meeting of the World Health Assembly in Geneva, Switzerland.

Rep. Sherrod Brown (D-Ohio) and Rep. Steve Chabot (R-Ohio) pointed out that President George W. Bush stated in his May 11 letter to Sen. Frank Murkowski (R-Ala.) that the United States "should find opportunities for Taiwan's voice to be heard in international organizations in order to make a contribution, even if membership is not possible."
In his letter Murkowski, Bush added that his administration "has focused on finding concrete ways for Taiwan to benefit and contribute to the World Health Organization."

Moreover, U.S. Secretary of Health and Human Services Tommy Thompson announced May 16 the Bush administration's support of Taiwan's participation in the activities of the WHO when he attended the last annual meeting of the World Health Assembly.

Rep. Brown last February introduced House Resolution 428, which urged the U.S. government to support Taiwan's participation in the WHO, and 31 senators headed by Murkowski wrote to the U.S. president in mid-March expressing their concerns about the administration's efforts in helping Taiwan join the WHO as an observer.
Following the passage of the resolution by both houses of Congress earlier this year, President Bush signed it into law.

The Brown-Chabot resolution is designed to amend that law so that the Bush administration can continue planning to endorse and obtain observer status for Taiwan to attend the World Health Assembly meeting in Geneva next year.

DOC.HEADLINE: HOUSE RESOLUTION PITCHING FOR ROC'S U.N. BID INTRODUCED

TEXT.P: Thirteen members of the U.S. House of Representatives introduced a resolution Thursday that urges the Bush administration to take a leading role in gaining international support for Taiwan's participation in the United Nations and other international organizations.

The House concurrent resolution, introduced by Rep. Bob Schaffer and twelve colleagues from both parties, points out that Taiwan and its 23 million people "deserve full and equal membership in the United Nations and other international organizations."

Congressman Schaffer emphasized Friday that "Taiwan continues as a beacon of freedom and democracy under the shadow of Communist China. Taiwan's courageous dedication to democratic principles reinforces its rightful place as a member of the United Nations. The citizens of our great nation stand shoulder to shoulder with Taiwan."
The resolution reaffirms the United States' commitment made in the 1994 Taiwan Policy Review to actively support Taiwan's membership in international organizations, said the Colorado Republican.

It notes that the global community has reacted positively to Taiwan's desire for international participation, as shown by Taiwan's membership in the Asian Development Bank, its admission into the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation forum as a full member, and its anticipated membership in the World Trade Organization.

As evidenced above, the resolution says, Taiwan "possesses ample resources and creativity to contribute to the work and funding of the United Nations and its affiliate organizations, such as the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund, as well as benefit from these organizations."
Rep. Schaffer, together with 40 congressional colleagues, introduced a similar House resolution last year.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PRESIDENT INSPECTS TYPHOON-TORN COUNTIES

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian inspected the counties of Nantou, Chiayi and Yunlin on Saturday to survey the damage caused by Monday's Typhoon Toraji.

Toraji now ranks as the sixth-most lethal typhoon to hit Taiwan since 1958, the year when the government began maintaining records on typhoon casualties. As of early afternoon Saturday, the death toll from Toraji had risen to 89, with another 133 people still unaccounted for.

In the village of Fengshan in Chiayi's Alishan Rural Township, residents appealed to Chen for help and suggested that the government can aid in resolving the serious landslide and mudflow problems in the area while adding to the government's coffers by exporting the gravel deposits that were washed down the mountains during the typhoon.

Minister of Economic Affairs Lin Hsin-yi warned that such a proposal might involve legal issues, but Chen said that exceptions can be made through policy changes if amending related laws might take too long to be of any use to dealing with the urgent matter.

Meanwhile, Vice President Annette Lu, who was inspecting another village in the same rural township, said that as the chairwoman of the presidential science and technology advisory committee, she will try to import the necessary technology to make the most effective use of the stones and gravel.
Lu added that Taiwan can try to follow the example of Japanese companies that turn these kinds of stones and gravel into floor tile products.

In Nantou, military and police helicopters took advantage of the fair weather to transport more relief materials to various rural areas that were completely cut off from the rest of the country due to destroyed or blocked roads.
According to government estimates, reconstruction projects in the wake of Toraji will cost approximately NT$10 billion (US$288 million).

Therefore, Minister-without-Portfolio Chen Chin-huang warned that the agreement struck by ruling and opposition legislative caucuses Friday to allow the Executive Yuan to use what remains of the fiscal 2001 Tax Redistribution Fund will not be enough to cover the foreseen expenditures.

The government estimates that total agricultural, forestry, fishing and livestock losses including damage to agricultural facilities amount to approximately NT$6.6 billion (US$190 million). (Fang Wen-hung)

DOC.HEADLINE: CROSS-STRAIT CONSULTATIONS SHOULD NOT BE 'PRIVATIZED': OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: "No privatization" is the government's bottom line for consultations between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, a senior official said Saturday.
Cabinet Secretary-General Chiou I-jen made the remarks at a meeting of the cross-strait panel under the Economic Development Advisory Conference (EDAC).

During the session, many panel members, including opposition lawmakers and business executives, criticized the government's for its alleged reluctance to liberalize cross-strait commercial exchanges and open direct "three links" -- trade, mail and transportation.

They said the government has often resisted the appeals for easing the existing "go slow, be patient" policy on mainland China-bound investment and for opening of direct cross-strait "three links" on the ground that such moves may jeopardize Taiwan's national security.
In response, Chiou said both easing the "go slow" policy and opening direct cross-strait "three links" involve many complex problems, not just national security issues.
Noting that such new opening measures could accelerate capital outflow and further drive up the unemployment rate, Chiou said the government must exercise prudence in handling relevant affairs.
Chiou pointed out that Beijing's "one China" precondition for resuming cross-strait dialogue entails "high price" for Taiwan to endure.

In his view, Chiou said Taiwan would have to pay a "price" if it accepts Beijing's "one China" principle, which downgrades the Republic of China to a local-level government under the People's Republic of China -- mainland China's official national title.
Chiou said the current Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) has no intention of using the "go slow" and "three links" issues as bargaining chips for cross-strait talks.

At the moment, Chiou said, stumbling blocks indeed exist in resuming cross-strait talks. "We are certainly willing to make every possible effort to push for resumption of cross-strait dialogue," Chiou said, adding that the government's bottom line for cross-strait talks is that they should not be completely privatized and should be handled by officially authorized organizations.

The session was co-chaired by Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen, Acer Group Chairman Stan Shih and Wu Jung-yi, head of the Taiwan Institute of Economic Research, a private think tank.
This was the panel's third meeting since its formation in late July. The panel is expected to come up with a package of proposals for further discussion at the EDAC scheduled for Aug. 24-26.

The panel will mainly address five categories of issues regarding cross-strait ties -- adjustment of the "go slow" policy; the timing for opening "three links"; mechanism for cross-strait capital flow; opening the door to mainland Chinese tourists; and strategy for coping with problems that may arise following Taipei's and Beijing's accession to the World Trade Organization.
During Saturday's meeting, all panel members agreed to hold special sessions to solicit opinions of senior executives of foreign-owned companies on both sides of the Taiwan Strait.
Starting Monday, the panel will also hold a series of seminars in different parts of the island to seek opinions of people in various social quarters on future government cross-strait policies.
Meanwhile, the panel has decided to invite relevant national security officials to brief its members on the possible impact of cross-strait economic relations on national security.

DOC.HEADLINE: EXPERT PREDICTS LOWER-THAN-2-PERCENT GROWTH FOR TAIWAN ECONOMY

TEXT.P: Chu Yun-peng, one of the 120 members of the upcoming Economic Development Advisory Conference, predicted Saturday at a technology and economics seminar that Taiwan's annual economic growth is unlikely to reach 2 percent this year.

Chu, an economics professor at National Taiwan University, said at the National Policy Foundation-organized seminar that although Taiwan's first-quarter growth was merely 1.06 percent and growth for the second and third quarters appears just as sluggish, he believes the fourth quarter will see some improvements and will register a better performance than last year's fourth quarter.

However, Chu, who is also a researcher at Academia Sinica's Institute of Social Sciences, added that Taiwan's fourth quarter recovery will still depend on whether the U.S. economy recovers. He added that even if the U.S. economy does begin to pick up, the trend will only help the domestic information technology industry and will have no effect on domestic consumption-based industries or the construction industry.

With regard to the possibility that the government might yield to industry pressure to imitate the U.S. administration's move to cut taxes in order to stimulate economic recovery, Chu expressed his doubt about the effectiveness of such a policy.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE PRESIDENT SAYS EMIGRATION AN OPTION IN POPULATION POLICY

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu said Saturday that emigration is an option for solving Taiwan's overpopulation problem.

She made the remark Friday while inspecting areas in central Taiwan devastated by Typhoon Toraji which swept across the island Monday, causing flooding, landslides and mudflows that left many people dead and many more missing.

She said that people in Taiwan must recognize the pressing problem of overpopulation and suggested emigration as a possible option to be considered by authorities working out a long-term population policy. However, she added that there is no immediate need for such an emigration policy and that it would not be compulsory if implemented.
Lu said that natural disasters plus manmade damage to Mother Nature have brought catastrophic consequences, pointing out that Taiwan's overused land needs time to rehabilitate.

She said that, living in a nation surrounded on all sides by water, the people of Taiwan should demonstrate the spirit of expedition by seeking opportunities overseas instead of continuing to exploit and develop the island's mountainous areas and thereby give Taiwan back its beautiful natural landscape.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN COMPUTER FIRMS TO FACE SEVERE COMPETITION FROM M'LAND: DELL

TEXT.P: An executive of Dell Corp.'s international procurement office (IPO) in Taipei said that Dell's decision to move its Asia-Pacific IPO from Taipei to Hong Kong will not affect its purchases from Taiwan in the short term but added that computer firms in mainland China are potential competitors Taiwan cannot ignore.
Fang Kuo-chien, general manager of computer giant Dell's IPO in Taipei, said that the Taipei IPO office will not shrink, although the IPO office in mainland China will continue to expand.

Since Dell has long-term contracts with its Taiwan suppliers, Fang said that cooperation relationships and strategic alliances with these suppliers have not changed. He added that if Dell considers changing suppliers, it will not be an immediate decision.

Fang said some of Dell's Taiwan suppliers have been making deliveries from their factories in mainland China, where the production costs are comparably lower. Mainland China is considered by all international computer firms as one of the most important markets as well as potential OEM suppliers.

While leading international computer firms, such as IBM and Toshiba, have invested in manufacturing plants on the mainland, Fang said that Taiwan companies are in a disadvantageous position due to government restrictions.

He said that he considers that Taiwan still maintains the advantage in terms of technology and international business experience. However, the lack of Taiwan authorities' flexibility will weaken the competitiveness of the island's companies, he added.

Dell's decision to move its Asia-Pacific IPO to Hong Kong is a pragmatic adjustment in the company's operations in this part of the world, Fang said. He would not rule out the possibility that Dell may move the office back to Taipei in the future when direct transportation links between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait exist.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP VICE CHAIRMAN SAYS PARTY'S GOAL IS PRESIDENCY IN 2004
DOC.DATELINE: Tainan, southern Taiwan, Aug. 4 (CNA) (By Fang Wen-hung)

TEXT.P: Opposition People First Party (PFP) Vice Chairman Chang Chau-hsiung said Saturday that the party's goal is to send PFP Chairman James Soong into the Presidential Office in 2004.

Criticizing the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's "ineptitude," the main opposition Kuomintang's "historic burden," and the opposition New Party's "expected bubble-bursting," Chang said that only the PFP can represent "60 percent" of the Taiwan mainstream without regard for ethnic or north-versus-south differences.

Chang said while visiting the offices of the PFP candidates in Tainan City who were nominated by the party to run in the year-end legislative elections that Soong's past experience as Taiwan provincial governor -- when he visited all 309 townships in the nation several times -- is his party's "largest resource."

Therefore, Chang said that the PFP decided to nominate two candidates in Tainan despite criticism from one candidate's camp that the move would force him out of the race because some believe that the party will win only one seat in the city.
He said that he hopes both nominees will be elected to the Legislative Yuan.

He explained that as the convener to a committee in charge of nominating candidates, he and the seven committee members agreed that if every region were to field only one PFP candidate, there would only be a total of 28 candidates -- less than even the opposition New Party, which nominated 35 people, and the soon-to-be-established Taiwan Solidarity Union, which is fielding 41 candidates.
He added that Soong also supports the decision to nominate more than one candidate per election precinct.

DOC.HEADLINE: YEH SHENG-MAO APPOINTED NEW INVESTIGATION BUREAU CHIEF

TEXT.P: Yeh Sheng-mao, newly appointed director of the Ministry of Justice Investigation Bureau (MJIB), said Saturday he will do his utmost to fulfill his duty after assuming office.
The Ministry of Justice (MOJ) announced in a news release late Friday that it has decided to promote Yeh from the MJIB deputy director post to the bureau's directorship due to practical needs.
Yeh, 58, has climbed the ladder from local investigator to the top MJIB post. He was head of the Taipei City Government's anti-corruption department before becoming the MJIB deputy director.
Throughout his career, Yeh has been noted for his low-profile, self-effacing working style, sources familiar with Yeh said.
According to the MOJ press release, Justice Minister Chen Ding-nan took the initiative in promoting Yeh to head the MJIB, Taiwan's equivalent of the U.S. Federal Bureau of Investigation.
The press release said Premier Chang Chun-hsiung approved Yeh's promotion Friday. As for the outgoing bureau chief Wang Kuang-yu's new assignment, the news release said it will be announced later.

MJIB sources said the government originally planned to appoint Wang as a national policy adviser to the Republic of China president. But Wang has reportedly shown little interest in assuming such a post.
Justice Minister Chen would not make any comment on the abrupt personnel change.

MJIB sources said Chen's decision to replace Wang with Yeh might be aimed at facilitating the government's plan to set up an independent anti-corruption agency to eradicate official corruption and establish clean politics.

Wang had voiced opposition to the proposal of forming an independent anti-corruption agency. The MJIB's current functions include cracking down on official corruption and drug trafficking, as well as investigating major economic crimes.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC, U.S. REACH CONSENSUS ON JUDICIAL ASSISTANCE

TEXT.P: Negotiators from the Republic of China and the United States have reached a consensus on bilateral judicial assistance after a week of talks, according to reports from Washington, D.C. Saturday.

The reports said the two sides have agreed to sign a memorandum of understanding (MOU) on bilateral judicial assistance and cooperation in the near future, marking an instance of international recognition of the ROC's judicial sovereignty.
Diplomatic sources said Taiwan-U.S. negotiations over judicial assistance had been stalled for nearly three years before seeing a breakthrough after the inauguration of U.S. President George W. Bush.
With a view to combating international crime, the Bush administration recently took the initiative in expressing its willingness to sign a judicial assistance agreement with the ROC.

A delegation of officials from the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, the Ministry of the Interior and the Ministry of Justice (MOJ) left for Washington, D.C. last week to discuss with their American counterparts the details of possible cooperation.

During their weeklong talks, representatives from the two sides reached a consensus on exchanges of criminal information, mutual access to judicial documents and evidence, and repatriation of criminal suspects.

The two sides have also agreed to allow their law enforcement officers to question witnesses and defendants in each other's territory and to assist each other in arresting and deporting fugitives or criminal suspects.

At the request of the United States, MOJ officials said, the two sides will strengthen cooperation in cracking down on illegal drug trafficking, including the smuggling of contraband controlled drugs, covert investigations and examination of drug originating sources.

As the ROC has yet to legislate regulations governing covert investigations and the delivery of controlled drugs, the officials said they hope the Legislative Yuan can accelerate the legislative process in preparation for signing the judicial assistance accord with the United States.

Judicial sources said the 10-member U.S. delegation was composed of officials from the State Department, the Justice Department and the American Institute in Taiwan, a quasi-official organization authorized to handle relations with the ROC in the absence of formal diplomatic ties.

The eight-member Taiwan delegation was composed of officials from the ROC representative office in the United States, the Ministry of Justice, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and the Criminal Investigation Bureau.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies on Sunday are as follows:
The China Times:
Presdient Chen urges the lift of ban on digging sand and stone in area prone to mudslides.
The United Daily News:
Prosecutors to question suspects in connection with scandal surrounding Lafayettes purchase after finding arm broker's secret bank accounts in Switzerland.
The Liberty Times:
ROC to sign judicial assistance accord with the United States.
The Taiwan Daily:
Taiwan to sign judicial assistance accord with the United States.
The Central Daily News:
Residents of disaster area criticize Government's "slow rescue operation".
The China Post:
ROC, U.S. to sign on bilateral judicial assistance agreement.
The Taiwan News:
Taiwan, U.S. reach consensus on judicial aid.
The Taipei Times:
Villagers decry late rescue efforts.

DOC.HEADLINE: LARGEST-EVER BIOSCIENCE SYMPOSIUM TO OPEN MONDAY

TEXT.P: The largest-ever bioscience conference in Taiwan will open at Academia Sinica, Taiwan's highest academic and research facility, Monday with more than 1,000 ethnic Chinese bioscientists attending.
The international symposium will be jointly sponsored by Academia Sinica, the National Health Research Institute and the Society of Chinese Bioscientists in America.

Academia Sinica said that participants will include 1997 Nobel Prize-winner in physics Steve Chu; Chinese-American David Ho, who pioneered a cocktail treatment of drugs for fighting AIDS; and ethnic Chinese scientists from the United States, Canada, Britain, Germany, Switzerland, Spain, Australian, Japan, Hong Kong, Singapore and mainland China.

President Chen Shui-bian will speak at the opening ceremony of the symposium. Academia Sinica President Lee Yuan-tseh will then lead all participants in a discussion of "international cooperation and competition in bioscientific research."
It is estimated that participants will deliver over 100 speeches and 250 papers will be read during the five-day symposium.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHIEF OF GENERAL STAFF TO VISIT UNITED STATES

TEXT.P: Chief of the General Staff General Tang Yao-ming is scheduled to visit the United States next week, military sources said Sunday.
This will be General Tang's first U.S. visit in his capacity as chief of the general staff of the Republic of China.

During his stay in Washington D.C., General Tang is scheduled to meet high-ranking U.S. military officers, possibly including U.S. Secretary of Defense Donald Rumsfeld, for discussions on the establishment of Taiwan's next-generation arms, the cross-strait situation and bilateral intelligence exchanges.
The United States has been the most important provider of defensive weapons to Taiwan.

The Ministry of National Defense, however, would not comment on General Tang's coming U.S. visit. But military officials said that it is a routine matter that the chief of the general staff and the commanders-in-chief of all branches of the armed forces were invited to visit the United States during their tenures.
If General Tang meets with Rumsfeld, it will be the first meeting between the top military officials of the two nations since U.S. President George W. Bush took office in January.
Local media recently reported that General Tang has been tapped to be appointed the new defense minister after the next Cabinet reshuffle.
General Tang's predecessor, General Tang Fei, visited the United States in his capacity as the chief of the general staff shortly before he was promoted to defense minister in 1998.
General Tang Fei's Washington trip contributed greatly to the upgrading of Taiwan-U.S. intelligence cooperation, the sources said.
Tang Fei was named premier by President Chen Shui-bian after Chen was sworn in May 2000.
The sources said that the chief of the general staff is expected to report to President Chen on his coming Washington trip at a regular military meeting Monday.
The armed forces chief underwent surgery to remove gallstones last month.

DOC.HEADLINE: NOBEL LAUREATE TO GIVE LECTURE IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Steven Chu, a Chinese-American physicist who won the 1997 Nobel Prize in physics, will visit Taipei and give a lecture about "laser cooling and trapping," -- the topic that won him the Nobel Prize.

Chu, also a member of Academia Sinica, Taiwan's most prestigious research institute, will be visiting Taiwan at the invitation of Academia Sinica, the National Health Research Institute and the Society of Chinese Bioscientists in America.
The main purpose of Chu's visit to Taiwan is to attend the largest-ever bioscience symposium among Chinese bioscientists to be held in Taiwan, which will open Monday.
During the five-day symposium, Chu will give a lecture in Academia Sinica on Aug. 9 to share his research experiences with people in Taiwan.

Officials of Academia Sinica said Chu, a professor in physics at Stanford University, has dedicated his research to atomic and laser physics and was the first scientist in the world to be able to control and move an atomic particle.

Chu and two other scientists -- William Phillips of the United States and Claude Cohen-Tannoudji of France -- shared the 1997 Nobel Prize in physics for developing ways of trapping atoms of gas and cooling them to within a millionth of a degree of nature's limit.

DOC.HEADLINE: PARAGUAYAN FOREIGN MINISTER TO VISIT ROC IN LATE AUGUST: PAPER
DOC.DATELINE: Asuncion Aug. 5 (CNA) (By Ramon Huang and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Paraguayan Foreign Minister Jose Antonio Moreno Ruffinelli is slated to visit the Republic of China Aug. 20-25.

During his first visit to Taiwan since assuming his post, Moreno is expected to discuss bilateral cooperative ventures with ROC officials and will apply for a US$160 million loan with ROC financial authorities, according to a Paraguayan newspaper, Noticias.
ROC Ambassador to Paraguay Yen Ping-fan, however, has dismissed the report of a possible loan, saying that "there is no such thing."

DOC.HEADLINE: NEGOTIATIONS ON ROC-U.S. JUDICIAL ASSISTANCE ACCORD CONFIRMED

TEXT.P: A report concerning talks between Taipei and Washington on the signing of a mutual judicial assistance accord was confirmed Saturday by a Republic of China official stationed in the United States.
Lee Ying-yuan, ROC deputy representative to the United States, confirmed the report to Taiwan's Central News Agency that Taipei and Washington have held "sincere and honest" talks on the issue.
According to Taiwan newspapers, the ROC and United States have wrapped up weeklong negotiations on an agreement and will soon sign a memorandum of understanding.

According to Lee, there exists a draft agreement which has served as the foundation for talks. But the two sides have yet to conclude the matter, as concrete measures drawn up in the accord which are related to each other's rights and obligations, and details such as evidence gathering must be approved by Taiwan's legislature, he pointed out.

Lee, however, said that the sensitive issue regarding the extradition of criminals was not touched upon during the talks. He acknowledged that it is still quite difficult for Taiwan's judicial authorities at present to arrest criminals on the lam in the United States.
The recent talks are a sign of the good and close relations between the two countries and are a reflection of their common desire to further boost cooperation, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC HOPES FOR CONTINUED SUPPORT BY U.S. FOR WHO BID: FOREIGN MINISTER

TEXT.P: Minister of Foreign Affairs Tien Hung-mao said Monday that joining the World Health Organization (WHO) is the long-term policy of the Republic of China government, however, whether the goal can be reached depends largely on the help of the United States.

U.S. Secretary of Health and Human Services Tommy Thompson announced May 16 the Bush administration's support of Taiwan's participation in the activities of the WHO when he attended the annual meeting of the World Health Assembly in Geneva, Switzerland.
Although Thompson's announcement was made after Taiwan's WHO bid had been rejected, his remarks, the first from a U.S. administration, still signaled important meaning for ROC's WHO bid next year.

Tien noted that besides the private sector's efforts in pushing for Taiwan's participation in the WHO, the government's preparations have never been interrupted. However, he added, whether Taiwan can enter the WHO will depend on whether the U.S. administrative branch will help.

Moreover, two U.S. congressmen -- Rep. Sherrod Brown (D-Ohio) and Rep. Steve Chabot (R-Ohio) -- have introduced a House resolution calling on the Bush administration to continue to endorse Taiwan's bid to obtain observer status at the 2002 annual meeting of the World Health Assembly in Geneva.

Besides, U.S. President George W. Bush stated in his May 11 letter to Sen. Frank Murkowski (R-Ala.) that the United States "should find opportunities for Taiwan's voice to be heard in international organizations in order to make a contribution, even if membership is not possible."

DOC.HEADLINE: DOMINICAN REPUBLIC PARLIAMENT CITES ROC OFFICIAL
DOC.DATELINE: Panama City, Panama, Aug. 5 (CNA) (By Oscar Chung and Ed Chen)

TEXT.P: The Lower House of the Dominican Republic has presented a citation to former Republic of China press counselor Fernando Shu at the ROC Embassy in Santo Domingo for his contributions to promoting information exchanges and parliamentary cooperation between the two countries.

Speakerwoman of the Lower House, Rafaela Albuqueque, presented the citation to Shu on behalf of the Lower House at a presentation ceremony held at the National Press Club in Santo Domingo with some 20 parliamentarians including Foreign Relations Committee Chairman Alberto Dib witnessing.
The Lower House speaker spoke highly of the good performance made by Shu when he was stationed in the Dominican Republic.

Albuqueque also took the opportunity to announce that a parliamentary mission will visit Taiwan soon and consult with its counterparts in Taipei to build an exchange mechanism between the two countries.

Meanwhile, the Dominican Republic-ROC Amity Association has also made Shu an honorary citizen for his contributions to promoting relations between the Dominican Republic press and the ROC embassy in Santo Domingo.
Shu assumed the post of press counselor at the ROC Embassy in Santo Domingo in 1992 and he was ordered home for reassignment in 2000.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP PARTY OFFICIAL SUPPORTS GOVERNMENT TO AX BETEL PALM TREES

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) will support the government's decision to cut down betel palm tress, said DPP Secretary-General Wu Nei-jen Sunday.
Wu said his party would subordinate its political interests to the welfare of the country as a whole as long as the government's decision is based on scientific studies.
Admitting that the destruction of betel palm plantations could damage the livelihood of growers and sellers, Wu said it is the supreme goal of the DPP to pursue the nation's long-term interests.

Some DPP lawmakers elected from betel palm-growing areas might take issue with the government's decision to cut down the trees, Wu said, but their objections will not sway the party's determination to defend the overall welfare of the country.
Legislator Tsai Huang-liang, DPP whip at the legislature, aired his opposition last week to the destruction of the betel palm trees in the absence of measures to compensate growers.
Tsai said the government should not blame the growers for Taiwan's mudslides which are often triggered by torrential rains and often claim lives.
Premier Chang Chun-hsiung is expected to meet with DPP lawmakers later Sunday to solicit their support for the government's decision.
Chang announced that the government would uproot betel palm plantations on the island's steep mountain slopes after Typhoon Toraji wrought havoc in eastern and central Taiwan on July 30.

The betel palm trees are grown for their seeds which are chewed along with spices as a popular mild stimulant by local people. The tree's shallow roots are blamed by environmentalists as the main cause of landslides in mountainous areas.

A large number of people depend on the cash crop for survival, however, and taking away the livelihoods of growers and sellers is expected to put a great deal of pressure on the local and central governments. Observers say that the situation may pit the government and environmentalists against farmers and sellers of betel nuts and could result in political fallout.
The question is especially sensitive to the DPP since betel palm plantations are common in central and southern Taiwan which is the power base of the DPP.

DOC.HEADLINE: RISK MANAGEMENT MECHANISM NEEDED TO GOVERN CROSS-STRAIT EXCHANGES: MAC

TEXT.P: Tsai Ing-wen, chairwoman of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), said Sunday that the government needs to establish a risk management mechanism regarding mainland Chinese tourists to Taiwan and Chinese capital investment in Taiwan.
Tsai made the remarks while presiding over a symposium of the Economic Development Advisory Conference in Hualien, eastern Taiwan.

Tsai also said that the MAC has completed the first stage of its review of the "no haste, be patient" policy of investment on the mainland, and some adjustments have been made, including the lifting of the ban on financial institutions to open representative offices on the mainland. The next stage will be to open domestic banks to have remittance services with their mainland counterparts, she said.
Participants in the symposium were most concerned about allowing mainland Chinese tourists to visit Taiwan and pointed out that Hualien would benefit from the move.
Tsai said whether or not to go ahead with the plan will hinge on the development of the tourism industry in Taiwan.
She also said that whether the issue was mainland tourists or Chinese investment in Taiwan, a mechanism to manage risk would have to be established.

Tzeng Hsin-hsiung, one of the participants and president of the Association of Rock and Mineral Products in Taiwan, asked the government to consider the survival of traditional industries after the opening, adding that the opening of mainland products to Taiwan will affect the survival of traditional industries, especially the rock and mineral products of mainland's marble and granite industries.
Meanwhile, in another EDAC meeting held in Taichung, central Taiwan, most of the participants urged the government to ease the "no haste, be patient" policy toward investing in the mainland.

In the meeting presided over by Acer Group Chairman Stan Shih, Tsai Yu-ching, one of the business participants, expressed the hope that the government would sign a 50-year peace agreement, investment guarantee agreement and tax agreement with the mainland as soon as possible.

Hsiao Chia-chi, director of the Bureau of Economics of the Taichung City Government, said that cross-strait exchanges are very close to becoming a reality, but regulations governing such exchanges have not been revised for a decade, and he urged the MAC to revise outdated regulations soon.

Cheng Ching-hsiung, secretary-general of the Taichung County Government, said that Taichung harbor can be used as a port for direct cross-strait shipping links, saying that it is well-suited for the purpose and is geographically nearest to the mainland.

He also expressed the hope that the central government would make good on its promises to establish an international airport in central Taiwan, upgrade Taichung into a municipality under the direct jurisdiction of the Cabinet and establish the third science-based industrial park there.

Professor Chang Wan-tung of Fujen Catholic University said that the government's mainland policy was formulated based on facts as understood two decades ago, but Taiwan's security should be built on economics, not only on the concept of a possible military confrontation with China.

Yunlin County planning official Hsu Ming-wen said that the county's Maioliao Harbor has the advantages of being a deep-water port and superb facilities, and if the government does not want to open direct trade immediately, then it can designate Maioliao as a special economic zone and use it as the basis for the development of Taiwan's traditional industries.

DOC.HEADLINE: TYPHOON TORAJI CLAIMS 93 LIVES, 127 PEOPLE MISSING AS OF SUNDAY

TEXT.P: Typhoon Toraji, which ravaged Taiwan July 29-30 has left 93 people dead, 127 missing and 189 injured as of 3:30 p.m. Sunday, according to statistics compiled by the Anti-Disaster Center of the Central Government.
The center said that Typhoon Toraji, the seventh-most lethal typhoon since 1958, caused NT$6.63 billion in agricultural and livestock losses.
The casualties in counties and cities were broken down as follows: --Hualien County: 31 killed, 16 missing and 16 injured.
--Nantou County: 29 killed, 97 missing and 172 wounded.
--Miaoli County: six killed and five missing.
--Taichung County: 13 killed, four missing and one injured.
--Taichung City: five killed and two missing.
--Changhwa County: eight killed, six of whom were unidentified, and one missing.
--Yunlin County: one killed and one missing.
--Pingtung County: one missing.

Regarding electricity, telecommunications and water supply, a total of 4,418 households in Taiwan are without power, mostly in Nantou County. A total of 3,200 homes have had phone service affected, mainly in Nantou County and 60 base stations for mobile phones have not yet been repaired. A total of 7,820 households around Taiwan have no water supply.

As of Sunday, the armed forces of the ROC have dispatched 26,562 soldiers and 1,176 various vehicles to help Toraji's victims with rehabilitation work. Helicopters from the ROC Air Force and the army and police have rescued 533, searched for 384 and transported 13,940 kilograms of relief goods to the typhoon-stricken areas.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT GROUP HOPES TO DIVERT CAMPAIGN FUNDS TO HELP CHILDREN AFFECTED BY TORAJI

TEXT.P: A legislator of the opposition Kuomintang said Sunday that he and some of his colleagues hope to convince KMT candidates in the year-end elections to divert advertising funds to help children affected by Typhoon Toraji.

Legislator Hsu Chung-hsiung said that he and his colleagues, including Ting Shou-chung, Hung Hsiu-chu, Pang Wei-kang, Hsu Shu-po and Tsai Ling-lan, want candidates to save some of the ad money that would be spent and instead put it toward the educations and living expenses of children affected by the recent deadly typhoon.
The legislators suggested that the funds could be used to educate the children until they graduated from college at age 22.

Hsu said that they will ask that the KMT actively take part in the campaign when the party convenes a regular meeting of the KMT Central Standing Committee Wednesday. Hsu said that the hope was that the effort could be supported by the KMT to make a positive impact on society.

He also urged a rigorous review of the current disaster rescue system, adding that he will suggest that the KMT push the ruling Democratic Progressive Party to increase personnel and the budget for disaster rescue operations.
Typhoon Toraji has left 93 people dead and caused severe property damage, mainly in Nantou County in central Taiwan and Hualien County in eastern Taiwan after it swept across Taiwan July 29-30.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC TO SIGN JUDICIAL ASSISTANCE PACT WITH UNITED STATES

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Justice (MOJ) said Sunday that if all goes well, the Republic of China will sign a judicial assistance agreement with the United States to jointly combat crime.

Justice officials noted that after years of effort, the negotiations between the ROC and the United States finally bore fruit last week, with the negotiating team from the Ministry of Justice reaching a consensus on bilateral judicial assistance with their U.S. counterparts.
They said that after the return of the team, the ROC and the United States will first initial the agreement and then formally sign it after the signing of a memorandum of understanding.

It has been learned that the agreement will possibly cover an anti-drug campaign, a cooperation project to identify the sources of the drugs, a framework to map out the regulations governing the control of drug delivery and undercover investigations, the establishment of a system for tracking large amounts of money transactions and the purchase of X-ray machines to inspect shipping containers.

The officials said that past MOJ heads, including Liao Cheng-hao, Cheng Chung-mo, Yeh Chin-feng and even the current Justice Minister, Cheng Ding-nan, have actively promoted the signing of the agreement, but the breakthrough only came last week.

The officials noted that after the United States listed Taiwan as a major drug transshipment center in 1995, all MOJ heads have stressed to the United States that Taiwan has been doing all it could to stop the flow of illegal drugs into and through the country.

The MOJ's teams, joined by officials from the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, Ministry of Finance, and the Ministry of the Interior have traveled to the United States to explain Taiwan's anti-drug efforts and its achievements.

The MOJ was elated when it learned that the United States had removed Taiwan from the list of drug transshipment countries early this year and has actively worked toward the signing of the judicial assistance agreement.

DOC.HEADLINE: US ENERGY CONSULTANT OFFERS RECOMMENDATIONS FOR NUCLEAR WASTE DISPOSAL

TEXT.P: A former U.S. energy official Sunday recommended that Taiwan use an international conference to determine where to dispose of its nuclear waste.

Ernest J. Moniz, former undersecretary of the Department of Energy under the Clinton administration, told Taiwan's Central News Agency July 31 in an interview in Taipei that an international conference might help the island find a suitable place to store its nuclear waste.
Moniz made the recommendation after Taiwan was stymied in its negotiations to ship its nuclear waste to North Korea or Russia for permanent storage.
Taiwan's Taiwan Power Company, which runs the island's three nuclear plants, has contacted Moscow and Pyongyang over the possibility of having them keep the company's radioactive waste.

Pyongyang agreed to accept Taiwan's nuclear waste in return for cash but this was scuttled because of strong objections from Seoul, which blamed Taiwan for trying to make the Korean Peninsula into its nuclear waste dumping site.
Taiwan's contact with Moscow looks more promising after Moscow enacted a law in June to allow the government to dispose of processed nuclear waste from other states.
Moniz, now a professor at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, has been recruited as a government adviser to Taiwan on science and technology.

He said Washington will not interfere with Taiwan's decision where to dispose of its nuclear waste but he said that Washington has always been opposed to the export of highly radioactive nuclear waste out of concerns that it might be re-processed into materials for nuclear weapons.
