An international conference bringing together related parties such as Taiwan, Japan, South and North Korea, mainland China, Russia and the United States would be an ideal forum to help Taiwan find a place to dispose of its nuclear waste, Moniz said.
Moniz arrived in Taiwan last week to attend an energy conference between July 31 and Aug. 2 in his capacity as the government's adviser.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI MAYOR HEADS TO KUALA LUMPUR, SEOUL, AND FUKUOKA

TEXT.P: Taipei City Mayor Ma Ying-jeou headed for Kuala Lumpur Sunday morning on the first leg of a 10-day visit to three Asian cities.
During his stay in Kuala Lumpur, Ma will deliver a speech to a group of Malaysian alumni of Taiwan schools.
Ethnic Chinese in Malaysia are reportedly excited to welcome Ma -- so much so that more than a thousand tickets to Ma's speech were long ago sold out.

Ma is scheduled to fly on to Seoul from Kuala Lumpur on Aug. 8. He will visit the Seoul City Government to consult and better understand the city's regulations on Internet cafes, computerized administration, garbage collection and resources recycling operations.
He is not scheduled to call on South Korean President Kim Dae-jung but might meet him while visiting a ceramics exhibition on Aug. 9.
Ma is expected to arrive in Fukuoka, Japan on Aug. 11 and see for himself why the English-language Asian Weekly magazine has chosen the city as the best Asian city to live in for two years in a row.
The mayor will promote the World Baseball Championship to be held later this year in Taipei at a baseball game in Fukuoka where he will don the uniform of the Chinese Taipei team.
Ma will return to Taiwan on Aug. 15.

DOC.HEADLINE: NATIONAL STRATEGIC RESEARCH CENTER TO BE LAUNCHED IN SEPTEMBER

TEXT.P: Taiwan's first state-financed military think tank, the National Center for Strategic Studies, will be inaugurated on September 1, said National Defense University President Gen. Hsia Ying-tsou Sunday.

The center, to be headed by Maj. Gen. Tseng Chang-jui, the dean of the Strategic Studies Institute under the National Defense University, will serve as a window on military exchanges with the United States, according to military sources.
Two middle-ranking military officers, who have studied at the International Institute for Strategic Studies in Washington and the Atlantic Council of the United States, will staff the new center.
The new center will send one military officer to each of the two U.S. institutes each year for research, said the sources.

DOC.HEADLINE: RECESSION BRINGS CHANCE TO DEVISE STRATEGIES: BUSINESS LEADER

TEXT.P: Now is a good time for the government to work out overall economic strategies for Taiwan's industries at a time when most local businesses have been hit by an economic slump, a prominent leader of the local small business community said Sunday.

Day Sheng-tong, chairman of the Small-and-Medium sized Business Association, told Taiwan's Central News Agency in an exclusive interview that the current recession provides a good opportunity for the government to iron out long-haul economic strategies, rather than short-term tactics, to create a sound environment to help revive Taiwan's industries.
"As long as Taiwan's environment is good enough, local small businesses will be able to take off again," he said.

Talking about the current economic slowdown which has pushed many Taiwan traditional and high-tech businesses to relocate to mainland China, Day attributed the situation to a booming stock market over the past five years. High profits taken out of the local bourse have lured over three million families to invest in the market, resulting in a "marginalization of industries" on the island, he said.

The craze for speculating in the lucrative bourse has made the people forget how Taiwan managed to stand up on its own two feet in the past, Day said. But he stressed optimistically that "Taiwan's future is bright as long as the government works out a long-haul economic development strategy."

Looking back, Day said the exodus of Taiwan's small-and-medium sized businesses to mainland China was the result of inadequate government policies which viewed small businesses -- once the locomotive of the country's economy -- as "sunset industries" in an attempt to better promote high-tech industries. But many Taiwan-based high-tech firms are also undecided whether or not should they move to the mainland now, he noted.

Echoing the opinion of the worldwide renown strategist Michael E. Porter, who visited Taiwan last month, Day said that Taiwan companies have paid too much attention in seeking ways to lower their production costs, which have in turn made them ignore the importance of hammering out strategies for their businesses.

As to the high-profile Economic Development Advisory Conference being sponsored by the government to seek solutions to Taiwan's sluggish economy, Day said the most import task for the conference is to draw up "strategies" rather than "tactics," and called for broad vision to achieve the objective.

In the face of fierce competition from mainland China, which boasts of a cheap labor force, the small business leader called it "unfair competition" and urged the government and local businesses to reassess Taiwan's position and to travel their own paths.

Regarding the question of how to save Taiwan's small business sector, Day proposed a rating system be set up by the government to help companies deal with banks in case of a loan request based on their personnel quality, research and development abilities, credibility and earnings.

In addition, he contended that the government should also ease its restriction on bank loans to small businesses. "Taiwan's small businesses are tenacious and flexible, and they will manage to stand on their feet again if the government is capable of creating a financially loose climate for them," he concluded.

DOC.HEADLINE: HELICOPTER DELIVERING RELIEF SUPPLIES MAKES FORCED LANDING
DOC.DATELINE: Taichung, central Taiwan, Aug. 5 (CNA) (By Elisa Kao)

TEXT.P: A helicopter from the army's airborne brigade made a forced landing Sunday in a grape-growing area in Taichung County while transporting supplies to victims of Typhoon Toraji.

Observers suspect mechanical failure was the cause of the forced landing. The carriage of the UH-1H helicopter was slightly damaged in the incident. The three personnel aboard were unharmed. The actual cause of the accident is under investigation by the military.

The accident occurred at 11:08 a.m. when the helicopter was returning to the 10th Field Corps in Taichung after completing its fifth transport mission Sunday among various villages in Nantou County, which were hard hit by Typhoon Toraji July 29-30.
Typhoon Toraji, the 7th-most lethal to hit Taiwan since 1958, has so far claimed 93 lives as of Sunday and left 127 people missing.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, Aug. 6, or the 17th day of the sixth month of the Year of the Snake according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1806: The Holy Roman Empire ends when Francis II abdicates. He later becomes Francis I, emperor of Austria.
1825: Bolivia becomes an independent republic after being ruled by the Spanish for nearly 300 years.
1881: Alexander Flemming, Scottish scientist who discovered penicillin at St. Mary's Hospital in London in 1928, is born. He won the 1945 Nobel Prize for medicine with Howard Florey and Ernest Chain.
1890: The electric chair is used for the first time to execute a convicted murderer, with William Kemmler being executing at Auburn Prison in New York.
1911: Lucille Ball, American actress and comedienne who starred in the series "I Love Lucy," is born.
1914: Yuan Shih-kai, who forced China's congress to elect him president on Oct. 10, 1913, declares China's neutrality in World War I.
1926: Gertrude Ederle, American sports star and 1924 Olympic gold medalist, completes the 35 miles (56 kilometers) that separate Cap Gris-Nez and Dover in 14 hours 31 minutes, becoming the first woman to swim the English Channel.
1932: The first international film festival is opened in Venice, with 29 films from the United States, Britain, France, Germany, the Soviet Union and Italy.
1933: Feng Yu-hsiang, an army general who revolted at Kalgan Pass (Changkiakow) in Chahar province on May 28, announces his revolt has failed.
1945: An atomic bomb, dubbed "Little Boy," is released by a U.S. Air Force B-29, known as the "Enola Gay," above the central Japanese city of Hiroshima, killing more than 90,000 people and injuring at least 9,000 others.
1949: At the invitation of Korean President Syngman Rhee, President Chiang Kai-shek flies to Chinhae, Korea, to discuss the formation of a Pacific alliance.
1952: The ROC Executive Yuan approves the designation of Sept. 28, instead of Aug. 27, as the birthday of Confucius, the great sage and teacher who has had a far-reaching influence on Chinese philosophy and culture.
1962: Jamaica becomes independent after 307 years of British rule.
1962: Film star Marilyn Monroe is found dead in the bedroom of her Hollywood home. She was 36.
1962: Ugandan dictator Idi Amin throws 50,000 Asians out of Uganda.
1971: British sailor Chay Blyth completes his solo non-stop 48,000-kilometer round-the-world voyage in 292 days on his 18-meter, all-steel ketch "British Steel."
1973: The second National Reconstruction Seminar opens in Taipei, with some 180 Chinese scholars attending.
1973: A fully automatic information handling system, the most modern in Southeast Asia, is inaugurated at Taipei's International Airport.
1978: Pope Paul VI, who succeeded John XXIII in 1963, dies at the age of 80.
1978: President Chiang Ching-kuo points out at an annual military conference that "we shall rely on ourselves in our fight against communism."
1990: The United Nations Security Council votes 13-0 to ban all trade with Iraq, except for medicine and some food for humanitarian relief, after the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait.
1991: A Republic of China-Fiji technological cooperation agreement is signed during Fijian Prime Minister Ratu Sir Kamisese Mara's visit to Taipei.
1997: A Korean Airlines Boeing 747-300 passenger plane crashes in a mountainous area of Guam, killing 254 people on board. There were only 20 survivors.
1999: The Philippine government proposes that Taipei and Manila either renegotiate their aviation accord or that air carriers from both countries enter into a commercial agreement so as to avoid the cessation of direct Taipei-Manila air services.
2000: One hundred couples across Taiwan who have been married for 60 years celebrate their diamond wedding anniversary on Chinese Valentine's Day.
2000: Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation urges its mainland counterpart, the Association for Relations across the Taiwan Strait, to help resolve a travel dispute that has arisen between the two sides of Taiwan Strait.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "By welcoming them when they come and giving them protection when they go, commending what is good in them and making allowance for their ignorance: that is how the ruler shows tenderness to strangers from far countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: POLL FINDS INCUMBENT TAIPEI MAGISTRATE OUTSHINES OTHER HOPEFULS

TEXT.P: While the opposition camp is still squabbling over who should represent it in the year-end election for Taipei county chief, an opinion poll found that incumbent Taipei Magistrate Su Chen-chang outshines any possible opposition hopefuls.

The telephone poll of 938 eligible Taipei county voters conducted by the mass-circulation Chinese-language United Daily News (UDN) Sunday evening found that 33 percent of the respondents voiced their support for Su's reelection bid.

The poll results released Monday also show that both the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) nominee, Lin Jih-jia, and the tiny opposition New Party (NP)-recommended Wang Chien-hsien each received the support of 12 percent of those surveyed, while opposition People First Party (PFP) candidate Chin Chin-sheng received 5 percent.
According to the poll, 38 percent of Taipei county voters have not yet decided for whom they will vote in the election scheduled for December.

Asked about their party affiliation, 19 percent said they incline to supporting the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP); 18 percent said they support the PFP; 15 percent said they back the KMT; 4 percent said they are NP supporters; and 44 percent said they have no evident party preferences.
A cross-analysis of poll results show that as the PFP just announced its candidate Thursday, its supporters remain far divided over their possible support target.

Only 23 PFP supporters said they would vote for the party's nominee, Chin Chin-sheng, while 25 percent said they prefer to back NP-recommended Wang Chien-hsien; 14 percent said they would support sitting Magistrate Su; 12 percent said they would support the KMT's Lin; and 26 percent said they have not yet made a decision.

Among KMT supporters, 34 percent remain undecided; 31 percent said they support the party's standard-bearer Lin; 18 percent said they prefer to back the DPP's Su; 15 percent support the NP's Wang; and only 1 percent gave a thumbs-up to the PFP's Chin.

In contrast, the poll found that although the number of NP supporters is limited, they unanimously support Wang. DPP supporters are also very united, demonstrating almost unanimous support for Su's reelection bid, according to the survey.

Of those surveyed who have no special party affiliation, 30 percent voiced their support for the sitting magistrate, while none of the three other hopefuls could secure a support rate of more than 10 percent.

If the year-end election turns out to be a three-way race among Su, Lin, and Chin, the survey results show that Su would still enjoy a large lead over his KMT and PFP competitors. In a three-way race scenario, 38 percent said they would vote for Su, 17 percent said they would back Lin and 12 percent said they would cast their ballots for Chin.

Even if the three opposition parties could finally field a common candidate, the poll found that none of the possible standard-bearers could compete with Su. In this scenario, Wang would be Su's closest competitor, gaining 30 percent of the vote to Su's 48 percent. In a race between Su and Lin, Su would grab 45 percent of the vote to Lin's 26 percent, while in Su-Chin race, the result would be 53 percent to 20 percent in favor of Su.

The UDN poll also found that 74 percent of the opposition camp supporters look forward to seeing the three opposition parties jointly field a common candidate, while only 21 percent said they hope to see each party nominate its own candidate.

Meanwhile, 76 percent of opposition camp supporters gave a thumbs-up to the proposal that a public opinion poll be held to decide who should represent the opposition camp in the year-end race for the Taipei County Government's top post, while 19 percent said they oppose such a proposal.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN WELCOMES FORMER U.S. PRESIDENT CLINTON TO VISIT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bien expressed his welcome Monday to former President Bill Clinton for his forthcoming visit to Taiwan in mid-September.
President Chen is expected to meet with Clinton and exchange views on politics, administrative management and other issues of mutual concern, officials from the Presidential Office said.

As one of the prestigious heads of state who has made exceptional contributions to the global community, Clinton will be accorded with "high-grade" hospitality during his visit in Taiwan, the officials added.

Clinton, who had visited Taiwan several times when he was governor of the U.S. state of Arkansas, is scheduled to visit Taiwan in mid-September at the invitation of the United Daily News (UDN), the Taipei-based Chinese-language newspaper reported Monday.

During his stay, Clinton, who served as the president of the United States for two terms between 1993 and 2001, is mainly scheduled to attend activities marking the 50th anniversary celebration of the founding of the UDN. He will also meet with other political and economic leaders in Taiwan for talks.
Clinton is also scheduled to deliver a speech during his visit and to meet with Taiwan youths for a seminar, the daily newspaper said.

Currently the youngest retired president of the United States, Clinton, 55, has been active on the public stage in what is seen to be an effort to recreate the "second spring" of his political career, local political observers said.

His new office located in New York's Harlem District was inaugurated July 30. On Aug. 3, he officiated at a ceremony in his home state of Arkansas, unveiling the plan to build the most expensive "presidential library" in U.S. history.
His is also currently chairman of the board of the International AIDS Trust.

Clinton will be the third former political leader of a major nation to accept an invitation by the UDN group to tour and lecture in Taiwan, following similar visits by former British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher and former Soviet Union President Mikhail Gorbachev.

After serving five consecutive terms as governor of Arkansas, Clinton, at the age of 46, beat incumbent President George Bush in the 1992 U.S. presidential election, giving the Democrats control of the White House for the first time in 12 years.
He was re-elected in 1997, making him the first Democrat to be re-elected as U.S. president in over 50 years.

During the eight years that Clinton was in office, the United States' economy reached its highest level of prosperity in 30 years and recorded the single longest period of uninterrupted growth in the history of the country.

In international affairs, Clinton helped shape a new global order in the post-Cold War era. By January 2001, when Clinton's second-term came to an end, volatile areas, including the Balkans, Northern Ireland, the Korean Peninsula, and the Middle East, had all witnessed successful diplomatic breakthroughs of one form or another following the "intervention" of Clinton.
On cross-strait relations, Clinton had tried his utmost to establish a security framework maintaining stability in the Taiwan Strait.
He followed an "engagement" policy toward mainland China in the hope that by conducting "strategic dialogue," the United States could exert a positive influence on the leadership in Beijing.

Although he personally spelled out the "Three Nos" statement concerning cross-strait relations that was not warmly received in Taiwan, he stressed throughout both his terms in office that "any formula or model" for resolving cross-strait disputes must first gain the consent of the people of Taiwan.

The "Three Nos" formulation denotes no support for Taiwan independence, no support for "two Chinas" or "one China, one Taiwan," and no support for Taiwan membership in international organizations where statehood is required.
Clinton's wife, Hillary Rodham Clinton, currently a senator for New York State, and his only daughter, Chelsea, will not be accompanying him on his forthcoming visit to Taiwan.

Clinton will be the third former U.S. president to visit Taiwan since the Republic of China severed formal diplomatic relations with the United States in 1979, following visits in the past by Gerald Ford and Jimmy Carter.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. SENATE FOREIGN RELATIONS COMMITTEE CHAIR VISITS TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The new chairman of the U.S. Senate Foreign Relations Committee arrived in Taipei Monday for a whirlwind overnight visit.

Sen. Joseph Biden (D.-Del.) was greeted at the airport by Republic of China Vice Foreign Minister Wu Tzu-dan and Raymond Burghardt, director of the Taipei Office of the American Institute in Taiwan, which represents U.S. interests in the ROC in the absence of formal diplomatic ties.

Taiwan is the first leg of Biden's first overseas trip since he replaced Sen. Jesse Helms (R-N.C.), one of Taiwan's strongest supporters and a harsh critic of mainland China, as head of the powerful Senate Foreign Relations Committee in early June.

Biden, heading a delegation of senators from both the Democratic Party and the Republican Party, will leave Taipei Tuesday morning to continue his current four-leg visit which will also take him to mainland China, North Korea and South Korea.
Biden and other delegation members will exchange views with senior officials of the four countries on U.S. national security-related strategic issues.

Biden is scheduled to meet with President Chen Shui-bian at 4 p.m. and will hold a news conference at the Grand Formosa Regent Hotel Monday evening. Foreign Minister Tien Hung-mao will host a dinner in honor of Biden and other visiting U.S. senators, including Sen. Paul Sarbanes, a Maryland Democrat; Sen. Arlen Specter, a Pennsylvania Republican; and Sen. Fred Thompson, a Tennessee Republican.

On the thorny issues between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, Biden said prior to his departure for his current East Asian trip that the "strategic ambiguity" approach adopted by successive U.S. administrations over the past two decades has actually implied two clear-cut messages -- Taiwan should not expect U.S. protection if it moves toward de jure independence and anything may happen if mainland China uses force against Taiwan.

Biden further said U.S. President George W. Bush's previous remark that the United States would do whatever it can to help defend Taiwan had gone beyond the U.S. security commitment to Taiwan. The Senate heavyweight said he does not think that the U.S. government is likely to issue a similar kind of statement in the future regarding cross-strait relations.

In a recent interview with Reuters, Biden said he was convinced that peaceful cross-strait integration is the ultimate goal of the United States and both sides of the Taiwan Strait. In his view, Biden said, the United States should neither encourage Taiwan independence nor let mainland China use force or military intimidation to shorten the process of cross-strait integration.
This is Biden's first visit to Taiwan since he became a senator in 1973.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHILD HELPS OPERATE EXCAVATOR IN POST-TYPHOON CLEANUP
DOC.DATELINE: Hualien, eastern Taiwan, Aug. 6 (CNA) (By Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: One can hardly believe that a child as young as seven years old, an age when most boys are playing with toy tractors, is actually operating a real excavator like a handyman in ravaged post-typhoon Hualien County.

Tsai Ming-chin was operating his father's excavator Sunday in a riverside area where people are still trying to unearth the bodies of those who were declared missing and are now believed to be dead, seven days after Typhoon Toraji swept across the island July 29-30.

Little Ming-chin and his father Tsai Lai's own home was destroyed by the devastation wrought by Typhoon Toraji. As of Monday, 99 people were confirmed killed as a result of the typhoon, while 116 others were still unaccounted for. Besides the heavy human casualties, some NT$7.7 billion (US$222.54 million) worth of losses to agriculture was caused by Toraji.
Ming-chin, who learned how to drive mechanical diggers before he could walk, was allowed to operate a real excavator alone by the age of five.
Now an "efficient" handyman, Ming-chin has helped his father carry out cleanup work in the aftermath of the typhoon. "Dad would allow me to do it when he was too busy to operate one," he said.

Hualien County and Nantou County were the two areas hardest hit by Toraji, which wreaked havoc in eastern and central Taiwan with strong winds and torrential rains that caused devastating floods, landslides and mudslides that buried people, washed away houses, destroyed roads and bridges, and ruined fields and plantations.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Shares prices opened low and closed even lower on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) on Monday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 59.95 points to close at 4,470.73.

Affected by a decline in U.S. stock prices, the bourse opened at 4,507.84 and continued to go down due to profit-taking selling pressure. The bourse fluctuated between 4,527.75 and 4,451.04 during trading.

A total of 1.61 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$40.7 billion (US$1.18 billion), a decrease from the previous trading session which saw 2.74 billion stocks change hands on a market turnover of NT$71.57 billion (US$2.07 billion).

Only two of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with construction stocks moving up the most at 1.1 percent, followed by pulp and paper issues at 0.1 percent. Foodstuff shares remained unchanged.

The other major categories posted losses, with electrical shares moving down the most at 1.6 percent, followed by bank and insurance stocks at 1.4 percent, textile issues at 1.3 percent, plastics and chemical stocks at 1 percent, and cement stocks at 0.3 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 298 to 204, with 74 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: LARGEST-EVER BIOSCIENCE CONFERENCE IN TAIWAN OPENS

TEXT.P: The largest-ever conference in Taiwan on bioscience opened Monday with more than 1,000 ethnic Chinese scientists gathered for the five-day meeting.

The international symposium, with a theme of "Frontiers of biotechnology and biomedical science in the new millennium," is jointly sponsored by Academia Sinica, the National Health Research Institute (NHRI) and the Society of Chinese Bioscientists in America.
President Chen Shui-bian spoke at the opening ceremony at Academia Sinica, the highest research institute in Taiwan, and reaffirmed the government's determination to develop bioscience.

The president said that the government has planned to set up a bioscience industrial park in Chunan, Miaoli County. The park will be under the administration of the nearby Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park.
He also expressed the hope that more such conferences will be held in Taiwan to upgrade bioscientific research and development and increase international cooperation in the field.

Ho I-kan, president of the Society of Chinese Bioscientists in America, said that the society has rallied ethnic Chinese scholars and experts living in the United States, Canada and other parts of the world to make the event the largest-ever gathering in Taiwan of top-notch ethnic Chinese in the biomedical field.
He said that the conference is especially significant as the government is actively promoting bioscientific technology to help further the island's economic transformation.

Academia Sinica President Lee Yuan-tseh said that Taiwan has excelled in high-tech industries over the past years, but will face more challenges ahead with the dawning of bioscientific technology. He expressed the hope that everyone will work harder to meet the challenges of the future.

NHRI President Wu Cheng-wen also said that academic research institutes will play major roles in bioscientific competition in the new century and his institute plans to target certain biomedical technologies that Taiwan may be able to enjoy an advantage in, such as finding the carcinogens of liver cancer and oral cancer common in Taiwan.

Participants in the conference will include Steven Chu, a 1997 Nobel laureate in physics; David Ho, who pioneered a drug cocktail treatment to combat AIDS; and more than 1,000 bioscientists from the United States, Canada, Britain, Germany, Switzerland, Spain, Australia, Japan, Hong Kong, Singapore and mainland China.
Chu will give a lecture on Aug. 9 to share his research with Taiwan people. He will speak on "laser cooling and trapping," -- the topic that won him the Nobel Prize.
Participants will deliver over 170 speeches and read 250 papers over the next few days.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NOT ENTERING DEFLATIONARY PERIOD: OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: The government is backing away from the word "deflation" even though economic figures indicate that commodity prices growth has shown month-on-month drops in the past several months, a government official said Monday.

Deflation would come about as the result of months of long downturns in price inflation and reduced demand for imports and domestic demand for exportable goods, said Chen Chang-hsiung, a bureau chief with the Cabinet-level Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS).

The slide in Taiwan's consumer prices diminished in July while the total amount of consumption by the private sector has not noticeably dropped from similar levels of the same month of the previous year, indicating that it is still too early to say that deflation is setting in, Chen said.
According to the latest GDBAS tallies, Taiwan's consumer prices edged up 0.11 percent in July from the year-earlier level as rises in tuition costs offset falls in food prices.
The consumer price index (CPI) was down 0.30 percent to 103.41 from a month earlier largely due to lower prices for clothes and garments, the GDBAS statistics indicated.
The July wholesale price index fell 0.22 percent to 97.27 from a year earlier but was up 0.20 percent month-on-month, according to the DGBAS tallies.

Chen noted that unless international oil prices should surge substantially in the next few months, the rise and fall of the island's consumer prices will not be the focus of economic issues this year.
Meanwhile, average prices for imports declined in July by 10.20 percent, marking the eighth monthly reduction in a row and the largest monthly drop since January 1999.
The July average price for exports also fell, by 9.25 percent, marking nine consecutive months of decline and the largest since May 1999.

DOC.HEADLINE: OBSERVERS SEE CROSS-TAIWAN STRAIT STOCK MARKET INTERACTIONS
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 6 (CNA) (By Deborah Kuo) (By Lillian Lin)

TEXT.P: Taipei, Aug. 6 (CNA): Observers of Taiwan's stock market said Monday that arbitrageurs were taking advantage of the agio by operating in the stock markets on both sides of the Taiwan Strait.

Ting Hsueh-wen, general manager of Apollo Investment Trust, said that the authorities should be alert to the consequences of heavy cash flows and interactions of the stock markets in Taipei, Shanghai and Shengzhen.

Ting said that Taiwan's foreign exchange deposits in the past week registered a record high, though the domestic money supply was declining. Taiwan's foreign exchange market and the stock market have been closely interrelated and it has been especially obvious during the past week when stock prices were on the rise in the wake of a New Taiwan dollar appreciation, he added.
Taiwan's stock market has rebounded since late July, with the weighted index climbing from around 4,000 points in late July to 4,530.68 points on Aug. 3.

While stock prices in Taiwan were going up, the stock markets in mainland China were declining. The general index of Shanghai B shares, for instance, dropped from 207 points on July 18 to 159 points on Aug. 3, down 30 percent.

Huang Chih-lung, an analyst from Capital Securities, said that it was a logical assumption that capital flows manipulated by arbitrageurs have caused stock prices to rise and fall on both sides of the Taiwan Strait.

Since the China Securities Regulatory Commission announced on Feb. 19, 2001 to open B shares of the Shanghai and Shengzhen stock markets to Chinese investors in two stages, the general index of Shanghai B shares rose from 80 points at the end of February to 240 points in late May, and the index of Shengzhen B shares from 130 points in late February to 450 points in late May.

In the meantime, the weighted index of the Taiwan Stock Market has continued to decline since late March from some 5,833.88 points on March 29 to 4136.39 points on July 25. The market has been gradually recovering.

Ting of the Apollo Investment Trust said that the waxing and waning phenomena happens to Taipei as well as the Shanghai and Shenzhen stock markets in times of big fluctuations. The "hot money" flowing between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait is growing like a snowball and its impact on the stock market will continue to grow, he added.

The government should pay special attention to the capital flows in the stock market as well as the foreign exchange market to prevent a drastic shrinkage of the stock market when the arbitrageurs withdraw their "hot money," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR UP ON TAIPEI FOREX MARKET

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar appreciated NT$0.019 against the greenback on the Taipei foreign exchange market Monday, closing at NT$34.650.
The local currency opened Monday at NT$34.606 and was traded between NT$34.498 and US$34.650.
Interbank U.S. dollar trading totaled US$562 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: OFFICIAL SAYS TAIWAN'S SEMICONDUCTOR FOUNDRIES MUST ADVANCE

TEXT.P: Taiwan's semiconductor foundries must shift from the production of 8-inch wafers to 12-inch wafers to maintain their competitiveness in the international market, an industrial official said Monday.

Shih Yen-hsiang, director-general of the Industrial Development Bureau, said that after Taiwan's two leading semiconductor foundries -- Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Corp. (TSMC) and United Microelectronics Corp., announced that they were going to concentrate on 12-inch wafer manufacturing, Macronix International and Winbond Electronics also decided to invest in 12-inch wafer manufacturing plants.
Utility rates of the manufacturers' 8-inch production facilities have been low in the past months due to the sluggish international market, Shih said.

Gloomy market forecasts for upstream manufacturing has caused business declines for the 48 wafer packaging plants and 37 testing factories in Taiwan, according to the Industrial Technology Research Institute (ITRI).

A ITRI analysis shows that output of the semiconductor industry around the world in 2001 will decline by 17 percent from last year. Taiwan's semiconductor sector's production value this year is estimated to reach NT$616.2 billion, down 13 percent from the total of NT$714.4 billion last year.

Accounting for 34 percent of the world market share, Taiwan's semiconductor packaging and testing factories grossed NT$116.6 billion in production value last year. The ITRI analysis indicates that the production value of the packaging sector will drop by 11.1 percent from the total of NT$83.3 billion last year, and the testing sector will drop by 15.5 percent from last year's NT$32.8 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: RESTRICTIONS ON SECURITIES MARKET TO EASE FURTHER: FINANCE MINISTER

TEXT.P: Minister of Finance Yen Ching-chang said Monday that in view of Taiwan's impending entry in the World Trade Organization (WHO), opening the securities and financial markets must progress rapidly.
Yen made the remarks at a seminar on the policies of merging securities brokerages and financing companies, investment trust and consultant companies Monday.

Yen said that as of the end of June, Taiwan securities brokerages and securities companies totaled 168, investment trust and investment consultant companies totaled 261, and the number of those who have opened accounts in the stock market totaled 12 million. Turnover on the Taiwan stock market totaled NT$9,829.4 billion in the six months, while turnover on the over-the-counter market totaled around NT$1,453.1 billion during the same period.

Yen said that he believed the saturation of financial institutions has resulted in fierce competition among the institutions, and that he wants to improve the investment climate to upgrade the competitiveness of Taiwan's financial institutes so that they can remain strong and compete in the international arena.

The finance ministry has actively tried several measurers to promote the reforms of the securities market, Yen said, including a bid to upgrade the ratio of institutional investors in the securities market, adding that the number of individual investors in the securities market now accounts for as much as 82 percent.
Yen noted that with such a high percentage, the Taiwan securities market has become volatile and it is necessary that the government do more to attract additional institutional investors.
He also spoke of the easing of restrictions on foreign investors in Taiwan's securities market to facilitate its internationalization.

He noted that the ceiling allowed for a single foreign institutional investor to invest in the Taiwan securities market has been adjusted upwards to US$2 billion from US$1.1 billion. The restrictions on Taiwan's listed stocks have also been lifted since this year.

Yen said that the daily trading hours of the stock market have been lengthened to four and a half hours from three hours on weekdays and the stock market is closed on Saturdays in line with the international standards.

Yen said that with WTO entry, the urgent task for the government will be to help securities firms to prepare and cope with overall changes. He also said that financial institutions must look for their own directions in the increasingly fierce competitive environment.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINESE TAIPEI TO REPRESENT ASIAN-PACIFIC REGION IN U.S. PONY BASEBALL
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Aug. 6 (CNA) (By Mike Chang and Ed Chen)

TEXT.P: The Chinese Taipei junior league baseball team Monday won the right to represent the Asian-Pacific region to vie for the championship of the Pony League in the U.S. Pony Baseball Tournament.

The Chinese Taipei team, which is made up of Chungshan Junior School students from Taichung City, defeated the South Korean team 6-2 in the final of the Asia-Pacific Junior Baseball Championship held in Hokkaido. The win left the team undefeated among the participating nations of South Korea, Japan and Taiwan.
The Chinese Taipei team trounced the hosts, Sapporo, 11-1 Aug. 4 and the Japan's national team 4-2 Aug. 5 at the competition held at the Sapporo Mapu Stadium in Hokkaido, Japan.

This was the second time that the Chinese Taipei team has won the right to represent the Asian-Pacific region in the U.S. Pony Baseball Tournament. The Chinese Taipei team captured the title at the finals held in the United States last year.
The organizing committee Asian-Pacific event has subsidized the Chinese Taipei team with US$2,000 to help it compete in the United States.

DOC.HEADLINE: SCHOLARS ADVOCATE GENETIC STUDY OF DISEASES COMMON AMONG CHINESE

TEXT.P: Bioscientists in major Chinese communities should focus on genetic research related to certain diseases commonly seen among Chinese people as well as on possible herbal treatments for those ailments, a senior health official said Monday.

Wu Cheng-wen, head of the National Health Research Institute (NHRI), said at a seminar on biotechnology and biomedical science that none of the 250 new anti-cancer drugs now being tested and developed in the international community are related to liver cancer, one of the top killers in Chinese societies.
As liver cancer is not prevalent in Western countries, Wu said, American and European researchers are generally not keen on liver cancer-related study.

Against this backdrop, Wu said, the four major Chinese communities -- Taiwan, mainland China, Hong Kong and Singapore -- should pool their wisdom and resources in doing research in this field. Nasopharyngeal cancer is also a suitable research subject for Chinese bioscientists, he added.

In addition, Wu said the results of genetic and basic medicine research in Chinese communities should be applied to medical engineering research for production of competitive medical equipment and relevant products.

Speaking on the same occasion, Cheng Yung-chi, an academician of the Academia Sinica, Taiwan's highest research institute, said the ongoing seminar is expected to introduce the results of Taiwan's biotechnology research to the world and provide a forum for exchanges of research achievements of all Chinese societies.

"By so doing, we hope to attract foreign investment in relevant research programs in Taiwan," said Cheng, also a noted traditional Chinese and herbal medicine researcher at Yale University in the United States.
Noting that the 21st century will be a century of "traditional Chinese medicine," Cheng said herbal medicine should be a priority research topic for major Chinese societies.
Cheng said he is convinced that herbal medicine would contribute to the treatment of hepatitis, diabetes and aging-related diseases as the ancient Chinese left rich legacies in relevant subjects.

Cheng suggested that ethnic Chinese bioscientists pool their energy in studying diseases prevailing or unique in Chinese societies, including finding out what genomes cause those diseases and conducting empirical research on herbal treatment developed by ancient Chinese.

Cheng said he is studying the effects of using traditional Chinese herbal medicine to treat the side-effects of chemotherapy. He said the U.S. Food and Drug Administration has authorized the first-stage of clinical research on the treatment developed by his research team.
David Ho, also a U.S.-based Academia Sinica academician, said he has also launched research programs on using traditional Chinese herbal medicine to treat AIDS.

More than 1,000 biotechnology and biomedical scientists from around the world, including dozens of world-renowned ethnic Chinese bioscientists, are attending the five-day seminar, co-sponsored by the Society of Chinese Bioscientists in America, the Academia Sinica and the NHRI.

The seminar is the largest of its kind ever held in Taiwan. NHRI Director Wu said he hopes the seminar will help inspire more local youths to dedicate themselves to biotechnology and biomedical science research.

Wu said Taiwan needs a large number of bioscientists to sustain its development in bioscience. "Taiwan now has only about 4,000 bioscientists. Such a small work force is not enough to back Taiwan's bid to play an important role in the global bioscience community," he noted.
Wu said he also hopes that the seminar can help boost international cooperation in relevant research fields.

DOC.HEADLINE: CKS INTERNATIONAL AIRPORT OPENS PRAYER ROOMS

TEXT.P: After careful planning, prayer rooms were formally opened at CKS International Airport Monday.

The three adjacent prayer rooms have one room equipped with rush mats for kneeling, another fitted with rows of chairs and still another with mattresses and a mark to show the direction of Mecca, airport officials said.
The officials said that the terminal has taken other terminals as a reference as well as solicited the assistance of a domestic religious group headed by Master Ching Hsin to design the prayer rooms.
The prayer rooms, located in the departure lounge on the third floor of the second terminal, will provide for all passengers and workers at the airport, the officials said.

They said that the room with rush mats will provide for Buddhist and Taoist followers, while the room with chairs will provide for Christians and Catholics, and the room with mattresses and the marker for the direction of Mecca will provide for Muslims.

The officials said that although the equipment in the prayer rooms vary, they are to provide for followers of various beliefs, adding that the equipment will facilitate the followers to practice their religious beliefs, not to bar the entry of other religious followers.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'MINI THREE LINKS' SEE ANOTHER BREAKTHROUGH

TEXT.P: The direct "mini three links" saw yet another breakthrough Monday when a Cambodia-registered freighter shipped a batch of construction materials directly from mainland China to the Republic of China's frontline island of Matsu.

The cargo ship transported construction materials, including doors, windows and granites, from the southeastern mainland Chinese port city of Mawei to Matsu with the permission of governments on both sides of the Taiwan Strait.
The direct cargo shipment followed a three-day visit to Matsu last week by a delegation of mainland Chinese officials in Fujian province where Mawei is located.

In the first seven months following the ROC's Jan.1 opening of its two offshore defense outposts of Kinmen and Matsu for direct trade, mail and shipping links with Fujian's Xiamen and Mawei, commonly known as the "mini three links," mainland authorities only allowed a foreign freighter to ship a boat load of gravel from Mawei to Matsu.

Matsu officials said Monday's event indicates that all the 5,000-plus products Taiwan has allowed to import can be shipped directly from Mawei to Matsu, which lies far closer to mainland China than to Taiwan.
To their knowledge, the officials said, mainland authorities have agreed to gradually ease restrictions on direct Matsu-Mawei cargo shipment.

The officials also quoted Zhang Qiu, a Chinese Communist Party official in Mawei who visited Matsu Aug. 2-4 as having said that the Mawei city government plans to a "Matsu shopping town" to facilitate cross-strait commercial exchanges.

"If this program can be realized, two-way cargo shipment between Matsu and Mawei will make headway, and the ROC government's purpose of boosting economic development in the two frontline islands by opening the 'mini three links' can be substantiated," said a Matsu official.

Mainland China has cold-shouldered the Taiwan-initiated "mini three links." It has not yet allowed regular Kinmen-Xiamen and Matsu-Mawei shipping services and has instead approved such applications on a case-by-case basis. Although many Kinmen residents have made direct voyages to Xiamen, the number of mainland residents making direct sailing to Kinmen or Matsu remain limited. And direct Kinmen-Xiamen and Matsu-Mawei cargo shipments have also been rare over the past seven months.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC TO GRANT 14-DAY LANDING VISAS TO SELECTED HK, MACAU RESIDENTS

TEXT.P: Starting Wednesday, the Republic of China will grant 14-day landing visas to Hong Kong and Macau citizens who have ever been to Taiwan or possess valid entry/exit permits, the Ministry of the Interior (MOI) announced Monday.

MOI officials said prospective Hong Kong and Macau visitors can apply for 14-day landing visas upon their arrival at either Chiang Kai-shek International Airport in northern Taiwan or Kaohsiung International Airport in southern Taiwan.

The new measures, however, will not be applied to those who are working at mainland China's official agencies, MOI officials said, adding that Hong Kong and Macau residents who have been convicted of crime, or may threaten Taiwan's national security and social stability, or had illegally smuggled residents in the two areas to Taiwan, will also be banned from applying landing visas.
The new measures are expected to help attract more Hong Kong and Macau tourists to Taiwan, the officials said.
Upon learning of the ROC government's announcement, the Hong Kong government said it welcomes Taiwan's new measures to facilitate Hong Kong residents' sightseeing trips to the island.

Official tallies show that ROC nationals made more than 2.8 million visits to Hong Kong and Macau last year, making Taiwan the second and third largest source of tourists to Hong Kong and Macau, respectively.
Meanwhile, Hong Kong and Macau residents also made over 295,000 visits to Taiwan in 2000.
All of the figures indicate that Hong Kong and Macau play an important intermediary role in relations and engagement between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAYOR MA SAYS ROC HAS ALREADY DECLARED INDEPENDENCE
DOC.DATELINE: Kuala Lumpur, Aug. 6 (CNA) (By Y.P. Chin and Elisa Kao)

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou said Monday that the Republic of China already declared independence from the Manchu government in 1911, so it does not need to declare independence again.
Ma made the remark in Kuala Lumpur to a group of Malaysian alumni of Taiwan schools. Ma was on the first leg of a 10-day visit to three Asian cities - Kuala Lumpur, Seoul and Fukuoka, Japan.
In response to questions, Ma said the young generation in Taiwan has been strongly influenced by the ideology of independence, which has seriously hurt the feelings of overseas Chinese.
Asked about cross-strait ties, Ma said that as long as Taiwan and mainland China continue their benign exchanges, unification will come at an opportune time.
He added that looking at China's history, the situations of separation constituted 35 percent, while unification took place 65 percent of the time, and both results were achieved by force.

Entering the 21th century, Ma said, people of both sides are enjoying high economic growth and have globalization and democracy in mind, therefore, exchanges between the two sides, either governmental or private, will be close, as they have been over the last 20 years.
He said that although the government has not permitted direct trade, mail and shipping links with mainland China, people are already doing them.
Ma also cited the increasing trade and marriages between the two sides of the Strait, adding that out of bilateral annual trade worth US$30 billion, Taiwan has enjoyed a surplus of US$15 billion.

The mayor noted that with exchanges increasing, there is more understanding and less difference in the life styles between people of both sides of the Strait. When the time is ripe, unification will come. He emphasized that Chinese people have the wisdom to reach that goal.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SOLIDARITY UNION OUTLINES DRAFT OF PARTY PLATFORM

TEXT.P: Party members of the soon-to-be formed Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) outlined a draft of their party platform Monday, vowing to "stabilize Taiwan's politics, revive its economy, cement its democracy and strengthen Taiwan."
TSU leader and former Minister of the Interior Huang Chu-wen made the announcement at the party's Taipei headquarters.

Out of a sense of mission for the country and its people, Huang said the party has pronounced its four principles and 12 party planks as a common goal for the people of Taiwan to strive together for the good of the country.

He said the TSU supports a new round of constitutional amendments and advocates a three-power government systems for Taiwan. As Taiwan has already held direct presidential elections and premiers are appointed by the president without approval by the legislature, the current government structure has effectively tilted toward the presidential system.
"The dual-leadership system is the worst system and the TSU is in favor of a presidential system," Huang said.

As to the question of whether the TSU will field a candidate for the next presidential election slated for 2004, Huang stressed that the TSU hopes to inject a new lease on life into Taiwan's politics to overhaul the country's parliamentary system.

"The establishment and development of the TSU is aimed at projecting a new parliamentary structure and the group has no plans to field any candidate for the next presidential election at present," he explained.

Regarding the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's worry that the formation of the TSU may erode its performance in the December legislative elections, Huang said that his group will not swallow up votes of DPP backers.

Emphasizing that the TSU wishes to help the government stabilize the political situation through winning seats and forging a majority with the ruling party in the 225-member Legislative Yuan, Huang said that "we have the confidence to succeed."

Huang said that the TSU will hold its establishment ceremony Aug. 12 and will not invite leaders of other political parties to attend the event. However, he added, former President Lee Teng-hui will take part in the activity, while President Chen Shui-bian remains undecided whether or not to attend.

Huang also announced a NT$1 million donation for people affected by Typhoon Toriji in central Nantou County. The storm swept through central and eastern Taiwan July 29-30, killing at least 99 and leaving 113 missing.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN IS WORKING WITH SWITZERLAND IN PROBE OF ARMS SALES SCANDAL

TEXT.P: A member of the Control Yuan said Monday Taiwan prosecutors are working with their Swiss counterparts in investigating the alleged scandal surrounding Taiwan's purchase of six warships from France.

Kang Ning-hsiang, who made a trip to France and Switzerland in June in a private capacity to collect evidence, said Taiwan law enforcers have contacted their Switzerland counterparts through his arrangement.

Kang said Swiss law enforcers expressed their willingness to work with Taiwan authorities to investigate the allegations that huge commissions were paid in connection with Taiwan's purchase of six Lafayette-class frigates from France in 1991.
Kang said he conveyed their offer of cooperation to Taiwan's chief prosecutor, Lu Ren-fa, who is personally in charge of the investigation.
As a consequence, Kang said, Taiwan prosecutors contacted Swiss law enforcers on July 29.
With the assistance of foreign law enforcers, Kang said, the probe into the allegations is moving into a new phrase and is being put on the right track.
The six frigates, with a price of 16 billion French francs, is at the center of separate investigations in Taiwan and France.

Taiwan began looking into the case after the mysterious death of a navy captain who was responsible for the navy's weapons procurement. His body was found floating in a harbor in northern Taiwan in 1993.

But the focus of the investigation into the captain's death was shifted away to the alleged kickbacks involved in the deal after former French Foreign Minister Roland Dumas, who approved the sales in 1991, was investigated over charges that he was bribed into giving the go-ahead to the sale.

The allegations mushroomed into a scandal which engulfed many French senior officials and ROC Navy officers after Dumas was sentenced to prison in May this year. The bank accounts where alleged ill-gotten gains are being kept in Switzerland have been frozen since April.

Local prosecutors indicted nine navy officers in July on charges of inflating the warships' price for the benefit of its French builders, but there is no indication thus far that bribery was involved.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN CAN SHRUG OFF DEFLATION WORRIES: CBC OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: Taiwan will not have the problem of deflation, as the annual growth rate of consumer prices rebounded in July and the ratio for August is expected to rise as a result of the effects of Typhoon Toraji, a Central Bank of China (CBC) official said Monday.

Yeh Jung-chao, director-general of the CBC's Economic Research Department, said in a regular news conference that the July consumer price index grew by 0.11 percent year-on-year, with the average growth rate standing at 0.27 percent for the first seven months of this year.

Looking to the future, Yeh predicted that consumer prices in Taiwan will remain stable due to the fact that business conditions will remain lackluster, growth in salary increases will slow and house rentals will not rise.

As the International Monetary Fund specifically defines that only continued falls in consumer prices for two years in a row will be considered as signs of deflation, he said that Taiwan can brush aside worries of possible deflation because it will not encounter such a problem.

The Cabinet-level Directorate-General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics has forecast that Taiwan's consumer price index will increase mildly by 1.21 percent for the whole of 2001, ahead of the average 0.76 percent forecast by local economic research institutes, according to Yeh.
