DOC.HEADLINE: LOCAL FISHING BOAT ON WAY HOME FROM GUAM AFTER BLOODY CONFLICT

TEXT.P: A Pingtung-based fishing boat was reported Monday to be returning to Taiwan under Coast Guard Administration guard from Guam following a bloody altercation aboard the vessel in June that landed Captain Hung Ming-chien in the hospital.

The 49.5-ton "Cheng Man Hsiang No. 1" left Tungkang Harbor Dec. 18 with a crew of 11, including nine mainland Chinese deckhands, heading for fishing grounds near Guam. However, the boat had not been in radio contact with the Tungkang District Fishermen's Association since June 12 this year.
The conflict in which Hung was injured is also reported to have left chief engineer Chen Kun-tsun of Taiwan and a mainland Chinese seaman missing.
Meanwhile, a relative of the shipowner said the owner had traveled to Guam the previous week to help handle the case, but was unable to get any information about the clash.
The shipowner, identified only by his surname of Hung, was scheduled to return to Taiwan Tuesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: COUNTY GOVERNMENT ORDERS EVACUATION OF TYPHOON-AFFECTED AREA
DOC.DATELINE: Nantou, Central Taiwan, Aug. 6 (CNA) (By Elisa Kao)

TEXT.P: The Disaster Contingency Center in Nantou, central Taiwan, announced Monday that the county's Fantzetien district has been declared a "controlled area" and that people in the area should be evacuated.

It became the first area to be declared controlled in the wake of Toraji, the 7th-most lethal typhoon to hit Taiwan since 1958 that had claimed 99 lives as of Monday and left 116 people missing. Nantou is one of the counties hardest-hit by the typhoon that battered Taiwan July 29-30.

Officials of the center said that people are prohibited from entering the mountainous Fantzetien district of Chushan township, where the communication with the outside world has been very difficult since the storm. The center also said the government must provide more helicopters in order to help evacuate the residents still stranded there.
Fifteen people, mostly residents, were evacuated Monday by three military and police helicopters.

DOC.HEADLINE: TYPHOON-INFLICTED AGRICULTURAL LOSSES SOAR TO NT$ 7.7 BILLION

TEXT.P: The losses caused by Typhoon Toraji in the agricultural, forestry, fishery and livestock fields, as well as damage to related facilities, have soared to NT$7.7 billion, a Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture (COA) spokesman said Monday.
Of the figure, damage to agricultural facilities and estimated repair costs account for NT$5.82 billion, with the remainder representing lost crops, fishery products and livestock.
Nantou County suffered the heaviest losses of NT$2.32 billion, followed by Miaoli County with losses of NT$1.13 billion and Hualien County with losses of NT$1.11 billion.
National Taiwan University's experimental forest, located at scenic Chitou, Nantou County, suffered losses of NT$1.28 billion.
Toraji, the sixth typhoon to affect Taiwan this year, had claimed 99 lives in eastern and central Taiwan as of Monday, while 116 others remained unaccounted for.

The Taoist Tienkung Temple in Kaohsiung County's Fengshan donated NT$30 million to a fund set up by the Ministry of the Interior -- the largest single donation -- Monday, bringing the amount to NT$150 million for helping the typhoon victims.
The temple also donated NT$30 million after the devastating earthquake that struck central Taiwan Sept. 21, 1999, to help the displaced residents.

DOC.HEADLINE: VISITING U.S. SENATOR SAYS NO CHANGE IN U.S. POLICY TOWARD TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Joseph R. Biden, Jr., chairman of the powerful U.S. Senate Committee on Foreign Relations, said Monday during a whirlwind visit to Taiwan that there is no change in U.S. policy toward the island.

Biden said at a press conference held after he and his four-member delegation called on Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian that there is "very strong support" in the U.S. Senate -- and the U.S. Congress -- for U.S. commitment to Taiwan in accordance with the 1979 Taiwan Relations Act (TRA).

Biden, who was involved in the drafting of the TRA, which governs U.S. relations with Taiwan after Washington switched diplomatic recognition to Beijing in 1979, was leading a delegation that includes Senator Paul Sarbanes, a Democrat from Maryland, Senator Arlen Specter, a Pennsylvania Republican, and Senator Fred Thompson, a Republican from Tennessee.

Biden said that he has had long discussions with the U.S. State Department and the White House, and that he could assure the people of Taiwan that U.S. President George W. Bush has abided by and will continue to abide by the TRA as the past several U.S. presidents have done.

A liberal Democrat from Delaware who succeeded conservative N. Carolina Republican Jesse Helms in June, Biden said that Beijing should not misunderstand U.S. commitment to Taiwan under the TRA, and neither should Taiwan.

Prior to arriving in Taiwan, he has said that the United States should neither encourage Taiwan independence nor allow mainland China to use force or military intimidation to shorten the process of cross-Taiwan Strait integration.
This is Biden's first overseas visit since becoming committee chairman, and his first visit to Taiwan since he became a senator in 1973.

At the press conference, he said that he is confident such a process can be managed in such a way that conflict can be avoided while a result on the island's future can involve the decision of the people of Taiwan.

Responding to a question on whether he believes Taiwan should be allowed to take part in a U.S.-directed Theater Missile Defense (TMD) project, Biden said that it remains to be seen whether Taiwan will be involved.

However, with regard to a U.S. National Missile Defense, he said that it is important to deal with possible missile threats in a "multi-layered" manner -- through both diplomacy and the fostering of the ability to defend the United States against such possible threats.

Meanwhile, he added that it is important to put Beijing and Moscow at ease before moving forward with such a missile defense plan and to make it clear that any system the United States develops is not aimed at neutralizing mainland China's nuclear deterrent.

In pursuing such a system, he continued, it is important to be careful not to trigger another arms race in the region. That was the reason that Bush touched base with Russian President Vladimir Putin regarding the issue during a meeting last month.

Similarly, he added that it was why U.S. Secretary of State Colin Powell went to Beijing to determine whether a limited missile defense could be built in such a way that mainland China would not feel the threat to respond.

Biden said that he agrees with a policy of engagement with Beijing because he believes that it will not be possible for mainland China to maintain a closed system when it is engaged in economic relations with the rest of the world.

He said that either the mainland will no longer be a part of the global economic community a few years from now, or it will gradually change because "the more they have to lose, the more they will start to follow international norms."

Meanwhile, Specter, who is a member of the Senate Appropriations Subcommittee on Foreign Operations, said that the United States wants to see a peaceful relationship maintained between mainland China and Taiwan, which he said "requires some delicacy, although the real action has to come from the parties themselves in terms of their restraint."

Sarbanes, another member of Biden's delegation, said that during the group's meeting with Chen, the senators expressed their admiration for the development of a vibrant democracy in Taiwan, the "evolution" that has taken place on the island and the role that Chen has played to make that possible.
Sarbanes, who is currently chairman of the Senate Committee on Banking, Housing and Urban Affairs, was also involved in the drafting of the TRA.
Biden's delegation is scheduled to visit mainland China and South Korea upon leaving Taiwan Tuesday morning.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW VISA MEASURE EXPECTED TO LURE 100,000 MORE H.K.,MACAU VISITORS

TEXT.P: A new visa measure by Taiwan is expected to attract 100,000 more travelers from Hong Kong and Macau to visit the island annually, tourism officials said Monday.

The Ministry of the Interior announced earlier in the day that those residents from Hong Kong and Macau who have visited Taiwan before or who already hold a valid visa can obtain a 14-day landing visa upon arrival, effective Wednesday.

Officials of the Bureau of Immigration predicted that the new measure will help Taiwan attract 100,000 more Hong Kong and Macau visitors per year and bring the number of visitors to more than 360,000.

Vice Interior Minister Lee Yi-yang said that opening the local tourist market for Hong Kong and Macau visitors is chiefly aimed at promoting exchanges and cooperation between Hong Kong, Macau and Taiwan.

Ho Jung-tsun, director of the Administrative Department of the Bureau of Immigration, pointed out that Hong Kong and Macau residents could originally obtain a Taiwan visa in three ways -- a single 30-day visa, a 12-entry-per-year multiple entry visa valid for 14 days' stay on each issuance and a three-year visa valid for a total of 12 entries.

Asked whether the new measure will cause an exodus from mainland China, Ho said that he did not worry about that because mainland Chinese living in Hong Kong or Macau must wait at least seven years before getting a Hong Kong or Macau identification card.
At the same time, any visitor taking advantage of the landing visa for the first time will still have to present a entry permit, Ho said.

Ho said landing visa applicants should present an application form, a recent photo and a 14-day round trip air ticket, while those who already hold a visa need simply present their passport along with their air ticket.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING BLOCKING TAIWAN'S TOURISM-OPENING BID: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: Beijing has been blocking Taiwan's bid to open its tourist market to visitors from mainland China, President Chen Shui-bian said Monday.

Chen made the accusation while meeting a high-profile U.S. parliamentary delegation led by Senator Joseph Biden (D.-Del.), chairman of the U.S. Senate Foreign Relations Committee, at the Presidential Office.

The president said that the Republic of China government has readied itself to play host to tourists from the mainland and has expressed to the Beijing authorities through various channels its desire for talks on the issue.

However, he continued that to the disappointment of Taipei, Beijing has been unwilling to negotiate with Taipei on the matter and has even asked Taiwan not to unilaterally announce the policy, which is aimed at increasing cross-Taiwan Strait exchanges.

Chen's remarks answered the question raised by many in the tourist trade as to why Taiwan postponed its tourist opening to mainland people. The Executive Yuan had originally planned to commence the new measure July 1.
"We are willing to wait, but the new measures may never be realized if Beijing refuses to talk," Chen admitted.

Saying he is determined to improve cross-strait relations and has on various occasions made clear his determination in this regard, Chen noted that the development of Taiwan-mainland ties over the past one year has been unsatisfactory. "The ball is definitely in Beijing's court now," the president added.

Chen said that Taiwan's opening of the "mini three links" between its frontline islands of Kinmen and Matsu and selected mainland ports earlier this year was supposed to be just a first step toward full trade, postal and transportation links between Taiwan proper and the mainland.

However, he went on, it is a pity that the "mini three links" policy has not proceeded smoothly due to Beijing's refusal to go to the negotiating table to work out necessary matching measures with Taiwan.

Chen expressed the hope that the leaders of both Taiwan and the mainland will "shake hands and embrace each other someday to jointly make the greatest sacrifice and contribution for the common welfare of the people of both sides."
Saying that it would be best for both Taipei and Beijing to shelve their disputes at the moment, Chen urged the Beijing leadership to "better understand Taiwan and himself."
He stressed that Taiwan's procurement of arms from the United States is purely for national defense and that the island will neither provoke nor engage in an arms race with mainland China.
He claimed that Taiwan is willing to cooperate with the United States to make the Asia-Pacific area a freer, more democratic and prosperous regional community.
Biden echoed Chen's view and added that his visit demonstrates the U.S. Congress' firm support for Taiwan.

Biden and his delegation will leave for the mainland Tuesday to continue their East Asian trip and Chen said he hoped that the trip will help them find out the root causes of the current cross-strait stalemate. They arrived in Taipei Monday for an overnight stay.

Taiwan is the first leg of Biden's first overseas trip since he replaced Sen. Jesse Helms (R-N.C.) -- one of Taiwan's staunch supporters and a harsh critic of mainland China -- as head of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee in June. After their mainland trip, Biden and his delegation will also visit South Korea.
Members of the delegation also include Sen. Paul Sarbanes (D.-Md.), Sen. Fred Thompson (R.-Tn.) and Sen. Arlen Specter (R.-Pa.)

DOC.HEADLINE: LOCAL VISA CARD TRANSACTIONS INCREASE BY 15 PERCENT

TEXT.P: VISA card transactions in Taiwan reached NT$280.9 billion (US$8.1 billion) in the first six months of this year, a 15 percent growth over the same period of last year, according VISA International officials said Monday.

The officials predicted that total VISA transactions in Taiwan for the whole of this year will exceed the NT$600 billion mark, as the third and fourth quarters of the year are the peak seasons for credit card spending as a result of summer vacations and the Christmas period.

Chen Chun-jen, president of VISA International Taiwan, said that with VISA spending becoming more and more convenient, he envisions stable growth in the number of VISA cards issued in Taiwan and corresponding stable transaction growth.

DOC.HEADLINE: EASING ON HONG KONG, MACAU VISA REQUIREMENTS DRAWS GOOD REACTION
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, Aug. 6 (CNA) (By Stanley Chang, Lu Chien-hui & Ed Chen)

TEXT.P: A spokesman for Hong Kong's Dragonair said Monday that the airline welcomes Taiwan's easing of visa rules for Hong Kong and Macau residents and said that the move will undoubtedly make Taiwan a more attractive destination.

The spokesman said that any moves to make the visa application process more convenient for a traveler will be welcomed, especially since the Kaohsiung-Hong Kong route is a "golden route" for Dragonair.
Dragonair provides four flights per day on its Kaohsiung-Hong Kong route.

Meanwhile, Chang Liang-jen, general manager of the Chung Hwa Travel Service in Hong Kong and concurrently Taiwan's representative to the former British colony, said that the move will help promote cultural and trade exchanges among Taiwan, Hong Kong and Macau.

The statement came in the wake of an announcement Monday by the Republic of China's Ministry of the Interior that previous visitors to Taiwan from Hong Kong and Macau would be granted 14-day landing visas, effective Wednesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: EDITORS' NOTE

TEXT.P: The new chairman of the U.S. Senate Foreign Relations Committee arrived in Taipei Monday for a whirlwind overnight visit.

Sen. Joseph Biden (D.-Del.) was greeted at the airport by Republic of China Vice Foreign Minister Wu Tzu-dan and Raymond Burghardt, director of the Taipei Office of the American Institute in Taiwan, which represents U.S. interests in the ROC in the absence of formal diplomatic ties.

Taiwan is the first leg of Biden's first overseas trip since he replaced Sen. Jesse Helms (R-N.C.), one of Taiwan's strongest supporters and a harsh critic of mainland China, as head of the powerful Senate Foreign Relations Committee in early June.

Biden, heading a delegation of senators from both the Democratic Party and the Republican Party, will leave Taipei Tuesday morning to continue his current three-leg visit which will also take him to mainland China and South Korea.
Biden and other delegation members will exchange views with senior officials of the four countries on U.S. national security-related strategic issues.

Biden is scheduled to meet with President Chen Shui-bian at 4 p.m. and will hold a news conference at the Grand Formosa Regent Hotel Monday evening. Foreign Minister Tien Hung-mao will host a dinner in honor of Biden and other visiting U.S. senators, including Sen. Paul Sarbanes, a Maryland Democrat; Sen. Arlen Specter, a Pennsylvania Republican; and Sen. Fred Thompson, a Tennessee Republican.

On the thorny issues between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, Biden said prior to his departure for his current East Asian trip that the "strategic ambiguity" approach adopted by successive U.S. administrations over the past two decades has actually implied two clear-cut messages -- Taiwan should not expect U.S. protection if it moves toward de jure independence and anything may happen if mainland China uses force against Taiwan.

Biden further said U.S. President George W. Bush's previous remark that the United States would do whatever it can to help defend Taiwan had gone beyond the U.S. security commitment to Taiwan. The Senate heavyweight said he does not think that the U.S. government is likely to issue a similar kind of statement in the future regarding cross-strait relations.

In a recent interview with Reuters, Biden said he was convinced that peaceful cross-strait integration is the ultimate goal of the United States and both sides of the Taiwan Strait. In his view, Biden said, the United States should neither encourage Taiwan independence nor let mainland China use force or military intimidation to shorten the process of cross-strait integration.
This is Biden's first visit to Taiwan since he became a senator in 1973.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINESE AMERICAN BIOSCIENTISTS STUDY TUMOR SUPPRESSING GENES

TEXT.P: Lee Wen-hwa and Eva Y. Lee -- a husband-and-wife team of Chinese American scientists -- are scheduled to present the results of their study on tumor suppressing genes at an ongoing seminar on biotechnology and biomedical science in Taipei.

Lee Wen-hwa, chairman of the Department of Molecular Medicine at the Health Science Center of the University of Texas, and his wife Eva Y. Lee, a professor at the same department, were given the Society of Chinese Bioscientists in America (SCBA) Presidential Award for their research on tumor suppressor genes and genome integrity in cancer progression.
In 1986, they discovered the retinoblastoma tumor suppressor gene (RB), making them the first scientists in the world to discover such suppressor genes.

According to their research, inactivation of tumor suppressor genes frequently leads to tumor formation. These genes might participate in DNA synthesis, repair, cell cycle checkpoint control and chromosome segregation to increase their fidelity in order to maintain genome integrity.
They said that if scientists could find out how these genes work, then not only might it be possible to prevent cancer, but it might be possible to save late-stage patients.
Lee Wen-hwa is also slated to present a paper on breast cancer susceptibility genes and DNA repair on Friday.

They are only two out of more than 1,000 scientists from around the world who are attending the five-day seminar, which is jointly sponsored by the SCBA, Academia Sinica and the National Health Research Institute.

Participants in the conference include Steve Chu, a 1997 Nobel laureate in physics; David Ho, who pioneered a drug cocktail treatment to combat AIDS -- for which he was named Time magazine's Man of the Year in 1996; and bioscientists from the United States, Canada, Britain, Germany, Switzerland, Spain, Australia, Japan, Hong Kong, Singapore and mainland China.
The seminar is the largest of its kind ever held in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: MALAYSIAN AIRLINES TO OFFER BIG DISCOUNTS ON INTERNATIONAL TRAVEL

TEXT.P: Malaysian Airlines will offer large discounts in September to promote its international flights, but fares for domestic flights in Malaysia were sharply increased from Aug. 1, a spokesman from the Malaysian Airlines Kaohsiung office said Monday.

From Sep. 1 to Dec. 14, travelers will be offered discounts of 40 percent on any international flight, except between Taiwan-Jeddah, Taiwan-Johannesburg, Taiwan-Cape Town, and Taiwan-Buenos Aires, the spokesman said.

However, domestic fares in Malaysia have been raised from Aug. 1, with an average increase of 51.8 percent. The price hikes were necessary, the spokesman said, because fares had not been adjusted in over a decade.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECONOMIST: NO SIGN OF TAIWAN INDUSTRY HOLLOW-OUT

TEXT.P: Taiwan's current economic slowdown is a temporary phase in economic circles and there is no sign of the feared "industry hollow-out", according to Taiwan's two major economic indicators, a government economist said Monday.

Lee Kao-chao, vice chairman of the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development, said that neither Taiwan's industrial production index nor its labor productivity has showed any sign of "industry hollow-out" or economic recession.

Taiwan's economy, which has plunged to its economic nadir for the time being, might have suffered somehow because of the island's current unfavorable political situation and its chilled ties with mainland China, but it is a far cry from recession or "a hollowing-out," he said.
"Recession" or "hollowing-out" means the long-term decline of productivity, such as the island experienced in 1990 when Taiwan's industrial production dipped by 0.2 percent, Lee explained.
But Taiwan's industrial production has enjoyed growth of between 6 percent and 7 percent since 1994, he went on.

The island's overall productivity grew at an average of 0.4 percent or 0.5 percent in the last few years, while labor productivity grew by 7 percent on average in the same period, except for 4.4 percent recorded in 1997, when the region was savaged by a financial crisis, Lee said.

Although the economist declared the alleged recession is none of his concern, he said he did worry about the island's low-technology industry, which is being edged out of the market by the world's many newcomers to the capitalist economy.

Saying that many places, such as India, mainland China, Russia, Eastern Europe and Vietnam, which have a combined population of 2.6 billion, began to embrace the capitalist economy after the end of the cold war, Lee continued that Taiwan's low-technology industry is losing ground to their counterparts in these places because of the island's higher labor costs, which are up to ten times those in the places mentioned.
Taiwan's high-technology industry, which has been closely integrated into the world economy, will recover quickly as long as the worldwide economy emerges from the doldrums, Lee said.
He made the statement at a symposium organized by the Taiwan Research Institute on Taiwan's economic recession and industry hollow-out.

Also present at the seminar were Day sheng-tong, president of the the Association of Small- and Medium-sized Enterprises, and Wei Duan, former director-general of the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics under the Executive Yuan.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA DENIES REPORT ON IVORY SMUGGLING BY AFRICAN DIPLOMAT

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) denied Monday a recent local news report that an envoy from an African ally of the Republic of China was found attempting to smuggle ivory into Taiwan.
A MOFA official said that the ministry had checked with customs officials and found the report to be groundless.
He noted that a non-diplomat visitor from Zambia presented a paper to customs July 6 for permission to bring in a box of semi-finished precious stones weighing 116 kilograms.

Customs officials said that some necklaces and pipes made of ivory-like materials were discovered in the box and added that these items had been forwarded to the Council of Agriculture and the Investigation Bureau for further examination.
They said that the Zambian visitor was allowed to enter the country after leaving his contact address with the customs.

The MOFA official said that the news report was obviously incorrect, as Zambia is not a diplomatic ally of the ROC and that the government has received no request for examination of the case from either the customs or any foreign diplomatic mission in Taipei.
He stressed that MOFA will not tolerate violation of the law by foreign missions, but noted that it also has to protect the images of friendly foreign missions.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. SENATORS HONORED BY ROC FOREIGN MINISTER

TEXT.P: Republic of China Foreign Minister Tien Hung-mao hosted a dinner in honor of Sen. Joseph Biden, chairman of the U.S. Senate Foreign Relations Committee, and three other visiting senators at a local hotel Monday.
The Senate delegation arrived in Taipei earlier that day for a 24-hour whirlwind visit on a three-country trip to Taiwan, mainland China and South Korea.
Before attending Tien's dinner, the senators met with President Chen Shui-bian.

The dinner was not open to the media, but Tien told reporters beforehand that the ROC government appreciates the long-standing efforts of Biden and other senators who support Taiwan's efforts to join international organizations.

He said the government hopes that Biden will continue his support for Taiwan and that the U.S. government will fulfill its commitment and obligations to Taiwan in accordance with the Taiwan Relations Act.

Tien went on to say that the government hopes that the visit by Biden's delegation will further consolidate congressional support for Taiwan in the future, especially the support from the liberals of the Democratic Party.
Besides Biden, the three other senators honored by Tien are Paul Sarbanes, Arlen Specter and Fred Thompson.
Following the Taipei visit of the Senate delegation, Tien said that Tom DeLay, the majority whip of the U.S. House of Representatives, will visit Taipei in the second half of this month.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC FOREIGN MINISTER WELCOMES FORMER U.S. PRESIDENT'S TAIWAN VISIT

TEXT.P: Minister of Foreign Affairs Tien Hong-mao welcomed Monday the news that former United States President Bill Clinton will make a trip to the Republic of China in September.
Although other former U.S. presidents have visited Taiwan in the past, Clinton will be visiting just six months into his retirement, which makes the visit especially significant, said Tien.
Tien said he looks forward to exchanging views with Clinton, who is also scheduled to meet with President Chen Shui-bian.
Clinton will visit Taiwan at the invitation of the United Daily News on a yet-to-be fixed date in September to mark the paper's 50th founding anniversary.

DOC.HEADLINE: `CODE RED' EXPOSES WEAKNESS IN TAIWAN COMPUTER SYSTEM: EXPERT

TEXT.P: The fact that Taiwan was the world's fourth hardest-hit area by the computer virus "Code Red" should press home to local computer maintenance technicians the importance of updating their computer systems, a local anti-virus expert said Monday.
More than 15,000 host computers in Taiwan fell prey to the "Code Red" which made its way into computer systems worldwide late last month, according to statistics compiled by local analysts.

Although the figure is far less than the 150,000 computers affected by the bug in the United States, and makes up only 4 percent of the 360,000 computers targeted for attack by the virus, it is still alarming that so many systems on the island could be hit by a virus in such a short period, the analyst said.

About 70,000 websites with the ".tw" suffix -- which refers to Taiwan -- were infected with the virus and forced to close for repair, which makes the island the fifth hardest-hit area in world in terms of affected websites, said the analyst.
The vulnerability of the host computers was due especially to the laxity of local IT technicians in updating their systems, according to the analyst.
However, he went on, the attack by "Code Red" has now alarmed these maintainers into plugging the holes in their systems to prevent a recurrence of the infection.

DOC.TEXT:

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, Aug. 7, or the 18th day of the sixth month of the Year of the Snake according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1556: A UFO appears above Basle in Switzerland.
1830: Louis Philippe, known as the "Citizen King," is proclaimed King of France upon the abdication of Charles X.
1858: Queen Victoria chooses Ottawa as the capital of the Dominion of Canada.
1903: Louis Leakey, British anthropologist, is born. He uncovered crucial evidence of man's early evolution, including a 1,750,000-year-old skull.
1904: Ralph Johnson Bunche, American diplomat, is born. He helped found the United Nations and won the Nobel Peace Prize for negotiating the 1949 Arab-Israeli truce.
1912: Japan and Russia sign an agreement determining their spheres of influence in Manchuria and Mongolia.
1913: Samuel Cody, American aviator, becomes Britain's first air fatality when his plane crashes at Famborough.
1942: U.S. marines land on Guadalcanal in the Pacific during World War II.
1945: The Soviet Union declares war on Japan seven days before the Japanese surrender in World War II.
1948: The Yangtze River overflows its banks, forcing three million people into homelessness.
1952: The ROC Legislative Yuan approves the designation of July 1, instead of January 1, as the beginning of the fiscal year.
1957: The ROC Navy sinks four Communist Chinese warships south of Kinmen.
1957: Oliver Hardy, the husky one in the Laurel and Hardy comic-duo who made more than 100 films from 1926 until 1950, dies of a stroke at the age of 65.
1959: The worst floods in more than 60 years hit central and southern Taiwan, killing 1,075 people, injuring 852, and causing more than NT$3.4 billion in property damage.
1974: Pingtung's Mei Ho Senior Little League baseball team leaves for Gary, Indiana, to participate in the 1974 Little League World Series.
1974: Paul Hogberg, president of the International Handball Federation, arrives in Taipei for a six-day visit.
1976: Vice Foreign Minister H.K. Yang meets with President Alfredo Stroessner in Paraguay.
1976: Kin Aziwa, newly-appointed deputy chief of the Japanese Interchange Association, Taipei Office, arrives to assume his post.
1983: Communist Chinese air force pilot Sun Tien-chin flies his MiG-21 jetfighter to South Korea to seek political asylum. He arrived in Taipei on Aug. 24.
1987: The leaders of Nicaragua, El Salvador, Guatemala, Honduras and Costa Rica sign a 14-page peace plan in Guatemala City aiming to settle a 10-year-old conflict in the region.
1990: President George Bush orders U.S. troops to Saudi Arabia to defend against Iraq.
1992: Beijing signs an agreement with Washington promising to probe any allegations that goods produced by prison labor are being shipped to U.S. markets.
1998: Bombs explode almost at the same time outside the American embassies in Kenya and Tanzania, killing more than 80 people and injuring over one thousand others.
1999: The Republic of China Premier Vincent Siew ends a five-day visit to Macedonia after a meeting with his Macedonian counterpart Ljubco Georgievski.
2000: Kuomintang Secretary-General Lin Feng-cheng says the KMT is happy that President Chen Shui-bian has decided to hold a multiparty roundtable meeting to discuss major national issues with the heads of the opposition parties.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "There are three things which a man should beware of in the three stages of his life. In youth, when the constitution of his body is not yet formed, he should beware of lust. In manhood, when his physical powers are in full vigor, he should beware of strife. In old age, when the physical powers are in decay, he should beware of greed."

DOC.HEADLINE: VISITING U.S. SENATORS DEPART TAIWAN, HEAD FOR MAINLAND CHINA

TEXT.P: The chairman of the powerful U.S. Senate Committee on Foreign Relations concluded his 24-hour whirlwind visit to Taiwan Tuesday and headed for Shanghai, the second stop on his three-leg trip to East Asia.

Leading a four-member bipartisan congressional delegation, Sen. Joseph R. Biden Jr. called on Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian and Minister of Foreign Affairs Tien Hung-mao while in Taipei to exchange views on ROC-U.S. bilateral relations and cross-Taiwan Strait security.

A liberal Democrat from Delaware who succeeded conservative North Carolina Republican Jesse Helms in June as committee chairman, Biden reaffirmed that there has been no change in the U.S. commitment to the 1979 Taiwan Relations Act, which has governed U.S. policy toward Taiwan since Washington switched diplomatic recognition from Taipei to Beijing that same year.
This is Biden's first overseas visit since becoming chairman and his first visit to Taiwan since he became a senator in 1973.

In Shanghai, his delegation is slated to call on the mayor of Shanghai and meet with mainland Chinese graduate students and professors at Fudan University -- known as "China's Stanford" -- to review political and economic liberalization policies, mainland China's impending World Trade Organization accession and its implications.
Biden is also scheduled to call on the top leadership in Beijing, including mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin, Premier Zhu Rongji, Defense Minister Chi Haotian and Foreign Minister Tang Jianhui.

His congressional delegation -- which includes Sen. Paul Sarbanes, a Democrat from Maryland, Sen. Arlen Specter, a Pennsylvania Republican, and Sen. Fred Thompson, a Republican from Tennessee -- will also visit Seoul and call on South Korean President Kim Dae-jung.

Local reports said that Tom DeLay, the majority whip in the U.S. House of Representatives, and Henry Hyde, chairman of the House Committee on International Relations, are slated to visit Taiwan later this month.
Former U.S. President Bill Clinton is also reportedly scheduled to visit Taiwan in September at the invitation of a local newspaper.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. SENATOR'S VISIT `POLITICALLY SIGNIFICANT': ROC FOREIGN MINISTER

TEXT.P: Republic of China Foreign Affairs Minister Tien Hung-mao said Tuesday that U.S. Sen. Joseph Biden's whirlwind visit to Taiwan had "major political significance" in light of the powerful senator's decision to make the island the first stop on his trip to East Asia.

Tien said that Biden, a liberal Democrat from Delaware who succeeded conservative North Carolina Republican Jesse Helms in June as chairman of the U.S. Senate Committee on Foreign Relations, has once sought the Democratic presidential nomination and has "considerable weight" in politics.

Biden's decision to visit Taipei before traveling on to Shanghai and Beijing runs against what many politicians or scholars do when they visit East Asia, showing that he has a "relative degree of acceptance and recognition" of Taiwan, Tien added.

Tien quoted Biden as saying at a dinner banquet hosted in the senator's honor the previous evening that although his visiting congressional delegation is made up of both Democrats and Republicans who often differ in their opinions on various issues and their attitude toward mainland China, their support for Taiwan is unanimous.

Biden's delegation, which includes Sen. Paul Sarbanes, a Democrat from Maryland, Sen. Arlen Specter, a Pennsylvania Republican, and Sen. Fred Thompson, a Republican from Tennessee, arrived in Taipei Monday and departed for Shanghai Tuesday morning.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI STOCK MARKET CONTINUES DOWNWARD STREAK

TEXT.P: The Taipei Stock Exchange continued its downward streak Tuesday, with the benchmark weighted price index losing 66.73 points to close at 4,404.
Market turnover totaled NT$35.72 billion (US$1.04 billion) in slow trading as many investors adopted a wait-and-see strategy over market uncertainty.

DOC.HEADLINE: LOCALLY DEVELOPED SATELLITE TO BE LAUNCHED NEXT MAY

TEXT.P: A locally designed and built picosatellite is scheduled to be launched into orbit in May next year, the National Space Program Office (NSPO) under the National Science Council (NSC) said Tuesday.
The launching of YAMSAT will usher in a new era of "do it yourself" in the Republic of China's space technology development, NSPO Director Lee Lo-chuan said.
YAMSAT will be designed and developed by a team of young local engineers, according to Lee.

"They have completed the designing and planning work and will join forces with the domestic academic and industrial communities in producing a spacecraft bus, on-board computer, antenna, solar array and scientific payload for the satellite," Lee said, adding that the team will also build a ground station to receive information.

Only a few kinds of integrated circuit (IC) components will be purchased from abroad for the project, and the rocket to put YAMSAT into orbit will be ordered from Russia with the assistance of Stanford University of the United States, Lee said.

"As this will be the first time that local space technology experts and engineers jointly develop and manufacture a satellite, the event is of great significance to Taiwan's space technology development regardless of whether the program succeeds or not," Lee explained.
He added that the Cabinet-level NSC has agreed to earmark NT$10 million (US$289,855) to finance the YAMSAT project.

Lin Hsin-chia, director of the project, said the square-shaped, pico-class YAMSAT will weigh only one kilogram. "It will be launched into orbit at an altitude of 600 kilometers, with a mission life of one month and a design life of two months," he noted.

The picosatellite will be launched by a Russian-made DNEPR rocket in May 2001, Lin said, adding that YAMSAT will be equipped with a locally developed micro-spectrometer to conduct atmosphere elements analysis.
Lin said his team will endeavor to complete development and construction of YAMSAT before the end of this year to ensure its smooth launch on schedule.

The ROC launched a 15-year space technology development program in 1991. Under the plan, Taiwan launched its first satellite, ROCSAT-I, produced by TRW Co. of the United States, in January 1999 for the Ka-band experimental communications payload and ionospheric plasma electrodynamics study.
The ROC has also commissioned the French firm Matra Co. and U.S.-based Orbital Science Corp. to produce its second and third satellites, respectively.

ROCSAT-2 is a smaller satellite designed for remote sensing and contains an electron-optical imager and a Sprite imager to carry out its tasks. In addition to its remote sensing mission, ROCSAT-2 also has the scientific mission of investigating various lightning phenomena in the upper atmosphere.
The ROCSAT-3 program is aimed at developing a constellation of eight low-orbit satellites for operational weather forecasting, space weather monitoring and climate research.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN EXCHANGE RATES
