DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK MARKET LOSES MORE GROUND

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) continued its downward streak Tuesday as investors cashed in gains following overnight losses in high-technology blue chips in the United States.
The weighted TAIEX index, the market's key barometer, lost 66.73 points, or 1.49 percent, to close at 4,404.

Market turnover shrank to NT$35.72 billion (US$1.04 billion) in thin trading as many investors kept on the sidelines over market uncertainty. A total of 1.34 billion shares changed hands during the three-and-half-hour trading session.

The market opened lower at 4,425.24 points and fell 1.5 percent in the first half hour of trading as investors quickly reacted to overnight losses in the United States and locked in their gains amid concern about prospects for Taiwan's high-tech industry.

All of the eight major stock categories lost ground, with cement stocks losing 0.8 percent; foodstuff issues falling 1 percent; plastics and chemical stocks shedding 1.6 percent; textile sector registering a 1.2 percent decline; electric and electronics stocks sliding 1.7 percent; paper issues moving down 1 percent; construction stocks dropping 1.6 percent; and banking issues posting a 1.2 percent fall.
Losers outnumbered gainers 346 to 144, with 88 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: DEFENSE MINISTER INSPECTS TYPHOON-TORN REGION

TEXT.P: Minister of National Defense Wu Shih-wen traveled to eastern Taiwan's Hualien County Tuesday for his latest round of inspections of the typhoon-battered disaster area.

Expressing the military's determination to assist local governments in their reconstruction efforts, he said that the soldiers sent to the various hardest-hit areas to support disaster relief operations will "stay to the last moment."

As of Tuesday afternoon, 100 people had been confirmed killed by the devastation wrought by Typhoon Toraji, which struck the island last Monday. In addition, 189 people were injured as a result of the typhoon, while another 114 are still missing.

Military spokesman Maj. Gen. Huang Suey-sheng said at a routine press conference that although disaster relief work is not the armed forces' basic mission or specialty, the military will treat relief operations as if they were military operations and will not stand idly by and watch fellow citizens suffer.

However, he added that his ministry must point out that the nation already has various levels of disaster contingency centers under the administrative system and that the military is only playing a supporting role in the disaster relief work.

Whenever the military receives instructions from these disaster contingency centers, he continued, the armed forces will move out and execute their orders in the shortest amount of time to provide relief.

Huang said that various companies that supply goods for the military's General Welfare Service Ministry -- the commissary goods administration -- have donated food, drinks, work gloves and other products for residents in the disaster areas and for the soldiers who are working to help those residents.
The first batch of such relief goods reached the counties of Nantou and Hualien on Monday, he added.

Meanwhile, Taipei City Government Spokesman Wu Yu-sheng said that Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou, who is currently visiting Malaysia, has given instructions by phone that the city government provide full support for the reconstruction efforts in the disaster areas.

Wu said that the city has already sent rescue and relief personnel to the disaster regions and has agreed to help Hualien County's Kuangfu Rural Township with reconstruction projects and counseling for the area's elementary school students.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock index futures market closed lower Tuesday, as Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index futures for August moved down 25 points to close at 4,395, with 11,081 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for September lost 38 points to finish at 4,395, with 288 contracts traded. December futures went up by 124 points to end at 4,365, with two contracts changing hands.
No transactions were recorded for other months.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Tuesday at 4,420 for August, 4,433 for September, 4,241 for December, 4,385 for next March and 4,385 for next June.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, both closed lower.

August TE futures moved down 2.5 points to close at 233, with 1,535 contract transactions, while September TE futures lost 1.8 points to finish at 233.2, with 44 contracts traded. TE futures for December moved down 3.1 points to close at 232, with one contract changing hands, and TE futures for next March dropped nine points to end at 234, with 18 contract transactions.
No transactions were recorded for other months.

August TF futures moved down 6.4 points to finish at 533.6, with 667 contracts changing hands, while September TF futures lost 10.4 points to close at 526, with four contracts traded. TF futures for next March dropped five points to end at 530, with one contract transaction.
No transactions were recorded for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT EXPRESSES FATHER'S DAY GREETINGS BY E-CARD

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian, his wife and Vice President Annette Lu expressed their Father's Day greetings Tuesday morning through the Presidential Office's Web site, wishing all the fathers in the world a happy Father's Day.

The first couple's e-card, with large trees in the background and images of a father and his child, shows the deep affection between fathers and their sons and daughters. In addition, the words on the card remind children to cherish every moment with their father.
The vice president's greeting card describes the importance of fathers, saying that they are teachers, and the light and happiness to their families.
Both the first couple and the vice president's e-cards can be viewed on the Presidential Office's Web site: www.president.gov.tw.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR DOWN ON TAIPEI FOREX MARKET

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar was down NT$0.018 against the greenback on the Taipei foreign exchange market Tuesday, closing at NT$34.668.
The local currency opened Tuesday at NT$34.628 and was traded between NT$34.628 and NT$34.680.
Interbank U.S. dollar trading totaled US$285 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: BUSINESSES SHOULD 'SAVE THEMSELVES TO SAVE THE JOBLESS'

TEXT.P: Minister of Economic Affairs Lin Hsin-yi said Tuesday that the best remedy for keeping people employed is to keep businesses healthy.
Lin made the remarks during discussions on rising unemployment in preparation for the upcoming Economic Development Advisory Conference.

Lin said that it is the social responsibility of businesses to take care of workers, but because the current economy is in the doldrums, businesses should first take care of themselves -- a step that will ultimately help workers.
Management and labor should not view each other as adversaries, Lin said; rather, they should understand that they are "in the same boat" and should work together to keep the ship afloat.

Lin said that the boat is currently too heavy and needs to be streamlined, adding that everyone should adopt the attitude that businesses must continue to develop and that businesses must" save themselves to save the jobless."
He also said that Hong Kong and Singapore have no minimum wage system, and that Taiwan's minimum wage, which currently stands at NT$15,840 (US$357), is not necessarily beneficial to laborers.
Lin said that he is not trying to cut the income of laborers, but he is hopeful that management will consult with laborers to reach a proper pay rate.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S FOREIGN EXCHANGE RESERVES UP IN JULY

TEXT.P: The Republic of China's foreign exchange reserves totaled US$110.108 billion at the end of July, the Taipei-based Central Bank of China (CBC) said Tuesday.
The figure represents an increase of US$983 million over June and was up US$3.366 billion over the end of last year.
The increase in July was mainly attributed to the net inflow of foreign capital and the gradual rise of the Taiwan currency against the greenback from July 11.
CBC statistics show that Taiwan was the world's fourth-largest holder of foreign exchange reserves at the end of July, next to Japan, mainland China and Hong Kong.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S DOTCOMS HOPE TO CHARGE USERS FOR THEIR SERVICES

TEXT.P: While dotcoms around the world are trying to find profit-making business models, Taiwan's Internet service providers (ISP) and Internet content providers (ICP) are looking into ways to charge users for their services, according to a survey conducted by Openfind Information Technology Inc.
The survey also shows that a considerable number of users are willing to pay in order to get better service.

Thirty-four percent of those polled are willing to pay for the information and services they receive from ICPs or ISPs. Based on the survey results, Openfind has decided to charge members of its "Cyber Information Agent," an Internet search engine, for information or services they offer.

In the past year, quite a few of Taiwan's Internet portal sites succumbed to the cold winter for Internet business when their profit-making models based on cyber advertisement income were found to be virtually worthless. The concept of offering "free content" and "free services" has made dotcoms "money burning" companies without revenues.

Leading ICPs and ISPs in Taiwan are studying ways to have their users pay for the services. Seednet, Taiwan's largest ISP, for instance, has started pay online services for horoscopes, fortune-telling, financial and money management consulting, and online anti-virus services.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC MISSION TO VISIT SILICON VALLEY NEXT WEEK
DOC.DATELINE: San Francisco, Aug. 6 (CNA) (By Neil Lu and Victor Lai)

TEXT.P: A Taiwan delegation consisting of experts on optics communications will arrive in Silicon Valley in California Aug. 14 to exchange views with local researchers.

The delegation will be headed by Vice Minister of Economic Affairs Yin Chi-ming. Members will come from the Institute for Information Industry, the Industrial Research Technology Institute and relevant organizations.
Besides visiting manufacturers in Silicon Valley, members of the delegation will attend a symposium on optics communications Aug. 15
Yin will report on the development trend of Taiwan's high-technology industries at a dinner organized by a local association Aug. 15.
At the dinner meeting, members of the delegation will also hear a report on power shortages in California and the countermeasures that have been taken.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW EDUCATIONAL POLICY OFFERS UNDERGRADUATE COURSES TO WORKING ADULTS
DOC.DATELINE: San Francisco, Aug. 6 (CNA) (By Neil Lu and Victor Lai) (By Lillian Lin)

TEXT.P: Taipei, Aug. 7 (CNA): The Ministry of Education has announced that working adults with four years of job experience and qualified language and mathematics abilities will be offered opportunities to attend universities or colleges.

The ministry has recently drafted a white paper stating its new policies for higher education. The working adult undergraduate educational program is a key point of the mid-term targets. Working adults over 25 years old are entitled to attend the program.

To promote internationalization in higher education, the ministry is encouraging local universities to cooperate in forming international academies for foreign students wishing to study in Taiwan in courses other than the Chinese language or culture. The proposed academies can offer such courses as business management in Chinese communities and computer science as well as information technologies. All courses will be conducted in English.

After making a thorough review of the practices of higher education, the ministry has drafted plans for future developments regarding proper distribution of educational resources, personnel training and international competitiveness, as well as adult education.
The ministry hopes that the new policies will provide greater flexibility to the universities and colleges and better opportunities for those wishing to study.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. LAWYER DONATES COMIC BOOKS ON TAIWAN HISTORY

TEXT.P: An American lawyer, Robin Winkler, donated 600 sets of a 10-volume prize-winning comic collection featuring Taiwan's history to the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) Tuesday to express his love for Taiwan.

Winkler presented the comic book collections to MOTC Minister Yeh Chu-lan in a brief ceremony held at the ministry. Winkler told Yeh that he has lived in Taiwan for 20 years and has married a Taiwan woman. "And I have come to perceive myself as a Taiwan folk," he added.

Winkler said he has found that many local people do not truly understand Taiwan. "Because of my love for Taiwan, I hope more people can gain a correct and clear understanding of Taiwan through this prize-winning comic collection," he explained.

The collection, which won the Golden Tripod Award presented by the Government Information Office last year, was compiled and created by more than 10 historians and a number of professional script writers and cartoonists.

MOTC Minister Yeh said she herself has bought a collection of the book. To her knowledge, Yeh said the production crew spent more than three years creating the 10-volume collection from a localized angle. "Although the themes and subjects were serious, the collection was presented in an animated comic style to attract readers," Yeh noted.
The minister further said the collection gives a detailed, comprehensive description of Taiwan's history and cultural development.

"Through the collection, we can understand that Taiwan has a rich, diverse cultural heritage which integrates legacies of Aborigines, Hakkas and immigrants from mainland China," Yeh said, adding that the collection caters to the tastes of both young and old readers.
Yeh said Winkler's donated comic collections will be presented to local travel associations and domestic and foreign airlines for free distribution to interested readers at home and abroad.
Speaking on the same occasion, Chen Ming-tung, vice chairman of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council, said the collection introduces Taiwan's various aspects from an international viewpoint.

Chen said mainland Chinese leaders tend to regard Taiwan as a territory under the PRC. "In reality, Taiwan has developed its own culture and social system over the past centuries," Chen said, adding that the current political entity in Taiwan is the product of concerted efforts of generations of residents on the island.

DOC.HEADLINE: KINMEN TO ADOPT RABIES PREVENTION MEASURES

TEXT.P: The offshore outpost of Kinmen will soon take several measures to prevent rabies from the mainland from making inroads into the island with the opening of the "mini three links" with the mainland since the beginning of this year.
The Kinmen Animal and Plant Quarantine and Prevention institute said that rabies is a high risk contagious disease that can affect humans and animals alike.

The institute noted that the mainland is a rabies infected area, and that cases of people dying from the disease are reported every year. With the direct trade, postal and transportation links between Kinmen and Matsu with the mainland, cross-strait exchanges of people, ships and goods have increased rapidly, and the risk of rabies landing on Kinmen has also increased, the institute added.
The institute said that it will start to take several measures at the end of the month.
The measures will include free sterilization and chip implantation of cats and dogs as well as inoculations against rabies.
Pet owners will also have to register their pets or face a fine of up to NT$20,000 (US$578), the institute said.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC MEDIA HEADS HOPE EXCHANGES WILL HELP REVIVE STALLED CROSS-STRAIT TIES

TEXT.P: Chairman Shaw Yu-ming of Taiwan's Central Daily News said Tuesday in Beijing that he is not optimistic about cross-strait relations, but he hopes increased media exchanges between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait will help redress the situation.

Shaw and other media heads of Taiwan media, who arrived in Beijing Monday, also called on the People's Daily and met with Chen Siwei, vice chairman of the National People's Congress Standing Committee, and Chen Yunlin, director of the Central Office for Taiwan Affairs Tuesday.
The former director general of the ROC's Government Information Office noted that the previous Kuomintang administration introduced the "no haste, be patient" policy toward investing in the mainland.

But at that time, Taiwan's economy was in good shape and the country could afford to have no trade exchanges with the mainland, but with the inauguration of the new administration and the exodus of businesses from Taiwan, the island's economy has gone from bad to worse, he added.

Shaw lamented that the administration of President Chen Shui-bian has not recognized the 1992 consensus on "one China, separate interpretations." This, Shao said, is causing the problems in cross-strait relations.

But as all countries come in droves to the mainland, and the expected impact after mainland China joins the WTO, Shaw said that Taiwan is bound to have to open direct trade, postal and transportation links, commonly known as the "three links," with the mainland to create mutually beneficial cross-strait relations, adding that a stalled cross-strait relationship will not help Taiwan's economy.

Shaw said that the KMT has, therefore, advocated the "one China, separate interpretations," resumption of dialogue on the implementation of the "three links," and the signing of a peace agreement in Taiwan so that relation between the two sides can progress toward stability.

DOC.HEADLINE: CROSS-STRAIT SYMPOSIUM ABOUT SPORTS TERMS KICKS OFF

TEXT.P: The third cross-strait symposium about sports terms opened Tuesday in Taipei, with sport representatives from Taiwan and mainland China sitting down to discuss the "unification" of various sports terms between the two sides.

Huang Ta-chou, chairman of the Chinese Taipei Olympic Committee, and Liou Baoli, deputy secretary-general of mainland Chinese Olympic Committee, presided over the symposium, which focused on discussions about terms related to cycling, fencing, football, wrestling and yachting.

The first cross-strait symposium about sports terms was held in Taipei in 1999, with discussions centering on terms concerning shooting, track and field events, swimming, baseball, softball, and national gymnastics (martial arts). The second symposium was held in Beijing in 2000, with discussions focusing on terms about handball, badminton, tennis, table tennis, basketball and volleyball.
Sport representatives from mainland China attending the symposium included various sport associations leaders, an international fencing judge and a college coach.
After the two-day symposium, the mainland Chinese sports delegation will also visit Taiwan's famous tourist spots. They are scheduled to leave Taiwan Aug. 12.

DOC.HEADLINE: 37 CONSCRIPTS RECEIVE TRAINING FOR ALTERNATIVE DIPLOMATIC SERVICE

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) launched a language and professional training program Tuesday for 37 conscripts who will soon be sent abroad for alternative diplomatic service.
They will be the first batch of Taiwan conscripts to join the diplomatic service as an alternative to compulsory military service.
The 37 bachelor's and master's degree holders have received four weeks of basic military training at the Chengkungling army training center in central Taiwan.

Over the next 10 weeks, they will receive language and professional training in preparation for work with the Republic of China's agricultural, fishery and medical missions stationed in various countries that maintain formal diplomatic ties with the ROC.

Speaking at a ceremony marking the opening of the training program, Minister of Foreign Affairs Tien Hung-mao encouraged the young conscripts to dedicate themselves to fulfilling their duties and helping promote friendship with the ROC's diplomatic allies.

In addition to language and professional training, MOFA officials said the courses will also include psychological and cultural adaptation, life management, first-aid training, health and disease prevention to help the young conscripts adapt themselves to life in remote foreign countries.

MOFA officials said 17 of the 37 conscripts are master's degree holders and that many of the others are graduates of medical schools. They added that a total of 211 conscripts had applied for alternative diplomatic service.

The ROC began to implement an alternative military service system last year, making it the first Asian country to introduce such a system. Thousands of conscripts qualified for alternative service have been assigned to work as school guards and firefighters or to join other social services, including reconstruction in disaster zones hard-hit by a devastating earthquake that rattled Taiwan Sept. 21, 1999.

DOC.HEADLINE: 13-YEAR-OLD ADMITTED AS YOUNGEST UNIVERSITY FRESHMAN IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: A 13-year-old prodigy student from southern Taiwan passed the Joint University Entrance Examinations (JUEE) with flying colors recently, allowing him to enter his top choice, the Electrical Engineering Department of National Taiwan University (NTU), this fall.

Thirteen-year-old Lin Chien-yi, who graduated from the National Tainan First Senior High school in southern Taiwan as the youngest graduate of the prestigious high school, became the youngest university freshman in Taiwan in the island's 48-year history of the highly competitive joint university entrance examinations.
JUEE authorities made public Tuesday the results of the national examinations -- the last one to be held as the examination system to determine university placement has been discontinued.

Unveiling the list of successful candidates in front of the gates of National Taiwan University, Minister of Education Ovid Tzeng urged all university freshmen-to-be to prepare themselves during the summer break to allow them to have a pleasant and confident start in their new college life.

Tzeng also exhorted those who were not admitted to universities to use "more diversified thinking" about their future, saying that some people are talented in non-academic fields and not all people are supposed to enter college or university as the only way to achieve their goals in life.

Since this is the final JUEE in Taiwan, many students who took the JUEE in early July and have been looking forward to entering departments and schools of their choice, were accompanied by their parents to check out the name list which was posted at National Taiwan University Tuesday. Many took photographs of the historic last test results.

The JUEE has long been considered a flawed system by educators and called a nightmare by high school students in Taiwan. Minister Tzeng said during his inspection tour of the tests in early July that even though the examinations themselves were fair, their existence had side-tracked the real emphasis of learning for high school students into studying only to pass exams.
Tzeng said he is looking forward to the new university entrance program which will give students more options and hold them responsible for their decisions.

According to the JUEE authorities, a total of 77,450 high school graduates out of the 120,143 students who took the battery JUEE tests this year were admitted, marking a record high 64.46 percent success rate in the system's 48-year history.

National Taiwan University's Department of Law, Department of Electrical Engineering, Department of Medicine and Department of Entomology remained the top choices in four different fields of studies by Taiwanese youths.

Some things were different this year, however, including the 13-year-old prodigy and that 10 mentally and physically-challenged students were admitted, many to their first choices. Sixteen inmates also passed the exams.

According to JUEE authorities, a total of 25 inmates took part in the joint examinations this year. Two of those who passed plan on entering National Taiwan University to study in the Department of Social Studies. Twelve are from Hualien Prison.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN BRIDES VISIT TAIPEI CITY HALL

TEXT.P: Thirty-five foreign brides who have married Taiwan men and now reside in Taipei embarked on a rare tour of Taipei City Hall Tuesday as part of a specially designed "growth camp" program.

They were the first group of foreign brides to attend the three-month "growth camp" training program organized by the Bureau of Civil Affairs under the Taipei municipal government with a view to helping foreign brides adapt to Taiwan's lifestyle and social customs.
After having attended 125 hours of training courses, the foreign brides appeared to be excited to have the opportunity to visit the nerve center of Taiwan's largest city.

They were particularly curious about decorations in the office of Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou, who is currently on a three-leg overseas visit that will take him to Kuala Lumpur, Seoul and Fukuoka to promote city-to-city exchanges.
Many of the foreign brides took turns to sit in Ma's chair and have their picture taken.
The foreign brides hail from a number of Southeast Asian countries, including Vietnam, Thailand and Indonesia. Some of them can now speak fluent mandarin Chinese or Taiwanese.
The city government-organized training workshop offers language teaching, Taiwanese cuisine, general local social customs and other relevant courses.

DOC.HEADLINE: SENATOR'S VISIT NOT TO CHANGE CROSS-STRAIT TIES: SCHOLARS

TEXT.P: The visit to Taiwan by the head of the U. S. Senate's Foreign Relations Committee, Joseph Biden, is not expected to help improve relations between Taiwan and mainland China, scholars who attended a seminar said Tuesday.

Stephen Chen, former Republic of China representative to the United States and currently a panel director of the Kuomintang-sponsored National Policy Foundation, said Taiwan-mainland ties will not change or improve despite Biden's recent visit.

As the positioning of Taiwan's national status is of a pivotal role to cross-strait relations, Chen said the government must first position Taiwan's national status before being able to seek a progress in bilateral ties.

Chen also criticized President Chen Shui-bian for urging Biden to push the United States to serve as a promoter of cross-strait relations though it is reluctant to play the role of mediator in this regard. According to Chen, such a call is tantamount to asking the United States go against its "six assurances" for Taipei and make the Taiwan Relations Act an empty shell.
Traveling at the head of a four-member congressional delegation, Biden arrived in Taiwan Monday and headed for Shanghai Tuesday.

According to Chen, Biden's remarks during his brief visit to Taiwan have been consistent. He stressed that the United States will back Taiwan, but not Taiwan independence, and called for cross-strait dialogue to peacefully settle bilateral disputes.

Wei Ai, director of the East Asian Study Center under National Chengchi University, also contended that Biden's visit to Taiwan will not be helpful to cross-strait ties because analyzing the matter from a long-term perspective, Washington will not make big changes in its policy toward the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.

He stressed that the United States will continue its engagement with mainland China and stick to its "one China" policy and the three communiques signed by Washington and Beijing to maintain peace across the Strait.

Teng Chung-chien, director of National Chengchi University's Diplomatic Department, said the United States will not support Taiwan independence nor will it allow mainland China to launch military attacks against Taiwan, judging from the basic tone of its "one China" policy, which advocates cross-strait dialogue and peaceful settlements.

In the current post-Cold War era, when economic benefits are the major concern of countries across the world, it is worth in-depth study whether or not the United States will continue backing Taiwan in case of conflict with mainland China by selling it defensive weapons should the island lose its economic advantages, Teng said.

DOC.HEADLINE: NUMBER OF PEOPLE LIVING UNDER POVERTY LINE INCREASES BY 14 PERCENT

TEXT.P: The economic slowdown has begun to bite in Taiwan, with the number of people living below the poverty line increasing by 14.2 percent in 2000, according to statistics released Tuesday by the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS).
The statistics show that there were 66,467 households living under the poverty line, 14 percent up over the year-earlier level.

As is common in other countries, Taiwan draws its poverty line at 60 percent of the average per capita consumer spending of the previous year. Any household with an income below that standard is considered to be living in poverty.
The government distributed NT$4.03 billion (US$118.52 million) in grants and benefits in 2000 to those people, in addition to offering them cheap housing for sale or rent, according to the DGBAS.

DOC.HEADLINE: BUSINESSMEN, WORKERS DIVIDED OVER CROSS-STRAIT INVESTMENT POLICY

TEXT.P: A group of Taiwan businessmen who have invested in mainland China strongly urged the government Tuesday to open direct trade, mail and transportation links across the Taiwan Strait.

The entrepreneurs, many of whom are senior executives of Taiwanese chambers of commerce in major mainland Chinese cities, made the call at a seminar organized by the cross-strait affairs panel under the soon-to-be-convened Economic Development Advisory Conference (EDAC).

Yeh Chun-jung, a representative of the Taiwanese Trade Association in Dongguan, in the southern mainland province of Guangdong, said the government should adjust its mainland policy in line with the changing global and regional political and economic situation, as well as the domestic investment climate.

Yeh said the government should not continue to reject the call for opening the direct cross-strait "three links" and easing the "go slow, be patient" policy on mainland China-bound investment on the excuse of "safeguarding national security."

Many representatives of Taiwan-financed companies in mainland China also urged the government to resume cross-strait dialogue under the so-called 1992 "one China, separate definitions" consensus in order to protect their interests.

Hsieh Kun-chung, president of the Taiwanese Business Association in Beijing, even suggested that the government revise the existing regulations governing cross-strait civilian exchanges to allow Taiwan investors to join mainland Chinese official organizations such as the National People's Congress and the Chinese People's Political Consultative Conference.

Speaking on the same occasion, representatives of Taiwan's major labor associations criticized mainland China-based Taiwan businessmen for their pressure on the government to ease cross-strait investment restrictions.
They claimed that mainland China-based Taiwan investors are only concerned about their personal interests and pay no heed to Taiwan's overall national well-being and economic development.

The seminar was co-chaired by the panel's three conveners -- Mainland Affairs Council Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen, Acer Group Chairman Stan Shih and Wu Rong-yi, president of the Taiwan Institute of Economic Research, a private think tank.
The panel is expected to come up with a package of proposals related to cross-strait relations for discussion at the EDAC, which is scheduled for Aug. 24-26.

DOC.HEADLINE: TORAJI DEATH TOLL REACHES 100, DONATIONS RISE

TEXT.P: Typhoon Toraji, which ravaged Taiwan July 29-30, had claimed 100 lives as of Tuesday, with another 114 people still missing, according to statistics compiled by the Central Disaster Contingency Center.

Nantou and Hualien counties, in central and eastern Taiwan, are the areas hardest-hit by Toraji, with 36 and 31 deaths reported in each county, respectively, followed by Taichung County with 13 deaths, Changhua County with eight deaths, Miaoli County with six deaths, Taichung City with five deaths and Yunlin County with one death.
Among those still unaccounted for, 83 are in Nantou County, 16 are in Hualien County, five are in Miaoli County, four are in Taichung County, two are in Taichung City and two are in Chiayi County.
Among the 189 people injured by the typhoon around the island, 47 are still in hospital.

Meanwhile, Interior Ministry officials said they had received donations worth NT$230.8 million (US$6.6 million) from around the country as of Tuesday and added that the China Steel Corp. said it would donate NT$50 million Wednesday for rescue and reconstruction work.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT URGED TO MAKE CHANGE IN POLICY TOWARD MAINLAND CHINA

TEXT.P: The government should step up efforts to ease its mainland China investment policy and set up direct links with the mainland in order to avoid Taiwan becoming a "second Cuba," mainland-based Taiwan businessmen said Tuesday.

More than 30 representatives of Taiwan investors in the mainland made the unanimous call at a panel meeting of the Economic Development Advisory Conference (EDAC), which was co-chaired by Mainland Affairs Council Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen and Acer Group Chairman Stan Shih, among others.

Voicing their strong desire that the government will soon relax the "no haste, be patient" policy governing mainland-bound investments by Taiwan businesses and quickly set up direct trade, transportation and postal links with the mainland, the businessmen urged the government to make the moves in order to "legalize already existing practices" and better protect their interests.

Yeh Chung-jung, a Taiwan businessman based in Dongguan, in mainland China's Guangdong Province, criticized the government for its reluctance to revise its policies under the pretext of "national security" at a time of a rapidly changing business environment.
Yeh expressed the hope that the EDAC will produce some real changes for the government's reference, rather than just "playing tricks to fool the people."

Chang Wan-tung, a professor of economic science at Fujen Catholic University, said the government's policies regarding mainland investment and the "three links" have become a burden instead of bargaining chips for Taiwan.

Should the government continue to walk this path, he warned, Taiwan might become another Cuba -- which lost its economic edge because of its political strife with the United States. He pointed out that the guarantee for Taiwan's national security is its economic clout rather than its defensive capabilities or political factors.

Chiang Yen-hsiung, chairman of the Taiwan Businessman Association in Shenzhen, urged the government to return to the so-called "1992 consensus" supposed by some to have been agreed upon by the two sides, adding that the government should negotiate with the mainland under the "one China, respective interpretations" principle.

Echoing Chiang's view, representatives of the Taiwan Electrical and Electronics Manufacturers Association proposed that the two sides continue their exchanges under a new slogan -- "one Chinese people, respective definitions."
In the face of the strong criticism from the private sector, Tsai, Taiwan's top policy maker toward mainland China, declined to respond to any of the proposals raised during the meeting.

Shi Hwei-you, vice chairman of the semi-official Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), which is in charge of exchanges with mainland China in the absence of official contacts across the Taiwan Strait, said the problems between Taiwan and mainland China are the two sides' positioning toward each other and the military hostilities.
Taiwan and the mainland should try to find an explanation acceptable to both sides and clinch a peace agreement to ease the tension, he suggested.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAISALT PRODUCTS MAKING INROADS INTO MAINLAND CHINA

TEXT.P: Consumer products from the state-run Taiwan Salt Industrial Corp. (Taisalt) are ready to make inroads into mainland China via Hong Kong, Taisalt sources said Tuesday.

Taisalt's consumer products -- which include shampoo, facial cleanser, shower milk and toothpaste and are all slightly different from other such products because they contain salt as a major ingredient -- will be first marketed in four Hong Kong-based supermarket franchises before being introduced to mainland China via the special administrative district, according to Taisalt Chairman Yu Kuang-hua.

The Taisalt products will have to enter the mainland via Hong Kong because Taisalt is a state-owned company and none of its products can legitimately be exported directly to mainland China under current regulations, Yu noted.
The four categories of Taisalt products are expected to generate NT$450 million (US$13 million) in Hong Kong and mainland China in the next three years, Yu added.

Addressing a press conference to mark the launch of Taisalt products on world markets, Yu noted that the products will also be marketed in the United States in the coming years, aimed primarily at Chinese American consumers.

Unconfirmed sources have said that Taisalt's salty shampoo has been hotly sought after by Japanese tourists to Taiwan over the past one year. The Japanese are said to have been buying the Taisalt shampoo because the product has a "miraculous effect" in arresting baldness.

Taisalt consumer products, particularly the salty facial cleansing milk, have enjoyed brisk domestic sales over the past year with recommendations being passed back and forth on the Internet, according to Taisalt marketing authorities.

The brisk sales -- up 110 percent in the first half year of 2000 over the same period of the previous year -- represent a "miracle" in the state-run company's transition to privatization amid the widespread economic distress in Taiwan, and marks an unprecedented page in the company's marketing history, Taisalt personnel said.
Taisalt is the one and only producer, supplier and distributor of salt and salt-derived products in Taiwan.

Also addressing the press conference, Lin Wen-yuan, vice chairman of the Commission of National Corporations under the Ministry of Economic Affairs, lauded Taisalt's performance in successfully marketing its consumer products as a fine example of business transition for all state-run enterprises making the sometimes painful change to private ownership.

DOC.HEADLINE: MACAU WELCOMES EASING OF ROC VISA REQUIREMENTS
DOC.DATELINE: Macau, Aug. 7 (CNA) (By C.H. Jen and Elisa Kao)

TEXT.P: The government of the Macau Special Administrative Region said Tuesday that it welcomes the decision by the Taiwan authorities to grant 14-day landing visas to Macau residents who have visited Taiwan before.

The Republic of China Ministry of the Interior announced a day earlier that residents of Hong Kong and Macau who have previously been to Taiwan or who already hold a valid visa can obtain a 14-day landing visa upon arrival, effective Wednesday.

Prior to the easing of requirements, Hong Kong and Macau residents could get a single 30-day visa, a 12-entry-per-year multiple entry visa valid for 14 days' stay on each issuance or a three-year visa valid for a total of 12 entries, all of which took around two weeks to process.

An official from the Macau Government Tourist Office said the new measure will benefit future tourist exchanges between Taiwan and Macau, adding that more Macau residents will take advantage of the new measure to visit Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: N.Y. ROUND-TABLE CONFERENCE ON CHINA ISSUE CANCELED

TEXT.P: Former Mainland Affairs Council Chairman Su Chi said Tuesday that a round-table conference scheduled to be held in New York Aug. 12-14 for delegates from Taiwan, mainland China, Hong Kong and the United States had been canceled.
"I do not know the reason, but the advance announcement of the holding of the conference is said to be the reason for the cancellation," Su said.
The round-table conference, dubbed the "second channel" of relations between Taipei, Beijing and Washington, had been organized by the U.S.-based National Committee on American Foreign Policy.

The conference would have been of special significance because it would have been the first gathering of its kind for officials from Taiwan, mainland China and the U.S. since the inauguration of the Bush administration, Su noted.
Su had been invited to attend the conference in his capacity as convener of the national security division under the National Policy Foundation -- an opposition Kuomintang think tank.

Other Taiwan delegates would have included Antonio Chiang, deputy secretary-general of the National Security Council (NSC); Kao Ying-mao, a consultant to the NSC; and Wu Jui-kuo, special assistant to opposition People First Party Chairman James Soong.
Since 1997, the National Committee on American Foreign Policy has convened the round-table conference once every six months to discuss Washington's China policy.
Conclusions of the conference are presented to policy makers in Washington, Taipei and Beijing for reference.

As the conference has played the role as a "second channel" of communication between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait since the suspension of bilateral contact in July 1999, ROC President Chen Shui-bian has openly affirmed the function of the conference.

After President George Bush took office Jan. 20, the national committee called a one-day mini round-table conference Feb. 8 to discuss the new government's China policy. Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou was the only non-American delegate invited to present a report to the conference.

DOC.HEADLINE: TSU `CAMPAIGN SCHOOL' BEING ORGANIZED TO FURTHER BOOST ELECTION BID

TEXT.P: An election campaign institute, dubbed the "Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) School," is expected to be established shortly, with classes scheduled to open in late August, TSU sources said Tuesday.

A number of specialists in politics who are "seasoned electioneers," like former President Lee Teng-hui, will lecture at the school, which is expected to open classes in northern and southern Taiwan so as to allow students in both the north and south of the country to have equal opportunities to attend, said TSU spokesman Su Chin-chiang.

The prospective students of the school, the first of its kind in Taiwan, will be the 40-odd candidates to be fielded by the TSU in the year-end legislative elections, along with related personnel in the soon-to-be-formed party, according to Su.
The TSU is scheduled to be formally established Aug. 12 as a new political party in Taiwan, with most of its members being followers of Lee.

One of the top goals of the TSU is to consolidate ballots of supporters of Lee, said Su, who added that TSU members have maintained close and frequent interaction with the former president and that the TSU school is a "stage" where cooperation between Lee and his supporters will come to the fore.

DOC.HEADLINE: MILITARY CHIEF ALERTS PUBLIC TO BEIJING'S `VEILED AMBITIONS'

TEXT.P: Chief of the General Staff Gen. Tang Yao-ming warned his countrymen Tuesday that the "seeming peace" across the Taiwan Strait belies Beijing's military ambitions against Taiwan.

In a speech to officers at the General Headquarters of the Combined Service Force, Tang said Taiwan should not base its national security on a "romantic vision" or "unrealistic illusion" regarding Beijing.

He warned that Beijing is pursuing a two-pronged policy: soliciting Taiwan's investment to "soften the alertness of the people of Taiwan," while building up military strength as a last resort to "bring the island to heel."

Beijing's "charm offense" against Taiwan businessmen is a circuitous way to bring pressure to bear on the Taiwan authorities through its own businessmen who are eager to explore the mainland markets, Tang claimed.
He warned the public not to lower their guard against Beijing, despite its repeated assurances that its military exercises are not targeted at Taiwan.
He also urged the Republic of China's armed forces to enhance their combat readiness in the face of Beijing's persistent military threat.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT VOWS TO DO UTMOST TO VISIT DENMARK

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian vowed Tuesday to do his utmost to travel to Denmark in November to receive in person a prize from the Liberal International organization.

In a meeting with a group of visiting Canadian parliamentarians, Chen said that the "2001 Prize for Freedom" granted to him by the Liberal International is an acknowledgment of the Taiwan people's achievements in democracy and that he is more than willing to collect it in person.
Promising to do everything possible to make the trip, the president said it would be a great pity if he is shut out of Copenhagen because of pressure from Beijing.
The Liberal International decided to award the prize to Chen earlier this year to honor his "outstanding contribution to freedom and liberalism in Taiwan."
Chen also challenged Ottawa to follow Washington's suit in granting him a visa for transit stops.
Although this would inevitably draw protests from Beijing, Chen said, Canada should "do what it thinks right."
As for ties between Taipei and Ottawa, Chen called for the conclusion of an accord to avoid double taxation, saying it would clear the way for economic exchanges.
He also appealed for visa-free status for short term Taiwan visitors to Canada, since Taiwan has already granted similar privileges to Canadian tourists.

Noting that several Republic of China officials have been denied access to Canada recently, Chen called on Ottawa to lift its prohibition on visas to Taiwan senior officials, which he said has seriously hindered the exchanges of high-level officials between the two sides.

He expressed thanks for Ottawa's support for the island's bids to join the World Trade Organization, and expressed hope that support will be expanded to the island's attempts to join the World Health Organization, because "there should be no boundaries for medical cooperation and healthcare cooperation" and the world suffers by excluding the island from the WHO.
Chen also urged Canada to concern itself more aggressively with peace across the Taiwan Strait.

DOC.HEADLINE: CROSS-AGENCY MEETING HELD TO DISCUSS RELEASE OF GREEK SKIPPER

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan called a cross-agency meeting Tuesday to discuss the release of two Greek seamen who have been barred from leaving Taiwan since their cargo ship spilled over 1,000 tons of oil off the coast of southern Taiwan in January.

Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) Administrator Hau Lung-bin told reporters after the meeting that no decision was made on whether to release the captain and chief engineer of the Amorgos.

He said that his agency would take action to resolve the issue "as soon as possible" and added that he would also ask the owner and the insurance company of the freighter to present letters of guarantee at an early date.

The cross-agency meeting was called at the request of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) and was attended by officials from the EPA, the Ministry of Transportation and Communications and the Justice Ministry.

The EPA contended that it has prohibited the two crewmen from leaving the country based on related laws with the purpose of "helping the investigation of the incident," which polluted a coral reef preservation region near Kenting National Park.

Regarding a report that the compensation demanded by the EPA is also "too high," the EPA chief said that assessment of the damage is being made by "an international company," and added that the amount will not be fixed for at least six months.
He noted that at the moment, the EPA just wants the owner and the insurance company to present letters of guarantee.
A ranking MOFA official admitted that his ministry has received great pressure from the families and friends of the crewmen, as well as human right groups.
He said that his ministry has played a role of conveying relevant information between the Taiwan and Greek sides, with the hope that the issue will be resolved soon.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI CITY MAYOR LEAVES KUALA LUMPUR FOR SEOUL

TEXT.P: Taipei City Mayor Ma Ying-jeou left the Malaysian capital of Kuala Lumpur for Seoul Tuesday after wrapping up a two-day visit.
Ma met with Kuala Lumpur city government officials earlier in the day to exchange views on a broad range of issues.
Ma said afterward that they agreed to programs for exchange visits of students and artists.
He was expected to arrive in the South Korean capital early Wednesday for a four-day visit.
During his stay in Seoul, Ma will inspect Seoul's garbage collection operation and learn about the city's regulation of Internet cafes.
Accompanied by a huge entourage and journalists, Ma left Taipei Sunday on his trip to the three Asian cities that will end in Fukuoka, Japan on Aug. 15.

DOC.HEADLINE: GAMBIAN ENVOY PRESENTS CREDENTIALS TO ROC PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: New Gambian Ambassador to the Republic of China Essa Bokar Sey presented his credentials to President Chen Shui-ban Tuesday at the Presidential Office.

After the presentation ceremony, Chen expressed his thanks for Gambian President Yahya Jammeh's concern over the heavy loss of life and damage to crops and property in Taiwan as a result of Typhoon Toraji, as well as for Gambia's firm support of Taiwan's bid for membership in the United Nations, the World Health Organization and other international organizations.
Chen said that the ROC and Gambia enjoy a steady and friendly relationship, as evidenced by Jammeh's three visits to Taiwan and his own trip to the African ally in August last year.
The president added that during his tenure as Taipei mayor, he fostered sisterhood relations between Taipei and the Gambian capital of Banjul and that he and Jammeh are "good friends."
Taiwan and Gambia resumed diplomatic relations in July, 1995 after a 21-year hiatus.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, Aug. 8, or the 19th day of the sixth month of the Year of the Snake according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
117: Hadrian becomes emperor of Rome after the death of Trajan.
1549: France declares war on England.
1588: The Spanish Armada is defeated by the British.
1900: The first Davis Cup tennis tournament, named after Dwight Filley Davis, begins in Brookline, Massachusetts.
1901: Ernest Lawrence, the American physicist who won the Nobel Prize for physics in 1939, is born. He invented the first subatomic particle accelerator and the color television tube.
1918: The Battle of Amiens begins when Allied forces advance against 20 German divisions and take 16,000 prisoners in two hours.
1919: A peace conference between India and Afghanistan results in the signing of the Treaty of Rawalpindi.
1923: Esther Williams, the American actress and former champion swimmer, is born. She became best-known for her appearance in "Bathing Beauty."
1944: Adolf Hitler has four of his top men hanged with piano wire for attempting to assassinate him.
1945: The United States drops its second atomic bomb, "Fat Man," on the Japanese city of Nagasaki, days after devastating Hiroshima with "Little Boy," the first such device ever used.
1957: General Chow Chih-jou is appointed governor of Taiwan, succeeding C.K. Yen.
1957: The Republic of China establishes diplomatic relations with Jordan.
1961: Mei Lan-fang, noted Beijing opera actor, dies of illness in Beijing at the age of 67.
1963: In one of the most audacious holdups of all time, robbers involved in "The Great Train Robbery" net an estimated 2.5 million pounds (US$4.6 million) in unused bank notes from a night mail train traveling between Glasgow and London.
1963: The United States, Britain and the USSR sign the nuclear Test Ban Treaty in the Kremlin.
1967: The "Bangkok Declaration" is signed by the foreign ministers of Indonesia, Malaysia, the Philippines, Singapore and Thailand. The declaration led to the formation of the Association of South East Asian Nations (ASEAN).
1974: Richard Nixon makes history as the first U.S. president to resign from office.
1977: The Interior Ministry reports that at the end of June, the population of Taiwan reached 16,655,140 and that of Taipei hit 2,113,030.
1983: A military coup led by Defense Minister General Oscar Humberto Mejia Victores overthrows President Efrain Rios Montt of Guatemala.
1988: ROC swimmer Wang Han and a six-man team swim across the English Channel in relays in 14 hours and 31 minutes.
1988: Premier Yu Kuo-hwa announces the decision to build a new highway linking Ilan and Nankang in Taipei County.
1990: National Defense Minister Chen Li-an announces that the Red Cross Society of the ROC will handle the repatriation of illegal mainland entrants in the future.
1994: Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation and mainland China's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait sign and make public a joint announcement confirming the results of the second round of talks between Chiao Jen-ho and Tang Shubei.
1999: The Fifth Asia Children's Literature Convention opens in Taipei with 300 authors of children's literature from Japan, South Korea, Hong Kong, the Philippines, Malaysia and the ROC attending.
2000: The Asian Witness Center of the Guinness Book of World Records names 109-year-old Hu Chin-yao as Taiwan's oldest father.
2000: Chinese Taipei captures the Bronco League World Series baseball championship for the thrid consecutive year, beating Puerto Rico 16-7 at Monterey, California.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "If those in authority have not the confidence of those under them, government of the people is an impossibility."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN-AUSTRALIA MINERAL AND ENERGY CONFAB OPENS IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: Officials from Taiwan and Australia gathered in Taipei Wednesday to participate in a two-day conference on mineral and energy resources.

Fang Liang-chi, executive secretary of the Energy Commission under the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA), and Tim Mackey, deputy executive director of the Australian Ministry of Industrial and Scientific Resources, will be key negotiators representing Taiwan and Australia, respectively, during the conference.
ROC Vice Economic Affairs Minister Yin Chi-ming presided over a ceremony at the Taiwan Power Building on Wednesday morning to open the conference.

Officials from the two sides are expected to discuss the energy policies of their respective countries, as well as the utilization of mineral and energy resources, including coal, petroleum, natural gas, and iron and steel, said officials from the Energy Commission.

Australian officials and exporters have shown evident concerns about a liquefied natural gas (LNG) purchase plan by the state-run Taiwan Power Co. (Taipower), and the subject is expected to be brought up sometime during the conference, according to the officials.

The Taiwan delegation to the meeting includes officials from the Energy Commission, the MOEA's Mines Department, and from state-run enterprises such as Taipower, China Steel Corp. and Chinese Petroleum Corp.
Taiwan has been one of the major overseas markets for Australia's exports of mineral and energy resources, including coal, petroleum and LNG.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK PRICES UP BY 110.1 POINTS

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange on Wednesday regained ground lost over the past two days, with the benchmark weighted price index surging 110.10 points to close at 4514.10.
Market turnover amounted to NT$55.562 billion (US$1.60 billion).

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC-U.S. JUDICIAL PACT TO FACILITATE FIGHT AGAINST CROSS-BORDER CRIME

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Wednesday that it welcomes the consensus reached between judicial authorities of the Republic of China and the United States on mutual assistance in criminal investigation.
MOFA spokeswoman Chang Siao-yue said representatives from the two countries met in Washington, D.C. from July 30-Aug. 3 to discuss details of a bilateral judicial assistance accord.
During the five-day meeting, Chang said, the two sides reached consensus on a 20-article judicial assistance agreement.

Under the accord, law enforcement officers will cooperate in the questioning of witnesses and the supply of relevant documents, transcriptions and evidence, as well as in carrying out searches and impounding property.
Chang said the Ministry of Justice (MOJ) played a leading role in discussing the content of the accord with the United States.
"Although the MOFA didn't participate in the consultations, we took great pleasure in seeing the two sides reach consensus on the key points of the long-talked-about accord," she added.

Chang said the new agreement will contribute to efforts by both sides at cracking down on cross-border criminal activities. The agreement, however, does not touch on the deportation of criminal suspects as such issues involve the signing of an extradition pact.

The draft accord will be initialed after the relevant government agencies of the two countries approve its content. And the pact will be formally signed after the legislative bodies of the two countries give the green light.

DOC.HEADLINE: JUNIOR TEAM CANADA TO VISIT TAIWAN

TEXT.P: A group of young Canadians will visit Taiwan later this week for a two-week stay during which they will meet with business, government and youth leaders as part of a program jointly sponsored by the Canadian government and private sector.

The group, dubbed Junior Team Canada, was formed under a program called Global Vision, which is designed to provide Canadian youths between 16 and 25 years old with the skills and knowledge needed to forge future careers in the international marketplace.
Amy Giroux, leader of the 25-member team, said Tuesday that she thanks the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in Canada for its assistance in making the visit happen.
She and her teammates were briefed on the latest developments in the Republic of China on Taiwan during a lunch meeting at the TECO office in downtown Ottawa.

After seeing a short film on Taiwan, the Canadian youths raised a series of questions on topics such as Taiwan citizens' perceptions of Canada, the pension fund situation in Taiwan, and the prospects for future cooperation between the two countries on major infrastructure projects.
Leading TECO officials answered the young Canadians' questions as best as they could and also wished them a happy and rewarding trip to Taiwan.

During their stay in Taiwan, the Canadian youths will attend functions organized by the Canadian Trade Office in Taipei, visit cultural and industrial establishments, and tour scenic spots around the island. They are scheduled to depart Taiwan for Thailand on Aug. 24.

DOC.HEADLINE: LAWMAKER QUESTIONS SINGAPORE-BASED FIRM'S OPERATIONS IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: A Taiwan legislator on Wednesday questioned the legality of the business practices of a Singapore-based company that shut down its operations in Taiwan after having bagged what is believed to be more than NT$10 million (US$289,000).

People First Party Legislator Chin Huei-chu said at a press conference at the Legislative Yuan that the Singapore firm successfully collected the money by issuing More Rewards Cards to some 110,00 Taiwan consumers over the period of about one year.

Beginning in April 2000, the firm used television ads intensively to attract Taiwan consumers to become More Rewards Card members, claiming that one would be entitled to "products at a super value" by simply paying NT$100 to become a More Rewards Card holder.

Meanwhile, More Rewards signed up a number of local companies and retail stores to participate in its "rewards points" program, whereby More Rewards Card holders could through their purchases accumulate points which could then be traded in for gifts from the participating stores.

In late February of this year, however, the cardholders and participating stores received notices from More Rewards indicating that the company had "temporarily suspended" its operations in Taiwan. Accompanying each notice was an envelop with some small-denomination postal stamps provided as "compensation" to the cardholders, according to Chin.
There has been no trace of the management of the Singaporean firm's Taiwan operations since March 1, except for a mailing address, Chin added.

She said that the "suspension" of the Singaporean firm's operations has not only made the membership of the Taiwan cardholders null and void, it has also affected the participating stores, to which More Rewards is indebted for more than NT$6 million (US$173,410).

Chin asked officials from the Cabinet-level Consumer Product Commission Council (CPCC), who were also present at the press conference as observers, whether More Rewards has violated any regulations governing business practices in Taiwan.

CPCC officials said that More Rewards obtained legal licenses from both the Taipei City Hall and the Ministry of Economic Affairs for their operations in Taiwan. Unless the cardholders or the participating stores file a complaint with the CPCC, More Rewards will not be dealt with, they added.

Until recently, none of the More Rewards Card holders have filed a law suit against the Singaporean firm. The officials said they reckoned that the chances of success if any of the cardholders make such a legal move are slim as they each only spent a mere NT$100 for the card, despite the fact that the total number of cardholders exceeds 110,000.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK MARKET SURGES 110.1 POINTS

TEXT.P: Shares prices opened high and closed even higher on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Wednesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, gaining 110.10 points to close at 4514.1.
After losing ground over the previous two days, the bourse opened at 4413.13 points Wednesday and then moved up for most of the trading session.

Market turnover totaled NT$55.561 billion (US$1.6 billion) on brisk trading for the day, compared with only NT$35.72 billion during the previous day's session. A total of 2.03 billion shares changed hands during the four-and-half-hour session.

All of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with plastics and chemical stocks moving up the most at 5.1 percent, followed by financial issues at 4.9 percent, textile shares at 4.7 percent, cement stocks at 3.6 percent, construction stocks at 3.5 percent, foodstuff issues at 2.6 percent, pulp and paper issues at 1.8 percent, and electronics stocks at 1.7 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 473 to 57, with 56 stocks remaining unchanged.
