DOC.HEADLINE: CLA NEEDS TIME TO TACKLE FOREIGN LABOR BASIC WAGE PROBLEMS: OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) said Wednesday it takes time to evaluate the pros and cons of a proposal to cancel basic wage protection for foreign workers.

The council was responding to reports that President Chen Shui-bian had expressed concern at a recent government policy consultative meeting to assess whether wages for foreign laborers are too high and whether the existing basic wage regulations will affect Taiwan industries' competitiveness in the world market.
Chen reportedly asked the Cabinet to study the feasibility of excluding foreign laborers from the basic wage requirement set forth in the existing Labor Standards Law.

He was quoted as having even said that if the difficulty in de-linking foreign and local labor wage issues lies in international factors, the Cabinet should not rule out the possibility of withdrawing from relevant international conventions.

Commenting on the reports, CLA Vice Chairman Kuo Chi-jen said relevant issues have been discussed many times. "As the issues involve complicated problems, no conclusion has been reached so far," he noted.

The Republic of China ratified an international convention on basic wages in 1930 and an international anti-occupational discrimination convention in 1961. As a result, foreign laborers in Taiwan are subject to the same protection as their local counterparts.

Kuo said the CLA has not yet considered the possibility of the ROC's withdrawal from the two international agreements. "I don't think that the labor wage issue has become so serious that we have to mull whether to withdraw from any relevant international accord," he noted.

Some CLA officials said the government must consider possible international reaction if it really wants to withdraw from the two international conventions to facilitate the proposed scrapping of basic wage protection for foreign laborers.

Cabinet Secretary-General Chiou I-jen was quoted as having said at Tuesday's nine-member policy consultative meeting that although Taiwan's average national income is lower than Singapore's and Hong Kong's, local employers are required to offer foreign workers wages 1.7 times to twice the amount offered in Singapore and Hong Kong.

"Many local employers have complained about this unreasonable phenomenon," Chiou said, adding that senior business executives have suggested that the government de-link wage calculating formulae for foreign and local laborers in order to better protect blue-collar Taiwan workers.
Chiou said the ROC is the only East Asian country that has signed both the multilateral labor wage convention and the international anti-occupational discrimination convention.

Among major East Asian countries, only the ROC, Japan and mainland China have joined the wage convention, while only the ROC and South Korea have ratified the anti-occupational discrimination convention.

According to Chiou, Taiwan lags behind only Japan in its basic wage level and the island's basic wage is 1.85 times that of South Korea. These relatively high labor costs will undermine Taiwan's global competitiveness, he said.
Taiwan's current basic labor wage is set at NT$15,480 (US$459.13) per month.
Nevertheless, Chiou said any changes to the foreign labor wage formula involves many complicated problems, including revisions to the existing law, general public opinion and international reaction.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC CHILDREN'S SOCCER TEAM ARRIVES IN PARAGUAY

TEXT.P: A soccer team from a Republic of China junior high school arrived in the Paraguayan capital of Asuncion Tuesday to play a series of matches and meet president Luis Angel Gonzalez Macchi, according to the school's president, Tzeng Cheng-chi.
The Lan-ya soccer team will also meet Minister of Foreign Affairs Jose Antonio Moreno Ruffinelli, as well as visiting the International Olympic Committee of Paraguay.
The team consists of 15 boys and two girls, including the daughter of Paraguayan Ambassador to the ROC Ceferino Valdez.
The team is scheduled to depart Aug. 18.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC TO CONTINUE COOPERATION WITH GAMBIA: ROC PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Wednesday during a meeting with two visiting ministers from The Gambia that the Republic of China will implement a protocol on cooperation between the ROC and the West African nation as scheduled.

The president made the remarks when he welcomed Secretary of State for Finance and Economic Affairs Pamara L. Jatta and Secretary of State for Trade, Industry and Employment Musa H. Sillah, both of whom were visiting Taiwan for the second time.
Chen noted that he also received the credentials of new Gambian Ambassador Essa Bokar Sey the previous day, showing the firm relations between the two countries.

The president asked the two ministers to convey his greeting to President Yayah Jammeh in appreciation for his concern, the importance attached to bilateral friendship and his long-term support for the ROC, especially his concern for the havoc wrecked by Typhoon Toraji.
He also expressed the hope that Jammeh will be re-elected in Gambia's presidential election so as to continue to lead the country toward prosperity.

Chen also said that since the two countries resumed diplomatic relations in July 1995 after a 21-year hiatus, all cooperation projects have proceeded smoothly and added that the protocol on cooperation between the two countries has gone well. He further expressed hope that the two sides continue to increase exchanges and cooperation based on this protocol.
He also asked the two ministers to introduce Lin Chun-yi -- the new ROC ambassador to Gambia soon to assume his post -- to their country.

Lin, a biologist and environmental activist, is both erudite and no stranger to Africa, the president said. During his service with a Christian church in the United States, Lin was assigned to Tanzania, Kenya and several other African states to assist in establishing their biology teaching systems.
The president expressed the hope that bilateral relations will be further strengthened after Lin takes the post.

Jatta also conveyed a personal letter from Jammeh to Chen, adding that his president has good personal friendship with Chen and attaches great importance to bilateral relations. He also said Gambia will continue to support the ROC in the international community because the ROC is "a true friend of Gambia."
The two ministers, who arrived Monday to promote trade and economic relations with the ROC, will leave Taiwan Friday.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN FOREIGN TRADE POSTS RECORD DROP IN JULY

TEXT.P: Taiwan's exports and imports in July reached US$9.72 billion and US$9.18 billion, respectively, marking record drops of 28.4 percent and 31.8 percent, respectively, over the same period of last year.
According to statistics released Wednesday by the Ministry of Finance, the drops were the largest since 1976, when the ministry began compiling statistics on the island's exports and imports.

Ministry officials attributed the reduction of foreign trade to the huge exports and imports registered in July of last year, which skewed the month-on-month comparison, and the ravages of Typhoon Toraji, which hit Taiwan late July.

DOC.HEADLINE: WORLD VISION HELPS BUILD PREFAB HOUSES FOR TYPHOON VICTIMS
DOC.DATELINE: Taichung, Central Taiwan, Aug. 8 (CNA) (By Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: World Vision Taiwan (WVT) announced Wednesday that it is preparing to donate NT$10 million (US$289,017) to help build prefabricated houses for typhoon victims in Hsinyi township, Nantou County.

WVT officials said it is hoped that 200 of the prefab dwellings will be built soon in four villages in the mountainous area to accommodate displaced residents, mostly aboriginal people, whose homes were washed away by landslides and mudslides wrought by the recent passage of Typhoon Toraji across Taiwan.

The NT$10 million, collected from the "Fast 30" campaign held in June islandwide for the needy will only partially finance the building of the 200 houses, which actually will cost some NT$44 million, with each house costing around NT$220,000, WVT officials said.

WVT plans to provide NT$160,000 to each applicant household in the four worst-affected villages, to enable the villagers to buy the prefab houses, as long as these households can produce related papers proving that they are legal land users in the area, the officials said.
Any shortfall in the funds can be made up with subsidies that the government has given to those who claimed home damages in the wake of the typhoon, they added.
WVT officials said the proposed prefab houses can be used for at least 10 years, barring future severe earthquakes.

Nantou County is one of the two areas hardest-hit by Toraji, which wreaked havoc in eastern and central Taiwan with strong winds and torrential rain that caused devastating floods, landslides and mudslides that buried people, washed away houses, destroyed roads and bridges and ruined fields and plantations.

As of Tuesday -- the ninth day after the typhoon -- 100 people had been confirmed killed as a result of the typhoon, while 114 others were still unaccounted for and 189 injured. Besides the heavy human casualties, some NT$8 billion (US$231 million)-worth of losses to agriculture was caused by Toraji.
WVT, one of Taiwan's major charity organizations, has in previous years sponsored 30-hour fasts islandwide to raise funds to help famine-stricken or deprived people in the Third World.
WVT also sponsors 30,000 children in Taiwan and 40,000 children living in poverty in other countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: CEBIT ASIA NOT EXPECTED TO AFFECT TAIPEI COMPUTER FAIR

TEXT.P: Mainland China's CeBIT Asia computer fair opened Wednesday in Shanghai, is not likely to pose an immediate threat to Taipei's own computer fair -- Computex.

Of the 521 companies involved in the Shanghai show, 176 are from Taiwan, including IC design firms such as Via Technologies and Silicon Integrated Systems, although leading local personal computer and notebook firms like Acer Inc., Quanta Computer and ASUSTEK Computer decided not to participate.

In the face of the grand inauguration of the first CeBIT Asia, which has been jointly organized by German and mainland Chinese authorities, Taiwan's China External Trade Development Council (CETRA) has sent officials to observe and gather information about the event.

Although it is widely assumed that CeBIT Asia has set its sights on overshadowing Taipei's annual computer fair -- Computex -- CETRA officials said it will not be easy for CeBIT to pose a threat to Computex in the short term, as the Taipei computer show's 20 years of service to foreign buyers has made it famous worldwide.

In addition, they noted that the scale of Computex, which usually draws more than 1,000 firms to display their most advanced products, is far larger than that of CeBIT Asia, despite the fact that many Taiwan-based computer firms have relocated to mainland China.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC ISLET BELIEVED TO BE NEW CROSS-STRAIT SMUGGLING HUB

TEXT.P: Pengchiayu Islet, Taiwan's northernmost point of territory, is believed to have become the new hub for smuggling and illicit maritime activities across the Taiwan Strait, sources from the Cabinet-level Coast Guard Administration (CGA) said Wednesday.

The islet, located 55 nautical miles from Taiwan's northeasternmost city of Keelung, is reportedly the site where mainland Chinese fishing boats meet their Taiwan counterparts and sell their fish catches to the Taiwan fishing boats, who nowadays do not even bother to fish for themselves as "buying the catch is much cheaper and easier than fishing," according to a coast guard official.

After receiving an increasing number of complaints about the rampant smuggling near Pengchiayu, two district prosecutors from Keelung City, under which the Pengchiayu Islet is an offshore administrative district, traveled to the islet Wednesday aboard a CGA cutter for a fact-finding tour of the islet and its adjacent waters.
The CGA itself seized 38 mainland Chinese fishing boats between January and July this year for poaching near Pengchiayu.
During the same period, CGA patrols also nabbed 536 mainland Chinese from 82 mainland fishing boats for conducting illegal transactions of fishery products totaling some 27.7 tons.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND CHINA EDGES OUT TAIWAN IN JAPANESE MARKET

TEXT.P: Taiwan-made products are being gradually edged out by mainland Chinese goods in Japan, according to a recent government report.

From March, Taiwan's outbound shipments to Japan have begun posting double-digit declines and the combined export value to Japan during the first five months of this year dropped by 2.36 percent, the report by the Board of Foreign Trade (BOFT) shows.

At the same time, exports of mainland Chinese products to Japan rose by 12.9 percent compared to the same period of last year, enjoying a 15.36 percent market share in that country, far ahead of Taiwan's 4.46 percent.

Among Taiwan's five major export items to Japan, mainland China outshines noticeably one of Asia's "Four Little Dragons," especially in the fields of machinery equipment, electrical appliances, optical instruments and plastic products, all of which registered an increase rate of more than 10 percent in exports to Japan, according to the BOFT.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC EXPATRIATES IN JAPAN PROTEST OVER NATIONALITY ISSUE
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Aug. 8 (CNA) (By Mike Chang and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: More than 150 Republic of China expatriates in Japan and their Japanese friends staged a protest in downtown Tokyo Wednesday against Japan's forced identification of their nationality as "Chinese."

The demonstrators, most of whom were members of the Taiwanese Association in Japan and Japan's Taiwan Research Forum, paraded from Kyobashi to the Tokyo Railway Station and reached the Japanese Immigration Bureau around noon to appeal for their cause.
The demonstrators carried banners and posters demanding that the Japanese Immigration Bureau scrap its current practice of identifying ROC expatriates' as "Chinese" on their Alien Registration Cards.

They demanded that the bureau change their nationality to "Taiwanese," insisting that Japan has no legitimate right to force ROC expatriates to accept their nationality as "Chinese," which usually refers to the People's Republic of China (PRC).
Lin Chien-liang, president of the Taiwanese Association in Japan, said it is an insult to ROC expatriates to be identified as "China" nationals.

In fact, Lin went on, Japan has never recognized that Taiwan is part of the PRC. In the 1972 Tokyo-Beijing Joint Communique on the establishment of bilateral diplomatic relations, Japan says only that it acknowledges and respects the PRC's sovereign claim to Taiwan.

Against this background, Lin claimed that the Japanese Ministry of Justice's registration of ROC expatriates' nationality as "Chinese" on their Alien Registration Cards is an illegal practice and "tantamount to document forgery."
Lin stressed that all major countries around the world, including Britain, the United States, France and Canada, have consistently registered ROC expatriates' nationality as "Taiwanese."

"Only Japan is an exception," Lin said. "As the crime rate among mainland Chinese expatriates in Japan is very high, the Japanese government's registration of Taiwan people's nationality as `Chinese' has brought them much trouble and confusion."
Therefore, he continued, the Taiwanese Association has launched a "nationality correction" campaign.

Lin was later allowed to enter the Immigration Bureau to discuss the issue with relevant Japanese officials. However, the immigration officials said that as the nationality issue is not within the bureau's power, they were not in a position to make any comment on the petition.
Lin said he was dissatisfied with the immigration officials' reaction to their petition. "We'll continue our protest and petition," he added.

The demonstrators then paraded to the Japanese Ministry of Justice to present their petition there and to demand that the ministry take immediate steps to phase out the insulting, harmful practice meted out to Taiwan expatriates in Japan.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP HEAD CALLS FOR FORGING OF `REAL MAINSTREAM' AMONG OPPOSITION
DOC.DATELINE: Hualien County, eastern Taiwan, Aug. 8 (CNA) (By Fang Wen-hung)

TEXT.P: Opposition People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong said Wednesday that Taiwan's three main opposition parties should not try to "parcel out the big pie" of year-end election votes but should instead aim at forging a "real mainstream."
During a visit to eastern Taiwan's Hualien County to inspect the extensive damage caused by last week's Typhoon Toraji, Soong urged the parties not to become engrossed in another battle of words.
He added that "the people" want to see the opposition parties arrive at a common ground on the issues that are of greatest concern to the public.

Soong said that although competition is inevitable during an election campaign, he hopes the opposition Kuomitang (KMT) will support PFP candidates as the PFP supports KMT candidates and will stop saying that the PFP is destroying unity among the opposition.

Responding to an opposition New Party claim that the PFP does not have a clear stance on its policies, Soong stressed that the PFP believes in "one China, with Taiwan and the mainland allowed to make its own interpretations as to the meaning of the term."

He added that cross-Taiwan Strait relations must proceed according to the stages set forth in the Guidelines for National Unification and that the conditions for immediate unification do not exist at present.

Describing himself as "both Taiwanese and Chinese," Soong said that he loves Taiwan and that both sides of the Taiwan Strait -- being Chinese -- should strive to create opportunities for peace and the forging of common ground.

DOC.HEADLINE: TSU UNVEILS PARTY MANIFESTO

TEXT.P: Huang Chu-wen, convenor of the soon-to-be-formed Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) political party, unveiled its inauguration manifesto Wednesday, stressing solidarity for a strong Taiwan.

Huang, accompanied by TSU spokesmen Su Chin-chiang and Chen Chien-ming, along with several other TSU legislative candidates, unveiled the manifesto at a press conference. They repeatedly chanted in unison their slogan to "unite and move forward for a strong Taiwan."

The TSU announced that party politics and parliamentary politics in Taiwan have not contributed to the country's democratic development but have rather become the biggest obstacle to its healthy development.

Huang, a former minister of the interior who is closely linked to former Republic of China President and former Kuomintang Chairman Lee Teng-hui, said that TSU members have decided to pursue the goal of a stable political situation, a revived economy, a solid democracy and a strong Taiwan.

On the basic stance of the TSU, Huang said that the ROC "is an independent sovereign state standing firm in the world," and that cross-strait relations are not about unification or independence, but about "different natures of democracy and freedom."

The people on both sides of the Taiwan Strait share the same language and have similar ethnic feelings, the present cross-strait relationship should be "based on the Republic of China and the People's Republic of China concurrently existing in the world" and they should engage with each other on an equal footing and on a mutually beneficial basis, according to the manifesto.

It also claimed that Taiwan, Penghu, Kinmen and Matsu are a single community and that there should be no ethnic or even regional differences, with everyone identifying with Taiwan and prepared to fight for Taiwan.

Huang stressed that the government should root out "black gold politics," saying that the government should deal severely with vote-buying in the year-end elections, especially vote-buying by a "super conglomerate" with huge party assets -- an oblique jab at the opposition Kuomintang.
The manifesto stressed that the party is being formed in order to "serve the people" and that the TSU will be "adamantly opposed to political parties engaged in endless political squabbling."

Lee, the "spiritual father" of the TSU, raised the ire of KMT members when he said that he wanted to form a political party to help the present minority government of President Chen Shui-bian gain enough seats to form a stable majority in the year-end legislative election.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL FIGURES TO CONVERGE IN TAIWAN FOR `PEACE' DRIVE

TEXT.P: Scores of prominent international figures, including six Nobel Peace Prize winners, have been invited to Taipei next week for a "Voice from Taiwan, Peace and Love" campaign initiated by Republic of China Vice President Annette Lu.
Lu said at a news conference Wednesday that the campaign will be launched Aug. 15 in commemoration of the end of World War II 56 years ago.

Noting that peace can only be secured with wisdom, Lu said that in the face of mainland China's mounting military threat, Taiwan must use what she described as "its unique soft national power" to win international support.
"Only by so doing can the small `Taiwan kitten' withstand the perennial threat of the fierce `China lion,'" Lu stressed.
Lu said she was moved by the fact that local organizers of the event have invited a number of international dignitaries to attend the "Voice from Taiwan" activity.

"This indicates that the international community is highly supportive of Taiwan. The people of Taiwan should not be pessimistic about the island's future," said Lu, an outspoken critic of mainland China's military threat and diplomatic embargo against Taiwan.

The Nobel Peace Prize winners invited to attend the event include former Polish President Lech Walesa; Oscar Arias Sanchez, who served as Costa Rica's president from 1986 to 1990; former South African President F.W. de Clerk and Betty Williams, a peace advocate from Ireland.

In addition to the Nobel Prize winners, lawmakers and parliamentarians from many friendly nations and chief executive officers from 11 NGO groups have agreed to take part in the "Voice from Taiwan" drive, which will feature a 2001 Global Peace Assembly forum scheduled for Aug. 15-16 and an Evening for Global Peace slated for Aug. 15.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC GOVERNMENT URGED TO STRENGTHEN TIES WITH MONGOLIA

TEXT.P: A senior official of the Cabinet-level Mongolian and Tibetan Commission suggested Wednesday that the government should join other Asian nations and render assistance to Mongolia in order to strengthen relations with the country.

Wang Wei-fang, a counselor at the commission, said that Mongolia has been promoting relations with foreign countries since early this year and its relations with South Korea, Singapore and Japan are closer than ever before.
The government of the Republic of China has made efforts to promote bilateral relations between the ROC and Mongolia since 1991, Wang went on.

Promoting multilateral relations has become a key point of foreign relations around the world since the rearrangement of the superpower map in 1990, Wang pointed out. Mongolia's president and premier visited economically developed countries in Asia already this year, she said.

She added that Mongolia has been struggling with political and economic transformation since the Soviet Union collapsed and that this has provided an opportunity for economically powerful Asian countries such as Japan, South Korea and Singapore to fill the vacuum left by the Soviet Union.
Japan, South Korea and Singapore will present their political and economic reforms for Mongolia as reference and eventually establish reciprocal relations with Mongolia, Wang said.

She went on to point out that relations between the ROC and Mongolia, even though they have been conducted since 1991, have been largely unsuccessful, and suggested that the government play a more positive role in promoting bilateral relations.

DOC.HEADLINE: Q2 ECONOMIC GROWTH RATE ABOVE ZERO: CEPD OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: Despite the fact that Taiwan's economic growth rate had slowed as compared to the percentage posted in the first quarter, the ratio for the second quarter of this year should be between 1 percent and zero, a government official said Wednesday.

Lee Kao-chao, vice chairman of the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development, forecast that the Q2 economic growth rate should be able to hit around 1 percent if private-sector consumption, which accounts for 62 percent of the country's economy, has not dwindled too much.

According to Lee, Taiwan's trade surplus grew from US$1.3 billion in the first quarter to US$3.3 billion in the second quarter, which will contribute a 2.7 percent rise in the country's economy. During the same three-month period, private investments and product stocks increased slightly, he noted.
Lee's forecast echoes a prediction by an official with the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics last week, which also put the Q2 economic growth rate at 1 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN MEDIA HEADS CALL ON COUNTERPARTS IN BEIJING
DOC.DATELINE: Beijing, Aug. 8 (CNA) (By Lee An-tung and Fang Wen-hung)

TEXT.P: A group of visiting media heads from Taiwan called on their counterparts in the mainland Chinese capital of Beijing Wednesday.

The delegation, headed by Cheng Chia-lin, president of Taiwan's Chinese Press Institute, visited China Central Television, where the deputy editor in chief, Zhao Lifan, said that Republic of China government regulations are restricting the number of mainland Chinese media allowed to station reporters in Taiwan at the same time.

While visiting mainland China's state-run Xinhua News Agency, Ma Shengrong, vice president of the 12,000-employee news organization, urged related ROC government agencies to relax such "unfair" regulations because mainland China does not have similar restrictions on reporters from Taiwan.
He said that his agency was able to send five reporters to Taiwan in the past but currently has no reporter stationed there because of the policy.

When Shaw Yu-ming, chairman of Taiwan's Central Daily News, inquired further, Ma pointed out that when Shaw was still director-general of the ROC Government Information Office, mainland reporters could not even apply to cover news in Taiwan.

The Taiwan media delegation also called on the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS), a quasi-official organization that acts as counterpart to Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF).
The group also met with Li Bingcai, deputy director of the Taiwan Affairs Office under the mainland Chinese State Council, and Lin Zepeng, director of the China News Service.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT ASKS VOTERS TO APPLY PRESSURE ON OPPOSITION FOR COOPERATION

TEXT.P: A Kuomintang (KMT) senior official turned to supporters of the KMT and its two allies to put pressure on the so-called "pan-blue forces" to cooperate, rather than compete against each other in the year-end elections.

Amid signs that the KMT and its two splinter groups, the People First Party and the New Party, have failed to jointly field candidates for local government heads, Liu Chao-shuan, the vice chairman of a KMT think tank, the National Policy Foundation, asked that supporters of the three parties demand that the party leaders sort out their differences instead of competing against each other and playing into the hands of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP).

In a speech at the meeting of the KMT Central Standing Committee, Liu said the KMT is still confident that cooperation by the three parties can be obtained given the strong desire from their supporters for them to find common ground.

The pressure from their supporters will force the three parties to compete shoulder to shoulder against the DPP despite the fact that their leaders might have their own axes to grind and their candidates might have personal feuds against each other, Liu said.
Liu appealed to the supporters of the "pan-blue forces" to withdraw their support to any one of the three parties whose leaders balk at or block efforts at cooperation.

He also suggested that the KMT conduct polls among candidates from the three parties as a guideline for the public to better understand their policies and, therefore, get some feel for which candidate has the best chance of winning.

Liu also recommended that his party form a shadow Cabinet to show its supporters what kind of government they could expect if the party wins a majority in the legislature and, therefore, were to be asked to form a Cabinet.
With five-decades of experience in ruling, Liu said the KMT has the most talented people to form the best ruling team, which ought to be made up of members of the "pan-blue forces," he said.

The KMT, which is the leading party in the legislature, has always advocated that any party which controls the legislature should form the backbone of the government under what it calls the bi-headed governmental system. The idea has been rejected by President Chen Shui-bian and his DPP.
Liu said the shadow Cabinet will help the KMT to sell its bi-headed governmental system to the voters.

Wednesday's meeting is the first for the KMT's newly-elected 31 Central Standing Committee members, during which KMT Chairman Lien Chan said it is the KMT's inescapable obligation to unite the other two parties to compete with the DPP in the year-end elections.

KMT Secretary-General Lin Fong-cheng said after the meeting that his party has not changed its stance of working together with the PFP and the New Party according to the wishes of the supporters of the three parties.
However, cooperation for the elections is a difficult task, and the three parties have agreed not to attack each other and vie for victory on their own.
Meaningful cooperation will begin only after the elections, Lin said.

DOC.HEADLINE: US SENATOR CHRISTOPHER BOND ARRIVING FOR TWO-DAY VISIT

TEXT.P: U.S. Senator Christopher Bond (R-MO) is scheduled to arrive in Taipei Thursday at the head of a five-member delegation for a two-day visit to the Republic of China, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs announced Wednesday.

While in Taipei, they will meet Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian and call on Minister of Foreign Affairs Tien Hung-mao and Minister of National Defense Wu Shih-wen. The purpose of their trip is to strengthen bilateral cooperation on investment and trade between Taiwan and the State of Missouri.

Christopher Bond was born in St. Louis in 1939. Bond became the 47th governor of the State of Missouri at 33 years of age on Jan. 8, 1973 -- the youngest governor the state has ever had. He was reelected to a second term as governor in 1980. Bond continued his service to Missouri from his newly won seat in the United States Senate.
Bond is a very good friend of Taiwan who has fully supported the Taiwan's bid to join the United Nations. He has visited the island three times in 1982, 1992 and 1995.
He and his entourage are scheduled to depart from Taipei Friday.

DOC.HEADLINE: MINISTER YEH CHU-LAN TO VISIT TOURISM INDUSTRY IN JAPAN, US

TEXT.P: Minister of Transportation and Communications Yeh Chu-lan is scheduled to leave Friday for a visit to the United States and Japan where she will observe tourism development and try to lure more Japanese investors to the tourism industry in Taiwan.

The main purpose of her upcoming U.S. and Japan trip will be to study the management of a resort villa in Las Vegas, the astronomical equipment at Hawaii Volcano National Park and hot springs in Japan.

Minister Yeh said she hoped that she can better understand management of the resort villa in Las Vegas and how it was successfully transformed in a desert, how the Hawaii Volcano National Park maintains its image and how Japan develops its hot springs tourism.

In addition, Yeh will introduce the Japanese tourist industry to the two biggest tourism investment projects being undertaken in Taiwan. They are the Tapeng Bay in Pingtung County in southern Taiwan and the Chinlun Hot Springs in Taitung County in eastern Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PRESIDENT HEARS PROGRESS OF ECONOMIC ADVISORY CONFERENCE

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian said Wednesday that the upcoming Economic Development Advisory Conference "must be a success" so that the countrymen will not be disappointed.
He made the remarks while hearing reports on the progress of the five divisions under the advisory conference.

As the five divisions are required to present their conclusions by Aug. 18 for final-stage discussions, Chen asked the Cabinet ministers responsible for division discussions to brief him on the progress of their preparations.
The president expressed his thanks to the officials for their efforts to ensure a successful conference.
He asked relevant ministries and agencies to consider drafting and amending related laws for prompt implementation of the conference's conclusions.
Chen told the participants that the cross-party conference carries the "maximum expectations" of the people and added that it "must be a success -- failure is not permissible."
During the division discussions, he said, the delegates from all quarters should be encouraged to present their various opinions before reaching a consensus.

Chen reiterated that he will faithfully respect the conclusions reached at the conference and the government should have 100 percent determination to implement the conclusions without any reservations.
As some topics cannot be settled by a single division, the president asked the organizers to consider convening joint meetings of related divisions.
He hoped that a pre-conference meeting by the conveners of the five divisions could be held in mid-August to coordinate their decisions before the start of the division discussions.

The officials who attended the day's meeting at the Presidential Office included Premier Chang Chun-hsiung, Presidential Secretary-General You Hsi-kun, Vice Premier Lai In-jaw, Minister of Economic Affairs Lin Hsin-yi, Executive Yuan Secretary-General Chiou I-jen, Mainland Affairs Council Chairwoman Tsai Eng-wen, Minister of Finance Yen Ching-chang, Minister of Transportation and Communications Yeh Chu-lan, Environmental Protection Administration chief Hau Lung-bin, Council of Agriculture Chairman Chen Hsi-huang, Council for Economic Planning and Development Chairman Chen Po-chih, Council of Labor Chairperson Chen Chu, and deputy presidential secretaries-general Chen Che-nan and Chien You-hsin.

DOC.HEADLINE: LABOR OFFICIAL IN FAVOR OF WAGE PROTECTION FOR FOREIGN WORKERS

TEXT.P: Taiwan's top labor official said Wednesday that she opposes the idea that foreign laborers' wages will no longer be subject to the country's minimum wage requirement, as the Republic of China is a country that values equality while pursuing competitiveness.

Chen Chu, chairwoman of the Cabinet-level Council of Labor Affairs (CLA), made the remark in response to a suggestion made by a presidential policy coordination panel that foreign workers not be subject to the minimum wage limit as stipulated in the country's Labor Standards Law.

The nine-member panel, composed of high ranking officials from the Presidential Office, Legislative Yuan, ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), and DPP caucus in the Legislative Yuan, has been asked by President Chen Shui-bian to study ways to reduce foreign labor costs for local entrepreneurs.

President Chen has been very concerned about the fact that among Asian countries, the foreign labor cost in Taiwan is behind only South Korea, but is 2.79 times that of Singapore and 1.42 times that of Hong Kong.

The Republic of China ratified an international convention on basic wages in 1930 and an international anti-occupational discrimination convention in 1961. As a result, foreign laborers in Taiwan are subject to the same protection as their local counterparts.

Chen Chu said that it is not yet a decision but a request by the panel that the CLA evaluate the idea. For this, she said Taiwan is a country that respects laborers while pursuing progress, therefore, it has the minimum wage regulation.

However, if foreign laborers are no longer protected by the minimum wage regulation, it is not only a step backwards, but could also cause disputes in the International Labour Organization, a group dedicated to the pursuit of social justice.

Chen noted that she understands the difficulty in Taiwan's economic development and suggested that foreign laborers' minimum wage be calculated on an hourly rather than a monthly basis, or have their salaries include board as is the case for local laborers.
At present, foreign laborers' salaries do not include board and employers have to spend more to cover this cost, Chen said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TZU CHI TO CONTINUE PROVIDING CARE FOR TYPHOON VICTIMS
DOC.DATELINE: Hualien, eastern Taiwan, Aug. 8 (CNA) (By Victor Lai)

TEXT.P: Dharma Master Cheng Yen, founder of the Buddhist Tzu Chi Compassionate and Relief Foundation, said Wednesday that Tzu Chi will continue to provide care for residents affected by Typhoon Toraji.
Tzu Chi, the largest charity organization in Taiwan, joined the rescue and relief operations soon after Toraji swept eastern and central Taiwan July 30.
The typhoon had claimed over 100 lives as of Wednesday, with some 120 others remaining unaccounted for.
In the past 10 days, Tzu Chi has mobilized over 2,900 volunteers to join the rescue and relief operations, mainly in Hualien and Nantou counties.
They provided hot meals and drinking water for 13,000 and medical treatment for 430, and helped clean 78 mud-filled houses.
Twelve prefabricated houses for the affected residents are being built by Tzu Chi at Chienching village in Wanjung township, Hualien County. They will be completed by the end of this month.
Tzu Chi has also distributed relief funds to 508 households and set up six service stations in disaster areas.
Cheng Yen presided over a meeting to review the rescue and relief operations Wednesday and said that Tzu Chi must continue providing care for the affected people.
Regarding whether to help reconstruction of damaged schools and resettlement of the affected residents, she said that Tzu Chi "will continue to make assessments."
Tzu Chi has not launched a campaign to raise funds for those left in need by the typhoon, but its members in the United States and Malaysia have begun collecting donations.
After the devastating earthquake that struck central Taiwan Sept. 21, 1999, Tzu Chi used more than NT$8 billion to rebuild over 50 destroyed schools in quake-affected regions.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI CITY MAYOR VISITS SEOUL

TEXT.P: Taipei City Mayor Ma Ying-jeou arrived in Seoul from Kuala Lumpur Wednesday morning for a three-day visit.
He was greeted by the Republic of China Representative to South Korea Lee Tsung-ju and officials from the Seoul City Hall at the Jinsen International Airport.
Ma and his entourage visited a football stadium on their way from the airport to Seoul.

The football stadium, designed to host the 2005 World Cup Football Championship, and with a capacity of 64,677 seats, is 94 percent completed. It is built on a landfill used by Seoul as a garbage dumping site between 1978 and 1993.
The Taipei delegation was reportedly impressed with the reclamation efforts and the fact that the land has also been turned into five beautiful parks in addition to the stadium.

Wednesday afternoon, Ma and his entourage went to a guest house of the Seoul City Government to be briefed on the city's garbage collection operations, including pig swill collection, and resources recycling operations.
Ma asked questions and took notes during the briefing.
After the briefing, Ma was escorted to a swill treatment center, a resources recycling center and an Internet cafe.
He is scheduled to attend the opening ceremony of a ceramic exhibition.
Seoul is the second leg of Ma's three-city trip in Asia which has already taken him to Kuala Lumpur and will bring him to Fukuoda, Japan on Aug. 11 before returning to Taiwan on Aug. 15.

DOC.HEADLINE: NATIONAL SECURITY PERSONNEL SHUFFLE CONFIRMED

TEXT.P: Sources within the Office of the President confirmed Wednesday evening that the national security system's top leadership posts will undergo a personnel shuffle.

According to the sources, Chuang Ming-yao, secretary-general of the National Security Council under the Office of the President, will become the new secretary-general of the Association of East Asian Relations -- a semi-official organization in charge of dealing with Japan in the absence of official diplomatic ties between the two countries.
Chuang's original post will be filled by Ting Yu-chou, head of the National Security Bureau, a subsidiary organ to the National Security Council.
Ting's vacated position will be filled by his deputy, Tsai Chao-ming.
Meanwhile, Hsu Chu-sheng, head of the Military Intelligence Bureau, will be replaced by Hsueh Shih-ming, commanding general of the Kinmen Defense Command.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOV'T URGED TO ADOPT MEASURES TO DEAL WITH WTO ENTRY

TEXT.P: Participants on a panel in preparation for the Economic Development Advisory Conference later this month reached consensus on several measures Wednesday, including advocating of signing of a bilateral free trade agreement with other nations, to deal with the situation following Taiwan's entry into the World Trade Organization (WTO).
The participants said that Taiwan can increase regional integration and upgrade overall competitiveness through the signing of bilateral free trade agreements with other nations.
They urged the government to help businesses avoid dumping charges by other countries by providing them with comprehensive information to help them deal with lawsuits.

They also said the government should present a detailed assessment every six months on the impact on related industries, the strategy to deal with them, and the progress of implementing such strategies and the performance after Taiwan's entry into the WTO.
The government should also set a pre-warning system for major products after WTO entry, they said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies on Thursday are as follows:
The China Times:
Ting Yu-chou to be promoted to the post of secretary-general of the National Security Council (NSC), while Tsai Chao-ming will succeed Ting as National Security Bureau (NSB) chief.
The United Daily News:

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, Aug. 9, or the 20th day of the sixth month of the Year of the Snake according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1757: Thomas Telford, Scottish bridge engineer, is born. He is best known for engineering the construction of the suspension bridge over the Menai Strait in Wales and the construction of Calendonian Canal between 1823-33 in Scotland.
1794: General Napoleon Bonaparte is arrested in France on suspicions of Robespierrism.
1814: Under the terms of the Treaty of Fort Jackson signed between the U.S. government and the native Creek tribe, the Creeks lose 9.3 million hectares of land -- over half of Alabama and part of southern Georgia -- to the United States.
1842: The United States signs the Webster-Ashburton Treaty with Britain, establishing the boundary between the U.S. and Canada from Maine to the Great Lakes.
1867: John Harrison Surratt is arrested for being an alleged conspirator in the assassination of President Abraham Lincoln.
1902: Edward VII, 64, is crowned King of Great Britain and Ireland after a six-week delay due to an emergency appendectomy.
1903: Giuseppe Sarto becomes Pope Pius X following the death of Pope Leo XIII.
1919: India concludes a secret pact with Britain, recognizing Britain as India's protector after Britain promised India a major role in its own government.
1928: Italian divers find precious diamonds in the wreckage of "Elizabethville," a Belgian ship sunk during World War I.
1937: Japanese troops clash with Chinese forces at Hungchiao airport in Shanghai.
1938: Rod Laver, Australian tennis star, is born. He won the singles title at Wimbledon four times.
1942: Mohandas K. Gandhi, leader of the Indian National Congress, is arrested in Britain for his "Quit India" campaign, which demands that the British should withdraw from India.
1945: Soviet troops enter Manchuria after the Soviet Union declares war on Japan.
1946: Henry Pu Yi, who was enthroned as the "Emperor of Manchukuo" in Changchun by Japanese militarists on Mar. 1, 1934, arrives in Tokyo to testify before an international court against Japanese war crimes committed during the invasion of China.
1954: The Republic of China Navy sinks 12 Communist Chinese ships at Tungshan seaport, Dongshan Island, near Fukien province.
1965: Singapore is separated from Malaysia and becomes an independent state within the Commonwealth of Nations.
1973: Ku Cheng-kang, honorary chairman of the World Anti-Communist League, leaves for Washington to attend a WACL Executive Committee meeting.
1974: Gerald R. Ford is sworn in as the 38th president of the United States after the resignation of Richard Nixon.
1979: Councilors in the English seaside town of Brighton cause a furor by agreeing to allow naturalists to bare all on "Cliff Beach," one of the less popular beaches in the district.
1990: Communist China's first airship, with a length of 40 meters, makes its maiden flight over Hupei province.
1994: The U.S. government announces trade sanctions against the ROC under the Pelly Amendment, placing a ban on imports of Taiwan wildlife products effective from August 19, 1994.
1999: The China External Trade Development Council signs a memorandum of understanding on technological cooperation with the Agency for International Development of Technology and Trade under the Trade and Industry Ministry of France.
1999: President Lee Teng-hui says the main reason he voiced the "special state-to-state relations" statement regarding cross-Taiwan Strait ties the previous month was to elucidate the fact that the Republic of China exists in the world.
2000: The Chinese International Economic Cooperation Association is established to promote Taiwan's trade and cooperation with the international community.
2000: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou signs the "Manifesto 2000" to throw his support behind the United Nations campaign for the development of a culture of peace and non-violence.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "There is only one way to gain confidence for one's authority. If a man is not trusted by one's friends, he will not gain the confidence for his authority."

DOC.HEADLINE: ENVIRONMENTALISTS RUNNING VEGETABLE OIL-POWERED BUS ACROSS CANADA

TEXT.P: A group of young environmentalists are trying to drive home a message to Canadians -- save the earth from greenhouse gas emissions before it is too late.

Their tool for sending out this message is a bus that runs on vegetable oil. A group that calls itself Climate Change Caravan is taking the bus across Canada from Vancouver to Halifax to focus attention on the urgent need to reduce greenhouse gas emissions.

At seven or eight miles to the gallon, the bus is not exactly fuel efficient. At about US$4.20 per liter, it's more than four times the price of gasoline, which currently costs about US$1 per liter in Canada.

But the environmentally friendly point is that the bus uses recycled oil. "It would be costly if we got it unused, but we get the oil from restaurants that deep-fry their food, and we just need to filter out all of the chunks of French fries and put the oil right into our bus. So it actually runs free," Climate Change Caravan Spokesman Graeme Verhulst said.
At stops on their Vancouver to Halifax trip, members of the caravan set up a windmill and a solar panel to power up their laptops and cell phones.

Verhulst pointed out that the level of greenhouse gas emissions from vegetable oil is about 50 percent lower than that from gasoline. "There is a little bit more nitrous oxide emitted, but no sulfites whatsoever, which is a big part of what makes up smog," he said.
The caravan, which also includes about 30 cyclists, was in Ottawa on Wednesday urging the federal government to increase its greenhouse gas emission targets.
Governments worldwide, including the government of Canada, are talking about reducing greenhouse gas emissions by between 5 percent and 6 percent, Verhulst noted.

"Scientists are calling for greenhouse gas reductions of between 50 (percent) and 80 percent in order to stabilize the climate at a safe level," he said, pointing out that "this is clearly not in the same ballpark."

He claimed that the unusually warm weather much of Canada is experiencing this summer proves that climate change is a serious issue. The resident of British Columbia warned that the problem will only get worse unless people start conserving energy.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER TO VISIT 4 ROC DIPLOMATIC ALLIES IN CARIBBEAN

TEXT.P: Premier Chang Chun-hsiung will visit four Republic of China diplomatic allies located in the eastern Caribbean, the vice minister of foreign affairs confirmed Thursday.

Wu Tzu-dan stressed that the premier's visit will be significant and that his itinerary will not overlap with Foreign Affairs Minister Tien Hung-mao's visit to the Caribbean in late August, pointing out the nature of the two visits is different.
He added that Tien will take part in a meeting of foreign ministers and the premier will be invited to attend significant events.

The four allies have invited the premier to lead a delegation for a visit, said Wu, noting that the MOFA is now making arrangements for the visit. He added that the details of the premier's visit will be announced later.

Government Spokesman Su Tzen-ping said that for diplomatic reasons, the MOFA will assess the feasibility of the ROC president, vice president or the presidents of the five yuans visiting ROC allies or nations that maintain substantial relations with the ROC but do not have formal diplomatic relations with it, and will then make suggestions to them after making its assessments.
Su said that the ROC government will announce any such visits in due time, adding that he could not confirm or deny the premier's trip to the Caribbean.
He made the remarks when responding to news about the premier's trip to Saint Christopher and Nevis, Saint Vincent and the Grenadines, Dominica, as well as Grenada.

The reports said that the premier's trip was arranged before Typhoon Toraji swept across Taiwan July 29-30. With the nation now focused on post-disaster reconstruction, the reports said the announcement of the visit is being cautiously assessed by the Executive Yuan.

It is learned that the premier's visit will fall sometime between the conclusion of the Economic Development Advisory Conference, to take place Aug. 24-26, and the start of the new session of the Legislative Yuan in early September.
If everything goes well and the trip takes place, it will represent Premier Chang's first overseas visit since assuming his current post.

Overseas Chinese living in Southeast Asia had earlier in his term invited the premier to visit the region, but Chang responded at that time by saying that it might be difficult for him to visit the countries in the region in his capacity as the ROC premier.

Chang, a devout Christian, was also invited to Seoul in May by South Korean legislators to attend a Taiwan and South Korean Christian parliamentarian alliance ceremony, but the premier said at that time that he appreciated the invitation but had no intention of taking an overseas trip.

Meanwhile, Lee Cheng-chung, a party whip of the opposition Kuomintang in the Legislature, said Thursday that he is opposed to any overseas trips by President Chen Shui-bian or the premier in the aftermath of Typhoon Toraji, pointing out that this is typhoon season and "not a time for tourism."

Citing reports of the president's planned visit to Denmark and the premier's planned visit to ROC diplomatic allies in the Caribbean, he said they are "rushing on overseas visits" and "leaving disaster-relief work behind."

He lamented the fact that the Executive Yuan told the Legislative Yuan earlier in the week that there is "no money for disaster relief but that they now seem to "have money to spend on traveling overseas."

DOC.HEADLINE: U.N. BID AIMED AT HIGHLIGHTING UNFAIR TREATMENT ROC ENDURES: ENVOY
DOC.DATELINE: Los Angeles, Aug. 9 (CNA) (By Lawrence Chu and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The Republic of China's bid to join major international organizations is mainly aimed at highlighting the unfair treatment it has endured in the world society, ROC Representative to the United States Chen Chien-jen said Wednesday.

In a speech delivered at a lunch meeting organized by the Los Angeles World Affairs Council, Chen said although the ROC's road to the United Nations may be rugged, the ROC government and people will not be daunted by any stumbling block standing in the way.
"The main purpose of our U.N. bid is to call for world attention to the unfair and unreasonable treatment our country has received over the past years," Chen told his audience.

Since 1992, the ROC has annually asked the U.N. General Assembly through its diplomatic allies to tackle issues regarding Taiwan's representation in the world body. However, its bid had consistently been shot down at the U.N. Steering Committee meeting and failed to make the General Assembly agenda due to mainland China's opposition.
This year, 10 of the ROC's allies have filed a similar request with the U.N. Secretariat. Its fate remains unclear as the Steering Committee has yet to discuss the issue.
The ROC, a U.N. founding member, has been shut out of the United Nations since mainland China took over the China seat in the world body in 1971.

In his speech, titled "A Robust Relationship: The Republic of China on Taiwan and the United States," Chen recognized the current constructive development in bilateral relations between the two countries.
The de facto ROC ambassador to the United States also said he himself is confident and optimistic about the future prospects for substantive ROC-U.S. relations.
As many American political and economic analysts have expressed concern about Taiwan's current economic downturn, Chen made some explanations in his speech.

Chen pointed out that Taiwan's present economic plight is largely related to a lingering global economic slowdown. With its economic strength, Chen said, Taiwan would certainly be able to overcome its current cyclic recession.
Touching on Taiwan's bid to join the World Trade Organization, Chen said the ROC is likely to be admitted to the Geneva-based world trade regulatory body in November or late this year.
Meanwhile, Chen said, the ROC hopes that the United States can take active steps to help promote Taiwan's bid to join the World Health Organization as an observer.

DOC.HEADLINE: TEACHER WHO DROWNED ESCORTING STUDENTS TO SAFETY CITED BY PRESIDENT
DOC.DATELINE: Yuanlin, central Taiwan, Aug. 9 (CNA) (By Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Elementary school teacher Hsu Pi-lan, who drowned while escorting pupils to safety at the height of a flood wrought by Typhoon Toraji, was commemorating Wednesday for her unselfishness with a national outpouring of grief and respect.

Education Minister Ovid Tzeng presented a citation awarded by President Chen Shui-bian to Hsu's husband Hung Chih-ying, who is also a teacher, lauding the young school teacher for the unselfish love she demonstrated to her students in the moment of crisis.

Hsu drowned July 30, probably because of fatigue, after making numerous trips back and forth from the school alongside a turbulent river to escort her first-grade students to higher ground. The water level of the turbulent river along which she was carrying out the rescue rose suddenly during the height of the typhoon.
Hsu was washed away downstream by the flood waters before the very eyes of her young students. Her body was found later in the day in a ditch along the river.

Although it was the summer break, teachers and students returned to the school July 30 for a mid-vacation back-to-school day, and the local authorities in Yuanlin were caught unprepared for the devastation that would be brought by the typhoon, failing to notify the school in time to cancel the event.
Hsu, a graduate of National Changhua Teachers University, had only been married to Hung for less than two years and had only recently become a mother, giving birth to a baby son two months earlier.
President Chen Shui-bian turned up at the home of Hsu and Hung earlier this week to pay his respects to Hsu and express his condolences to her family members.
During the funeral, Hsu's father, restraining his grief over the loss of his daughter, said he hopes Hsu's son will grow up healthy and someday become a teacher like his mother.
Hsu's father-in-law vowed at the funeral that he will see to it that a bridge is built near the school so that teachers and students will no longer suffer similar hardships going home in bad weather.

DOC.HEADLINE: PARAGUAYAN PRESIDENT RECEIVES ROC CHILDREN'S SOCCER TEAM
DOC.DATELINE: Asuncion, Aug. 8 (CNA) (By Ramon Huang and Rachael Yang)

TEXT.P: Paraguayan President Luis Angel Gonzalez Macchi met a soccer team from a Republic of China junior high school Wednesday morning, wishing the team a happy time while in Paraguay.
The soccer team also called on Minister of Foreign Affairs Jose Antonio Moreno Ruffinelli, who confirmed that he is scheduled to visit the ROC in late August.

The soccer team of Lan-ya Junior High School, located at Tien Mu in Taipei City, consists of 15 boys and two girls, including the daughter of Paraguayan Ambassador to the ROC Ceferino Valdez as well as children of foreign expatriates residing in Taipei.
The Lan-ya team, led by Tzeng Cheng-chi, principal of the school, arrived in Asuncion on Aug. 7 for a goodwill visit.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI STOCK EXCHANGE

TEXT.P: Share prices opened low and closed even lower on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Thursday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 65.58 points, or 1.5 percent, to close at 4,448.52.

On the back of losses on Wall Street and a slump in electronics and financial stock prices, the bourse opened at 4,469.92, hitting a high of 4,521.16 points and a low of 4,445.15 during the four-and-half-hour trading session.
A total of 1.99 billion shares changes hands on a market turnover of NT$52.218 billion (US$1.5 billion).

Three out of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with plastics and chemical stocks moving up the most at 1.4 percent, followed by textile issues at 0.7 percent, and pulp and paper shares at 0.3 percent. Cement stocks remained unchanged.

The other major categories posted losses, with electrical and electronics shares moving down the most at 2.0 percent, followed by financial stocks and construction shares, both at 1.0 percent, and foodstuff stocks at 0.1 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 297 to 184, with 103 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN IT INDUSTRY REGISTERS UNPRECEDENTED NEGATIVE GROWTH

TEXT.P: The production value of Taiwan's information technology industry amounted to US$17.125 billion for the first half of this year, down 13 percent from that of the same period the previous year, according to a report released Thursday.

The report by Market Intelligence Center (MIC) of the Institute for Information Industry showed that the center has revised downward its forecast for the Taiwan IT industry's production value for 2001 for the third time since early this year.

The MIC report forecasted that Taiwan's IT industry will show negative growth in its production value for this year, with output estimated to reach only US$37.714 billion, down 19.79 percent from that of last year.
The international market for IT hardware products has been sluggish due to the global economic slowdown and the high levels of inventory.

Sales of notebooks, CDT monitors, motherboards, desktop computers, DVD players and scanners have declined considerably over the past several months, and only LCD monitors and digital cameras have demonstrated a growth in sales, according to the MIC report.

A breakdown of the report's figures shows that in the first half of this year, the notebook sector registered a 4 percent decline in sales volume and a 16.9 percent decline in value, the monitor sector showed a 12.7 percent decline in production volume and a 19.7 percent drop in value, while the desktop sector registered a 9.5 percent decline in production volume and a 14.1 percent drop in value.

The report also said that the market for notebooks is expected to gradually recover in the second half of this year. However, the profit margin of Taiwan's OEM notebook factories may shrink further if and when international firms apply price cuts to grab more market share.

DOC.HEADLINE: TEXTILE MANUFACTURERS HOPE TO IMPROVE COMPETITIVENESS THROUGH MERGERS

TEXT.P: Executives of Taiwan's leading textile manufacturers met with Minister of Economic Affairs Lin Hsin-yi Thursday to study merger possibilities in order to improve their competitiveness, according to an official of the Industrial Development Bureau.

Shih Yen-hsiang, director-general of the Industrial Development Bureau, said that Taiwan's textile industry has been facing problems of sluggish business due to oversupply of fibers and yarns in the international market. It is estimated that Taiwan's fiber and yarn production capacity is at least 20 percent over demand.
Textile manufacturers had been major foreign exchange earners for Taiwan before the traditional industries ran into difficulties.

Production value of the textile industry in 2000 amounted to NT$468,722 million, accounting for 5.53 percent of the production value of all manufacturing industries. In 1996, production value of the textile industry accounted for 8.76 percent of the overall production value of the manufacturing sector, according to statistics compiled by the Taiwan Textile Federation (TTF).

The TTF statistics indicate that in 1997 Taiwan's textile industry employed 285,730 workers, representing 12 percent of the workforce of the manufacturing sector. By 2000, the number of employees of the textile industry totaled only 239,024, representing 9.8 percent of the manufacturing workforce.

Manufacturers have reached agreement that Taiwan's textile industry must lower their production costs and avoid cut-throat competition, and the only way to maintain their international competitiveness is through mergers and cooperation.
The Industrial Development Bureau will play an active role in coordinating the planning and processing of the mergers.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN-AUSTRALIA ENERGY CONFAB FOCUSES ON LNG PURCHASE PLAN

TEXT.P: Officials from Taiwan and Australia have been focusing their discussions over the last two days on a liquefied natural gas (LNG) purchase plan by the state-run Taiwan Power Co. (Taipower).

The negotiators from the two sides, however, failed to reach any agreement as of Thursday noon concerning a mammoth Taipower LNG purchase plan for a proposed hydraulic power plant in central Taiwan and a related project for an LNG receiving station.

Australian LNG suppliers and exporters have long expressed interest in the Taipower LNG purchase plan and have cooperated with Dutch Shell to try to win the bid for the NT$400 billion contract. There are several other multinational concerns that have entered the bidding.
Taipower is planning to build a four-megawatt hydraulic power plant in Tahtan, central Taiwan, using LNG as fuel to generate the power.

The first generating unit of the Tahtan power plant is scheduled to become operational in 2003 and some 1.73 million metric tons of LNG are expected to be needed annually when the entire power plant is completed and all its planned generating units are running, Taipower officials who attended the two-day Taiwan-Australia Mineral and Energy Conference said.

The 25-year Taipower Tahtan LNG purchase contract, worth some NT$400 billion (US$11.56 billion), is more attractive than building two nuclear power plants in Taiwan, making it a key prospect for world energy suppliers and bidders, including the Australian-Dutch co-op, the French company Total Fina ELF, and U.S. oil giant Mobil.

The Australian-Dutch team plans to obtain LNG in Australia and sell the fossil fuel to Taiwan, while Total Fina ELF is said to be cooperating with Taiwan's Far Eastern Group in its bid, and Mobil is said to be sourcing LNG from Qatar, the Middle East, which it will then sell to a Taiwan-based construction and energy company.

The Taiwan construction and energy company, which is believed to have been financed by Mobil, has obtained a development license from the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) to build an LNG receiving terminal on the coast of Taoyuan, northern Taiwan. The legality of the development project has been questioned by foreign firms associated with the bidding.

The Australia-Dutch team has offered to build a movable LNG receiving station anywhere offshore facing the northern Taiwan counties of Taoyuan, Miaoli or Hsichu to facilitate the Taipower Tahtan LNG purchase plan. The MOEA officials, nevertheless, have not revealed their positions toward the idea.

Taipower conducted its first open bid for the Tahtan LNG purchases on Jan. 19 this year, but it was aborted because only two companies participated in the bid, which is insufficient according to the legal requirement of three bidders. The second such open bid is scheduled to be held Aug. 16, Taipower officials said.
Commenting on the development of the Taipower LNG purchase plan, MOEA officials who took part in the conference said the bids and all related businesses will be conducted "openly and transparently."
ROC Vice Minister of Economic Affairs Yin Chin-ming presided over a ceremony at the Taiwan Power Building Wednesday to open the conference.

Fang Liang-chi, executive secretary of the Energy Commission under the MOEA, and Tim Mackey, deputy executive director of the Australian Ministry of Industrial and Scientific Resources, were key negotiators representing Taiwan and Australia, respectively, during the two-day conference.
