DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI MAYOR TO SOLICIT VIEWS FROM FOREIGN BUSINESSMEN

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou will invite foreign businessmen in Taipei to attend a seminar later this month to solicit their views on living and doing business in Taiwan.

Ma will listen to their views about Taipei's traffic, investment environment, financial and tax measures as well as city administration. Both American and European chambers of commerce are expected to attend.
Richard Henson, president of the American Chamber of Commerce in Taipei, has confirmed that he will attend the seminar.

The European Chamber of Commerce in Taipei also said that many problems faced by foreign businessmen in Taiwan are not related to local governments, but it appreciates the Taipei City Government for willing to listen to their views.

It pointed out that foreign businessmen are generally positive about the improvement of living and traffic conditions in Taipei over the recent years, though they are reserved about its social order, especially rampant occurrence of break-ins in Tienmu on the outskirts of Taipei where many foreign businessmen live, adding that many of them have the unhappy experience of being burglarized.

Foreign businessmen said that Taipei will have to undergo internationalization to become an international metropolis to attract foreign investment. They cited the example of Wall Street in the United States, saying that it is famous for its financial service, and nobody would think of moving the manufacturing industry to New York.
They have, therefore, suggested that the future direction of development of Taipei City will not in the manufacturing industry, but in the service industry by creating a good investment environment.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN MARKETING OF GERMAN ANTI-CHOLESTEROL DRUG HALTED

TEXT.P: Even as Taiwan's health authorities began discussions about freezing a license to allow Bayer's cholesterol-lowering medicine, Baycol, to be sold in Taiwan, the German company's Taiwan operations decided Thursday to pull the plug on the drug.

Bayer announced Wednesday that it was stopping sales of Baycol, also called cerivastatin, in very country except Japan, after reports of muscle destruction linked to 31 U.S. deaths and at least nine more fatalities around the world since the drug was first introduced in 1997.
According to Hu You-pu, director of the Bureau of Medical Affairs (BMA) under the Cabinet-level Department of Health, Bayer has spent a year in Taiwan conducting human tests on Baycol.
Without any cases of adverse side-effects being reported over the past year, the BMA granted Bayer permission to sell the drug to hospitals in Taiwan a month ago, Hu said.
The marketing license for over-the-counter sales of Baycol, however, has not yet been issued to Bayer, Taiwan, He added.

Huang Yi-wen, a spokesman for Bayer, Taiwan, said Baycol was originally scheduled to be officially introduced around the island in October, but now the Taiwan marketing plan has been scrapped, irrespective of what Taiwan health authorities decide regarding licensing.

Baycol is one of an extraordinarily popular family of drugs called statins that dramatically lower cholesterol and reduce patients' risk of heart attacks. Yet every statin has been linked to very rare reports of the muscle side effect called rhabdomyolysis, according to foreign wire service reports.

DOC.HEADLINE: CONSTRUCTION ON TAIWAN'S HIGH-SPEED RAILWAY PROCEEDING SMOOTHLY

TEXT.P: A Taiwan High-Speed Rail Corp. (THSRC) spokesman said Thursday that construction on the island's much-anticipated high-speed rail system is proceeding smoothly and is not expected to suffer any major delay in its inauguration.

The spokesman was responding to a foreign wire service report that the high-profile Taiwan and Japanese bullet train project to link Taiwan's two biggest cities could face a setback due to gaps in opinion between the two sides over design and other details.

The report quoted unidentified Japanese sources as saying that the THSRC and Japan's Taiwan Shinkansen Consortium (TSC) have agreed on the model of the bullet train, but were stalled on the design of the railway line.

Those details, including format and materials, were supposed to be agreed upon by the end of May, the Japanese sources said. As the project has just begun, and if the two sides remain locked in a wrangle over such basic matters, the Japanese sources said, it is possible that the project could miss its October 2005 deadline.
"We were baffled by the report," said the THSRC spokesman who preferred to remain anonymous.

The spokesman said THSRC and TSC executives and engineers have met every month to exchange views on major contract provisions since the two groups formally struck the NT$95 billion (US$2.9 billion) deal on the new railway's core equipment and power system Dec. 12, 2000.

"Communications between the two sides have been smooth," the spokesman said, adding that there have been no major disagreements over the basic design and format of Taiwan's first high-speed rail project.

According to the spokesman, bidding for all of the rail system's 12 civil construction projects have been finalized and boring for the railway's first tunnel --- the Hsiashui Tunnel -- in Paoshan, Hsinchu County was completed in May.
Meanwhile, the spokesman said, a ceremony marking the finish of tunneling work for the railway's second tunnel in Tunghsiao, Miaoli County is scheduled to be held next Friday.
At the moment, the spokesman said, the THSRC remains fully confident that the new high-speed railway will be able to open to traffic in October 2005 as originally scheduled.

A CNA report from Tokyo also quoted TSC spokesman Toshihiko Nagao as having said that the project is moving smoothly and there is no major gap between the Japanese and Taiwanese sides concerning the design and format of the rail system.
TSC unexpectedly defeated the Alstom-Siemens Eurotrain consortium in December 1999 to win exclusive negotiating rights for the THSRC's core system and equipment contract.

The Japanese consortium is formed by a number of major Japanese trading and industrial companies, including Mitsubishi Heavy Industries, Marubeni Crop., Mitsui Corp., Sumitomo Corp., Kawasaki Heavy Industries and Toshiba Electric.

The new rail system, with a price tag of NT$446 billion (US$12.85 billion), is designed to shorten the travel time between Taipei in the north and Kaohsiung in the south. With a maximum speed of 300 kilometers per hour, a trip from Taipei to Kaohsiung with only a single stop at Taichung will take about 90 minutes.

It is the island's first infrastructure project built under a BOT (build-operate-transfer) formula, under which private contractors are authorized to build and operate the system for a fixed period, and should then transfer the system to the government after the period expires.

DOC.HEADLINE: PROMPT DECISION ON PERSONNEL RESHUFFLE AIMED AT AVOIDING CONFUSION

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian's prompt decision on a sweeping reshuffle of national security and military intelligence personnel is mainly aimed at avoiding unnecessary confusion, presidential aides said Thursday.
In a swift but low-profile move, the Presidential Office announced a major shake-up of the national security and military intelligence agencies Wednesday evening.

It was the largest-ever security and intelligence personnel reshuffle since President Chen assumed office in the Republic of China's first democratic transfer of power between different political parties in May 2000.
After more than a year of observation, presidential aides said, President Chen has become fully aware of the merits and flaws of various national security and military intelligence agencies.
"Against this backdrop, it's logical for Chen to make some personnel adjustments," a close aide said, adding that the quick, low-profile approach was designed to avert speculation and confusion.

There has been speculation about a possible military, intelligence and national security personnel reshuffle in recent weeks, causing difficulties for senior military officers, including Minister of National Defense Wu Shih-wen and Chief of the General Staff Tang Yao-ming.

But sources close to Chen said although intelligence and security agencies have close working relationships with the military, the latest security and intelligence personnel reshuffle does not necessarily imply that the military leadership would also undergo a shake-up.

In the latest personnel reshuffle, National Security Bureau (NSB) Director Ting Yu-chou will be promoted to the post of secretary-general of the National Security Council (NSC), which oversees NSB operations.

Incumbent NSC Secretary-General Chuang Ming-yao, a former navy commander-in-chief, will become president of the Association of East Asian Relations -- a semi-official organization in charge of exchanges with Japan in the absence of formal diplomatic ties between the two countries.
Ting's vacated position will be filled by his deputy, Tsai Chao-ming.
Meanwhile, Hsu Chu-sheng, head of the Military Intelligence Bureau, will be replaced by Hsueh Shih-ming, commanding general of the Kinmen Defense Command.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC MINISTER TO VISIT U.S., JAPAN WITH TOURIST INDUSTRY MISSION

TEXT.P: Republic of China Minister of Transportation and Communications Yeh Chu-lan will leave for the United States and Japan Friday together with a mission organized by the tourist industry.
At a time when the island's economic performance is at low ebb, Yeh said she hopes to stimulate the tourist industry to create more jobs.
Furthermore, she added that she has a long-cherished idea of building an international-level multi-functional recreational center on nearby islands or in regions with special characteristics.
During the 12-day trip, Yeh will study the success stories of the management of resorts in Las Vegas and Hawaii, as well as the experiences of hot springs operations in Japan.

Regarding casinos, the minister said that the Ministry of Transportation and Communications will not advocate building casinos in Taiwan before related laws have been enacted to legalize gambling at casinos.
She will also take advantage of the trip to encourage foreign enterprises to invest in the projected Tapeng Harbor recreational center in Pingtung County.

The Tapeng project will be developed on government-owned land through the build-operate-transfer model with a total investment of US$500 million. The government will pour in US$300 million for infrastructure construction.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW PARTY NOMINATES CANDIDATE FOR HEAD OF TAIPEI COUNTY

TEXT.P: The New Party nominated former Minister of Finance Wang Chien-shuan Thursday as its candidate to run for Taipei County magistrate in the year-end elections.
In a hastily called news conference, New Party leader legislator Hsieh Chi-ta announced Wang's candidacy.

However, a New Party candidate for legislator in Taipei County, Lin Chung-chen, said the party's followers still hope the Kuomintang, the People First Party and the New Party will throw their weight behind one candidate acceptable to all of them, rather than field their own candidates in the race.

Given the high popularity of the current Democratic Progressive Party magistrate Su Tseng-chang, Lin said the three opposition parties could hardly expect to win the election without uniting behind one candidate.
The three parties have contacted each other in the hope of naming a joint candidate. But the negotiations have gone nowhere and each party has named their own candidate.

DOC.HEADLINE: ASIAN ALUMNI OF TAIWAN SCHOOLS TO MEET IN BANGKOK
DOC.DATELINE: Bangkok, Aug. 9 (CNA) (By Kuo Fang-chih and Elisa Kao)

TEXT.P: More than 800 alumni of Taiwan universities and colleges from various Asian countries will come to Bangkok for their 10th annual meeting scheduled for Aug. 12.

Alumni of Taiwan schools from Indonesia, Singapore, Malaysia, Thailand, Vietnam and Brunei will participate in the annual meeting, which will also treat them to a tour of the Menam River and a friendly golf competition.

Fu Chi-yun, chairman of the Thailand Alumni Association of Taiwan Schools, said Thursday that the meeting is designed to reunite Asian alumni of Taiwan schools to create a new chapter in history, especially at the time when all the countries in the world are mired in economic woes.

DOC.HEADLINE: NATIONAL COFFERS SUFFER LOSSES AMID RECESSION

TEXT.P: Tax revenues for the government in July hit NT$158.1 billion (US$4.6 billion), down 5.7 percent from the same month in 2000, the Ministry of Finance reported Thursday.
Statistics compiled by the ministry show that business tax revenues posted the largest decrease of 16 percent last month, followed by land value increment taxes and stock transactions taxes.

In July, land value increment taxes totaled NT$3.6 billion, down 49.8 percent year-on-year and the lowest level since December 1986, while stock transactions taxes totaled NT$3.1 billion, down 51.7 percent from a year ago and the lowest level since March 1999, ministry tallies indicate.

Hsu Kuo-chung, head of the ministry's Department of Statistics, said stock transactions taxes are estimated at NT$55.1 billion and at NT$56.6 billion for the whole of 2001 should the daily trading volume in the local stock market is set at NT$55 billion and NT$60 billion, respectively, both lagging the government target of NT$87.2 billion.

At the same time, July customs revenues totaled NT$7.6 billion, down 14.6 percent from a year ago, the same tallies show. However, income taxes hit NT$83.2 billion, up 12 percent over the level in July 2000.

During the first seven months of this year, the national coffers of the state received a total of NT$892.2 billion in taxes, down 6.4 percent from the same period of a year ago, and accounted for 67.3 percent of the annual target for the whole of the year, the same tallies indicate.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.N BID NOT AIMED AT CHALLENGING BEIJING'S SEAT: MOFA

TEXT.P: The Republic of China's bid to join the United Nations is by no means aimed at challenging mainland China's seat in the world body, Vice Minister of Foreign Affairs Wu Tzu-dan said Thursday.

Wu made the remarks after 10 of the ROC's diplomatic allies presented a joint proposal to the U.N. Secretariat Wednesday urging the U.N. General Assembly to set up a working panel to examine Taiwan's "exceptional international situation" and its desire for representation in the United Nations and its affiliated agencies.
Wu said the ROC highly appreciates its allies' presentation of the proposal without yielding to threat and intimidation from mainland China, a permanent member of the U.N. Security Council.
The 10 countries are Belize, Burkina Faso, Chad, Dominica, El Salvador, Gambia, Nicaragua, Palau, Senegal and Tuvalu.
The ROC, a U.N. founding members, has been shut out of the United Nations since 1971 when the world body gave the China seat to mainland China.
Wu said the expulsion has created major obstacles to the ROC government and its 23 million people.
"We hope the U.N. General Assembly will consider our people's common desire for a representation in the United Nations and its affiliated agencies," Wu said.
The veteran diplomat also urged mainalnd China to face up to the reality of the ROC's continued existence in Taiwan.

Wu reminded mainland Chinese leaders that their continued diplomatic embargo against the ROC would only draw a backlash from the people of Taiwan and thus hinder improvement of relations across the Taiwan Strait.
Wu further called on other U.N. members to pay heed to the legitimacy of the ROC's U.N. bid and throw support behind the proposal to set up a panel to study Taiwan's membership bid.

In their joint proposal, the 10 ROC allies urged the U.N. General Assembly to form a special working group to study Taiwan's U.N. bid and invite ROC representatives to take part in the working panel to facilitate its work.

The proposal also urged the U.N. General Assembly and the international community to express more concern about the development in cross-strait relations and to encourage both sides to resume dialogue.

Since 1992, the ROC has annually asked the U.N. General Assembly through its diplomatic allies to tackle issues regarding Taiwan's representation in the world body. However, its bid had consistently been shot down at the U.N. Steering Committee meeting and failed to make the General Assembly agenda due to mainland China's opposition.
It remains unclear whether the proposal can make the General Assembly agenda this year As the Steering Committee has yet to discuss the issue.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2001 INTERNATIONAL SOFTWARE SHOW KICKS OFF IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: The 2001 International Software Show kicked off in Taipei Thursday with the participation of nearly 200 software companies manning 600 display booths.

At the opening of the annual software show, which is in its 12th year, Vice Premier Lai In-jaw reiterated the government's determination to make various government services more convenient and effective by bringing them online.
He handed out awards to the government agencies whose Web sites were judged to be exemplary. A total of 53 Web sites out of 311 entries won a coveted honor.
The five-day event, free to the public and organized by the Information Service Industry Association (ISIA) of the Republic of China, is expected to draw over 200,000 visitors.
ISIA Chairman James Wong said that the software industry can be said to be the yardstick among all knowledge-based industries.

Despite global and local economic sluggishness, he went on, Taiwan's information software industry has continued to grow at 20 percent to 30 percent each year, with current annual production already surpassing the NT$100 billion (US$2.9 billion) mark.
He pointed out that during the past three months alone, over 60 newly established software companies have joined the ISIA, with over half of them capitalized at over NT$100 million (US$2.9 million).
Because the software industry has continued to grow, it will create 8,000 to 10,000 additional jobs per year, he added.

The Institute for Information Industry has predicted that the local software industry's annual production will reach NT$200 billion (US$5.8 billion) in 2002 and NT$400 billion (US$11.5 billion) in 2005.

DOC.HEADLINE: SOME 6,000 OVERSEAS CHINESE RESIDING IN NORTH KOREA
DOC.DATELINE: Seoul, Aug. 9 (CNA) (By Chiang Yuan-chen and Ed Chen)

TEXT.P: More than 6,000 overseas mainland Chinese are now residing in North Korea and over the 95 percent of them are farmers and laborers, the semi-official Korean Trade Promotion Corp. (KOTRA) quoted a mainland Chinese newspaper as reporting Thursday.

According to the "Liaoning Korean Newspaper," all the overseas Chinese in North Korea had become farmers or laborers as a result of the socialism reform measures adopted by the North Korean regime in 1950.

The adoption of socialism by North Korean authorities in 1950 forced those overseas Chinese who worked in handicraft manufacturing, ran groceries or restaurants to immediately take up work as farmers thus damaging the economy.
The majority of overseas Chinese now in North Korea who retained their mainland Chinese nationality came from Shantung province, it reported.

Meanwhile, KOTRA reported that most overseas Chinese in North Korea lived a middle class existence and were better off than their North Korean compatriots. They enjoyed an 11-year compulsory educational system and receive free medical care and tax exemptions. The North Korean government has also subsidized them for food, housing and utilities.
At present, more than 100 overseas Chinese students from North Korea are studying in colleges and universities in mainland China, KOTRA reported.
More than 60,000 overseas Chinese had been living in North Korea when the Second World War ended. The majority of overseas Chinese returned to mainland China when the Korean War broke out in 1950.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC FOREIGN MINISTER TO ATTEND MEETING WITH CARIBBEAN COUNTERPARTS

TEXT.P: Republic of China Minister of Foreign Affairs Tien Hung-mao is scheduled to attend a meeting in Grenada Aug. 31 with his counterparts from four ROC diplomatic allies in the eastern Caribbean.
Tien is slated to depart Taipei Aug. 27 for a transit stop in New York, where he will meet with overseas Chinese leaders and members of local think tanks.

He will arrive in Grenada Aug. 30 and meet with the foreign ministers of the Commonwealth of Dominica, Grenada, Saint Kitts and Nevis, and Saint Vincent and the Grenadines the following day for a multilateral conference.

Returning from Grenada, he is scheduled to stop over in Puerto Rico, New York and Boston, giving a speech at Harvard University's John F. Kennedy School of Government on Sept. 6 before departing for Taipei Sept. 7.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. SENATOR TO MEET PRESIDENT CHEN

TEXT.P: U.S. Senator Christopher Bond (R-M0) arrived in Taipei Thursday afternoon leading a five-member delegation for a two-day visit to the Republic of China.

During their stay in Taipei, they will meet ROC president Chen Shui-bian and call on Minister of Foreign Affairs Tien Hung-mao and Minister of National Defense Wu Shih-wen for talks on a wide range of topics and ways to strengthen bilateral economic and trade relations between Taiwan and the State of Missouri.

Senator Bond, born in St. Louis in 1939, became the 47th governor of the State of Missouri at 33 years of age in 1973 - the youngest governor the state has ever had. He was reelected to a second term as governor of the state in 1980. He was elected as senator in 1986.
Bond has been very friendly to Taiwan and has supported Republic of China's bid to join the United Nations. He has visited Taiwan three times, in 1982, 1992 and 1995.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT$ 30 BILLION `DREAM MALL' BEGINS CONSTRUCTION IN KAOHSIUNG

TEXT.P: Construction work on a NT$30 billion "dream mall" is under way after a ground-breaking ceremony held Thursday in the southern Taiwan city of Kaohsiung.

The ceremony was jointly presided over by UNI-President Enterprises Corp. Chairman Kao Ching-yuan, Kaohsiung Mayor Frank Hsieh and Kaohsiung City Council Speaker Huang Chi-chuan, with more than 200 representatives from enterprises around Taiwan and abroad witnessing the event.
In an address, Kao expressed hope that the planned multifunctional business center, with support from the Kaohsiung city government, will provide 15,000 jobs for the people in southern Taiwan.

The project will be divided into three phases, with the first described as the largest shopping mall in Taiwan. The second and third phases will comprise residential and office buildings, as well as tourist hotels.
The mall is expected to attract 25 million customers annually and bring in about NT$20 billion in annual revenue, according to an official from UNI-President, the project's investor.
Hsieh expressed his thanks to the President group for its support of Kaohsiung city government proposal to build Kaohsiung into a multifunctional business center.

Hsieh said that a group of Kaohsiung city officials are scheduled to travel to Europe in September to lure foreign investors to invest in the southern city. With Taiwan's imminent admission into the World Trade Organization (WTO), he said, future cross-Taiwan Strait trade and the advantages of the city's position as an air and sea transportation hub will turn Kaohsiung into an economic treasure-house.
The mall is scheduled to be completed by 2004.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC MIGHT ALLOW BEIJING TRADE PROMOTION ORGANIZATION INTO TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The Taiwan authorities are mulling whether to revise current regulations to allow Beijing's China Council for Promotion of International Trade (CCPIT) to operate in Taiwan, a local trade official said Thursday.
China External Trade Development Council (CETRA) chief Shea Jia-dong added that any such revision would be in return for similar rights granted to CETRA by the Beijing authorities.

In a symposium with members of the Importers and Exporters Association of Taipei (IEAT), Shea said his council is more than willing to branch into the mainland market, but noted that Taiwan's prohibition on Beijing's CCPIT to operate in Taiwan gives Beijing the pretext to block CETRA's access to the mainland.
In order to help CETRA, the Mainland Affairs Council is reviewing the existing regulations to see if they can be revised to accommodate the operation of CCPIT in Taiwan, Shea said.
Shea also noted that CETRA has still managed to rent an office in Beijing on a temporary basis.
Shea made the remarks in response to a plea from IEAT members for CETRA's assistance in mainland China.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOV'T MULLING EASING LIMITS ON M'LAND INVESTMENT BY TEXTILE FIRMS

TEXT.P: Republic of China Economics Minister Lin Hsin-yi said Thursday that the government is considering easing restrictions on local textile firms wishing to invest in mainland China.

Lin made the remark in a meeting with executives of Taiwan's major textile companies, including Far Eastern Textile Ltd., Formosa Chemicals and Fiber Corp. and Shinkong Synthetic Fibers Corp., in an attempt to integrate the island's textile industry and reinforce its competitiveness.

Lin said that the eased restrictions will apply to textile and chemical fiber enterprises, which at present are only allowed to invest in the mainland on a case-by-case basis after screening by the ROC authorities.
Lin added that the textile leaders also discussed mergers and that he promised to push for the legislation of a corporate merger law to facilitate such moves.

Lin also announced that his ministry will buy a 48-percent stake in a textile industrial zone in Yunlin, central Taiwan and will help resolve a drainage problem in the zone, as well as offering incentives to those willing to invest in the high-tech fiber sector.

DOC.HEADLINE: LCD MONITORS, DIGITAL CAMERAS LEAD GROWTH AMIDST OVERALL DECLINE

TEXT.P: The Institute for Information Industry announced Thursday that local production of LCD monitors and digital cameras are both expected to grow immensely from last year amidst an overall decline in the information hardware industry.

Chan Wen-nan, director of the institute's Market Intelligence Center (MIC), said that the actual production of LCD monitors from January to June hit 2.9 million units, an increase of 168.7 percent from the same period of last year.

He added that the MIC predicts that the growth momentum will continue in the second half of the year so that total annual production for LCD monitors in 2001 will hit 8.4 million units, a 188.8 percent increase from last year.
Production value-wise, the MIC predicted that LCD monitors will bring in US$3.141 billion, an annual increase of 66 percent.
Chan said that the local LCD monitor industry is expected to continue growing in leaps and bounds in 2002, with an estimated total annual production of 23 million units worth nearly US$8 billion.
Turning to digital cameras, the MIC predicted that total annual production for 2001 will surpass 10 million units, an annual increase of 86.3 percent over last year.
Production value-wise, that volume is expected to translate into a 147.5 percent growth, reaping in US$1.4 billion, Chan said.
He added that digital cameras from Taiwan are expected to make up 44.5 percent of the global market in 2001, an increase from 37.3 percent last year.
Meanwhile, the MIC predicted that production for other locally manufactured information hardware will post declines this year.

Production of Taiwan-made notebook computers, which comprised 52.5 percent of the world market last year, are expected to grow 3 percent in 2001 to 13 million units, but the equivalent production value -- estimated at US$12 billion -- will mark an 11 percent decrease from last year.

Affected by fierce competition from South Korea, conventional CDT monitors are expected to decline 18.9 percent in total production to 48 million units worth US$5.4 billion, a 34.5 percent decrease from 2000.

The MIC predicted that local production of desktop computers will grow by 2.4 percent to hit 28.3 million units this year, which translates into a total value of US$7 billion, a 9.2 percent decrease from last year.
Motherboard production is expected to reach 80 million units, down 3.7 percent from last year, with a total value of US$5.3 billion -- 5.5 percent lower than 2000.
CD-ROM drive production is expected to decline by 2 percent to 58 million units, bringing in an estimated US$2.3 billion -- 0.1 percent more than last year.

Despite Taiwan's 92 percent dominance in the global scanner market, production of local scanners is expected to slide to 22 million units, an 18.2 percent decrease from last year, with an accompanying 16.8 percent decrease in production value to US$900 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: CEPD HEAD: FOREIGN WORKERS SHOULD NOT ENJOY MINIMUM WAGE LIMIT

TEXT.P: The Republic of China's top economic policy planner said Thursday that he supports the idea that foreign laborers' wages should no longer be subject to the minimum wage requirement enjoyed by their local counterparts.

Chen Poh-chih, chairman of the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD), was responding to a suggestion by a presidential policy coordination panel, which was asked by President Chen Shui-bian to study ways to reduce foreign labor costs for local entrepreneurs.
The president has been very concerned about the fact that foreign labor costs in Taiwan are behind only South Korea, but 2.79 times those of Singapore and 1.42 times those of Hong Kong.

The economic policy planner also complained the exorbitant labor brokerage fees paid by foreign workers do no good to neither employers nor the foreign workers and added that a better policy should be planned to benefit both sides.

He said he supports the idea that foreign workers will no longer be subject to minimum wage requirements as stipulated in the country's Labor Standards Law and that the market should decide the wages.

Asked whether the move will violate "national treatment," Chen said he sees no such problem, adding that it is quite natural that salaries should vary in different industries. Besides, he went on, the ROC government has never been discriminatory toward security in the workplace, health, or basic human rights of its foreign workers.

DOC.HEADLINE: EPZ-BASED TRADITIONAL INDUSTRIES BUCK RECESSION

TEXT.P: Amid the global economic recession hitting the hi-tech sector, business revenues of Taiwan's traditional industries based in export processing zones (EPZs) have gone against the trend by posting increases, the EPZ Administration said Thursday.

According to administration officials, the business revenue of Taiwan's EPZs totaled NT$183.9 billion in the first seven months of this year, down 11.62 percent from the same period of 2000. However, the overall business revenue of EPZ-based traditional industries, which accounts for 10 percent of the total EPZ revenue, grew to NT$11.99 billion during the same period.

For instance, the officials said, the chemical and plastics industry saw a rise in business revenue of 18.83 percent year-on-year, while the food processing industry and the machinery industry experienced growth of 26.24 percent and 8.38 percent, respectively.

At the same time, the officials went on, IC-related, information industry-related and optical and electronics firms based in the EPZs -- which contribute 75.6 percent of the EPZs' total business revenue -- posted large declines in operational income, while EPZ-based traditional small- and medium-sized businesses made a great contribution to Taiwan's economy and have in turn become a stabilizer in the present economic slump.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC FOREIGN MINISTRY WELCOMES U.S. CONGRESSIONAL DELEGATIONS

TEXT.P: The Republic of China Ministry of Foreign Affairs said Thursday that it welcomes the various U.S. congressional delegations visiting Taiwan this month and hopes bilateral relations will be strengthened through mutual communication and cooperation.

Ministry officials said that in addition to a 20-member entourage led by Sen. Joseph Biden -- a Delaware Democrat and chairman of the Senate Committee on Foreign Relations -- which ended a visit Tuesday, another seven-member delegation led by Sen. Christopher Bond, a Missouri Republican, is currently in Taiwan for a two-day visit.

Also scheduled to visit Taiwan later this month are a 21-member delegation to be led by Texas Republican Rep. Tom DeLay, majority whip of the U.S House of Representatives; a 25-member delegation to be headed by Rep. Henry Hyde, an Illinois Republican and chairman of the U.S. House of Representatives Committee on International Relations; a five-member delegation to be led by Rep. Ben Gilman, a Republican from New York and an honorary chairman of the same committee; a four-person delegation to be headed by Rep. Rob Simmons, a Connecticut Republican; and a five-person delegation to be led by Rep. Joe Hoeffel, a Democrat from Pennsylvania.
The U.S. congressmen are expected to meet with ROC President Chen Shui-bian and call on various government officials to exchange opinions on cross-Taiwan Strait issues and other important topics.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW BOOK ABOUT ROC FORMER PRESIDENT LAUNCHED

TEXT.P: As if the shock caused by the many tell-all books on former President Lee Teng-hui has not been enough, another one purporting to explore Lee's "inner world" hit Taiwan stores Thursday.
The book, penned by Lee's personal secretary, Lee Ching-yi, is touted to provide a close-up of Lee Teng-hui and a detailed portrayal of his life in retirement.

In a ceremony to mark the launch of the book, carried out at the Taiwan Research Institute, of which Lee Teng-hui is chairman, the ex-president said: "Lee Ching-yi is the one who knows my thoughts best."

He said Lee Ching-yi, who has worked as his personal secretary for more than 10 years, provides readers with a rare glimpse into the former president's personal life through her graphic, compassionate and "politically untainted" descriptions.
The book's publisher Wang Jung-wen said on the occasion that in this book, "there is no bloody political struggle" and therefore it gives a more crystallized view of Lee Teng-hui's personality.

The ex-president's former personal chief of staff, Su Chih-cheng, was also present at the launch and he praised Lee Teng-hui as a rare political leader with great wisdom in the humanities and philosophy.

There have been many books published about Lee Teng-hui since he stepped down as president last year. Some are based on interviews with Lee Teng-hui and have caused uproar in Taipei political circles by revealing many of the politician's well-guarded grudges against his former political allies.

DOC.HEADLINE: KAOHSIUNG FIRM TO SIGN NT$ 11 BILLION CONTRACT WITH SIEMENS GROUP

TEXT.P: The Kaohsiung Rapid Transit Corporation (KRTC) will sign a NT$11 billion contract with Germany's Siemens Group in Singapore Friday for the purchase of trains, electrical power systems and other related equipment.
Siemens won a bid to undertake the electrical power system engineering project for the southern city's rapid transit systems, and owned a 10 percent share of KRTC.
Under the terms of the contract, Siemens will provide 126 carriages, the main electrical power system and related services for the transit system.

The company had originally hoped to sign the contract in Germany, while the Kaohsiung firm wanted to sign the contract in Taiwan. After several rounds of consultations, both sides made concessions and agreed to sign the deal in Singapore.

Regarding the supply of the transit system's elevators, escalators, platform gates, air-conditioning systems and turnstile machines, the KRTC will choose suppliers through open bidding in which Siemens can also compete.
The rapid transit system in the southern port city is expected to start partial operations in late 2004.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI MAYOR, KOREAN PRESIDENT VISIT WORLD CERAMIC EXPO
DOC.DATELINE: Seoul, Aug. 9 (CNA) (By Chiang Yuan-chen & Ed Chen)

TEXT.P: Visiting Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou, along with South Korean President Kim Dae-jung and other officials, witnessed the opening ceremony Thursday of the 2001 World Ceramic Exposition held at Ichon City, Kyonggi Province, 250 km southeast of Seoul.
Ma, who is visiting South Korea at the head of a seven-member delegation, was accompanied by Lee Tsung-ju, Republic of China representative to Korea.
With "shaping the future with earth" as its main theme, the show was scheduled to open to the public the following day for an 80-day run.
Also invited to the opening ceremony were Tony Franks, president of the International Academy of Ceramics and Korean Minister of Culture and Tourism Kim Han-gill.
In his address, President Kim called on his fellow countrymen to redouble their efforts to build Kyonggi into a "ceramic cultural Mecca."
Following the opening ceremony, Ma visited an e-game center financed by the Ministry of Culture and Tourism and the Korean film classification screen committee.

Ma was slated the next day to visit the Seoul city government and to proceed Saturday to Fukuoka City, Japan, for the third leg of his trip undertaken with the aim of strengthening ties between Taipei City and Kuala Lumpur, Seoul and Fukuoka -- three of Taipei's sister cities.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER, PFP CHAIRMAN VISIT TYPHOON-AFFECTED AREAS IN NANTOU
DOC.DATELINE: Nantou, central Taiwan, Aug. 9 (CNA) (By Victor Lai)

TEXT.P: Premier Chang Chun-hsiung visited several typhoon-affected areas in Nantou County Thursday and hinted that the government will offer additional relief funds for victims of Typhoon Toraji.
Chang's helicopter first landed at National Taiwan University's Hsitou experimental forest in Luku Township and he later visited Tungpu and two villages in Hsinyi Township.

The premier said that the government will continue its efforts to search for those who were still missing after the typhoon and added that the government will use donations from the public to help the displaced residents.
He said that the Executive Yuan hopes to give an additional NT$200,000 to the families of those killed in the mudslides and flooding triggered by the typhoon.
Regarding the children of the victims, the premier said that the government will also use public donations to help pay for their education.

Meanwhile, opposition People First Party Chairman James Soong also visited several typhoon-affected regions in Hsinyi and Chushan townships Thursday, accompanied by PFP Legislator Chen Chen-sheng and former Legislator Chen Chih-pin.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies on Friday are as follows:
The China Times:
Premier Chang pledges to set up a fund to help Toraji typhoon victims.
The United Daily News:
Labor affairs chief says basic wages can be adjusted along with the changing economic situation.
The Liberty Times:
The Ministry of Economic Affairs proposes cutting or suspending commodity taxes for two to three years.
The Taiwan Daily:
The investment panel under the Economic Development Advisory Conference proposes suspension of elderly subsidy and other welfare measures at this time of economic downturn.
The Central Daily News:
New Party nominates ex-Finance Minister Wang Chien-shien to run for Taipei county commissioner.
The China Post:
New Party heavyweight joins in Taipei County race.
The Taiwan News:
Allies in U.N. push for Taiwan membership.
The Taipei Times:
Premier set to visit allies in Caribbean.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, Aug. 10, or the 21st day of the sixth month of the Year of the Snake according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
843: The Treaty of Verdun divides the Frankish empire.
1810: Count (Camillo Benso) Cavour, Italian statesman, is born. He played a major role in the unification of Italy and became prime minister of the new kingdom.
1821: Missouri is admitted as the 24th state of the United States.
1846: The Smithsonian Institute is established in Washington as a center for scientific research with a bequest from English scientist James Smithson.
1874: Herbert Hoover, the 31st president of the United States, is born. His belief in individual freedom led him to reject federal relief for unemployment during the Depression and lost him the 1932 election to Franklin D. Roosevelt.
1894: Varahagiri Venkata Giri, president of India from 1969 to 1974, is born. He was prominent in India's labor movement.
1904: During the Russo-Japanese War, the Russian fleet suffers heavy loses when the Japanese fleet blocks it from escaping from Port Arthur in the Battle of the Yellow Sea.
1913: The Treaty of Bucharest is signed, ending the second Balkan War and partitioning Macedonia among Serbia, Greece, Romania and Bulgaria.
1926: Northwest Airlines is established in Chicago.
1944: Yicheng County in Hupei Province changes its name to Chihchung County in memory of the bravery of Gen. Chang Chih-chung who died in action during the War of Resistance Against Japan.
1944: American forces recapture Guam from the Japanese after three weeks of fighting in which only 500 of the 18,000 defending Japanese troops survived and surrendered.
1945: Robert H. Goddard, American pioneer of rocket science, dies at the age of 63. He conducted the first successful launch of a liquid-propellant rocket in 1926. The rocket climbed 184 feet (56 meters) into the air at a speed of about 60 miles (97 kilometers) per hour.
1946: Gen. George C. Marshall, a special envoy of U.S. President Harry Truman to China on a mission to mediate the civil war between the Nationalists and the Chinese communists, issues a statement declaring that his efforts have failed.
1950: U.S. State Department official Karl L. Rankin arrives in Taipei as charge d'affaires of the U.S. Embassy.
1961: Britain applies to join the European Economic Community.
1966: Orbiter I, the first American moon satellite, is launched from Cape Kennedy.
1975: Flight service between the Republic of China and Japan resumes after the ROC government announced on April 20, 1974 the termination of the Taiwan-Japan flights of China Airlines and Japan Airlines.
1979: The newly completed Keelung-Suao Highway is opened to traffic.
1981: The joint meeting of the Second Asian Conference of the International Association for Cross-Cultural Psychology and the First Asian Conference of the International Council of Psychologists opens in Taipei.
1990: The ROC government declares its support of a United Nations call for world sanctions against Iraq over its invasion of Kuwait.
1993: The New KMT Alliance breaks with the ruling Kuomintang and forms the New Party.
1993: Shih Yueh-po, a Chinese passenger, hijacks a mainland Chinese Boeing 767 passenger plane to Chiang Kai-shek International Airport in Taoyuan.
1998: Some 2,000 people die in floods in mainland China.
1998: Prince Al-Muhtadee Billah, eldest son of Sultan Hassan Bolkiah of Brunei, is proclaimed heir to the throne.
1999: The Republic of China inaugurates Asia's first flight recorder laboratory, allowing local personnel to analyze aircraft flight recorder (black box) data rather than having to send such data to a third country for analysis.
2000: President Chen Shui-bian accuses Beijing of hypocrisy in terms of its definition of "one China," and reiterates Taiwan's rejection of Beijing's demand that it embrace "one China" on Beijing's terms.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "There is only one way to be trusted by one's friends. If a man does not command the obedience of the members of his family, he will not be trusted by his friends."

DOC.HEADLINE: FALUN GONG IN CANADA URGES GOV'T TO EXPEL VISITING PRC OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: Falun Gong practitioners in Canada have urged the federal government to expel or charge a visiting Communist Chinese official suspected of aiding in the suppression of Falun Gong followers in mainland China.

The Falun Dafa Association of Canada, along with Canadian citizens Mrs. Jinyu Li and Mr. Xueye Zhu, was referring to Dong Yiming, a department chief of the Appeal Processing Office of Communist China's National Appeal Bureau, who is currently visiting Toronto.

They accuse Dong of being "directly responsible, instrumental and complicit in the systematic murder, torture, persecution and illegal labor camp internment of thousands of Falun Dafa practitioners in China."
Li and Zhu, who claim they are victims of Dong's actions, said they plan to confront him during his brief stay and public appearances in Canada.

They claim that Dong's entry into Canada is a clear breach of the Immigration Act and that his actions, which constitute crimes against humanity, are a criminal offense under the Criminal Act of Canada.

Meanwhile, Falun Gong practitioners in Canada are embarking on a nationwide "SOS! Urgent: Rescue the Falun Gong Practitioners Persecuted in China" tour. They will head to cities and towns in each of Canada's provinces and territories during August and September to raise awareness and gather support for their cause.

They will seek to gather signatures for a petition asking the Canadian government to help release the husband of Jinyu Li, who has been held in a Chinese labor camp for the last 18 months, to help rescue practitioners persecuted in mainland China, and to coordinate a team for an international investigation into the persecution of the Falun Gong by Beijing.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRC'S ARREST, RELEASE OF AMERICANS `HOSTAGE DIPLOMACY:' U.S. SENATOR

TEXT.P: U.S. Senate Democratic leader Tom Daschle on Thursday called Communist China's recent arrest and release of Americans "hostage diplomacy, and not a sign of improvement in the way China treats its people."

In a speech titled "A New Century of American Leadership," the South Dakota Democrat noted that "we need to recognize that it is in our national interest to help our former adversaries, like Russia and China, build a pluralistic society tied to the West."

Sen. Daschle said the 20th century in many ways was "the story of our triumph over two great and pernicious adversaries, Nazism and communism. Today we do not need a great adversary to be a great country. Unfortunately, some don't accept this reality. And with the collapse of the Soviet Union, they would like to see China take its place."

"I believe we need to take a more nuanced view. China is a nation at a crossroads. Today, China is in the midst of a sweeping economic reform. Although democracy is growing at the local level, China still has a sordid record on human rights and still has not guaranteed the right to worship, to speak, or to choose one's leaders," he added.
He pointed out that "the release of our visiting scholars, while welcome news, was not an exception" to the mainland Chinese government's record of lack of respect for human rights.
The senator said the question for the United States therefore is: "How do we get China to embrace the norms of international behavior, including the rule of law?"

"We don't do it by abandoning the kind of frank and open exchange that allows us to raise our differences in the first place or by trying to isolate a nation with 1.2 billion people and a nuclear arsenal capable of reaching targets in the United States or by turning our backs on what could develop into one of the world's largest economies," he explained.

"We have to engage China, even as we challenge China on key areas of difference. It is in America's clear national security interest to do so. It is in America's vital economic interest to do so. And in the long run, it is the only way to help bring freedom and reform to the people of China," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: FIVE-YEAR-OLD BECOMES TAIWAN'S YOUNGEST AUTHOR

TEXT.P: A five-year-old boy named Duoduo (Donald) recently had his first book published, becoming Taiwan's youngest author.

By launching on Thursday the book "I'm 5, My English is Better Than Yours," co-authored by Duoduo and his marketing manager-turned-housewife mother Chu Ching-yu (Mary), the child unleashed the "Duoduo legend" in Taiwan. Duoduo was born to Taiwanese parents who have never lived in an English-speaking country.

The "Duoduo" book, which began to appear on shelves at bookstores around the island Thursday, contains a number of forward articles written by adults who express their amazement at the fact that Donald has learned more than 3,000 English words by the tender age of 5.

One of the forwards was written by Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou, a Harvard-trained law specialist who speaks fluent English. Apparently impressed by Duoduo's abilities, Ma wrote that in order "to learn English and learn well, better begin early."

Duoduo initially showed a little bit of shyness and "boredom" at the party hosted by the publisher marking the launch of the book, but he become more cheerful when he began playing spelling games with reporters.

When asked by Liao Su Si-zi, owner of the locally-renowned Shinseo Bookstore, why he could memorize so many English words at such a young age, Duoduo answered matter-of-factly that "you remember them after repeating them many many times."

Duoduo's mother, Mary, who gave up her well-paying job as a marketing manager at a Taipei publication company to become a full-time housewife and "mentor" to Duoduo, said the boy has been "using" and "playing with" the English language, rather than "studying" it -- thereby enabling him to memorize in a fun way more than 3,000 English words and phrases in only about one-and-a-half years.

Mary said all she has done is to try to create an "English environment" for her son, exposing him to the language as much as possible, such as by buying him English books, only tuning to English-speaking television channels and radio programs, and playing simple words games like "pictionary" or charades with him.

Despite his young age, Duoduo is exceptionally "shrewd". When his mother asked him when exactly he plans to compile his own English dictionary, as the publisher had asked, Duoduo replied by saying "Don't even think about it. There will be no second book."

After playing spelling games with reporters, Duoduo was asked by his mother if it would be okay for him to answer some questions from the reporters. Duoduo responded, also in English, by saying "just a second." Then, after a few moments, said "now they can ask, but only questions related to English."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK PRICES RISE BY 28.39 POINTS

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) rose on Friday, with the benchmark weighted price index rising 28.39 points to close at 4,476.91.
Market turnover amounted to NT$42.028 billion (US$1.21 billion) during the four-and-half-hour trading session.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW MILITARY INTELLIGENCE BUREAU HEAD SWORN IN

TEXT.P: Hsueh Shih-ming took over as the new head of the Military Intelligence Bureau Friday in the first wave of a reshuffle of national security and military intelligence personnel announced by the Presidential Office earlier this week.
Hseuh took over the post from Hsu Chu-sheng, who will serve as inspector general in the Navy General Headquarters, in a changeover ceremony presided over by Chief of the General Staff Tang Yao-ming.

Earlier in the day, Tang flew over to the offshore island of Kinmen to present Hsueh with a medal in recognition of his contributions over the past 13 months as the commanding general of Kinmen Defense Command.

Tang also took the opportunity to remind military personnel not to harbor false hopes about peace in the Taiwan Strait after Beijing's successful bid for the 2008 Olympics in early July and to remain vigilant and step up combat preparedness in order to ensure national security.

He also said that although the domestic economy has been sluggish, national security is still paramount, vowing to solicit a pay raise for military personnel so as to attract more intelligent young people to join the military.

The Kinmen Defense Command head vacancy is expected to be filled by Aug. 16. It has been learned that Lt. Gen. Hu Cheng-pu, deputy chief of the Chief of General Staff for Operations, and Lt. Gen. Wang Keng-lin, commandant of Infantry School, are the candidates under consideration.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHEN URGES BEIJING TO ACCEPT REALITY OF HIS POSITION AS ROC PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Friday that the mainland Chinese leadership should accept the reality of his position as president of the Republic of China to facilitate solving the "one China" dispute between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.
Chen made the remarks while meeting with U.S. Senator Christopher Bond (R-Mo.), who arrived in Taipei Thursday for a two-day visit.

Chen said the ROC Constitution has set a tone for resolving the cross-strait "one China" dispute. "It is the best answer for dealing with the `one China' issue for the governments and people of both sides of the Taiwan Strait," he added.
Noting that he was elected by the people of Taiwan as president of the ROC in accordance with the ROC Constitution, Chen said he hopes mainland China accepts him as the ROC's head of state.
"If mainland China were to decline to accept this reality, it would violate the ROC Constitution. Not only me, but also the 23 million people of Taiwan could not accept such a scenario," Chen said.

The president told his guest that since he assumed office, he has given priority to promoting cross-strait rapprochement. "I have seized every possible opportunity to extend an olive branch to Beijing. I have not only hoped to resume cross-strait dialogue but have also intended to forge reconciliation, cooperation and permanent peace with mainland China," he explained.

In his view, Chen said, the informal leadership meeting of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum to be held in Shanghai in late October provides a good setting for the top leaders of the two sides of the Taiwan Strait to meet.

Chen said he has on many occasions expressed his strong desire to attend the forthcoming APEC summit meeting in person. "Since the ROC is an APEC member, its president has the legitimate right to attend the APEC summit," he noted.

APEC, a regional economic cooperation forum, is one of the few international organizations which simultaneously accepts both mainland China and Taiwan as members. However, because of Beijing's opposition, the ROC president has been barred from personally attending the annual APEC leadership meeting in the past. As a result, the ROC head of state has had to name a proxy to take part in the event on his behalf. Chen named Central Bank of China Governor Perng Fai-nan to attend the 2000 APEC summit in Brunei.

Mainland China insists that Taiwan accept its version of the "one China" principle as a prerequisite to resuming the long-stalled cross-strait dialogue. However, Chen's administration has said that Beijing's "one China" principle is unacceptable because it downgrades the ROC to a local-level government under Beijing's jurisdiction.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIEX BENCHMARK INDEX MOVES UP 28.39 POINTS

TEXT.P: Prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) moved higher Friday, with the benchmark index rising 28.39 points, or 0.6 percent, to finish at 4,476.91.

On the strength of financial stocks and the shares of Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing and United Micro Electronics, the stock market opened higher at 4,470.75, hitting a high of 4.491.45 and a low of 4,394.09 during the day's trading session.
A total of 1.59 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$42.028 billion (US$1.21 billion).

All but two of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with construction stocks increasing the most at 3.6 percent, followed by financial shares at 1.2 percent, foodstuff shares at 0.9 percent, pulp and paper shares at 0.8 percent, electronics shares at 0.6 percent, and cement stocks at 0.1 percent.
In comparison, textile issues dropped 0.6 percent, and plastics and chemicals shares dropped 0.1 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 260 to 223, with 101 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES HIGHER ON TAIWAN FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock index futures market closed higher Friday, as Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index futures for August rose 64 points to close at 4,469, with 13,585 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX index futures for September rose 56 points to finish at 4,457, with 2,260 contracts traded, while December futures dropped 99 points to finish at 4,351, with one contract transaction. Next June futures plunged 126 points to finish at 4,360, with one contract changing hands.
No transactions were recorded for other months.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX index futures trading were set Friday at 4,405 for August, 4,401 for September, 4,450 for December, 4,370 for next March and 4,489 for next June.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, both closed higher.

August TE futures moved up three points to close at 233.5, with 1,851 contract transactions, while September TE futures rose 2.35 points to close at 232.4, with 320 contracts traded. TE futures for next March rose 7.5 points to close at 226, with two contract transactions.
No transactions were recorded for other months.

August TF futures moved up 8.8 points to finish at 556, with 924 contracts changing hands, while September TF futures gained 9.6 points to close at 556, with 77 contracts traded. TF futures for next June rose 1.8 points to finish at 544, with 16 contract transactions.
No transactions were recorded for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: CETRA TO EXPLORE FIVE NEW FOREIGN MARKETS

TEXT.P: The China External Trade Development Council (CETRA) will send officials to explore new markets in five foreign countries, CETRA's chairman said Friday.

Shea Jia-dong said that two officials will be assigned to each of the five countries -- Myanmar, Pakistan, Kazakhstan, the Ukraine, and Iraq. No Taiwan trade officials have been stationed in any of the five countries in the past.
The officials will remain in the respective countries for two to three months, gathering business information and helping Taiwan traders.
Taiwan businesspeople who are interested in trading in any of the five new markets are encouraged to contact CETRA to get more information.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR UP ON TAIPEI FOREX MARKET

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar appreciated NT$0.037 against the greenback on the Taipei foreign exchange market Friday, closing at NT$34.625.
The local currency opened Friday at NT$34.625 and was traded between NT$34.581 and NT$34.625.
Interbank U.S. dollar trading totaled US$642 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTEREST GROUPS WELCOME TO ACT AS CROSS-STRAIT GO-BETWEENS: MAC

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) has completed the planning for opening Taiwan to mainland Chinese tourists, but the plan has not been put into practice due to a lack of cross-strait exchanges, MAC Vice Chairman Chen Ming-tung said Friday.

Chen said that Taiwan has always hoped that both sides of the Taiwan Strait can sit down together to discuss cross-strait exchanges, adding that before such meetings can take place, the MAC is willing to have interest groups and those concerned about cross-strait relations act as go-betweens.

Chen, at a regular MAC press conference, also said that if the Economic Development Advisory Conference reaches consensus on opening Taiwan to mainland Chinese tourists, the government will definitely implement the policy.
The government had earlier planned on opening the island up to mainland tourists beginning July 1 this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: LABOR AFFAIRS OFFICIAL INSISTS ON MAINTAINING MINIMUM WAGE REQUIREMENT

TEXT.P: Labor affairs officials have insisted that the minimum wage requirement under the Labor Standards Law must not be abolished and that in times of economic recession, the level should be adjusted downward to reflect the economic environment.

Chen Chu, chairman of the Council of Labor Affairs under the Executive Yuan, stated the position of the council in response to suggestions by economic officials to abolish the minimum wage requirement for the sake of local business and industry's competitiveness.

Chen Po-chih, chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD), suggested Thursday that foreign laborers should not be included in the minimum wage requirement in view of the fact that employers of foreign laborers in Taiwan pay much higher personnel costs as compared with other countries.

CEPD Vice Chairman K.C. Lee, supporting Chen's argument, said some 99 percent of Taiwan's local laborers work at jobs where they are paid much more than the minimum wage of NT$15,840 (about US$460) per month and that the requirement has become mainly a protection for foreign laborers.
Lee added that in times of economic recession, it is reasonable to abolish the minimum wage requirement and provide employers with more flexibility in recruiting employees.
Labor affairs officials insist that the minimum wage requirement must be maintained and that the minimum wage level can be adjusted in accordance with the economic climate.

Since the minimum wage requirement came into force in 1956, the minimum wage has been adjusted upward 18 times and has never been adjusted downward, according to statistics compiled by the Ministry of Economic Affairs.
The minimum wage has remained at NT$15,840 since 1997 when business and industry voiced strong opposition to a further upward adjustment.
Labor officials said that an upward adjustment is unlikely this year and that in consideration of the current economic climate, a downward adjustment might be made.

DOC.HEADLINE: `LET THE MOUNTAINS REPLENISH,' ACADEMICS URGE

TEXT.P: Taiwan should begin to let the mountains replenish themselves and suspend all economic activities on them, including tourism, a group of academics urged Friday.

At a press conference, dubbed "Bear in Mind the Lessons of Typhoon Toraji and Face the Warnings from Mother Nature," the academics said Taiwan's green land, which covers about two-thirds of the island and is mostly mountainous, has been gradually turned into soil-depleting betel nut orchards.

The Taiwan Environmental Protection Union (TEPU), an activist group comprised mainly of professors from National Taiwan University (NTU), hosted the press conference in the wake of the devastating Typhoon Toraji, which killed some 100 people and left 110 others unaccounted for, mainly as a result of floods and mudslides triggered by the storm.

NTU forestation professor Chen Hsin-hsiung blamed over-farming and over-development as the main culprits of the mudslides and related destruction that the latest typhoon wrought on central and eastern Taiwan.

Chen said Typhoon Toraji brought a tremendous 900 millimeters of rainfall to mountainous Nantou County, a factor that many people pinpointed as the culprit of the disaster suffered by the central Taiwan county.

As a matter of fact, he pointed out, rainfall reached an even more threatening level of 1,100 millimeters in the same area in 1959, but the natural disasters triggered by that rainfall were much less severe.

Chiu Chang-ping, an adviser to the TEPU and formerly an NTU professor of civil engineering, put the blame for increasingly frequent mudslides in central Taiwan in recent years on the development of the New Cross-Island Highway that cuts through the heart of virgin mountains in central Taiwan.

Apart from the destruction that the development of the cross-island highway has brought to the surrounding environment, the opening of the road paved the way for profiteers, leading them directly into deep mountains where they started "high added-value" plantations such as betel nuts, fruit, tea and mountain vegetables, encroaching inch-by-inch on the virgin mountain areas, Chiu added.

In addition, he noted, clandestine deforestation has been so rampant in the mountainous areas that it is reported that it takes only half an hour for the "mountain thieves" to load a truck of illegally logged timber and drive it down from the mountains.

Chiu lamented that every time a mudslide occurs, the government hurries to rescue the victims and repair the roads and land, but gives little thought to improving water conservation and other conservation efforts that would help consolidate the unstable areas.
This, he explained, is why roads, bridges and other infrastructure facilities are repaired but break again as soon as a new flood or typhoon strikes.
Chiu suggested that Taiwan's mountains be allowed to enter a "hibernation" period to allow the land to replenish itself, adding that even tourism should be halted in unstable areas.

Chen Man-li, chairwoman of the Homemakers' Union and Foundation, urged during the press conference that President Chen Shui-bian announce 2001 as the inaugural year of environmental protection in Taiwan and that he instruct all Cabinet-level agencies, as well as government at all levels, to conserve the environment, instead of leaving the job solely to the under-funded and under-supported Environmental Protection Administration.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOEA MULLING EASING RULES FOR BUSINESS VISITORS FROM MAINLAND CHINA

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) will cooperate with the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) to lower the restrictions on businessmen from mainland China wishing to visit Taiwan, officials with the Board of Foreign Trade (BOFT) said Friday.

BOFT officials said the present measures allow only those mainland Chinese businessmen who have actually bought locally made products to travel to Taiwan to take part in relevant meetings, tours and related activities, such as product inspections.

In the face of the increased trade and economic exchanges between the two sides, however, it is necessary to relax the present measures to facilitate visits to Taiwan by mainland Chinese buyers as a means of helping generate greater purchase from the mainland, they noted.

Ideas being studied include slashing a combined lowest purchase requirement level by mainland Chinese businesses to Taiwan-based firms from US$500,000 to US$200,000 over three years, lowering the lowest level for sole purchase missions from US$200,000 to US$100,000 and removing the requirement that visits to Taiwan by mainland businessmen are only permitted for carrying out quality control missions here, according to the officials.

MOEA statistics show that a total of 672 mainland Chinese visitors came to Taiwan to purchase and inspect product quality last year, accounting for only 10.5 percent of the total number of people permitted to visit for trade or economic activities.

DOC.HEADLINE: FLEXIBLE WORKING HOURS UNCOMMON IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Only 6 percent of the jobs in Taiwan allow flexible working hours, a percentage that is much lower than in some other countries, according to a report compiled by the National Science Council of the Executive Yuan.

The recently released report indicates that women workers dropping out of the workforce to tend their families generally have difficulty finding employment later. Jobs with flexible working hours that would allow working mothers to juggle family and career are hard to find.

The same report points out that many employees in the private sector have turned to family businesses because of the economic recession. These people usually remain self-employed even when the economic prospects take a turn for the better, according to the report.

The report also says there is evidence that many firms tend to lay off senior employees to avoid paying their pensions. Under the Labor Standards Law, an employee is entitled to apply for retirement and a pension after having served a company or agency for 25 years.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN EXPERIMENTING WITH STEM CELL TREATMENT FOR PARKINSON'S DISEASE

TEXT.P: Taiwan scientists have begun experimenting with embryonic stem cell treatment of Parkinson's disease, local researchers announced Friday.

They made the remarks after U.S. President George W. Bush announced Thursday that he will allow federally funded research into embryonic stem cells on a limited basis, in a compromise decision that ended months of sometimes agonized soul searching in the United States.

Lin Hsin-jung, director of the neurosurgery department of the Tri-Service General Hospital, said he managed to obtain Department of Health (DOH) permission several years ago to experiment with embryonic stem cell treatment of Parkinson's disease.

Lin said his research team has injected stem cells harvested from miscarried human embryos into the brains of patients with Parkinson's disease, a severe ailment that causes muscles to become weak and the limbs to shake.

"We have injected stem cells into the area of the brain that controls muscle movement, where the disease kills nerve cells, with a view to regenerating the neurons and reversing the illness," Lin explained.

To date, Lin said, such embryonic stem cell transplants have not been successful in curing the disease. "But the therapeutic effects of the stem cell transplants can compete with surgical therapy," he noted.

Meanwhile, Lin said he has also filed an application with the DOH for clinical experiments involving the transplant of striate cells from embryonic stem cells into the brains of patients with Huntington's chorea, a rare inherited disease of the central nervous system characterized by progressive dementia, abnormal posture and involuntary movements.
Lin said his research team has already completed clinical trials on animals. "We'll begin clinical experiments on humans after receiving DOH approval," he added.

Shih Tzu-pi, director of the Graduate Institute of Cell and Molecular Biology of Taipei Medical University, said that as embryonic stem cells have the ability to transform themselves into virtually any other type of cell in the body, scientists hope to harness the transformational qualities of stem cells to provide treatments for a variety of diseases affecting millions of people worldwide.
"Many scientists believe stem cells can be used in treating brain maladies like Alzheimer's and Parkinson's disease, as well as diabetes, heart attacks, strokes and spinal injuries," he added.
Noting that stem cells are primitive cells which have the ability to transform themselves into many other types of cells, Shih said they offer the potential of regenerating damaged organs or tissue.

The DOH has not yet allowed stem cell plantation as a regular medical treatment, but several private companies, including Yuen Foong Yu Group, have introduced umbilical cord stem cell storage services. With the concept of "biological insurance" becoming increasingly popular in the United States, those firms believe that stem cell storage services will also have great market potential in Taiwan.

Shih noted that after the birth of a child, the umbilical cord is basically medical waste. "But stem cells harnessed from umbilical cords might have promising therapeutic effects. Moreover, self-transplantation of stem cells can avoid the problems of rejection. Therefore, storing umbilical cord stem cells may offer much promise for treatments of one's own diseases in the future," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL FIGURES TO CONVERGE ON TAIWAN FOR `WORLD PEACE FORUM'

TEXT.P: Six Nobel Peace Prize winners, 14 congressmen and parliamentarians from the United States and Japan, and the heads of 11 international NGOs, have been invited to Taipei next week to participate in a campaign for world peace initiated by Republic of China Vice President Annette Lu.

Lu said that Taiwan has no reason to be pessimistic about itself because the fact that so many international figures have been invited to come to the island on such short notice reveals the degree of international support for Taiwan.
"Taiwan is not a trouble-maker, but a peace-maker," Lu added.
The series of activities are scheduled to begin Aug. 14, when Lu will accompany the guests on a trip to the frontline ROC island of Kinmen and host a banquet in their honor in the evening.
A "World Peace Forum" will be convened Aug. 15-16 with the theme "Creating Eternal Peace in the Taiwan Strait." Former ROC President Lee Teng-hui is slated to speak at the forum's opening ceremony.

An outdoor concert titled "A Night of World Peace" will be held the evening of Aug. 15 at Taipei's Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall, where Lu and the Nobel laureates will jointly start a "Terrestrial Globe of Peace" in commemoration of the end of World War II 56 years ago.

The Nobel Peace Prize winners invited to attend the event include former Polish President Lech Walesa; Oscar Arias Sanchez, who served as Costa Rica's president from 1986 to 1990; former South African President F.W. de Clerk; Betty Williams, a peace advocate from Ireland; Jody Williams, a U.S. anti-land mine activist; and Joseph Rotblat, a British nuclear scientist who advocates the elimination of nuclear arms around the world.

DOC.HEADLINE: RESIDENCY QUOTA FOR MAINLAND CHINESE SPOUSES TO BE FURTHER EASED

TEXT.P: A Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) official promised Friday that the annual quota for mainland Chinese spouses allowed to settle in Taiwan will be further increased next year.

Liu Teh-hsun, director of the MAC's department of legal affairs, made the promise at a public hearing organized by opposition New Party Legislator Lai Shyh-bao on the many restrictions faced by mainlanders who have married Taiwan people.

At present, the Republic of China government grants permanent residency to 3,600 mainland Chinese spouses annually. This quota has not been adjusted for three years due to a freeze imposed by the Legislative Yuan, but as it will expire at the end of this year, Liu said, the MAC has begun considering raising the residency quota.
Lai said at the public hearing that mainland Chinese brides have to wait for many years before they can secure residency permits in Taiwan.

Moreover, he went on, mainland Chinese spouses face stringent work restrictions. "The government should ease all those restrictions in line with the general world human rights trends," the outspoken lawmaker added.

More than 100 mainland Chinese brides and their spouses attended the hearing. Wang Jing, a mainland bride from Hubei, urged the ROC government to ease job restrictions on mainland spouses. "I hope to work to help my family make ends meet, as my husband's salary is not enough to finance the living expenses of my in-laws and our children," she complained.

Representatives of the private Cross-Strait Marriage Coordination Association presented many proposals for improving the treatment of mainland spouses, including allowing them to travel directly across the Taiwan Strait via the ROC's frontline islands of Kinmen and Matsu to help ease their financial burden, and allowing those who have been married to local people for a year to apply for permanent residency on the island.
In response, Liu said the MAC will heed the mainland spouses' petitions and will take steps to ease certain restrictions based on humanitarian grounds.

Meanwhile, the MAC, which charts Taiwan's policy toward mainland China, will launch a "growth camp" program next week to help mainland Chinese spouses adapt themselves to the lifestyle and social customs in Taiwan.
The program, to kick off Tuesday, will offer Taiwanese dialect teaching, legal counseling, health knowledge, first-aid training and parenting courses.
This will be the first time that the MAC has offered the training program for mainland Chinese spouses.
According to MAC tallies, the number of cross-strait marriages has exceeded 100,000 and the number of mainland spouses allowed to settle in Taiwan has also increased rapidly.
"Against this background, we have decided to organize specially designed training programs for mainland Chinese spouses to help them cope with family and legal problems," said an MAC official.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PREMIER TO VISIT FOUR CARIBBEAN ALLIES

TEXT.P: The Government Information Office (GIO) confirmed Friday that Premier Chang Chun-hsiung will visit four Caribbean states between Aug.31 and Sept. 12.

The GIO said in a press release that Chang will visit St. Vincent and the Grenadines to mark the 20th anniversary of the establishment of ties between the two countries and will then visit St. Christopher, Dominica and Grenada.
It will be Chang's first overseas visit since he took office Oct. 4 last year.
The GIO press release said leaders of the four Caribbean allies have already visited Taiwan and have invited Chang to visit their states in return.
In order to save on travel costs, the press release went on, Chang will be accompanied by only about ten Cabinet ministers and business leaders.
In light of a United Nations assembly scheduled to open Sept. 11 in New York, Chang will ask the four states to continue their support for Taiwan's bids to rejoin the U.N.
Chang's itinerary will be announced after details have been worked out with the host countries, said the press release.

Chang's chief of staff Chiou I-jen said Friday that Chang is making the trip mainly because of the invitation from St. Vincent and the Grenadines Premier James Mitchell, who requested Chang's presence to mark the 20th anniversary of the establishment of diplomatic ties between the two counties.

Mitchell put forward the invitation some two months ago before Taiwan was ravaged by Typhoon Toraji, which claimed the lives of more than 100 and Chiou said the island's rescue work is already on the track, while diplomacy is also a vital part of the premier's job.

Although Foreign Minister Tien Hung-mao is expected to visit the region Aug. 27, it would be impolite to have him take Chang's place on this occasion, since the invitation was extended to Chang, Chiou said.
Once the premier is in the region, there would be no reason not to drop in on the other three states, of which are Taiwan's close allies, said Chiou.

Chiou offered the reasoning behind Chang's trip in response to criticism by the local China Times newspaper, which described the trip as inappropriate, given that the island is still reeling from the effects of Toraji.
What is more, the China Times said, Chang's trip is a waste of the nation's resources at a time when the government is tightening its belt to cope with its mounting debts.
The paper pointed out that Tien will meet his counterparts from all four Caribbean states in Grenada Aug. 27.
Tien has dropped planned visits to St. Vincent and the Grenadines because of Chang's visit, and will travel instead to Porto Rico.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER PREMIER PROPOSES MEASURES TO SAVE TAIWAN'S ECONOMY

TEXT.P: Former Premier Vincent Siew proposed Friday that Taiwan should focus on playing the roles of a research and development innovation center and a global logistics center in order to save the local economy.

A vice chairman of the presidential Economic Development Advisory Conference (EDAC), Siew said at a seminar on Taiwan's economic prospects that he will unveil his full assessment on the economy in the upcoming EDAC conference slated to be held Aug. 24-26.

Siew said that a major part of Taiwan's economic problems can be traced to a confidence crisis.
