He added that the public tends to lose confidence in future economic prospects when "political disturbances" are added to the mix at a time of global economic sluggishness, while the government lacks a clear set of economic policies to guide future development directions.
He went on to say that Taiwan is also facing the problem of economic structural transformation and must find the best strategic positions as the new economic structure is being established.

Siew proposed that the government should create a "Taiwan Innovation Research and Development Fund" to invest in strategic industries with their innovative research or assist in the establishment of new companies that aim to bring new and innovative products to the market.
He also proposed the establishment of an "Industry Structure Reform Committee" to provide guidance for local companies trying to reorganize or merge with one another.

Meanwhile, he suggested that the number of local banks should be greatly decreased within three years through mergers and that these banks should write off bad loans within the same period in order to drive the rate of overdue loans down to below 3 percent.

Siew proposed that the government should immediately adjust its "go slow, be patient" policy regulating Taiwan business investment in mainland China and gradually allow direct trade, investment and shipping between Taiwan and the mainland.

He added that technology specialists from mainland China should be allowed to come to Taiwan so that both capital and human resources could undergo bilateral exchanges, which would be to the benefit of the island.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN EXPATRIATES TO LAUNCH PUBLICITY CAMPAIGN FOR ROC'S U.N. BID
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Aug. 9 (CNA) (By Eric Tseng and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Major Taiwanese associations on the U.S. East Coast will launch a series of publicity programs to promote the Republic of China's bid to join the United Nations, sources said Thursday.

The groups, led by the Formosan Association of Public Affairs (FAPA), are pushing overseas Chinese associations and prominent Chinese community leaders across the United States to lobby American Congress members to ask their government not to speak against the ROC's U.N. bid this year.

When the U.N. Steering Committee discussed whether to include the ROC's U.N. bid into the General Assembly agenda last year, the United States, Britain and France all voiced opposition to the proposal.
A FAPA spokesman said he hopes this will not happen again this year.

The spokesman said major Taiwan expatriate groups, including the FAPA, the Taiwanese Association and the U.S. East Coast chapter of the ROC's ruling Democratic Progressive Party, will organize a parade in areas adjacent to the U.N. headquarters Sept. 11 to express the people of Taiwan's strong desire for a U.N. seat.
"Through the parade, we hope to attract the attention of the U.N. missions of countries around the world and the American public to our U.N. bid," said the FAPA spokesman.
The ROC, a U.N. founding member, has been shut out of the United Nations and its affiliated organizations since 1971, when the General Assembly gave the China seat to mainland China.

Ten of the ROC's diplomatic allies presented a joint proposal to the U.N. Secretariat Wednesday demanding that the U.N. General Assembly set up a special working group to address the "exceptional international situation" faced by Taiwan over the past three decades.
This was the ninth time that ROC allies have filed such a proposal to push the U.N. General Assembly to study measures for the people of Taiwan's voice to be heard in the United Nations.

In the past years, the ROC allies' proposal has consistently been shot down at the U.N. Steering Committee due to mainland China's opposition. The fate of this year's proposal "remains unclear," the sources said, as the Steering Committee has yet to discuss the issue. The General Assembly is scheduled to open its annual session in mid-September.
The 10 countries which jointly presented the proposal this year are Belize, Burkina Faso, Chad, Dominica, El Salvador, The Gambia, Nicaragua, Palau, Senegal and Tuvalu.

In their joint proposal, the 10 ROC allies urged the U.N. General Assembly to form a special working group to study Taiwan's U.N. bid and invite ROC representatives to take part in the working panel to facilitate its work.

The proposal also urged the U.N. General Assembly and the international community to express more concern about the development of cross-Taiwan Strait relations and to encourage both sides to resume dialogue.

The ROC representative office in New York invited the U.N. ambassadors of Greneda, The Gambia, Nicaragua and Tuvalu to attend a news conference Thursday to explain why their countries would support the ROC's U.N. bid.
All four ambassadors said friendship was only one of the reasons behind their countries' support for the ROC's drive to seek a U.N. seat.

Noting that the ROC's U.N. bid is a fight for "concept and belief," the four ambassadors said they have thrown their support behind the ROC's cause mainly out of their belief in justice and fairness. They said it is extremely unreasonable and unfair to exclude the ROC from the United Nations and its affiliates.

The ambassadors said the ROC is fully qualified for a U.N. seat in view of its economic strength, political democratization and willingness and capability to help other countries in their national development.

DOC.HEADLINE: IC INDUSTRY TO REBOUND IN FOURTH QUARTER: TSMC HEAD

TEXT.P: The local hi-tech industry has had bad luck this year due to overstocking, but the IC-industry is expected to revive in the fourth quarter of this year, Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Corp. (TSMC) Chairman Morris Chang said Friday.

In both the short term and the long term, the prospects for the local IC industry are optimistic, Chang said, predicting that the local industry will regain momentum in the next quarter and will strongly rebound in the middle of next year. Based on the principles of Moore's Law, he pointed out, the long-haul prospects for the industry are optimistic.
The TSMC chief made the remarks while attending a seminar on high technology in Taiwan, mainland China and Hong Kong.

Although Taiwan's semiconductor foundries are the most advanced in the world, Chang claimed, "legal protection and quick innovation" are the most important "economic values" for hi-tech businesses. Taiwan hi-tech businesses should seek to upgrade the "economic value" of their products, or they will be caught up by their mainland Chinese counterparts in five or 10 years, he warned.

Chang also pointed out that Taiwan is facing the problem of a lack of "creative talent." He said it is important that a creative culture and inventive climate is built in Taiwan and that Taiwan must connect its economic strength and technology clout with those of mainland China and Hong Kong to explore the most value-added technologies and products.

In response to a proposal that the Taiwan authorities should allow the local IC industry to develop in mainland China, Chang said "the viewpoint may be correct" because by doing so, it would be easier to recruit well-trained professional elite in the mainland.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI MAYOR PRAISES EFFICIENCY OF SEOUL MASS RAPID TRANSPORT SYSTEM

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou Friday praised the efficiency and convenience provided by the Seoul Mass Rapid Transport (SMRT) system after taking the train from the Seoul City Hall to his hotel.
Ma, accompanied by a 30-member delegation, had been visiting the city government's departments of transport, culture and tourism.

Ma heard a briefing on the city's "digital media city" project aimed at promoting the development of the high-tech industry in Korea. The project is expected to turn the northwestern part of the city into a good business area and Ma questioned all the details of the project.
Later in the day, Ma was also briefed on Seoul's culture and tourism.
He then lunched with members of the academic sector before visiting a "games academy" and the film classification screening committee.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC FINANCE MINISTRY ENCOURAGING BANK MERGERS
DOC.DATELINE: Los Angeles, Aug. 9 (CNA) (By Shu Lu-sheng & Victor Lai)

TEXT.P: Republic of China Finance Minister Yen Ching-chang said in Los Angeles Thursday that his ministry is taking various measures to encourage mergers of local financial institutions.
He made the remarks while speaking on "The Direction of the ROC's Financial Management" on the opening day of the 17th World Chinese Financial Conference.

To ensure the healthy development of Taiwan's financial industry, Yen said that effective steps must be taken to eliminate 53 ill-managed private banks and 362 grassroots financial institutions through mergers.
After the Financial Organizations Merger Law and the Financial Holding Control Law are implemented, he noted that the island's financial industry will become sounder than it is at present.

The minister added that following government approval of the statutes on financial reconstruction and foundation establishment, some NT$140 billion will be collected within four years to help local financial institutions that are on the brink of bankruptcy.
He went on to say that steps will also be taken to make local bank management more transparent in order to attract more foreign capital.

Yen stressed the importance of improving the competitiveness of Taiwan's financial industry through a series of reforms to provide a better environment for investment by international financial institutions.

The three-day conference is being attended by delegates from over 100 financial institutions in Taiwan and the United States. The main theme is "The New Era Challenge and Opportunity for the World Chinese Financial Industry."

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER TAIWAN GANG LEADER TO BE FREED BY CAMBODIAN COURT
DOC.DATELINE: Bangkok, Aug. 10 (CNA) (By Kuo Fang-chih and Fang Wen-hung)

TEXT.P: A local court in Cambodia ruled Friday that Chen Chi-li, a former leader of Taiwan's notorious Bamboo Union gang, be released on a suspended jail sentence for illegal possession of arms and illegal use of diplomatic license plates.

Chen, who was acquitted of two other charges -- membership in an illegal armed group and forgery of nationality documents -- received a three-year sentence that he will not have to serve if he stays out of trouble for the next five years.

The judge in Chen's case said that the 59-year-old Cambodian government adviser has already been held since last July while awaiting the final verdict, and that he has made contributions to Cambodia by helping the Southeast Asian country build schools and public housing.
Two other defendants, 28-year-old Lia Mong In from Taiwan and 45-year-old Quong Ou Quing from mainland China, were also given three-year suspended sentences for illegal possession of arms.
Chen was quoted as saying that he will continue to stay in Cambodia after he is released, and that he will not return to Taiwan, where he is wanted on other charges.

DOC.HEADLINE: CABINET WILL NOT HOLD NON-BINDING REFERENDUM ON NUCLEAR POWER PLANT

TEXT.P: The Cabinet announced Friday that it has decided not to hold a non-binding referendum on the controversial fourth nuclear power plant alongside the year-end elections for legislators and local government chiefs.
Cabinet Secretary-General Chiou I-jen said at a news conference that Premier Chang Chun-hsiung made the decision after "prudently evaluating" the conclusions reached by a special Cabinet task force.

"The special panel made a thorough study of the issue from eight angles -- the scope, funding, manpower, legality, possible impact on the local economy, elements of uncertainty, possible reaction of anti-nuclear groups and environmental activists, and government credibility," Chiou said.

As the possible effects of "elements of uncertainty" are difficult to control and evaluate, Chiou said Chang finally decided to scrap a previous plan to hold a referendum on the fourth nuclear power plant project. As Taiwan has yet to legislate a plebiscite law, if the proposed referendum were to be held, its results would in any case be non-binding.
Chiou said the premier felt sorry for his failure to honor the promise to cancel the referendum plan.
Chiou stressed that the cancellation does not imply that the Cabinet opposes the people's right to a referendum under the Constitution.
Chiou said that whether a referendum on the controversial plant will be held in the future will depend on the domestic political situation.
The current government, led by the anti-nuclear Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), abruptly announced its decision to halt construction on the partially built nuclear power plant last October.
The announcement immediately drew strong opposition from the three major opposition parties -- the Kuomintang (KMT), the People First Party (PFP) and the New Party (NP).

The three opposition parties, which jointly control nearly two-thirds of the seats in the legislature, then formed an alliance to boycott the DPP minority government's policy proposals at every turn. Bowing to pressure from the opposition alliance, the DPP government finally resumed construction of the controversial power plant early this year after a 101-day hiatus.

At that time, Chang promised to hold a non-binding referendum on the project along with the year-end legislative elections in an effort to defuse a backlash from anti-nuclear diehards, including former DPP Chairman Yin Yi-hsiung.

The proposal drew mixed reactions in local society. Chang then formed a panel to study the feasibility of the referendum plan. As the Taiwan economy has been mired in a downturn since the beginning of this year, many people have voiced opposition to the referendum plan as they fear that renewed debate on the issue would again cause political instability and hinder economic recovery.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN CHARITIES TO HELP TIBETANS IN INDIA: VP

TEXT.P: Republic of China Vice President Annette Lu said Friday that Taiwan's charity organizations will try to render assistance to Tibetans residing in India.
Lu made the remarks while receiving Lodi Rinpoche -- a special envoy of the Dalai Lama to the United States -- and Korchen Rinpoche.

Lu launched a drive to "send love to India" after an earthquake rattled that country in January, causing heavy casualties. Many charity organizations have responded to Lu's appeal and dispatched relief goods to India.

The drive's organizing committee also organized a delegation to make sure the relief goods reached the area of devastation. The delegation also visited Dharamsala, the site of the Dalai Lama's Tibetan government-in-exile, to observe the living conditions of Tibetans in that area, Lu said.
Lu added that she will continue the "send love to India" campaign, as Tibetans there badly need the assistance.

She also invited her guests to take part in her World Peace rally slated for Aug. 15, the anniversary of the end of World War II. Six Nobel Peace Prize winners have been invited to the rally, as well as various other dignitaries.

Lu also asked her guests to convey her personal regards to the Dalai Lama. The Tibetan officials also expressed their heartfelt thanks to the government and people of the Republic of China for the hospitality extended to the Dalai Lama during his last visit to Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: TRANSPORTATION MINISTER LEAVES FOR U.S. TO LURE TOURIST DOLLARS

TEXT.P: Transportation and Communications Minister Yeh Chu-lan left for the United States Friday on a 12-day overseas tour to sell Taiwan's tourist market to foreign investors.

Yeh said prior to her departure for Los Angeles that she hopes to prop up Taiwan's tourist industry, create more job opportunities and "stimulate foreign experiences" and bring in foreign tourist dollars for several large-scale investment projects at home, including a recreational center plan for Tapeng Bay in southern Pingtung County.

The Tapeng Bay recreational center plan is the largest of its kind launched by the government in recent years, Yeh said. The government will pump in US$300 million in building infrastructure on government-owned land in Tapeng Bay, with the remaining US$200 million-worth of investment open to foreign investors and private businesses wishing to take part in the joint venture through the build-operate-transfer model.

Yeh's trip will take her to Las Vegas, where she will study how the desert city has succeeded in building its casino empire in the sand. The transportation minister will also head for Hawaii to learn what the local tourism authorities have done to create brand awareness and to Japan to study how the neighboring country projects and markets its hot springs.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEF ASKS ARATS TO HELP HANDLE RADIO INTERFERENCE CASE

TEXT.P: The Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) wrote Friday to its mainland Chinese counterpart the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) to ask for help resolving a problem with radio interference from mainland stations.

Cheng Sheng Broadcasting Corp. Ltd. had informed the SEF that its Taichung-based radio station was receiving heavy interference by radio waves beamed from the Strait Radio Station in mainland China. The interference was also reported by the Broadcasting Corporation of China, another local station.
The SEF stressed in the letter that Taiwan is an open society and will not intentionally block any information related to mainland China.

The letter expressed the hope that ARATS will take immediate action to stop the radio interference and noted that the people on both sides of the Taiwan Strait should be able to freely select their choice of radio program, which will upgrade the quality of exchanges between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.
The SEF and ARATS are quasi-official organizations set up by Taipei and Beijing, respectively, to handle cross-strait exchanges in the absence of official ties.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND CHINESE HIJACKERS EXECUTED FOR MURDER IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: After being on death row for almost 10 years, two mainland Chinese hijackers were executed Friday night at the Taipei Prison for kidnap and murder.
Minister of Justice Chen Ding-nan signed the execution orders for Cho Chang-jen and Chiang Hung-chuan Friday, clearing up the last formalities for their execution.
Cho and Chiang were charged with kidnapping and murdering a local businessman in 1991.

Although their cases had been tried six times by courts at various levels, the death sentences handed down by the court of the first trial remained unchanged and were finalized last Sept. 22, when the Supreme Court threw out their appeal.
They were given a reprieve last October when the country's supreme watchdog the Control Yuan stepped in at the request of Cho's wife to review the case and put the executions on hold.
After an eight-month examination, the Control Yuan decided recently not to interfere, saying it found no evidence to justify a reopening of the trial.

The case has drawn the limelight from the very beginning because the two inmates were once hailed as anti-communist heroes in Taiwan. Cho and Chiang, along with four others, fled to Taiwan from mainland China by hijacking a mainland Chinese airplane to South Korea in 1983.
They were escorted to Taiwan in 1984 after being tried and jailed briefly in South Korea as hijackers.
The disputes over the six hijackers strained Taipei-Seoul ties when the two countries were close Cold War allies.
Cho married one of the female hijackers after settling in Taiwan.
One of Cho's accomplice in the kidnap-murder case, Shih Hsiao-nin, who is one of the six hijackers in the 1983 case, was sentenced to life imprisonment.

Cho and Chiang were the first "anti-communist heroes" to be executed for crimes in Taiwan. They each agreed to donate their organs after being executed, which means they were each shot with a pistol at close range in the neck rather than in the heart, to protect their organs from damage.

DOC.HEADLINE: GUATEMALA PRESIDENT TO VISIT ROC IN OCTOBER
DOC.DATELINE: Panama City, Aug. 10 (CNA) (By Chung Hai-tai & Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: Guatemalan President Alfonso Portillo Cabrera is slated to visit the Republic of China to celebrate the ROC's Oct. 10 national day, Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission Vice Minister Chen Rong-jye said Friday.
Chen quoted Portillo as saying that he was impressed by ROC President Chen Shui-bian when Chen visited Guatemala City in May and would pay a return visit to Taipei.
Chen called on Portillo in Guatemala City Thursday after attending an ethnic Chinese conference in Guatemala City. The conference brought together leaders of Chinese communities in Central America.
Chen and the Chinese leaders attending the conference also called on Vice President Juan Francisco Reyes.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PRESIDENT'S REMARKS ON `ONE CHINA' TOUCH OFF MIXED REACTIONS

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian's remarks that the "one China" issue should be resolved through the tone of the ROC Constitution drew mixed responses from various parties Friday.
Chang Jung-kung, an official of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT), said that the KMT has always handled the "one China" in accordance with the Constitution.

He said that 14 national policy advisors to Chen proposed last month that the government act to resolve the "one China" issue in line with the Constitution, but the proposal was immediately opposed by over 30 senior advisors and national policy advisors to the president.

Therefore, Chang said, he doubted Chen's ability to live up to the remarks he made Friday and that he also doubted his ability to quell the divided opinions within the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP).

Chen told visiting U.S. Senator Christopher Bond that "only in line with the spirit of the ROC Constitution can the cross-strait differences be resolved" and added that adhering to the Constitution "is also the best answer to the method for resolving the `one China' issue for the governments and people of the two sides of the Taiwan Strait."
Opposition People First Party (DPP) spokesman Chang Hsien-yao described Chen's statement as a very important step forward from his previous position on the issue.
He expressed the hope that the DPP will extend help to the president on the issue rather than becoming a "blocking stone" on the road to the normalization of cross-strait relations.
DPP legislative caucus leader Chou Hsi-wei said that Chen is "always inconsistent" in his remarks made to foreign visitors and to the people at home.
Therefore, he urged the president to clearly spell out whether he recognizes the "one China" as stated in the Constitution.
On the other hand, DPP legislative caucus leader Tsai Huang-lang pointed out that "one China" in the Constitution means the Republic of China.
He said that mainland China "must respect the ROC as a country with independent sovereignty and respect Chen as the 10th president elected in accordance with the Constitution."
Tsai said that substantive negotiations on "one China" can proceed only after the two sides of the Taiwan Strait are able to conduct talks on a peaceful and equitable basis.
Meanwhile, Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Vice Chairman Chen Ming-tung reiterated the MAC's position, saying that both sides should sit down again to find an acceptable solution to "one China."
He said Taiwan will never accept Beijing's "one China" stance, which regards the PRC as the "one China."
"It is impossible for the ROC government, the president or other officials to accept this," Chen stressed.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies on Saturday are as follows:
The China Times:
The Ministry of Finance posts special teams in 36 problem grassroots banking institutions.
The United Daily News:
Finance ministry teams to help 36 problem banking institutions restructure and streamline management.
The Liberty Times:
Restructuring of 36 problem banking institutions kick off.
The Taiwan Daily:
President Chen attempts to clarify ROC's 'one China' position.
The Central Daily News:
Two former defectors from mainland China executed on conviction of kidnapping and murder.
The China Post:
Government rejects referendum on fourth nuclear power plant.
The Taiwan News:
Cabinet ends referendum push for 4th nuclear power plant.
The Taipei Times:
Accept the ROC, President Chen tells China.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, Aug. 11, or the 22nd day of the sixth month of the Year of the Snake according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1786: The Rajah of Kedah in Malaya cedes Penang to Britain.
1858: Christiaan Eijkman, the Dutch physician who won the 1929 Nobel Prize for medicine for his discovery of Vitamin B, is born.
1863: The French, who occupy southern Vietnam, make Cambodia a protectorate.
1919: Scottish-born American industrialist and philanthropist Andrew Carnegie dies at the age of 84. He amassed a fortune in the steel industry and donated millions of dollars for the benefit of the public.
1921: Warren G. Harding, the 29th president of the United States, formally invites China, Japan, Britain, France and Italy to join a disarmament meeting in Washington, D.C. to cope with an increasingly dangerous international situation after World War I.
1930: Britain goes broke. The United States and France each lend it US$46 million, while American bankers extend another US$111 million.
1932: Herbert Hoover, the 31st president of the United States, says it is time to scrap Prohibition. He lost the presidency to Franklin D. Roosevelt later that same year.
1936: Nationalist Chinese forces of Chiang Kai-shek enter Canton after foiling a rebellion led by Chen Chi-tang in the city in southern China.
1945: The Allies inform Japan that its surrender offer is acceptable.
1945: Communist "Yenan General Headquarters" orders Chinese communist troops to start an all-out revolt against the Republic of China government.
1950: The U.N. Security Council rejects a Soviet proposal for the immediate expulsion of the ROC delegation. The Russian delegation walks out in protest.
1960: Chad gains independence from France.
1960: The ROC recognizes the Ivory Coast and Chad.
1966: A peace treaty is signed in Jakarta, ending three years of hostilities between Malaysia and Indonesia.
1972: President Richard M. Nixon completes his "Vietnamization" of the Vietnam War by pulling out the last 92 American soldiers from the Southeast Asian country.
1973: The Asian Peoples' Anti-Communist League opens its three-day 19th Conference in Taipei.
1975: The first meeting of the Asian and Pacific Congress on Health, Physical Education and Recreation opens in Taipei with 250 experts from 17 nations and areas attending.
1976: The industrial and commercial panel of the National Reconstruction Seminar opens a three-day meeting to make recommendations to the government.
1986: Sixteen people are killed and 87 others injured in an accidental explosion aboard the tanker SS Canari which is waiting to be scrapped in a shipwrecking yard in Kaohsiung Harbor.
1992: The United States, Canada and Mexico reach an agreement to set up a North American free-trade zone that would rank as the world's largest single trading bloc.
1993: The ROC Cable Television Law goes into effect.
1997: An international meeting called to shore up the shaky Thai economy offers loans of US$16 billion to the financial crisis-hit country.
1999: Taiwan's China Airlines signs an agreement with Boeing Co. of the United States to buy 13 B747-400 cargo planes for an estimated US$2.5 billion.
2000: A group of bankers urge the ROC government to take effective measures to crack down on credit card crime in order to prevent Taiwan from becoming an "Asian financial crime center."
2000: A "Tzu Chi Village" in South Africa built by Taiwan's Buddhist Compassion Relief Tzu Chi Foundation, a charity organization, is formally inaugurated. Meanwhile, the Tzu Chi Medical Center announces the 99th and 100th overseas cases in which it has supplied bone marrow for transplant operations.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "There is only one way to command the obedience of the members of one's family. If a man looking into his own heart is not true to himself, he will not command the obedience of the members of his family."

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY (Aug. 12)
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, Aug. 12, or the 23rd day of the sixth month of the Year of the Snake according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1099: The Crusaders defeat the Egyptians at Ascalon on the Palestine coast in the First Crusade.
1813: Austria declares war against Napoleon.
1848: George Stephenson, the British railway pioneer who built the first passenger railway in 1825, dies at the age of 67. He also developed the first practical steam locomotive, the "Rocket."
1877: A group of people witness a public demonstration of a new device, a phonograph that records the human voice, at Thomas Edison's "invention factory" at Menlo Park, New Jersey.
1881: Cecil B. De Mille, the American film director, is born. He is legendary for his large-scale Biblical and historical epics such as "The Ten Commandments," "Samson and Delilah" and "Cleopatra."
1898: The United States and Spain sign a protocol ending the Spanish-American War, with Spain relinquishing Cuba and ceding Puerto Rico to the United States. In addition, the Hawaiian Islands are formally annexed by the United States.
1908: The Ford Motor Co. introduces its Model T car, a sturdy, black, four-cylinder number that comes in two versions: tourer and roadster. Both retail at incredibly low prices: the roadster at US$825 and the tourer for just US$25 more.
1912: William Booth, a Methodist minister who founded the Salvation Army in London in 1865, dies of illness in London at the age of 83. The Salvation Army works to foster a love of God and to provide for the needy. It offers its services to people of any race, creed, sex or age.
1914: Britain declares war on Austria-Hungary.
1946: The stolen body of dictator Benito Mussolini is found in northern Italy.
1948: The United States recognizes South Korea.
1954: The last batch of United Nations forces in the Korean War pulls out of Korea.
1961: Chen Chia-keng, an overseas Chinese from Singapore and founder of Amoy University, dies of illness in Beijing at the age of 88.
1970: The Union of Soviet Socialist Republics and West Germany sign a non-aggression pact in Moscow.
1970: A China Airlines (CAL) passenger plane of the Republic of China crashes into a mountain on its way from Hualien in eastern Taiwan to Taipei, killing or injuring 31 people.
1978: Taiwan's fastest electrified train, the Tzu Chiang Express, makes a test run between Taipei and Taichung.
1978: Mainland China and Japan sign a treaty of peace and friendship in Beijing.
1985: A Japan Airlines Boeing 747 Jumbo jet crashes into Mount Osutaka on its way from Tokyo to Osaka, killing all but four of the 524 people aboard.
1990: Beijing's attempt to restore its tarnished image after the slaughter in Tiananmen Square receives a severe setback. Official documentation of the disturbances now reveals that more than 450 were killed, the majority by bullets, while 750 were injured and 3,000 were detained.
1991: Two mainland journalists arrive in Taipei, marking the first-ever visit to the ROC by the mainland Chinese press.
1995: The United States government decides to stop all nuclear testing.
1996: ROC Vice President and Premier Lien Chan departs for the Dominican Republic to attend the Aug. 16 inauguration of President Leonel Fernandez.
1999: CAL signs an agreement with Airbus Industrie of Europe for a US$1.8 billion order for seven A340-300 passenger jets, with an option for one more A340-300 and four A330-300s.
2000: Yeh Chu-lan, ROC minister of transportation and communications, accepts the resignation of Chunghwa Telecom Co. Chairman Steven Chen and names MOTC Vice Minister Mao Chi-kuo to fill the chairmanship of the state-owned firm.
2000: Democratic Progressive Party Chairman Frank Hsieh urges mainland China to produce a president through popular elections so as to bridge the gap between the political systems and public opinion on either side of the Taiwan Strait.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "There is only one way for a man to be true to himself. If he does not know what is good, a man cannot be true to himself."

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC VICE PRESIDENT CALLS FOR ENVIRONMENTAL CONSERVATION

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu said Saturday that now is the time to carry out a complete re-assessment of water and land conservation in Taiwan in order to find the best ways to protect the environment.

Speaking at a seminar organized by the presidential Technology Advisory Committee on the possible factors that led to the widespread devastation caused by the passing of last Monday's Typhoon Toraji and how post-disaster reconstruction should proceed, Lu said that seeing the verdant countryside destroyed made her feel as if "God has become angry" and as if the land is fighting back against mankind.

Lu, who serves as chairwoman of the advisory committee, pointed out that some believe the disastrous losses brought about by Toraji could be attributed to the global climate changes that have led to an increase in the number of typhoons in the region, while others say that artificial factors, including excessive development, are the major culprits.

Stressing that although she is not expressing her dissatisfaction at the nation's betel nut farmers, Lu said that the fashionable "betel nut culture" -- as evidenced by the 3 million people in Taiwan who chew them, consuming 15 million betel nuts a year, or the equivalent worth of NT$100 billion (US$2.89 billion) -- must be "re-evaluated."

Typhoon Toraji, which killed 103 people and left 110 still missing in Central Taiwan, caused massive mudslides that some have attributed to the over-planting of shallow-rooted betel nut trees in slopeland areas.

Meanwhile, at a seminar organized by the National Policy Foundation on the effects of the most recently agreed upon international measures to control global warming on Taiwan, former Vice Premier Liu Chao-shiuan warned that Taiwan's average surface temperature has already gone up by 1.3 degrees Celsius since 1940 -- a figure even greater than the global average increase of 0.6 degrees Celsius since the beginning of the 20th century.
He pointed out that the addition of other factors such as excessive development of slopeland areas and excessive drawing of underground water will lead to more natural disasters.

Lee Chien-ming, deputy director of the Taiwan Research Institute's Department of Enterprise Economics, said at the same seminar that the government should begin planning pragmatic measures in response to the possibility that Taiwan will soon face international regulations on lowering greenhouse gas emissions.

DOC.HEADLINE: 36 FINANCIAL INSTITUTIONS UNDER SUPERVISION

TEXT.P: The Bureau of Monetary Affairs under the Finance Ministry and the Central Deposits Insurance Corp. took the initiative Friday to put 36 faltering local financial institutions under supervision.
The move is the first phase of a "Monetary Reconstruction Fund" action to consolidate the operations of local banks and farmers as well as fishermen's cooperatives.

The Monetary Reconstruction Fund under the Executive Yuan has formed a task force composed of personnel specialized in legal affairs, information technology and credit business, who have been temporarily transferred from the Bank of Taiwan, the Land Bank of Taiwan, the Taiwan Cooperative Bank and the Farmer's Bank of China.

The task force personnel have been assigned to the 36 institutions to check on their cash deposit status as well as their credit accounts. The institutions with negative net assets include 27 credit departments of farmer's associations, two credit departments of fishermen's associations and seven credit cooperatives, mostly in rural or coastal areas of central and southern Taiwan.
The task force will supervise the operations of these badly performing banks over the next three months and help them find merger possibilities.

Vice Finance Minister Chen Chun, who is concurrently vice chairman of the Monetary Reconstruction Fund management committee, said that the services of these 36 institutions will not be affected by the task force's supervision. He added that the Finance Ministry and the Central Bank of China would give a joint explanation of the operations to the press Sunday.

He said that the rights and benefits of all deposit accounts of the 36 institutions are guaranteed. He also noted that the accumulated amount of the deposit accounts total some NT$200 billion, representing less than 1 percent of the overall amount of all banking deposits in Taiwan.

Immediately after the stationing of the task force personnel, 14 farmer's and fishermen's cooperatives agreed to hand over the management of their credit departments. These departments are likely to be merged with public banks in the future.

The Monetary Reconstruction Fund was set up in July to help solve the financial problems of Taiwan's financial institutions. The task force will evaluate the status of the problem institutions and the fund can entrust the Central Deposit Insurance Corp. to manage the debts and assets of these institutions.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. ANALYST: 2008 OLYMPICS SHOULD BE LINKED TO ASIA-PACIFIC PEACE

TEXT.P: An American China expert said Friday that linking the 2008 Olympic Games directly to peace in the Asia-Pacific region would provide effective leverage over mainland China's behavior for the next seven years.

John Tkacik, a research fellow at the Heritage Foundation, a U.S. think tank, said it also would demonstrate that the United States is committed to "furthering human rights and democratic principles" and that affronts to those values will not be ignored.

Tkacik wrote in an analysis that many Americans remain concerned that mainland China's penchant for repression of dissent at home and aggressive behavior toward its neighbors could compromise the Olympics.

The Beijing Games will not begin for another seven years, time enough for the United States and other freedom-loving countries to compel Beijing to adopt true Olympic values and to demonstrate good behavior beyond its borders and at home by treating all people fairly, said Tkacik.

For example, he said, Washington should make clear to Beijing that the international community expects it to welcome rather than repress the profound contributions that religious beliefs, practices and charitable works make to society; encourage political reform; commit to the rule of law based on international norms; and eschew military bluster against Taiwan while accepting Taiwan's offers to discuss their differences as equals.

To this end, Tkacik said, America's leaders should caution Beijing that its use of force against Taiwan could spark an international boycott of the 2008 Games, should insist that visitors to mainland China be free of official threats to their person and property because of their political, social or religious views and keep the focus on mainland China's behavior.

Congress, for example, could require the State Department to make quarterly updates of its human rights records on mainland China, as well as regular reports on Beijing's aggressive behavior toward its neighbors and nations littoral to the South China Sea. "Such reports would indicate whether more concrete sanctions were needed," according to Tkacik.

DOC.HEADLINE: MINISTER ADVOCATES DIRECT CROSS-STRAIT TRADE AFTER WTO ENTRY

TEXT.P: Minister of Economic Affairs Lin Hsin-yi has voiced explicit support for opening direct trade links between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait after both sides are admitted to the World Trade Organization (WTO).

Lin expressed his advocacy in a written report delivered Saturday at a preparatory meeting of the cross-strait affairs panel under the soon-to-be-convened Economic Development Advisory Conference (EDAC).

It was the first time that Lin had made a concrete suggestion on the opening of direct cross-strait trade. Under current Republic of China law, cross-strait trade must be conducted via a third country or area.
In his report, Lin also suggested that the two sides should start negotiations as early as possible for opening direct sea and air cargo transportation links.

Lin said that direct cross-strait shipping and air links would help cut transport time and cost as well as reduce cargo inventory. "And direct cargo transport links would also bring about positive effects on cross-strait trade and Taiwan's bid to become a global business planning and resourcing hub," he noted.
Meanwhile, he said, Taiwan should allow more mainland Chinese products to enter its market to facilitate local enterprises' global business planning.

At present, only 56.4 of the items produced in the mainland are allowed to enter Taiwan. "As the times and industrial structure have been changing rapidly, we must review existing restrictions and make necessary adjustments," the minister said.

With a view to averting any possible adverse impact of opening direct cross-strait trade and expanding the list of mainland products to be allowed into the local market, Lin said Taiwan must simultaneously establish comprehensive import relief and self-defense systems in compliance with relevant WTO requirements.

Current WTO regulations allow member economies to establish self-defense systems to prevent dumping of farm produce, textiles and other categories of products. To prevent non-market economies from exporting goods at prices under fair market value, the WTO also permits its members to adopt defensive anti-dumping measures to cope with unfair trade practices of those countries.
With its cheap labor, low land cost and vast market, Lin said, mainland China has become one of the world's most important production centers for computers and consumer electronics.

Moreover, he went on, mainland China has used its large potential market in exchange for technology transfers and access to setting product standards. As a result, Lin said, mainland China's influence on Taiwan's economic and industrial development has increased steadily. "Against this backdrop, we must adjust our cross-strait trade policy from time to time to cope with the new challenges," he added.

Nevertheless, Lin remained cautious toward appeals by local entrepreneurs -- particularly those in the petrochemical and silicon wafer industries -- to ease restrictions on mainland China-bound investments.
Lin reaffirmed the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) stance on establishing a dynamic, flexible mechanism for adjusting the existing "go slow, be patient" policy on cross-strait investment.

He admitted that the current restrictions on the scale of cross-strait investment and the businesses allowed to invest have become outdated and may hinder Taiwan companies' development in the increasingly competitive global market.

Noting that Taiwan companies' investment projects have become ever larger, Lin said the current US$50 million ceiling for a single mainland China-bound investment plan may blunt Taiwan enterprises' competitive edge.

Therefore, he said, the MOEA suggests that mainland China-bound investment projects worth more than US$50 million be screened and approved on a case-by-case basis in accordance with the general situations of different industries.

In addition, Lin said the cap for accumulated mainland investment amount of each company should also be adjusted in line with the principle of "dynamic adjustment" to facilitate management of mainland China-bound investment.
In conclusion, he urged Taiwan enterprises to join forces with the government to develop the island into a research and development center and a hub for high value-added industries.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TOURISTS INJURED IN U.S. BUS ACCIDENT
DOC.DATELINE: Tainan, southern Taiwan, Aug. 11 (CNA) (By Fang Wen-hung)

TEXT.P: Family members of two local elementary school teachers who were injured in a bus accident Thursday on a sightseeing trip in Arizona were scheduled to depart for the United States Saturday to be with their injured relatives.
Su Hsiao-chien suffered severe head, rib and leg injuries when a bus carrying her and 47 other passengers was involved in an accident on a trip to the Grand Canyon and Las Vegas.
She was taken to a nearby hospital by helicopter and remained in serious condition as of Friday, according to a hospital spokeswoman.
Su's colleague, Kuo Wen-chun, suffered minor injuries and was discharged from the hospital after treatment, along with five other injured tourists from Taiwan who were also on the bus.

DOC.HEADLINE: KUOMINTANG URGES ROC PRESIDENT TO CLARIFY `ONE CHINA' REMARK

TEXT.P: The opposition Kuomintang (KMT) urged Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian Saturday to clarify his remarks that the "one China" issue should be resolved through the ROC Constitution, claiming that regional stability is at stake.

Chang Jung-kung, a KMT official in charge of mainland Chinese affairs, said that if Chen were to allow the mixed responses to his remarks and the different interpretations to spin out of control, then the public's faith in his leadership would only continue to falter -- which would be "very disadvantageous" to Taiwan at a "perilous time" for the situation in the Taiwan Strait.

Chen told visiting U.S. Senator Christopher Bond Friday that "only in line with the spirit of the ROC Constitution can cross-strait differences be resolved" and added that adhering to the Constitution "is also the best answer to the method for resolving the `one China' issue for the governments and people of the two sides of the Taiwan Strait."

Chang said that if Chen truly has the sincerity to interpret "one China" according to the Constitution, then that stance would be in line with the beliefs of the opposition KMT, People First Party and New Party.

That position would also be congruent with a recent recommendation on the issue by 14 of Chen's national policy advisers and with the final suggestion of a supra-partisan team that was instructed by the president last year to study the issue, Chang added.

He went on to say that voices against "one China, according to the Constitution" come mainly from within the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) itself and he urged Chen to clarify his remarks in order to resolve the internal differences between the government and the DPP.
Left unchecked, Chang continued, the different interpretations will only reinforce the "international image" that the Chen administration wavers on its mainland China policies.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN REMAINS WORLD'S NO. 1 NOTEBOOK SUPPLIER

TEXT.P: Estimated to gross 52.1 percent of the world notebook market share, Taiwan will remain the top supplier of notebooks this year, though the market share is declining, according to the Institute of Information Industry (III).

A recently released analysis of the Market Intelligence Center (MIC) of the III shows that in the first half of this year, Taiwan's notebook manufacturers put out 6,196,000 notebook computers with a production value amounting to US$5.816 billion.

Facing growing competition from South Korea and shrinking orders from Japan, both the production volume and value were less than those of the same period of last year, down 4 percent and 16.9 percent, respectively, according to the analysis.
Taking into account the international economic environment, local notebook manufacturers are not optimistic about the prospects for the third quarter and uncertain about the fourth quarter.

The MIC forecasts that Taiwan's notebook output will reach 13,094,000 units this year, about 52.1 percent of the overall world demand of 25,116,000 units. Last year, Taiwan's notebook output totaled 12,707,000 units, supplying 52.5 percent of the world demand.

According to the analysis, Taiwan's notebook manufacturers have been successful in the international market by supplying quality products at comparatively lower prices. However, they must not rely on the existing advantages, especially when their South Korean counterparts are putting much effort into research and development.

In recent months, Japanese manufacturers have supplied fewer and fewer OEM orders to Taiwan's notebook factories, because depreciation of the yen has led Japanese manufacturers to increase their self-sufficiency and to reduce supplies from abroad.
The analysis suggests that local manufacturers develop products of higher added-value and acquire patent rights for their designs in order to improve their international competitiveness.

DOC.HEADLINE: DENMARK'S SOCIALIST PEOPLE'S PARTY CALLS FOR VISA FOR ROC PRESIDENT
DOC.DATELINE: Paris, Aug. 10 (CNA) (By Tzou Ming-jhie and Fang Wen-hung)

TEXT.P: Denmark's Socialist People's Party Chairman Holger K. Nielsen said Friday that Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian should be granted a visa to allow him to receive in person the Liberal International 2001 "Prize for Freedom" in Copenhagen in November.

In an interview with the Politikken daily in response to Danish Foreign Minister Mogens Lykketoft's decision not to grant Chen a visa in accordance with what Lykketoft described as an agreement among E.U. nations not to issue visas for top officials from Taiwan, Nielsen said that the 1988 agreement is not politically binding.
He went on to say that the ROC is a free and democratic country that should be given the space and the opportunity to participate in international social activities.

Saying that Denmark has "no reason" to refuse Chen a visa, Nielsen said that Liberal International, a London-based federation of liberal parties from around the world, is not a government organization and that Chen is "not a troublemaker, but a peacemaker."

According to a Danish news agency, the 1988 agreement between 15 E.U. nations called only for a stop to official exchanges with senior ROC government officials starting from 1992 and does not restrict the issuance of visas for private visits. The agreement is not an official E.U. law and is therefore non-binding, the agency added.
The Liberal International decided to award the prize to Chen to honor his "outstanding contribution to freedom and liberalism in Taiwan."

DOC.HEADLINE: CAA MAY FACE LONG-TERM SUIT OVER SQ006 DISASTER

TEXT.P: The Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) may be trapped in a long-term suit over the crash of a Singapore Airlines (SIA) plane at Chiang Kai-shek (CKS) International Airport in northern Taiwan last October, aviation officials said Saturday.

CAA sources said family members of some of those who were killed in the crash of SIA Flight SQ006 Oct. 31, 2000 have jointly filed a lawsuit against the airline in the United States because they were dissatisfied with the SIA compensation terms.
As the Singapore carrier claims that CKS airport had some management flaws in the case, it has asked the family members to list the CAA as a co-defendant to share the responsibility for the tragedy.
The bereaved family members were able to file the suit in the United States because the ill-fated Boeing 747 was bound for Los Angeles from Singapore via Taipei.
Nevertheless, it remains unclear whether the U.S. court will agree to handle the lawsuit.
CAA officials said they do not think that the CAA should be held responsible for the crash that killed 83 of the 179 passengers and crew aboard.

But the final investigative report on the causes of the air disaster has yet to be released. If the final report concludes that airport facilities or measures -- including control tower instructions -- should be reviewed, the CAA's image and reputation will be tarnished.

CAA officials said SIA has retained many prominent lawyers to defend its stance. As international lawsuits over air crashes usually turn out to be long-term legal battles, the officials said, the CAA plans to set aside a budget to finance relevant legal expenses.

The Republic of China's Aviation Safety Council came up with a factual report on the SQ006 crash early this year, while a final report on the disaster's main causes and other relevant factors is scheduled to be released late this year or early in 2002.

The jumbo jet mistakenly entered the closed No. 5 runway while it was waiting to take off from CKS airport in stormy weather. The plane burst into flames after hitting construction equipment on the runway, which had been closed for repair.
The Aviation Safety Council immediately launched an investigation into the possible causes of the tragedy. Civil aviation experts from the United States and Singapore also joined the probe.

The most inexplicable point in the case is why the SIA pilots would have entered the wrong runway. Although the Singapore carrier issued a public apology for the error of the plane's three pilots, it also questioned the airport's failure to adopt enough precautionary measures to prevent aircraft from entering the closed runway.

The pilots -- flight commander Capt. Foong Chee Kong, 41, a Malaysian, and Singaporean co-pilots Latif Cyrano, 36, and Ng Keng Leng, 38 -- were allowed to return to Singapore last December after Singaporean authorities guaranteed that they will come to Taipei when they are needed for the crash investigation.

DOC.HEADLINE: 90 PERCENT OF LOCAL GRADUATES WORRIED ABOUT JOB MARKET: SURVEY

TEXT.P: The results of a recent public opinion survey show that 90 percent of the young people who graduated from colleges and high schools in June are worried about the difficulty of finding a job.
The survey was conducted among 2,279 young people by the "1111 Manpower Bank" under the commission of the E-Generation Politicians Alliance and Taipei City Councilwoman Chen Shui-fen.

The results indicate that the four most-favored jobs for this year's graduates are the opto-communications information technology industry, the finance industry, the computer software industry and the Internet multimedia industry.

According to the results of the survey, salaries and relevant benefits become the most important deciding factors when young people choose their jobs, with their personal interests and the companies' prospects being other factors for consideration.
As high as 90 percent of the respondents said they feared that they would not be able to find a satisfactory job.
Legislator Chen Hung-chi (Kuomintang-Taipei City), chairman of the E-Generation Politicians Alliance, said that the government should treat the survey results as a warning signal.
He also urged young people to consider their interests and abilities when starting a job hunt.
Chen cited government statistics as saying that the average time taken to find a job is 25.9 weeks for unemployed people and 26.1 weeks for new graduates.

DOC.HEADLINE: POLICE, IT EXPERTS DIVIDED ON SETTING UP FINGERPRINT DATABANK

TEXT.P: Local society remained divided Saturday over whether a national fingerprint databank should be established to facilitate criminal investigations and prevention of identification (ID) card forgery.

While police authorities have advocated the "necessity" of setting up a nationwide fingerprint databank, some information technology experts think otherwise and have expressed doubts about the so-called crime-prevention function of such a databank.

Lin Kuo-tung, deputy director of the Criminal Investigation Bureau under the National Police Administration, said at a seminar organized by Taipei City Councilor Chou Po-ya Saturday that establishing a national fingerprint databank should have been launched in 1997.

"However, the project has long been delayed out of considerations of human rights and dignity, as well as the possibility of the integration of ID cards and National Health Insurance cards," Lin said.

He claimed that although requiring Republic of China citizens to have their fingerprints taken "might hurt their personal dignity or basic human rights," the measure has many merits, including facilitating identity checks and criminal investigations, as well as protecting ordinary people from falling victim to ID card forgery.
Lin said "several countries" have implemented the measure requiring all of their people to have their fingerprints taken.

Yu Ying-fu, a Fu Jen Catholic University professor, claimed that "more than 80 percent" of the residents of Taipei City's Ta-an district have come to accept the measure since the district's household registration office began to set up a databank of fingerprints of district residents.
"Many Ta-an residents have recognized the convenience offered by the fingerprint databank when they come to the district office without their ID cards," Yu said.

Speaking on the same occasion, Chuang Ting-jui, an associate research fellow with Academia Sinica's Institute of Information Science, pointed out, however, that fingerprints have nothing to do with household registration affairs.
Chuang said that requiring a person to have his or her fingerprints taken violates not only the household registration law but also the country's Constitution.
Moreover, he went on, establishing a fingerprint databank will not necessarily help criminal investigations, as criminals tend to wear gloves to avoid leaving fingerprints.
In addition, he noted, a national fingerprint databank would need strict security measures to prevent tampering with the database.

DOC.HEADLINE: FAMILY MEMBERS PROTEST OVER CAMPUS DEATH OF STUDENT IN AUSTRALIA

TEXT.P: Family members of a Taiwan student who was killed on the campus of an Australian university last year staged a protest Saturday at a Taipei hotel where several Australian universities were holding a joint exhibit to attract local students.

The relatives of Lin Chun, 26, who was killed on the campus of the University of New South Wales (UNSW) by a runaway lorry April 19 last year, said their protest was mainly aimed at pushing Australian authorities to promise to improve campus safety.

Lin's husband, Wu Cheng-chung, said his wife was just walking across a pedestrian precinct to collect her transcript when she was "senselessly" crushed to death against a brick wall by an unmanned, out of control truck.
"Why did the driver park his truck in a `No Parking' area?" Wu asked.

He said he was particularly saddened by UNSW's reluctance to give an explanation of what he said was its "lax" campus safety measures. "I was also disappointed by Australian law enforcement authorities' failure to publish their investigative report," he said, adding: "The coroner's report is `seriously overdue.'" According to Wu, this made it impossible for him to believe the report.
Wu also criticized the Australian government for "failing to respect life."
Wu said he hopes that his "peaceful and rational" demonstration will pressure the Australian government to promise to pay heed to the safety of expatriate Taiwan students.
Wu also threatened to launch a campaign urging young Taiwan students not to travel to Australia to study if the Australian government refuses to improve the situation.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. UNHAPPY WITH HANDLING OF PROPOSED VISIT BY ROC PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: The suggestion of a visit to Washington, D.C. this year by President Chen Shui-bian of the Republic of China has apparently raised some eyebrows within the Bush administration, with one official taking exception to the lack of consultation between the two governments.
"The administration was disappointed at learning of the news only through media inquiries," the unnamed official said Friday.
"The way this was handled raises questions and concerns about how well Washington and Taipei understand each other's intentions and objectives," he added.
The official made the comments on a recent exchange of letters between Chen's office and Richard A. Ryan, president of the prestigious National Press Club (NPC) in Washington.
In a letter dated July 25, Chen said that he "would be most happy and honored to accept "a written invitation from Ryan to appear as a luncheon speaker at the NPC."

He said that he would instruct his representative to make arrangements with Ryan's staff for the speech, to be delivered in September or October, as the NPC president suggested, or at a date that is mutually convenient.
If realized, such a visit would mark a historic breakthrough in the unofficial ties between the United States and Taiwan. No ROC head of state has ever visited the U.S. capital.

A visit around the time of President George W. Bush's own trip to mainland China would be particularly sensitive given Beijing's likely reaction. Bush is scheduled to attend the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation summit in Shanghai Oct. 20 and then travel to Beijing for meetings with senior Chinese leaders.

Asked by reporters, both the White House and the State Department said that the administration has received no request for a visit by Chen to Washington. Now there are doubts as to whether there will be such a request any time soon.

In a rare interview, the official told the CNA that the Bush administration officials have made "serious efforts ... to improve the quality of our relations and to treat Taiwan's leaders with dignity and respect."
"Under these circumstances, one would hope for improved consultations (between Taipei and Washington)," he said. "This episode was not a good example of the kind of consultations we try to achieve."
When asked to comment, C.J. Chen, Taiwan's chief representative to Washington, would only say that Chen's response to the invitation indicated his intention to "reciprocate goodwill."

He refused to disclose the contents of any discussions with U.S. officials. However, another Taiwan diplomat admitted that there were "some ruffled feathers" in the administration, but stressed that the episode is "over."
Neither side would give any details but informed sources have said that Taiwan officials have had better access to U.S. officials now than during the previous Clinton administration.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC VICE PRESIDENT SPEAKS OF DEVELOPMENT OF CROSS-STRAIT TIES

TEXT.P: Republic of China Vice President Annette Lu said Friday that she is not opposed to direct transport links between Taiwan and mainland China.

As it is very inconvenient to travel to the mainland by way of Hong Kong and Macao, she said that Penghu could be designated as a transshipment airport as it is located at the mid-point of the Taiwan Strait.

Lu said that Beijing has been exerting "soft and hard tactics" toward Taiwan -- inviting Taiwan businessmen to investment in the mainland China on the one hand while increasing its military threat to Taiwan on the other.
The vice president urged the people of Taiwan and the international community to ask Beijing to remove hundreds of missiles targeting Taiwan along its southern coast.

She said that the present cross-strait situation remains tense and noted that Taiwan should strengthen its defense capability and engage in preventive diplomatic work against the threat from the mainland.
Lu said that she had launched a campaign to encourage the people of Taiwan to write letters to Beijing's leaders, telling them that they want peace, not war.
She expressed hope that all travelers from Taiwan will urge Beijing to remove the missiles whenever they meet with relatives and friends in mainland China.
Turning to the projected rally for world peace to be held in Taipei next week, Lu said that she formed the Taiwan Alliance for World Peace July 13 to promote peace-related activities.

According to Lu, several international non-governmental organizations have thrown their support behind the activities and added that foreign participants will include "leaders from 11 international organizations, 14 parliamentarians from six countries and six Nobel Peace Prize winners."
At the upcoming Peace Forum, Lu said, the participants will hear reports on the present situation of cross-strait relations and will also visit the ROC-controlled island of Kinmen.
She said that the forum will discuss how to create "genuine everlasting peace" across the Taiwan Strait and will also discuss whether Beijing's "one China" policy is a model or a hindrance to peace.
Lu expressed the hope that the foreign participants will get an impression that "Taiwan is a peacemaker," not a "troublemaker."
She added that because of her busy work schedule in preparing for her world peace rally, she will be unable to attend an international symposium scheduled to be held in Switzerland Aug. 17.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies on Sunday are as follows:
The China Times:
Ministry of Finance earmarked NT$60 billion to stabilize finance market during its campaign to reorganize faltering local financial institutions.
The United Daily News:
Central Bank of China promises to supply ample cash to prevent run on banks during the government's campaign to rectify staggering financial institutions.
The Liberty Times:
Minister of Finance: deposits with faltering local financial institutions will be fully secured.
The Taiwan Daily:
Minister of Economic Affairs recommends direct shipping links with mainland China.
The Central Daily News:
Minister of Finance, Central Bank of China vow to stabilize financial market amid looming risk of run on banks.
The China Post:
Lin calls for relaxing of 'no haste, be patient' policy.
The Taiwan News:
DPP members urge resignation of defectors.
The Taipei Times:
Lin advises direct links after WTO.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW PARTY CALLS FOR POLL TO DETERMINE CANDIDATE FOR OPPOSITION

TEXT.P: The opposition New Party called Sunday for the three opposition parties to choose, through polls, a common candidate to run for magistrate of Taipei County in the year-end elections.

Ho Chen-sheng, deputy secretary-general of the New Party, said Wang Chien-shien, the New Party's candidate for the Taipei County magistrateship, would meet Chin Chin-sheng, the candidate named by the opposition People First Party, for the same post Monday, to explore a way to nominate a joint candidate in the race.

Ho said Wang would suggest that Chin accept a poll as a way to choose a candidate acceptable to both parties and also the opposition Kuomintang, which has also nominated its own candidate in the race.

Given that the year-end election is only three months away, Ho said, however, that Chin's demand to have the polls staged two months after would-be nominators of three parties had already started canvassing votes for the straw poll is unrealistic.
It would be a waste of time and resources, since two would-be candidates would be excluded from the race after they had already devoted energy to the straw polls, said Ho.
He also called on the PFP back down on its demand that candidates should be given different preference in the straw polls according to the number of their party followers.

Ho said victory in the year-end election lies more in the merits of the individual candidates than in the candidate's political affiliation, and therefore the candidate from the bigger party would not necessarily have a better chance of winning the race than their smaller party rivals.

The three opposition parties fielded their own candidates after a fruitless attempt to search for a candidate who could command the support of all, even though they know that individually, their candidates will have a hard job competing against incumbent magistrate Su Tseng-chang of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SOLIDARITY UNION UNVEILS 39 LEGISLATIVE CANDIDATES

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU), which was formally inaugurated Sunday, unveiled the 39 candidates it will put forward to run in the year-end legislative elections.

The make-up of the party candidates runs the whole political gamut of Taiwan, including 19 from the opposition Kuomintang (KMT), nine from Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), two from the People First Party, one from the New Party, one from the Taiwan Independence Party, three from the New Nation Alliance and four independents.
As soon as the names were announced, both the KMT and DPP members immediately quit their former parties.
In terms of geographic distribution, TSU candidates cover the whole of the Taiwan area except for the offshore islands such as Kinmen, Matsu and Penghu.

Former National Assembly members who lost their political stage after they voted to abolish the assembly on May 24, 2000 make up the bulk of the TSU candidates, accounting for 30.7 percent, or 12 people, followed by county councilmen, accounting for 23 percent, or nine people. Former legislators account for three of the TSU candidates.

DOC.HEADLINE: OVERSEAS CHINESE IN CENTRAL AMERICA HOLD ANNUAL MEETING

TEXT.P: Overseas Chinese communities based in six central American countries held their 36th joint annual conference and their 29th fraternity meeting Thursday in Guatemala City, with Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission (OCAC) Vice Minister Chen Rong-jye attending the event.

More than 480 ROC nationals residing in Panama, Costa Rica, Nicaragua, Honduras, El Salvador and Belize took part in the meeting, which opened with a display of the national flags of the ROC and the six countries amid the music of the national anthems of the Republic of China and Guatemala.

Conference President Sun Hua-ping, on behalf of the organizer authorities and attending guests, read written messages from President Chen Shui-bian, Premier Chang Chun-hsiung, Foreign Affairs Minister Tien Hung-mao and OCAC Chairwoman Chang Fu-mei. Opposition Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan also sent a congratulatory message to the gathering.

Stressing that the ROC government's policy on overseas Chinese affairs is consistent and coherent, Chen said the OCAC will serve all overseas Chinese who identify themselves with the ROC and love Taiwan based on the current principles, regardless of their political affiliation or ethnicity.

ROC Ambassador to Guatemala Andrew J.S. Wu also praised ROC nationals residing in Guatemala for their diligence, saying that they have made great contributions to local development in their host country and to the promotion of bilateral ties. Later the same day, Wu held a banquet for Chinese community representatives from across Central America.

DOC.HEADLINE: DIRECT CROSS-STRAIT TRADE TO BENEFIT MANY INDUSTRIES

TEXT.P: Many investment consulting companies voiced agreement Sunday with Economics Minister Lin Hsin-yi's proposal to open direct trade links between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait after both sides are admitted to the World Trade Organization (WTO).

Lin expressed his support for the idea in a written report presented Saturday at a preparatory meeting of the cross-strait affairs panel under the soon-to-be-convened Economic Development Advisory Conference (EDAC), initiated by President Chen Shui-bian to spur the local economy.

It was the first time that Lin had made a concrete suggestion on the opening of direct cross-strait trade and allowing more mainland Chinese products to enter the Taiwan market. Under current Republic of China law, cross-strait trade must be conducted via a third country or area.

Tin Yu-chia, president of International Investment Trust Co. Ltd., said that the opening of cross-strait trade will have great negative impact on Taiwan's agricultural sector as a result of an influx of cheap farm products from the mainland and claimed that some 200,000 farmers will lose their jobs.

Some industries, such as the automobile, tire, electric appliance, heavy electrical machinery, and paper making industries are expected to lose their competitive edge after the opening of cross-strait trade, while the local textile industry will also experience pressure from competitors as a result of the scrapping of import quotas, Tin said.

However, he went on, other sectors, such as banking, stocks and securities, insurance, oil products, retail marketing, telecommunications, and electronic components are expected to go to mainland China in search of the huge market share there after the opening of these markets.

Some investment consulting companies predicted that after the opening of direct cross-strait trade links, direct transport links will follow, which are expected to reduce significantly the transport costs for local industries and also represent a stimulus to Taiwan's stock market.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC WINS RIGHT TO HOST WORLD MEDICAL COLLEGE STUDENT'S MEETING

TEXT.P: The Medical College Student's Confederation of the Republic of China (MCSCROC) has won the right to host the annual convention of the World Medical College Student's Organization (WMCSO) to be held in Taipei next August, it was announced Sunday.

According to an official of the Taiwan Medical Alliance Foundation, MCSCROC President Chuang Hai-hua is currently in Denmark at the head of a delegation attending a convention to mark the 50th founding anniversary of the WMCSO.
This will be the first time in 26 years that the WMSO convention has been held in Asia.
Founded in 1952, the WMCSO is aimed at promoting exchanges between medical college students.

According to Chuang, President Chen Shui-bian attaches great importance to this event and in addition to receiving members of the ROC delegation, Chen promised to assume the post of honorary adviser to the organizing committee.
The Presidential Office has prepared invitations in Chen's name and has given them to the ROC delegation to distribute to the participants at the Danish convention, according to Chuang.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIR, SHIPPING INDUSTRIES WAITING FOR DIRECT CROSS-STRAIT TRADE LINKS

TEXT.P: The domestic shipping and air industries had prepared for the start of a direct cross-Taiwan Strait trade link long before Minister of Economic Affairs Lin Hsin-yi voiced explicit support of such links Saturday.

Lin voiced his support in a preparatory meeting on cross-strait affairs under the soon-to-be-convened Economic Development Advisory Conference (EDAC), saying that direct cross-strait shipping and air links would help cut transport time and costs.
However, most shipping operators, eyeing the trade potential after direct cross-strait links, began jockeying for position a long time ago.

Industry representatives noted that the market potential of mainland China has attracted worldwide attention following its economic reform policy. Statistics show that annual trade in the mainland has grown by an average of more than 10 percent annually over recent years, with the percentage of trade between Taiwan and mainland China even higher.
The scale of mainland China's container market accommodation is even more stunning. As of the end of 2,000, it had reached 10 million TEUs (twenty-feet equivalent units).

Tempted by such rosy prospects, Taiwan shipping companies such as Evergreen Marine Corp. and Yangming Marine Transport Corp. set up set up representative offices six or seven years ago in the mainland.

But as the two sides of the Taiwan Straits have yet to open direct trade links, operators have been unable to set up branches there, and their profits have suffered because they have been unable to handle some of the business. In addition their ships have to go through third places for indirect shipping, which adds to operational costs.

Industry representatives believe that shipping costs will be dramatically cut after the two sides establish direct trade links, citing the example of a container of 400 TEUs. If the container is taken directly from Taiwan to Shanghai without passing through Ishigaki island -- as required under the present situation -- the shipping time will be cut by one day and the distance traveled cut by 164.5 nautical miles.

In contrast, if the container vessel sails at 14 knots and docks in a third country, the transport cost will increase by US$2,400, harbor costs will increase by US$1,640, wages for the crew will rise by US$857 and insurance will increase by US$118.5.
Meanwhile, direct cross-strait trade links will also be a boon for the air industry.

Chuei Yung, chairman of Far Eastern Air Transport Corp., said that after direct cross-strait links are established, it is estimated that it will bring trade potential of between NT$30 billion and NT$60 billion, in contrast with the present NT$20 billion.

Far Eastern Air Transport has been trying to establish a foothold in the mainland for a long time. In addition to setting up a representative office in Beijing, its repair and maintenance department was certified by the Civil Aviation Administration of China last September, becoming the second airliner in Taiwan after China Airlines to have obtain such certification.

Although direct air links will have no benefits for CAL and Far Eastern Airlines, which basically focus on international flights, operators estimate that if one can have first freedom -- meaning permission to fly over territorial airspace -- it will cut flying time from Taiwan to European destinations by two or three hours and fuel costs will also be dramatically cut.

On the other hand, if other freedoms are obtained and Taiwan aircraft can fly directly to various airports in the mainland, then not only operation costs, but also fuel costs, will be cut dramatically.

The operators estimate that fuel costs from Taipei to Fuzhou will be cut the most -- by 75 percent -- with Taipei-Xiamen costs cut by 62.5 percent. Taipei-Shanghai and Taipei-Beijing will also be cut by between 30 percent and 40 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SOLIDARITY UNION FOUNDED WITH PRESIDENT'S BLESSING

TEXT.P: A political party formed by some of former President Lee Teng-hui's followers was formally inaugurated Sunday, with a written congratulatory message from President Chen Shui-bian read out at the ceremony.

Chen lauded the Taiwan Solidarity Union's (TSU's) goals of "stabilizing the political situation, reinvigorating the economy, deepening democracy and strengthening Taiwan," as a benefit to Taiwan's development of party politics.
Noting that democracy is politics based on political parties, Chen said he looks forward to cooperation with the TSU to improve the island's democracy and advance the country's development.

The TSU, designed to solidify former President Lee Teng-hui's political legacy and cement Chen's minority government, approved its party charter Sunday and elected former Minister of the Interior Huang Chu-wen, who is said to have acted as Lee Teng-hui's frontman in setting up the party, as its chairman.
Lee, who is said to have worked behind the scenes for the party's foundation and is touted as its "spiritual leader", gave a speech at the inauguration.

The former president and opposition Kuomintang chairman said in Taiwanese that the party politics prevailing on the island has deviated from the sound development of democracy and has damaged the island's economy.
He blamed the island's political instability on the partisan politics in which political parties give priority to their own political interests in defiance of public opinion.

Lee said the foundation of the TSU marks the awareness of the "silent public" who are fed up with the political parties and the opposition-controlled legislature, which are at the epicenter of the island's political instability.
