Huang echoed Lee's view, denouncing party politics and the legislature for hindering rather than advancing democracy. He vowed to revamp the legislature by nominating 39 candidates to vie for seats in the year-end legislative elections.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP HOPES TO ESTABLISH STRATEGIC PARTNERSHIP WITH TSU
DOC.DATELINE: Nantou, Central Taiwan, Aug. 12 (CNA) (By Elisa Kao)

TEXT.P: Ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairman Frank Hsieh expressed Sunday his hope that the party can establish a strategic partnership with the new Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU).
The TSU, officially formed Sunday, has set a goal of pursuing a stable political situation, a revived economy, a solid democracy and a strong Taiwan.

Hsieh indicated that the forming of the TSU will have an impact on other political parties in the year-end elections for legislators and local government heads, but will have "less of an impact on political parties that have faith in themselves."
He encouraged the DPP candidates to have faith in themselves so that they will not be influenced by the forming of the TSU.
Concerning DPP relations with the TSU, Hsieh said that as a ruling party, the DPP will try to establish a benign interaction with other political parties.
The DPP will build a strategic partnership with the TSU, Hsieh said, although he admitted that there will be some conflicts for votes between the two parties in some electoral areas.
With regard to the fact that some DPP members have withdrawn from the party to join the TSU, Hsieh said the party will handle this matter according to party rules.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI MAYOR VISITS JAPANESE CITY OF FUKUOKA
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Aug. 12 (CNA) (By Mike Chang & Ed Chen)

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou began a four-day visit to Fukuoka Saturday on the third leg of a current three-city tour of Asia.

On Sunday, accompanied by Huang Ming-lang, representative of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in Fukuoka, Ma visited cultural establishments in the city, including a museum, a library and the Fukuoka Iron Tower.

He later visited a citizen's recreation center at a coastal park, where he was briefed on the park's facilities by the park administrator. Ma gave an exclusive interview with a local TV channel that evening.

During his four-day stay, Ma is slated to call on Fukuoka city government officials and visit the Asina Fine Arts Museum, Fukuoka Port, the Canal City, a computer research and development zone and the Fukuoka baseball dome.
Ma, who has already visited to Kuala Lumpur and Seoul, will return to Taipei Wednesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: PEACE CAN ONLY BE REACHED BY WISDOM: VP

TEXT.P: Republic of China Vice President Annette Lu said Sunday that the peace can be reached only by action, wisdom and determination.

Lu made the remark at a cocktail party in honor of various international figures invited to Taiwan to attend a "Voice from Taiwan; Peace and Love" campaign organized by the vice president for Aug. 15 in commemoration of the end of World War II.
Lu noted that although the United Nations has not admitted Taiwan, the island has opened a door to the world peace and added that it's her belief that the U.N. will "soon open its doors to Taiwan."
"Taiwan is not a troublemaker, but a peacemaker," Lu said, adding that Taiwan will demonstrate with action that it is more qualified than some U.N. members to join the organization.
"In addition to trying hard to join the U.N., we should let the world know that without Taiwan, it will be a great loss for U.N.," Lu added.

Lester Wolff, a former United States congressman who participated in drawing up the Taiwan Relations Act, said at the party that the series of activities initiated by Lu are "quite important" for world peace.
Six Nobel Peace Prize winners, 14 congressmen and parliamentarians from the U.S. and Japan, and the heads of 11 international NGOs, have been invited to participate in the activities.

The event is scheduled to begin Aug. 14, with a world peace forum convened Aug. 15-16, where the participants will discuss matters related to cross-Taiwan Strait relations, security and stability in the Asia Pacific region, experiences in world war and peace activities, crisis and perspectives of peace between the two sides of Taiwan Strait.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE PRESIDENT ON CROSS-STRAIT TIES (I)

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu said Saturday that she sees a strong undercurrent in cross-strait relations, in spite of the fact that ties have appeared to be "relatively stable" as a result of the toned-down rhetoric by the leaders of both sides.

She said that Beijing has now adopted a "two-pronged" approach toward Taiwan -- aggressively luring Taiwan businesses to investment in the mainland on one hand and continuing its military build-up to threaten Taiwan on the other.
Judging from this two-handed policy, the "seemingly relatively stable relations now do not necessarily assure calm and peaceful ties in the future," Lu warned.

Lu made the remarks in an interview with CNA during which the first female vice president of the Republic of China gave her views on a wide range of issues, including the opening of direct postal, trade and transportation links between Taiwan and the mainland, Taiwan's lifting of its restriction on mainland China-bound investment, the year-end elections of lawmakers and local government heads, Taiwan's foreign relations and the "Voice from Taiwan, Peace and Love" campaign that Lu personally initiated.

Six Nobel Peace Prize winners, including former Polish President Lech Walesa, Oscar Arias Sanchez, who served as Costa Rica's president from 1986 to 1990, former South African President F.W. de Clerk and Betty Williams, a peace advocate from Ireland, have been invited to take part in the event.

In addition to the Nobel Prize winners, lawmakers and parliamentarians from many friendly nations and chief executive officers from 11 NGO groups have agreed to take part in the "Voice from Taiwan" drive, which will feature a 2001 Global Peace Assembly forum scheduled for Aug. 15-16 and an Evening for Global Peace slated for Aug. 15.
Following is the a text of Lu's interview:
Q: How would you view the development of cross-strait ties following Beijing's successful 2008 Olympic bid?

A: It's better for the leaders of both sides to reduce their exchanges of rhetoric, letting ties become relatively calm. But by doing only that will not necessarily mean that relations will then run smoothly.
I think that Beijing has applied a hard-and-soft two-handed policy to Taiwan.

Beijing has been especially successful in launching its "soft" offensive, or "economic war" against Taiwan, by attracting a large amount of Taiwan investment to the mainland, causing substantial damage to Taiwan's economy.

On the other hand, Beijing has deployed 350 missiles, over 100 Su-27 and Su-30 fighters at air bases just 250 nautical miles away from Taiwan, along with another 700 fighters in bases some 600 nautical miles from the island, in addition to accelerating its development of cruise missiles.
I have therefore initiated the "Voice from Taiwan, Peace and Love" campaign by inviting world leaders to attend a peace forum in Taipei.
I believe that the dignitaries attending the forum will help air Taiwan's desire for peace at the United Nations and other international occasions.

I would also like to urge that the people of Taiwan, while touring the mainland to visit relatives, do business, or whatever, to appeal to "every mainland person they meet to dismantle the missiles aimed at Taiwan."
By so doing, the mainland people will finally come to understand that they would benefit much if Beijing would use the missile development money to take care of them. (more)

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE PRESIDENT LU ON CROSS-STRAIT TIES (II)
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 12 (CNA) (By Bear Lee) (By Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Q: What is your viewpoint about the easing of the "no haste, be patient" mainland investment policy and on the establishment of the direct "three links," which are being discussed by the current panel meeting of the Economic Development Advisory Conference?

A: I think the requirement for all mainland-bound investment projects worth more than US$50 million to be first approved by the government on a case-by-case basis is the key point to the current government regulations governing Taiwan investment in the mainland. All those people who have urged the government to remove the restriction may harbor a desire to investment there without any limits.

If the US$50 million belongs only to one person, nobody has any right to criticize. But the capital of most investors comes from bank loans, which are collected from public savings. Should all this investment money be changed into renminbi, it is by no means a personal issue. The government must weigh whether it should allow such practices, and the holding of a public referendum should be the best way to decide it.

At the same time, the government should take measures to control capital outflow and bank loans efficiently and it should also drop the "no haste, be patient" slogan, which is too difficult for the public to understand. The public will easily get it if the government asks directly whether mainland-bound investment projects worth more than US$50 million should be allowed.

As a matter of fact, I am not opposed to Taiwan's opening of direct transport ties with mainland China, because it is unreasonable and inconvenient for mainland-bound Taiwan travelers to transfer in Hong Kong or Macau. I think it would be ideal to designate an airport on the offshore Penghu Island to serve as a direct-link airport between Taiwan and mainland China due to the island's location at the mid-point of the Taiwan Strait.

If the government studied the issue seriously in that direction, it should and must talk with the Beijing authorities when the time is ripe. I think Penghu is a good location to serve as a base for direct aviation links between the two sides and would be better than any airport in Taipei or Taoyuan.
Q: What do you think of the year-end legislative elections?

A: I am very tired of taking part in elections. As Taiwan has developed into a democracy, holding elections have become a common practice and the people in Taiwan should see the matter with a "business as usual" attitude.

I think Taiwan society has wasted too much resources on elections. Taking part in elections is a personal issue for each and all candidates, but too much coverage by the media has in turn become an election campaign for certain candidates. Some candidates have totally forgotten their responsibility of seeking benefits for their supporters, concentrating instead on media grandstanding.
I have participated in five elections and was elected every time. But I will not do so again, because it is a hard task.

Q: What objectives do you wish to achieve by launching the "Voice from Taiwan, Peace and Love" series of activities, in which several international figures and Nobel Price winners are expected to take part?

A: This campaign is supported by United Nations-affiliated Non Government Organizations (NGOs). In addition to the chairman of the NGO's world chapter, who will personally attend the activities in Taiwan, the heads of 11 international organizations, as well as 14 parliamentary members from six countries, will also travel to Taiwan.

It is worth noting that two parliamentarians from Thailand decided to participate in the event despite opposition from Beijing. This is proof that we can still cement Taiwan's ties with other countries without going abroad. At the same time, it is also worth noting that the chief of the Inside the U.N. television station -- the sole television station under the U.N. -- will also visit Taiwan for the rally.

Each of the six Nobel Peace Prize winners who are to arrive in Taiwan for the activities have an outstanding background. For instance, former Costa Rican President Oscar Arias Sanchez has contributed to harmony and integration among the countries of Central America and helped found the System of Central American Integration. Taiwan, Japan and South Korea should learn from his example by forging an Asia-Pacific Alliance.

Many democracy activists, as well as President Chen Shui-bian and myself, also admire very much former Polish President Lech Walesa, who overthrew Poland's communist regime with the Solidarity Union set by himself.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE PRESIDENT LU ON CROSS STRAIT TIES (III)
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 12 (CNA) (By Bear Lee) (By Flor Wang) (By Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: Former South African President F.W. de Clerk also enjoys worldwide recognition for his admirable transfer of power from the white minority to the black majority and that is the reason why de Clerk is slated to deliver a speech immediately after former President Lee Teng-hui at the opening of the Global Peace Assembly.

I believe that transferring power is very different from seeking power and de Clerk's attendance carries a very significant meaning, which provides an opportunity for the people of Taiwan to realize the true meaning of the term "transfer of power."
The other three Nobel Peace Prize winners, although not heads of state, have also accomplished remarkable achievements.

Betty Williams, who was originally an ordinary housewife, stood up bravely to the British troops after seeing the North Ireland independence activists cruelly crushed by tanks of the British troops. Her presence here is to remind the public that peace can also be achieved through such means.

Joseph Rotblat, a 93-year-old scientist, will also visit Taiwan to join us in the series of activities. Rotblat, a former specialist dedicated to the development of the atomic bomb during World War II, is now committed to the anti-nuclear movement and demilitarization campaigns. His willingness to take part in our activities has deeply touched us.
There are two more interesting people coming. One is Park Sir Young, daughter of former South Korean President Park Chung Hee.

Although Park senior is a controversial person in South Korea, he is still a spiritual leader for many South Korean people according to my friend over there, therefore we invited his daughter to join us.
Another interesting person is the daughter-in-law of former Indian President Varahagiri Venkata Giri, who is now a minister for women's affairs.

Another of the dignitaries, whose name I prefer to withhold, served once as the chairman of the United Nations General Assembly session and was appointed to a vital position by his government last week. The announcement of his new appointment has been delayed until after his visit to Taipei.
I am glad to have so many foreign dignitaries to grace the occasion, but I regret that many of my fellow countrymen lack confidence in our country.
Just as "people with integrity will never be isolated," a peace-loving and democratic Taiwan with compassion and respect for human rights will find allies around the world.

Many of my critics ridicule me in that my words speak louder than my actions, but I have delivered on my pledges one by one and they will have to admit that it is right to describe Taiwan as a gentle and friendly country.
I think it is the will of heaven to have so many dignitaries descend on Taiwan.

Actually there are two more dignitaries who want to attend the occasion but we could not accommodate them because of our strapped budget and the fact that they gave too little notice. They will have to wait until next time.
As to the budget for the event, estimated at about NT$20 million (about US$5.88 million), it has been raised by the private sector since the government turned down our requests for assistance.

The peace forum will consist of three parts, beginning with a brief from the government on the current cross-strait situation and a visit by the foreign dignitaries to the frontline island of Kinmen, followed by a discussion for foreign scholars on peace in Asia and wrapped up with a recounting by the foreign dignitaries of their experiences in pushing for peace.
The forum will try to work out a way for a persistent peace across the Taiwan Straits and give out a message that Taiwan is a peacemaker rather than a troublemaker.
Q: Do you have any plans for overseas trips in the near future? It is said that you will travel abroad in October.
A: I have no plans to visit foreign countries in October. I am busy organizing the world peace forum.
In my view, any overseas trip has to meet two criteria. First, it has to be conducted with dignity and second, it must serve Taiwan's diplomatic interests.

DOC.HEADLINE: TWO ROC WARSHIPS DAMAGED BY KOREAN FREIGHTER

TEXT.P: Two Republic of China Navy destroyers berthed at the East Pier No. 5 in Keelung Harbor were bumped Sunday by a Korean freighter trying to berth at the next pier.
The 7000-ton Hansung-7 bulk carrier caused damage to parts of the foredecks and the ship's rails of the two destroyers, while a soldier was slightly injured.

The naval logistics command in Keelung submitted an accident report to the Keelung Harbor Administration and an investigation of the maritime responsibility is under way, according to the naval authorities.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECONOMIC PANEL SUGGESTS EASING OF MAINLAND INVESTMENT (I)

TEXT.P: Participants in a preparatory meeting of a major economic conference suggested Sunday that the government ease its restrictions on investing in mainland China.

The participants in the meeting on cross-strait affairs panel reached consensus on several major issues in the fourth and last panel meeting before the opening of the Economic Development Advisory Conference (EDAC) in late August.
They agreed on several major cross-strait trade issues based on the principles of "Taiwan be given first priority, global planning, mutually beneficial cross-strait relations, and risk management."

The issues were related to the opening of cross-strait trade and investment, the establishment of a cross-strait capital flow mechanism, the entry into the World Trade Organization by both sides of the Taiwan Strait, direct cross-strait trade, postal and transport links, the establishment of a special economic zone and the opening of Taiwan to tourists from the mainland.
Although the participants agreed largely on the trade issues, they had heated debate on cross-strait talks and drafted a written statement only after lengthy discussion.

The panel finally wrote that the government should forge a national consensus in line with the spirit of the ROC Constitution, should shelve political disputes to allow dialogue with the mainalnd soon, and should hold talks with the mainland on direct trade, postal and transport links and other issues related to the welfare of the public.

As the panelists could not agree on the so-called "1992 consensus" of "one China, separate interpretations" between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, they said the government should forge a national consensus to solve the differences.
The panel will present its agreements for discussion by EDAC, which will convene Aug. 24-26.

On the opening of cross-strait trade and investment, the panel suggested the current "go slow, be patient" policy toward investing in the mainland be changed to "active opening and effective management" based on the principle of "global planning and strategic opening."

The "go slow" policy, advocated by former President Lee Teng-hui in 1996, bars Taiwan manufacturers from investing in the infrastructure and high-tech industry in the mainland, and puts a US$50 million investment cap on individual investment projects.

The panel suggested that a team comprised of government, industry and academic figures be set up to regularly review the easing of restrictions on which industries should be allowed to invest in the mainland and to promote the signing of a cross-strait investment guarantee agreement and a tax pact.

The panel also suggested the establishment of a healthy inflow mechanism for money invested in the mainland, the development of an offshore banking unit (OBU) as a capital financing center for Taiwan businessmen overseas and in the mainland, and an assessment of the opening of local banks designated as foreign currency operators to have direct remittance services with financial institutions in the mainland.

The panel also suggested allowing the financial service industry to invest in the mainland and the establishment of branches or subsidiaries to provide assistance to Taiwan businessmen wanting to withdraw from the mainland, as well as allowing mainland capital to be invested in Taiwan's land and real estate market. It also suggested a gradual opening of the securities market in Taiwan to mainland capital and the assessment of the feasibility of establishing an overseas capital market. (By Lilian Wu) (more)

DOC.HEADLINE: ECONOMIC PANEL SUGGESTS EASING OF MAINLAND INVESTMENT (II)

TEXT.P: On the entry of the WTO by the two sides of the Taiwan Strait expected later this year, the panel suggested that in line with the progress of WTO entry, the government should open direct trade, postal and transport links with the mainland and further open the local market to mainland products if the mainland will lower its trade barriers.

It also suggested that the government take an overall plan for cross-strait shipping and put it into practice through cross-strait discussion. Before the two sides of the Taiwan Strait sign a direct shipping agreement, it said, some transitional measures should be taken, including the expansion of functions of offshore transshipping centers, opening of the commodity flow, allowing private shipping operators to discuss with their mainland counterparts for business cooperation, and assessments on the establishment of special trade and economic zones.

The panel also said that Taiwan should open to tourism from the mainland and should discuss with the mainland authorities the timing of such opening. If necessary, the opening could be put into practice on a trial basis, the panel added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, Aug. 13, or the 24th day of the sixth month of the Year of the Snake according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1814: The British formally take over the colony at the Cape of Good Hope, located at the southernmost tip of the African continent, from the Dutch.
1860: Annie Oakley, the American sharpshooter who could hit the edge of a playing card at 30 paces, is born as Phoebe Anne Oakley Moses.
1898: American forces led by George Dewey capture Manila during the Spanish-American War.
1899: Hollywood film director Alfred Hitchcock is born in England. He directed such classics as "Psycho," and "The Birds."
1910: Florence Nightingale, the British nurse known as "the Lady with the Lamp," dies at the age of 90. She organized and directed a unit of field nurses during the Crimean War and is considered the founder of modern nursing.
1923: Mustafa Kemal Ataturk is elected president of Turkey.
1927: Chiang Kai-shek, commander-in-chief of China's Nationalist Revolutionary Forces, resigns in order to bring about solidarity between the Nanking and Hankow factions of the Kuomintang.
1927: Fidel Castro, the Cuban revolutionary who became the country's socialist president in 1959, is born.
1927: Japanese troops launch a major attack on Shanghai and are met with stiff resistance from Chinese defenders.
1942: The United States and Britain decide to carry out joint research on the atomic bomb.
1949: Mao Tse-tung names Beijing as Communist China's capital.
1960: The Central African Republic gains independence from France.
1961: Communist East Germany begins the erection of the Berlin Wall, drawing strong protests from Western nations.
1967: Fifteen grand justices nominated by President Chiang Kai-shek are approved by the Republic of China's Control Yuan.
1969: Communist China and the Soviet Union accuse each other of sending troops across their Central Asian border and inflicting heavy casualties.
1973: The second executive board meeting of the Asian Cultural Center opens in Taipei.
1974: Mort Young, deputy editor-in-chief of Hearst Newspapers in the United States, arrives in Taipei for a two-week visit.
1975: An eight-member Taiwan dance troupe leaves for La Paz to perform at celebrations marking Bolivia's independence day.
1976: Over 140 youths from 20 nations join in the opening ceremony of the International Youth Recreation Tour to the Republic of China sponsored by the China Youth Corps.
1976: The ROC Cabinet approves extension of the Sino-Uruguayan Agreement on Agricultural Cooperation for two years.
1978: A building serving as the Beirut headquarters of the Palestine Liberation Front and containing the offices of their rivals, Al-Fatah, is ripped apart by a bomb, leaving some 150 people dead.
1984: Six mainland Chinese freedom seeker freed by the Korean government arrive in Taipei. The six hijacked a Chinese communist Trident plane from Shenyang, Manchuria to Seoul, Korea on May 5, 1983.
1989: Two hot air balloons collide in the worst-ever hot air balloon disaster in Australia, with one of the balloons plunging 182 meters to the ground, killing 12 people.
1993: A hotel collapsed in Thailand, killing over 120 people.
1999: The Council for Economic Planning and Development under the EExecutive Yuan estimates that the ROC's economic growth rate will reach 5.5 percent for the year.
2000: President Chen Shui-bian and his 200-member entourage leave Taipei, beginning a 13-day visit to six states in the Caribbean, Central America and Africa.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Trust is the law of God. Acquired truth is the law of man."
