DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI AND FUKUOKA TO STEP UP EXCHANGES
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Aug. 13 (CNA) (By Mike Chang and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Visiting Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou and his Fukuoka counterpart Hirotaro Yamasaki agreed over a breakfast meeting Monday to step up exchanges between their two cities.
Yamasaki led several city officials to the hotel where Ma was staying to take part in a breakfast meeting where the two mayors exchanged views on city administration.
The Fukuoka mayor expressed keen interest in visiting high-tech facilities in Taiwan, especially the Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park in northern Taiwan.

Ma, for his part, invited Yamasaki to visit a computer software industrial park in Nankang in suburban Taipei, saying that Nankang's "software information industry" and Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park's "hardware industry" each have their own distinctive features.
Yamasaki gladly accepted the invitation and said he will work out related matters later.
The two mayors also reached consensus on student and artist exchanges between Taipei and Fukuoka, as well as on trade and high-tech exchanges.

After the breakfast meeting, Ma visited the city's museum and harbor facilities as well as its "island city" which is presently under construction. In the afternoon, he visited a computer software research and development park and the Dome Stadium.
He is scheduled to attend a dinner party later in the day hosted by the Fukuoka Branch of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in Osaka.
Ma on Saturday began a five-day visit to Fukuoka, the final leg of his current three-city tour in Asia. The first two stops on his tour were Kuala Lumpur and Seoul.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECONOMICS MINISTER LEAVES FOR VIETNAM TO ATTEND MEETING

TEXT.P: Minister of Economic Affairs Lin Hsin-yi left for Vietnam Monday to attend an annual conference on promoting trade and economic cooperation between the Republic of China and the Indochinese country.
This was the eighth consecutive year that major trade organizations in the two countries have jointly organized the meeting to boost bilateral economic ties.
Lin headed a delegation of Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) officials, including Vice Minister Chen Ruey-long, and senior business executives to attend the conference.

During his visit, Lin will also tour a Hanoi industrial park developed by Taiwan business groups and meet with Taiwan investors in Vietnam to gain a better understanding of their operations there. Lin is scheduled to return to Taiepi Wednesday.
Despite the absence of formal diplomatic ties, ROC-Vietnamese economic relations have been growing steadily. Taiwan is now Vietnam's fourth largest trading partner.
With their geographic proximity and similar cultural backgrounds, MOEA officials said, the two countries should have many new opportunities to cooperate in the future.

According to MOEA tallies, two-way trade between the ROC and Vietnam amounted to US$2.12 billion last year, with Taiwan exporting US$1.66 billion worth of goods to Vietnam while importing US$460 million worth of Vietnamese products.

Taiwan mainly exported semi-finished textile goods, leather, footwear parts and processing machines to Vietnam, while raw materials, farm produce and semi-finished products formed the bulk of imports from Vietnam.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI STOCK INDEX EDGES UP

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange continued its upward trend Monday, with the benchmark weighted price index gaining 43.85 points to close at 4,520.76.
Market turnover, however, shrank slightly from last Friday's level to NT$39.08 billion (US$1.13 billion).

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES HIGHER ON TAIWAN FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock index futures market closed higher Monday, as Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index futures for August rose 21 points to close at 4,490, with 6,211 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX index futures for September rose 27 points to finish at 4,484, with 5,140 contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for other months.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX index futures trading were set Monday at 4,469 for August, 4,457 for September, 4,351 for December, 4,434 for next March and 4,363 for next June.
Electronics (TE) and Financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, closed mixed Monday.

August TE futures dropped 2.25 points to close at 231.25, with 1,066 contract transactions, while September TE futures two points to finish at 230,40, with 687 contracts changing hands. TE futures for next June dropped 15.40 points to close at 228, with 25 contracts transactions.
No transactions were recorded for other months.

August TF futures moved up 26 points to finish at 582.0, with 1,099 contracts changing hands, while September TF futures gained 25.6 points to close at 581.6, with 380 contracts traded. TF futures for next June dropped 24 points to finish at 530.0, with two contract transactions.
No transactions were recorded for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. CONGRESSMEN ARRIVE IN TAIPEI TO ATTEND WORLD PEACE FORUM

TEXT.P: U.S. Rep. Benjamin A. Gilman, chairman emeritus of the House International Relations Committee, arrived in Taipei Monday, leading a delegation to attend a World Peace Forum and related activities organized by Republic of China Vice President Annette Lu.
The delegation led by Rep. Gilman (R-N.Y.), who has visited Taiwan nine times in the past, also includes Rep. Charles B. Rangel, a Democtat from New York, and Frank Guarini, a former congressman.

The two-day World Peace Forum, which begins Aug. 15, is part of a campaign titled "Voice From Taiwan; Peace and Love" held in commemoration of the end of World War II. The series of activities is scheduled to begin Tuesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: STOCK PRICES MOVE UP BY 43.85 POINTS

TEXT.P: Buoyed by news of the government's policy to ease cross-Taiwan Strait trade and investment restrictions as well as its plan to reform local financial institutions, Taiwan stock prices rose 43.85 points, or 0.9 percent, to close at 4,520.76 Monday.
On the strength of traditional industry stocks and financial issues, the stock market opened higher at 4.492.28, hitting a high of 4,557.85 points and a low of 4.470.17 during the trading session.
Market turnover, however, shrank slightly from last Friday's level to NT$39.08 billion (US$1.13 billion).

All but one of eight major stock categories gained ground, with financial stocks rising the most at 4.9 percent, followed by plastics and chemical stocks at 4.5 percent, textile stocks at 4.1 percent, foodstuff issues at 3.9 percent, pulp and paper shares at 2.9 percent, cement stocks at 2.6 percent, and construction issues at 0.9 percent.
In comparison, electronics stocks dropped 0.7 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 344 to 159, with 79 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: TRADE OFFICIAL CAUTIONS AGAINST INVESTMENT RISKS IN M'LAND CHINA

TEXT.P: A trade official suggested Monday that Taiwan investors interested in making investments across the Taiwan Strait should study the market situation more carefully and avoid putting money in sectors or regions with excessive investments.

Huang Chih-peng, secretary-general of the China External Trade Development Council and former director of the Economics Ministry's Industrial Development and Investment Center, said that Taiwan investors should take into consideration the political environment, basic infrastructure, distribution of public resources, sales channels, the balance of supply and demand, as well as personnel costs and factory sites before investing.

Statistics compiled by mainland Chinese authorities show that Taiwan investors have set up at least 46,000 companies on the mainland, although the official figure released by Taiwan authorities is around 23,000.

As for the investment amount, official figures released by Taiwan authorities show that between 1991 and 2000, Taiwan investors poured US$17.1 billion into the mainland market. Mainland China's official figure for the amount is around US$50 billion, while the private sector in Taiwan estimates the amount at between US$80 billion and US$100 billion.

Being the world's seventh largest economy and the eighth largest trading country, mainland China has become a magnet for foreign capital. Taiwan's business and industrial sectors have also stepped up their pace to win themselves footholds in the huge market.

Huang said that mainland China offers certain investment advantages, but added that investors should recognize the fact that many foreign investors have failed in mainland China in the years past due to the lack of transparency and the unexpected costs that ambiguous regulations have entailed.

As a matter of fact, businesspeople from Taiwan, after having spent years managing their businesses on the mainland, know better the principles governing business on the mainland, according to a mainland affairs specialist.

He said that Taiwan businesspeople have worked out a three-part principle -- the first part being basic capability; the second being no involvement in politics and no violation of regulations; and the third part being good relations with the local governments, good contacts with authorities on both sides of the strait, and good public relations.
The specialist added that accessing the mainland market is by no means easier than accessing markets in other parts of the world.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR UP ON TAIPEI FOREX MARKET

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar appreciated NT$0.026 against the greenback on the Taipei foreign exchange market Monday, closing at NT$34.599.
The local currency opened Monday at NT$34.597 and was traded between NT$34.571 and NT$34.601.
Interbank U.S. dollar trading totaled US$313 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP WILL LEAD IN YEAR-END LEGISLATIVE ELECTIONS: e-SOCIETY POLL

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) will gain the most votes but will still be unable to garner over half the total ballots cast in the year-end legislative elections, according to the results of a poll released Monday.

The telephone poll of 1,068 eligible voters randomly selected from around the island, conducted by e-Society Research Group over the weekend, found that none of major domestic political parties will secure more than half of the total vote.
The survey results showed that the DPP will receive 33.7 percent of the vote, slightly higher than the 30.5 percent share that will be seized by the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT).

According to the poll, the three other opposition parties' shares of the vote will be 21.15 percent, 2.8 percent, and 2.6 percent for the People First Party (PFP), the newly formed Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU), and the pro-unification New Party (NP), respectively.

e-Society President Ho Sun Sea told a news conference that the vote ratios were estimated on each party's overall competitiveness which was measured on public perceptions of party image and ruling capabilities.
In the party image evaluation, five indicators -- heed to public opinion, integrity, leadership performance, candidate qualifications and efforts to promote ethnic harmony -- were gauged.

In this regard, the DPP led in three categories -- heed to public opinion, integrity and candidate qualifications, while the PFP outshone other parties in leadership performance and ethnic harmony promotion.

The erstwhile ruling and now opposition KMT ranked in the middle in all indicators studied except for the "integrity" category in which the KMT tied the TSU for last place. Another noteworthy finding was that the NP ranked second in the "integrity" category.

In the e-Society poll, each party's ruling capabilities were gauged in terms of five indicators -- improving the economy and cross-Taiwan Strait relations, defending Taiwan's rights and interests, administrative ability and party identification.

The survey found that the KMT topped all other parties in the categories of improving the economy and cross-strait ties and administrative ability, while the DPP led in defending Taiwan's rights and interests, and the PFP ranked first in party identification.

Based on all of the above-mentioned factors, the DPP received the highest approval rating in terms of overall party competitiveness at 28 percent, followed by the KMT at 26.7 percent, the PFP at 17.8 percent, the TSU at 2.3 percent and the NP at 1.9 percent.

Quoting the results of three similar polls conducted by e-Society from Jan. 18-Aug. 10, Ho said both the DPP's and the PFP's "party identification" rating showed a moderate declining trend, while the KMT's surged from 11.6 percent to 16.6 percent during the same period.

In terms of support ratings of the candidates of the various parties, the DPP still leads with a rating of 26 percent, followed by the PFP's 19.3 percent, the KMT's 18.9 percent, the NP's 2.8 percent and the TSU's 2.7 percent.

The survey also found that 60.5 percent of the respondents who voted for DPP candidate Chen Shui-bian in the 2000 presidential election would still cast ballots for DPP nominees in the year-end elections, but 5.7 percent said they would switch to back TSU candidates.

Meanwhile, 54.9 percent of the respondents who voted for KMT candidate Lien Chan in the last presidential election would continue to back KMT standard-bearers, while 8.1 percent said they would switch their ballots to PFP candidates and 3.1 percent said they would throw their support behind TSU nominees.

Among those who voted for PFP Chairman James Soong in the previous presidential election, 51.1 percent said they would opt for PFP candidates in the year-end race, but 20.8 percent said they would cast ballots for KMT hopefuls, while none of them would support TSU candidates.

Asked whether they were satisfied with the various parties' performances, 24.3 percent said they are dissatisfied with the performances of all major domestic parties, while 33.8 percent said they have no opinion. The survey results also showed that the DPP's approval rating stands at 16.5 percent, compared to the KMT's 11.7 percent and the KMT's 11 percent.

Analyzing the survey results, professor Liu Yi-chou said that as Taiwan's party development has plunged to a low ebb, candidate's personal image, capabilities and qualifications will be critical in deciding whether they can win in the year-end legislative elections.

DOC.HEADLINE: MONETARY RECONSTRUCTION MEASURES WON'T LEAD TO CRISIS: OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: The operations of the 36 local monetary institutions under the financial authorities' supervision were normal on Monday, the first working day after special task force personnel were assigned to the institutions to check on their management.

The Monetary Reconstruction Fund-initiated action last Friday exposed the problems of many monetary institutions with negative net assets. In taking the action, the financial authorities were preparing against the worst-case scenario of a run on banks while giving full guarantees concerning the rights and benefits of all deposit accounts.

Chen Hsi-huang, chairman of the Council of Agriculture, said that he does not anticipate that the emergency measures against the problem monetary institutions, which are mostly affiliated with farmers or fishermen's associations, will bring a tempest to the fundamental monetary system.

He said that the credit departments of the farmers or fishermen's associations have been playing an important role in Taiwan's fundamental monetary system. The 314 such credit departments located around the island and on Taiwan's offshore islands have been providing the agricultural community with services considered too trivial even for regional banks.
The accumulated deposits at the 314 credit departments exceed NT$1,200 billion and the small loans extended by them amount to some NT$800 billion, according to the official.
He said that the fundamental monetary system of the agricultural sector remains stable, although many of the credit departments of the farmers or fishermen's associations have negative net assets.
Statistics compiled by the Council of Agriculture show that 21 of the credit departments have negative net assets, while another 29 are on the brink of having negative assets.
The 50 institutions will be given three years to improve their management. If all attempted remedies fail, the institutions will then be forced to be merged, according to the agricultural official.

DOC.HEADLINE: EXPERT OF U.S. THINK TANK MAY TAKE OVER AS AIT CHAIRMAN
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Aug. 12 (CNA) (By Jay Chen and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: American Institute in Taiwan Chairman Richard Bush will step down this autumn, and the man who is most likely to succeed him is Larry M. Wortzel, an expert at the Heritage Foundation, sources in Washington said.

The sources noted that Wortzel, the director of the U.S. think tank's Asian Studies Center, who served as an assistant army attache in mainalnd China during the time of the Tiananmen Massacre, has become the major candidate for the post.

But a Bush administration source also said that Wortzel could also serve as AIT's Taipei office director, with Douglas Paal, who was earlier reported to be appointed to serve as AIT Taipei director, being stationed in the AIT headquarters in Washington.

The sources said that Paal has been attacked by some conservatives for his views, pointing out that although Assistant Secretary of State James Kelly is supportive of Paal, senators Jesse Helms (R-N.C.) and Jon Kyl (R-Ariz.) had sent letters to President Bush questioning Paal's appointment.

Compared with Republican conservatives, Paal's stance on cross-strait relations has been considered to be too neutral and his opposition to the Communist Chinese regime not strong enough. His criticism of the Bush administration's China policy has also given some a reason to attack him, sources said.

A Bush administration source said that the current AIT chairman is likely to step down after President Bush's visit to mainland China later this year. But before his resignation, Richard Bush is expected to visit Taiwan to brief Taipei on the contents of President Bush's mainland trip and to bid farewell to the officials there.

Bush assumed the AIT chairmanship in September 1997 and has since commanded high respect from both Taipei and Washington, but sources said that he is a Democrat and has served for four years already and the Bush administration is hoping that a Republican will take over the post.
Wortzel, who maintains an anti-Communist stance, specializes in East Asian politics and is an expert on mainland China's military development and diplomatic affairs.

He is friendly toward Taiwan and has said that he does not think it is right for the United States to allow major congressional committee chairmen to visit Taiwan while restricting politically-appointed officials and high-ranking military officials from visiting the island.

Serving as a colonel before retiring from the U.S. Army three years ago, Wortzel was offered an opportunity to visit Taiwan before his retirement, but the State Department expressed its opposition to the visit at a sensitive time when then U.S. President Bill Clinton was visiting mainland China.

Wortzel is a graduate of the Armed Forces Staff College and the U.S. Army War College, and he attended the National University of Singapore. He earned his bachelor's degree from Columbus College, Georgia, and his master's as well as his doctoral degree from the University of Hawaii.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER REAFFIRMS COMMITMENT TO EDAC CONSENSUS

TEXT.P: Premier Chang Chun-hsiung reaffirmed Monday the government's commitment to fully implementing any consensus or conclusions reached at the soon-to-be-convened Economic Development Advisory Conference (EDAC).

Chang made the reaffirmation at the inauguration ceremony for the Cross-Strait Economic and Trade Association, a new body formed by a group of opposition Kuomintang legislators to promote commercial exchanges across the Taiwan Strait.

Chang said the EDAC is mainly designed to provide a forum for the ruling and opposition parties, as well as private commerce and industry executives, to exchange views on major domestic economic problems, including cross-strait trade and investment affairs.

"So any consensus reached at the conference will be implemented," Chang stressed, adding that consensus forged through candid discussions between the ruling and opposition parties tends to be easier to implement.

Noting that cross-strait relations have been a major concern in the Republic of China's sustainable national development, Chang said the government has been handling relevant issues with great prudence.
At the present stage, Chang said, the government is conducting a comprehensive, multi-dimensional review of its policy toward cross-strait affairs.
"And we'll continue to promote cross-strait relations in a pragmatic manner under the premises of national security, economic development and public well-being," Chang pledged.

He went on to say the two sides of the Taiwan Strait should forge rapprochement based on the principles of parity and dignity and replace confrontation with cooperation. He urged mainland China to resume regular cross-strait dialogue to discuss constructive ways to promote mutually beneficial ties as early as possible.

In view of the existing difficulties in cross-strait government-to-government communication, Chang said he is pleased to see the formation of the Cross-Strait Economic and Trade Association that will offer services to the large number of Taiwan entrepreneurs who have invested in mainland China.
Despite the absence of official cross-strait communication channels, Chang said, the government will also make continued efforts to offer necessary assistance to Taiwan investors in the mainland.

Meanwhile, Legislator Ho Chi-hui, who concurrently heads the Cross-Strait Economic and Trade Association, said the newly inaugurated organization will set up offices in major mainland Chinese cities, including Beijing, Shanghai, Qingdao, Guangzhou, Shenzhen and Xiamen, to better serve Taiwan businesspeople there.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC ACADEMICIAN RECEIVES TWO PRESTIGIOUS U.S. STATISTICAL AWARDS

TEXT.P: Academia Sinica member George C. Tiao has become the first scholar and the first ethnic Chinese to receive both the prestigious Wilks Memorial Award and the Julius Shiskin Award in statistics in the same year.

According to Academia Sinica, Tiao was awarded the 2001 Wilks Memorial Award by the American Statistical Association earlier this month for his contributions to "the advancement of scientific or technical knowledge, ingenious application of existing knowledge, and successful activity in the fostering of cooperative scientific efforts that have been directly involved in matters of national defense or public interest."

The W. Allen Wallis Professor of Econometrics and Statistics of the Graduate School of Business at the University of Chicago, Tiao was also given the 2001 Julius Shiskin Award for Economic Statistics sponsored in July by the National Association for Business Economics, the Washington Statistical Society, and the Business and Economic Statistics Section of the American Statistical Association.

The award recognizes Tiao's research and leadership contributions to the methodological foundations of the first model-based approach to seasonal adjustment that has been adopted by several national statistical offices and central banks.

Tiao received his Ph.D. in Economics from the University of Wisconsin in Madison and then joined the Statistics and Business faculties of that university, where he collaborated on Bayesian statistics and time series analysis with other noted scholars.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT TO EXPEL PARTY MEMBERS WHO JOIN TSU

TEXT.P: An opposition Kuomintang (KMT) spokesman said Monday that 12 KMT members are among the 39 prospective candidates who will run on the ticket of the just-established Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) in December's legislative elections.
The spokesman said the KMT Evaluation and Discipline Committee would convene a meeting Tuesday to "expel" them from the party in accordance with party regulations.

Local newspapers had reported that of the 39 TSU candidates, 19 belonged to the KMT, but a check by the party found that seven of the named candidates had not registered as KMT members at the end of last year, which means they had already lost their KMT memberships.

Although eight of the candidates issued statements Monday to announce their party resignations, a KMT official said that just making an announcement or mailing back the party certificates do not comply with the procedures for quitting the party.
Spokesman Wang Chih-kang stated the day before that all party members will be expelled if they join other parties.
Meanwhile, KMT Chairman Lien Chan said Monday that the Evaluation and Discipline Committee will consider how to deal with the behavior and remarks of former KMT Chairman Lee Teng-hui.
Lee was invited to speak at the inauguration of the TSU. He also openly voiced his support for the TSU candidates.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA PROTESTS BEIJING'S REMARKS ON ROC'S U.N. BID

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) issued a press release Monday protesting mainland China's remarks on the Republic of China's bid to join the United Nations.
The ministry said its press statement that the ROC and the People's Republic of China have co-existed on the two sides of the Taiwan Strait for more than 50 years.
Noting that the two sides have different political systems, social values and external relations, the ministry said, the ROC and the PRC are neither subject to each other nor represent each other.

Against this backdrop, the ministry said, mainland China's claim that Taiwan is a province under the PRC and thus has not rights to join the United Nations is a serious deviation from the fact and a self-deceit trick.

The ministry further said U.N. Resolution No. 2758, adopted in 1971, which gave the China seat to mainland China at the expense of the ROC grossly violated the principles of fairness and justice and the United Nations' own principle of membership universality.

Noting that the ROC is a constructive, responsible member of the international community, the ministry said, the ROC has every legitimate right to join the United Nations and other international organizations.

If mainalnd China continues to block Taiwan's presence in the world arena, the ministry said, mainland China would only draw backlash from the 23 million people of Taiwan and the large number of overseas Chinese people who are concerned about Taiwan's well-being. Mainland China's opposition would also hurt relations across the Taiwan Strait, the ministry said, adding that mainland leaders should pragmatically face up to the reality of the ROC's continued existence in Taiwan.

Mainland China's U.N. delegation voiced opposition to Taiwan's U.N. bid in a press conference on Aug. 9 after 10 of ROC diplomatic allies filed a proposal Aug. 7 with the U.N. Secretariat urging the U.N. General Assembly to set up a task force to study Taiwan's desire for a U.N. seat.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT ACCOUNTING AGENCY DISMISSES REPORTS OF INFLATED GDP

TEXT.P: The government's Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) dismissed as a "misunderstanding" Monday a local media report that claimed the agency inflated the GDP by including the "underground economy" in its calculations.

Yeh Wan-an, a member of the directorate general's GDP Statistics Evaluation Committee, said that the government follows the U.N. System of National Accounts (SNA) when calculating the GDP and includes the underground economy "just like every other country."

Yeh said that all legal underground economic activities such as peddling are traditionally counted by various means and only such illegal economic activities as drugs and prostitution cannot be estimated.

DOC.HEADLINE: CEPD HEAD: GOVERNMENT WILL CONTINUE TO REGULATE MAINLAND INVESTMENT

TEXT.P: Amid media reports that the Executive Yuan will move to ease the current mainland China investment policy, a government official said Monday that the government will adopt a "total amount control" to regulate future Taiwan capital outflow to mainland China.

Council of Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) Chairman Chen Po-chih dismissed the reports by clarifying that the government will "rationally" relax relevant rules on future mainland-bound investment by Taiwan firms while seeking to prevent a side effect of "capital hollow-out."
The CEPD chief made the remarks while answering reporters' questions during the interval of a seminar on Taiwan's industrial upgrading.

According to local media, the Executive Yuan called a meeting recently in which it was decided that a restriction covered in the present "no haste, be patient" mainland investment policy -- the ban on single investment plans worth over US$50 million -- will be lifted and replaced by a "total amount control" on each company's investment volume in the mainland in compliance with the current regulations.
Meanwhile, Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen confirmed that the Cabinet called a meeting on cross-strait trade and investment policy but failed to make any final decision.

As to a proposal raised a day earlier by a panel meeting of the Economic Development Advisory Conference (EDAC) urging the government to remove the ban on each mainland-bound investment plan worth more than US$50 million, Tsai said the government will conduct "substantial screenings" on such investment plans in the future in order to gain an understanding as to whether they are necessary or whether they would have serious implications for Taiwan's capital movements.

The MAC chairwoman noted that the government has different screening processes for different investment thresholds and called on the public "not to take the matter too seriously." She added that consensus reached at the EDAC will serve as the government's policy framework.

Regarding speculation that the government will lift the mainland investment ceiling on funds collected by companies from the local stock market and the over-the-counter market from the current level of 20 percent to 40 percent and that the government is projecting to open six ports for direct cargo shipping ties with mainland China, Tsai said only that "nothing has been settled."

Turning to a warning issued by National Security Bureau Director Ting Yu-chou that Beijing is attempting to use an economic approach to push for Taiwan's unification with the mainland and a recent mention by President Chen Shui-bian of a cross-strait economic war, Tsai claimed that "it is unlikely that the situation between the two sides will reach such a point."

"The economies of the two sides are complementary to each other and the mutually beneficial exchanges were viewed as the basic principle of cross-strait economic activities during the EDAC panel meeting," she stressed.

Tsai admitted that national security should be considered in cross-strait economic activities but she also made it clear that Taiwan-mainland trade and investment activities are permitted, as long as all possible risks are assessed in advance.

DOC.HEADLINE: LAWMAKER URGES GOVERNMENT TO GUARD AGAINST `NEW BEIJING PLOT'

TEXT.P: A lawmaker of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) called on the Executive Yuan Monday to take precautions against what he claimed is "Beijing's scheme to achieve political goals by means of commerce."
According to Tsai Huang-liang, party whip of the DPP caucus at the Legislative Yuan, Beijing plans to downgrade Taiwan to the status of Hong Kong by using economic means.

He called on the Cabinet to map out counter-measures in fields related to national security, social stability and the stabilization of financial and monetary order before Taiwan is admitted into the World Trade Organization (WTO).

Tsai quoted Ting Yu-chou, director of the National Security Bureau (NSB), as reporting that Beijing is studying a so-called "one country four districts" and a "one country, four legal systems" formula as an economic means of achieving unification with Taiwan.
Ting reported Beijing's scheme Sunday when he briefed a closed-door meeting of the cross-strait panel of the upcoming Economic Development Advisory Conference (EDAC) slated for late August.

Tsai said that the purpose of Beijing's new economic united front move is to use business to put pressure on the Republic of China government so as to force Taiwan to accept Beijing's "one country, two systems" proposal.

He stressed that the Cabinet will do whatever it can to implement the consensus reached at the upcoming EDAC. Nevertheless, the Cabinet should also adopt precautions against Beijing's repeated attempts to downgrade Taiwan politically.

Tsai also suggested that the Cabinet should take necessary measures to speed up the building of Taiwan into a global operations center, to map out measures to protect local industry and to cope with the dumping of mainland-produced commodities coming into Taiwan as WTO entry draws near.

DOC.HEADLINE: TSU TO BE TAIWAN'S 95TH POLITICAL PARTY

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU), which was founded Sunday, will become Taiwan's 95th political party when its founding is approved by the Ministry of the Interior, probably within the next five days.

TSU Secretary-General Su Chin-chiang submitted Monday a name list of TSU officials, the TSU charter and the minutes of the founding congress of the party to the ministry as part of the procedure for establishing a new political party.
The Ministry of Interior automatically approves new parties so long as they do not espouse communism, try to split national territory, or copy the name of an existing political party.

Former Minister of the Interior Huang Chu-wen, who is the TSU convener, was elected to chair the newly founded party and Su Chin-chiang was elected as secretary-general of the TSU at the founding congress the previous day.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S.-BASED MGM GROUP INTERESTED IN TAPENG BAY DEVELOPMENT PLAN
DOC.DATELINE: San Francisco, Aug. 12 (CNA) (By Neil Lu and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: The Las Vegas-based MGM Group is interested in a development plan for Tapeng Bay in the southern Taiwan county of Pingtung, Republic of China Transportation and Communications Minister Yeh Chu-lan said here Sunday.

Yeh, who is visiting the United States to attract foreign investment for Taiwan's tourist market, said the MGM Group has decided to dispatch officials in late September or early October to assess the Tapeng Bay recreational center project, despite the fact that she has set a precondition that no gambling facilities will be allowed in the compound.

The MGM Group enjoys a leadership role in the local casino business in Las Vegas after having taken over the management of the classy Bellagio and Mirage casino hotels. It is understood that the group sent personnel to Penghu Island last year to study the possibility of creating a gambling center there.

Accompanied by ROC officials stationed in San Francisco, Yeh also called at several casino hotels and tourist spots in Las Vegas to study how the city has succeeded in building such a big tourist empire in the sands of the Nevada desert. She was slated to pay a visit to the head of the Nevada tourist office and explain the Tapeng development project to the local tourism authorities Monday.
Traveling at the head of a delegation, Yeh arrived Friday in Las Vegas at the start of a 12-day tour to sell Taiwan's tourism market. She will also fly to Hawaii and Japan.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO COMMENT ON JAPAN PREMIER'S WAR SHRINE VISIT UNTIL TUESDAY: MOFA

TEXT.P: The Republic of China Ministry of Foreign Affairs made no immediate comment on a Monday visit by Japanese Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi to a war shrine despite fierce protests at home and in neighboring Asian countries.

MOFA spokeswoman Chang Siao-yue said that MOFA had instructed the ROC representative Office in Japan to "understand the real situation" and added that MOFA would probably release a statement about Koizumi's visit to the Yasukuni War Shrine the following day.

Koizumi said after the visit that he felt shame that he broke his promise to visit the shrine Aug. 15 to mark the end of World War Two. However, he went on, his visit two days sooner than originally planned was made out of consideration of Japan's national interest.

DOC.HEADLINE: ONE-FOURTH OF TAIWAN'S TEENAGE STUDENTS FREQUENT INTERNET CAFES: POLL
DOC.DATELINE: Taoyuan County, northern Taiwan, Aug. 13 (CNA) (By Fang Wen-hung)

TEXT.P: A new study released Monday shows that approximately one-fourth of the nation's 1.76 million middle school, high school and vocational school students frequent the ubiquitous Internet cafes at least once a week.
According to the study, which surveyed a random sampling of students in 129 schools nationwide, about half of the 9,305 respondents said that they had been to an Internet cafe at least once.
Approximately 7.2 percent of the respondents -- which works out to the equivalent of approximately 127,000 students nationwide -- said that they frequent Internet cafes at least three times a week.
The students on average stay in the cafes for a whopping 8.5 hours per visit.
Male students are more inclined to play online games at the cafes, while female students said that they prefer to visit online chat rooms.

In general, the respondents who said that they visit the cafes mainly to play online games accounted for 33 percent of the total. Another 29 percent said that they go there to chat online, while another 23 percent said that they go to the cafes to look for information online.

Meanwhile, 3.9 percent of those polled said that they go to Internet cafes to look for pornographic Web sites, 2.3 percent said that they gamble online and 1.7 percent said they go to the cafes to buy illegal stimulant drugs from dealers.
The study results show that those students who said they did not go to Internet cafes either have personal computers at home or are forbidden by their parents from entering Internet cafes.

The study was conducted by Hsu Fu-sheng, an assistant professor at the Central Police University, and Huang Fang-ming, an assistant professor at the National College of Physical Education and Sports. The results were presented at a seminar on law and order organized by the Central Police University.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI DISPUTES BEIJING'S CLAIMS THAT TAIWAN IS PRC PROVINCE

TEXT.P: The Republic of China disputed Monday Beijing's claims that Taiwan is one of its provinces.

The ROC Foreign Ministry said in a press release that the ROC and the People's Republic of China have lived across the Taiwan Strait from one another for more than five decades. Neither has jurisdiction over, or represents, the other and each has its own political system, diplomatic ties and social values, the press release noted.
Therefore, it went on, Beijing's claims that Taiwan is a province of the PRC and is thereby not eligible for United Nations membership is a groundless lie devised to deceive itself and others.

The ministry said the 1971 U.N. resolution to give the ROC's seat to the PRC denied the 23 million people of Taiwan the right to be represented at the international organization and contradicted the principles of justice, fairness and universal membership for which it has fought.

As a responsible member of the international community, the ROC is entitled to membership of any international group and Beijing's blockage of the island's bids for membership will only alienate the island's 23 million people, said the press release.
The ministry said the PRC should come to terms with the fact that the ROC on Taiwan is a sovereign country and should promote bilateral ties accordingly.
The press release was issued in response to a statement made Thursday in New York by Beijing's mission to the United Nations.

DOC.HEADLINE: LOCAL CHARITY CONDUCTS 299TH BONE MARROW DONATION
DOC.DATELINE: Hualien, eastern Taiwan, Aug. 13 (CNA) (By Victor Lai)

TEXT.P: The Hualien Tzu Chi Medical Center Monday conducted its 299th bone marrow donation, using marrow donated by a 19-year-old Taiwan male college student for transplant to a 46-year-old woman in Seoul.
The student, who now studies at Tzu Chi University, presented a blood sample to Tzu Chi blood bank together with his elder sister when he was a sixth grader seven years ago.

Learning of the opportunity to donate his bone marrow to the South Korean patient, the student was happy to make the donation, with the consent of his family. His mother is a commissioner of Tzu Chi, a Buddhist charity organization based in Hualien.
Soon after the extraction at the medical center, the student's bone marrow was handed to South Korean nursing staff for prompt delivery from Hualien to Seoul.
In order for a marrow transplant to be successful, the marrow must be implanted into the patient within 24 hours of extraction from the donor.
It was the 184th donation to a foreign recipient since Tzu Chi established its bone marrow databank seven years ago. So far, it has collected over 210,000 blood samples from willing marrow donors.

DOC.HEADLINE: `VOICE FROM TAIWAN; WORLD PEACE' DRIVE TO KICK OFF TUESDAY

TEXT.P: A three-day "Voice from Taiwan; World Peace" campaign initiated by Republic of China Vice President Annette Lu will kick off Tuesday, the organizing committee announced Monday.

More than 80 internationally renowned figures, including five Nobel Peace Prize winners, 14 congressmen from the United States, Japan and Thailand and 11 leaders of international non-governmental organizations (NGOs) have been invited to attend the activities.

Former Costa Rican President Oscar Arias Sanchez, a Nobel laureate, arrived in Taipei Sunday for the event, with former Polish President Lech Walesa, Former South African President F.W. de Klerk, Judy Williams, a U.S. anti-land mine activist and Joseph Rotblat, a British nuclear scientist who advocates the elimination of nuclear arms around the world, expected to arrive Tuesday or Wednesday.
Betty Williams, a peace advocate from Ireland, was confirmed unable to come.

Lu will accompany her guests on a trip to the ROC-held offshore island of Kinmen Tuesday, formally kicking off the activities. She will later host a dinner party in honor of the more than 80 international figures attending the event.

"A World Peace Forum" will be held Aug. 15-16 with the theme "Building a cross-strait sustainable peace." In addition to the invited guests, representatives of local political parties, along with former ROC President Lee Teng-hui, have also been invited to attend, with Lee and Walesa delivering speeches at the opening ceremony.

An outdoor concert entitled "A Night of World Peace" will be held in front of the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall Wednesday night, and Lu and the five Nobel laureates will jointly turn a a "Peaceful Terrestrial Globe" during the concert.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT TO THROW FIRST BALL IN WILLIAM JONES CUP

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian will throw the first ball in the first game of the William Jones Cup International Basketball Tournament Aug. 16, the organizers of the event said Monday.

The tournament, to be staged in Fengshan City, Kaohsiung County between Aug. 16 and Aug. 24, will bring together teams from eight countries -- Russia, Canada, Mongolia, South Korea, South Africa, the Philippines, Honduras and the Republic of China.

Kaohsiung County Magistrate Yu Cheng-hsien and head of the Republic of China Basketball Association Wang Jen-cheng will introduce the eight teams to the public at a news conference in Kaohsiung City Aug. 15, said the organizers.
It will be the first time in the tournament's 25-year history that the event has taken place in southern Taiwan -- Chen's power base -- rather than in Taipei City.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP'S TAIPEI COUNTY CANDIDATE LAYS OUT CONDITIONS OF COOPERATION

TEXT.P: A People First Party (PFP) candidate for the post of Taipei County magistrate spelled out Monday three conditions under which he will cooperate with Taiwan's two other main opposition parties.

Chin Chin-sheng, who was nominated by the PFP to run for Taipei County magistrate, said he would response favorably to the Kuomintang's (KMT's) calls for cooperation in the Taipei County race if the main opposition promises to support PFP candidate Chung Shao-he in Kaohsiung County and to support New Party candidate Wang Chien-shien in Taipei County.
In anticipation that Wang will win a straw poll among the candidates of the three parties, Chin said he wanted the KMT leaders to promise their support for Wang.

With the two conditions being fulfilled, Chin said, he would response in kind to the KMT's calls for the three parties to rally behind one candidate rather than naming their own candidates separately.

Chin laid out the conditions during a meeting with Wang during which he asked Wang to act as a mediator between the KMT and the PFP with the purpose of promoting cooperation between them in the year-end elections.
Wang pointed out after the meeting that the three parties will be unlikely to win the Taipei County magistrate position if each sticks to its own candidate.
He suggested picking a candidate from among the three parties' choices through polls and expressed his willingness to promote cooperation between the KMT and the PFP.

Taipei County is a power-base of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, which has controlled the county hall for 12 years in a row. There is no sign that its winning streak will be broken in the year-end elections.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT MEETS WITH U.S. CONGRESSMAN

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian met Monday with visiting U.S. Representative Rob Simmons, a Republican from Connecticut.
Chen expressed thanks to Simmons for greeting him in New York on May 21 when he stopped there on his way to El Salvador.

Noting that Simmons had been posted in Taiwan for three years and that his eldest daughter was born here, Chen said Simmons is one of the few U.S. congressmen who has special ties with and affection for the island.

Chen exchanged views with Simmons on the island's ties with the United States, and stressed the importance of U.S. arms sales to Taiwan which, he said, improve the island's capability to safeguard the peace across the Taiwan Strait.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT WILL NOT REPRIMAND FORMER CHAIRMAN

TEXT.P: The opposition Kuomintang (KMT) will not reprimand former KMT Chairman Lee Teng-hui for his presence at the inauguration of the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) Sunday.

Although some local KMT chapters demanded at the party's routine central work meeting Monday that Lee be reprimanded, KMT Secretary-General Lin Fong-cheng made no response, indicating that the party is taking a low-key posture over Lee's move.
Lee was KMT party chairman until the party lost its 55-year grip on power in Taiwan to the Democratic Progressive Party in the March 2000 presidential election.
At the TSU inaugural ceremony, Lee was critical of the "vicious power struggle" between the existing political parties and pledged his support for TSU candidates in December's legislative elections.

The KMT Evaluation and Discipline Committee will call a meeting Tuesday, however, to discuss punishment for the 12 former KMT members who quit the party to run on the TSU ticket in the upcoming elections.
A KMT spokesman said that the 12 members are expected to be "expelled" from the party in accordance with party regulations.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PRESIDENT RECEIVES AUSTRALIAN PARLIAMENTARIANS

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian received a delegation of Australian parliamentarians Monday and extended his appreciation for Australia's support for Taiwan's bid to join the World Trade Organization (WTO).

He also expressed the hope that Australia will support Taiwan's efforts to become an observer in the World Health Organization so that it can make contributions in the health field as a member of the international community.

Talking about Australia's support for the deployment of two U.S. aircraft carriers to waters close to the Taiwan Strait during the 1996 crisis across the Taiwan Strait, Chen described the moral courage of the Australian foreign minister as "admirable."

He also lauded a joint communique signed at last month's U.S.-Australian ministerial consultation meeting, which stated that Taiwan and mainland China should resolve their disputes through peaceful negotiations.
During the day's talks, the president asked the Australian government to change the "unfair" visa treatment for Taiwan tourists making short-term visits to Australia.

DOC.HEADLINE: VP HOPES `CAT CAN PEACEFULLY LIVE WITH LION'

TEXT.P: Republic of China Vice President Annette Lu said the purpose of a "Voice from Taiwan, World Peace and Love" campaign initiated by herself is to show how a "terrible lion" -- mainland China -- can live peacefully with a "lovely cat" -- Taiwan.

She made the remarks while receiving Rep. Ben Gilman, honorary chairman of the International Relations Committee of the U.S. House of Representatives, delegates from South Korea and delegates from Japan who are attending the event.
She also expressed hope that the international guests will convey the "voice from Taiwan for world peace" to every corner of the earth.

Both Beijing's and Taipei's WTO entry is a consensus reached among the United States and other "important" Western countries, Lu pointed out, claiming that Beijing "plans to use cross-strait WTO entry to downgrade Taiwan to the status of that of Hong Kong and Macau" with a "one country four districts" formula with the aim of further squeezing Taiwan's space in the international arena.
"We will absolutely not accept this kind of arrangement and the people in Taiwan should speak out their rejection to let the people of the whole world know of our determination," Lu stressed.

Taiwan has been isolated and forsaken by international society and the democratic Taiwan is like a "lovely kitty cat" compared with mainland China, which is like a "terrible lion," according to Lu. Her peace forum is supposed to find ways for Taiwan to live peacefully with the mainland, Lu said.

Gilman said in return that he firmly supports the ROC's bid for membership of international organizations including the United Nations. He also said that the cross-strait dispute should be resolved peacefully.

Gilman also quoted former U.S. President Ronald Reagan's statement before he signed the so-called Aug. 17 joint declaration in 1982. Part of Reagan's statement read: "Arms sales will continue in accordance with the act and with the full expectation that the approach of the Chinese government to the resolution of the Taiwan issue will continue to be peaceful. We attach great significance to the Chinese statement in the communique regarding China's fundamental policy, and it is clear from our statements that our future actions will be conducted with this peaceful policy fully in mind. We have an abiding interest and concern that any resolution be peaceful. I shall never waver from this fundamental position."
Lu's "world peace" activities will kick off Tuesday with more than 80 international figures converging at the rally.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, Aug. 14, or the 25th day of the sixth month of the Year of the Snake according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1811: The British occupy Java.
1811: Paraguay proclaims independence from Spain.
1900: Forces of eight powers -- Britain, Japan, the United States, Germany, Russia, France, Austria and Italy -- march from Tientsin and scale the walls of Beijing, relieving the foreign legation besieged there since the start of the Boxer Uprising two months earlier.
1917: The Beijing government declares war on Germany and Austro-Hungary.
1937: The ROC Air Force shoots down nine of 18 Japanese aircraft which are bombing Hangchow, capital of Chekiang Province in eastern China.
1945: Japan surrenders unconditionally, ending World War II.
1945: The Sino-Soviet Treaty of Friendship and Alliance is signed in Moscow.
1945: Nationalist leader Chiang Kai-shek invites Chinese Communist Party Chairman Mao Tse-tung to come to Chungking for a conference.
1947: Pakistan gains independence from Britain.
1949: Konrad Adenauer becomes the first chancellor of West Germany.
1951: Randolph W. Hearst, the newspaper publisher known as the king of America's "yellow" press, dies at the age of 88. Beginning with the San Francisco Examiner in 1887, he built the world's largest publishing empire comprising 28 major newspapers.
1951: Seamen aboard the Ta Han, a 2,000-ton mainland Chinese freighter, defect to Taiwan, sailing their ship to the port of Kaohsiung.
1958: The ROC Air Force shoots down three communist MiG-17s over Matsu.
1958: The United States decides to maintain an embargo on trade with Communist China, North Korea, and North Vietnam, despite NATO's announcement of a relaxation of trade restrictions with the Soviet bloc and Communist China.
1971: Ground for the construction of Taiwan's north-south freeway is broken near Linkou.
1973: Over 300 Chinese and foreign computer scientists meet at the Academia Sinica for the First International Symposium on Computers.
1974: The Taipei Century Symphony Orchestra leaves for the United States on a three-week goodwill tour.
1977: The ROC Air Force celebrates the 40th anniversary of its victory over the Japanese at Hangchow, with General Szetu Fu presiding.
1979: Wang Yun-wu, senior advisor to the president of the Republic of China, dies of heart failure at the Veterans General Hospital at the age of 92.
1980: More than 360 scholars from home and abroad take part in the International Conference on Sinology at the Academia Sinica.
1985: The ROC Executive Yuan issues a report on the investigation of official administrative responsibilities involved in the 10th Credit Cooperative scandal. Fifteen financial officials are reprimanded, given demerits, or dismissed.
1988: Major racial conflict breaks out in Burundi in east- central Africa, killing more than 24,000.
1999: The United States defeats Chinese-Taipei 10-9 to win the 18th International Baseball Association (IBA) Big League Championship in Kaohsiung.
2000: The Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics releases a forecast showing that Taiwan's per capital GDP will hit more than US$14,500 this year.
2000: Premier Tang Fei instructs the Ministry of Justice to review and revise relevant laws and regulations so as to enable the government to effectively crack down on types of crimes that are increasingly harming Taiwan society.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "He who intuitively apprehends truth is one who, without effort, hits what is right, and without thinking understands what he wants to know; whose life is easily and naturally in harmony with the moral law. Such a one is what we call a saint or a man of divine nature."

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL OPTOELECTRONICS EXPOSITION OPENING THURSDAY IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: A total of 200 optoelectronics manufacturers will present their new designs at the Opto Taiwan 2001 at the Taipei World Trade Center exhibition hall from Aug. 16-19.

Sponsored by the Photonics Industry and Technology Development Association (PIDA), the exhibition will feature optoelectronics components, optical input-output devices, optical storage devices, optical fiber communications and laser applications.

According to statistics compiled by the association, the production value of Taiwan's optoelectronics industry for 2000 amounted to NT$342.6 billion, a 46 percent increase over the previous year's total of NT$233.6 billion.
Since 1996, the optoelectronics sector has registered double-digit annual growth rates and has attained the highest annual growth among all high technological sectors.

Last year, Taiwan-produced scanners, CD-ROMs, compact disks, laser diodes, black-and-white CIS sensors, vacuum fluorescent displays and LED packagings topped the world list in terms of production value, according to the association.
With growing demand in the international market, the optical fiber communications sector has dedicated much effort to research and development.

At the Opto Taiwan 2001, the manufacturers will present new designs of optical fibers, optical cables, optical active components and optical passive components. An official of the association said that he expects the optical fiber communications sector will be a focus of attention at the four-day exhibition.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK PRICES UP BY 68.84 POINTS

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) gained ground on Tuesday, with the benchmark weighted price index moving up 68.84 points to close at 4,589.6.
Market turnover amounted to NT$45.29 billion (US$1.31 billion).

DOC.HEADLINE: KOIZUMI'S SHRINE VISIT HURTS ASIAN NEIGHBORS' FEELINGS: MOFA

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Tuesday that Japanese Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi's visit to a controversial war shrine has hurt the feelings of people in neighboring Asian countries.

MOFA spokeswoman Chang Siao-yue made the remarks at a news conference after Koizumi on Monday visited the controversial Yasukuni Shrine, which is dedicated to Japan's war dead, including Class A war criminals executed by the Allies at the end of World War II.
Chang said the Republic of China looks forward to seeing the Japanese government courageously and righteously face up to history and its past mistakes.

"We hope that Japan can give priority to forging long-term rapprochement with its Asian neighbors with vision and far-sightedness," Chang said, adding that Japan should join forces with other Asian countries in promoting freedom, democracy and stability in Asia.
Chang went on to say that the MOFA has directed the ROC's representative office in Tokyo to express Taiwan's stance on the issue.

Koizumi paid his silent respects at the controversial war shrine Monday, keeping a vow to visit the shrine but abandoning a promise to do so on the anniversary of Japan's Aug. 15, 1945 World War II surrender, which falls on Wednesday.

Koizumi said he had decided to change the date of the visit because the original plan to go on the surrender anniversary had generated outrage from Japan's neighbors as well as concern among members of his own ruling coalition.
Many Asians see the Yasukuni Shrine as a monument to militarism, and some Japanese fear official visits to it violate the principle of separation of religion and state.

Bowing to such concerns, Koizumi did not undergo traditional Shinto purification rituals at the altar. He also tried to dispel criticism that the visit was intended to glorify Japanese militarism. "Our country should never again walk the path to war," he said in a statement issued just before the visit.
Koizumi's shrine visit immediately triggered strident protests from mainland China and South Korea, which see paying homage at the shrine as a tribute to Japanese wartime aggression in Asia.
The MOFA was originally scheduled to issue a press release Monday afternoon to express its stance, but it delayed the issue of its reaction until Tuesday.
Chang said that as Koizumi's move is a sensitive political issue, the MOFA must make a prudent and comprehensive evaluation of the situation before expressing its position.
Meanwhile, the Ministry of National Defense (MND) expressed the ROC military's indignation Tuesday at Koizumi's visit to the controversial shrine.

MND spokesman Huang Suey-sheng said at a routine news conference that many ROC military servicemen and civilians sacrificed their lives during the Eight-Year War of Resistance Against Japan (1937-1945).
"We would not like to see any Japanese prime minister pay homage at the shrine, where Japanese war dead, including executed war criminals, are honored," Huang said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Shares prices opened high and closed even higher on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) on Tuesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 68.84 points to close at 4,589.6.
The bourse opened at 4,547.75 and continued to go up due to the good performance of electronics shares. The bourse fluctuated between 4,589.6 and 4,523.35 during trading.

A total of 1.95 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$45.29 billion (US$1.31 billion), an increase from the previous trading session which saw 1.76 billion stocks change hands on a market turnover of NT$39.08 billion (US$1.13 billion).
Only two of the eight major stock categories lost ground, with cement stocks moving down the most at 1 percent, followed by construction shares at 0.1 percent.

The other major categories posted gains, with electrical shares moving up the most at 2.1 percent, followed by plastics and chemical stocks at 1.2 percent, pulp and paper issues at 1 percent, textile issues at 0.4 percent, bank and insurance stocks at 0.3 percent, and foodstuff shares at 0.2 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 321 to 182, with 85 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock index futures market were higher on Tuesday, as Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index futures for August moved up 129 points to close at 4,619, with 4,329 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index futures for September rose 121 points to finish at 4,605, with 9,820 contract transactions, while next June futures increased 166 points to finish at 4,550, with 20 contracts changing hands.

Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were also higher.
