No transactions were recorded for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: EASING CROSS-STRAIT RULES WON'T AFFECT MOST MANUFACTURERS' PLANS: POLL

TEXT.P: The results of a survey of local manufacturers released Tuesday shows that nearly two thirds of those polled will not change their domestic investment plans even when Taiwan authorities allow direct trade and transportation across the Taiwan Strait.

The Statistics Department of the Ministry of Economic Affairs sent questionnaires to 4,000 local manufacturers in March regarding their investment willingness. Among the 3,055 replies received in May, 1,904 copies came from small businesses with less than 100 employees, 237 came from medium-size businesses with between 100 and 200 employees, and 914 came from large enterprises.

The survey revealed that 61.41 percent of the respondents said that the government's decision on cross-strait direct links will have no effect on their domestic investment plans in terms of investment value, 15.35 percent said they will reduce the amount of their domestic investments, and 23.24 percent said they will boost the amount of their domestic investments.

Referring to the impact of Taiwan's entry into the World Trade Organization, 73.85 percent of those polled said they will not change their domestic investment plans, 16.56 percent said they will reduce the amount of their investments, and 9.59 percent said they will increase them.

Taiwan's economy began taking a downturn during the fourth quarter of last year, and domestic investment willingness has been low since then. The survey showed that only 25.01 percent of those polled plan to increase their investments from the levels of the previous year, while 31.91 percent plan to make less investments this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE PRESIDENT AND WORLD PEACE FORUM GUESTS VISIT KINMEN

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu on Tuesday traveled to Taiwan's offshore island of Kinmen, located just opposite mainland China, one day before the world peace forum she initiated formally kicks off Wednesday.

Lu, accompanied by several forum guests, including Nobel laureate and former Costa Rican President Oscar Arias Sanchez, flew to Kinmen in a special air force plane. They were warmly welcomed by Fukien Provincial Government Chairman Yen Chung-cheng, Army Deputy Commander-in-Chief Kao Hua-chu and Kinmen County Magistrate Chen Shui-tsai.

Lu first went to Kinmen National Park's tourist center to assemble with other guests who had arrived earlier. The nearly 100 guests then shouted "love and peace" in unison to highlight the theme of the world peace forum.
The forum will take place Aug. 15-16, with the theme being "Creating Eternal Peace in the Taiwan Strait."

An outdoor concert titled " A Night of World Peace" will be held the evening of Aug. 15 at Taipei's Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall, where Lu and six Nobel laureate guests will jointly inaugurate a "Terrestrial Globe of Peace" in commemoration of the end of World War II some 56 years ago.
After meeting up with the other guests at Kinmen's National Park, Lu and the group then toured the park's tourist center, accompanied by Kinmen National Park administrator Hsu Wen-lung.

Lu showed concern while viewing the vintage 75 millimeter artillery guns that were used during past cross-strait fighting, expressing the hope that war can be "decommissioned" just as these weapons have been and that peace can take its place.

Lu and the guests then toured the island's underground tunnels constructed for military defense to gain a better understanding of the efforts exerted by Republic of China military forces stationed on Kinmen and by the island's residents in preserving peace.

DOC.HEADLINE: LECH WALESA ARRIVES IN TAIPEI TO ATTEND WORLD PEACE FORUM

TEXT.P: Former Polish President and 1983 Nobel Peace Prize winner Lech Walesa arrived in Taipei Tuesday to attend the World Peace Forum organized by Republic of China Vice President Annette Lu.
Walesa is the second Nobel Prize laureate to arrive in Taiwan for the forum. Former Costa Rican President Oscar Arias Sanchez, the 1987 winner, arrived here Sunday.
Other Nobel Peace Prize winners scheduled to arrive Tuesday including former South African President Frederik W. de Klerk, the 1993 winner, and Joseph Rotbalt, the 1995 winner.

The World Peace Forum, which will be held Aug. 15-16 in Taipei, is part of the "Voice from Taiwan: Peace and Love" campaign. The participants to the forum will exchange opinions on cross-strait relations, regional stability in the Asia-Pacific, and international peace.

After two months of efforts, the organizers invited 80 people from various countries to attend the campaign, including five Nobel Prize winners, 14 lawmakers from the United States, Japan and Thailand, and 11 representatives of international organizations.
The "Voice from Taiwan: Peace and Love" campaign and related activities began Tuesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TOURISM INDUSTRY NEEDS INT'L EXPERIENCE, CAPITAL: MOTC HEAD
DOC.DATELINE: San Francisco, Aug. 13 (CNA) (By Neil Lu and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Republic of China Minister of Transportation and Communications Yeh Chu-lan said Monday after visiting Las Vegas that promoting Taiwan tourism will require international knowledge, capital and experience.

Yeh, in order to promote Taiwan tourism and solicit overseas capital for a development project in Tapeng Bay in southern Taiwan county of Pintung, toured Las Vegas tourism facilities from Aug. 10 and met with Nevada State government officials and tourism operators.

She said the reason for the success of Las Vegas can be traced to its long-term experience, its comprehensive planning, its comprehensive legal system, and its law abiding citizens. She added that Las Vegas' financial auditing of casinos, facility inspections, and even its employee background checks have been rigorous.

Nevada State's tourism head told Yeh that a place cannot draw in tourists with simply one attraction, pointing out that Las Vegas not only has casinos, but has also become a convention, shopping and leisure center.

Yeh said that Taiwan is blessed with natural beauty as well as with a multicultural and dynamic society, but added that the island's tourism industry lacks international experience, capital and knowledge. She noted that the island's hotel management and leisure facilities cannot match up with those of the United States.

She also said that U.S.-based MGM Group has expressed interest in the development project in Tapeng Bay and that the group will send officials in late September and early October for an on-site inspection. Las Vegas tourism officials will also be invited to visit Taiwan, Yeh added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TWO F-16 WINGS TO BE COMMISSIONED IN EARLY 2002

TEXT.P: Two F-16 jet fighter wings will be commissioned into service in the Republic of China Air Force early next year, Air Force Commander-in-Chief Chen Chao-min announced Tuesday.

Chen made the remarks at a rally at the Air Force General Headquarters (AFGH) in Taipei to mark the 64th anniversary of the air force's "Aug. 14 Victory," which refers to the defeat of a Japanese attack on an ROC air base in Chienchiao, southeastern mainland China, during World War II.

Chen said the air force has been undergoing restructuring and deploying a new generation airborne arsenal in recent years. By now, the air force has completed commissioning of a squadron of E2-T airborne warning and control system (AWACS) aircraft, two wings of Ching-kuo indigenous defense fighters and one wing of French-made Mirage 2000-5 jet fighters.
In addition, Chen said, combat training for two F-16 wings has entered the final stage. "They are scheduled to formally join air force services in early 2002," he added.

The air force has taken delivery of nearly all of the 150 U.S.-made F-16s that make up the two wings, with the exception of a few of them which are still in the United States, where they are being used to train ROC pilots. The F-16s are now stationed at the Chiayi and Hualien air bases.

In fact, air force sources said, the two F-16 wings can become ready for combat missions at the end of this year, when 28 sets of pathfinder\sharpshooter as well as a number of reconnaissance pods to be installed on the F-16s, will be delivered to Taiwan.

As the current Cabinet is likely to undergo a reshuffle after the December legislative elections, the sources said, the air force has decided not to hold a formal commissioning ceremony for the two F-16 wings until after a new Cabinet is formed early next year.

Addressing the AFGH rally, Chen said the air force's top mission at the moment is to maintain air supremacy over the Taiwan Strait and to join forces with other military branches to defeat any invading enemies.

Chen encouraged all air force officers and men to glamorize the air force tradition and create even more glory in the future. "While marking the Aug. 14 Chienchiao victory anniversary, we must understand the historic significance of the event and learn from the self-sacrifice spirit of our air force," he noted.

Chen further said all air force personnel must dedicate themselves to defending national security with loyalty and combat prowess. "To accomplish our mission, we must pay heed to mainland China's military development, intensify combat skill training and strengthen risk management and flight safety control," he added.

At the rally, 201 air force officers were cited for their outstanding performance in various fields, including flight safety control, information, combat control, aviation control and logistic support.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND CHINA LOOMING AS NO. 1 RIVAL FOR TAIWAN HI-TECH: POLL

TEXT.P: Some 50 percent of Taiwan's hi-tech businesses believe that mainland China will become Taiwan's leading competitor due to the "go-west" exodus by the local information industry, according to the results of a recent poll.

At the same time, nearly 90 percent of Taiwan's hi-tech firms are worried that Taiwan-based foreign companies will move their production lines out of Taiwan in the coming three years, the survey made public by Business Weekly in early August shows.

The poll of companies whose business revenues exceeded NT$500 million in 2000 shows that 70 percent praised the government's role in the development of Taiwan's information industry over the past 20 years, but only 8.9 percent think Taiwan's economy will remain "in good shape" in the coming three years, lagging 43.6 percent who said it will be "regular" and 47.5 percent that are "pessimistic" about the issue.

Of those who hold a "pessimistic view" of Taiwan's economy, 35 percent attributed "political woes" to the deteriorating economy, while 14 percent and 11 percent blamed "industry exodus" and "government policies," respectively, for the situation.

Some 50.2 percent said that those local computer firms that have set up plants in mainland China will pose the largest threat to those maintaining their operations at home in the coming three years. A dwindling economy, Taiwan's falling status as a manufacturing center and a talent exodus are also problems troubling them, the survey points out.

As to the question of the future of Taiwan's computer industry, around 30 percent of the personal computer-related businesses surveyed said it is "extremely good" or "good," fewer than 48.7 percent that said it will be "business as usual" and ahead of 20 percent that were "extremely pessimistic" or "pessimistic" about the issue.
In related news, a local official has warned that Taiwan industries should seek profound transformation or they will be caught up soon by their mainland Chinese competitors.

Industrial Development Bureau (IDB) Director-General Shih Yen-shiang said recently that Taiwan businesses must shift to high value-added manufacturing and focus on R&D, design, marketing and creating own-brand names. He predicted that local industries will be outperformed by their mainland Chinese counterparts within five years should they fail to do so.

According to the IDB head, Taiwan industries are facing a historic challenge in that they must ride out the painful transformation period in order to survive at a time when globalization is sweeping the world and the mainland is quickly emerging as a strong rival.

He pointed out that those businesses that fail to achieve this objective will be eventually phased out, no matter whether they choose to relocate to mainland China or maintain their operations in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT TO INVEST NT$ 3 TRILLION IN PUBLIC PROJECTS

TEXT.P: The government will raise a budget allocation of NT$3 trillion for public projects for the coming five years at the Legislative Yuan, a government official said Tuesday.

Chang Ching-sun, vice chairman of the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD), said the CEPD wishes to allocate the money once for all for all the public projects slated to be carried out in the coming five years.

The CEPD move came after participants of the ongoing Economic Development Advisory Conference (EDAC) reached consensus on increasing government spending on public projects to help prop up the demand in the local market, Chang said.

According to the CEPD vice chairman, the next five years will be a critical period for the development of Taiwan's industries, and greater government investment in public projects will be very important to complement this. Since the EDAC has endorsed the move, it means that the local economy will not be interrupted too much by political factors in the future, he noted.
With the endorsement from all sectors, Chang said the CEPD hopes to raise the budget allocations in six months and that they will be approved by the Legislative Yuan in its new session.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC VICE PRESIDENT VISITS KINMEN WITH INTERNATIONAL PEACE ADVOCATES

TEXT.P: A 90-member delegation of international peace advocates led by Republic of China Vice President Annette Lu and including Nobel Peace Prize winner Oscar Arias Sanchez visited the frontline ROC island of Kinmen Tuesday.

Accompanied by local government officials, the group of peace advocates, including heads of international NGOs and legislators from Holland, Japan, South Korea, Thailand and the Philippines, toured local historic military sites such as the underground combat readiness tunnels and the cavernous Atlas Dome, which was entirely carved out of granite by 1,000 soldiers in 1963 and can serve as an emergency medical center in times of conflict.

Lu said at a lunch banquet welcoming her and the foreign guests that her present visit -- her third to Kinmen since she became vice president last May -- is the most significant so far because of the peace advocates accompanying her to the heavily garrisoned island known for its strategic position in the Taiwan Strait.

She added her hope that her guests can exchange views on how to bring peace to the Taiwan Strait after they return to Taiwan-proper to continue their series of activities for the 2001 Global Peace Assembly being held in Taipei.

Thanking all the soldiers and local military commanders for protecting the nation, she said that peace for many people is just a slogan, but for the servicemen and women in Kinmen, it is a matter of life and death and a sacred mission.

Noting that she is confident that the "bell of peace" will in the near future be heard around the world, including Kinmen, she said that she hopes Kinmen will -- under the leadership of the government and with the contribution of the people of Kinmen -- become a "bridge of peace" between Taiwan and mainland China.

Arias, president of Costa Rica from 1986-1990 and who received the Nobel Peace Prize in 1987, said at the banquet that "peace is necessary," and that in a civilized world, no one should resort to the use of military force to solve conflicts.

He said that in a rational world, conflicts should be resolved at the negotiating table, adding that the same is true for the situation in the Taiwan Strait, so that the new generation in Taiwan can live in a "new century of peace."

"Dialogue produces miracles," Arias said, explaining that "you need to look in the face and the eyes of the other party and for that, you need to sit around a negotiating table. And if the other party doesn't want to take part in dialogue, be humble, invite it to dialogue, and if it refuses, invite it again."
The essence of dialogue is compromise, he added.
He called for a closer look at the real dangers to world peace -- poverty, illiteracy and environmental degradation -- instead of starting a new arms race.
"How can we live in peace in the future if half of the world population lives in poverty, if people don't have access to potable water, if most of the people in the world are illiterate?" he asked.

A two-day "World Peace Forum" is scheduled to kick off Wednesday, with the theme of "Creating Eternal Peace in the Taiwan Strait." Former ROC President Lee Teng-hui is slated to speak at the forum's opening ceremony.

An outdoor concert titled "A Night of World Peace" will be held Wednesday evening at Taipei's Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall, where Lu and the Nobel laureates who were invited to participate in the series of events will jointly inaugurate a "Terrestrial Globe of Peace" in commemoration of the end of World War II some 56 years ago.

The Nobel Peace Prize winners invited to attend the event include Arias; former Polish President Lech Walesa; former South African President Frederick W. de Klerk; Jody Williams, a U.S. anti-land mine activist; and Joseph Rotblat, a British nuclear scientist who advocates the elimination of nuclear arms around the world.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP-ORGANIZED TAIWAN-JAPAN AMITY ASSOCIATION TO BE SET UP

TEXT.P: A Taiwan-Japan Amity Association set up by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) will be formally established Wednesday to strengthen bilateral relations, a DPP official said Tuesday.

Frank Hsieh, DPP chairman and concurrently president of the new organization, will preside over the founding ceremony, with Presidential Office Secretary-General Yu Shyi-kun, Vice Foreign Minister Chiou Rong-nan, President of the East Asian Relations Association Lin Chin-chin, and President of Japan's Interchange Association Shintaro Yamashita witnessing the event.

The official said that the association will become the DPP's liaison window between Taiwan and Japan so as to promote relations with various Japanese political parties and organizations friendly to Taiwan.

The association will consist chiefly of officials from the DPP Central Committee and DPP members in the Presidential Office, the Executive Yuan, and other government agencies. The aim of the association will be to promote cooperation between the political parties of the two countries in order to strengthen Taiwan-Japan relations.

A seminar titled "Security and Development; a Political Dialogue between Taiwan and Japan" will be held in Taipei in mid September under the co-sponsorship of the Taiwan-Japan Amity Association and the Japan-Taiwan Dietmen Amity Council under the control of Japan's Opposition Democratic Party.
Discussions will center on the security of the Asian-Pacific region and the economic development in this part of the world, according to the official.

DOC.HEADLINE: COUPLE INVOLVED IN TAIPEI BUS HIJACKING INDICTED

TEXT.P: The Taipei Prosecutor's Office indicted Tuesday a married couple accused of hijacking a tour bus in Taipei in June.
The couple -- Chang Wen-liang and his wife Chuang Pao-yun -- were charged with committing an offense against public safety.
The couple used a remodeled handgun in Taipei June 23 to hold the driver of a tour bus and 13 passengers hostage, demanding to meet Justice Minister Chen Ding-nan to present a petition of grievance.

A standoff between Taipei police and the hijackers lasted for about four hours and did not come to an end until after Chen acquiesced to the hijackers' demands by appearing in the dense crowd of rubberneckers that had gathered at the scene, totally overwhelming the police, who failed completely to maintain order at the scene.
Prosecution authorities said in the indictment that the couple's resorting to bus hijacking to highlight their appeal had caused public unrest and a waste of public resources.
Therefore, they asked the Taipei District Court to sentence the couple to seven years in prison.

The hijacking incident began at around 2 p.m. June 23, when the hijackers forced a tour bus on which they were traveling to come to a stop on at a busy city intersection and then demanded to meet with Chen.
Chen rushed to a nearby police precinct but remained behind the scenes to allow the police to continue attempting to engage the hijackers in communication.
For nearly four hours, police were unable to determine how many hostages were aboard the bus because all the curtains were drawn and the hijackers refused a cellular phone offered to them.

All communication had to be carried out via handwritten signs that were held up to the bus windows and the hijackers did not reveal themselves, relying instead on a female hostage to read the notes held up by the police.
The standoff ended after Taipei SWAT teams stormed the bus and rescued the hostages on board. No one was injured in the incident.

The woman hijacker stepped off the bus first and rushed toward Chen to deliver a petition of grievance. Seconds after the woman left the bus, SWAT teams detonated two flashbangs outside the bus "to disorient" the remaining hijacker still aboard the bus and shattered a window to attract his attention. Fortunately, other policemen then swarmed in from the other side and took control of the situation.
The Taipei Prosecutor's Office said other prosecution authorities are still handling the hijacking couple's petition of grievance concerning a land deal and an injury charge involving their son.

DOC.HEADLINE: EDITOR'S NOTE:
DOC.TEXT:

Since the EDAC has endorsed the move, it means that the local economy will not be interrupted too much by political factors in the future, he noted.
With the endorsement from all sectors, Chang said the CEPD hopes to raise the budget allocations in six months and that they will be approved by the Legislative Yuan in its new session.

DOC.HEADLINE: CLA `NO WORK, NO PAY' PROPOSAL LAMBASTED

TEXT.P: A "no work, no pay" formula proposed Tuesday by the Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) to scrap monthly salaries for domestic workers in favor of hourly or daily rates, was immediately met with a backlash and opposition.
Meanwhile, however, a presidential policy consultative meeting reached consensus Tuesday that the nation's minimum wage requirement will not be scrapped.

CLA Chairwoman Chen Chu claimed that the proposed "no work, no pay" formula that would see workers paid by hour in order to fully reflect production costs, is "in line with the global trend" and would not be seen as taking away human rights protection for blue-collar workers.

Dismissing Chen's statement, Legislator Chien Hsi-chieh of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) said Chen was "irresponsible" for saying that the "no work, no pay" formula is a global trend. He pointed out that on the contrary, many industrially advanced countries are now reviewing the formula to assess its impact on real industrial development and progress.
Chien said the "no work, no pay" formula will only result in reducing pay and rights for blue-collar workers and would contribute nothing to raising the nation's international competitiveness.

As the highest-level government agency responsible for protecting laborers' rights, the CLA has downgraded itself into nothing more than a tool of the capital-holding management side by proposing such an unjust formula, Chien added.

Lin Feng-hsi, DPP party whip at the Legislative Yuan, said the DPP legislative caucus will not throw its support behind the "no work, no pay" proposal, which he described as lacking justice to the blue-collar workers.

Noting that Taiwan's sagging economy is not going to be saved simply by sacrificing the interests of local workers, Lin said any changes in the patterns of payment must be made through negotiations and agreements between business and enterprise owners and the laborers.
The "no work, no pay" proposal also faced an immediate backlash from Taiwan's labor union groups.
Demonstrating in downtown Taipei, members of the labor groups said their incomes would be cut by one-third if they were to be paid by the hour.

Under the new "no work, no pay" formula, enterprise owners and operators would be able to withhold pay for the 52 days in a year that are currently paid holidays under the existing Labor Standards Law.
The opposition Kuomintang slammed the formula as "immoral." Lee Cheng-tsung, KMT party whip at the Legislative Yuan, said the KMT would never allow the proposal to clear the legislative floor.

On Tuesday, the nine-member presidential policy consultative meeting also decided that the minimum wage requirement, which currently guarantees domestic workers a minimum of NT$15,840 (US$458) a month, will not be scrapped in order to protect the workers' basic rights and interests.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S BUSINESS ENVIRONMENT RATING TO RISE TO 18TH PLACE: EIU
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 14 (CNA) (By Mark Ou and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's general business and industry environment will improve in the next five years, rising to the world's 18th-best from the current 21st place, according to the latest evaluation by a British economic research firm.

The Economist Intelligence Unit (EIU), an affiliate of the London-based Economist weekly, had studied the general commerce and industry climate of 60 major economies around the world and released a report on its findings this week.
In the previous EIU review, Taiwan's business climate for the 1996-2000 period received a score of 7.37 points, ranking 21st among all the economies scrutinized.
In its latest report, the EIU predicted that Taiwan's business climate will improve during the 2001-2005 period to receive a score of 8.06 points and 18th place in its global ranking.
Under the EIU scaling system, a score above eight points receives a "very good" rating and a score of 6.5 points to eight points is given a rating of "good."

The EIU report said Taiwan is expected to make progress and improvements in overall economic environment, policy on foreign investment, privatization, foreign trade and foreign exchange controls, bank financing, labor market and infrastructure construction over the next five years.
Nevertheless, the report said Taiwan's political stability, tax burden and market opportunities may deteriorate mildly during the same period.

The Netherlands will continue to boast the world's best business environment in the next five years, followed by the United States, Britain, Canada, Switzerland, Ireland, Finland, Singapore, Sweden and Hong Kong.

Most noteworthy is the fact that Hong Kong's rating declined from third to 10th place. The EIU report attributed the sharp fall partly to the territory's political changes, control policy and a widening gap between its labor demand and supply. Hong Kong, a former British colony, reverted to Beijing's rule July 1, 1997.

Commenting on the report, Chang Yao-chung, director of the Statistics Department under the Ministry of Economic Affairs, said Taiwan's economic future lies in the development of its service industry, including developing Taiwan into an Asia-Pacific business operation hub as well as a trading and banking center.

Chang said recent government moves to overhaul and streamline the banking sector, to ease various investment restrictions and to pave the way for opening direct trade across the Taiwan Strait are all aimed at creating a better investment climate and improving the island's overall economic structure.
Noting that the series of measures will help revive investor confidence, Chang said Taiwan's economic situation will certainly take an upturn next year.

Chen Po-chih, chairman of the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development, echoed Chang's view, saying that Taiwan's investment climate will improve after the Aug. 24-26 Economic Development Advisory Conference comes up with a package of measures to address some of the existing problems and outline future development directions.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC EXPRESSES REGRETS OVER JAPANESE PREMIER'S WAR SHRINE VISIT
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Aug. 14 (CNA) (By Mike Chang & Ed Chen)

TEXT.P: The Republic of China Representative Office in Japan, on behalf of the ROC government, expressed regret Tuesday over a visit by Japanese Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi to the Yasukuni War Shrine the previous day.

The Taipei Economic and Cultural Representative Office in Japan also expressed its "understanding" of a statement by Koizumi that Japan will have to make a self-examination over the bitterness of neighboring Asian countries toward Japan. The widespread bitterness is a result of the atrocities perpetrated by the Japanese on their Asian neighbors during World War II.
The ROC representative office expressed hope that Japan will handle the issue with wisdom and prudence after taking into account the feelings of its neighbors.
The Yasukuni War Shrine honors the memory of many Japanese considered by the rest of the world to be Class A war criminals and anger at Koizumi's visit is most bitter among its neighbors in Asia.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW TAIWAN DOLLAR RISES AGAINST U.S. UNIT

TEXT.P: The new Taiwan dollar rose NT$0.017 against the U.S. dollar Tuesday on the Taipei foreign exchange market, finishing at 34.582.
The local unit opened at 34.572 and was traded between a low of 34.546 and the day's high, which was its closing level.
Interbank transactions in U.S. dollars totaled US$640 million.

Market dealers attributed the local currency's appreciation to a stronger yen, which boosted all Asian currencies. But they pointed out that the Central Bank of China might have interfered in late trading out of concern that the local unit may appreciate too quickly against the greenback.
Market dealers forecast that the new Taiwan dollar might hover in the range between 34.55 and 34.57 over the next few days.

DOC.HEADLINE: TWO CREWMEN OF GREEK VESSEL ALLOWED TO LEAVE TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Two crewmen of a Greek vessel which ran aground off the costs of southern Taiwan's Pingtung County and polluted nearby waters in January were allowed by the government to leave Taiwan, an Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) official said Tuesday.

The decision to allow the men to leave was made during an inter-ministerial Cabinet meeting a day earlier. EPA head Hau Long-ping said Tuesday that the EPA was asked to allow the men to leave while continuing to seek compensation from the owners and insurers of the Greek ship the Amargos with the help of law firms at home and abroad.
Hau said it was "unnecessary" to continue detaining the pair in Taiwan, as the owners and insurers had actually come to Taiwan but left without having negotiated with the Taiwan authorities.

"Since they care not a bit for the two crew members, it is meaningless to continue detaining them in Taiwan and the government decided to let them depart out of consideration of human rights, legal and diplomatic factors," Hau said.

Hau added that he has consulted with both local and foreign law specialists regarding the case and that he has been told that the EPA still stands a good chance of winning the lawsuit for compensation for the cleanup operation. Hau said that he has full confidence in getting the money.
According to the EPA head, the two Greek seamen were made to sign a pledge promising to cooperate with the ROC judicial authorities investigating the case and to accept the final verdict.
If the pair break their promise, the EPA will undoubtedly file an international lawsuit in order to display Taiwan's determination to protect its ecosystems.
The Amargos ran aground and broke in two off the coast of Kenting National Park Jan. 14 and seriously polluted a large area of nearby waters when its fuel tanks ruptured.
Because of the EPA's ineptitude, it failed to take timely action to limit the damage, and its mishandling of the situation later led to former EPA head Lin Chun-yi resigning to take responsibility.

The EPA estimated that it has spent NT$90 million in cleaning up the contamination, while damage incurred to the local fishing industry and ecosystem has yet to be calculated. Future compensation must take into account these two points, EPA officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN BACKS CALL TO EASE 'GO SLOW' POLICY

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian voiced explicit support Tuesday for the proposals to ease restrictions on mainland China-bound investment.
"I believe that it's wise choice to replace the existing 'go slow, be patient' mainland investment policy with an open, active and effective management approach," Chen said.
The president made the remarks during a community reach-out tour of the southern Taiwan county of Kaohsiung where he visited several Buddhist and Taoist temples and a large semiconductor company.

This was the first time that Chen has expressed his views on the issue since the cross-strait affairs panel under the soon-to-be-convened Economic Development Advisory Conference (EDAC) reached a consensus urging the government to adjust the "go slow" policy on mainland China-bound investment.

The proposal has drawn mixed reaction in local society. Vice President Annette Lu, for instance, has expressed worries about the possible adverse impact on Taiwan's economic well-being of further relaxation of mainland China-bound investment.
President Chen said he himself thinks that adjusting the "go slow" investment policy is "the right path we must follow."

"Only when we have confidence can we not be afraid of competition. Like riding a bicycle, we can't limit ourselves to riding in a room. Only when we go outside can we find more opportunities," Chen said.

The president further said he is convinced that so long as Taiwan can adhere to the principles of "Taiwan first, global planning, risk management and reciprocity," it would have a secure environment for sustainable national development.

In this era of globalization, Chen went on, development of trade and economic relations between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait is a prevailing trend. "We can't resist this trend in order to maintain our competitiveness in the global market," he noted.
Nevertheless, Chen said, the government must still exercise prudence in handling relevant affairs because they involve Taiwan's long-term political and economic interests.

Noting that all EDAC members are now endeavoring to forge national consensus on certain critical issues, Chen said he believes that the Aug. 24-26 EDAC plenary meeting would be able to outline clear policy direction and guidelines.

Chen said his administration would also do its best to respond to the demands of various social quarters and continue to improve the domestic investment climate and develop Taiwan into a "green silicon island."

DOC.HEADLINE: MILITARY TO SHOWCASE LOCALLY DEVELOPED DEFENSIVE WEAPONS

TEXT.P: The Ministry of National Defense will showcase some 20 locally developed weapons and pieces of equipment at the 2001 Aeronautics Exhibition scheduled to open Wednesday in Taipei, Military Spokesman Huang Shuey-sheng said Tuesday.

The new items to be displayed at the two-day show at the Taipei World Trade Center include the Hsiungfeng-II anti-ship missile, the vehicle-loaded Tienchien (Skysword)-1 air-defense system, the RT2000 artillery multiple launch rocket system, the Chunghsiang-2 unmanned plane, the T86 rifle, digital military maps, night vision goggles, and day-and-night monitoring systems.
All the items were either developed by the Chungshan Institute of Science and Technology -- the research arm of the military -- or the Combined Service Force.

Saying that the items are just part of the result of the government's long-term efforts to establish a self-sufficient defense industry, Huang added that his ministry will continue to concentrate on this aspect of development in the future.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP LAWMAKER PERSUADES EX-GANG LEADER TO RETURN TO TAIWAN FOR TRIAL

TEXT.P: Lin Feng-hsi, legislative caucus leader of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, said Tuesday that he met with just-released former Bamboo Union gang leader Chen Chi-li in Phnom Pehn Aug. 12 to try to persuade him to return to Taiwan.

Chen, who is wanted on criminal charges in Taiwan, was freed together with two associates Aug. 10 after a Cambodian court sentenced them to short suspended jail terms for illegal arms possession. They had been detained since summer last year.

Lin said at a press conference that he went to Cambodia to persuade Chen to come back to Taiwan for trial because he feared that Chen might go to mainland China through the arrangement of Chen's friend "White Wolf" Chang An-lo.
He said that he met with Chen at the home of a "common friend" in Phnom Penh and talked from noon till midnight.
Chen was quoted as saying that he "will certainly come back to Taiwan" when his health, hurt by a recent stroke in prison, becomes more stable and after his financial matters are handled.
However, when asked when Chen will return to Taiwan, Lin replied that "the time is not ripe yet."

Chen reportedly expressed his hope that the Republic of China Ministry of Foreign Affairs will issue him documents allowing him to enter Taiwan, and added that he is willing to be investigated in Taiwan.
Chen is wanted on criminal charges in Taiwan stemming from a crackdown against organized crime in September 1997.

He told Lin that he left Taiwan for mainland China "for medical treatment" before his name went on the wanted list and added that he later proceeded to Cambodia because he feared the information collected by related Taiwan authorities against him was "unfair."
Lin told reporters that Taiwan security authorities were aware of his travel plans before he left for Cambodia.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT EXPELS 11 PARTY DEFECTORS

TEXT.P: The opposition Kuomintang (KMT) decided Tuesday to expel 11 party members who quit the party to run on the ticket of the just-established Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) party in the year-end legislative elections.

The KMT Evaluation and Discipline Committee, meanwhile, decided to shelve a proposal that former KMT Chairman Lee Teng-hui be reprimanded for his presence at the inauguration of the TSU -- a party formed mainly by Lee's followers and supporters.

Huang Chin-teh, deputy speaker of the Taoyuan County Council, who was originally on a blacklist of 12 party members who will be dealt with for their defection to the TSU, was not expelled, as his case remained "arguable and debatable," said Chen Keng-chin, director-general of the KMT Evaluation and Discipline Committee.

Huang was later discovered to have decided to run in the December legislative elections representing the "Huang clan" in the northern county of Taoyuan, rather than on the TSU ticket, according to Chen.

As for the Lee issue, Chen said that the party's Evaluation and Discipline Committee will implement any measure that is conducive to the party's existence and development but will give second thoughts to proposals that could impair the party's interests, such as reprimanding Lee.

Chen said the committee members decided that it is improper at present for the party to move to have Lee punished. Asked when exactly the KMT will deal with Lee, Chen said "it depends on how things go."

DOC.HEADLINE: FAMILIES PAID NT$ 23 M. FOR LOSSES IN PACHANG CREEK INCIDENT

TEXT.P: The government announced Tuesday that 17 people in three families who lost their loved ones in the Pachang Creek tragedy of July 22, 2000, had been repaid a total of NT$23.64 million (US$683,632) for their losses.

The payment, made Aug. 2, was in accordance with the National Compensation Law after the government reached an agreement with members of the three families recently, said officials from the National Fire Administration under the Ministry of the Interior.

On July 22, 2000, people in Taiwan watched in horror and anxiety as live television cameras beamed images of four hapless riverbed clean-up workers huddled together in the raging Pachang Creek in the southern county of Chiayi in the midst of a flash flood.

The victims waited for over two hours as local officials bickered over who should dispatch rescue helicopters. By the time the helicopters finally arrived, they were too late, as all four had been swept to their deaths in the surging current.
The deaths triggered public uproar and shaved about 20 percentage points off newly inaugurated President Chen Shui-bian's approval rating.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI MAYOR PITCHES TO OPEN JAPANESE BASEBALL GAME

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou, wearing the Chinese Taipei baseball team uniform, threw out the first pitch Tuesday at a baseball game between the Daiei and Seibu teams at the Fukuoka Baseball Diamond.

At the same time, Ma announced that Taiwan will host the World Cup Baseball Tournament scheduled to be held in November and extended an invitation to Sadaharu Oh (Wang Chen-chih) -- the chief coach for Daiei -- to attend.

Ma, who was on the last leg of a three-city tour of Taipei's sister cities in Asia, had earlier visited a resources recycling center in the Japanese city. He spoke highly of the efficiency of the garbage recycling center.
Ma also welcomed a visit by the Wang-led Daiei nine for an exhibition game in Taipei next May.
Ma will conclude his four-day visit to Fukuoka Wednesday and return to Taipei. He has already visited Kuala Lumpur and Seoul.

DOC.HEADLINE: CETRA TO TAP FOREIGN MARKETS

TEXT.P: In order to tap foreign markets, the China External Trade Development Council (CETRA) will implement a "trade point project" to expand Taiwan's foreign trade, a CETRA official said Tuesday.

CETRA Secretary-General Huang Chih-peng presented a CETRA flag to six trade "explorers" who will tap trade opportunities in five new emerging market -- Myanmar, Pakistan, Ukraine, Iraq and Kazakhstan.

The project will consist of two-member teams equipped with notebooks, printers and digital cameras, who will visit the emerging market countries for three-month stays to collect first-hand information on trade opportunities and send regular and timely reports home to help local traders wishing to explore these markets.

The trade promotion teams are expected to call on more than 200 trade organizations, importers and exporters, chain stores and large enterprises and write 150 articles on business news during their visits.
The information sent in by the teams will be available on the CETRA Web site, the official added.

DOC.HEADLINE: NOBEL PEACE PRIZE WINNER CALLS FOR CROSS-STRAIT DIALOGUE

TEXT.P: Former Costa Rican President Oscar Arias Sanchez, a 1987 Nobel Peace Prize winner, said in Kinmen Tuesday that Taiwan and mainland China should engage in dialogue to ease the tension across the Taiwan Strait.
Arias, who was invited to attend the Aug. 15 "World Peace Forum" in Taipei, visited the offshore island with Republic of China Vice President Annette Lu.

Speaking at a lunch gathering, the Nobel laureate said that "at the start of the new century, we must discard Marxism and Leninism" and "replace war with love and peace" so as to create an everlasting peace for humankind.

Touching on the development of cross-strait relations, Arias noted that "more dialogues are required to ease the tension across the strait," and added that "the conflict should be resolved through dialogue and compromise and with a rational approach and mutual understanding."

He said that "a miracle" will emerge from bilateral dialogues and went on to say "if one side is not willing to sit down for talks, the other side should make the request again and again, with a humble and harmonious attitude."

Arias said that there are many ways to build world peace in the 21st century, but attention must be given to the genuine crises that pose a threat to the peace of the world, such as poverty, illiteracy and the worsening of the environment.
"If more than half of the world's population live in poverty, how can we survive in peace?" he asked.
The former president, who was awarded the Nobel peace prize for promoting a peace project for Central America, pointed out that peace needs support with justice.
"We must exert more effort to realize peace and pursue justice," he said, adding that leaders of all countries should educate their people to create everlasting peace with morality and love.

DOC.HEADLINE: MINIMUM WAGE FOR LABORERS SHOULD NOT BE SCRAPPED: EDAC PANEL

TEXT.P: Members of the Economic Development Advisory Conference (EDAC) agreed at a panel discussion Tuesday that the minimum wage protection for the nation's laborers should not be scrapped.

The panel also agreed that in accordance with the principle of fairness and in light of Taiwan's imminent entry into the World Trade Organization, foreign workers should also be subject to the same minimum wage protection as their local counterparts.

There have been mounting calls, especially from the enterprises which employ large numbers of foreign workers, that the foreign employees' pay be de-linked from the nation's minimum wage protection of NT$15,840 monthly as stipulated by the Labor Standard law, so as to lower their production costs and sharpen their competitive edge.
Taiwan, which employs over 300,000 foreign workers, is reported to be one of the places where foreign workers enjoy the highest degree of wage protection.
The panel, however, suggested a change in the foreign workers' wage system by deducting their board and meal costs but lowering the brokerage fees charged to the workers.

The meeting suggested that the existing 84-hour bi-weekly work hour system should not be dropped in favor of the 44-hour weekly work-hour system and that female worker's night-time work hours should be subject to the same conditions as their male counterparts.

The panel demanded that a "movable" pension system for the workers should be adopted and that workers should be allowed to decide whether to claim their pensions year by year or in a lump sum upon retirement.
Meanwhile, another EDAC panel shelved a proposal by Minister of Economic Affairs Lin Hsin-yi that the commodities tax be either dismantled of halved for certain products.

Scrapping the commodities tax, which Lin claimed is "outdated," would cost the national coffers hundreds of billions of new Taiwan dollars and would force the government to increase the business tax to make up the shortfall, said Lei Chien, a panel member.
Conclusions of the panel discussion will be forwarded to the EDAC, which will meet later this month, for further deliberation. (Bear Lee)

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, Aug. 15, or the 26th day of the sixth month of the Year of the Snake according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1057: Macbeth, King of Scotland who ascended to the throne after killing his cousin King Duncan in battle in 1040, is killed by Duncan's son Malcolm at Lumphanan, near Aberdeen. The legend of his rise to power and his reign are the basis of Shakespeare's tragedy "Macbeth."
1769: Napoleon Bonaparte, military leader and the emperor of France from 1804 to 1815, is born in Ajaccio, Corsica.
1900: The Kuang Hsu Emperor and his aunt, the Empress Dowager Tzu-hsi, flee to northwestern China from Beijing as the capital is captured by the forces of eight foreign powers during the Boxer Uprising.
1914: The 82-km-long Panama Canal, connecting the Atlantic and Pacific oceans, is opened after 35 years of construction.
1945: The Republic of China Legislative Yuan unanimously approves the United Nations Charter.
1947: India gains independence from Britain with Jawaharlal Nehru as the first prime minister.
1948: President Syngman Rhee formally proclaims South Korea as the Republic of Korea.
1949: A Southeast China Governor's Office is established in Taipei with General Chen Cheng as governor.
1959: The ROC Army receives Nike-Hercules surface-to-air missiles from the United States under a military aid program.
1960: The Council of Grand Justices of the Judicial Yuan rules that, according to Article 77 of the Constitution, courts of all levels shall be placed under the jurisdiction of the Judicial Yuan.
1960: The Republic of China recognizes the Congo (Brazzaville) Republic.
1962: The Netherlands signs a treaty agreeing to Indonesian rule of Irian Jaya (Netherlands New Guinea).
1967: Kung Hsiang-hsi, former ROC premier and finance minister, dies in the United States at the age of 88.
1974: South Korean President Park Chung Hee's wife is shot dead by an assassin in an attempt on Park's life.
1974: The Seventh Asian Youth Camp holds its opening ceremony in Taipei.
1976: Premier Chiang Ching-kuo urges college students to contribute their wisdom and energy to the country as he presides over the closing ceremony of the summer vacation military training program of college students at the Cheng-kung base in Taichung.
1979: Direct dialing service to the United States, Hong Kong and Singapore is initiated by the Taiwan Telecommunications Administration.
1980: The wreckage of the Titanic, the British luxury liner which sank after hitting an iceberg during its maiden voyage to New York on April 14, 1912, is found laying on the ocean floor 3,657 meters below the surface of the Atlantic Ocean.
1981: The First ROC-Indian Cultural and Economic Seminar on India's 34th Independence Day is held in Taipei.
1981: The Republic of China and Saint Vincent establish formal diplomatic relations.
1985: Premier Yu Kuo-hwa accepts the resignation of Finance Minister Loh Jen-kong.
1986: Premier Yu Kuo-hwa, in an interview with Saudi Arabian journalists from the Okaz Daily and Al-Bilad Daily, points out that the achievements of the ROC over the past thirty-some years has won the nation international recognition and made it an indispensable force against communist expansion in the Asia-Pacific region.
1990: President Mikhail Gorbachev restores Soviet citizenship to Nobel Prize-winning author Alexander Solshenitsyn, who was exiled to the West in 1974 for his novels attacking Stalinism.
1995: The Chinese mainland begins eleven days of tactical guided missile exercises by firing live artillery shells into the sea 136 kilometers north of Taiwan.
1999: Chiao Jen-ho, chairman of the Cabinet-level Overseas Chinese Commission, donates US$100,000 and 20 computers to the Chinese Benevolent Federation in San Francisco.
2000: The Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture announces that beef imports from Argentina and Paraguay will be temporarily banned due to an outbreak of foot-and-mouth disease in the two South American countries.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "He who acquires truth is one who finds out what is good and holds fast to it."

DOC.HEADLINE: GOV'T DETERMINED TO RECTIFY FINANCIAL INSTITUTIONS: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Premier Chang Chun-hsiung on Wednesday reiterated the government's determination in setting faltering local-level financial institutions right.

Rectifying and reorganizing local-level financial institutions is one of the most critical and important parts of the financial reforms program that the government has pushed to accomplish, Chang noted.

Personnel from an ad hoc task force organized by the Monetary Reconstruction Fund under the Executive Yuan have been assigned to 36 faltering financial institutions islandwide since Monday, formally putting those banks, mostly farmer's and fishermen's cooperatives, under government supervision.

Chang called for relevant officials from the Ministry of Finance, the Council of Agriculture and the Central Bank of China -- the executive agencies in charge of the reforms -- to be careful and fair, but also determined when carrying out the task of straightening out the local-level financial institutions.

The task is designed to root out illegal credit loans, embezzlement, the siphoning off of public funds, the exchanging of vested interests, and other irregularities that have been depleting the country's financial strength, he added.

Those sent to supervise the faltering financial institutions, temporarily transferred from the Bank of Taiwan, the Land Bank of Taiwan, the Taiwan Cooperative Bank and the Farmer's Bank of China, will check on their assigned institution's cash deposit status as well as its credit accounts.

The institutions with negative net assets include 27 credit departments of farmer's associations, two credit departments of fishermen's associations and seven credit cooperatives, mostly in rural or coastal areas of central and southern Taiwan.

The task force will supervise the operations of these badly performing banks over the next three months and help them find merger possibilities, according to officials from the Monetary Reconstruction Fund.

Immediately after the stationing of the task force personnel, 14 farmer's and fishermen's cooperatives agreed to hand over the management of their credit departments. These departments are likely to be merged with public banks in the future, the officials said.

The Monetary Reconstruction Fund was set up in July of this year to help redress the financial problems of Taiwan's financial institutions. The task force will evaluate the status of the problem institutions and whether the fund can entrust the Central Deposit Insurance Corp. with the task of managing the debts and assets of these organizations, the officials said.

Meanwhile, Finance Minister Yen Ching-chang said task force personnel will be dispatched to any of the 326 other financial institutions islandwide which are currently operating normally if any irregularities are reported at any one of them in the future.

DOC.HEADLINE: POLL FINDS KMT MOST LIKELY TO BE HURT BY ESTABLISHMENT OF TSU

TEXT.P: The establishment of the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) is most likely to hurt the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) in the year-end legislative elections, according to the results of an opinion poll released Wednesday.

The telephone poll of 1,074 adult residents randomly selected from around the island, conducted by the local magazine "Open" from Aug. 10-11, found that 33.1 percent of those interviewed said they think that the TSU's inauguration will be most harmful to the KMT.

Meanwhile, 14 percent of the respondents said they believe that the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) will suffer the most as a result of the establishment of the TSU, and 4.9 percent said the People First Party (PFP) will be hurt the most, while 4.1 percent said they think that all the major domestic political parties will be affected by the TSU's birth.
In contrast, 3.6 percent said they don't think that the TSU's arrival will hurt any of local political parties.

The survey results also showed that 26.4 percent support the proposal that the KMT and its two splinter groups -- the People First Party (PFP) and the New Party (NP) -- cooperate in the year-end legislative elections. The three parties are generally believed to share common views or stance on the development of relations across the Taiwan Strait.

In comparison, only 16.2 percent threw their support behind the proposal that the DPP and the TSU, which was formally inaugurated Aug. 12 with the blessing of former President Lee Teng-hui, cooperate in the year-end elections. Both the DPP and the TSU have placed more emphasis on Taiwan's separate identity and well-being.
But 19.3 percent said they would not like to see any inter-party cooperation.

Asked which domestic politician is most capable of cultivating a personal following, 22.3 percent said PFP Chairman James Soong, 12 percent mentioned President Chen Shui-bian and 6.5 percent cited KMT Chairman Lien Chan.

DOC.HEADLINE: THEATER DEFENSE COULD LEAD CHINA TO SOVIET-STYLE COLLAPSE: EXPERT

TEXT.P: A renowned U.S. China expert has pointed out that if the United States goes ahead with plans to build a theater missile defense system, it may push mainland China into a systemic crisis that could lead to the collapse of the Communist regime.

Steven Mosher, president of the Population Research Institute, said in an article in a recent issue of the Bulletin Atomic Scientists monthly that just as Ronald Reagan's strategic defense initiative pushed Soviet leaders into desperate measures that ultimately led to the collapse of the Soviet Union, U.S. President George W. Bush may push Communist China toward a similar fate by constructing a theater missile defense.

President Bush's theater missile defense would "do more than just protect the free world from attacks by rogue nations like Iraq, Libya and China. This new defensive system, to be developed with Germany, Italy, Japan and Israel, would put tremendous pressure on Red China to evolve into a free market democracy or die," said the author of "Hegemony: China's Plan to Dominate Asia and the World"

In the article, Mosher was quoted as saying that building a theater missile defense "would eventually break the back of Beijing's military budget" and might help Communist China "go the way of the former Soviet Union."

He noted that "China's main strategic objective is to stealthily build up a conventional and nuclear weapons force that is able to intimidate Taiwan and defeat U.S. forces in Asia, while avoiding an all-out arms race with the United States."

"By upping the ante with missile defense, Bush is forcing the Chinese Politburo into a stark choice -- go head-to-head with the United States and run the risk of systemic collapse, or defer military competition for a generation in favor of peacefully building up China's infrastructure."

The expert on U.S.-mainland Chinese relations and military affairs said he is convinced that the "odds are that Beijing will choose plowshares over swords. In buying time for ourselves, we buy time for China's democracy movement."

"The Bush administration must be praised for its firm commitment to missile defense today. Twenty years from now, when Chinese hegemony has ceased being a threat to Asia, Americans will liken this peaceful initiative to Reagan's Cold War victory over the former Soviet Union," Mosher concluded.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Shares prices opened high and closed even higher on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) on Wednesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 33.51 points to close at 4,623.11.

The bourse opened at 4,593.65 and continued to go up due to the good performance of both electronics shares and communications stocks. The bourse fluctuated between 4,665.37 and 4,581.64 during trading.

A total of 2.55 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$64.52 billion (US$1.87 billion), an increase from the previous trading session which saw 1.95 billion stocks change hands on a market turnover of NT$45.29 billion (US$1.13 billion).

All of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with construction stocks moving up the most at 2.5 percent, followed by foodstuff shares at 2 percent, bank and insurance stocks at 1.2 percent, textile issues and cement stocks, both at 1 percent, pulp and paper issues at 0.7 percent, electrical shares at 0.5 percent, and plastics and chemical stocks at 0.3 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 410 to 102, with 81 stocks remaining unchanged.
