DOC.HEADLINE: AUTHORITIES AND ADVISORS IN AGREEMENT ON WORKERS' PENSION REFORM

TEXT.P: The Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) announced Wednesday that it agrees with a resolution Tuesday by the Economic Development Advisory Conference (EDAC) regarding a reform to the workers' pension program.

The EDAC's labor affairs panel Tuesday reached a resolution regarding retirement payments to workers in the private sector. Members of the panel suggested that a worker should have a personal pension account transferable in case of change of employment and that an employer must pay 6 percent of the employee's total monthly wage aggregate into the worker's retirement account.

In consideration of the financial burden on employers, the advisors suggested that the allocations contributed by the employers can begin at 2 percent of the employee's monthly wage and gradually increase to 6 percent.

According to the Labor Standards Law and the existing practices of the Rules for the Allocation and Management of Workers' Retirement Fund, retirees are entitled to a maximum pension equal to 45 times their average wage in the six months prior to their retirement.
The advisors suggested that retirees be given the choice of taking the whole sum of their personal pension account on the day of their retirement, or receiving regular pension payments.
A CEPD official said that the personal pension account system and a fixed rate of allocations have clearly defined the rights of employees and the obligations of employers.
He said that a solid pension program for employees in the private sector can relieve the burden on younger generations and save social welfare costs.

Chen Chu, chairman of the Council of Labor Affairs, also advocated the establishment of transferable personal pension accounts for employees in view of the fact that 90 percent of workers in the private sector retire or are laid off without payments. The proposed system can guarantee the rights and benefits of employees in the private sector, she added.

DOC.HEADLINE: ASSOCIATION OF EAST ASIAN RELATIONS GETS NEW CHAIRMAN

TEXT.P: The Association of East Asian Relations (AEAR) convened a board of directors and supervisors meeting Wednesday to formally approve the nomination of Chuang Ming-yao as its new chairman, replacing Lin Chin-ching who had served in the post since October 1996.
Chuang, 72, has served as secretary-general of the National Security Council since the inauguration of President Chen Shui-bian in May last year.
His past positions include Republic of China Navy commander-in-chief, vice defense minister, strategy advisor and national policy advisor to the president, and ROC representative to Japan.
The AEAR is a quasi-official organization established to handle substantive relations between Taiwan and Japan after the two countries broke off formal diplomatic relations in September 1972.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN URGES BEIJING TO PUT ASIDE CONFLICT AND WORK FOR PEACE

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian urged mainland Chinese leaders Wednesday to put aside conflict and faithfully work for permanent peace in the Taiwan Strait as well as for Asia-Pacific and global peace.

Chen made the call while meeting with five Nobel Peace Prize winners who have converged in Taipei to take part in a "Voice from Taiwan: Peace and Love" campaign, also known as the 2001 Global Peace Assembly, organized by Vice President Annette Lu.
Chen first extended his hearty welcome to the five Nobel laureates, saying their visit is a great encouragement to the Republic of China's efforts to pursue democracy and maintain peace.
Despite mainland China's perennial military threat, Chen said, Taiwan managed to complete its historic transition of power between different political parties in the last year of the 20th century.

"The 23 million people of Taiwan used love, hope and confidence to overcome hostility, threat and fear. They also used their sacred ballots to prove to the world their firm belief in such universal values as freedom, democracy and peace," Chen explained.

Noting that peace is a human being's highest rational pursuit, Chen said he deeply appreciates the arrival of the five Nobel Peace Prize winners to witness Taiwan's achievements in pursuing democracy and promoting peace.

Chen quoted a Buddhist scripture passage -- "Anyone who lays down the butcher knife to repent can become like Buddha" -- to urge leaders in Beijing to put aside any notions of conflict and to work for peace.
As the ROC's head of state, Chen said he must follow the common will and determination of the 23 million people of Taiwan to pursue permanent peace.

"I earnestly hope that the top leaders on the other side of the Taiwan Strait can fully understand the true meaning of `putting aside conflict to create peace' so that the people on both sides can join forces to contribute to regional and world peace," Chen stressed.

Vice President Lu, who accompanied the five Nobel laureates to meet President Chen, said she is convinced that the five guests will help send messages of peace between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait after their current visit. "They can serve as envoys for cross-strait peace," she added.

For his part, former South African President Fredrik W. de Klerk, a co-winner of the 1993 Nobel Peace Prize, said that at present, conflicts rage in several places in Asia, including Sri Lanka, India and Pakistan.
Against this backdrop, de Klerk said defusing cross-strait tensions is critical to maintaining Asia-Pacific regional peace and stability.
De Klerk said if mainland China regards Taiwan as an enemy, it should sit down and talk with Taiwan to resolve bilateral disputes.
No matter how cross-strait relations develop, de Klerk said he does not want to see the ROC become more like the People's Republic of China.
"I hope to see the PRC become more like the ROC, and I believe that this is a common expectation of the entire free world," de Klerk added.

Former Costa Rican President Oscar Arias Sanchez, the 1987 Nobel Peace Prize winner, said that cross-strait disputes should be resolved through peaceful means and that resorting to the use of force should be condemned.

The three other Nobel laureates -- former Polish President Lech Walesa, anti-landmine activist Jody Williams, and Joseph Rotblat, an anti-nuclear expert -- also expressed their hope that the stalled cross-strait dialogue can be resumed quickly and that all cross-strait issues can be resolved peacefully.
The two-day "Peace and Love" campaign will close Thursday.

DOC.HEADLINE: ONE-SIXTH OF TAIWAN LISTED COMPANIES PLAN TO LAY OFF WORKERS

TEXT.P: The global economic recession has brought a chilly winter to employees of Taiwan businesses, with even those working for companies listed on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TSE) worrying about their job security.

The results of a survey conducted by the Chinese-language Business Weekly among TSE listed companies scheduled to be released on Thursday indicates that one sixth of those companies polled will lay off personnel as part of their belt-tightening measures.

The business magazine recently sent questionnaires to 794 listed companies and received 354 replies. Among the respondents, 72.9 percent said they have adopted such cost-saving measures to counter the effects of Taiwan's sluggish economy.

While reducing personnel expenses is an important cost-saving measure that has been adopted by many companies, 32.7 percent of the respondents said they have frozen the number of employees on the payroll, 16.6 percent have laid off personnel, and 11.5 percent have applied early retirement measures.

The survey report also showed that the most probable targets of company layoff programs are those aged over 50, those who have worked with a company for more than 20 years, and those who hold middle-level positions.
Employees with professional skills, a good working attitude, foreign language abilities, and a spirit of teamwork are more secure from losing their jobs, according to the survey.

Nearly 60 percent of the respondents said that they have no plans to hire additional personnel even when Taiwan's economic prospects make a turn for the better. For new recruitment plans, priorities will be given to sales personnel and technical workers.
The survey was conducted in early August. In addition to questionnaires, the magazine also conducted telephone interviews with executives of the surveyed companies.

DOC.HEADLINE: TRUST ABSENT IN CROSS-STRAIT RELATIONSHIP: ADVISOR

TEXT.P: Despite the fact that Taiwan and mainland China have both benefited from their economic and trade exchanges over the past several years, mutual trust has been absent in their relationship, a presidential adviser said Wednesday.

Hsiao Hsin-huang, a presidential adviser and a fellow researcher at Academia Sinica, said that while the economies of Taiwan and mainland China have become increasingly integrated, contradictions between the two sides persist in the political and military arenas.

This discordance was actually present in the relationship between East and West Germany before German unification, and it can been seen in the present relationship between North and South Korea, Hsiao pointed out.

Although Taiwan and mainland China share a common ancestry as well as the same culture and language, the two sides are far apart socially, politically and economically, he said, adding that Taiwan strove for more than two decades to attain its economic achievements and that it will take mainland China almost the same amount of time to do the same.

Hsiao suggested that the leadership on both sides of the Taiwan Strait should focus their attention on dealing with their respective domestic problems rather than wasting time and energy on cross-strait wrangling.
Cross-strait political disputes or discrepancies should not be put at the top of the priority list and should instead be left to the next generation to address, he continued.
Hsiao made the remarks while attending the first round-table discussion, which focused exclusively on cross-strait relations, at the 2001 World Peace Forum initiated by Vice President Annette Lu.

Wu Rong-yi, president of the private economics think-tank the Taiwan Institute of Economic Research, who also spoke at the round-table discussion, said Taiwan's "be patient, no haste" policy toward mainland China is strategically correct.

Taiwan should come up with effective measures to address related issues at a time when Taiwan's economic dependence on mainland China has become increasingly strong and when Beijing has not renounced the use of force against the island to settle disputes, Wu added.

Lin Chong-pin, vice chairman of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), Taiwan's top government agency in charge of policies regarding mainland China, said Beijing's consistent military threats and rhetoric toward Taiwan have basically remained unchanged since President Chen Shui-bian took office in May 2000.

For its part, the MAC has tried over the past year to uphold its stance of maintaining "useful and constructive relations" with mainland China while avoiding making remarks that might provoke Beijing, Lin added.

Meanwhile, Vice Defense Minister Chen Pi-chao warned that mainland China, with the continuing build-up of its military and the upgrading of its strategic applications, may gain the upper hand over Taiwan militarily in the foreseeable future
Mainland China's military upgrading includes increases in the defense budget, new purchases of advanced weaponry from the Russian Federation, and the promotion of younger officers.

Ridiculing Beijing's description of itself as the "peace seeker" while it simultaneously increases its military budget at a rate of 17 percent annually, Chen said mainland China has become the world's major arms supplying country since the Soviet Union disintegrated.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT URGES BEIJING TO RESPOND TO ROC OLIVE BRANCH

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian urged mainland China Wednesday to make a positive response to the Republic of China's olive branch by resuming the long-stalled dialogue between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.

Chen made the pitch in a written message read at the opening of a two-day "World Peace Forum," part of the 2001 Global Peace Assembly, also known as the "Voice from Taiwan: Peace and Love," activities, organized by Vice President Annette Lu.
In his message, Chen said his administration has continued to promote cross-strait exchanges with goodwill ever since its inauguration more than a year ago.

"We look forward to seeing the Beijing authorities respond to our olive branch and resume regular cross-strait dialogue in order to forge a mutually beneficial cooperative relationship and lay a solid foundation for eternal cross-strait peace," Chen said.
Noting that mankind has endured two world wars and numerous regional and civil wars in the 20th century, Chen noted that war brings only death, calamity and remorse.

"As a result, peace has become a common goal and a universal value. And history has proven that only love and respect can achieve peace. All humans should learn a lesson from previous wars and work together to avert war and create peace," the president stressed.
He went on to say that although the Cold War has become history along with the 20th century, crises of civil wars and regional conflicts still lurk in many areas around the globe.

"For instance, the Taiwan Strait has become a potential factor affecting regional peace and world security due to a lack of constructive communications between the two sides of the strait," Chen said, adding that he hopes cross-strait relations can improve as soon as possible for the sake of mutual benefits and regional stability.

Vice President Lu, former South African President Fredrik W. de Klerk and former Polish President Lech Walesa delivered speeches at the opening ceremony. Both de Klerk and Walesa are Nobel Peace Prize winners.

Three other Nobel Peace Prize laureates -- former Costa Rican President Oscar Arias Sanchez, Jody Williams, a U.S. anti-landmine activist, and Joseph Rotblat, a British nuclear scientist who advocates the elimination of nuclear arms around the world -- also attended the ceremony.
The participants further included scores of heads of international NGOs and legislators from the United States, Holland, Japan, South Korea, Thailand and the Philippines.

Several ROC government officials and scholars, including Mainland Affairs Council Vice Chairman Lin Chong-pin and Vice Minister of National Defense Chen Pi-chao, presented papers on cross-strait relations for discussion at the forum.
The forum focused its discussions Wednesday on relations across the Taiwan Strait as well as Asia-Pacific security and stability and the experience of war and peace.

An outdoor concert, titled "An Evening for Global Peace," was scheduled to be held later in the evening in the square in front of Taipei's Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall, where Lu and the five Nobel laureates were to jointly inaugurate a "Terrestrial Globe of Peace" in commemoration of the end of World War II 56 years ago.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP ESTABLISHES TAIWAN-JAPAN GOODWILL ASSOCIATION

TEXT.P: Taiwan's ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) formally established the Taiwan-Japan Goodwill Association Wednesday to further bolster bilateral ties between the two countries.

Addressing a ceremony marking the association's founding, DPP Chairman Frank Hsieh said the Taiwan-Japan Goodwill Association has vowed to break diplomatic restrictions to help cement substantive bilateral exchanges between Taiwan and Japan based on a "win-win" approach.

Hsieh noted that private bilateral exchanges between Taiwan and Japan, two neighboring countries located only 116 km apart, have never declined since the two countries severed formal diplomatic relations in 1972.
On the contrary, he went on, business and tourism exchanges have increased by leaps and bounds over the years.

The absence of formal ties between the two sides has meant that exchanges have had to be taken care of by non-governmental groups, including city and county councils or sub-groups of political parties, such as the new association, Hsieh added.

Presidential Secretary General Yu Shyi-kun, on behalf of President Chen Shui-bian, turned up at the ceremony to congratulate Hsieh -- who will serve as chairman of the association -- over the founding of the association.

Speaking at the inaugural ceremony, Yu said Japan is Taiwan's largest source of import trade and vice versa and that both countries are widely considered as the two most democratic nations in the region -- all factors indicating that the two countries have maintained close long-term ties despite the absence of formal diplomatic relations.

Also on hand to celebrate the association's establishment were Vice Foreign Affairs Minister Chiu Jong-nan; Lin Chin-chin, president of the Association of East Asian Relations; and Shintaro Yamashita, director-general of the Interchange Association of Japan.

DOC.HEADLINE: IA INDUSTRY FORECAST TO CONTINUE GROWING

TEXT.P: Despite a global economic downturn, Taiwan's information application (IA) industry is expected to continue growing in the coming years, according to forecasts made public Wednesday by the Market Information Center (MIC) under the Institute for Information Industry (III).

In 2000, Taiwan produced 5.97 million units of thin client computers, smart handheld devices and NetTVs -- the country's three major IA products -- and the number is expected to climb to 8.6 million and 11.4 million in 2001 and 2002, an increase of 44.1 percent and 32.5 percent, respectively, according to MIC statistics.

With the statistics broken down further, output units of thin client computers will increase from 598,000 units in 2000 to 728,000 units this year, while the number of handheld devices and NetTVs will grow to 2.27 million units and 5.61 million units, up from 1.21 million and 4.15 million, respectively.

In terms of production value, the combined figure of the three kinds of products totaled US$1.24 billion last year and is forecast to rise to US$1.81 billion and US$2.31 billion in 2001 and 2002, respectively, representing growth of 46 percent and 27.5 percent for the two years.

An MIC official suggested that Taiwan should integrate the "five C's" -- consumers, communications, computers, contents, control-technology -- to explore Internet-related application markets such as the automobile, aviation and construction industries, in line with comprehensive distribution networks and after-sales services.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW TAIWAN DOLLAR GAINS GROUND ON WEAKER U.S. DOLLAR

TEXT.P: The new Taiwan dollar rose NT$0.012 against the U.S. dollar Wednesday on the Taipei foreign exchange market, closing at 34.57.
The local currency opened at 34.561 and was traded between a high of 34.524 and the day's low of 34.57.
Interbank transactions in U.S. dollar totaled US$755 million.
Market dealers attributed the rise of the local unit to a weaker U.S. dollar in recent days and forecast that the NT dollar will continue to hover around the 34.5 level.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2001 TAIWAN-HONG KONG TRADE FORUM OPENS

TEXT.P: The 2001 Taiwan-Hong Kong Trade and Economic Forum opened here Wednesday with more than 300 representatives of the Hong Kong and Taiwan business communities taking part.

Taipei World Trade Center Chairman Shea Jia-dong, National Chiao Tung University President Chang Chun-yen and National Tsinghua University President Liu Hui-lang and various Hong Kong officials were among the participants.
Discussions during the forum centered on trade and technology development and cooperation between Taiwan and Hong Kong.

The organizers said they sponsored the forum with an aim of injecting a new lease of energy into bilateral exchanges in the face of increased globalization, regional bloc trade and the imminent entry of Taiwan and mainland China into the World Trade Organization.

Two-way Taiwan-Hong Kong trade totaled US$32.8 billion last year, with Hong Kong ranking as Taiwan's third-largest trade partner and its second-largest export market, according to Taiwan customs statistics. At the same time, bilateral investment capital grew from US$30 million in the 1980s to US$5.8 million as of the end of 2000, the statistics show.

DOC.HEADLINE: EX-RCA WORKERS DEMONSTRATE AT SITE OF WORLD PEACE FORUM

TEXT.P: Scores of former RCA Taiwan workers demonstrated at the site of a global peace forum Wednesday, urging the participants in the conference to help them resolve an alleged occupational disaster dispute.

The former RCA Taiwan employees wore headbands and chanted slogans: "We want world peace and labor safety; no war; no occupational disasters; and no occupational injuries" in front of the hotel where an opening ceremony for the "World Peace Forum" was being held.

The demonstrators claimed that water and soil pollution at the now-defunct RCA plant in the northern Taiwan county of Taoyuan is responsible for 1,375 cases of cancer and 216 deaths among former RCA Taiwan employees.

The petitioners likened environmental pollution and occupational disasters to "invisible mass homicide." They urged Republic of China Vice President Annette Lu, organizer of the peace forum, and the five Nobel Peace Prize winners and several American congressmen who were attending the forum, to help push RCA's U.S. parent company to send officials to handle their compensation claims.

RCA first set up production lines in Taoyuan in 1970 to produce television sets and other electronic home appliances. After the plant's closure in 1991, it was disclosed that a well had been dug at the factory for the underground dumping of toxic by-products.

The soil and underground water used by RCA employees was later confirmed to be heavily contaminated by trichloroethylene and tetrachloroethylene. A government report indicated that the solvents greatly heightened the risk of cancer in the neighborhood of the plant.
The World Peace Forum is part of the 2001 Global Peace Assembly, also known as the "Voice from Taiwan: Peace and Love" activities organized by Lu.

Five Nobel laureates -- former South African President Fredrik W. de Klerk, former Polish President Lech Walesa, former Costa Rican President Oscar Arias Sanchez, Jody Williams, a U.S. anti-landmine activist, and Joseph Rotblat, a British nuclear scientist who advocates the elimination of nuclear arms around the world -- are attending the two-day activities.
The participants also include scores of heads of international NGOs and legislators from the United States, Holland, Japan, South Korea, Thailand and the Philippines.

An outdoor concert titled "An Evening for Global Peace," was scheduled to be held later in the evening in the square in front of Taipei's Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall, where Lu and the five Nobel laureates were to jointly inaugurate a "Terrestrial Globe of Peace" in commemoration of the end of World War II 56 years ago.

DOC.HEADLINE: NOBEL PEACE LAUREATE CALLS FOR NUCLEAR WEAPONS BAN

TEXT.P: 1995 Nobel Peace Prize laureate Joseph Rotblat called Wednesday on the nations of the world to ban nuclear weapons and instead devote themselves to world peace.

The British scientist who advocates the elimination of nuclear arms made the call at seminar titled "Experience of War and Peace" held at a Taipei hotel. The seminar was part of the two-day "Voice from Taipei: Peace and Love" campaign initiated by Republic of China Vice President Annette Lu.
Rotblat said that the nuclear arms race between the United States and the Soviet Union during the Cold War period had nearly destroyed the earth and terminated mankind.
Today, the nuclear crisis has eased somewhat following the end of the Cold War, Rotblat said, adding that it has not actually ended as there are still thousands of nuclear bombs in the world.
He said that he is now launching a campaign to urge the countries of the world to sign a treaty by which nuclear would be made illegal.

Echoing Rotblat's call, Association of World Citizens Chairman Douglas Mattern said at the seminar that the world as a whole pours US$800 billion into military spending every year and that over 3,000 nuclear warheads are held by the so-called "nuclear club" countries.
With such a large amount of money being spent on military buildup, only a limited "leftover" budget can be used for humanitarian relief work, he added.

Jody Williams, the 1997 Nobel Prize winner and anti-land mine activist from the United States, called for persistent efforts for peace, saying that the greatest possible efforts by everybody can change the world.

Varahagiri Mohini Giri, former chairman of India's Women's Rights Association said that waiting itself will not end war, and she added that the both sides of the Taiwan Strait should try to reduce hostility toward each other through dialogue and cultural exchanges.
Some 80 prominent international figures, including five Nobel Prize winners and NGOs delegates from around the countries are taking part in the campaign.

An outdoor concert titled "an Evening for Global Peace," will be held in the evening in the square in front of Taipei's Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall, where Lu and the Nobel laureates will jointly inaugurate a "Terrestrial Globe of Peace," in commemoration of the end of World War II 56 years ago.

DOC.HEADLINE: GROUP STAGES SIT-IN PROTEST ON KOIZUMI'S WAR SHRINE VISIT

TEXT.P: The China Reunification Alliance (CRA), a local organization promoting the reunification of China, staged a sit-in protest Wednesday in front of the Japan Interchange Association's Taipei Office against Japanese Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi's visit to the Yasukuni War Shrine.

The protesters said that Taiwan was a victim of Japanese militarism, and after marching from the Japan Interchange Office to the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall, they asked Republic of China Vice President Annette Lu to "say no" to the Japanese government at the 2001 Global Peace Assemble she has initiated.
Koizumi's war shrine visit sparked criticism and fierce protests from neighboring Asian countries and 20 South Koreans even chopped off the tips of their little fingers in a public protest.
Legislator Hsieh Chi-ta of the opposition New Party (NP), who took part in the sit-in, called on the people of Taiwan to boycott Japanese products.

Referring to Japan's war criminals, many of whom are honored at the Yasukuni shrine, Hsieh said that "the hatred can be forgiven but can absolutely not be forgotten" because history should never be forgotten.

She also criticized the President Chen Shui-bian Administration for its "weak response" to Koizumi's visit to the shrine and claimed that the people of Taiwan have already forgotten that the Japanese imperial army killed 35 million Chinese civilians and 3.5 million Chinese soldiers during the eight-year Sino-Japanese War.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN, VIETNAM TO ENHANCE ECONOMIC EXCHANGES

TEXT.P: Taiwan and Vietnam reached several agreements on strengthening bilateral economic exchanges at the third ROC-Vietnam ministerial economic and trade consultation conference which was held in Vietnam Aug. 13-14.
According to information from Vietnam, delegations from Taiwan and Vietnam discussed industry, investment and trade at the two-day meeting.
The Vietnamese side asked the ROC Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) to encourage more Taiwan businessmen to invest in Vietnam and help the realization of already promised investment projects.

Regarding complaints that some Taiwan businessmen have encountered trouble caused by language and judicial barriers, the Vietnamese side agreed to set up a special committee of cross-agency specialists to help resolve their problems.
The Vietnamese side also agreed to consider correcting the "unreasonable" ratio set for foreign businessmen in Vietnam to turn their products for export.
The Taiwan side suggested that the Vietnamese bicycle manufacturing industry could learn from Taiwan's experience in developing its bicycle industry.
It also urged the Vietnamese side to sign a ROC-Vietnam trade agreement and to amend out-dated and ambiguous articles in the Labor Law.
The Vietnamese side asked Taiwan to lift restrictions on imports of agricultural products, beer and rice liquor.
The 100-member ROC delegation to the conference was headed by Minister of Economic Affairs Lin Hsi-yi.

Its members were from the MOEA, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, the Ministry of Finance, the Council of Agriculture and the National Science Council, as well as several state-run and private enterprises.
Lin was scheduled to return to Taipei Wednesday, while Vice Minister of Economic Affairs Chen Ruey-long was slated to proceed to Ho Chi Minh City and other Vietnamese cities.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. HOUSE DELEGATION TO VISIT TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Henry Hyde, chairman of the U.S. House International Relations Committee, will lead a congressional delegation to Taiwan next week as part of his first trip to the region since becoming chairman of the panel early this year.
During the three-day visit to Taipei, Hyde will deliver "one of his most important speeches as chairman of the International Relations Committee," according to Sam Stratman, the committee spokesman.
Stratman said the speech, to be delivered during a luncheon Aug. 24, will focus on "regional lessons learned from democratic developments in Taiwan."

He said that Hyde initiated the idea of giving the speech, a rarity in the usually tight schedule of any congressional visitor to Taipei. Hyde is not expected to make any speeches during the first two legs of what will be a three-nation trip.

The delegation was scheduled to leave Wednesday for New Zealand and travel on to Australia before arriving in Taiwan Aug. 22. Other members of the delegation include two House Democrats and three Republicans.

An Illinois Republican, Hyde is one of a handful of surviving members of Congress who took part in the drafting of the Taiwan Relations Act in 1978-79. He was first elected to the U.S. House of Representatives in 1974.
He became a household name when, as chairman of the Judiciary Committee, he presided over the House hearings on the impeachment of then-President Bill Clinton in 1998.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE PRESIDENT DISPUTES BEIJING'S CLAIMS AT GLOBAL PEACE ASSEMBLY

TEXT.P: At the opening of a forum on world peace held in Taiwan Wednesday, Vice President Annette Lu disputed Beijing's claim that Taiwan is a part of its territory.
Speaking at the opening of the Global Peace Assembly, Lu cited historical facts to debunk Beijing's claim of sovereignty over Taiwan.

The country's first female deputy head of state said Taiwan was formally made a province of Chinese territory in 1887 by Chin dynasty leaders, although it had been farmed and developed by Chinese long before that.
But Chin dynasty rule of the island stopped in 1895 when the island was ceded to Japan, which colonized the island for the next five decades until 1945, the end of World War Two.

The Republic of China (ROC) which led the Chinese to victory in the eight-year war against Japan, took over the island after the war, but the peace treaty concluded in San Francisco in 1951 between Japan and the allied states in World War II passed up, on purpose, the question of who owns Taiwan and left the ownership of the island uncertain, Lu said.
The historical background bears out the fact that the People's Republic of China (PRC), founded in 1949 in Beijing, never exercised jurisdiction over Taiwan, Lu said.

Although Beijing often insists making "commitment to one China" a prerequisite for forging diplomatic ties with foreign countries, there are still 78 states that have forged ties with Beijing without committing themselves on the issue. This fact proves countries that recognize the PRC do not necessarily acknowledge the so-called "one China" principle, she said.

The 1971 United Nations resolution which recognized the PRC as the sole legitimate ruler of China did not say who should represent Taiwan, thus giving rise to false allegations that Taiwan is part of China, Lu said.

Although Beijing tells its people that both mainland China and Taiwan are parts of China, it insists on international occasions that the PRC is the only legitimate ruler of China and that Taiwan is one of its provinces.
Beijing's differing claims at home and abroad are a ploy to annex Taiwan and downgrade it into "another Hong Kong or Macau," Lu said.
Lu said Taiwan is neither Hong Kong, nor Macau, but a sovereign state, and added that while its fate is up to the its 23 million people, Beijing seems unable to come to terms with this fact.

Lu went on to drum up support for the island's bids to join the United Nations, saying that it is unfair to exclude the state from the world organization in light of the fact that it is the world's 145th-biggest country, with the 43rd-biggest population, the seventh-biggest in terms of overseas investment and the 13rd-biggest trade nation in the world.

In an attempt to beat Beijing in its own game, Lu said the PRC, in its dispute with Taiwan, should fulfill the vow it made in the 1972 Shanghai Communique with the United State -- that it will support repressed people and nations in their struggle for freedom.
Lu said she hopes the participants in the forum, including five Nobel Peace Prize winners, will put their heads together and come up with ways for the PRC and the ROC to coexist peacefully for ever.
The Global Peace Assembly was the climax of the "Voice from Taiwan: Peace and Love" event which began Monday in Taipei and will last through Thursday.

DOC.HEADLINE: WILLIAM JONES CUP BASKETBALL TOURNEY TO OPEN IN SOUTH TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The 24th William Jones Cup International Basketball Tournament will open in Fengshan in Kaohsiung County, South Taiwan for the first time Wednesday for nine days of competition.

Kaohsiung County Magistrate Yu Cheng-hsien said Tuesday that Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian will attend the opening ceremony and throw the ball to open the game between Chinese Taipei and South Africa.
Teams representing Russia, Canada, Mongolia, the Philippines and Honduras will also take part in the championship.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN ABORIGINAL TROUPE TO PERFORM IN MEXICO

TEXT.P: The Taiwan aboriginal Chuyin Cultural And Artist Troupe will head for Mexico Thursday to perform in an international aboriginal arts festival in the Latin American country.

The Chuyin troupe, which in 1999 and 2000 performed in California and Ohio in the United States and in New Zealand, was the first Taiwanese group ever to perform before a U.S. Major League baseball season opener in 1999.

The name "Chuyin" -- the sound when pestle strikes a mortar -- is meant to remind aboriginal descendants of their ancestors in the hopes that they can appreciate their own culture, said the troupe leader, Kao Shu-chuan.
Taitung County Chief Chen Chien-nien met the Chuyin Cultural Troupe on Wednesday and offered them his best wishes regarding their upcoming performance.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT HEAD CRITICIZES GOVERNMENT'S RESPONSE TO KOIZUMI SHRINE VISIT

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan Wednesday voiced his criticism of the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP)-led government's low-profile response to Japanese Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi's visit to the Yasukuni War Shrine.
Lien expressed regret over Koizumi's visit to the shrine and stressed that the mistakes of history can be forgiven but should not be forgotten.
He made the remarks at a regular weekly meeting of the KMT's Central Standing Committee, according to KMT Spokesman Wang Chih-kang.

Lien pointed out that the KMT-led government led the Republic of China to defeat Japan in the eight-year Sino-Japanese War, upon which Taiwan was retroceded to the ROC 56 years ago. Although this brave deed might have been forgotten by many, the KMT has always showed respect and appreciation for those who sacrificed their lives for the nation during the war, Lien said.

Koizumi's visit to the Yasukuni War Shrine Monday sparked strong criticism and fierce protests from neighboring Asian countries. Lien pointed out that many convicted war criminals from World War II are enshrined at the Yasukuni War Shrine and added that these war criminals harmed millions of Chinese people and soldiers.

Wang quoted Lien as saying that the DPP-led government should try every means to make sure the younger generation does not forget history because the mistakes of history can be forgiven but should not be forgotten.

DOC.HEADLINE: EX ROC PRESIDENT TO HOLD ELECTION COURSES FOR TSU CANDIDATES

TEXT.P: Former Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui will preside Aug. 19-20 over "election campaign courses" for the candidates of the newly established Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) for the year-end election, TSU spokesman Su Chin-chiang said Wednesday.

Su said that Lee and TSU Chairman Huang Chu-wen will teach campaign practices, while Huang Hui-chen, secretary-general of the National Cultural Association, and Wu Hsiang-hui, a public relations expert, will detail election practices to the candidates and help them reach consensus on the election campaign.
Lee is described as the spiritual leader of the TSU, which was formed Aug. 12.
Tsai Tsung-chi, a TSU candidate in the December legislative election, said that more than 100 TSU members will attend the classes.

DOC.HEADLINE: SPECIALISTS DISCUSS HONG KONG-TAIWAN ECONOMIC RELATIONS
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, Aug. 15 (CNA) (By Rabbit Lam, Mandy Wong & Victor Lai)

TEXT.P: Specialists from Taiwan and Hong Kong attended the Fifth Hong Kong-Taiwan Economic and Trade Forum Wednesday to discuss the future development of bilateral economic and trade relations.
Shea Jia-dong, chairman of the Taipei World Trade Center, said that Taiwan and Hong Kong are competitors, but also cooperation partners.

Because of Hong Kong's sound financial management system and its convenient flows of capital and cargo, he said, many Taiwan enterprises have set up operational offices in Hong Kong to solicit orders from big international companies.
He added that Hong Kong has also played a very important role in the flow of cross-Taiwan Strait capital and personnel exchanges in the absence of direct links between Taiwan and mainland China.

Shea asserted that once direct trade, transportation and postal service links between Taiwan and mainland China are realized in the wake of World Trade Organization (WTO) entry for both sides, Hong Kong's role may become less important.

Therefore, for the benefit of both sides, Shea suggested that Taiwan and Hong Kong step up personnel exchanges and exchange their experiences in investing in mainland China and in exploring foreign markets.

He also suggested that both sides coordinate their resources to jointly develop the mainland market and promote the use of Hong Kong's financial, transport and trade services and Taiwan's research capability.

Meanwhile, the leader of the Hong Kong Trade Development Council said at the forum that Hong Kong's status as the region's financial center cannot be replaced by any other mainland city after the realization of the three direct links between Taiwan and the mainland.

He said that at least three functions of Hong Kong are irreplaceable in the foreseeable future -- its financial center status, the sound service system to support its foreign trade, and the efficient sea, land and air transport network.

The leader predicted a "triple win" for Taiwan, mainland China and Hong Kong in the future, as Taiwan can employ its research and development power to production in mainland China, while using Hong Kong as a service center and trading base.
Other dignitaries invited to speak at the forum included Liang Kuo-hsin, deputy director-general of the Board of Foreign Trade under Taiwan's Ministry of Economic Affairs.

DOC.HEADLINE: GIO CHIEF DENIES REPORT ABOUT CABINET RESHUFFLE

TEXT.P: Government Information Office (GIO) Director-General Su Tzen-ping denied Wednesday a report that the government might reshuffle the Cabinet after the Economic Development Advisory Conference is convened.
Asked to comment on the media speculation, Su said that he had heard nothing about a Cabinet reshuffle.
He also denied speculation that Premier Chang Chun-hsiung intends to resign.

Earlier in the day, People First Party Vice Chairman Chang Chao-hsiung claimed in a radio interview that President Chen Shui-bian might invite former Premier Vincent Siew, now a vice chairman of the opposition Kuomintang, to form a new Cabinet.
Chang's remarks drew immediate denials from Siew himself and the GIO chief.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT `EXPELS' 11 MEMBERS WHO JOINED NEWLY FOUNDED TSU

TEXT.P: The opposition Kuomintang (KMT) decided as expected Wednesday to formally "expel" 11 party members who left the party to join the newly founded Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) that will compete with the KMT in year-end legislative and county chief elections.

The party's supreme policy making body -- the Central Standing Committee -- approved a motion by the party's Evaluation and Discipline Committee to "kick out" the 11 members who publicly declared their political switch during the inauguration of the TSU Aug. 12.

The party also decided that for the time being, it would not address the issue concerning former KMT Chairman Lee Teng-hui, who is credited as being the spiritual leader of the TSU and who gave his warm blessings to the TSU in person during its Aug. 12 inauguration.
KMT authorities who paid close attention to Lee's speech on that occasion decided that Lee's words did not amount to an endorsement of the TSU's causes.

KMT Central Standing Committee member Hung Hsiu-chu, who called for Lee's expulsion for his role in forming the TSU, said afterward that she agreed with her party's decision on Lee, as any disciplinary action against him could backfire by making him into "a hero being persecuted by his own party."

However, Hung urged the party to apply its rules to all members irrespective of their positions, which means even Lee should not be spared from disciplinary action if he stumps for non-party members during the forthcoming election.
KMT Chairman Lien Chan was said to have remitted Hung's request to the discipline committee for further study.

According to reports, 12 KMT members are preparing to run on the TSU ticket, but one of them was "coerced" by "exterior factors" and was therefore exempted from the party ax, according to the Central Standing Committee.

Meanwhile, three of those expelled Wednesday brought libel actions against KMT disciplinary committee head Chen Keng-chin on the grounds that they had quit the KMT when they swore allegiance to the TSU Aug. 12 and that the KMT's decision to expel them is therefore aimed at humiliating them rather than disciplining them.
A KMT spokesman brushed aside the charges, saying the party "prefers to let the law take its course."

The TSU, organized by former Minister of the Interior Huang Chu-wen, was formally founded Aug. 12 and is expected to field 39 candidates in the year-end legislative race. The candidates on the party's ticket cover the whole gamut of Taiwan's political arena.

DOC.HEADLINE: EDAC PANEL PROPOSES 1-YEAR SUSPENSION OF STOCK TRADING TAX

TEXT.P: Members of the Economic Development Advisory Conference (EDAC) reached agreement at a panel discussion Wednesday that the government should suspend the stock transaction tax for one year in a bid to help prop up the local stock exchange.
Local share prices have nose-dived, with the weighted index halved to around 4,500 points recently from the year-earlier level.

The panel also suggested that the land value increment tax, which is levied upon land transactions, be suspended for two years in order to help stimulate the construction industry -- considered to be the driving force of traditional industries.

Chen Po-chih, chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development, said at the meeting that Taiwan's tax revenue as a percentage of its gross national product (GDP) is already the lowest among the industrialized countries and that the rate is expected to further drop to a historic low of 12 percent this year, substantially undermining the nation's competitive edge.

Meanwhile, participants of an another EDAC panel discussion agreed that the total number of foreign workers in Taiwan should be frozen at a certain level. Taiwan currently employs around 300,000 foreign laborers, mostly from Thailand, the Philippines and Indonesia.

The agreements reached at the EDAC panel meetings will be forwarded to EDAC, which is scheduled to convene later this month to further deliberate over the discussions before submitting them to the government for reference in policy-making .

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE PRESIDENT `REACHES OUT' TO BEIJING AT GLOBAL PEACE EVENING

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu urged Beijing's leaders to react in kind to the "peace-loving people of Taiwan" at a Wednesday night rally called to mark the end of World War Two.
Speaking at the Evening for Global Peace rally, staged in the plaza of Taipei's Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall, Lu said that 56 years ago to the day, Japan capitulated, formally ending World War Two.
The rally, which is a part of Lu's three-day "Voice from Taiwan: Peace and Love" campaign, was organized to mark "the people's desire that there will be no more war, bloodshed and violence."
Lu said the rally is meant to show the world that Taiwan is a peacemaker rather a troublemaker.

Noting that the desire for peace transcends national boundaries, Lu said she hopes the aspirations of the Taiwan people for peace will inspire the people of mainland China and their leaders to pursue peace across the Taiwan Strait.

Stressing that people of integrity will find companions wherever they go, Lu said the Republic of China is an "exemplary state" and will "never be isolated" in the international community despite Beijing's efforts to shut it out of international bodies.

When Lu delivered her speech, a small group of people who favor reunification with mainland China, demonstrated near the rally site. They handed out leaflets and chanted "Peace, Yes, Taiwan Independence, No," until they were persuaded by police to leave.
Five Nobel Peace Prize winners who were invited to take part the "Voice from Taiwan: Peace and Love" campaign joined Lu and some 5,000 people at the rally.

DOC.HEADLINE: `GO SLOW, BE PATIENT' POLICY TO BE ADJUSTED: ROC PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian indicated Wednesday that the "go slow, be patient" policy governing local investment in mainland China will be adjusted.
He made the remarks while speaking at a dinner in honor of several foreign dignitaries, including U.S. Congressman Ben Gilman and his wife, and former congressmen Frank Guarini and Lester Wolff.

Chen said that he proposed in his "cross-century message of Dec. 31 last year that the "go slow, be patient" policy should be replaced with "positive opening and efficient control," and added that his proposal has now been endorsed by the Cross-Strait Affairs Division of the Economic Development Advisory Conference.

However, the president stressed that before implementing the "positive opening," four principles must be enforced -- Taiwan first, global consideration, a mutually beneficial win-win situation, and sound risk management.

During the talks, Chen expressed his thanks to his visitors for their support for Taiwan's interests. The visitors were in Taiwan attending the "World Peace Forum" at the invitation of ROC Vice President Annette Lu.
Chen also reiterated his hope that he will be allowed to attend the informal leadership meeting of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation forum scheduled to be held in Shanghai in late October.
He said that if the leaders of Taiwan and the mainland can engage in talks on topics of mutual concern, it would be a big help in the security and stability across the Taiwan Strait.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies on Thursday are as follows:
The China Times:
First batch of cargoes for direct cross-strait sea-air transshipment arrive at Kaohsiung Harbor.
The United Daily News:
The EDAC's employment panel reaches consensus on easing flexible working hour scheme.
The Liberty Times:
The EDAC's financial and banking affairs panel passes a proposal to halve the land value increment taxes for two years, with a vote of 12-9.
The Taiwan Daily:
The EDAC panel passes proposals to suspend the stock transaction tax for a year, with a vote of 10-9, and to halve the land value increment taxes for two years, with a vote of 12-9.
The Central Daily News:
President Chen admonishes vice president over mainland-bound investments.
The China Post:
President Chen asks Beijing to ditch 'butcher knife.'
The Taiwan News:
Chen, Lu clash over cross-strait policy.
The Taipei Times:
President Chen hits back at his vice president.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, Aug. 16, or the 27th day of the sixth month of the Year of the Snake according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1777: Americans led by Gen. John Stark defeat the British at the Battle of Bennington during the American Revolution.
1825: Bolivia declares its independence from Spain.
1886: Ramakrishna, the Indian Hindu saint and religious educator, dies. He taught the essential unity and truth of all religions.
1909: Japanese Chutaro Kido discovers an iron mine in Anshan, Liaoning Province, located in Manchuria, where Japan has extensive economic privileges. The Southern Manchuria Railway later sets up a steel plant in Anshan.
1913: Menachem Begin, Israeli prime minister from 1977 to 1983, is born in Russia. He shared the 1978 Nobel Peace Prize with Anwar Sadat of Egypt.
1913: Lo Fu-hsing, who had participated in Dr. Sun Yat-sen's overthrow of the Ching dynasty, organizes a revolt in Tahu, Hsinchu County, against Japanese rule of Taiwan in the so-called Miaoli Incident. He was executed after the uprising failed.
1923: Lee Kuan Yew, prime minister of Singapore from 1959 to 1990, is born.
1923: Shimon Peres, Israeli prime minister from 1984 to 1986, is born in Poland.
1937: The Supreme National Defense Council decides at a meeting that the Nationalist government should authorize Chiang Kai-shek as generalisimo to lead the Republic of China Armed Forces in the War of Resistance Against Japan.
1948: George Herman Ruth, known as "Babe" Ruth, the most famous baseball player of all time, dies in New York City at the age of 53. He broke the Major League home run record in three consecutive seasons (1919-21) and then again in 1927 with a staggering 60 home runs.
1949: Margaret Mitchell, the author of "Gone with the Wind," dies after being hit by a car two days earlier. She was 49.
1950: Taiwan, formerly consisting of eight counties and nine cities, is re-divided into 16 counties and five cities.
1960: The new republic of Cyprus comes into being, with Archbishop Makarios as its first president.
1960: The Republic of China recognizes Gabon.
1968: The first Poseidon missile is launched.
1974: Wu Kuan-hsiung, secretary-general of the China External Trade Development Council, and Ahmad Sowaidi, president of the Chamber of Commerce of the State of Qatar, sign a trade cooperation memorandum.
1975: The Republic of China and Nauru sign a civil aviation agreement.
1977: Elvis Presley, the king of rock and roll, dies from heart failure at the age of 42 after collapsing in his mansion in Memphis, Tennessee.
1978: Cardinal Yu Pin dies of heart attack in Rome at the age of 77.
1979: John G. Diefenbaker, Canadian politician who served as prime minister from 1957 to 1963, dies at the age of 84. As prime minister of a Progressive Conservative government, he lost the 1963 election because of opposition to proposals to build nuclear weapons in Canada.
1990: President Saddam Hussein of Iraq warns U.S. President George Bush that thousands of the troops he sent to the Gulf will return home in coffins.
1993: The 14th National Congress of the Kuomintang opens.
1996: Leonel Fernandez becomes the 100th president of the Dominican Republic.
1999: Two Republic of China warships, the Hui Yang and the Han Yang, are decommissioned after almost 30 years of service, bringing to 10 the total number of naval vessels decommissioned by the ROC.
2000: ROC President Chen Shui-bian and his delegation take part in the inauguration of Dominican Republic President Hipolito Mejia held at the Parliament Building.
2000: ROC Premier Tang Fei unveils a proposal to transform Taiwan into a knowledge-based economy that is on par with the those of the world's most advanced nations within ten years.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "In order to acquire truth, it is necessary to obtain a wide and extensive knowledge of what has been said and done in the world; to critically inquire into it; to carefully ponder over it; to clearly sift it; and to earnestly carry it out."

DOC.HEADLINE: REUNIFICATION OF TAIWAN AND MAINLAND INEVITABLE: EXPERT

TEXT.P: A renowned American expert on Asian affairs recently wrote that the reunification of Taiwan with mainland China is inevitable but will take many years, probably decades, to occur and may not happen until Communist China's political system changes.

Michael A. McDevitt, director of the Center for Strategic Studies at the Center for Naval Analyses, wrote in the latest issue of the PacNet Newsletter, published by the Center for Strategic and International Studies' Pacific Forum, that Taiwan is on the seam between Communist China's geographic sphere of military influence on the Asian continent and the United States' military sphere of influence on the rim of East Asia.

Taiwan is far enough off-shore from mainland China to be out of reach of mainland China's military, the retired rear admiral pointed out, adding that for the last 50 years, the United States' naval power, deployed from facilities in Japan, has kept Taiwan out of Beijing's grasp.

McDevitt noted that "this is one aspect of history that is unlikely to change until Taipei and Beijing reach an understanding on how to reconcile a vibrant democracy on Taiwan and growing Chinese impatience for `reunification of the motherland.'"

Because the United States stands ready to prevent Taiwan from being militarily intimated into reunifying with the mainland, "Beijing needs to appreciate that the military option remains essentially foreclosed," he wrote.

"The only course open to Beijing is to rely on political, social and economic initiatives to make the people of Taiwan see the advantages of once and for all removing the threat of war by reaching some sort of political accommodation with China," he explained.
McDevitt said he is convinced that this will undoubtedly take a long period of time to occur and "may not transpire until China's political system changes, but it will have to happen.

"One aspect of history that is relevant to the future is the likelihood that China will continue to cling fiercely to the notion that reunification with Taiwan is the only way to make China whole," he said.

The Asian affairs expert stressed that the latest diplomatic flap between Japan and mainland China as well as South Korea about Japan's militaristic past, while important in its own right, "must not overshadow the most important geo-strategic issue for the future -- the rise of China,"
