Market turnover amounted to NT$62.61 billion (US$1.81 billion).

DOC.HEADLINE: CROSS-STRAIT JOINT-VENTURE OIL EXPLORATION PLAN REVIVED

TEXT.P: A joint-venture plan involving flagship Taiwan and mainland Chinese petroleum corporations exploring for oil in the Taiwan Strait has recently been revived after a five-year hiatus.

A draft agreement on the plan was jointly inked in 1996 by Overseas Petroleum Investment Co. (OPIC), an offshoot of Taiwan's state-run Chinese Petroleum Corp. (CPC), and the Beijing-based China National Offshore Oil Corporation (CNOOC), featuring joint oil exploration in waters located southeast of the mouth of mainland China's Zhujiang (Pearl River), CPC sources said Thursday.
Encompassing 15,400 square kilometers, the targeted area straddles the imaginary demarcation mid-line in the Taiwan Strait that has been tacitly accepted by both Taipei and Beijing for decades.

The OPIC-CNOOC cooperative project was called to a halt later in 1996 after former Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui called for the "no haste, be patient" policy to curb fast-growing Taiwan economic and business expansion into mainland China.

If everything goes smoothly, a formal pact on the OPIC-CNOOC cooperation is expected to be formally signed by the end of this year, paving the way for the two companies to launch formal exploratory drilling, probably in 2002, CPC officials said.
The cooperative project is expected to usher in a new era of cooperation between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait in exploring for and tapping oil reserves in the Taiwan Strait and other areas.

Under the initial contract, OPIC and CNOOC will each contribute US$500,000 for oil and liquefied natural gas (LNG) exploration in the targeted area, which lies 250 kilometers southwest of the southern Taiwan city of Kaohsiung and 150 kilometers south of the city of Swatow in the mainland Chinese province of Guangdong.

Experts from both sides are optimistic about the prospects of the cooperative project, saying that the targeted area is rich in oil and LNG resources. The seven fields found over the years near the mouth of the Pearl River are expected to produce about 10 million tons of petroleum per year, they added.

Before the implementation of the Taiwan's "no haste, be patient" policy, high-ranking officials from CPC and CNOOC had met many times on different occasions for seminars and workshops, tangibly for the cross-strait joint oil exploration project.

The meetings included former CPC Chairman Chang Tzu-yuan's visit to Beijing in 1995 to meet with CNOOC officials, and CNOOC President Wang Yen's visit to Taipei in 1996, as well as meetings between executive officials from both companies in Guangzhou, Singapore and the United States for talks on technical issues, according to CPC officials.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. GIVES APPROVAL TO TRANSIT REQUEST FOR PREMIER CHANG

TEXT.P: The U.S. government has given approval to a request for permission for Premier Chang Chun-hsiung to make transit stops in four American cities en route to and from the Caribbean in September.
A State Department official said that Chang's first U.S. transit stop will be in New York, where he will arrive Sept. 1 and depart Sept. 2.

En route back to Taipei, Chang will briefly stopover in Miami Sept. 8 on his way to Los Angeles where he will spend that night before heading to Honolulu the next day and then returning to Taipei Sept. 11, the official said.
Chang's U.S. transit stopovers next month will represent the first he has made since becoming premier last fall.
"We approved the request based on the criteria we've used for past transits -- safety, comfort and convenience -- while respecting the dignity of the traveler," the State Department official said.
"We understand that Mr. Chang's itinerary will be private and unofficial, consistent with the purposes of a transit," he added.
The official noted that there will be no public or media events during Chang's transit stops and that there are no plans for administration officials to meet with the premier.

He said that any further questions related to Chang's itinerary should be addressed to the government in Taiwan, adding only that the premier will be greeted during his transits in the United States en route to and from the Caribbean by Richard Bush, chairman of the American Institute in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC INTERIOR MINISTER TO ATTEND APEC WOMEN'S SUMMIT IN BEIJING

TEXT.P: Republic of China Interior Minister Chang Po-ya is scheduled to leave for Beijing next Monday to take part in a women leaders' summit under the framework of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum.

The Sixth APEC Women Leaders' Summit meeting, carrying the theme of "Challenges and Opportunities that Asian-Pacific Women are Facing Amidst Economic Globalization," is slated for Aug. 22-24 in Beijing.

Chang, to be the first ROC minister to take part in an APEC women leaders' summit, is expected to head a 20-member Taiwan delegation of women leaders from industrial, governmental and academic circles.

Noting that issues related to women's rights and welfare have gained increasing attention in the international community in recent years, Chang said she is also looking forward to meeting with officials from other APEC member countries during the summit period to exchange views on matters of mutual concern.

The Taiwan delegation to Beijing will include Lee Cher-jean, deputy director of the Government Information Office; Pauline Fu, chairwoman of the Export-Import Bank of the ROC; sociologist Chen Hsiao-hung; as well as officials from the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and the Cabinet-level Council of Labor Affairs.

Beijing authorities sent Chang an invitation to the summit Wednesday via the private economic think-tank the Taiwan Institute of Economic Research, addressing her not as "minister," but simply as "Ms. Chang."
The World Women Leaders' Summit is scheduled to be held in Mexico City next year.

DOC.HEADLINE: DIRECT CROSS-STRAIT SEA-AIR TRANSSHIPMENT SERVICES KICK OFF

TEXT.P: Direct sea-air transshipment services across the Taiwan Strait has kicked off to a smooth start, with the first installment of cargoes from mainland China being airlifted to Europe via Taiwan late Wednesday.

Airline sources said Thursday that the Republic of China's decision to expand the functions of its Kaohsiung offshore cross-strait transshipment center to cover airborne transshipment services has received positive response from manufacturers in mainland China.

The first batch of mainland cargoes to use this new channel for transshipment was shipped to the southern Taiwan port of Kaohsiung from mainland China's Xiamen via a vessel of the Taiwan-based Uniglory Marine Corp. Wednesday.
The 17 tons of cargoes, which would be airlifted to Europe and the United States in three installments, were then transported to CKS International Airport in northern Taiwan via truck.

The first installment, weighing more than two tons, was airlifted to Paris via an EVA Airways cargo plane Wednesday evening. EVA sources said before the opening of the airborne transshipment services, it took five to seven days to send goods from mainland China to Europe via the Kaohsiung offshore transshipment center.
"Now, it takes only 48 hours for the cargoes to reach Paris," said an EVA executive.
The two remaining installments of goods were airlifted to Amsterdam and New York, respectively, via EVA cargo planes Thursday.

The EVA executive said as the export destinations of mainland Chinese goods cover a wide range of areas, the newly opened cross-strait sea-air transshipment services can help enhance mainland exporters' speed and flexibility in cargo delivery.
Both Uniglory Marine and EVA Airways are affiliates of Taiwan's Evergreen Group, which operates the world's largest container shipping fleet.

The executive said as Evergreen Group has long developed a convenient sea-land-air transport network in Europe and the United States, it has managed to become the first company to offer direct cross-strait sea-air transshipment services to mainland Chinese manufacturers.

Meanwhile, the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) said Thursday it plans to further expand the functions of the Kaohsiung offshore transshipment center to include direct cross-strait air-sea transshipment services, under which mainland China-bound goods from third countries can be airlifted to Taiwan's two international airports for transport via ship from Kaohsiung Harbor to mainland ports. Nevertheless, trade sources said the demand such a type of transshipment services may not be large.

In the future, MOTC Vice Minister Ho-Chen Tan said the Kaohsiung offshore transshipment center may also be allowed to handle export processing and packaging for mainland products to be exported to third countries.
At present, mainland goods to be transshipped to third countries via Kaohsiung can neither clear customs nor enter Taiwan proper.

Ho-Chen said if the soon-to-be-convened Economic Development Advisory Conference manages to reach a conclusion on further easing cross-strait transportation services, the MOTC will revise current regulations governing the offshore transshipping center operations to accommodate the above-mentioned new services.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Shares prices opened high and closed even higher on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) on Thursday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 64.22 points to close at 4,687.33.

Despite a decline in U.S. stock prices, the bourse opened at 4,651.03 and continued to go up due to news reports of several tax-reduction proposals being adopted at an important economic development meeting. The index fluctuated between 4,710.14 and 4,632.68 during trading.

A total of 2.76 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$62.61 billion (US$1.81 billion), compared with the previous trading session which saw 2.55 billion stocks change hands on a market turnover of NT$64.52 billion (US$1.87 billion).

All of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with construction stocks moving up the most at 5.5 percent, followed by plastics and chemical shares at 4.3 percent, textile issues at 3.8 percent, pulp and paper issues at 3.3 percent, bank and insurance stocks at 3.2 percent, cement stocks at 2.8 percent, foodstuff shares at 2.6 percent, and electrical stocks at 0.2 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 463 to 80, with 53 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: FUBON GROUP TO TRANSFORM INTO FINANCIAL HOLDING COMPANY

TEXT.P: Fubon Group Vice President Tsai Ming-chung said Wednesday that the group will transform into a financial holding company and will apply to be listed on the New York Stock Exchange.

At an investors conference Wednesday afternoon, Tsai told the investors that the Fubon Group will submit the application for the transformation to the Ministry of Finance and that the transformation will take several steps to accomplish.

The five companies affiliated with the group -- Fubon Insurance Co., Fubon Commercial Bank, Fubon Securities Investment Trust Co., Fubon Life Insurance Assurance Co. and Fubon Securities Co. -- will be brought together into the financial holding company in two stages, according to Tsai.
Kung Tien-hsin, a standing member of the board of the Fubon Group, said the transformation will reinforce Fubon's sales advantages in the financial sector.

Last year, the group's business revenues amounted to NT$43 billion, of which 60 percent came from life insurance and property insurance sales, 20 percent came from banking business, and 20 percent came from securities business, he said.

Fubon Group signed a strategic alliance agreement with the Citibank Group last year. The Citibank Group has invested US$800 million in Fubon Group, making Fubon's capital value amount to US$3.3 billion.
Under the exclusive agreement, the two financial groups will cooperate in exploring insurance and banking business opportunities in Southeast Asia and mainland China.
Kung said that the two groups have jointly set up an insurance company in Hong Kong and that similar establishments will be set up in Thailand, Malaysia, South Korea and Singapore.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock index futures market were higher on Thursday, as Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index futures for September moved up 49 points to close at 4,649, with 11,838 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for October rose 20 points to finish at 4,640, with 17 contract transactions, while December futures increased 37 points to finish at 4,620, with five contracts traded.
No transactions were reported for other months.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Thursday at 4,600 for September, 4,620 for October, 4,583 for December, 4,585 for next March, and 4,551 for next June.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were generally higher.
September TE futures edged up 0.3 points to close at 237.6, with 1,856 contract transactions, while October TE futures lost 3.2 points to finish at 237.15, with nine contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for other months.
September TF futures moved up 14.4 points to finish at 598.6, with 1,720 contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: SECURITIES HOUSES IN TAIWAN SEEKING MORE MERGER POSSIBILITIES

TEXT.P: The announcement Wednesday afternoon of the merger between Yuanta Core Pacific Securities Co. and Sampo Securities Co. is being seen by Taiwan's market observers as the beginning of another wave of mergers of securities houses aimed at improving the companies' competitiveness.

At the end of last year, a series of such mergers changed the landscape of the securities business in Taiwan, and the leading securities houses have been playing even more predominant roles in the market since then.

The Yuanta Core Pacific Securities Co. is already the biggest securities house in Taiwan, taking 7.45 percent of the market share. When Sampo's 0.51 percent market share is added after the merger, other securities houses will likely find it even more difficult to challenge Yuanta Core Pacific's leading position.

According to the general manager of Yuanta Core Pacific Securities Co., Chang Li-chiu, the company has 69 posts around the island and Sampo has 14. An important task in the merger process will be to avoid any overlapping of their operations, he added.

Chang said that Yuanta Core Pacific's capital value amounts to NT$23.62 billion and its net assets total NT$45.78 billion, while Sampo's capital value amounts to NT$3.78 billion and its net assets total NT$3.89 billion.

Under the merger agreement, one Yuanta Core Pacific share will trade for 2.5 Sampo shares. The new company's capital value will amount to NT$25.13 billion and its net assets will total NT$49.67 billion.
Chang said that the Yuanta Core Pacific Co. is contacting other small securities houses to look into further merger possibilities in a bid to maintain its predominant role in the market.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S OPTOELECTRONICS INDUSTRY EXPECTED TO MAINTAIN HIGH GROWTH

TEXT.P: The Photonics Industry and Technology Development Association (PIDA) has estimated that Taiwan's optoelectronics sector's production value in 2001 will reach NT$440 billion, an increase of 31.2 percent from the level of the previous year.

The association has forecast that all six categories of optoelectronics items will attain high growth in terms of production value this year. The opto-electronic components will grow by 22.2 percent, opto-electronic displays by 56.7 percent, optical input/output devices by 13.4 percent, optical storage devices by 15.2 percent, optical fiber communications by 45.7 percent, and laser and other applications by 29.7 percent, according to the association.

The optoelectronics sector remains the sector with the highest growth in Taiwan's information industry. The growth rate is expected to slow down starting next year, with the growth rate estimated to reach only 11.6 percent for 2002 and only 11.5 percent for 2003, according to the association.

A PIDA sponsored exhibition of optoelectronics products is being held at the China External Trade Development Council's exhibition hall in Taipei. Some 200 manufacturers are presenting their new designs at the four-day "Opto Taiwan 2001" exposition from Aug. 16-19.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR UP ON TAIPEI FOREX MARKET

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar appreciated NT0.05 against the greenback on the Taipei foreign exchange market Thursday, closing at NT$34.520.
The local currency opened Thursday at NT$34.520 and was traded between NT$34.463 and NT$34.520.
Interbank U.S. dollar trading totaled US$950 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: WALESA MEETS `OLD FRIEND' FORMER DPP CHAIRMAN FOR CHAT

TEXT.P: Former Polish President Lech Walesa said Thursday in Taipei that mainland China should feel obliged to Taiwan for bringing it an inspiration for democracy and allowing both sides of the Taiwan Strait to stride into the global market of democracy.

Walesa, who is currently in Taipei mainly to take part in the 2001 Global Peace Assembly forum hosted by Vice President Annette Lu, called at the Legislative Yuan where he met with his "old friend" former Democratic Progressive Party Chairman Shih Ming-teh for a chat.

The labor union leader-turned Polish president said the cross-Taiwan Strait issue, which has gained increasing attention in the international community in recent years, should be addressed in a rational and peaceful manner as the world has entered the 21st century and it is no longer an era of wars.
Walesa said the cross-strait issue is indeed a thorny one, but he called for the leadership on both sides to "live here and now, and never look back."

For his part, Shih, a dissident-turned-politician and now an Independent legislator, again offered his appreciation to Walesa for the latter's endorsement several years ago of Shih to be nominated for the Nobel Peace Prize.
Shih gave high marks to Walesa's contributions to Poland's hard-earned democratization, calling him "the first gunshot in the disintegration of the Soviet Union."
He said Walesa is a dramatic statesman who has written history with his life and, also with his life, has helped end confrontations between the East and the West.

DOC.HEADLINE: AEROSPACE TECHNOLOGY CRITICAL TO TAIWAN: U.S. NMD PLANNER

TEXT.P: Development of aerospace technology is critical to Taiwan's well-being, a former chief architect of the U.S. national missile defense (NMD) system said in Taipei Thursday.
Charles A. Horner, a former North American Defence and U.S. Space Commander-in-Chief, made the remarks while attending an opening ceremony for the 2001 Taipei Aerospace Technology Exhibition.
Horner said he thinks that Taiwan should devote more energy to aerospace technology development in the face of mainland China's perennial military threat.

Horner, a Persian Gulf War hero, said the United States was able to easily win the 1991 Persian Gulf War, also known as Operation Desert Storm, mainly because of its successful aerospace technology development.

Horner is visiting Taiwan at the invitation of the Taiwan branch of the U.S.-based defense equipment firm Northrop Grumman. During his stay, he is scheduled to meet with Republic of China Air Force Commander-in-Chief Chen Chao-min and other relevant government officials.

As Horner used to be one of the chief planners of the U.S. NMD program, local pundits are interested in whether Horner will exchange views with top ROC military officers on the NMD project as well as on the possibility of Taiwan joining the U.S.-initiated theater missile defense (TMD) project.
In response to the question, Horner said that as he has retired from public service, he is not in a position to discuss the issue. Horner said he takes great pleasure in visiting Taiwan again.
"I like Taipei very much," he said, adding that he will meet with ROC defense ministry officials during his current visit.
As for Taiwan's aerospace technology development, Horner said quality is of the most importance. "You must make every possible effort to ensure quality in aerospace industry development," he added.

In related news, the Taiwan representative of U.S.-based Bell Helicopter Textron Inc. said that as the U.S. Army will stop supporting services for production of the UH-1H helicopter in 2004, Taiwan may have difficulties securing spare parts and related components for its fleet of UH-1H helicopters.
Bell is promoting two new types of helicopters -- the AH-1Z Super Cobra helicopter and an upgraded version of the UH-1H helicopter -- at the ongoing Taipei aerospace show.

Bell originally hoped to sell a special 412 type of helicopter to Taiwan in 1999. But the ROC Army later decided to purchase new tanks and missiles first and shelve its new helicopter procurement plan.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA IS `PRUDENTLY OPTIMISTIC' REGARDING TAIPEI-WASHINGTON TIES

TEXT.P: The Republic of China Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) remains "prudently optimistic" regarding the development of bilateral ties between Taiwan and the United States in the second half of 2001, a MOFA official said Thursday.

Stanley Kao, director general of the MOFA's Department of North American Affairs, said a great number of U.S. congressmen have paid visits to Taiwan in spate this year, particularly since midyear, indicated a warming up of substantive bilateral relations between the United States and Taiwan.
In addition to increased visits by U.S. lawmakers to Taiwan, Kao said the MOFA has maintained smooth communications channels with relevant official agencies in Washington.

During their visits in Taiwan, the U.S. lawmakers, including Sen. Joseph Biden, a Delaware Democrat and chairman of the Senate Committee on Foreign Relations, and Rep. Ben Gilman, a Republican from New York and an honorary chairman of the U.S. House of Representatives' Committee on International Relations, reiterated the United States' concern about security and stability in the Taiwan Strait, Kao added.

The lawmakers also reiterated the U.S. commitments to Taiwan stipulated by the Taiwan Relations Act, Kao said, adding that all these developments have had a positive effect on efforts to upgrade substantive relations between Taiwan and the United States.

On the heels of Biden and Gilman's visits, a 21-member delegation to be led by Texas Republican Rep. Tom DeLay, majority whip in the U.S. House of Representatives, and a 25-member delegation to be headed by Rep. Henry Hyde, an Illinois Republican and chairman of the U.S. House of Representatives Committee on International Relations, are scheduled to visit Taiwan next week.
Dyde is expected to deliver a speech of high importance to his Taiwan friends during his stay in Taipei, according to Kao.

In regard to an expectant meeting between U.S. President George W. Bush and mainland Chinese President Chiang Zemin during a summit meeting under the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation forum to be held in Shanghai in October, Kao said the MOFA would welcome such a meeting so long as such engagement activities are conducive to bolstering security and stability for the entire Asia-Pacific region.
Meanwhile, Kao said it is hoped that Taiwan's interests are not compromised when the United States conducts "engagement" interactions with mainland China.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC LEGISLATORS CONCLUDE VISIT TO SENEGAL, GAMBIA
DOC.DATELINE: Rome, Aug. 16 (CNA) (By Tony Fang & Victor Lai)

TEXT.P: Republic of China Legislative Yuan Vice President Yao Eng-chi and members of the Legislative Yuan's Foreign and Overseas Chinese Affairs Committee arrived in Rome Thursday after a visit to Senegal and the Gambia.

Yao said the visit to the two African allies of the ROC was designed to understand the work of ROC diplomatic missions and agricultural technical teams there and to study what kind of assistance Taiwan can provide for the allies.
He noted that leaders of the two countries expressed their thanks for the ROC government's aid and reaffirmed their continued support for the ROC in the international community.

Yao said that a diplomatic strategy research center supported by the Senegal Foreign Ministry will organize a regional forum at the end of October to study how to support the ROC's bid to return to the United Nations.
In Senegal, the ROC group attended a forum to exchange views on international affairs with about 30 local parliamentarians.
The group also toured rice paddies operated by the agricultural technical team from Taiwan, accompanied by Senegal's agriculture minister.

Following their Senegal visit, the legislators proceeded to the Gambia, where they held talks with Gambian government leaders and met with members of the ROC diplomatic mission and technical team there.
Yao said that from the fact-finding trip, he sees the need for further strengthening of bilateral relations between Taiwan and the two African allies.

Yao and two other members of the delegation, Fang Yang-sheng and Yen Chin-fu, were later honored at a dinner hosted by ROC representative to Italy Lin Ki-tseng and representatives of the local overseas Chinese community.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2001 TAIPEI OPTOELECTRONICS FAIR OPENS

TEXT.P: The 2001 Taipei International Opto Fair opened Thursday at the Taipei World Trade Center, with 200 optoelectronics makers participating in the fair that will run through Sunday.

The Photonics Industry and Technology Development Association, sponsor of the event, said the scale of the fair is the largest-ever of its kind, an indication that there is ample room for the future development of the local industry, despite the global economic downturn.

Optoelectronics components, optical input-output and storage devices, as well as optical fiber communications and laser applications products will be the mainstay of items displayed at the fair, the association said, pointing out that these products represent the key-point development direction for the local industry.

In 2000, Taiwan produced NT$342.6 billion-worth of optoelectronics goods. Seven categories, including CD-ROMs, laser diodes, black-and-white CIS sensors and LED packages, topped other countries in the world in terms of production value.

DOC.HEADLINE: CROSS-STRAIT DIALOGUE IN INTEREST OF BOTH SIDES: U.S. ENVOY

TEXT.P: Putting aside poltiical factors and the "one China" controversy is a "wise formula" for the two sides of the Taiwan strait to resume dialogue, the de facto U.S. ambassador to the Republic of Chian said Thursday.

Raymond Burghardt, director of the Taipei office of the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT), which represents U.S. interests in the ROC in the absence of formal diplomatic ties, made the remarks in a speech delivered at a seminar on the crises and opportunities for cross-strait peace.

Burghardt said he doesn't think that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait would face a crisis of military conflict in the next few years as the top leaders on both sides do not want to impair the current fragile peace in the strait.
Either Taian declares independence or mainalnd China takes military action againt Taiwan would destroy this fragile peace, Burghardt warned.
In his view, Burghardt said, the two sides of the Taiwan Strait need not continue their squabbling over whether they reached a consensus on the "one China" issue in 1992.

The two sides should instead ditch their "one China" dispute and sit down to discuss practical issues immediately, Burghardt said. Perhaps, he added, the two sides would come to understand before long that the most important, genuine and only consensus reached in their 1992 and 1998 meetings was that it's in the interest of both sides to engage in dialogue.

Burghardt further said the government is not the only driving force behind peace. In fact, he said, the academic, investment, trade and cultural exchanges between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait since 1988 have been the most important process to create peace.

This process has let the two sides forge a multilayer interdependent relationship, Burghardt said, adding that development of cross-strait trade and economic ties should never be stopped by either side simply for political reasons.
Burghardt went on to say that Beijing is wrong to accuse the United States of using Taiwan as an "invincible aircraft carrier" to contain mainland China.

He pointed out that the U.S. commitment to Taiwan as embodied in the Taiwan Relations Act is purely based on their long-term common values. And such common values have helped boost Taiwan's democratization over the past years, Burghardt said.

The de facto U.S. ambassador reiterated that the fundamental U.S. policy on cross-strait issues is that any dispute should be resolved strictly by peaceful means and that any solution should respect the free will of the people of Taiwan.
In addition, Burghardt said the United States has consistently encouraged the two sides of the Taiwan Strait to resume peaceful dialogue without setting any political conditions or trappings.
The seminar, part of the 2001 Global Peace Assembly activities, was chaired by Benjamin Gilman, chairman of the Committee on International Relations of the U.S. House of Representatives.
Gilman said Beijing's pressuring the international community and Taiwan to accept its claim that "Taiwan is part of China" has made mainland China a source of regional tension and crisis.
In his view, Gilman said the People's Republic of China, mainland China's official title, and the Republic of China on Taiwan enjoy equal, separate sovereignty.
Gilman said the international community must accept this fact because it is key to peace in the Taiwan Strait.
The Global Peace Assembly, also known as the "Voice from Taiwan: Peace and Love" campaign, was organized by ROC Vice President Annette Lu.

Five Nobel Peace Prize winners -- former South African President Fredrik W. de Klerk, former Polish President Lech Walesa, former Costa Rican President Oscar Arias Sanchez, Jody Williams, a U.S. anti-landmine activist, and Joseph Rotblat, a British nuclear scientist who advocates the elimination of nuclear arms around the world -- have been invited to attended the two-day activities.

The participants further included scores of heads of international NGOs and legislators from the United States, Holland, Japan, South Korea, Thailand and the Philippines. The peace campaign ended Thursday afternoon with the issue of a number of conclusions on promoting world peace.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN IS `NOT ISOLATED': VICE PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: Republic of China Vice President Annette Lu claimed Thursday that Taiwan is "no longer isolated in the world community" as its voice calling for peace is supported by many "world peace lovers."
Lu made the remarks in a speech marking the end of a series of activities dubbed the "Voice from Taiwan: Peace and Love" campaign that she initiated.

International figures including Nobel Peace Prize laureates, parliamentarians, NGO representatives and scholars gathered in Taiwan Aug. 15-16 to offer their experiences and inspiration to not only preserve peace and security across the Taiwan Strait, but also around the world.

According to Lu, the principles of "soft power" -- which she said includes democracy, human rights, high-technology, peace and love -- that she has been advocating for years have finally obtained the support of friends of Taiwan that came to the island to take part in the campaign.
The vice president said she once donated money to Jody Williams' anti-land mine organization and to India for rescue efforts, and that she has obtained support from these two sources as a result.
She went on to say that Taiwan has never brought problems to the world and has conquered poverty during the past 50 years, with its per capita income reaching US$15,000 at present.
In the two-day campaign, the participants highlighted six principles of peace-making that they said can be applied to resolving the conflict in the Taiwan Strait. They are as follows:

-- Acknowledge that problems can only be solved through negotiation: Since Taiwan has renounced the use of force, the People's Republic of China should also renounce the use of force and threat of war, while both sides should be prepared to compromise;
-- Create win-win outcomes: Both sides should abandon one-sided solutions that disregard the current reality;
-- Practice patience and never give up trying: Both sides should accept that obstacles will arise and should be creative in finding new approaches; and

-- Establish mechanisms for conducting the peace process: Both sides should invite Nobel Peace Prize winners to suggest possible methods to resume constructive dialogue and ultimately to achieve a lasting and permanent peace.

DOC.HEADLINE: ANNIVERSARY OF TIES BETWEEN ROC, ST. VINCENT MARKED
DOC.DATELINE: Panama City, Aug. 16 (CNA) (By Oscar Chung & Ed Chen)

TEXT.P: The Saint Vincent and the Grenadines parliament held a special session Thursday to mark the 20th anniversary of the establishment of diplomatic relations with the Republic of China.

ROC Ambassador to St. Vincent and the Grenadines Chiang Li-shang and newly appointed Charge D'affaires at the ROC Embassy in St. Vincent and the Grenadines Lo Tien-hong were among the dignitaries invited to attend the session.

Prime Minister Ralph Gonsalves said that both the ROC and St. Vincent and the Grenadines uphold freedom, democracy and human rights and that the marking of the 20th anniversary of the establishment of ties between the two countries has set a new milestone for the bilateral friendship.

After outlining the various assistance offered by the ROC, Gonsalves reiterated that his government will continue to support the ROC's bids for membership of international organizations and noted that preparations are in full swing for a September official visit by ROC Premier Chang Chun-hsiung.

An opposition leader also highly praised the ROC for its support of the Caribbean nation and said the opposition parties will also support the ROC's bids for membership of international organizations.

Later, Chiang hosted a cocktail reception attended by more than 200 overseas Chinese and foreign dignitaries, including Governor-General Charles J. Antrobus and former Prime Minister James F. Mitchell during which he noted that bilateral relations are very cordial and that senior officials of the two countries exchange frequent visits.
He also expressed thanks for St. Vincent and the Grenadines government for its firm support of the ROC's bids for membership of international organizations.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP SECRETARY-GENERAL QUITS NEGOTIATIONS WITH KMT ON COOPERATION

TEXT.P: Talks on cooperation between the two major opposition parties -- the Kuomintang (KMT) and the People First Party (PFP) -- took a wrong turn Thursday when PFP Secretary-General Chung Jung-chi walked away from the negotiating table.

Chung, who was charged by PFP Chairman James Soong with heading up the negotiations with the KMT on choosing joint candidates in the year-end county chief elections in 25 counties and cities, blamed the KMT for having "no intention of supporting PFP members in any county."
He also warned the KMT that it will win no more than three county halls without PFP support.

Chung accused KMT party officials of ignoring or even reneging on accords struck by its leaders with the PFP and of violating an agreed-upon gag rule by leaking to mass media false information on the unfinished negotiations.
Chung noted that he had refrained from divulging any of the results of the negotiations with KMT Secretary-General Lin Fong-cheng.
"But the KMT continues to give out misleading information, which can't but lead me to suspect that senior KMT sources are either out of touch with the talks or have ulterior motives," said Chung.

As an example, Chung noted that Lin told the mass media earlier this month that the PFP supported the KMT's choice of Legislator Lin chih-chia to run for magistrate in Taipei County, when he actually told Lin "no comment" on the KMT decision.
Chung said he made the "no comment" response after being told on the phone by Lin that KMT had no choice but to nominate Lin.
On the other hand, Chung went on, the KMT is reluctant to endorse PFP choices in Miaoli and Taitung counties, although the two aspirants preferred by the PFP have considerable chances of winning.
Saying that he is frustrated with the fruitless negotiations, Chung said he would have no further involvement, although he claimed that Soong did not blame him for the failure.
Chung urged Soong to ask somebody else to conduct the negotiations.
Meanwhile, an anonymous KMT official took Chung's announcement in his stride Thursday, saying it is not news, as Chung has threatened to withdraw from the talks many times.

In a further blow to the idea of cooperation between the opposition parties, the source also said that the KMT contact had expressed similar frustrations and had asked to be relieved of the task of negotiating with the PFP.
According to the sources, the disarray once again apparent in the opposition camps lies in the PFP's "fixation on its own narrow views," which block the chances of cooperation.
He criticized the PFP for doing exactly what it claimed the KMT had done -- releasing distorted information that gave rise to controversy.
The KMT official also blamed PFP Deputy Chairman Chang Chao-hsiung for making some "unfriendly" remarks about the KMT recently, which he said is not helpful for bilateral cooperation.
He suggested that the PFP look into Chang's background as a "supporter of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party," saying that this might have had something to do with his controversial remarks.

However, Chao Shou-po, director-general of KMT Organization Development Committee, claimed that the door to cooperation with PFP will not be closed because of Chung's dropping out of the negotiations.
Noting that their "political cooperation" is meant to win the election, Chao called on Chung not to be bothered by the ups and downs of the negotiations.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA WARNS OF NIGERIAN FRAUDSTERS

TEXT.P: The people of Taiwan should be wary of e-mail fraud perpetrated by foreigners, the Republic of China Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) warned Thursday.
MOFA officials warned Taiwan people to guard against scams that often originate in Nigeria, whereby fraudsters send out mass e-mailings in an attempt to swindle money from naive or greedy people.

According to the MOFA officials, the most recent of these e-mails to make the rounds claims that Mariam Abacha -- the wife of a disgraced former Nigerian president -- is seeking people in Taiwan to "help her get her money out of a Nigerian bank" and is promising a 20 percent commission to anyone who can help her transfer the money.

As is normal in this type of scam, the e-mail then says that the new Nigerian government is currently settling and liquidating Abacha's assets by freezing her bank deposits at home and abroad, canceling all her VIP rights and arresting her eldest son.

The e-mail then says that in order to free up the money, it must be deposited in another account in a foreign country. Anyone naive -- or greedy -- enough to fall for the scam and replies to the original e-mail receives a second message.

The messages sometimes vary, but always say, in essence, that in order to facilitate the transfer of funds, the recipient must provide a sample of his firm's headed notepaper, together with bank account information. An advance "handling fee" is sometimes also demanded. Once the fraudsters receive this, they use the notepaper and the bank information to clean out the victim's account.

The trick, known as the "419 scam" because of the relevant number in the Nigerian Criminal Code, is common and has been well-known throughout the world since the 1980s, but as of 1996, had nevertheless managed to dupe strangers out of an estimated US$5 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER ROC PRESIDENT MEETS NOBEL PEACE PRIZE LAUREATES

TEXT.P: Former Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui met Thursday with a group of Nobel Peace Prize winners and participants in a "peace campaign" being conducted in Taiwan, and exchanged views with them on world peace.

Lee and the Nobel laureates, who include former South African President F.W. de Klerk, former Polish President Lech Walesa and former Costa Rican President Oscar Arias Sanchez, as well as Association of World Citizens Chairman Douglas Mattern, were invited to breakfast by ROC Vice President Annette Lu, who initiated the series of activities dubbed "Voice from Taiwan: Peace and Love" that were held Aug. 15-16.
Lu praised the four former presidents as "history makers" and "peace promoters" who had elevated their citizen's living standards and "allowed world order to be maintained."
She emphasized that peace shall only be achieved under the premise of security, while national security depends largely on preventive diplomacy.

The vice president said it is Taiwan's honor to be able to invite such renowned world figures to attend the peace campaign and added her hope that it can contribute significantly to peace across the Taiwan Strait and around the world.

Lee said that cross-strait peace involves not only the Asia-Pacific region but also the whole world. He expressed hope that the visitors can pool their wisdom to contribute toward lasting peace in the region.

He noted that although the two sides of the Taiwan Strait opened talks in 1992, the dialogue was interrupted unilaterally by Beijing in 1995. Despite efforts by the Taiwan side, the talks still have not resumed, Lee said.
He urged Taiwan to participate in more world activities in the future to promote world peace.

For his part, Arias said that mainland China's economic reforms will be accompanied by political reforms and he urged Taiwan to have patience and wait. He also maintained that dialogue is the best way to resolve conflict and expressed hope that both sides of the Taiwan Strait can address their disputes through peaceful dialogue.

De Klerk said Taiwan is in a situation similar to that of South Africa during apartheid, when it was an international pariah. However, he went on, Taiwan should not be treated so unfairly by the world community, as its democratic, human rights and economic developments are compliant with world trends.
De Klerk also said that the cross-strait dispute can only be resolved by dialogue and negotiation.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN UNIVERSITIES TO BE ABLE TO ENLIST STUDENTS IN MAINLAND CHINA

TEXT.P: Universities in Taiwan will be able to open extension programs outside the island as early as February, according to a Ministry of Education press statement released Thursday.

The press release said that the ministry has acquiesced to local universities' demands to be allowed to offer extension programs in Southeast Asia and mainland China to Taiwan businessmen operating there.
It estimated the revision of current regulations to accommodate the overseas education programs will be ready by February at the earliest.
The extension classes opened in mainland China will cater only to Taiwan businessmen until such time as the government grants credentials to mainland Chinese schools.
It will open to mainland Chinese students only after the government has certified the academic excellence of mainland Chinese schools, said the press release.

Although Minister of Education Ovid Tzeng has said he hopes the policy of acknowledging academic credits granted by mainland Chinese schools will be confirmed by the end of the year, many local universities have jumped the gun by contacting mainland Chinese authorities in the hope of opening extension classes for Taiwan businessmen there.
Under the ministry's plan, credits earned in the extension programs will be applicable toward a bachelor or master degree.
Vice Minister of Education Lu Mu-lin said the extension programs may expand to the United States once the island is admitted to the World Trade Organization.

However, he cautioned that local universities will have to upgrade their academic levels if they want to attract foreign students or else they will be edged out of the market by more competitive rivals.

DOC.HEADLINE: GROUP PLANS TO ESTABLISH BIO-TECH PHARMACEUTICAL FIRM IN TAIWAN
DOC.DATELINE: San Francisco, Aug. 15 (CNA) (By Neil Lu & Victor Lai)

TEXT.P: Republic of China Vice Minister of Economic Affairs Yin Chi-ming confirmed in San Francisco Wednesday that an overseas Chinese group is considering establishing a large bio-tech pharmaceutical manufacturing firm in Taiwan.
However, he said that he could not disclose the name of the group or whether the investment capital will top US$400 million, as had been reported by local news media.
If the project proceeds smoothly, Yin said that the firm "will absolutely become the largest bio-tech pharmaceutical manufacturing company in Taiwan."
He said that his ministry "has considerable interest" in the project because the development of bio-tech is in line with the government's target set for the development of high-tech industries.

The official went on to say that he had already asked the group to make a sound assessment and present details of its operation plan so that the ROC government can decide how the Executive Yuan's development fund and a government-affiliated company can invest in the venture.
The overseas Chinese group was said to be hoping that Taiwan will provide capital for the bio-tech venture.
Yin came to San Francisco at the head of a delegation from Taiwan to visit opto-communications firms in Silicon Valley and to solicit foreign investment in Taiwan's high-tech industries.
Members of the delegation are from the Ministry of Economic Affairs, the Institute for Information Industry, the Industrial Technology Research Institute and the opto-communications industry.

They attended a symposium on technology related to the development of opto-communications in Silicon Valley that day and were later honored at a dinner hosted by the Yushan Scientific Technological Association of the West Coast.

Yin told those present at the dinner that Taiwan's economy is suffering a slowdown but that the island "should not be pessimistic," saying that the Executive Yuan's development fund has continued receiving new investment cases, mainly from the bio-tech field.
The delegation was scheduled to leave for New York Thursday to attend a symposium and visit IBM and other high-tech enterprises.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PRESIDENT UNDERSTANDS U.S. POSITION ON CHINA ISSUE: SENATOR
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Aug. 16 (CNA) (By Jay Chen & Victor Lai)

TEXT.P: Senator Joseph Biden, chairman of the Senate Committee on Foreign Relations, said on a television program Wednesday that Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian understands U.S. policy toward mainland China and Taiwan.

Biden, who assumed the chairmanship of the committee last June, headed a Senate mission on a visit to Taipei and Beijing early this month for talks with Chen and mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin, respectively.
Asked about the prospects for Taipei and Beijing reaching an understanding, he said: "I don't think there's any prospect of understanding in the near term, and as a final settlement."

But Biden stated that there is a clear understanding on Chen's part that "although we strongly support the Taiwan Relations Act, which means we will allow them to be in a position to defend themselves ... we do not support their independence."

He said that the policy "was settled with Richard Nixon six presidents ago," adding that although representing the "independence party" (the Democratic Progressive Party), Chen "fully understood that."
"I know he understood it. He made it extremely clear that he understood that," the senator went on.
Regarding the current cross-Taiwan Strait situation, Biden said that "there is a lessening" of the tension and added: "I don't see any immediate flashpoint."
He said that mainland China does not possess the capability to take military action against Taiwan and that Taiwan is not prepared to declare independence.
"I think things are pretty calm right now," Biden said, but noted that "it is very, very, very important to the Chinese that we recognize the `one China' policy."

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP PLEDGES SUPPORT FOR LIFTING OF CURBS ON CROSS-STRAIT TRADE

TEXT.P: The Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) caucus at the Legislative Yuan will support the easing of curbs on trade with mainland China, party whip Legislator Tsai Huang-liang said Thursday.

After being briefed by Chairman of Mainland Affairs Council Tsai Ing-wen on the consensus reached by a panel under the Economic Development Advisory Conference, Legislator Tsai said his caucus will support the panel's calls for relaxing restrictions on trade with mainland China, even though it goes against the DPP's grain to engage with Beijing and despite "noise" from within the party.
He said there is still concern among DPP lawmakers that closer trade with mainland China will deepen the hollowing out of Taiwan's industry and sharpen the economic crisis the island is suffering.
Some party lawmakers are also worried that the party's shift in stance may cost it support from its radical members, who prefer to keep mainland China at arm's length, he said.
However, the DPP will subordinate its political interests to the general welfare of the country and will throw its weight behind the conclusions reached by EDAC, he went on.

The remarks are in line with President Chen Shui-bian's announcement Tuesday that his government will phase out the "no haste, be patient" restrictions on trade with mainland China and replace it with "aggressive opening and efficient regulation."
It is Chen's idea to call on the EDAC to chart a path for the island through the present economic slump.

DOC.HEADLINE: WILLIAM JONES CUP OPENS IN KAOHSIUNG

TEXT.P: The 24th William Jones Cup International Basketball Tournament opened in Fengshan City, Kaohsiung County Thursday, with President Chen Shui-bian throwing the ball for a game between Chinese Taipei and South Africa.
Speaking before the game, Chen promised to attend every William Jones Cup tournament during his presidential tenure.
He also praised Kaohsiung County, which is the first place other than Taipei to play host to the tournament, for providing an excellent stadium for the event.
In the game itself, the host team won 100-57.
Chinese, Taipei, whose players are three centimeters higher than their South African rivals on average, were superior in skills and strategy too, leading 49-22 at the end of the first half.
There were two more games earlier in the day. In the first one, South Korea defeated Mongolia 118-70, while in the second game, Canada beat Russia 89-60.
A total of seven teams are competing in the tournament, which will last until Aug. 24.

DOC.HEADLINE: CROSS-STRAIT COOPERATION IN CONSTRUCTING AIR CARGO TERMINAL

TEXT.P: The construction of an air cargo terminal financed with investment from Taiwan and mainland China civil aviation sectors began Thursday in Xiamen, in mainland China's Fujian Province, according to local aviation officials.
The venture marks the first step in cooperation between civil aviation sectors of both sides of the Taiwan Strait.

The construction of the 39,000 square meter terminal in Xiamen International Airport will cost 224.5 million renminbi and is expected to be completed late next year. It will be able to handle 150,000 tons of cargo annually once completed.
An international air group under the Xiamen city government accounts for 51 percent of the total investment, while a group of Taiwan airlines account for the remaining 49 percent.
Taiwan's major airlines, including China Airlines, EVA Airways Corp. and Far East Air Transport Corp., are all participating in the project.

At the foundation-laying ceremony, a mainland Chinese official responsible for civil aviation affairs urged Taiwan's aviation sector to explore opportunities in eastern mainland China, which boasts 33 airports and accounts for 30 percent of the mainland's civil aviation production, to pave the way for long-discussed direct links between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT POLICY BASED ON PUBLIC OPINION: PRESIDENT CHEN

TEXT.P: The implementation of government policies should be based on public opinion and this is also the purpose behind the government's holding of the Economic Development Advisory Conference (EDAC), President Chen Shui-bian said Thursday.

The government hopes to pool the wisdom from all social sectors in a bid to forge consensus for Taiwan's future, Chen said in a speech during visits to Quanta Computer based in Taoyuan County and Powerchip Semiconductor Corporation based in the Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park.

Hailing the outstanding performance achieved by Quanta's management and staff amid the global recession, Chen said he agreed with the remarks made by Quanta Chairman Barry Lam that "in the present economic recession, we have to make greater efforts to look to the needs and demands of the consumers so as to decide the next move for devising and marketing new products."

"Managing a business may differ from running a country, but the key point to success is the same," the president said, adding that the government must pay heed to social demand while seeking to implement its policies. "An arrogant and obstinate government will eventually be phased out," he said.

Turning to the much discussed cross-Taiwan Strait trade ties, Chen said the most important issue on this front is whether Taiwan has full confidence to riding out the challenges by "surpassing self-built barriers in order to explore more splendid horizons."

In the face of fierce competition across the globe, Chen promised to rally behind Taiwan's businesses to help them upgrade and transform Taiwan's economy. He also pointed out that Taiwan should focus on developing high value-added industries in the coming knowledge-based economic era.

As Taiwan is now confronting a juncture in history, local industries should realize that they must lay a solid foundation to sharpen their competitiveness, he said, added that he is willing to "get down on his knees" for the sake of a sound development of local industries.

According to the president, many environmental experts have negatively affected local industrial development under the pretext of "environmental protection consideration." He urged all such professional experts not to negatively affect any investment projects for the sake of the nation's economic development.
Chen made the remarks after learning that an expansion project of a Taoyuan-based computer company had been delayed by environmental protection officials.

In response to the president's remarks, an official with the Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) said the expansion project was blocked because the company had illegally started construction before gaining approval of its environmental impact report.

The EPA official said the environmental assessment officials were following the regulations set by the local government in investigating the case, but he admitted that the overall environment assessment system can be improved.

As the central government has no say in such missions, which are independently run by local governments, the EPA officials said relevant government authorities are working on devising rules to serve as a framework for future environmental assessment missions.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN EASES RESTRICTIONS ON TRANSPORT LINKS WITH MAINLAND CHINA

TEXT.P: A cargo taken by ship from mainland China's Xiamen City arrived in Taiwan's southern port of Kaohsiung Thursday to be taken to the island's northern airport for transshipment overseas, marking a further easing of restrictions on cross-strait links.

The ship, loaded with 17 tons of goods from Xiamen, was unloaded at Kaohsiung in the afternoon from where the goods were transported to Chiang Kai-shek Airport for transshipment to Paris, Amsterdam and New York.

Using the new route, it takes about 36 hours for cargoes to be delivered to the above-mentioned destinations, about half of the time in comparison to the old transshipment method by which mainland goods are exported through either Shanghai, Guangzhou or Hong Kong.
The sea-air cross-strait links came one month after Taiwan's Ministry of Transportation and Communications amended regulations to expand cross-strait transportation links.

Taiwan in 1997 inaugurated limited marine links across the strait in which mainland-originating goods can be shipped to the offshore shipping center in Kaohsiung for transshipment to other parts of the world. But the goods cannot be unloaded in the island.
Meanwhile, another shipment of four tons of garments was being shipped through Taiwan on the same route, ready to be flown overseas Friday.

Wu Chin-min, president of the Evergreen Marine Corp., estimated that the cargo -- most of which will be electronic products produced by Taiwan-invested plants in Fujian -- transported through the newly opened line, will reach between 1,000 tons and 4,000 tons per month.

DOC.HEADLINE: AEROSPACE EXHIBITION OPENS IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: The Sixth Taipei Aerospace Technology Exhibition opened at the Taipei World Trade Center Exhibition Hall Thursday, with 45 aerospace companies from the Republic of China and overseas participating.

The four-day exhibition is being jointly organized by Taiwan's China External Trade Development Council (CETRA) and Singapore-based Reed Exhibition Companies. Products on display include aerospace equipment, such as aircraft, navigation equipment, airport equipment, satellites and aircraft maintenance avionics.

Fifteen domestic companies and organizations , including the Aerospace Industrial Development Corp., the Ministry of National Defense, and Chung Shan Institute of Science and Technology, are taking part in the exhibition.

The 30 foreign companies participating in the exhibition include Dassault Aviation from France, Rolls Royce from Britain, the Boeing Company and Lockheed Martin from the United States, as well as other companies from Canada, Malaysia, Spain and Thailand.
The Taipei Aerospace Technology Exhibition is scheduled to close Aug. 19.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, Aug. 17, or the 28th day of the sixth month of the Year of the Snake according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1424: The English defeat the Scots and the French at the Battle of Verneuil during the Hundred Years' War.
1743: Jack Broughton, champion bare-knuckle English fighter, publishes a set of rules to control boxing. He also introduces 10-oz (300-g) gloves, called mufflers, to protect the hands and face from bruising during training.
1786: Davy Crockett, American frontiersman and politician, is born. He was a U.S. representative from Tennessee who joined with Texan revolutionaries fighting against Mexico. He died at the siege of the Alamo in 1836.
1892: Mae West, American comedy actress and international sex symbol known for her sultry stage persona during the 1930s, is born. She wrote most of her own stage productions and film scripts.
1896: A massive influx of prospectors to the Yukon Territory of Canada is expected after the discovery of a major gold field at Bonanza Creek on the Klondike River.
1896: The first pedestrian to be killed by a car is knocked down in Croydon, England, by a car traveling at just 6.4 kilometers per hour.
1908: The world's first animated cartoon premiers in Paris.
1943: American forces under Gen. George S. Patton liberate Messina, Italy, arriving just hours ahead of Sir Bernard L. Montgomery's British Eighth Army.
1945: After the end of Japanese occupation during World War II, Indonesia declares itself a republic under the leadership of Dr. Sukarno.
1946: After ordering Chinese communist troops to start an all-out revolt against the government on Aug. 11, 1945, the communist Yenan General Headquarters issues a second mobilization order instructing all communist forces to launch a full-scale war against the Nationalists.
1960: Gabon gains independence from France.
1961: The polio vaccine developed by American researcher Albert B. Sarbin is approved for use in the United States.
1975: Europe's first particle accelerator, a device that speeds up the movement of tiny bits of matter, is formally inaugurated in Geneva, Switzerland.
1976: A strong earthquake rocks Mindanao in the Philippines, killing some 8,000 people.
1982: The Republic of China Ministry of Foreign Affairs issues a statement urging the United States to recognize Beijing's ambitious attempt to take over Taiwan, following the issue of the "Aug. 17 Joint Communique" by the United States and mainland China. The ministry also asks the United States to implement the Taiwan Relations Act.
1987: Rudolf Hess, Adolf Hitler's close friend and deputy leader of the Nazi party, commits suicide in his cell in Spandau Prison in West Berlin at the age of 93.
1988: Gen. Zia ul-Haq, Pakistan's iron-fisted ruler for the previous 11 years, dies at the age of 64 when his camouflaged C-130 Hercules plane crashes shortly after takeoff from Bahawalpur.
1989: An Australian airliner becomes the first commercial plane to fly nonstop from London to Sydney.
1993: The ROC and Australia sign two memoranda, one protecting industrial property rights and the second promoting investment and technical cooperation.
1995: A French supersonic jetliner completes a round-the-globe trip in 31 hours 27 minutes and 49 seconds, one hour and 20 minutes faster than the previous record.
1995: ROC Control Yuan President Chen Li-an announces his candidacy for the 1996 presidential election, one day before renouncing his KMT membership, which he had held for 42 years.
2000: The International Cultural and Education Foundation of Dharma Drum Mountain announces the establishment of the Dharma Drum Mountain Foundation for the Humanities and Social Sciences Prize.
2000: Panamanian President Mireya Moscoso expresses her warm welcome to Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou, who is in Panama for a two-day visit.
2000: Chen Yi-song, leader of the Agriculture Technical Mission to the Republic of the Gambia, says that ROC's agriculture technologists have transform the Gambia River basin, which used to yield nothing but peanuts, into the Ricee bowl of West Africa over a period of five years.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "It matters not what you learn, but once learning a thing, you must never give it up until you have mastered it."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN POLICE BUST CROSS-BORDER HEROIN TRAFFICKERS

TEXT.P: Police busted three cross-border narcotics traffickers Friday in Taipei, seizing four kilograms of high-grade heroin with a street value of NT$20 million (US$580,000), sources from the Ministry of Justice Investigation Bureau (MJIB) said.
The MJIB agents were able to nab the three suspects, including a Taiwan male named Hsu Chiao-hua, a male Malaysian citizen surnamed Hsiao, and a British man called Paul, after receiving a tip-off.

A police group, under the leadership of Taipei district prosecutor Chu Chao-min, was aware of the fact that the three men flew into Taipei from Thailand late Thursday loaded with heroin and then checked into two downtown hotels.

The police waited until Friday morning and then raided one of the hotels, nabbing Hsu and Hsiao. They then tracked down the British suspect and arrested him at the other hotel. Hsiao and Paul were found to be carrying 10 packages of heroin totaling four kilograms in the inner compartments of their business suitcases.

MJIB investigators believe that the three suspects were only carrying out "downstream" errands for a well-organized international drug ring which uses high pay to hire people like Hsu, Hsiao and Paul to smuggle illegal narcotics from Thailand into Taiwan.
Hsu confessed that he and other international traffickers have sneaked high-grade heroin from Thailand into Taiwan several times over the past several months.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK PRICES DOWN BY 48.97 POINTS

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) lost ground on Friday, with the benchmark weighted price index moving down 48.97 points to close at 4,638.36.
Market turnover amounted to NT$50.6 billion (US$1.47 billion).
