DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Shares prices opened high but closed lower on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) on Friday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 48.97 points to close at 4,638.36.

Encouraged by a rebound in U.S. stock prices, the bourse opened at 4,713.58 but later began to go down due to profit-taking selling pressure. The index fluctuated between 4,715.2 and 4,626.84 during trading.

A total of 2.31 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$50.6 billion (US$1.47 billion), a decrease from the previous trading session which saw 2.76 billion stocks change hands on a market turnover of NT$62.61 billion (US$1.81 billion).
Only two of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with pulp and paper issues moving up the most at 0.8 percent, followed by construction stocks at 0.2 percent.

The other major categories posted losses, with plastics and chemical stocks moving down the most at 3.3 percent, followed by textile issues and foodstuff shares, both at 2.7 percent, bank and insurance shares at 1.7 percent, cement stocks at 1.3 percent, and electrical shares at 0.8 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 332 to 185, with 74 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock index futures market were lower on Friday, as Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index futures for September moved down 19 points to close at 4,630, with 10,522 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for October lost 40 points to finish at 4,600, with 7 contracts traded. No transactions were reported for other months.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Friday at 4,649 for September, 4,640 for October, 4,620 for December, 4,634 for next March, and 4,600 for next June.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, reported mixed results.
September TE futures edged up 0.35 points to close at 237.95, with 1,753 contract transactions. No transactions were recorded for other months.
September TF futures moved down 6.8 points to finish at 591.8, with 922 contract transactions, while next March TF futures rose 5.6 points to close at 597, with only one contract traded.
No transactions were recorded for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: CEPD PUSHING AIR AND SEA TRANSSHIPMENT PLAN FOR KAOHSIUNG

TEXT.P: The Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) under the Executive Yuan is pushing with all out effort the air-sea transshipment plan for southern Taiwan's port city of Kaohsiung in order to strengthen its competitiveness.

CEPD Chairman Chen Po-chih made the remarks while explaining the air and sea transshipment plan at a seminar held in Kaohsiung on the construction and trade opportunities of a center for global planning and research.

Chen said that Taiwan, located at the center of the Asia-Pacific region, is a transport network linchpin, adding that the city of Kaohsiung has the added advantage of having an international harbor and airport.

He noted that the average navigation time between Hong Kong and the five other major harbors in the Asia-Pacific region is 64 hours, the average between Shanghai and the five other major ports is 78 hours, and that for Singapore is up to 124 hours, while the average time between Taiwan and the five major ports is only 53 hours.
In addition to the navigation time advantage, Taiwan's average flying time to seven major cities in the western Pacific is also the shortest at only two hours and 55 minutes.
Chen said that the CEPD is also planning to build a new harbor outside Kaohsiung Harbor and to upgrade Kaohsiung Harbor's efficiency in order to cut operation costs.
Furthermore, the CEPD will invest around NT$12.1 billion between 2002 and 2007 on building new roads connecting to Kaohsiung Harbor.

Chen noted that the air and sea transshipment plan will not be limited to Kaohsiung Harbor and CKS International Airport or to Kaohsiung Harbor and Kaohsiung's international airport, saying he hopes that the plan will help maintain the management competitiveness of Taiwan manufacturers as they will be able to make use of the island's sea and air transshipment service to carry out their international commercial activities.

At present, the time it takes for ships to enter and depart Kaohsiung Harbor averages 17.3 hours, down from an average of 21.5 hours in 1994, while the average time for imported cargo to clear customs at CKS International Airport is two days, down from 4.2 days in 1995.

DOC.HEADLINE: EPA HEAD DEFENDS ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACT ASSESSMENT REGULATIONS

TEXT.P: Taiwan's top environmental protection official on Friday defended Taoyuan County's environmental impact assessment regulations but also stressed that all the regulations should be universally observed without exceptions.

Commenting on the recent controversy between Taoyuan County environmental authorities and the management of Quanta Computer Inc. over an environmental impact assessment issue, which led to a strong reaction from President Chen Shui-bian on Thursday, Hau Lung-pin, administrator of the Environmental Protection Administration (EPA), said environmental protection assessment systems and executive policies should be fair, equitable and transparent, and should be observed universally.

Hau noted that Taoyuan County's environmental officials have every right to impose stricter-than-standards rules in accordance with the pollution conditions in Nankan River which flows near the plants of Quanta Computer Inc., but he also stressed that the rules should be imposed on all manufacturing companies in the county, instead of on only a few.

President Chen said Thursday that he is willing to "kneel down" for the sake of speeding up the review process for Taiwan companies seeking approval of their enivronment impact assessments for new projects, blasting some local environmental officials for becoming a "rock" on the road to development.

During a visit to companies in Taoyuan County's science-based industrial park Thursday, Chen criticized the local government for setting environmental standards that are higher than those set by the Cabinet and, as a result, causing delays in some high-technology companies' operations and expansion.

"I want to make a plea for the businesses. I can even kneel down and beg. I hope that environmental officials do not rely only on their specialized knowledge and keep dragging out the process," the president said.

The embattled Taoyuan County government, however, stressed later in the day that environmental officials have not abused their authority and that the county's evaluation standards are all in accordance with the laws.

On Friday, a spokesman for the Taoyuan environmental protection authority said to the media, which again turned up at Nankan River to see the pollution that has been caused by discharges from hi-tech manufacturing companies along the river, that he believes President Chen would not make such remarks on behalf of business if he saw the level of pollution in the river.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NOTEBOOK MAKERS READY FOR MASS PRODUCTION IN M'LAND CHINA

TEXT.P: Taiwan's notebook manufacturers are on the heels of other manufacturing industries in making investments in mainland China, and several notebook computer manufacturers will be ready to begin mass production there by the second half of next year.

Industrial sources have estimated that between 10 percent and 20 percent of the output of Taiwan notebook computer manufacturers will be made in mainland China by next year. At present, the level is about five percent.
An estimate by the consulting company Displaysearch shows that notebook production volume worldwide will reach 26.8 million sets by 2002, and Taiwan manufacturers will put out 18 million sets.

As new plants and production facilities of Taiwan notebook manufacturers on the mainland become ready to begin operations in the first quarter of next year, more deliveries are expected to be made from mainland China. Industrial sources estimate that Taiwan manufacturers will deliver between 1.8 million and 3.6 million sets of notebook computers from their mainland factories next year.

Several leading notebook manufacturers, including Compal, Arima, Inventec, Asustek, First International, Quanta, CLEVO and Twinhead are OEM suppliers of finished or semi-finished products and mother boards to such international computer giants as Dell, Compaq and Sony.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR DOWN ON TAIPEI FOREX MARKET

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar was down NT$0.021 against the greenback on the Taipei foreign exchange market Friday, closing at NT$34.541.
The local currency opened Friday at NT$34.495 and was traded between NT$34.489 and NT$34.557.
Interbank U.S. dollar trading totaled US$455 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.N. STEERING COMMITTEE TO DISCUSS ROC'S MEMBERSHIP BID SEPT. 12
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Aug. 16 (CNA) (By Eric Tseng and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The U.N. Steering Committee will meet Sept. 12 to discuss whether to include in the agenda of the next General Assembly session a request by 10 of the Republic of China's allies regarding its membership issue, U.N. sources said Thursday.

In an Aug. 8 joint letter to U.N. Secretary-General Kofi Annan, the 10 ROC diplomatic allies requested the inclusion in the agenda of the 56th General Assembly a supplementary item asking the United Nations to reconsider the abnormal situation of excluding the ROC.
The U.N. Secretariat published the letter and an explanatory memorandum attached to the letter earlier this week and has distributed all these documents to U.N. member states.

The supplementary item, titled "Need to examine the exceptional international situation pertaining to the Republic of China on Taiwan, and ensure that the fundamental right of its 23 million people to participate in the work and activities of the United Nations is fully respected," and the attached explanatory memorandum have been published in six languages -- Chinese, English, French, Russian, Spanish and Arabic.

In their joint letter to Annan, the 10 ROC allies asked the U.N. General Assembly to set up a special task force to work out measures to ensure that the voice of the 23 million people of Taiwan be heard in the United Nations and its related agencies.
They also urged the United Nations to invite ROC representatives to take part in the proposed working panel to facilitate its operations.

Moreover, the ROC allies urged the U.N. General Assembly and the international community to express more concern about the development of cross-Taiwan Strait relations and to encourage both sides to resume peaceful dialogue.
The 10 countries were Belize, Burkina Faso, Chad, Dominica, El Salvador, The Gambia, Nicaragua, Palau, Senegal and Tuvalu.

The ROC, a U.N. founding member, has been shut out of the United Nations since 1971 when the General Assembly Resolution No. 2758 gave the China seat to the People's Republic of China, mainland China's official title, at the expense of Taiwan.

This was the ninth time that ROC allies have filed such a proposal to push the U.N. General Assembly to study measures for the people of Taiwan's voice to be heard in the United Nations and its affiliated organizations.

In the past years, the ROC allies' proposal has consistently been shot down at the U.N. Steering Committee due to mainland China's opposition. The fate of this year's proposal "remains unclear." The General Assembly is scheduled to begin its general debate session Sept. 24.

The ROC government has repeatedly stressed that Taiwan's U.N. bid does not challenge the PRC's seat in the United Nations. Nevertheless, it has reminded mainland Chinese leaders that their continuous obstruction to Taiwan's participation in the international community can only draw backlash from the people of Taiwan and thus hamper the development of cross-strait relations.

Mainland China's ambassador to the United Nations, Wang Yingfan, reiterated in an Aug. 13 letter to Annan that it was an "indisputable objectivity and legal fact that there is only one China," and that Taiwan was "an inseparable part of China's territory."
In his letter, Wang also rebuffed the annual attempt by a handful of U.N. member states to raise the issue of Taiwan's bid to join the United Nations at the General Assembly.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHEN SEEKS SUPPORT FOR RELAXING RESTRICTIONS ON TRADE WITH MAINLAND

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian is scheduled to meet some senior presidential advisers Friday evening over dinner in an attempt to gain support for Taiwan's imminent easing of curbs on trade with and investment in mainland China.

Chen is expected to aggressively seek support from several "hardline" Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) core members for a consensus reached by a panel under the Economic Development Advisory Conference calling for relaxing restrictions on trade with mainland China.

The panel's consensus is evidently in line with President Chen's announcement Tuesday that his government will phase out the "no haste, be patient" policy of restrictions on trade with mainland China and replace it with a policy of "positive opening and efficient control."
Chen added that before implementing the new policy, four principles must first be enforced -- Taiwan first, global consideration, a mutually beneficial situation, and sound risk management.

Koo Kuan-min, a senior presidential adviser who patently opposes lifting curbs on cross-strait trade, said the government should not only "restrain" the out-bound relocation of industries of "strategic importance," but should also provide positive protections to those industries to allow them to flourish in Taiwan.

Koo ridiculed the term "positive opening, efficient control," saying that it would turn out to be meaningless when supporters hope for a positive and aggressive liberalization while opponents call for effective and stepped-up controls.

Taking Japan and the United States as examples, Koo said the two countries, known for their long years of business and investment expansion overseas, strictly impose restrictions on certain industries, banning strategically-important industries from making investments abroad in order to protect the industries' and the nations' interests.

DOC.HEADLINE: LIEN SAYS HE CAN MEET WITH SOONG `ANYTIME'

TEXT.P: Chairman Lien Chan of the opposition Kuomintang said Friday that if necessary, he can meet with James Soong, chairman of the People First Party (PFP), anytime.

Lien made the comment in response to Soong's remark that he wishes to meet with Lien as soon as possible, made one day after PFP Secretary-General Chung Jung-chi walked out of negotiations with the KMT on cooperation between the two opposition parties in the year-end legislative elections, sparking speculation that the possibility of an opposition camp alliance may be disintegrating.

Chung blamed the collapse of the talks on the KMT for having "no intention of supporting PFP members in any county." He also warned the KMT that it will win no more than three county halls without PFP support."

Lien said that since the two parties began holding discussions regarding year-end election cooperation, he has met with Soong almost every one or two weeks, and "if necessary, he will meet with Soong anytime."

On the possible hurdles to KMT-PFP cooperation, KMT officials said that the party is hoping that both sides can give up emotional rhetoric so that bilateral negotiations do not turn into a war of words.
Lien earlier said at a commencement ceremony for a seminar of college student group representatives that the KMT is the party that is most concerned about the welfare of the general public.

Lien lamented the fact that not enough effort has been put toward publicizing the KMT's performance, adding that the KMT, which had ruled Taiwan for over five decades until 2000, has contributed to the development of Taiwan in every aspect.

He said that he is baffled that some polls have shown the KMT is not seen as the political party that is most concerned about the people, adding that this does mean that a political party, which he did not name, that has created a high suicide rate, unemployment rate and crime rate during its rule is the party that is most concerned about the people.

DOC.HEADLINE: NATURAL SCIENCE MUSEUM PRESENTING AUSTRONESIAN EXHIBITION

TEXT.P: The National Museum of Natural Science in Taichung is presenting an exhibition featuring the Austronesian culture, while many in the academic world believe Taiwan is the "homeland" of the Oceanic culture.

Since the 1980s, international linguists and anthropologists have made breakthroughs in their research into tracing the origin of the Austronesian culture, with many now believing that the Austronesian tribes first moved from the southeastern coast of the Chinese mainland to Taiwan some five or six thousands years ago. From Taiwan, the descendants of these people sailed to other islands, as far west as Madagascar and as far east as the Easter Islands, according to museum academicians.
The some 150 million islanders now living in Malaysia, Indonesia, the Philippines, Micronesia, Melanesia and Polynesia are believed to be the descendants of these people.
The research work of the linguists and anthropologists has traced between 300 and 500 dialects spoken by present-day islanders back to Proto-austronesian origins.

The exhibition is trying to give a picture of the similarities in various islanders' ways of living, even though diversified social structures and customs have developed over the past several thousand years among the Austronesian descendants living in different parts of the world.

The museum spokesman said that the exhibition is trying to recollect the islanders' ways of living before colonization and the effects of the intrusion of the capitalist market economy on their societies.
The exhibition will last until Feb. 28, 2002.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAICHUNG MAYOR TO WITHDRAW FROM DPP TO RUN AS INDEPENDENT

TEXT.P: Taichung City Mayor Chang Wen-ying will announce Saturday that she will withdraw from the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) to seek reelection as an independent.

Chang, who lost in an earlier DPP primary to Legislator Tsai Ming-hsien, has reaffirmed that she will not be absent from the year-end election. Some have speculated that the opposition People First Party or the newly formed Taiwan Solidarity Union will ally with Chang for the election.
But Chang revealed Friday that she will not wait for the DPP's disciplinary actions and will announce her withdrawal from the party Saturday.
Although she will withdraw from the DPP, she said she will not join any other party and will instead run as an independent, Chang said.
Chang also said that she will invite DPP heavyweights and her close allies Shih Ming-teh and Hsu Hsin-liang to stump for her reelection bid.
Chang said that she is confident about her performance over the past four years and believes that her administration has taken care of the people's interests.
She has actively visited the people during her term and believes that she has the widest support of Taichung citizens.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN ECONOMIC GROWTH PLUNGES TO MINUS FIGURE IN 2ND QUARTER

TEXT.P: Taiwan's economic growth plunged to minus 2.35 percent in the second quarter of the year, well below the 3.26 percent previously estimated, the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) announced Friday.
DGBAS officials said the poorer-than-expected performance will drive down the estimated growth for the whole year from 4.02 percent to minus 0.37 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: PARAGUAYAN FOREIGN MINISTER TO MEET ROC PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: Paraguayan Foreign Minister Jose Antonio Moreno Ruffinelli will arrive in Taipei Aug. 20 for a six-day visit to the Republic of China.
Leading a five-member delegation, Moreno will meet President Chen Shui-bian, Premier Chang Chun-hsiung, Foreign Minister Tien Hung-mao and other ranking ROC officials.

Moreno and Tien will exchange medals of honor. Moreno was awarded the Order of Brilliant Star with Grand Cordon when he visited Taipei in 1993 in his capacity as speaker of the Paraguayan House of Representatives.
While here, the Paraguayan officials will also visit various economic and cultural establishments of the ROC.

TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, Aug. 18, or the 29th day of the sixth month of the Year of the Snake according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1227: The Mongol ruler Genghis Khan, conqueror of a vast empire that extended from the Pacific to the Dnieper River, dies after falling from his horse. He was 65.
1503: Pope Alexander VI, originally Rodrigo Borgia, Spanish-born pontiff since 1492, dies in Rome at the age of 72 after succumbing to a fever. He was noted as a patron of the arts and for his corrupt papacy.
1759: The British led by Admiral Boscowen defeat a French fleet at Lagos, Portugal.
1825: Scottish explorer Alexander Gordon Laing becomes the first European to reach Timbuktu, located in present-day Mali.
1830: Franz-Joseph I, the Austro-Hungarian emperor who invaded Serbia and helped initiate World War I, is born.
1900: Vijaya Lakshmi Pandit, Indian politician and diplomat, is born. She served as ambassador to Moscow, Washington and Mexico and was president of the UN General Assembly in 1953.
1917: Casper Weinberger, American statesman and secretary of defense for President Ronald Reagan, is born.
1932: Scottish aviator Jim Mollison makes the first westbound transatlantic solo flight, from Portmarnock, Ireland to Pennfield, New Brunswick.
1945: Henry Pu Yi steps down as emperor of Manchukuo, a puppet regime installed in China by the Japanese in 1932. He was nabbed by Russian troops two days later.
1946: Albert Einstein, German-born American theoretical physicist, declares that he had written a memo to President Franklin D. Roosevelt asking the president not to use the atomic bomb against Japan.
1966: Some one million Red Guards hold a huge demonstration in Beijing's Tiananmen Square in celebration of the "great proletarian cultural revolution" launched by Chinese Communist Party Chairman Mao Tse-tung.
1974: Taiwan baseball teams for the first time win the Little League, Senior League and Big League world titles in the same year.
1984: South Africa is banned from taking part in the Olympic Games because of its policy of apartheid.
1985: A ship sinks near Harbin in northeastern China, leaving 171 people dead or missing.
1987: Terrorists throw grenades into the Congress of Sri Lanka, killing two people and injuring 16 others, including Prime Minister Ranasinghe Premadasa.
1988: The Mainland Affairs Task Force is established under the Republic of China Executive Yuan.
1989: Colombian presidential candidate Luis Carlos Galan is assassinated. The Colombian government takes immediate action by launching a nationwide crackdown on drug dealers.
1991: Vice President Li Yuan-zu of the ROC leaves for a state visit to Costa Rica, Nicaragua and Honduras and to attend the 23rd Plenary Meeting of the World League for Freedom and Democracy in San Jose, Costa Rica.
1992: The Department of Anti-Corruption is established under the ROC Ministry of Justice.
1994: An earthquake rocks the Mascara region of western Algeria, killing more than 120 people.
1995: A referendum is held in Bermuda, with 73 percent of the voters in the British dependency voting against independence.
1997: Typhoon Winnie hits Taiwan, killing some 40 people and injuring 81 others.
2000: The Paraguayan embassy in Taipei requests that the Ministry of Foreign Affairs lift an import ban on beef from Paraguay, saying that there have been no cases of foot-and-mouth disease among the country's livestock.
2000: The Taiwan Journalists' Association issues a statement expressing its disappointment and regret over the appointment of former KMT Youth Commission Director Lai Kuo-chow to chair the board of directors of Taiwan Television Enterprises, Ltd.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "It matters not what you inquire into, but when you inquire into a thing you must never give it up until you have thoroughly understood it."

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY (Aug. 19, 2001)
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, Aug. 19, or the first day of the seventh month of the Year of the Snake according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
14 A.D.: Augustus, originally Octavian, the first Roman emperor and the grand-nephew of Julius Caesar, dies at the age of 77. He defeated Mark Anthony and Cleopatra in 31 A.D. and subsequently gained control over the empire.
1662: Blaise Pascal, the French mathematician, physicist and religious philosopher, dies in Paris at the age of 39.
1871: Orville Wright, the American aviation pioneer, who, with his brother Wilbur, made the first powered and controlled flight, is born.
1878: Manuel Luis Quezon y Molina, first president of the Philippines Commonwealth established under U.S. tutelage in 1935, is born.
1901: Shang Tai, the last monarch of the Ryukyu Kingdom, dies in Tokyo at the age of 58.
1904: Japanese troops launch a disastrous attack on Russian-held Port Arthur (Lushun) in northeastern China during the Russo-Japanese War. Of the 51,000 troops involved, only about 35,000 survived.
1934: Nearly 90 percent of Germans vote to give Adolf Hitler the presidency in addition to his position as chancellor.
1936: Kwangsi rebels in China set up an independent regime in Kweilin.
1936: A total of 16 senior members of the Soviet Communist Party are executed after Josef Stalin orders a purge of the party to get rid of followers of Leon Trotsky, a leader of the Bolshevik Revolution.
1945: Forces led by Ho Chi Minh and the Viet Minh begin the August Revolution against French colonial rule in Vietnam.
1946: Chinese Communist Party leader Mao Tse-tung announces that communist forces will launch a full-scale war against the Chinese government.
1946: Bill Clinton, the 42nd president of the United States, is born. He served as governor of Arkansas from 1978 to 1980 and again from 1982 until he was elected U.S. president in November 1992.
1960: The Soviet Union sentences U-2 spy plane pilot Gary Powers to 10 years in detention.
1966: An earthquake rocks eastern Turkey, killing more than 2,000 people.
1979: Pol Pot, ex-dictator of Cambodia, is sentenced to death in absentia for genocide by the Cambodian government.
1989: Poland becomes the first country in Eastern Europe to end one-party rule, as Solidarity's Tadeuz Mazowiecki takes office as prime minister.
1990: Iraqi President Saddam Hussein offers to release all Western hostages in exchange for a U.S. withdrawal from the Gulf region and an end to the blockade.
1991: Mikhail Gorbachev, the Soviet leader who gave a nervous world two words of hope -- "glasnost" and "perestroika" -- is toppled, just one day short of the scheduled signing of the Union Treaty, a document hated by the hardliners because it signals the beginning of the end of the Soviet empire they know and love.
1995: The Republic of China Foreign Ministry issues a position paper entitled "Why the U.N. Resolution No. 2758 Adopted in 1971 Should be Re-examined Today." The paper stresses that the resolution, which excluded the ROC from the United Nations, is obsolete and unjust.
1996: ROC Vice President and Premier Lien Chan visits the Ukraine.
1996: Niger switches diplomatic recognition from Taipei to Beijing.
1999: The Taiwan Independence Party nominates its chairman, Cheng Pang-chen, as its candidate for the ROC's next presidential election slated for March 2000.
2000: James Soong, chairman of the People First Party, urges the two sides of the Taiwan Strait to draw inspiration from the development and integration of the 15-member European Union.
2000: An agreement sending International Cooperation and Development volunteers from the ROC to Nicaragua is passed during a regular meeting of the Executive Yuan.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "It matters not what you try to figure out, but once you try to figure out a thing, you must never give it up until you have got what you want."

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND CHINESE SHIPPING TYCOONS ARRIVE IN TAIPEI FOR VISIT

TEXT.P: A group of mainland Chinese shipping industry heavyweights arrived in Taipei Saturday for a market-inspection visit.

Members of the group included Wei Jiafu, president of China Ocean Shipping Group, one of mainland China's largest shipping companies, and Gao Weijie, executive vice president of China Ocean Shipping Group.

Wei said after his arrival at Chiang Kai-shek International Airport that he and his associates were invited by a local maritime transport research association to see for themselves Taiwan's major harbor facilities and the general situation of its shipping industry.

"This is my first trip to Taiwan. I have long hoped to visit Taiwan. In addition to visiting major Taiwan ports, I'll also meet with my friends here. I have many friends in Taiwan's shipping circles," Wei said, adding that he will also pay courtesy calls on his company's major Taiwan clients.

Asked his view on Taiwan's recent opening of direct sea-air transshipment services between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, Wei said he hopes full-fledged direct cross-strait shipping services can be opened in the not-too-distant future.
China Ocean Shipping Group has maintained cooperative ties with Taiwan's Yangming Marine Transport Corp. and Evergreen Marine Corp. in international shipping services.

DOC.HEADLINE: FIFTY-THREE-YEAR-OLD ADMITTED AS OLDEST FRESHMAN TO MEDICAL SCHOOL

TEXT.P: Fifty-three-year-old Mr. Chen was recently admitted to the National Taiwan University College of Medicine, becoming the oldest freshman in the history of Taiwan's most prestigious medical school.

Chen in July passed the hotly contested Joint University Entrance Examination to determine university placements -- the final time Taiwan's educational system will hold such a test -- to become one of the 180 government-financed freshmen admitted to the NTU medical school for the 2001 academic year.
The company owner-turned-student was the focus of attention at an orientation program for new NTU medical school students that began Friday.
Chen oriented himself at his new school in the company of his son, who is a fifth-year medical student at the same university.
The cool younger Chen said that he does not feel "strange" that his father will become a junior university mate of his, saying that "my dad has the right to do whatever he chooses to do."

The older Chen is expected to study at the NTU medical school for seven years before doing his internship at public-run medical centers for a further four years. By the time he successfully completes the program and is ready to serve as a licensed doctor, he will already be 64 years old, one year younger than the age that ordinary public functionaries are eligible to retire at.

Chen's "case" has raised questions about whether there should be admission age restrictions for government-subsidized medical school students and also whether precious educational resources should be spent on people who are already too old to work by the time they complete their studies.

In response to such questions, Tan Kai-yuan, director of the Bureau of Medical Affairs under the Cabinet-level Department of Health (DOH), said the DOH has never before had someone of Chen's advanced age become a government-subsidized medical school student, but he added that this does not necessarily mean it is illegal or undesirable.

Tan said that Chen's success on Taiwan's difficult joint entrance exam is confirmation of his study abilities, adding that a person of a more senior age studying medical care for the elderly, which has gained increasing prominence worldwide in the modern age, may have some advantages.

Lee Mao-hua, deputy director of the DOH Bureau of Medical Affairs, said that there are no age restrictions on government-subsidized medical school admissions and that the DOH is not planning to impose any.
"We believe that older people are equally capable of contributing to society and the country," he added.
The senior Chen defended himself against critics of admitting older students, saying "a fair and equitable society should allow everybody opportunities of self-challenge."
"Shouldn't social and educational resources be distributed equally to every member of society, even regardless of age?" he asked his opponents.

Chen noted that he has finally been able to fulfill his dream of 30 years by being admitted to medical school. After not receiving placement in medical school after writing the entrance exam after completing high school, he was instead admitted into a private university to study business.

After graduating with a degree in business, Chen ran his own trading company, dealing in classical music records and auto parts. He shut down his business some five years ago as a result of economic recession.

In recent years, he said, his desire to study medicine flared up again after accompanying his son who was preparing for the joint university entrance exam. His own exam results in the previous years allowed him the choice of entering Tzuchi Medical University or Chung Shan Medical and Dental College. He turned down the two choices for the reason that they were "too far from home."

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC DEFENSE MINISTRY CHECKING U.S. NAVY EXERCISE REPORT

TEXT.P: The Ministry of National Defense (MND) is checking a report about a U.S. Navy exercise in the South China Sea, military spokesman Huang Suey-sheng said Saturday.

Foreign wire service reports said two U.S. aircraft carrier battle groups have staged a rare exercise in the South China Sea in an apparent show of support for Taiwan as mainland China is conducting large-scale war games on its southeastern coast facing Taiwan.

According to the reports, the USS Carl Vinson and the USS Constellation led Friday's one-day exercise involving 13 other vessels, including three submarines, as well as 150 aircraft and more than 15,000 personnel.
The reports quoted an official report on the U.S. 7th Fleet's Internet website as saying that the exercise was a "rare meeting at sea" for the two U.S. battle groups.
Asked about the MND's views on the reports, Huang said the MND is studying the content of the reports and will closely monitor any military exercises in relevant waters.

The Hong Kong-based daily the South China Morning Post quoted defense experts as saying that the rare U.S. show of force in the South China Sea was a pointed message to Beijing as the People's Liberation Army (PLA) conducts large-scale war games on the southeastern mainland coast opposite Taiwan.

"There are no coincidences around the Taiwan Strait, and the Americans would have been fully aware of the PLA exercises when they planned this," Paul Beaver, an independent defense analyst in Britain, was quoted as having told the Hong Kong newspaper.
"They are demonstrating to the PLA that they have an interest in the future of Taiwan," he pointed out.

However, a spokesman for the U.S. 7th Fleet stressed that the exercises were routine and not a show of force. "The exercises were also not intended to send any `specific message' to (mainland) China," he added.

The "passing exercise" of the two U.S. aircraft carrier battle groups was believed to have been comprised of the launching of fighter jets and joint operations between the crews of the giant aircraft carriers.

"Along with the valuable training benefits achieved during the exercise, the meeting of the two aircraft carrier battle groups on the high seas demonstrates a commitment to providing peace and cooperation in the region while preserving the right to freedom of navigation," the 7th Fleet website report said.
The website report did not give the exact location in the South China Sea for the exercises.

The USS Constellation is due to arrive in Hong Kong Monday for a port call before making its way home to San Diego, Calif., following a six-month deployment that included operations in the Persian Gulf. The USS Carl Vinson, meanwhile, has just begun a six-month deployment.

DOC.HEADLINE: TSU `CAMPAIGN SCHOOL' WORKSHOP TO OPEN SUNDAY

TEXT.P: The "Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) School," established recently as an election campaign institute, is scheduled to open its first two-day workshop Sunday at the Grand Hotel, TSU sources said Saturday.

Former Republic of China President and former Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lee Teng-hui, the "spiritual father" of the newly-established TSU party, will lecture at the workshop, said TSU Secretary-General Su Chin-chiang.

Lee and a number of other specialists in politics who are "seasoned electioneers" will lecture at the workshop, allowing students to pick up tips on how to win an election beginning from the campaign trail and also how to map out campaign strategies, Su said.

The students of the school, the first of its kind in Taiwan, will be the 40-odd candidates to be fielded by the TSU in the year-end legislative elections, as well as personnel in the newly-founded party, according to Su.
The TSU was formally established Aug. 12 as the 95th political party in Taiwan, becoming the first political party on the island to use "Taiwan" in its official designation.

One of the top goals of the TSU is to consolidate and gain the votes of Lee supporters, said Su, who added that TSU members have maintained close and frequent contact with the former president and that the TSU school will be a "stage" where cooperation between Lee and his supporters and followers will come to the fore.
Su stressed that although the TSU has just been established, it will in a persistent "step by step" manner map out a strategy for victory in the December elections.

Lee raised the ire of KMT members last week when he said that he wanted to form a political party to help the present minority government of President Chen Shui-bian gain enough seats in the year-end legislative elections to gain a stable majority.

In support of Lee, Su called for the KMT camp not to disdain Lee or his level of clout, saying that as the former president of the Republic of China, Lee has much more influence in Taiwan society than that of only a former chairman of a political party.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI CHINESE FOOD FAIR TO FEATURE NORTHERN DELICACIES

TEXT.P: Northern Chinese delicacies, including feast dishes descending from the ancient Tang Dynasty, are expected to be featured at the 2001 Taipei Chinese Food Fair slated for Aug. 23-26.

Topping this year's Chinese food fair will be the Luming (Deer Singing) Banquet, a flagship feast from Liaoning Province in northeastern China and a reproduction of royal dishes from the Tang Dynasty under the instruction of top Liaoning chef Liu Jingxian, who came to Taiwan personally to demonstrate his culinary skills.

The Grand Hotel, one of the 15 leading restaurants in Taipei which will show off their gourmet attractions in their respective pavilions during the four-day fair, dispatched seven of its major chefs to northeastern China, exclusively to learn cooking and related skills for the 2001 fair, said Grand Hotel General Manager Niu Kuang-yueh.
According to Niu, the Grand Hotel chefs revised the 36-course Luming Banquet into a 20-course extravagance due to limited resources of the ingredients needed to prepare the original one.
Entrees of the Luming Banquet will be available for people patronizing the fair which will require an admission fee of NT$250 per head.

In addition to the Luming Banquet dishes, delicacies prepared with Taiwan's native mushrooms and fungi will also be a centerpiece of this year's fair, said officials from the China External Trade Development Council (CETRA), which is co-sponsoring the exhibition with the Tourism Bureau.

Also expected to satisfy the appetite of Taiwan food lovers during the fair will be nutritious traditional foods, Chinese snack foods of all varieties, as well as northern Chinese specialties, such as steamed buns, steamed dumplings and noodles, all displayed and ready to serve at some 60 booths, CETRA officials added.

In addition, four culinary workshops and contests will be arranged during the fair, allowing visitors the opportunity to demonstrate and exchange information on their own cooking skills, the officials said.
The Taipei Chinese Food Fair is the second most popular trade fair in Taiwan, second only to the Taipei Computer Exhibition. It attracts hundreds of thousands of visitors every year.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW PARTY HEAVYWEIGHTS VISIT MARTYRS SHRINE IN PROTEST OF JAPAN

TEXT.P: Core members of the pro-unification opposition New Party (NP) visited the Yuanshan Martyrs Shrine Saturday in protest of Japanese Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi's recent visit to a controversial war memorial.

More than 100 NP stalwarts, led by party convener Hsieh Chi-ta, paid homage to the Republic of China's war dead at the shrine in suburban Taipei. The visitors included NP public functionaries, candidates for the year-end legislative elections and voluntary party workers.

"The shrine visit signifies our determination to take concrete action to show our patriotism," Hsieh said, adding that the move was also aimed at highlighting the party's protest against Koizumi's recent visit to the controversial Yasukuni Shrine, which is dedicated to Japan's war dead, including Class A war criminals executed by the Allies at the end of World War II.

Hsieh, also an incumbent legislator, said Koizumi should not have paid homage at the shrine as many Chinese people died as a result of atrocities committed by Japanese war criminals to which the shrine is partially dedicated.

In an effort to prevent a revival of militarism in Japan, Hsieh said the New Party will continue its campaign to push the Japanese government to repent for its past mistakes and correct all the distorted descriptions of its wartime role and atrocities in its history textbooks for high school students.

Hsieh urged people on both sides of the Taiwan Strait and ethnic Chinese around the world to boycott Japanese goods to pressure the Japanese government to scrap the controversial history textbooks and show remorse for Japan's wartime atrocities.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAICHUNG MAYOR QUITS DPP

TEXT.P: Taichung Mayor Chang Wen-ying announced her decision to quit the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Saturday, but she stopped short of declaring her candidacy in the next mayoral election scheduled for Dec. 1.
Chang said at a news conference that it was a painful decision for her to quit the DPP, recalling that she had joined the opposition camp long before the DPP was legally established.
"Nobody could have imagined that I would one day leave the erstwhile opposition and now ruling DPP," an emotional Chang said.

Chang, a veteran member of the DPP's Formosa faction, lost to Tsai Ming-hsien, an incumbent legislator, in the intraparty primary election in April. Tsai is a key figure of the New Wave faction, the DPP's largest faction.
Chang said that she was deeply disappointed by fierce factional strife in the party primary process.
"It seems to me that many DPP members have forgotten the party's ideals and fundamental principles," she lamented.
Chang said she still treasures her friendships with many of her previous DPP associates. "I hope these friendly ties will never be disrupted," she added.
She has said on many occasions that she would not be absent from the year-end elections for city and county government chiefs as well as legislators.

Chang is widely expected to seek a second mayoral term, but she didn't announce her re-election bid at Saturday's news conference. Instead, she said she will announce her final decision on which election race she will join after completing a comprehensive review.
After Chang lost to Tsai in the DPP primary, many party heavyweights, including President Chen Shui-bian, tried persuading Chang to run for a legislative seat in the Taichung City constituency.
However, Chang said that it is up to Taichung citizens, not her competitor, to decide what post she should assume.

Asked about her chances of success in running as an independent in the year-end mayoral election, Chang said that over the past four years, she has worked very hard to serve all Taichung residents regardless of their party affiliations. "I hope to win the support of a wide array of voters, not just a special group of voters," she explained.
Chang is expected to formally announce in the near future her candidacy in the mayoral election as well as her campaign team members.

Two former DPP chairmen, Hsu Hsin-liang and Shih Ming-teh, were present at the news conference to throw their support behind Chang. Both Hsu and Shih had quit the DPP over different political concepts and policy lines.
Shih said he was disappointed by the DPP's performance since taking power in the Republic of China's first-ever democratic transfer of power between different political parties in May 2000.

"The DPP has not acted like a ruling party. It often acts like it is still an opposition party," Shih claimed, adding that the DPP should change its concepts, style and strategy in order to win the public's trust.

It is widely believed that a decision by Chang to run as an independent for the central Taiwan city's mayoral post would have a great impact on DPP candidate Tsai Ming-hsien's mayoral bid as Chang has enjoyed a high approval rating for her performance over the past four years, party sources said.

Some political observers said Chang's participation in the race would also affect the main opposition Kuomintang nominee Jason Hu's chances of success. Hu originally hoped to win Chang's support after Chang lost the DPP primary, observers said.
It remains unclear whether the opposition People First Party (PFP) will field its own candidate for the Taichung mayoral race or cooperate with the KMT or Chang.
PFP Chairman James Soong said he will meet with KMT Chairman Lien Chan before making a decision on whether to forge an alliance with Chang.

PFP sources said key party figures remain divided over whether the party should cooperate with Chang. Some core members said Chang should take the initiative in expressing an intention to forge an alliance with the PFP.
"Otherwise, the PFP can't throw its support behind Chang," said a party heavyweight.

DOC.HEADLINE: MODERATE QUAKE HITS ORCHID ISLAND

TEXT.P: A moderate earthquake struck Orchid Island, off the Pacific coast of southern Taiwan, Tuesday morning, with no immediate reports of injuries, seismologists at the Central Weather Bureau said.

The tremor, measuring 4.4 on the Richter scale, struck at 9:58 a.m., with its epicenter located 33.7 kilometers north of Orchid Island's seismological detection station, at a depth of 15.2 kilometers.
The quake was only felt on Orchid Island and in Taitung, eastern Taiwan, with an intensity of 3 degrees and 2 degrees, respectively.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT DENIES REPORT THAT IT HAS TRIED BLOCKING BEIJING-TAIPEI DIALOGUE

TEXT.P: Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan denied Sunday that his party has tried to block dialogue between Beijing and the administration of President Chen Shui-bian.

"It is the KMT's long-standing position that Taipei and Beijing should resume dialogue as soon as possible on the basis of the consensus reached between the two sides in 1992 and according to Taipei's Guidelines for National Unification," Lien said while administering the swearing-in of a group of party officials.

He was asked to comment on a report released Friday by the U.S. think tank the Center for Strategic and International Studies (CSIS) which said that members of the KMT, which was voted out of power in 2000 after five decades of rule, have asked leaders in Beijing not to hold dialogue with the Chen administration.

The CSIS cited Chinese sources as saying that KMT delegations visiting Beijing took pains to persuade mainland leaders to not make contact with the government in Taipei led by President Chen Shui-bian whose pro-Taiwan independence stance has long been frowned upon by the Chinese Communist Party.

Noting that Beijing's engagement with the present Republic of China administration would likely boost Chen's chances of reelection, the CSIS said the delegations made up of KMT members reportedly urged Beijing to snub Chen and await the KMT's return to power.
Denouncing the CSIS's claims as "absurd", Lien said the CSIS report's conclusions were likely due to "ignorance" and "a lack of understanding of the situation."

Beijing severed all contact with Taipei after July, 1999 when Lee Teng-hui, the ROC president at the time, referred to the relationship between Taiwan and mainland China as a "special state-to-state relationship."

Beijing maintained its boycott of dialogue with Taipei after Chen was swept into power in 2000 on the grounds that Chen refused to admit that there is only one China covering both Taiwan and mainland China.
Meanwhile, the KMT backed down from Lee's definition of the cross-strait relationship after he stepped down as party chairman in March 2000.

DOC.HEADLINE: SCUBA DIVERS RESCUED AFTER MISSING FOR 24 HOURS
DOC.DATELINE: Taitung, eastern Taiwan, Aug. 19 (CNA) (By Edward Chen)

TEXT.P: Four divers who went missing Saturday while scuba diving in waters off the Green Island were rescued by a freighter Sunday afternoon off the coast of Taitung County's Sanhsien Tai, police said.
The Sea Gull Squadron of the Republic of China Armed Forces sent a helicopter to the scene to carry the rescued divers back to land, police said.

The four divers, part of a group of nine divers from Taipei's Green Bay Diving Club who together went diving in Green Island's White Sand Bay at 11:00 a.m., were reported missing at 12:10 p.m. Saturday.

After receiving the report, police immediately informed rescue teams based in the area who then conducted a search for the missing divers, identified as Hsin Kuang-lo, Huang Yun-hui, Lee Kuo-ming and Chan Hsiu-chen.

Rescue teams searched for the divers until 7 p.m., but to no avail. The divers remained missing for more than 24 hours until the following day when the freighter discovered and rescued them at 1:00 p.m..

DOC.HEADLINE: GOV'T FORECASTS TAIWAN'S 2001 PER CAPITA GNP TO DROP BELOW 1996 LEVEL

TEXT.P: As if the worst economic growth forecast for 2001 released Thursday by the government were not bad enough, it has also forecast that Taiwan's per capital Gross National Product (GNP) will dip to just below the level of five years ago, the China Times reported Sunday.

Quoting an assessment by the government's Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS), the daily said Taiwan's per capita GNP will drop by more than US$1,000 to US$13,144 for 2001.
The big drop in Taiwan's per capita GNP is as unusual as the minus 0.37 percent growth rate for 2001 predicted Thursday by the DGBAS, according to the daily.

Citing data collected by the International Monetary Fund, the paper said Taiwan registered a per capita GNP of US$3,200 in 1984, giving it a ranking of 31st in the world. Taiwan's per capita GNP broke the US$10,000 mark in 1992, moving it up to 25th place globally.

That figure put the island in third place among the four so-called "Asian tigers," lagging behind Hong Kong, whose per capita GNP was 17th highest in the world that year, and Singapore, with the 18th highest, but well ahead of South Korea, whose per capita GNP ranked 30th globally.

Economists credited Taiwan's rapid ascendance up the global rankings list to the island's staggering average economic growth rate of 9 percent in the late 1980's, and also to the nearly 50 percent appreciation in the value of the New Taiwan dollar against the greenback.
The upward trend continued into the second half of the 1990s, with the per capita GNP hitting US$13,260 in 1996 and US$13,590 in 1997.

The streak was only interrupted for one year in 1998, when the per capita GNP dipped to US$12,360, because the Asian financial crisis made a 9.4 percent dent in the island's exports and triggered a 16 percent depreciation in the value of the local currency against the U.S. dollar.
Expansion resumed after 1998, with the per capita GNP surging to US$14,188 last year, the daily reported.

The government had initially predicted that Taiwan's per capita GNP would break the US$15,000 threshold this year, but it was forced to make a downward revision in its forecast as a result of the worse-than-expected performance of the economy as the year progressed.

The DGBAS's latest estimation puts Taiwan's per capita GNP for 2001 at US$13,144, below the US$13,211 registered for 1996, which will push Taiwan down two spots on the global rankings list to 27th place, the daily said.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC AIR FORCE PARTICIPATES IN U.S. AIR SHOW
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Aug. 19 (CNA) (By Nelson Chung and Elisa Kao)

TEXT.P: Republic of China Air Force officials on Aug. 18 attended the "Wings Over Frederick Air Show" in the State of Maryland, in which American spectators showed much interest in the ROC Air Force flag and posters.
This was the first time the ROC Air Force was represented at a foreign air show. The reason for the invitation was that one of the main themes of the air show was the "Flying Tigers."

The "Flying Tigers" was a group of volunteer aviators organized by then-Brig. Gen. Claire Chennault to help China combat Japanese forces with P-40 "Warhawk" single-propeller planes in the early stages of World War Two.

After the United States entered the war in the wake of the December 1941 Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor, the "Flying Tigers" became the U.S. 14th Air Force and Chennault was officially appointed as its commander.

Chia Tse-min, the ROC Air Force Academy's dean of education who led the ROC delegation to the air show, introduced to the American public the development of the ROC Air Force and also the founder of the "Flying Tigers."

Chia said that the spectators' enthusiastic reaction could be seen in the fact that all the 6,000 ROC Air Force posters, hundreds of flags and other souvenirs handed out to spectators quickly ran out during the two-day show. Also, two leather jackets used by "Flying Tigers" pilots attracted much attention among the American spectators.

During the show, three former "Flying Tigers" pilots, all now in their eighties, narrated the history of their participation in the war against Japanese forces in mainland China and answered spectators' questions.

The organizer of the air show also exhibited a P-40 single-propeller plane used by the "Flying Tigers" as well as other military planes used by the air forces of the United States and the former Soviet Union during World War II.

DOC.HEADLINE: TSU OPENS 'ELECTION COURSE'

TEXT.P: A 36-hour course on conducting election campaigns launched by the newly-established Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU), Taiwan's 95th political party, began at the Grand Hotel Taipei Sunday.
TSU Chairman Huang Chu-wen said that the TSU, as a newly-established political party, badly needs the support and assistance of the people in Taiwan.

He said that he will help the TSU's candidates across the island win the upcoming year-end legislative elections. Founded Aug. 12, 2001, the TSU has nominated 39 candidates for the year-end elections.

Huang said that several renowned political figures, including former President Lee Teng-hui, who is reportedly TSU's "spiritual leader," will lecture during the course on election strategy and practices.
Lee will speak on the party's politics and national development, while TSU Secretary-General Su Chin-chiang will lecture on strategies for publicizing a campaign.

Secretary-General of the National Cultural Association Huang Hui-chen will speak on the development of the TSU, while Wu Hsiang-hui, an expert on election practices, will give an analysis of past 10 biggest elections and on election practices.

Liao Hsiao-chun of Taiwan Television Enterprises will speak on the relationship between the media and the candidate during an election, and Fan Yang-sung, an election strategist, will lecture on his area of expertise.

DOC.HEADLINE: EXPANSION PLANNED FOR KAOHSIUNG INTERNATIONAL AIRPORT

TEXT.P: In a bid to promote Kaohsiung to become a global business operations center, the central government will invest between NT$3 billion and NT$4 billion in a "twin-port" plan for the southern Taiwan city by expanding its international airport, a government official was quoted by the China Times Express as saying Sunday.

Ho Mei-yueh, vice chair of the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD), said the CEPD will handle the case proposed by the Kaohsiung city government by first lengthening the runways at Kaohsiung International Airport in an effort to facilitate the landing and taking off of large air cargo planes.

The CEPD's decision came after the government's offshore transshipment center in Kaohsiung, Taiwan's largest port city, kicked off its air-sea transshipment operations Saturday for products from mainland China headed for a third destination.

Under the cooperation agreement between China Airlines and Yangming Marine Transport Corp., Kaohsiung port and Kaohsiung International Airport started their first-ever joint operations by transshipping products from Xiamen in mainland China's Fujian province to Philadelphia in the United States in only two days, 10 days shorter than the normal shipping time by sea.

As the current runways at Kaohsiung International Airport are too short for large airplanes such as Boeing 747s to use, Ho said the CEPD will first improve its runway facilities in line with its "twin-port" plan in a move to develop Kaohsiung into a global business operations center.

Completion of the planned construction and expansion projects at the airport is expected to attract greater investment by transport businesses and international couriers, such as UPS and DHL, giving a boost both to the airport's operations and the city's offshore transshipment center.

Furthermore, the joint air-sea transport operations launched at the Kaohsiung offshore transshipment center will also shorten the travel time for high-tech products made by Taiwan firms based in mainland China's Shenzhen, Dongguan, Zhongshan, as well as those locally-made goods at the nearby Luchu and Tainan science-based industrial parks.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN-MADE DIGITAL CAMERA PRODUCTION VOLUME FORECAST TO HIT 6.8 M

TEXT.P: The production volume of Taiwan-made digital cameras is expected to increase to 6.8 million in 2001 from 4.27 million in 2000, giving the locally-made goods a 34 percent global market share, the Photonics Industry and Technology Development Association forecast Sunday.

The association said that it has revised downward its earlier digital-camera production volume forecast of 7.27 million as a result of the global economic slowdown but that it has maintained its forecast regarding the product's world market share.
It predicted that the global production volume for digital cameras will rise to more than 20 million for this year, a 50 percent increase over the 2000 level.

Attributing the large increase in production volume last year to the combination of the hi-tech product with the Internet as well as to greater demand resulting from falling prices, Yeh Teh-chuan, chairman of the association, claimed that the local digital-camera makers' prospects are bright so long as they further strengthen their research and development capabilities and seek more outsourcing opportunities from large international companies.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, Aug. 20, or the second day of the seventh month of the Year of the Snake according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1741: Danish explorer Vitus Bering discovers Alaska on a mission sponsored by Russia.
1794: Gen. Napoleon Bonaparte is freed from the jail where he was being held on suspicion of Robespierrism.
1833: Benjamin Harrison, the 23rd president of the United States, is born. The first Pan-American Conference took place (1889) during his administration, which passed the Sherman Anti-Trust Act in 1890.
1860: Raymond Poincare, French statesman and president from 1913 to 1920, is born.
1905: Dr. Sun Yat-sen, who had been exiled for his involvement in the anti-Ching movement, organizes the Revolution Alliance in Tokyo. The organization, headed by Dr. Sun, sponsored an entire network of revolutionaries inside China.
1912: William Booth, British religious leader who founded the Salvation Army in 1878, dies at the age of 83.
1925: Liao Chung-kai, one of a 16-member steering committee that established a national government in July 1925, is assassinated in Canton, five months after the demise of Dr. Sun Yat-sen in Peking. Liao was 47.
1928: Both the Wen River and the Mi River in the province of Shantung overflow their banks, drowning 18,000 people and leaving some 30,000 others homeless.
1940: A total of 153 Japanese military aircraft carry out a heavy bombing raid on Chungking, the war-time capital of the Republic of China.
1940: Radar is used for the first time, with the British employing it during World War II.
1940: Leon Trotsky, one of the leaders of the Russian Revolution, is stabbed to death by a Spanish communist with an alpine ax in his home in Coyoacan, near Mexico City. He was 61.
1944: Representatives of China, the United States, the United Kingdom and the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics meet in Washington, D.C., to discuss the establishment of a world organization after World War II.
1944: Rajiv Gandhi, former Indian prime minister, is born. The son of Indira Gandhi was assassinated on May 21, 1991.
1945: Chiang Kai-shek sends a second invitation to Mao Tse-tung after inviting him to come to Chungking for a conference on Aug. 14, 1945.
1955: Gen. Sun Li-jen, chief military aide to the president, submits a request for disciplinary action against himself as a gesture of self-reproach in regard to a communist espionage case involving Kuo Ting-liang.
1967: A total of 247 people, including Taipei City Councilor Lin Shui-chuan, are arrested for attempting to stage an armed rebellion for Taiwan independence.
1968: Soviet and Warsaw Pact troops begin the invasion of Czechoslovakia in an attempt to crush the "Prague Spring" reforms.
1972: The Republic of China Mei Ho baseball team defeats a U.S. team from California 9-0 to win the Senior League world title.
1986: President Chiang Ching-kuo receives Richard Lugar, chairman of the U.S. Senate Foreign Relations Committee. Lugar says that the U.S. government has not changed its basic support of the Republic of China and that he hopes the ROC will open its markets to reduce the ROC-US trade deficit.
1988: A U.N.-mediated cease-fire between Iran and Iraq takes effect, ending nearly eight years of war.
1995: An express train collides with another train in northern India, killing nearly 300 passengers and injuring more than 200 others.
1999: The Central Bank of China announces that Taiwan's second-quarter balance of international payments surplus amounted to US$5.47 billion, the highest single-quarter total in 12 years.
2000: Chinese Taipei captures the Pony League World Series title by defeating a team from West Covina, California 8-3, giving Chinese Taipei its fourth championship in seven years.
2000: ROC President Chen Shui-bian and his delegation arrive in Gambia at the start of his one-week, three-nation African tour which will also take him to Burkina Faso and Chad.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "It matters not what you try to sift out, but when you once try to sift out a thing, you must never give it up until you have sifted it out clearly and distinctly."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK PRICES DOWN BY 88 POINTS

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) lost ground on Monday, with the benchmark weighted price index moving down 88 points to close at 4,550.36.
Market turnover amounted to NT$44.48 billion (US$1.29 billion).

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC FACT-FINDING GROUP HEADS TO XIAMEN TO EXPEDITE CROSS-STRAIT TRADE

TEXT.P: A fact-finding Taiwan team comprised of officials from Cabinet-level agencies and the Kinmen government left for mainland China's Xiamen City Monday on a investigative tour aimed at facilitating direct trade links across the Taiwan Strait.

Members of the group, including 11 officials from the Republic of China's Finance Ministry and Economic Affairs Ministry as well as from the Council of Agriculture and the Department of Health, along with officials from Kinmen's Reconstruction Bureau and Tourism Bureau, sailed aboard the Kinmen-based ferry "Taiwu" directly from Kinmen's Liaoluo Port to Xiamen.

The group members are scheduled to spend five days in Xiamen familiarizing themselves with the situation regarding cross-strait customs regulations, produce and animal quarantine inspections, and other related matters.
The group's visit to Xiamen is also considered a path clearer, paving the way for Fujian Province's consumer products companies to stage the first-ever mainland Chinese trade exposition in Kinmen.

If the proposed trade expo, to be co-sponsored by Kinmen's Business and Trade Association and the trade authority from Fujian Province's Jinjiang City, is successfully held in Kinmen, it will mark the first legal direct imports of mainland Chinese consumer products to Kinmen since the ROC government inaugurated the "mini three links" at the start of this year.
The "mini three links" refers to direct trade, postal, and shipping links between the ROC's frontline islands of Kinmen and Matsu and mainland China's port cities of Xiamen and Mawei.

According to Hsu Chun-min, chairman of the Kinmen Business and Trade Association, people from the two sides have indeed been exchanging visits since the "mini three links" policy went into effect, but legal direct trade, except for a couple of mainland Chinese gravel shipments to Kinmen, has not occurred due to rigid controls by authorities on both sides.
Mainland China has up to the present time refused to allow across-the-board regular direct Kinmen-Xiamen shipping services and has instead approved such applications on a case-be-case basis.

Ironically, illicit "petty trade" among fishermen between Kinmen and Xiamen, located jut 2.4 kilometers apart, has become rampant despite Taiwan's implementation of the "mini three links," which were designed to turn illegal trade activities legal, Hsu said.

If the proposed "Jinjiang Trade Expo" slated for Aug. 30-Sept. 2 successfully takes place, it will serve as a catalyst, expediting legal imports of mainland Chinese consumer goods, including foodstuffs, garments, umbrellas, hardware, building materials, electronics and toys to the ROC offshore areas, Hsu continued.
He added that the ice-breaking expo is also expected to be a shot in the arm for Kinmen's sluggish economy, which has so far not witnessed any benefits from the opening of the "mini three links."
Wang Yuandong, deputy mayor of Jinjiang City, will lead a 185-member trade delegation to Kinmen in late August to beef up publicity of the proposed "Jinjiang Trade Expo," according to Hsu.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN CHRISTIANS COMPLETE WORLD'S 1ST HANDWRITTEN CHINESE BIBLE

TEXT.P: More than 6,000 Christians in Taiwan have jointly completed the world's first handwritten Chinese Bible to mark the advent of the new millennium.

The drive to create a handwritten Chinese-language Bible was launched by the Bible Society in the Republic of China last September, with the handwriting portion of the task being completed in May this year.
The society then spent three more months compiling and arranging the handwritten manuscript which weighs a total of 34.5 kilograms. The manuscript was compiled into seven volumes.
The society displayed the seven-volume Bible for the first time Sunday in a ceremony held at the Shuanglien Presbyterian Church in Taipei.

ROC Bible Society Chairman Weng Hsiu-kung, a Christian pastor, said it is a blessing to be able to record God's words by hand. In ancient times, people wrote the Bible word by word. With the development of printing technology, Christians can now easily read the Bible.

"We launched the `writing the Bible by hand' campaign in the new millennium mainly to let today's Christians understand the hardships and contributions of their predecessors," Weng said, adding that it is also expected to remind the participants to respect God's words.

According to Weng, the handwriting drive started with former ROC President Lee Teng-hui and his wife Tseng Wen-hui, both devout Christians, handwriting the first three verses of the first chapter of the book of Genesis.

A total of 150 local Christian churches, organizations and schools then mobilized their staff and rank-and-file members to write the remaining parts of the Bible. Each contributor was required to present two copies of the section he or she had written. As a result, two copies of the handwritten Chinese Bible were completed.
Weng said that one copy will be sent to the Bible Society in the United States for permanent display and that the original copy will be kept at the ROC Bible Society.
"The different handwriting styles of the 6,000-plus contributors symbolize that despite their individuality, all Christians share a common belief in God," Weng explained.
He further said that each participant has donated at least NT$100 (US$2.90) for each section he or she has written, including the former ROC first couple.

"As a result, we have collected NT$2.6 million in cash donations. The fund will be used to produce special versions of the Bible for the blind, various aboriginal tribes and other local ethnic groups," Weng added.
