DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Shares prices opened low and then fluctuated on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) on Monday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 88 points to close at 4,550.36.

Affected by a decline in U.S. stock prices and by reports of a lower-than-expected economic growth rate for the second quarter this year in Taiwan, the bourse opened at 4,520.12 and fluctuated between 4,595.75 and 4,520.12 during trading.

A total of 1.77 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$44.48 billion (US$1.81 billion), a decrease from the previous trading session which saw 2.29 billion stocks change hands on a market turnover of NT$50.6 billion (US$1.47 billion).
Only one of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with pulp and paper issues edging up 0.2 percent.

The other major categories posted losses, with construction stocks moving down the most at 2.5 percent, followed by electrical shares at 2 percent, bank and insurance stocks at 1.9 percent, textile issues at 1.8 percent, cement stocks at 1.1 percent, and foodstuff shares and plastics and chemical stocks, both at 0.7 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 436 to 96, with 49 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOV'T URGED TO OPEN DIRECT CROSS-STRAIT LINKS TO REV UP ECONOMY

TEXT.P: Wary of Taiwan's worsening economic downturn, several scholars at leading Taiwan universities on Monday urged the government to take pragmatic measures to help prop up the floundering economy.

Prof. Lin Tsu-chia from National Chengchi University suggested that at a time when the country is facing unprecedented economic distress, the government should adopt aggressive measures, such as opening direct trade, travel and communications links with mainland China, to stimulate the sluggish economy.

Other active and clear-cut measures, including allowing Taiwan financial institutions to branch out to mainland China and letting mainland Chinese professionals come to Taiwan to work, should also be taken to help strengthen cross-strait fund interflows and to facilitate business and trade activities, Lin added.

Prof. Lin Chien-fu from National Taiwan University called for the administration of President Chen Shui-bian not to just wrestle with monetary policies and instead expend more mental energy on mapping out pragmatic and useful measures to help Taiwan out of its current economic quagmire.

Prof. Hsu Chen-ming, also from National Taiwan University, criticized Premier Chang Chun-hsiung and the ministers of finance and economic affairs for continuing to paint a rosy picture about Taiwan's economic prospects while major economic forecasters abroad are indicating that Taiwan's economy is expected to post negative growth this year.

All the statements made by Cabinet officials on the island's "not-so-bad" economic prospects were smashed last week when the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) publicized its forecast estimating that Taiwan's economy will post a minus 0.37 percent growth rate for this year. This would represent the island's first-ever, full-year negative growth rate.
The DGBAS's forecast comes after Taiwan's economy posted negative 2.35 percent growth for this year's second quarter.

Hsu also suggested that the Chen administration move to accelerate cross-strait business and trade exchanges, saying that Taiwan should take advantage of the opportunities presented by mainland China's strongly-performing economy.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock index futures market were lower on Monday, as Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index futures for September moved down 88 points to close at 4,542, with 9,508 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for October lost 29 points to finish at 4,575, with 3 contracts traded. No transactions were reported for other months.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Monday at 4,630 for September, 4,606 for October, 4,601 for December, 4,615 for next March, and 4,581 for next June.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were also lower.
September TE futures moved down 4.65 points to close at 233.3, with 1,326 contract transactions, while December TE futures fell 4.65 points to finish at 234.1, with 12 contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for other months.
September TF futures moved down 5.4 points to finish at 586.4, with 681 contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN DECORATES OUTGOING U.S. ENVOY

TEXT.P: The outgoing de-facto U.S. ambassador to the Republic of China received a decoration Monday from the ROC government for his contribution to promoting substantive Taipei-Washington relations.

In a ceremony held at the Presidential Office, President Chen Shui-bian decorated Raymond Burghardt, director of the Taipei Office of the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT), with the Order of Brilliant Star with Grand Cordon, which symbolizes the highest honor the ROC presents to a foreign national.
President Chen said when he made a historic transit stop in New York in May, AIT Chairman Richard Bush told him that ROC-U.S. relations are now in better shape than ever.

"Progress in ROC-U.S. relations is the result of concerted efforts by many people, but I think that Burghardt has played a very important role in leading the AIT Taipei Office to help upgrade bilateral ties between our two countries," Chen said.

Noting that Taipei-Washington communication channels have been working smoothly, Chen said the two countries have forged a strong mutual trust over the past years. "I'm hopeful that our substantive relationship will continue to grow in the future," he added.
For his part, Burghardt, who has been appointed new U.S. ambassador to Vietnam, said he appreciates the ROC government's recognition of his work.

Burghardt said he has seen for himself the people of Taiwan's diligence and can-do spirit during his two-year service. "I have come to learn that Taiwan is an admirable place," Burghardt said, adding that his Taipei stint has also enabled him to better understand the people of Taiwan's frustration as some people in the world have not given them the due respect they deserve.

Burghardt went on to say that relations between the United States and Taiwan are extraordinary. Despite the absence of formal diplomatic ties, he said, the two sides have maintained a very close and important relationship. Burghardt said so long as both sides abide by their commitments, Taiwan-U.S. relations will further expand in the future.

During his tenure, both the ROC and the United States have undergone transitions of power between different political parties. In the process, Burghardt said, both sides can weather all difficulties and continue strengthening their relationship. In his view, Burghardt said these achievements should be attributed in part to President Chen's open-mindedness and friendly attitude.

Noting that few people have the opportunity to contribute to maintaining regional peace and stability, Burghardt said he feels honored to have the opportunity to carry out what he believes to be the right choice during his two-year service in Taiwan.
AIT is a quasi-official U.S. organization authorized to handle ROC-U.S. relations in the absence of official ties.

DOC.HEADLINE: N.T. DOLLAR DOWN ON TAIPEI FOREX MARKET

TEXT.P: The new Taiwan dollar was down NT$0.065 against the U.S. dollar on the Taipei foreign exchange market Monday, closing at 34.606.
The local currency opened Monday at 34.541 and was traded between 34.541 and 34.660.
Interbank U.S. dollar trading totaled US$355 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENTIAL EDUCATIONAL MEDALS TO BE AWARDED TO 42 YOUTHS

TEXT.P: A total of 42 youths from around the island are expected to be bestowed with Presidential Medals for Education Monday in recognition of their bravery, long service or good conduct, according to sources from the Ministry of Education.

The 42 Republic of China citizens, under 19 years old, were selected after receiving recommendations from schools, local governments and educational foundations as potential recipients of the Presidential Medals for Education, the first and highest possible honor for the nation's youths, from the president of the ROC, ministry officials said.
The youths were selected to receive the award because of their determination to advance themselves despite economic poverty, physical challenges or other major difficulties, ministry officials said.

Some recipients of the medals have made significant contributions to society or to communities. Others have exceptional performances in academic competitions or have shown a high degree of skill in talent contests, the officials added.
The presidential medals are given to enhance morality, instill correct concepts of values and to herald social justice among the public, according to the officials.

DOC.HEADLINE: HAPPY BLOOD DONOR GIVES MORE THAN 100,000CC IN 18 YEARS

TEXT.P: A blood donor in Taoyuan, northern Taiwan, has been donating blood for 18 consecutive years to help people in need, sources from the Taipei Blood Center said Monday.

During the past two years, Chiu Hsin-chih, a 44-year-old resident of Pahteh City, Taoyuan County, has become even more enthusiastic about his blood donation by bicycling from his hometown to Taipei to give blood, saying that long-distance bicycling makes him a happier and more efficient donor.

Since early 1999, Chiu has regularly ridden his bicycle from Pahteh to the Taipei Blood Center in downtown Taipei twice a month to give blood and returned, also on his bicycle, riding an approximate 50 kilometers for the round-trip journey each time.
"Bicycle riding is a good sport and it helps pump the blood," a healthy container truck driver Chiu said.
Chiu said he had never thought that his first blood donation under the "connivance" of his pals from the military in 1983 would develop into a habit which has continued for 18 years.
According to records from the Taoyuan Blood Center, where he gave blood before 1999, and the Taipei Blood Center, Chiu has given more than 100,000cc of blood over the past 18 years.

DOC.HEADLINE: SCHOLAR CAUTIONS OF AFTEREFFECTS OF MONETARY CONSOLIDATION ACTIONS

TEXT.P: Professor Norman Yin of National Chengchi University said Monday that the first-wave actions of the "Monetary Reconstruction Fund" task force to consolidate the operations of local banks have been carried out smoothly, but the authorities should be cautious of possible aftereffects.

On Aug. 10, without pre-warnings, the task force personnel were assigned to 36 local financial institutions, mostly credit departments of farmers and fishermen's associations, to supervise their operations. The net assets of all of these 36 local financial institutions are presently in the red.
Prof. Yin said that the sweeping actions did not cause a crisis of confidence because of the backing of the NT$140 billion fund and the authorities' full guarantee of customers' rights.

However, the professor said that the authorities should be extremely careful with follow-up work. While the "Monetary Reconstruction Fund" promises to take care of the bad debts of the problem financial institutions, there is still the risk that the executives of some of these faltering institutions will take advantage of the trouble-shooting measures and clear out the assets, he noted.

Finance Minister Yen Ching-chang has warned that the task force personnel will put any of the local bank or farmers associations' credit departments under supervision if irregularities are found in their financial status or operations.

The "Monetary Reconstruction Fund" was set up in July to help solve the financial problems of Taiwan's financial institutions. Most of the local financial institutions affiliated with farmers or fishermen's associations are small in scale and lack transparency. These financial institutions are not expected to be able to face the challenge when Taiwan opens its financial services market.
The authorities expect that the "Monetary Reconstruction Fund" may help these financial institutions make a safe exit from the market.

DOC.HEADLINE: ILAN COUNTY PLANS TO BUILD 'CHILDREN'S PARK'

TEXT.P: The success of the "International Children's Festival" has encouraged the sponsor of the event -- the Ilan County Government -- to develop a permanent children's park in this northeastern coastal county famous for its natural beauty and hot springs.

A spokesman for the Ilan County Government said Monday that the 44-day children's festival which concluded on Aug. 19 attracted 800,000 visitors. In addition to revenues from admissions, income received by travel, hotel, restaurant and souvenir businesses are estimated to have reached NT$1 billion this year.
The Ilan County Government sponsored the first International Children's Festival six years ago. Except for 1999, the event has been held annually during summer vacation.

"Close to water and embraced by green" was the theme of the festival this year. In recent years, the sponsor had invited artistic groups from all over the world to perform folk music, dances and shows for children. This year, performances by 22 artistic groups from Asia, Europe, Africa, Latin America and Oceania added an exotic touch to the summer events.

While the five festivals in the past six years have become ever more popular among children, the Ilan County Government has decided to develop the festival venue, Chingshui Park, into a permanent children's park, said the spokesman.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRIVATE MANUFACTURING SECTORS ESTIMATED TO INVEST NT$600 BILLION

TEXT.P: Taiwan private manufacturing sectors are expected to invest more than NT$ 600 billion (US$17.3 billion) this year, including the NT$12 billion (US$ 347 million) that Acer Group invested in July, the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) said Monday.

From January to July this year, 160 major investment projects worth a total of NT$367.5 billion (US$10.6 billion) were completed. Of the total, 13 cases worth NT$153.271 billion (US$4.4 billion) were completed in May alone, according to the ministry's inter-development investment promotion center.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN EXPORTS OF BANANAS TO JAPAN HIT ALL-TIME LOW

TEXT.P: Taiwan exported only 2.05 million boxes of bananas to Japan from March to June, the lowest level in history, the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture (COA) said Monday.

During February to April, all Taiwan exports of bananas to Japan reached only 50 percent of original targets and the 2.05 million boxes was also well below the target of 3.5 million boxes set earlier by relevant authorities, COA officials said, adding that the price per box also dropped from US$11 in 2000 to the present US$9.45.

Hsu Fu-kun, general manager of Taiwan Fruit and Vegetable Cooperative Association, attributed the falls to Japan's removal of preferential customs duties on Taiwan bananas and strong competition from mainland China and the Philippines. He noted that the association is planning to send officials to Japan in late September to try to secure an additional order of 500,000 boxes.

DOC.HEADLINE: EX-DPP CHAIR ADVOCATES 'NEUTRALIZATION' OF TAIWAN STRAIT

TEXT.P: An estranged former chairman of the Republic of China's ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) advocated neutralization of the Taiwan Strait Monday for the sake of regional peace and stability.
Shih Ming-teh, an incumbent legislator who quit the DPP over differences in political concepts and policy lines, made the suggestion at a seminar on East Asian security and strategy.

Shih said the present status quo on the two sides of the Taiwan Strait must be maintained. "Otherwise, peace will be lost in the Taiwan Strait and the national interests of both Taiwan and Japan would be affected," he noted.

Against this backdrop, Shih said he looks forward to seeing the Taiwan Strait neutralized. "I hope that all Asia-Pacific countries will sign a joint declaration pushing to open the Taiwan Strait to all countries around the world in line with the United Nations convention on the open sea," he added.

The outspoken lawmaker further said relevant Asia-Pacific countries should sign a multilateral treaty or agreement on designating special regions where deployment of troops and weaponry systems would be prohibited. "Only by doing this can we maintain regional peace and stability," Shih stressed.
Speaking on the same occasion, Lien Chan, chairman of Taiwan's main opposition Kuomintang, said Asia remains an area with potential threats of conflict.

In his view, Lien said, top leaders on both sides of the Taiwan Strait should work together to end their disputes and avert war and conflict. "Otherwise, all East Asian countries could be affected by a cross-strait conflict," Lien said, adding that Asia's peace and security lies in promotion of common interests of all Asian countries, including mainland China.

The one-day seminar was sponsored by a Japanese think tank dedicated to research of current international and regional issues and trends. This was the first time that the Japanese World Events Study Association has organized a symposium in Taipei. Twenty-four Japanese parliamentarians and scores of representatives from Japanese journalistic, academic and business circles traveled to Taipei to attend the seminar.

Takanori Nakajo, a senior executive with the Japanese think tank, said in his opening remarks that Japan's current security system centers around its defense cooperation treaty with the United States. As Japan's security is closely related to Asian peace, Nakajo said the U.S.-Japanese security cooperation system should be updated and expanded to cover issues crucial to peace and stability in the entire Asian region.
Eimei Kase, a Japanese diplomatic commentator, said mainalnd China is the only country that has continued to expand its military buildup after the end of the Cold War.

At present, Kase said, Taiwan, Japan and the United States are the main targets of mainland China's missile deployment. As mainland China tends to consider democratic countries as its enemies, Taiwan and Japan should cooperate in fighting against mainland China's military expansionism to maintain peace and stability in Asia.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENTIAL OFFICE DENIES REPORT OF PREMIER REPLACEMENT

TEXT.P: The press report of the possible replacement of Premier Chang Chun-hsiung is completely unfounded and sheer speculation, a senior Presidential Office spokesman said Monday.

Yu Shyi-kun, secretary-general to the president, was responding to a newspaper report that President Chen Shui-bian had asked his senior advisers and some business tycoons about the feasibility of replacing Premier Chang with a more capable politician to revitalize Taiwan's faltering economy.

Yu said the president was infuriated by the report. "President Chen said the report was fictitious and unthinkable," Yu said, adding that Chen had ordered him to make a public clarification of the report.
Yu said the report was purely fabricated. "We feel deep regret over the appearance of such a report on the front page of a local newspaper," he added.

According to the report, Chen took advantage of a dinner with several senior advisers and national policy advisers last Friday to seek their opinions about the feasibility of replacing Premier Chang before or after the year-end elections for legislators and local government chiefs.
The report further said Chen had also met with senior commerce and industry executives to solicit their views on the premier replacement issue.
However, Yu debunked all those allegations, saying that Premier Chang was present at last Friday's dinner party at President Chen's official residence.

"How could Chen have talked about any possible personnel change topics at such an occasion?" Yu asked, adding that he himself was also present at the time. "Nobody mentioned the word 'premier' during the dinner party," he stressed.
Yu said that several business heavyweights asked to meet Chen last week to discuss some issues related to the soon-to-be-convened Economic Development Advisory Conference.

"As the president's schedule was fully booked, he asked me to meet with the business leaders on his behalf. Our talks surrounded issues related to the conference and no one said anything about a change in personnel," Yu said.
During this time of economic hardship, Yu said local people all hope that the public and private sectors will work together to address various problems to revamp the domestic economy.
"We hope never again to see this kind of irresponsible press report," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: 8TH JOINT MEETING OF CETRA, KOTRA TO START WEDNESDAY
DOC.DATELINE: Seoul, Aug. 20 (CNA) (By Chiang Yuan-chen and David Hsu)

TEXT.P: The eighth joint meeting of the Korean Trade Promotion Corporation (KOTRA) and the Taipei-based China External Trade Development Council (CETRA) will begin Wednesday in Seoul, sources with the Taipei mission in Korea said Monday.
CETRA Secretary-General Huang Chih-peng will lead a Taipei delegation to Seoul Tuesday to attend the meeting, the sources said.
CETRA signed a cooperative agreement with KOTRA Aug. 10, 1984 and the two sides have since held seven joint meetings before Taipei severed diplomatic ties with Seoul in 1992.
After several reciprocal visits, CETRA and KOTRA decided to resume the joint CETRA-KOTRA meetings in a bid to promote bilateral economic and trade relations.
On Thursday, Huang and his entourage will also visit the Korea Foreign Trade Association, the Korea Chamber of Commerce and Industry and the Taipei mission in Korea.
They are scheduled to return to Taipei Friday.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT SPOKESMAN SHIES AWAY FROM JUDGING FORMER CHIEF'S WORDS

TEXT.P: A Kuomintang spokesman brushed aside questions Monday about whether the party's former chairman, Lee Teng-hui, has betrayed the party by identifying himself with the cause of the newly formed Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU).

KMT spokesman Wang Chih-kang said that whether Lee's remarks have crossed the line from simple public speaking to words that are in violation of party rules should be judged by the KMT disciplinary committee.
Wang said he is in no position to pass judgment on Lee's behavior before the disciplinary committee deliberates on the matter.

Wang was asked to comment on Lee's remarks to a group of aspiring TSU candidates Monday where the former president said that he identified himself with the TSU's political mission and hoped that the newly formed political movement would become a major force in the year-end elections.

Lee, who was invited to speak about politics to TSU candidates, said that only a victory by the TSU would ensure that the island becomes politically stable. A good showing in the year-end elections would bring the nation out of its economic malaise and reinforce democracy, he said.

The retired KMT chairman also defended his decision of not washing his hands of politics after stepping down, saying that he, like an old father, cannot stand by and watch his two feuding sons make a mess of the house.

Meanwhile, KMT legislator Hung Hsing-rong urged Lee Monday to quit the KMT and pitch for the TSU rather than sit on the fence and keep the KMT, the TSU and even the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) in agony.

Hung made the suggestion after the TSU on Monday reputed Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng's claims that Lee will stump for KMT candidates during the elections, despite his public endorsement of the TSU.
TSU members said Wang, who has been Lee's political crony in the KMT, misquoted Lee's statement.
Citing two former DPP chiefs who have defected from the party as an example, Hung said it is not unusual in Taiwan for politicians to switch their political allegiances.
Lee should declare his withdrawal from the KMT to spare the party the embarrassment of seeing its former chief pitching for competitors, Hung said.

Another KMT legislator and a supporter of Lee, Chen Horng-chi, said Lee didn't lend his support to the TSU, instead it was the TSU which attached itself to Lee in the hopes of riding on Lee's coattails.

As Lee's status as the former head of the KMT cannot be changed, the KMT could better use its energy by formulating a vote-earning policy rather than wracking its brain on how to cope with Lee's behavior, Chen said.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER PRESIDENT HOPES TSU IS VICTORIOUS IN YEAR-END ELECTIONS

TEXT.P: Former Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui on Monday expressed his hope that the newly established Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) will become a major party after the year-end legislative elections.
Lee made the remarks during a speech he gave to the TSU on election strategies and practices.

The former ROC president said his political ideals are similar to that of the TSU -- to pursue the goal of a stable political environment in Taiwan, a revived economy, a solid democracy and a strong Taiwan.
He indicated that the TSU must become a major party after the year-end legislative and county chiefs elections so that it can implement its political policies and so that Taiwan can progress.
Lee said that although he has not officially joined the TSU, he "spiritually" supports the new party, which was organized by former Minister of the Interior Huang Chu-wen.

Concerning the criticism that the retired Lee does not want to give up his political influence, Lee noted that he is still involved not because of his need for power, but because he was upset by Taiwan's chaotic political situation and faltering economy.

He emphasized that he will feel comfortable if Taiwan can establish a consolidated democracy now, considering that he will not live more than another 10 years. Lee said he cannot sit idly by while the democratization that he advocated during his 12-year tenure of office nears collapse.

The 78-year-old Lee, who has been dubbed "Mr. Democracy" of Taiwan, said that he hopes TSU will bring to fruition what he failed to accomplish during his 12-year tenure. This can only be done if the TSU becomes a leading party, Lee added.

Lee also explained his past achievements of pushing for the return of the military from political parties to the people, de-linking political parties from the government, and restructuring the congress.

Other lecturers for Monday's event included Huang Chu-wen, who spoke on "Strategies to Win," and Wu Hsiang-hui, an election expert, who gave an analysis on the past 10 biggest elections and on election practices.

DOC.HEADLINE: CONTRACTION IN GOVERNMENT, PRIVATE SPENDING SAID HARMFUL TO ECONOMY

TEXT.P: The negative economic growth rate in the second quarter, coupled with a contraction in both government spending and private consumption are all to blame for Taiwan's present economic problems, a government official said Monday.

Council for Economic Planning and Development Vice Chairman (CEPD) Lee Kao-chao said the sharp decline in private consumption, together with falls in government spending, are very harmful to business sentiments and will hamper the recovery of the local economy.

According to Lee, investment in public works by the government and state-run enterprises dropped by 0.39 percent and 8.63 percent, respectively, in the second quarter, while government spending also slid by 0.96 percent during the same period.

Lee added, however, that the Central Bank of China's (CBC's) loose monetary policy will help improve the local financial situation. The CBC's cuts in major interest rates since late last year will gradually show their effects, he added, attributing the rise of the money supply levels in May and June to the CBC's series of adjustments.
The CBC announced the year's eighth lowering of interest rates last week.

As to proposals by members of the local business community that the government slash its stock transaction tax, land value increment tax and sales tax, Lee said any such proposed tax reductions should be accompanied by "complementary measures."
Lee also predicted that Taiwan's economy will bottom out in the third quarter and begin to improve in the fourth quarter, based on the fact that the U.S. economy is gradually regaining its momentum.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2001 EMPLOYMENT RATE FORECAST TO AVERAGE OVER 4.1 PERCENT

TEXT.P: Taiwan's unemployment rate for the whole of 2001 will remain above 4.1 percent, an official with the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) forecast Monday.

CEPD Vice Chairman Lee Kao-chao said given the fact that the average jobless rate in the first half of the year averaged 3.94 percent and that the ratio for the next three months is expected to surpass 5 percent, the country's annual unemployment is expected to hit a record high of more than 4.1 percent.

According to Lee, Taiwan's jobless rate will rise between 0.5 percentage points and 0.7 percentage points with every 1 percentage point by which the economy shrinks. As the country's economy posted negative growth in the second quarter and is expected to also post negative growth in the third quarter, he said it will be unlikely that the jobless rate -- a lagging index of business sentiment -- to diminish in the short term.

Commenting on a prediction that Taiwan's unemployment rate will fall below 4.2 percent in September, Lee called the viewpoint "too optimistic," claiming that the ratio will not fall below the level by the end of this year and will remain relatively high for the next year.

DOC.HEADLINE: TZU CHI FOUNDATION MAKES 300TH BONE MARROW DONATION

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Buddhist Compassionate Relief Tzu Chi Foundation made its 300th bone marrow donation Monday, with the recipient a college student in Hangzhou City, in mainland China's Zhejiang Province.
It was also the 185th overseas bone marrow donation by Tzu Chi, according to the foundation's bone marrow databank.
The donor, a 19-year-old man, is a student at Tzu Chi College of Technology, who had tried to donate his marrow the previous year but was rejected because he was not yet 18.

The marrow, which was immediately taken to Hangzhou City by a team of Tzu Chi members, was expected to arrive later in the evening. It will be the foundation's 95th bone marrow donation to a mainland Chinese recipient.
The Tzu Chi bone marrow databank, established in 1993, had accumulated data on 220,013 potential bone marrow donors as of late July, with recipients scattered throughout the world.

DOC.HEADLINE: PARAGUAYAN FOREIGN MINISTER ARRIVES IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Paraguayan Foreign Minister Jose Antonio Moreno Ruffinelli arrived in Taipei Monday for a six-day visit.
During his stay in Taiwan, Moreno will meet President Chen Shui-bian, Premier Chang Chun-hsiung, Foreign Minister Tien Hung-mao and other ranking Republic of China officials.
He will also visit various economic and cultural establishments of the ROC, including the Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park and the National Palace Museum.

Moreno, who formerly served as speaker of the Paraguayan House of Representatives, made his first visit to the ROC in 1993. During that visit, he was awarded the Order of Brilliant Star with Grand Cordon.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOEA PLANNING TO BUILD TAIWAN INTO HIGH VALUE-ADDED CENTER

TEXT.P: Economics Minister Lin Hsin-yi said Monday that the Ministry of Economic Affairs is planning to transform Taiwan into a highly value-added product manufacturing center "within the next five years."
Speaking at a press conference, Lin said that the market and resources of mainland China should be incorporated as a link in Taiwan's industrial global deployment.
Facing the crisis of the hollowing out of local industry, capital and talent, Taiwan should adopt a new vision for its national economic development, Lin said.

He presented a farsighted policy of internationalizing Taiwan's economic position, stressing that national security is still the highest value for the nation, but adding that Taiwan should adopt a new security vision to replace the conservative "security defense viewpoint."

Vice Economics Minister Yiin Chii-ming said that Taiwan is facing its biggest crises of industry, capital and talent since Taiwan businessmen began poured their capital investment into mainland China. He further said that Taiwan has lost the opportunity to play a "strategic position" role.

The ministry's new "economic blueprint" will aim at building Taiwan into a high value-added production center in the coming five years, making it one of the three largest bonded air and sea transshipment hubs in Asia, Yiin said, without elaborating.

Lin pointed out that the government can no longer maintain its "do it all" attitude but should adopt a "lean but efficient" concept. The MOEA should play a pivotal role in the process of this economic development, he said.

The MOEA will push for an upgrading of technology and competitiveness while "pulling" more foreign investment and reviewing all the outdated regulations and laws to upgrade administrative efficiency, he added.

The MOEA will also complete the work of six support systems to support the high value-added manufacturing center idea, he said, describing these systems as the implementation of a new research and development system; the development of the island as a bonded transshipment hub; the development of a mechanism for venture businesses; the establishment of an online supply chain administrative process; the pooling of capital mechanism for the high tech industry; and the setting up of an improved financial service system.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINESE TAIPEI WINS SILVER MEDAL IN POWER LIFTING AT WORLD GAMES

TEXT.P: Chinese Taipei's Chen Kuan-ting won a silver medal Monday in the lightweight powerlifting at the Sixth World Games presently under way in Akita City, Japan.

It was the second silver won by the Chinese Taipei delegation since the World Games kicked off Aug. 16. Chinese Taipei scored its first in "gateball," a Japanese sport based on croquet and one of five demonstration events at the World Games Sunday.
Chen won the powerlifting silver with a total combined lift of 420 kg -- 175 kg in the squat, 90 kg in the bench lift and 155 kg in the dead lift.
Chao Chen-yeh added another bronze medal in the heavyweight power lifting category for the Chinese Taipei delegation.

The Chinese Taipei delegation has so far chalked up two silvers and one bronze since the games began. More than 2,200 athletes from 91 countries around the world are participating in 26 events over the course of the 11-day competition, the first of its kind to be held in Asia since the first World Games was held in Santa Clara, the United States, in 1985.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN RESONATES IN CHINESE, AMERICAN PSYCHES: CANADIAN EXPERT

TEXT.P: Taiwan is like no other issue; it resonates "deeply in both the Chinese and American psyches," a Canadian expert claimed Monday.
According to Thomas Axworthy, chairman of the Asia Pacific Foundation of Canada, how both countries handle the future of Taiwan "will be one of the pre-eminent issues of the 21st century."
"If miscalculations are made, conflict will be inevitable and then Taiwan will become an ultimate concern of us all," he warned in an article he contributed to The Globe and Mail, a Canadian daily.

Titled "Taiwan is the Tinder in Asian-American Relations," his article points out that there is no doubt that the mainland Chinese leadership is "visibly apprehensive" about the possibility of Taiwan independence.
During a recent academic discussion in Hong Kong in which he participated, Axworthy witnessed the mainland Chinese expressing their concern over the need for stability.
"The Chinese nightmare is disintegration and Taiwanese independence is viewed as a precursor to the breakup of China itself," he said.

"My American colleagues, on the other hand, rightly applauded the democratic transformation of Taiwan and view it not as a rebel state, but as a beacon of freedom," said Axworthy, who is also adjunct lecturer on public policy at Harvard University.
For each side of the debate, he noted, Taiwan is a symbol of something much deeper -- in fact, "representative of each country's ultimate concern."
For mainland China, introverted, proud and only recently emerged from a century of civil war and cultural revolution, the ultimate concern is territorial integrity, Axworthy said.

For the United States, extrovert and in the high noon of its influence, there are no threats to territorial integrity. The ultimate American value is liberty and the promotion of the American way around the globe, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO DECIDE FATE OF ITS RESEARCH REACTOR

TEXT.P: A panel under the Atomic Energy Council (AEC) will meet Tuesday to decide whether to go ahead with the rebuilding of Taiwan's Research Reactor II (TRR II).
The panel, made up of Academia Sinica President Lee Yuan-tseh and five other experts, is reportedly to choose between going ahead with the initial rebuilding plan or suspending it for three years.

The China Times, a local daily, said Monday that the panel is expected to choose suspension of the reconstruction of the reactor, which would be tantamount to phasing out the whole plan, since the prospects of a resumption after three years are slim in light of the government's tight budget.
The paper said the panel based its decision on the grounds that new technology has made the planned rector obsolete even before it has been built.
In addition, the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's anti-nuclear stance is surely a factor contributing to the abolishment of the reactor, said the paper.
AEC Vice Chairman Ouyang Min-sheng said Monday that any panel decision will be subject to the approval of the National Science Council and the ratification of the Executive Yuan.

Ouyang said that even if the panel decides to suspend the construction of the new reactor, the budget earmarked for it -- NT$38 million (US$1.11 million) for this year -- will be used to dismantle the old reactor or to finance the research into energy and environmental protection science.
The Taiwan research reactor, purchased from Canada in 1969 for scientific research, was forced to shut down by Washington in 1988 after it was found to have being used secretly for military purposes.
The Institute of Nuclear Energy Research under the AEC came up with the TRR II plan in 1990 to improve the reactor rather than demolish it.

The plan, which went through the National Science Council in 1998 and was approved by the Executive Yuan in the same year, envisioned the reconstruction of the reactor in seven years at a cost of NT$3.28 billion.

The China Times said a three-year interruption in the research into nuclear energy will be another blow to the island's nuclear industry after the government's flip-flop on the construction of a controversial nuclear plant last year.
It will also obstruct the replenishment of Taiwan's aging nuclear researchers who, numbered at about a thousand, have an average age of 47, according to the China Times.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING GIVES ROC INTERIOR MINISTER `VIP' TREATMENT

TEXT.P: Republic of China Interior Minister Chang Po-ya, traveling at the head of a 20-member delegation, arrived in Beijing Monday to attend the 2001 Women's Leaders Meeting under the framework of the Asian-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum.
Despite Beijing's identification of her as "Ms. Chang" on her invitation letter, Beijing officials provided Chang and her entourage with "VIP" treatment at the airport.

This is Chang's first visit to mainland China, although she had promoted the passage of the Statute Governing the Relations between the People of the Taiwan Area and the Mainland Area" when she was a legislator.

Restricted by her status as the director-general of the National Health Department and then the Minister of the Interior, she was unable to have a chance to visit the mainland for the past several years.

Chang said that her participation in the 2001 Women's Leaders Meeting under the sponsorship of APEC -- a warm-up for the APEC Ministerial Women's meeting scheduled to be held in Mexico next year -- is chiefly to exchange views with other Asian women's leaders.
Although Beijing called her as "Ms. Chang" in its invitation letter, another invitation letter issued by Beijing for customs purposes gave her the honorific of "minister."

The 2001 Women's Leaders Meeting will open in Beijing Wednesday and Chang will visit the Beijing Union Medical Hospital a day prior to the meeting. Dr. Sun Yet-sen, the ROC founder, was hospitalized for liver cancer at that hospital in 1925.

DOC.HEADLINE: KOREA, RUSSIA, PHILIPPINES WIN IN WILLIAM JONES CUP

TEXT.P: South Korea trounced Canada 92-65 Monday at the 2001 William Jones Cup Basketball Invitational being held at Fengshan Stadium, Kaohsiung.
It was the fourth consecutive victory for the Korean five, while Canada tasted its fourth consecutive loss since the tournament opened last week.
Korea was ahead of Canada 54-30 at the end of the first half.
In earlier matches, Russia beat Mongolia 103-73 and the Philippines beat South Africa 95-57.

DOC.HEADLINE: VP DENIES TIFF WITH FORMER, INCUMBENT HEADS OF STATE

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu denied Monday there has been any tiff between her and President Chen Shui-bian or former President Lee Teng-hui over their snubbing of her "peace assembly" last week.

In a press release issued through her office, Lu said that although Chen and Lee were "unable" to attend the "Voice from Taiwan: Peace and Love" event from Aug. 13-16, they received the foreign dignitaries who attended, including five Nobel Peace prize laureates.

Lu expressed thanks to Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng and the Ministry of Foreign Affairs for their assistance in organizing the event, as well as to a dozen civic groups for their sponsorship.

The vice president, whose advocacy of mass Taiwanese immigration to Belize caused an uproar in that Caribbean state recently, also said in a belated attempt at damage control that her statement was aimed at urging the government to formulate a long-term immigration policy rather than overwhelming the Caribbean state with Taiwan immigrants.
She also disputed local press reports that she competed for the limelight with President Chen Shui-bian by inspecting typhoon-ravaged areas early this month, hot on the heels of the president.

Rather than simply grandstanding, Lu said in the press release, she visited the disaster area which was hardest-hit by Typhoon Toraji and needed relief the most. She said she did not care if she was accompanied by officials or journalist on her trips.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI BIOTECH FORUM TO BE HELD LATE AUGUST

TEXT.P: The 2001 Taipei International Master Forum on Biotechnology is scheduled to be held Aug. 27-29 with dozens of biotech industrialists from the United States, Europe and the Asia-Pacific region participating, the organizer said Monday.

The forum, aimed at promoting the Taiwan bio-tech industry's cooperation with the international community, is organized by the Biological Medical Engineering Center under the Industrial Technology Research Institute (ITRI) and will be held at the Tri Service General Hospital.

ITRI Vice President Lee Chung-hsi said it will be the first time the ITRI will have sponsored an international forum on biotechnology that will discuss topics such as bio-information, genetic engineering, bio-chips and organic engineering.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PREMIER DESCRIBES TRANSIT VIA U.S. AS `DIPLOMATIC BREAKTHROUGH'

TEXT.P: Premier Chang Chun-hsiung claimed Monday that stopovers he plans to make in four U.S. cities en route to four of the Republic of China's diplomatic allies in the Caribbean can be considered a "diplomatic breakthrough."
Chang will make an official 12-day visit to the four diplomatic allies -- St. Christopher and Nevis, St. Vincent and the Grenadines, the Commonwealth of Dominica and Grenada -- from Sept. 1.
Chang and his entourage will make transit stops in New York Miami, Los Angeles and Hawaii on their way to and from the Caribbean visit.

According to the ROC Foreign Ministry, one of the main purposes of the visit is to attend activities marking the 20th anniversary of the establishment of diplomatic ties between the ROC and St. Vincent and Grenadines.

Chang said during an inspection tour of the Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission that U.S. stopovers by ROC government officials should respect the rules of the two countries. He added that his being allowed to visit four U.S. cities can be considered as a "diplomatic advance" and expressed hope that this can help strengthen bilateral ties.

He added that although the U.S. and ROC authorities have some "understandings" on restrictions on ROC government officials' activities during their transit in U.S., he hopes to meet overseas Chinese there to let them know more about Taiwan's "real situation" and vice versa.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, Aug. 21, or the third day of the seventh month of the Year of the Snake according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1754: Scottish engineer William Murdoch is born. He pioneered the use of coal-gas for lighting in 1792 while working with James Watt and Matthew Bouton on their steam engines.
1765: William IV, the English monarch known as "the sailor king" for his service in the Royal Navy, is born. He joined the navy at 13 and was a close friend of British Adm. Nelson. The king was renowned for his affairs and had 10 illegitimate children by actress Dorothea Jordan.
1902: Manufacturer Martin Leland starts his luxury car venture by naming his new automobile after Antoine de la Motte Cadillac, the French colonial administrator and Detroit's founding father.
1908: Orville Wright, American aviation pioneer, and his brother Wilbur make the first military aircraft for the United States.
1930: Princess Margaret, sister of British Queen Elizabeth II, is born.
1944: Representatives from China, Britain, Russia and the United States meet at Dumbarton Oaks near Washington, D.C. to plan for the formation of the United Nations.
1937: The Treaty of Non-Aggression between China and the Soviet Union is signed in Nanking.
1959: The Baghdad Pact is formally renamed the Central Treaty Organization (CENTO) following Iraq's withdrawal earlier in the year.
1959: Hawaii becomes the 50th state of the United States.
1963: South Vietnam declares martial law after raids on Buddhist pagodas and the arrest of hundreds of Buddhist monks.
1976: Prince Maphevu Harry Dlamini, prime minister of the Kingdom of Swaziland, accompanied by Madame Dlamini and a party of eight, arrives in the Republic of China for a seven-day visit.
1982: King Sobhuza II of Swaziland dies at the age of 83. He was one of the world's longest-reigning monarchs, having been on the throne sine 1921.
1982: Republic of China Economics Minister William Y.T. Chao announces the partial lifting of an import ban on 842 types of Japanese consumer goods.
1983: Benigno Aquino, leader of the anti-Marcos faction in the Philippines, is gunned down as he steps onto the asphalt at Manila Airport after returning from a three-year sojourn in the United States. He was 51.
1984: A massive demonstration is held in Manila to mark the first anniversary of the assassination of Benigno Aquino.
1985: ROC President Chiang Ching-kuo appoints Robert C. Chien as the new finance minister, succeeding Loh Jen-kong who resigned on Aug. 15.
1986: A cloud of toxic gas is released from the volcanic Lake Nyos, near Wum in northwest Cameroon, killing more than 1,200 people.
1990: An ROC Air Force B-1900 air transport plane crashes in Tungshih Village in Yunlin County, killing all 16 people aboard, including three major-generals and nine colonels.
1990: The Indian Parliament approves presidential rule in Jammu and Kashmir and gives the armed forces special powers in the riot-torn state.
1991: President Mikhail Gorbachev arrives back in Moscow after the collapse of a coup attempt by hardliners.
1991: Latvia declares its independence from the Soviet Union.
1997: Abdur Rahim Gaffurzai, the newly appointed prime minister of Afghanistan, is killed along with 13 others in a plane crash.
1999: Over 96 percent of the Kuomintang's party delegates vote to support Vice President Lien Chan as the party's candidate in the following spring's presidential election.
2000: Former ROC President Lee Teng-hui proposes the establishment of an Asian monetary fund to promote economic cooperation in Asia.
2000: ROC President Chen Shui-bian and his Gambian counterpart Yahya Jammeh sign a joint communique pledging to continue enhancing close cooperation between the two countries.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "It matters not what you try to carry out, but when you once try to carry out a thing you must never give it up until you have done it thoroughly and well."

DOC.HEADLINE: EX-OFFICIAL ANNOUNCES CANDIDACY FOR HUALIEN COUNTY CHIEF RACE

TEXT.P: Yu Ying-lung, a Soochow University professor, announced his decision Tuesday to accept the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP's) offer to run as its candidate in the Hualien County magistrate election scheduled for Dec. 1.
The political science professor told a news conference that it was a tough decision for him to make to quit his teaching post and opt for a political career.

"After a period of soul searching, I have finally decided to express my love for my homeland with concrete action. I'll change my role from a political science scholar to a down-to-earth `political worker,'" Yu said.

Yu resigned from the post of vice chairman of the Cabinet-level Research, Development and Evaluation Commission early this year to take part in the DPP primary for party nomination for the year-end legislative elections in the Hualien constituency. Yu, however, was unsuccessful in his bid.
He said that he had originally planned to quit politics forever. But after a series of meetings with top government and party officials in recent weeks, Yu said, he has changed his mind.

"The central government's strong commitment to promoting development and construction projects in the eastern part of the island was a decisive factor in my decision to enter the year-end election race," Yu explained.

In his view, Yu said the government's plans to build a science-based industrial park in eastern Taiwan and to speed up railway services between Taipei and Hualien are feasible and that the projects can bring prosperity to the eastern Taiwan county.

Hualien County has long been controlled by the erstwhile ruling and now opposition Kuomintang (KMT). The DPP's support base in the county remains limited. In the 2000 presidential election, independent candidate James Soong, now chairman of the opposition People First Party (PFP), won the largest share of the vote in the county.

Both the KMT and the PFP have fielded their own candidates for the county chief elections. The DPP decided to draft Yu to represent the party in the race after Typhoon Toraji wreaked havoc in the county's mountainous regions in late July.
The DPP leadership reportedly hopes that Yu's participation in the contest can help expand the party's power base in this rural county known for its beautiful natural scenery.

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) gained ground on Tuesday, with the benchmark weighted price index moving up 12.37 points to close at 4,562.73.
Market turnover amounted to NT$39.85 billion (US$1.15 billion).

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Shares prices opened high and closed even higher on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) on Tuesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 12.37 points to close at 4,562.73.
Encouraged by a rise in U.S. stock prices, the bourse opened at 4,553.95 and then fluctuated between 4,575.65 and 4,519.7 during trading.

A total of 1.61 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$39.85 billion (US$1.15 billion), a decrease from the previous trading session which saw 1.77 billion stocks change hands on a market turnover of NT$44.48 billion (US$1.81 billion).

Three of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with electrical shares moving up the most at 0.5 percent, followed by cement stocks and textile issues, both at 0.3 percent. Foodstuff shares remained unchanged.

The other major categories posted losses, with pulp and paper issues moving down the most at 2.3 percent, followed by plastics and chemical shares at 0.5 percent, construction stocks at 0.4 percent, and bank and insurance shares at 0.1 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 286 to 206, with 92 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC EXPRESSES REGRET OVER BEIJING'S MIXING POLITICS WITH SPORTS

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) issued a press release Tuesday expressing its deep regret over mainland China's failure to separate politics from sports.

The council, which charts Taiwan's policy toward mainland China, issued the press statement after mainland China demanded that Republic of China Minister of Education Ovid Tzeng enter Beijing with a "Taiwan compatriot entry permit" to attend the opening ceremony for the World University Games (WUC) scheduled for Aug. 22-Sept. 1.
The MAC statement said that since mainland Chinese WUC organizers had issued a VIP card to Tzeng, Beijing authorities should not have rejected Tzeng's use of the card to gain entry into the country.

Tzeng, who was originally scheduled to leave for Beijing Tuesday, has canceled his mainland travel plan as he said he felt that Beijing's demand that he use a "Taiwan compatriot entry permit" was a deliberate attempt to downgrade the ROC's status.
The "Taiwan compatriot entry permit" is a special travel paper issued by mainland Chinese authorities to prospective ROC visitors.
The MAC said it supports Tzeng's decision to cancel his mainland travel plan to safeguard national dignity.
"We feel regret over Beijing's failure to let `sports be sports and politics be politics,'" the MAC said in its press release.

The ROC has sent a delegation of athletes to take part in the World University Games, the first major international sports event to be hosted by Beijing since it won the right to host the 2008 Olympic Games last month.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock index futures market were higher on Tuesday, as Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index futures for September moved up 24 points to close at 4,566, with 10,098 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for October remained unchanged at 4,575, with 35 contracts traded. No transactions were reported for other months.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Tuesday at 4,542 for September, 4,575 for October, 4,513 for December, 4,527 for next March, and 4,493 for next June.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, reported mixed results.
September TE futures moved up 1.2 points to close at 234.5, with 1,201 contract transactions, while October TE futures decreased 1.75 points to finish at 231.1, with only one contract traded.
December TE futures edged down 0.2 points to finish at 233.9, also with only one contract traded. No transactions were recorded for other months.
September TF futures gained 0.8 points to finish at 587.2, with 736 contract transactions, while October TF futures fell 15.6 points to close at 580, with two contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: DRAM MANUFACTURERS FACING SLUGGISH SALES IN NEXT TWO YEARS

TEXT.P: Oversupply and falling prices have forced down the production value of DRAM (dynamic random-access memory) and global production value this year will only reach US$14.2 billion, as compared with US$29 billion the previous year, according to an industrial source.

Chang Tung-lung, vice general manager and spokesman of Mosel Vitelic Inc., said Tuesday that DRAM manufacturers are facing the worst setback in business sales this year, and only a gradual recovery can be expected next year.
Chang said that the global production value of DRAM is expected to drop considerably this year due to large inventories of communications-related products and a global economic recession.

In the first quarter of this year, the sales value of DRAM manufacturers all over the world was 31 percent less than that of the same period last year. Moreover, the second quarter value was 28.5 percent less than that of the first quarter.

Mosel Vitelic is one of Taiwan's leading DRAM manufacturers. In the first six months of this year, it's revenues amounted to NT$6.1 billion, down 57.32 percent from NT$14.4 billion during the same period of the previous year.
Chang said that from January to June, Mosel Vitelic had a deficit before tax of NT$7.2 billion, and the deficit for the whole year of 2001 may exceed NT$10 billion.

However, he said long-term prospects for DRAM manufacturers remain positive. Starting late next year, the market is expected to recover gradually, and the global production value by 2004 is expected to reach a new peak of US$39 billion, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: PLA MILITARY DRILLS AROUND DONGSHAN ISLAND UNDER SCRUTINY: MND

TEXT.P: The Ministry of National Defense (MND) has been closely monitoring mainland China's ongoing military exercises near its southeastern coast on Dongshan Island, military spokesman Huang Suey-sheng said Tuesday.
Noting that the People's Liberation Army (PLA) has annually conducted drills around Dongshan Island, Huang said the current exercises are routine.

"We have kept a close watch on the PLA training exercises," Huang said, adding that the MND could not give any details about the content of the PLA's ongoing exercises for the sake of protecting Taiwan's intelligence security.
Huang went on to say that like the armed forces of all countries around the world, the PLA routinely conducts various kinds of training drills annually.
This year, Huang said, mainland China's official mouthpiece and Hong Kong news media have continuously given sensational coverage to the PLA's Dongshan Island exercises.

"We believe this is part of mainland China's consistent saber-rattling strategy toward Taiwan. They use their official mouthpiece to give exaggerated reports of the military live-fire war games to intimidate the people of Taiwan and try to wear them down psychologically," Huang said.

He urged local news media to refrain from dancing to the beat of their mainland Chinese counterparts and to base their reports on the PLA activities mainly on MND press releases to avoid affecting public morale.
Hong Kong's pro-Beijing Chinese-language daily Wen Wei Po reported Tuesday that the PLA will launch its largest-ever integrated military exercises around Dongshan Island Wednesday.

Quoting unnamed sources, the paper said top military leaders of mainland China's central military commission will arrive in Dongshan, near Fujian province, to watch the war games. Fujian lies opposite Taiwan.
The paper also reported in its Sunday edition that the upcoming exercises would simulate an invasion of the Taiwan-controlled Penghu islands.
Mainland Chinese fishing boats and other vessels have been given advance notice to stay out of the region and return to port, the paper said.

The military exercises, which have already lasted four months, are the largest the PLA has ever conducted in terms of scale, duration, total number of personnel involved and advanced weaponry used, the paper said, adding that some 100,000 troops have been involved.

DOC.HEADLINE: N.T. DOLLAR UP ON TAIPEI FOREX MARKET
