The local currency opened Tuesday at 34.656 and was traded between 34.575 and 34.656.
Interbank U.S. dollar trading totaled US$440 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2001 TAIPEI CHINESE FOOD FAIR TO OPEN WITH EMPHASIS ON NOODLES

TEXT.P: The twelfth Taipei Chinese Food Fair, featuring various kinds of Chinese noodles and showcasing many special dishes, will open Aug. 23 at the Taipei World Trade Center, officials of Tourism Bureau said Tuesday.

The main feature of this year's food fair is noodles, including hand-stretched noodles, northeastern Chinese noodles and southern Chinese snacks. In addition, the fair will also present Chinese and Taiwanese mushroom dishes, as well as traditional dishes said to promote good health.

At the four-day fair, chefs from Liaoning province in northeastern China will come to present an ancient Chinese royal feast called the Luming Banquet, and other traditional foods of northeastern China.
The fair will be open from 9:30 a.m. to 5 p.m. and it will end Aug. 26.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECONOMICS MINISTRY TO HELP SMALL BUSINESSES RAISE DEVELOPMENT FUND
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 21 (CNA) (By Rachael Yang) (By Lillian Lin)

TEXT.P: Taipei, Aug. 21 (CNA): The Ministry of Economic Affairs has decided to set up a "small and medium business development corporation" to help small businesses with the potential to raise capital and to seek technical cooperation possibilities.

An official of the ministry's Small and Medium Enterprise Administration, said Tuesday that small businesses in general have had difficulties raising capital, especially in times of economic recession.
Accounting for nearly 98 percent of Taiwan's enterprises, small and medium businesses are the backbone of Taiwan's economy.

To help start-ups, the Small and Medium Enterprise Administration has set up 56 small and medium enterprise development centers around the island since 1996. The centers with laboratory and training facilities are providing new companies with consultative services. As of the end of June, more than 700 start-ups in the fields of information, electronics, automation, multi-media, medical care, bio-technology and the environmental protection sectors have received services from the centers.

While funding the businesses remains a problem for many start-ups, the ministry has decided to set up a development corporation, which can make capital investments in a new business, the official said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SPENDING IN ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION LOW: CEPD

TEXT.P: Taiwan's investment in environmental protection as a ratio to its GDP (gross domestic product) is well below the levels of developed countries, the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) reported Tuesday.

Taiwan's spending for environmental protection as a ratio to the country's GDP was 0.91 percent in 1999, or US$120 for each Taiwan national, the CEPD quoted statistics compiled by the Environmental Protection Administration as saying.

Although the figure is 4.3 percentage points higher than the 1998 level, the CEPD said it is still far behind the United States' US$422 in 1994, Germany's US$310 in 1995 and South Korea's US$268 in 1997.

Analyzing Taiwan's need for natural resources and its capabilities to dispose of waste based on a set of measures devised by the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development, the CEPD said Taiwan's emissions of carbon dioxide are relatively higher than those of other countries and called it an indication that the island should develop low carbon emission industries.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER RECEIVES PARAGUAY'S FOREIGN MINISTER

TEXT.P: Republic of China Premier Chang Chun-hsiung reiterated Tuesday that the ROC government will abide by the memorandum of trade and investment signed by the ROC and Paraguay to further cement the established ties between Taipei and Asuncion.
Premier Chang made the promise while meeting with visiting Paraguayan Foreign Minister Jose Antonio Moreno Ruffinelli at the Executive Yuan Tuesday morning.

Chang, on behalf of the ROC government and people, extended his warm welcome to Moreno and expressed his gratitude for the foreign minister's contributions to promoting relations between the two countries and his support for the ROC's bids for membership in international organizations.
Moreno said that the establishment of relations between the ROC and Paraguay was not based on material interests but on the common ideas of freedom and democracy.

Facing stiff economic challenges in the Southern Cone Common Market (MERCOSUL), in which Paraguay is one of the founding countries, Paraguay is trying to open its foreign markets, including those in Southeast Asian countries, Moreno said.

The Paraguayan government attached importance to the ROC-Paraguay Trade and Investment Memorandum signed between ROC President Chen Shui-bian and Paraguayan President Luis Angel Gonzalez Macchi during President Chen's last visit to Paraguay in June this year, Moreno said.

The Paraguayan diplomatic head also expressed his hope that the ROC and Paraguay will strengthen cooperation on economic and trade issues to help Paraguay tap into the Asian market. Moreno also said that the Paraguayan government has mapped out economic development strategies to be based on agriculture and industry.

Moreno arrived in Taipei Monday for a weeklong visit. During his stay in Taiwan, Moreno will be received by President Chen and call on ROC government officials, including Minister of Foreign Affairs Tien Hung-mao. He will also visit economic and cultural establishments before concluding his visit on Aug. 25.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT VOWS TO PUSH FOR INTERMINISTERIAL RESOURCES INTEGRATION

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Tuesday he will push the Cabinet to do more to integrate the resources of various government departments to upgrade the nation's overall competitiveness.

Chen made the comment while attending a ceremony marking the delivery of the 100th empennage, or airplane tail, by Taiwan's state-owned Aerospace Industry Development Corp. (AIDC) to Boeing Co. of the United States.

Addressing the ceremony held at the AIDC factory in Shalu in the central county of Taichung, Chen said the AIDC is responsible for upgrading the performance and combat capability of locally developed defense fighter aircraft as well as the island's civil aviation technology.

"Against this backdrop, the AIDC faces difficult challenges and needs the support of all relevant government agencies," Chen said, adding that integration of the resources of various government departments is critical to the AIDC's operations and the development of the domestic civil aviation industry.

The AIDC, Taiwan's only aircraft manufacturer, was originally the Republic of China's military manufacturing arm. It developed and produced the ROC Air Force's Ching-kuo Indigenous Defense Fighters (IDFs). As part of the government's efforts to expand the AIDC's role in the development of the civil aviation industry, the AIDC was reorganized into a corporate-style enterprise under the Ministry of Economic Affairs a few years ago.
President Chen said he is pleased to see the AIDC cooperating with Boeing and other major foreign aerospace companies in producing commercial aircraft, helicopters and transport aircraft.

The AIDC is one of the 15 companies in nine countries, including Australia, Canada and Germany, to cooperate with Boeing in developing the B717-200 twin-engine, 100-seat passenger plane. Boeing plans to produce a total of 600 B717-200s and has so far secured orders for 297 planes. The AIDC is responsible for manufacturing the aircraft's empennage.
The 100th empennage delivery ceremony started with President Chen and Boeing representative Ralph Adams slowly unveiling a red satin cloth covering an empennage.

Minister of Economic Affairs Lin Hsin-yi, Deputy Secretary-General to the President Eugene Chien, Taichung County Magistrate Liao Yung-lai and other government officials and elected representatives also attended the ceremony.

Chen said the cooperative project with Boeing indicates the AIDC's determination to move toward globalization and corporate-style operations in addition to continuing its role in manufacturing military planes.
Chen further said that the government is determined to promote the privatization of the AIDC to upgrade its operational efficiency and competitiveness in the global aerospace market.

"I hope AIDC management personnel will adopt flexible strategies and use wisdom and vision to lead the company to realize its goal of becoming a world-class aerospace company and help boost the development of our aviation industry," the president added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPOWER WIND TURBINES ON PENGHU BEGIN COMMERCIAL PRODUCTION

TEXT.P: Two wind turbines installed in the offshore island county of Penghu by the state-run Taiwan Power Company (Taipower) began generating electricity recently, in an operation that is both beneficial to Taipower and the island's environment.

Taking advantage of Penghu's year-round strong winds, Taipower invested NT$150 million (US$4.34 million) in the windmill plant in Penghu's Chungtunyu township, installing four wind turbines which are expected to have a combined generation capacity of 2,400 kilowatts, according to Taipower officials.

The first two turbines became operational in August -- ahead of schedule -- while the third and fourth are expected to begin commercial production in September, said Chen Hsin-cheng, director of the plant.

The four horizontal axis wind turbines, using German-made ENERCON turbines, are expected to lower Taipower's costs of electricity generation in Penghu by NT$5 per kilowatt/hour, substantively cutting the losses that Taipower has incurred over the past decades when it used diesel to generate power in the offshore county.

Until recently, Taipower has spent NT$8 for each KWH of electricity that the company generates in Penghu, but has sold the power to Penghu households and other electricity users at an average rate of NT$2.2 per KWH, resulting in Taiwan's sole power supplier losing NT$1 billion per year, according to Chen.
In comparison, wind power costs Taipower only NT$3 for each KWH of electricity.
The windmills have the additional benefit of being environmentally "clean" and producing none of the air pollution caused by the diesel-powered plant on the island.
The four white wind turbines, located on the yellow sand beach of Chungtunyu, will also be a tourism attraction, Chen added.

DOC.HEADLINE: ENGLISH TAIWAN WEBSITES SURPASS 120,000: TWNIC

TEXT.P: The number of Taiwan-based websites with English-language domain names had reached 121,945 as of July 21, an official of the non-profit Taiwan Network Information Center (TWNIC) said Tuesday.
TWNIC Chairman Chen Wen-sheng added that the number is increasing in a rate of between 1,000 and 1,500 per month.

According to Chen, more than 70 percent of the total, or 88,840 websites, are registered with the ".com.tw" suffix, ahead of 3,280 websites with ".org.tw," 1,328 with ".net. tw," 22,992 with ".idv.tw," 1,498 with ".gov.tw," and 4,007 with ".edu.tw."
As of the end of July, there were 28,953 local websites registered with a Chinese domain name, he added, noting that only 50 percent of these websites are actually operating.
According to Chen, the TWNIC will launch a series of activities in September to attract more businesses to apply for registration in both Chinese and English ".tw" domain names.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. CONGRESSMAN TO VISIT ROC

TEXT.P: Henry J. Hyde, chairman of the U.S. House of Representatives' International Relations Committee (R-IL), will lead a 25-member delegation on a visit to Taipei Wednesday.
On Thursday, Hyde and his delegation will first be given a briefing by the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) and will then meet with ROC former President Lee Teng-hui.

ROC Minister of Foreign Affairs Tien Hung-mao will then host a luncheon for the delegation before it visits President Chen Shui-bian at the Presidential Office. Premier Chang Chun-hsiung will later host a dinner for the guests.
Hyde will give a lecture Friday on "the future of China's democracy" at a downtown hotel and will wrap up his visit with a trip to the National Palace Museum.

DOC.HEADLINE: 400-PLUS UNDERPRIVILEGED GROUPS PROTEST EDAC PROPOSALS

TEXT.P: More than 400 underprivileged groups issued a joint statement Tuesday urging the government not to yield to pressure from business groups to adopt certain "unfair, unjust and short-sighted" economy boosting measures.

Representatives of labor, environmental and disabled groups from around the island, led by Liu Hsia and Huang Ching-hsien, two national policy advisers to the president, issued the joint appeal at a news conference held at the Legislative Yuan.

Liu, a handicapped writer, said she is worried that the soon-to-be-convened Economic Development Advisory Conference (EDAC) will be dominated by commerce and industry delegates and will reach conclusions in their favor at the expense of the interests of the underprivileged and even the entire nation.

"Our petition is aimed at reminding President Chen Shui-bian to honor his campaign promises to bring hope and happiness to middle- and low-income families as well as the underprivileged," Liu said, adding that they also want to remind Chen "not to lean toward capitalism."
Huang, who concurrently serves as one the three conveners of the EDAC employment panel, said he is dismayed by many of the proposals reached at EDAC panel sessions so far.

For instance, Huang said, the EDAC cross-Taiwan Strait affairs panel has come up with a proposal to ease curbs on mainland China-bound investment, even though now is not the right time for Taiwan to relax its "go slow, be patient" policy on mainland investments.

"I'm afraid that once large local enterprises are allowed to invest in mainland China, Taiwan's unemployment rate will shoot up to 10 percent and 1 million labor families will face livelihood difficulties," he said.

The join statement issued by the 400-plus underprivileged groups pointed out that the initial EDAC proposals to suspend the stock transaction tax, halve the land value increment tax, cancel the environmental impact evaluation mechanism, reduce the number of paid holidays for laborers and freeze living subsidies for the elderly have all violated the principles of social justice.

"Those proposals, if implemented, would expand the government's budget deficits, worsen Taiwan's living environment, sacrifice welfare services for senior citizens and lower labor working conditions," the joint statement said.

It demanded that the Chen administration refrain from accepting the demands of the island vested interest business groups to avoid hindering Taiwan's long-term development and the establishment of a sound social security system.
The joint petition also demanded that the government avoid pursuing economic growth at the expense of environmental protection, labor rights and social welfare services.
The proposals presented by the five EDAC preparatory panels are pending discussion and approval by the EDAC plenary sessions scheduled for Aug. 24-26.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT TO PUSH FOR INTER-PARTY MEETING AFTER EDAC

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan said Tuesday that the KMT will take actions to push for inter-party consultations after the Aug. 24-26 Economic Development Advisory Conference (EDAC).

Lien made the remarks after listening to briefings by KMT's EDAC representatives on preparations for the much-anticipated conference aimed at seeking feasible ways to revitalize Taiwan's faltering economy.

Lien said the KMT, which controls a majority in the current Legislative Yuan, will play a leading role in holding inter-party consultations on measures to substantiate consensus or conclusions to be reached at the EDAC.
Lien said inter-party consultations are needed to facilitate revisions to existing laws and legislate new statutes to pave the way for implementing EDAC consensus.
Lien said the erstwhile ruling and now opposition KMT will supervise the Democratic Progressive Party-led minority government in implementing EDAC consensus.

"We'll also push the DPP government to work out timetables for easing restrictions on mainland China-bound investments and opening direct 'three links' across the Taiwan Strait," Lien said, adding that he had discussed the issues with opposition People First Party Chairman James Soong.

In addition to proposals concerning cross-strait affairs, Lien said, the KMT will also present its views on other major economic issues at the upcoming EDAC plenary session, including upgrading industrial technology, promoting high-tech industry development, upgrading management of small- and medium-sized enterprises, ensuring sufficient supplies of water and electricity, balancing environmental protection and industrial development, revising labor laws and regulations, accelerating financial reforms and modernizing taxation and budget systems.
Meanwhile, Lien renewed his three appeals, urging the DPP government to respect the constitutional system, substantiate political accountability and promoting constructive cross-strait interaction.

DOC.HEADLINE: TRANSPORTATION MINISTER PROMOTING TOURISM IN JAPAN
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Aug. 21 (CNA) (By Mike Chang & Ed Chen)

TEXT.P: Visiting Republic of China Minister of Transport and Communications (MOTC) Yeh Chu-lan presided over a Taiwan-Japan Tourism Development Symposium that opened Tuesday in Tokyo.
In a speech at the opening ceremony, Yeh claimed that with the concerted efforts of the government and people of Taiwan, the island is being developed into an "island of tourism."

Yeh also expressed the hope that the tourism industry in the two countries will further strengthen their cooperation so as to break the one million mark of Japanese tourists visiting Taiwan this year.
She also said Taiwan and Japan should negotiate on increasing the number of flights between Taipei and Tokyo.

Discussions at the symposium centered on how to tap the tourist market, how to resolve the issues of the seat shortage on flights between Taipei and Tokyo, how to avoid price wars and how to promote capital investment in the tourist industry.
Yeh also presented citations and prizes to five Japanese tourism promoters for their contributions to bilateral tourist exchanges last year.

ROC Representative to Japan Lo Fu-chen, Japan's Taiwan Tourist Promotion Association President Yoshimi Kato, and Taiwan Visitor's Association Secretary-General Tseng Chien-shuen also spoke at the seminar.

Statistics show that 910,000 Taiwan tourists visited Japan last year, while Taiwan attracted 920,000 Japanese visitors. A total of 523,000 Japanese tourists visited Taiwan in the first half of this year and the number is expected to break the one million mark at the end of this year.

Yeh arrived in Tokyo for a five-day visit last Friday at the head of a 20-member delegation after ending a trip to Las Vegas, San Francisco and Hawaii to observe the tourist industry development in the United States.
She also visited Hakone, a renowned Japanese tourist spot, to observe the facilities and services.
Yeh and her entourage left for home Tuesday night.

DOC.HEADLINE: INVESTIGATION BUREAU GETS NEW CHIEF

TEXT.P: Justice Minister Chen Ding-nan presided over a changeover ceremony Tuesday to mark the change in leadership of the Ministry of Justice Investigation Bureau (MJIB) from Wang Kuang-yu to his successor, Yeh Sheng-mao.

Addressing the ceremony, Chen exhorted Yeh and all MJIB staff to spare no effort to root out "black gold" politics from Taiwan, help straighten out the domestic financial order and accelerate cross-border cooperation in cracking down on international crime.
Chen personally took the initiative in promoting Yeh -- previously Wang's deputy director -- to head the MJIB, Taiwan's equivalent of the U.S. Federal Bureau of Investigation.
At the change-over ceremony, Yeh vowed to do his utmost to fulfill his duties after assuming office.

Yeh, 58, a graduate of National Chungshing University's Department of Law, climbed the ladder from local investigator to the top MJIB position. He was head of the Taipei city government's anti-corruption department before becoming the MJIB deputy director.
Throughout his career, he has been noted for his low-profile, self-effacing working style, according to sources familiar with him.
Premier Chang Chun-hsiung approved Yeh's promotion in early August.
Wang, meanwhile, was appointed as a national policy adviser to President Chen Shui-bian, a post he accepted with evident pleasure.
Also addressing the changeover ceremony, Wang said: "Once you are an investigator, you are an investigator all your life," and vowed that he will be a volunteer for the MJIB for the rest of his life.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. CONGRESSMAN TO SPEAK ON DEMOCRACY DURING ROC VISIT

TEXT.P: During a trip to Taipei later this week, Henry Hyde, chairman of the U.S. House International Relations Committee, will deliver a major speech on the future of democracy in mainland China, his office said on Monday.
According an excerpt of remarks scheduled to be delivered Aug. 24, Hyde says that the United States should hold Taiwan "as an inspiring example to all of China."

"We must protect it, not because we have a duty to come to the defense of freedom, but because it provides tangible hope that the world's largest nation ... will one day enter the ranks of the free nations of the world," he says.
Hyde also says that Taiwan's "mere existence ... is proof that (Beijing's) propaganda about the impossibility of democracy in China is false."

He is due to arrive in Taipei Aug. 22 as head of a congressional delegation on the last leg of a three-nation tour. This is his first trip to the region since becoming chairman of the influential committee early this year.

An Illinois Republican, Hyde is one of a handful of surviving members of Congress who took part in the drafting of the Taiwan Relations Act in 1978-79. He was first elected to the U.S. House of Representatives in 1974.
Hyde became a household name when, as chairman of the Judiciary Committee, he presided over the House hearings on the impeachment of President Bill Clinton in 1998.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA EXPRESSES CONCERN OVER ROBBERY OF ROC OFFICIAL IN S. AFRICA

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) expressed concern Tuesday when Republic of China Deputy Representative to South Africa Shen Pai-huang was robbed on the day he arrived to assume his duties.
MOFA spokeswoman Chang Siao-yue said MOFA had already instructed the ROC Representative Office in South Africa to make a report to the South African police authorities.
In addition to expressing its deep concern, MOFA will try its best to safeguard ROC officials' lives and property, Chang said.

DOC.HEADLINE: POLITICAL RIPPLES CAUSED BY FORMER PRESIDENT KEEP SPREADING

TEXT.P: The ripples caused by former President Lee Teng-hui continued to spread within the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Tuesday, with his supporters urging lenience and patience and his critics demanding his expulsion from the party he used to head.

Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng, who is considered to be one of Lee's political allies within the KMT, cautioned the party to deal carefully with the controversy surrounding Lee in order to avoid a backlash against the party itself in the year-end legislative elections.
In an interview with a local radio station, Wang defended his claims that Lee offered to stump for KMT candidates in the elections.

Wang recounted that he and KMT Vice Chairman Wu Poh-hsiung visited Lee Aug. 10. He said he praised Lee for fostering many KMT politicians during his 12-year tenure as party chief, whereupon Lee said he would stump for his political proteges if necessary.

Wang's claims, made Aug. 15, were dismissed by the newly founded Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) the next day as a "political placebo concocted by Wang," adding that Lee would not extend his support to any candidate other than TSU nominees.
The TSU's argument was corroborated by Lee himself Monday when he spoke to reporters who inquired about his willingness to campaign for KMT candidates.
As his presence at the inauguration of the TSU Aug. 12 along with Lee, Wang said he attended the occasion in his capacity as president of the Legislative Yuan rather than as KMT vice chairman.
Support from the TSU, which has filed 39 candidates to run in the legislative election, would only help Wang's bid for re-election as legislative speaker, according to local political analysts.
He urged the KMT to take the year-end elections into account while dealing with the controversy surrounding Lee.

Meanwhile, KMT Central Standing Committee member Hung Hsiu-chu threatened to move to expel Lee from the party in the following day's meeting of the Central Standing Committee if Lee refuses to quit on his own.
She made the threat after Lee publicly identified himself with the TSU's mission and threw his weight behind the party Monday while presiding over a training camp for TSU candidates.
Hung said Lee's betrayal of the KMT is evident and that the issue has come to a head. The party, she said, can no longer turn a deaf ear to Lee's words and close its eyes to his deeds.
KMT Chairman Lien Chan, when asked for comment on Lee's purported lambasting of the KMT Monday to TSU candidates, snapped curtly: "I am not interested."
KMT Secretary-General Lin Fong-cheng's answer was more diplomatic. He said: "Our party will deal carefully with questions concerning Lee's words and deeds."

Lee's Monday speech, in which he likened himself to a worried father being forced to engage in politics after retirement because he cannot stand by and watch his "two feuding sons" undo his 12 years of work, drew flak from his political rivals Tuesday.
Legislator Chou Hsi-wei of the opposition People First Party (PFP) criticized Lee for trying to justify his desire to hang on to power by passing himself off as the country's patriarch.
The PFP whip at the Legislative Yuan said Lee -- who blamed the KMT for failing to carry out his line, or the so-called "Lee Teng-hui road" -- never actually spelled out his line clearly.
Another PFP legislator, Chin Huei-chu, said Lee's recent behavior vindicates the PFP's claims from the very beginning that he is political burden, not a political asset of the KMT.
The PFP was founded by former KMT Secretary-General James Soong after he fell out with Lee in the lead-up to the 2000 presidential election.

Yet another of Lee's political rivals, former New Party legislator Yok Mu-ming, who is to run in the year-end elections, claimed that Lee had been named by the TSU as a candidate for "legislator-at-large," positions which are meted out in proportion to the number of votes garnered by political parties in elections.

However, Yok's claims were immediately denied by TSU spokesman Su Chin-chiang, who described them as "nonsense." Su said his party has not yet named candidates for non-elected lawmakers and has never considered putting Lee on its candidate list.

DOC.HEADLINE: BMW OFFICIALS TO ARRIVE FOR TALKS ON PROCUREMENT OF AUTO PARTS

TEXT.P: German auto maker BMW will send procurement executives to Taiwan in late September to discuss the procurement of Taiwan-made auto parts and components, sources with the China External Trade Development Council (CETRA) said Tuesday.

Executives of BMW's international procurement department will be in Taiwan Sept. 24-Oct. 9 for talks with eight local auto parts and components suppliers, which have won QS9000 certificates of quality, the sources said.
If BMW reaches agreements with these suppliers, it will bring US$100 million-worth of trade opportunities per year for local auto parts and components suppliers, the officials pointed out.

DOC.HEADLINE: PANAMANIAN PARLIAMENTARIANS TO VISIT ROC

TEXT.P: A 12-member delegation from the Legislative Assembly of the Republic of Panama led by Legislator Omar Chen Chang will arrive in Taipei Wednesday for a six-day visit.
During the visit, delegation members will call on Vice President of the Legislative Yuan Yao Eng-chi, Vice Minister of Foreign Affairs Lan Chih-min and other government officials.

They will also meet with members of the Association of Legislators of the Central American Countries and the Republic of China, and visit several cultural and economic establishments before departing Aug. 27.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP, NP VOICE SUPPORT FOR KMT-PROPOSED POLITICAL CONSULTATION

TEXT.P: Opposition People First Party (PFP) and New Party (NP) officials voiced support Tuesday for a Kuomintang (KMT) proposal for a political consultation meeting after the Economic Development Advisory Conference (EDAC) is held.

Legislator Chou Hsi-wei, head of the PFP caucus at the Legislative Yuan and Legislator Ying Chih-hung, head of the NP caucus at the Legislative Yuan, said that they are happy to see that the political party consultation meeting proposed by KMT Chairman Lien Chan will be convened.

Chou pointed out that PFP Chairman James Soong had earlier proposed a similar meeting, but said that the KMT and the ruling Democratic Progressive Party had adopted a "big brother" attitude. He called on both the KMT and DPP to ditch this attitude and approach the idea of cooperation with sincerity.

DOC.HEADLINE: ACER INCORPORATED TARGETS US$4 B. IN TRANSACTIONS IN 3 YEARS

TEXT.P: The Acer Incorporated, one of Taiwan's leading computer manufacturers, has set a target of NT$150 billion (US$4.34 billion)-worth of business transactions in three years after a spate of re-organization efforts.

Acer Incorporated, the flagship of the Acer group, is scheduled to annex Acer Sertek Inc., an important export arm of Acer-made computers and related products, in early 2001. This will allow the Acer Incorporated to target its NT$150 billion goal, which would see annual profits reaching NT$14-15 billion, according to Peng Ching-ping, head of Acer Group's Finance Department.

Stan Shih, Acer group founder, CEO and chairman, said integration from within the conglomerate is one of the vital directions that will allow the group to survive cut-throat competition and to reinvigorate itself during lean years.

To begin with the integration process, Acer group began in 1999 to turn management of all of its overseas operations -- scattered throughout Europe, the United States, Southeast Asia, Latin America and mainland China -- over to a single headquarters based in Taipei.

At the end of 2000, a spate of integration kicked off, including a merger of the group's key software maker and a PC magazine, a merger of a display technology affiliate with an optoelectronics firm, the selling off of a semiconductor manufacturer and the dismantling of a computer peripherals producer.

DOC.HEADLINE: CONSTRUCTION OF RESEARCH REACTOR TO BE SUSPENDED FOR THREE YEARS

TEXT.P: A panel under the Atomic Energy Council (AEC) decided Tuesday to suspend the construction of Taiwan Research Reactor II (TRR II)..

The panel, made up of Academia Sinica President Lee Yuan-tseh and five other experts, based their decision on the government's tight budget and the fact that reinvigorating the sagging economy is its chief concern at present, according to AEC Vice Chairman Ouyang Min-sheng.

Although the panel's decision is "meant to relieve the government's financial burden," Ouyang said his council will seek to keep the budget -- about NT$200 million to NT$300 million (US$5.88 million to US$8.82 million) per year and NT$800 million to NT$1 billion (US$23.52 million to US$29.41 million) over three years -- and use it to finance research alternative energy sources.

Noting that nuclear research has already taken deep root in Taiwan, Ouyang said his council hopes to use the budget to help the Institute of Nuclear Energy Research under the AEC to adjust its studies and keep its nuclear researchers in the field.
The TRR II budget for this year -- NT$38 million (US$1.11 million) -- has already been reimbursed and will be used to demolish the island's original research reactor, Ouyang said.

The original research reactor, purchased from Canada in 1969 for scientific research, was forced to shut down by Washington in 1988 after it was found to have been used secretly for military purposes.
The Institute of Nuclear Energy Research came up with a plan in 1990 to improve the TRR II reactor rather than demolish it.

The plan, which passed the National Science Council in 1998 and was approved by the Executive Yuan the same year, envisioned the reconstruction of the reactor in seven years at a cost of NT$3.28 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN BEATS HONDURAS IN WILLIAM JONES CUP BASKETBALL INVITATIONAL

TEXT.P: Chinese Taipei beat Honduras 90-77 Tuesday to take its fifth consecutive victory in the 24th William Jones Cup Basketball Invitational now being held in Fengshan City, Kaohsiung County.
In another two games held earlier in the day, Canada defeated Mongolia 97-64 and South Korea beat the Philippines 97-88.
Score standings as of Tuesday were:
Team W. L. Chinese Taipei 5 0 South Korea 5 0 Russia 4 0 Philippines 3 2 Honduras 1 3 Canada 1 4 Mongolia 0 5 South Africa 0 5

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN WINS 2 CONSECUTIVE LITTLE LEAGUE VICTORIES
DOC.DATELINE: Mexico City, Aug. 20 (CNA) (By Chen Chang-hui & Ed Chen)

TEXT.P: Chinese Taipei trounced the United States 12-1 Monday at the International Little League Championship Tournament in Mexico City.

The Chinese Taipei nine scored its first point at the top of the second inning and had gained nine points by the top of the fourth. It added two more points at the top of the seventh inning, while the U.S. team had to be content with one point in the second half of the third.
Chinese Taipei collected 11 safe hits, including two home runs by Tsai Wei-ling and Feng Hsiao-kang.
In another game between Chinese Taipei and Puerto Rica later in the day, the Chinese Taipei nine blanked the Puerto Rican team 3-0.
Chinese Taipei has so far chalked up four wins and one loss in the children's baseball competition. The team was scheduled to take on Honduras Tuesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINESE TAIPEI BEATS PERU IN UNIVERSIADE WOMEN'S BASKETBALL

TEXT.P: Chinese Taipei beat Peru 89-66 in the women's basketball at the World University Games Tuesday, in a prelude to the games proper, which were slated to officially begin Wednesday.
Chinese Taipei, which outgunned Peru, fielded all 12 of its squad in turn as a warm-up exercise for the Universiade.
It led the first half 43-27. But Peru closed the gap late in the second half and once came within 7 points of Chinese Taipei.
Although Chinese Taipei won the game, it committed 19 faults and failed to give a good account of itself, according to the coach.
The Universiade has brought together 20 basketball teams from around the world that will be competing in four groups.

DOC.HEADLINE: MANUFACTURING SECTOR TO CUT 170,000 WORKERS AFTER TAIWAN'S WTO ENTRY

TEXT.P: Taiwan's imminent entry into the World Trade Organization (WTO) is expected to reduce the manufacturing industries' demand for workers by 170,000, Minister of Economic Affairs Lin Hsin-yi said Tuesday.
Lin made remarks at a meeting of the Taiwan Confectionery, Biscuit and Floury Food Association, in which Lin asked association members to globalize in anticipation of the country's entry into WTO.
As a result, Lin said, the local manufacturing industry may have to lay off 170,000 workers after WTO entry.

According to a prediction by the Ministry of Economic Affairs, the contribution of the manufacturing sector to the nation's gross domestic product (GDP) will continue to decline from present 27 percent to 21 percent after the WTO entry, while the service industry is expected to contribute more to the GDP, said Lin.
He further predicted that the manufacturing sector's contribution to the GDP will continue to decline to between 15 percent and 20 percent.

Lin added that the increase of Taiwan's outbound investment and the decrease of inbound investment in the manufacturing sector has caused an imbalance in the demand and supply of the labor market in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, Aug. 21, or the fourth day of the seventh month of the Year of the Snake according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1834: Samuel Pierpoint Langley, American astronomer and aviation pioneer, is born. He built the first successful heavier-than-air flying machines in 1896.
1849: Amaral, the Portuguese governor of Macao, is assassinated for practicing anti-Chinese politics.
1868: Ten thousand Chinese plunder the China Inland Mission as the Taiping Rebellion gathers momentum.
1910: Korea is formally annexed by Japan after five years as a Japanese protectorate.
1911: Leonardo da Vinci's Mona Lisa, one of the world's most famous paintings, is stolen from the Louvre in Paris. It was returned two years later.
1919: Some 5,000 Jews are massacred in the Ukraine.
1932: Japanese troops attack Jehol in northern China.
1937: The Chinese Communist Party issues a statement calling on the people to obey the National government and join the War of Resistance Against Japan, and changes its "Red Army" into the Eighth Army.
1941: German troops reach the outskirts of Leningrad.
1942: Madame Chiang Kai-shek leaves for the United States for a visit at the invitation of President Franklin D. Roosevelt. FDR announced on March 30 the establishment of the Pacific War Council in Washington, comprised of China, the United States, the United Kingdom, New Zealand, Australia, Canada and the Netherlands.
1968: Warsaw Pact tanks enter Prague, the Czech capital, to crush the first flowering of Alexander Dubcek's reforms.
1973: Henry Kissinger is named U.S. secretary of state, succeeding William Rogers.
1981: A Boeing 737 passenger plane owned by the Far East Air Transport Corp. crashes near Miaoli in central Taiwan, killing all 110 people aboard.
1983: China Airlines suspends its CI811 flight to Manila on orders of the Philippine civil aviation authorities. Manila had warned international airlines not to allow opposition leader Benigno Aquino to board their aircraft for a return to the Philippines on the grounds that he did not have legal travel papers.
Aquino was gunned down on Aug. 21 while soldiers were escorting him from his China Airlines flight from Taipei upon his return to Manila after three years of self-exile in the United States.
1985: The Executive Yuan approves the appointment by President Chiang Ching-kuo of Ronald H. C. Ho (Ho Hsien-chung) as the new finance political vice minister.
1985: A British Airtour Boeing 747 bound for Corfu catches fire at Manchester Airport shortly after engine failure had forced the pilot to abandon the takeoff. The fire killed 54 people aboard.
1986: Francisco Zepeda Andino, the new Honduran ambassador to the Republic of China, presents his credentials to President Chiang Ching-kuo.
1986: Wang Han successfully swims across the Strait of Gibraltar, becoming the first Chinese person to do so.
1986: Typhoon Wayne blasts across central and southern Taiwan and the Pescadores (Penghu), killing or injuring 256 people and causing property losses estimated at NT$11.5 billion. The typhoon damage is the heaviest in the past twenty years. The Executive Yuan allocates NT$1 billion to help victims.
1995: The KMT convenes its 14th National Congress and Lee Teng-hui, party chairman, announces he will seek the party's presidential nomination. Lin Yang-kang, a KMT vice chairman, declares his intention not to seek the party's nomination and to instead run as an independent.
1996: The 61-nation Conference on Disarmament in Geneva ends in failure after India blocked an agreement on a Comprehensive Nuclear Test Ban Treaty.
1999: A China Airlines passenger plane with 315 on board crash-lands at Chek Lap Kok airport in Hong Kong during a typhoon, killing two and injuring 211.
2000: Opposition People First Party Chairman James Soong says that it is still too early to talk about overhauling the Guidelines for National Unification as the government has yet to demonstrate consistency regarding its cross-strait policies.
2000: Burkina Faso President Blaise Compaore decorades visiting ROC President Chen Shui-bian with the Order of Grande Croix in recognition of his contribution to promoting bilateral ties.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "If another man succeeds through one effort, use a hundred efforts. If another man succeeds though ten efforts, use a thousand efforts. Let a man really proceed in this manner, and, though dull, he will surely become intelligent; though weak, he will surely become strong."

DOC.HEADLINE: BUSINESSES SAY OKINAWA MAY SERVE AS ENTREPOT FOR CROSS-STRAIT TRADE

TEXT.P: Members from Taiwan's business sector suggested Wednesday that the Republic of China government use Okinawa as a transshipment point to help open direct cross-strait air links, said Huang Ho-ming, chairman of the non-profit Institute for Information Industry.

Some business leaders in Taiwan have suggested that the government consider using Japan's Okinawa prefecture as a midway point between Taiwan and mainland China to facilitate the opening of direct air links across the Taiwan Strait without having the ROC's sovereignty compromised, Huang said.

Addressing a luncheon meeting held by the Taipei-based European Council of Commerce and Trade (ECCT), Huang said the Okinawa idea is one of the suggestions that the domestic business sector offered to the government amid increased calls from the administration and the ruling Democratic Progressive Party to ease curbs on trade with mainland China and to phase out the "no haste, be patient" trade policy.

Huang said, however, that Taiwan should expect to face problems from Beijing on direct air links despite Taiwan's open-mindedness. Beijing insists that Taiwan is within mainland China's aviation information control zone -- an advocacy tantamount to a proclamation that Beijing has sovereignty over Taiwan, a concept unacceptable to Taipei.

Unconfirmed sources reported that Wang Fuqing, deputy director of the Taiwan Affairs Office under Beijing's State Council, said Tuesday in Fuzhou that direct trade, travel and communications links across the Taiwan Strait can be launched very soon, "as long as the 'three links' activities are considered as internal affairs and conducted between businesses in a private capacity."

Huang noted that using Okinawa as a middle ground -- Taiwan carriers flying first to Okinawa and from there heading to cities in mainland China -- would involve two aviation information control zones, with Taiwan's sovereignty remaining intact.
It could be a pragmatic approach to skirt the current political deadlock over the direct air links issue, Huang added.
Huang solicited support for the Okinawa concept from foreign businesses in Taiwan, including members of the ECCT.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK PRICES DOWN BY 75.21 POINTS

Market turnover amounted to NT$46.93 billion (US$1.36 billion).

DOC.HEADLINE: NUMBER OF FOREIGN LABORERS DROPS SHARPLY

TEXT.P: The government's foreign labor retrenchment policy has finally borne fruit after nearly a year of implementation as the total number of legal foreign workers registered a sharp decline in July, the Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) said Wednesday.
According to the latest CLA statistics, Taiwan had 326,261 alien workers at the end of July. The number marked a decrease of 3,351 from a historic high of 329,612 recorded in June.
The CLA tallies also showed that Indonesia replaced the Philippines for the first time in July as Taiwan's second largest foreign labor import source.

In terms of nationality, Thailand remained the top source of foreign labor imports in July, accounting for 139,924 or 42.89 percent of total foreign workers. Compared with June, the number of Thai workers declined 1,868.

In contrast, the number of Indonesian workers increased 1,170 to reach 89,608 in July, making up 27.47 percent of the total. Indonesians now form the backbone of foreign caregivers and housemaids in Taiwan.

The number of Philippine workers has been falling steadily since the suspension of direct flight services between Taiwan and the Philippines. CLA officials said the Philippines representative office's interference with labor-management disputes was also a major reason behind the decrease in Filipinos.
At the end of July, 85,787 Philippine nationals were working in Taiwan, down 2,986 from June. The number marked an even greater decline from a peak of 110,000 recorded not long ago.
Taiwan began to import blue-collar workers from Vietnam last year and the number of Vietnamese laborers had already reached 10,869 by the end of July.
According to CLA tallies, 73 Malaysian nationals still worked in Taiwan at the end of July. Malaysia itself faces labor shortage problems.

Of all foreign workers, 105,559 were working as caregivers in July; 57,297 were working for major investment projects in the manufacturing sector; and 33,026 were working for large infrastructure construction projects.

Taipei, Aug. 22 (CNA) Shares prices opened low and closed even lower on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) on Wednesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 75.21 points to close at 4,487.52.
Affected by a plunge in U.S. stock prices, the bourse opened at 4,509.03, and continued to go down due to heavy selling pressure. The index fluctuated between 4,575.44 and 4,483.04.

Only one of the eight major stock categories lost ground, with electrical shares moving down 3.2 percent.
The other major categories posted gains, with textile issues moving up the most at 2.7 percent, followed by construction stocks at 1.9 percent, plastics and chemical shares at 1.7 percent, foodstuffs stocks and bank and insurance shares, both at 1.1 percent, cement stocks and pulp and paper issues, both at 0.4 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 249 to 248, with 94 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. RESEARCHER ADVOCATES CHEN'S ATTENDANCE AT SHANGHAI APEC MEETING

TEXT.P: Both the U.S. Congress and the Bush administration should encourage the Communist Chinese leadership to invite Taiwan's president, Chen Shui-bian, to attend the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation forum's Shanghai summit, according to a U.S. researcher.

In an analysis titled "China-Taiwan dialogue could begin at the APEC summit," John J. Tkacik Jr., a research fellow in China policy in the Asian Studies Center at The Heritage Foundation, wrote that, "This could be an early sign that the United States must prepare for a prolonged period of firmness with China if peace and stability in the Pacific are to be preserved."
Beijing's continued insistence on barring Chen's attendance could be construed as evidence that Communist China may opt to use force to impose its will in the Taiwan Strait, Tkacik said.

Given the importance of Taiwan to both the national security and economic interests of the United States, Rep. Gary Ackerman (D-N.Y.) submitted House Concurrent Resolution 194 in late July expressing the sentiments of Congress to encourage full participation in the APEC summit by President Chen.

Tkacik pointed out that by denying Chen a chance to attend the Shanghai summit, "China is missing an historic opportunity to begin substantive dialogue with its neighbor across the Taiwan Strait. The forum could begin a process of defusing a half-century of pent-up tension in one of the world's most dangerous flash points."

The Ackerman resolution could provide a crucial push to break the stalemate between mainland China and Taiwan, promoting "direct dialogue, without precondition, between leaders on both sides of the Taiwan Strait." The resolution, which will be voted on in early September, acknowledges that President Chen's attendance at the summit would be "a constructive step" and an ideal starting point for peaceful cross-strait dialogue -- a key objective of the United States' China policy in the administrations of both Bill Clinton and George W. Bush, he said.

In September, a representative of President Bush will visit Beijing to review the agenda for a forthcoming visit by the U.S. president. With the House resolution in hand, that envoy could present an authoritative demarche urging Communist China's leadership to be open to the possibility of direct dialogue without precondition with Taiwan's leader about their points of disagreement and encourage Beijing's leaders to invite the democratically elected leader of the people of Taiwan to the APEC Shanghai summit, Tkacik said .

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN EXPORT ORDERS POST DOUBLE-DIGIT FALL IN JULY

TEXT.P: Taiwan's export orders received in July slid 16.8 percent year-on-year to US$10.80 billion as a result of global and domestic sluggishness, sources from the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) reported Wednesday.

The country's industrial output also declined in July -- down 10.39 percent year-on-year -- due to a drastic fall in the export trade, said Chang Yao-tsung, director-general of the MOEA Statistics Department.

Export orders received by Taiwan's electronics manufacturing sector -- the backbone of the island's foreign exchange reserves-earning export trade system -- plummeted by a more alarming rate of 36.17 percent over the year-earlier levels, which was also the largest fall in this area in history, according to MOEA tallies.

Chang attributed the unprecedented fall in the electronics export sector in July mainly to a high comparison basis set in July 2000, when most electronics companies posted growth ranging from 60 percent to 80 percent.
Chang forecast that the sharp decline in export orders may ease in the last two quarters this year, but it will still rely on a rebound of domestic consumption and demand to drive any recovery.
He does not think the U.S. Fed's interest rates cut will have an immediate positive impact on Taiwan's export trade. The U.S. Fed has cut rates seven times this year.
The slowing economies in Japan and Europe will not contribute to help Taiwan's exports pick up either, he added.

Meanwhile, the Ministry of Finance (MOF) estimated Wednesday that Taiwan's export and import trade in August would shrink 25 percent and 30 percent, respectively, from the year-earlier levels, marking the largest single-month fall in history.

According to the latest MOF statistics, Taiwan exported US$5.54 billion worth of products in the Aug. 1-17 period, while importing US$5.09 billion worth of goods from abroad, down 24.9 percent and 27.7 percent, respectively from the corresponding period in 2000.
MOF officials forecast that Taiwan's export trade will decline 14.9 percent this year while import trade could fall 19.1 percent as a result of the global economic downturn.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN PORTS HANDLING FEWER CONTAINERS

TEXT.P: Due to dwindling import and export trade resulting from the global economic downturn, the total number of cargo containers handled by Taiwan ports dropped in the first half of this year, according to statistics released recently by the government.

Tallies compiled by the Cabinet-level Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) show that the total number of cargo containers loaded and unloaded by Taiwan's Keelung, Taichung and Kaohsiung ports in the first six months fell by 0.5 percent from the year-earlier level.

According to the DGBAS, the three ports handled a total of 5.12 TEUs (twenty-foot equivalent units) in the first half, 3.69 million of which were handled by Kaohsiung, up 2.1 percentage points from a year ago, while the number of TEUs handled by Keelung and Taichung were down 6.3 percent and 7 percent, respectively, year-on-year.

The decline in the first half is in stark contrast to growth in the past, such as an annual increase of 10.1 percent for 1999 and 7.7 percent for 2000, business sources said, attributing the fall to the sluggish traditional industries which used to form the bulk of container cargoes. They warned that a severe challenge is awaiting the local industry.

During the same six-month period, the number of import and export containers handled by the three major Taiwan ports also declined by 5 percent and 4.5 percent, respectively, from a year ago, owing to the fact that Taiwan's export and import sectors shrank by 10.8 percent and 16.9 percent, respectively.

DOC.HEADLINE: HOUSEHOLD LAW TO BE REVISED TO CANCEL FINGERPRINT REQUIREMENT

TEXT.P: The Cabinet approved a draft revision to the existing household registration law Wednesday to cancel a regulation that requires Republic of China nationals aged over 14 to have their fingerprints taken while applying for ID cards.
The Cabinet passed the draft amendment at its weekly meeting. The revision bill will then be referred to the Legislative Yuan for screening and approval.

In preparation for a nationwide identification card renewal plan, the current Democratic Progressive Party-led administration has been evaluating since its inauguration the appropriateness of the existing fingerprinting requirement.
Speaking at the Cabinet meeting, Premier Chang Chun-hsiung said the compulsory fingerprint regulation will be scrapped to protect human rights.
The Cabinet issued a news release after its weekly meeting to further explain reasons behind its decision.

First and foremost, the news statement said, it has become dubious or questionable whether the establishment of a fingerprint databank can truly facilitate criminal investigations and crime prevention now that sophisticated criminal activities have become prevalent and that few criminals would leave fingerprints at crime scenes.

Second, the news release said it seems to be out of proportion to require all ROC nationals aged over 14 to have their fingerprints taken simply for facilitating determination of the identities of a few unidentified corpses or homeless people.

Third, the statement said that as fingerprints are a personal feature, it should be protected under Article 22 of the ROC Constitution and other relevant laws that protect personal information or privacy.

The statement further said the reasonableness of forcing ordinary citizens to be fingerprinted while applying for ID cards is doubtful as the current household registration law has not prescribed clear rules governing the purposes and scope of the use of the fingerprints.
Finally, the statement said that at present, only a few countries in the world demand that all of its people have their fingerprints taken and no advanced countries have implemented such a system.
"If we continue this practice, our national image may be undermined," the statement added.
