DOC.HEADLINE: LIEN DIRECTS KMT TO STUDY HOW TO DEAL WITH FORMER PARTY HEAD

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan on Wednesday instructed the party's Evaluation and Disciplinary Committee to study how to deal with former KMT Chairman Lee Teng-hui for his apparent "betrayal" of the KMT.

Lien instructed that the situation regarding Lee be handled in accordance with "party rules," saying that no member of the party, irrespective of their position, should be treated as an exception to the system. He also said that the KMT "should do whatever it must" to protect the interests of the party.

Wednesday was the first time that Lien has given specific instructions concerning Lee, who said earlier this month that he wanted to form a political party to help the present minority government of President Chen Shui-bian win enough seats in the year-end legislative elections to gain a stable majority.

Lee further raised the ire of KMT members after he publicly identified himself with the mission of the newly established Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) party, and threw his weight behind the TSU Monday while presiding over a political workshop for TSU legislative candidates.

Despite Lee's apparent drift from the KMT, decision-makers within the party have taken a passive approach toward Lee, continuing to shelve proposals that Lee be reprimanded for his presence at the inauguration of the TSU on Aug. 12 -- a party founded mainly by Lee's followers and supporters -- on the grounds that any action that could mar the image and effectiveness of the party should be seriously studied before being put into action.

During a KMT Central Standing Committee (CSC) meeting held Wednesday, CSC member Hung Hsiu-chu, who called for Lee's expulsion for his role in forming the TSU, said "cool treatment" of the Lee case is no longer tolerable. She demanded that a timetable be set to carry out Lien's instructions regarding Lee.

DOC.HEADLINE: MORE THAN 70% BACK OPENING OF DIRECT 'THREE LINKS': POLL

TEXT.P: The majority of the people of Taiwan support the proposal to open direct trade, mail and transportation links between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, according to the results of an opinion poll released Wednesday.

The telephone poll of 998 randomly selected adult residents, conducted by the Open magazine Aug. 20-21, found that more than 70 percent of the respondents threw their support behind the proposal to open the direct cross-strait "three links."
The reasons cited by the "three links" proponents included improving cross-strait relations and increasing job opportunities, according to the survey.

In contrast, about 20 percent of those interviewed said they opposed the "three links" overture out of their worries that the opening measure could threaten Taiwan's national security and accelerate capital outflow.
Nearly 50 percent said they believe that the opening of direct "three links" would speed up unification of the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, while 42.4 percent said they think otherwise.

According to the poll, 40 percent thought that mainland China was the biggest obstacle to implementing the "three links" proposal; 31.2 percent said Taiwan's ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) should take the greatest blame for slow progress in promoting the open-door policy; and 10.4 percent said Taiwan's opposition parties should be blamed.
Meanwhile, 50 percent of survey respondents gave a thumbs-up to the proposal to ease the "go slow, be patient" policy on mainland China-bound investment.
The poll has a margin of error of 3.1 percent.

Both the "three links" and cross-strait investment curbs relaxation plans will be further discussed at the Economic Development Advisory Conference (EDAC) scheduled for Aug. 24-26. So long as all EDAC delegates can forge consensus on the two "open-door" measures, the DPP government has promised to implement them.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN-JAPAN PARLIAMENTARIANS AMITY ALLIANCE TO BE FORMED IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: A Taiwan-Japan Parliamentarians Amity Alliance aimed at strengthening relations between Taiwan and Japan will be formally founded Friday in Taipei.

Legislator Lin Chung-mo of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), the president of Taiwan's chapter of the alliance, said that the organization will provide an another communication channel for Taiwan and Japan.
The alliance will be made up of 44 legislators from the ROC and 28 Japanese parliamentarians.
President of the Legislative Yuan Wang Jin-pyng will be invited to serve as honorary president of the alliance's Taiwan chapter, Lin said.

A nine-member Japanese parliamentary mission, which will be led by Koki Kobayashi (LDP), a member of the Lower House and concurrently president of Japan chapter, is scheduled to arrive in Taipei Thursday.

In addition to attending the founding ceremony of the alliance, the Japanese parliamentarians will call on President Chen Shui-bian at the Presidential Office shortly upon their arrival Thursday afternoon. They will also call on former President Lee Teng-hui Friday afternoon.
The forming ceremony will be held at 9:30 a.m. Friday at the Ambassador Hotel in Taipei and a gala party will be held in the evening.
The alliance will be the third parliamentary organization established to promote relations between Taiwan and Japan.
The partisan Japan-ROC Dietmen Council was the first parliamentary body established to promote relations between the two countries after Japan switched diplomatic ties from Taipei to Beijing in 1972.
The Japan-Taiwan Dietmen Amity Association was the second parliamentary body and was founded in April this year by Japan's opposition Democratic Party.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN BANKS DEFINED AS `FOREIGN' BY MAINLAND CHINA: OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: Vice Finance Minister Sean Chen said Wednesday that monetary institutions in Taiwan, Hong Kong and Macao are defined in Beijing's regulatory provisions for foreign monetary institutions as "foreign."

Chen was referring to a report from Beijing that Shi Jiliang, vice governor of the People's Bank of China, spoke ambiguously Tuesday about the status of Taiwan banks' representative offices in the mainland.

According to a report by the Commercial Times, Shi said in a meeting with bankers from Taipei that Beijing will promulgate in early September regulatory provisions for representative offices of Taiwan banks in the mainland. Such offices will be entitled to privileges listed in the new provisions only if they accept the "one China" principle.

Shi added, however, that after mainland China is admitted into the World Trade Organization, Taiwan banks applying for permission to set up representative offices will be treated as foreign investors.

Chen said that the "one China" principle was brought up by Shi during a "social conversation" and that he would prefer to stick to the regulations in black and white, whereby the status of Taiwan monetary institutions in the mainland is clearly defined as foreign investors.

He said that operations of Taiwan banks' representative offices in the mainland will be confined to understanding the market situation and added that the Finance Ministry's screening of applications will not be affected by Shi's opinions.

DOC.HEADLINE: NP BACKS CROSS-PARTY TALKS TO IMPLEMENT EDAC CONSENSUS

TEXT.P: Members of the opposition New Party (NP) welcomed Wednesday a proposed inter-party summit to help implement consensus reached in the upcoming Economic Development Advisory Conference (EDAC).
NP officials said that the party is willing to take part in such talks to create a positive climate among Taiwan's various political parties.
NP members, including Legislator Lai Shyh-bao and Taipei City Councilor Fei Hung-tai -- who are also EDAC participants -- made the remarks at a news conference.

Lai said the NP supports the proposal raised by the main opposition Kuomintang and is in favor of carrying out EDAC consensus through the establishment of a set of mechanisms. He pointed out that the NP will be willing to participate in cross-party negotiations on the issue and said that a positive relationship among different political parties would be a boon to the people.
The NP members also made public the following 10 policies in the news conference to demonstrate the party's stance with regard to the EDAC:
-- Build special economic zones and establish free-trade zones;
-- Create "an elite" government;
-- Working conditions for laborers must be based on labor-management negotiations;
-- Labor-management talks must be held with labor unions;
-- Set up a system to help mainland China-based Taiwan businessmen;
-- Recruit professional talent from mainland China and other countries;
-- Oppose tax reductions for the rich and tax increases for the poor;
-- Reopen dialogue with mainland China as soon as possible based on the so-called "1992 consensus;" and
-- Ease the "no haste, be patient" policy with regard to investment in the mainland and open direct links with the mainland.

DOC.HEADLINE: LAWMAKER CRITICIZES OFFICIALS OVER LAVISH OVERSEAS TRIPS

TEXT.P: An opposition lawmaker criticized several senior government officials Wednesday for their alleged spendthrift lavishness when they go on overseas trips.

Legislator Liu Wen-hsiung of the opposition People First Party (PFP) said that despite the government's current financial straits, some Cabinet officials did not seem to have felt the pinch and have continued to make expensive overseas visits.

According to Liu's tallies, Cabinet members have made a total of 127 overseas visits at an accumulated cost of NT$45 million (US$1.3 million) since the inauguration of the Democratic Progressive Party-led government in May 2000.

Liu said Chang Fu-mei, minister of the Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission, topped the "spendthrift" list. "Chang has made 12 overseas trips, with an aggregate travel bill of NT$5.48 million since she assumed office," Liu claimed.

Minister of Economic Affairs Lin Hsin-yi ranked second, with six overseas visits at a total cost of NT$3.92 million; followed by Lee Ming-liang, minister of the Department of Health, with four visits at an accumulated cost of NT$2.71 million.

Liu urged the Cabinet-level Research, Development and Evaluation Commission to cut the overseas travel budgets for certain ministries while compiling the government's overall budget plan for fiscal 2002. "The commission should also carefully assess the results or effects of overseas visits of senior government officials to avoid wasting public funds," he added.

Meanwhile, he lauded several senior officials for their self-restraint in making overseas trips. Those officials included Premier Chang Chun-hsiung, Vice Premier Lai Ing-jaw, Council of Labor Affairs Chairwoman Chen Chu and Minister of Justice Chen Ding-nan.

But Liu accused Minister of Transportation and Communications Yeh Chu-lan of having spent a large sum of money on clothes during her just-concluded 10-day trip to the United States and Japan, ostensibly to inspect tourist facilities and management.

He also expressed his doubts as to why the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) still had to spend about NT$1 million for Yeh and two other officials' tourism-promotion trips, since their trips were financed by their hosts.
In response, Yeh said she did not use "a penny of public funds" on her spending spree. "I used my own money for the purchases," she stressed.
MOTC officials also claimed that the ministry spent only about NT$650,000 for Yeh and the two other officials' just-concluded trips to Las Vegas, Hawaii and Japan.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'NEXT MAGAZINE' VANDALIZED

TEXT.P: The offices of a weekly magazine known for its paparazzi style of printing stories about local celebrities was vandalized Wednesday by three men wielding baseball bats.

The three men, said to be in their twenties, entered the tenth floor office of Next Magazine via the fire escape stairway and smashed glass doors and computers. None of the three made any attempt to conceal their identities.
They left the office about five minutes later without attacking any of the staff and a security camera caught the men leaving the office the same way as they entered and running away on foot.
Police sources said the vandalism was intended as a warning over an article in the latest edition of the magazine that alleges a local gangster is the owner of a local pub.

The magazine, owned by Hong Kong publisher Jimmy Lai, is known for its invasive reporting style of public figures, and it has been defendants in at least three lawsuits since its May 30 launch in Taiwan.
An editor at the magazine said that he had received threatening phone calls before Wednesday, but vowed to keep pursuing and revealing "social reality."

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PRESIDENT URGES JAPAN NOT TO GLORIFY WARLIKE PAST

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian urged Japan Wednesday to face up to its wartime atrocities and not to gloss over them.

"There is but one historic fact, and the objective fact should not be distorted or altered," Chen told a group of visiting Japanese education leaders led by Shiro Odamura, head of Takushoku University.

He also told his guests that senior Japanese leaders should take into account the feelings of their Asian neighbors before visiting a controversial shrine dedicated to Japanese war dead, including several Class-A war criminals.
It was the first time that Chen had made public comments on the Japanese textbook issue and on Japanese Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi's recent visit to the controversial Yasukuni Shrine.
On the Japanese history textbook issue, Chen said history books must honestly record historical facts and should not carry any distorted descriptions.

He further said that no one should find any reasons to justify the launching of a war because no wars can be justified or tolerated. He was referring to a controversial set of Japanese high school textbooks which give distorted accounts of Japan's role in World War II as well as its wartime atrocities in Taiwan, mainland China, South Korea and other Asian countries.
Last week, Japanese Prime Minister Koizumi visited the Yasukuni shrine, which honors 2.5 million war dead since the late 1800s, including executed war criminals from World War II.

Chen said he hopes senior Japanese officials will pay more heed to the feelings of the people of its neighboring countries before making such visits. He also urged Japan not to try to glorify its militarist past and instead work harder to promote regional peace, stability and prosperity.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA TELLS PEOPLE NOT TO BUY FALSE PASSPORTS

TEXT.P: Republic of China Foreign Ministry officials reaffirmed Wednesday that only passports carrying the words "Republic of China" and issued by the ministry are valid and recognized internationally.

The statement, issued in a press release, came following reports that some people in Taiwan have used bogus passports bearing the name "Republic of Taiwan," and have succeeded in obtaining visas from some South American countries.

The reports also claim that some people have succeeded in entering South American countries using "Republic of Taiwan" passports, while those holding "Republic of China" passports have been denied entry.

ROC Foreign Ministry spokeswoman Chang Siao-yue said the ministry could not verify the report as it had yet to see a "Republic of Taiwan" passport. However, she went on, if such a thing had occurred, it would have been the mistake of the visa officials of the foreign countries in question and would have "no political implication."

She warned local people not to believe that "Republic of Taiwan" passports are valid and emphasized that only "Republic of China" passports issued by the Foreign Ministry can offer protection to ROC nationals traveling abroad.

DOC.HEADLINE: TSMC 12-INCH WAFER PLANT COMPLETES TRIAL PRODUCTION

TEXT.P: A spokesman for Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Corporation (TSMC) said Wednesday that the company had completed trial production of its first 12-inch wafer at a plant based in the Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park.

Using the 0.15 micron process technology, TSMC -- Taiwan's leading microchip maker -- succeeded in producing 8Mb SRAMs (static random access memory chips), the spokesman said, adding that the first batch of chips all passed function inspection tests.

Monthly output volume of the plant's 12-inch silicon chips has been projected at 25,000 units, while production facilities to be installed in the plant by the end of this year will be capable of manufacturing 4,500 units per month, according to the spokesman.
TSMC President Tsai Lee-hsing said the manufacturing technology of the 12-inch silicon wafers will prevail in the chip industry because of its cheaper production costs and high quality.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINESE TAIPEI SUFFERS 1ST LOSS IN UNIVERSIADE WOMEN'S BASKETBALL
DOC.DATELINE: Beijing, Aug. 22 (CNA) (By Lee An-tung & Ed Chen)

TEXT.P: The Czech Republic defeated Chinese Taipei 107-69 Wednesday in the women's basketball event at the Universiade now being held in Beijing.
The Czech five, who lost to Chinese Taipei last year, overwhelmed the game from start to finish and led 51-26 at half time.
Chinese Taipei has so far chalked up one win and one loss at the competition.

The team will take on host mainland China Thursday. Chinese Taipei will be able to advance to the quarter-finals only if it defeats mainland China and only if the Czech team beats the host team as well.
Meanwhile, the Chinese Taipei men's volleyball team also suffered its first setback, losing 0-3 to France.
Chinese Taipei will take on South Korea Thursday. A total of 27 national teams are competing in the men's division of the volleyball tournament.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN JOB SEEKERS HAD 0.4 JOB OPPORTUNITIES IN JULY

TEXT.P: Taiwan people searching for jobs in July got an average of just 0.4 job offerings, far less than the number of job opportunities offered in the past, according to recruitment agency statistics released Wednesday.

The statistics compiled by the human resources databank "104" show that although the jobs offered in July increased by 2 percent over June, they were still insufficient for the sharp increase in the number of on-line job seekers, thus requiring every job seeker to spend an average of 32 days to find an adequate job, 6.4 days longer than in June.

The results of the survey, conducted in early August by the "104" databank among new graduates, show that 80.7 percent of them had not yet found a job. Among the new graduates who had not found a job, 30.1 percent of them said the reason was that they did not like the jobs available, while others blamed the sluggish economy and still others described themselves as incompetent.

According to the databank, most of the job openings in July were in sales, followed by computer systems, software, hardware, telecommunications, manufacturing, and engineering research and development.

Meanwhile, officials of the Cabinet-level Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) noted Wednesday that the number of job seekers registered in government job brokerage organizations in the first seven months of the year had reached 228,000, an increase of 35.4 percent over the same period of last year, while the jobs on offer totaled 232,000, a decrease of 23.4 percent over the same period of 2000.

As a result, every job seeker had an average of 1.02 job opportunities in the first seven months of the year, compared with an average of 1.8 job opportunities offered in the same period of last year.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERIOR MINISTER ATTENDS APEC WOMEN'S LEADERS MEETING IN BEIJING
DOC.DATELINE: Beijing, Aug. 22 (CNA) (By Lee An-tung and David Hsu)

TEXT.P: Republic of China Minister of the Interior Chang Po-ya, along with a 20-strong delegation, attended the 2001 Women's Leaders Meeting under the framework of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum Wednesday.

The three-day meeting, taking place at Beijing's Great Hall of the People, began with a hearing on the participation of women in Asia-Pacific economic activities and on the carrying out of resolutions reached at last year's meeting.
On Thursday, the meeting will continue with panel discussions on small- and medium-sized enterprises, science and technology, manpower resources and women's participation in economic activities.
Chang will present a report at the panel discussion on women's participation in economic activities.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN UNEMPLOYMENT WILL BE UNDER 4.5 PERCENT IN 2001: OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: Taiwan's unemployment rate for this year could be kept under 4.5 percent, since the speed of corporate layoffs has been slowing down, an economic planner said Wednesday.

Lee Kao-chao, vice chairman of the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD), said that job opportunities increased in June, as many enterprises anticipate an economic rebound.
He also said that if the unemployment rates in July and August do not exceed 5 percent, the jobless rate for the whole year can be kept under 4.5 percent.

Lee noted that Taiwan suffered a sharp drop in economic growth as a result of the 1973 energy crisis, when its growth rate of 10 percent slid to near zero, creating a great impact on local companies. As a result, enterprises had to slash their workforces, which made unemployment surge.

However, he added, entrepreneurs were unable to find workers after the crisis passed. He said this is making present entrepreneurs maintain a wait-and-see attitude toward their economic prospects and predicted that they will not lay off too many workers.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINESE TAIPEI CHALKS UP 2 SILVERS, 2 BRONZES AT WORLD GAMES
DOC.DATELINE: Akita, Japan, Aug. 22 (CNA) (By Mike Chang, Chang Tsui-yu & Ed Chen)

TEXT.P: Chinese Taipei edged out Portugal 17-16 to take the bronze medal in the "korfball" event at the Sixth World Games presently under way in Akita City, Japan.
The game is a form of netball played by mixed teams of men and women.
Wednesday's medal took the Chinese Taipei delegation's medal tally so far to two silvers and two bronzes since the games opened Aug. 16.
More than 2,200 athletes -- including 69 from Taiwan -- from 91 countries are competing in 26 official events and five demonstration events during the 11 days of competition.
Chinese Taipei has already won a silver in gateball -- a Japanese version of croquet -- and a silver and a bronze in women's power lifting.
This is the first time the quadrennial World Games has been held outside the American and European continents since the first games were held in Santa Clara, the United States, in 1985.

DOC.HEADLINE: PENTAGON OFFICIAL HINTS AT EASING OF RESTRICTIONS ON TAIWAN CONTACTS

TEXT.P: The U.S. government is reviewing long-standing restrictions on contacts with Taiwan officials, a senior Pentagon official said Monday, apparently suggesting that the level of communications may be upgraded.
"There's some cost, I suppose, if you don't have communications at a high political or military level," said Peter W. Rodman, assistant secretary of defense for international security affairs.

For years, colonel or its equivalent is the highest rank at which the U.S. administration allows contacts with Taiwan officials, although it has been a practice for a chief of Taiwan's general staff to come to Washington once during his term for secret meetings with senior Pentagon officials.

Speaking to reporters at the Pentagon, Rodman said that he does not predict any imminent change to the restrictions and nor is the United States proposing any changes to the basic structure of the relationship as set forth in the Taiwan Relations Act and Washington's three joint communiques with Beijing, he said.

"But we are looking at practical issues in our relations with Taiwan, both the practical issue of improving our understanding of each other's thinking and strategic outlook, and also to strengthen deterrence, which is a clearly stated objective that we have," Rodman said.
He said that communication with Taiwan is important. "It doesn't serve anybody's interest for us and Taiwan not to be able to communicate on security matters," he said.
On war games that mainland China's armed forces are conducting along the southeast coast of the mainland, Rodman pointed out that they are routine exercises.

"I'm sure they learned something from it," he said. "But we're watching them closely and perhaps we can learn something from that exercise too. But I certainly don't see an imminent threat of a conflict."

A former chief of the State Department's policy planning staff, Rodman was sworn in last month as the senior official responsible for the Pentagon's security policy for Asia, Latin America and Africa.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SINGER PERFORMS AT BEIJING UNIVERSIADE OPENING CEREMONY

TEXT.P: Renowned Taiwan singer Chang Hui-mei, better known as A-mei, sang with a choir of mainland Chinese and Taiwanese singers Wednesday at the opening ceremony of the 21st Universiade in Beijing.

It was Chang's first appearance in mainland China since being barred from performing there by the Beijing authorities for singing the national anthem of the Republic of China at the inaugural ceremony of President Chen Shui-bian May 20, 2000.
Chang, who sang two songs -- "Sister" and "Holding Hands," expressed hope that her performance will put her relationship with her fans in Beijing back on track.

The opening ceremony of the 21st Universiade was held at the Workers' Stadium in Beijing. Because the Universiade is the first big sporting event to be sponsored by Beijing since it won the right to host the 2008 Olympics, the Beijing authorities were reported to have spent an additional 20 million renminbi on the event.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN MORE CERTAIN ABOUT WTO ACCESS IN OCTOBER

TEXT.P: Taiwan will have a clearer idea of whether it will be allowed to enter the World Trade Organization (WTO) in October after a WTO working group meeting scheduled for Sept. 14 for a last review the island's bid, an economics official said Wednesday.

Vice Economics Minister Chen Ruey-long said that barring last-minute glitches, the island's bid will pass the working group and be remitted for final approval by the WTO ministerial conference scheduled for October in Qatar.

According to Chen, Beijing's insistence that it must be admitted to the world trade regulatory body ahead of Taiwan will not derail the schedule, in light of the fact that Beijing's WTO access is expected to be approved on the same occasion.

There should be at least one month separation between the working group's final meeting and the WTO's approval of the application, in order to give WTO member states time to review the applicant's paperwork, said Chen.
Taiwan wrapped up its bilateral negotiations with WTO members on the terms of its entry long ago, but has been prevented from sealing its membership until Beijing has completed its own negotiations.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC AUDITOR-GENERAL VISITS PANAMANIAN VICE PRESIDENT
DOC.DATELINE: Panama City, Aug. 21 (CNA) (By Oscar Chung and David Hsu)

TEXT.P: Republic of China Auditor-General Su Chen-ping called Monday on Panamanian First Vice President Arturo Vallarino and Panamanian Auditor-General Alvin Weeden.
Su is in Panama at Weeden's invitation to attend the annual auditing meeting of the Latin American and Caribbean region.
During their talks, Vallarino thanked ROC government for the technological and economic assistance it has provided to his country.
Su and Weeden later exchanged views on the strengthening of auditing cooperation and the training of auditing talent between the two countries.
More than 150 auditors-general and specialists from 20 countries are participating in this year's meeting.
Su and his entourage are scheduled to return to Taipei Saturday.

DOC.HEADLINE: SOUTHEAST ASIAN MARKET `VERY IMPORTANT' TO ROC: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian said Wednesday that the government will attach much importance to the Southeast Asian market while it seeks a more aggressive and efficient manner of regulating local investment in mainland China.
Chen also said that Taiwan and the countries of Southeast Asia should strengthen their consultations and offer incentives to stimulate two-way trade and investment.
He made the remarks while receiving a delegation of the Chinese Chamber of Commerce and Industry in the Philippines at the Presidential Office.
Chen also expressed his gratitude to his guests for their long-term support for the ROC and praised their contributions to bilateral relations.
Since its founding in 1998, the chamber has greatly contributed to bilateral commercial ties and cooperation and has protected Taiwan investors' rights and interests in the Philippines.
Chen predicted that Taiwan investment in the Philippine will gradually recover, as the political situation in the Philippines is "stable."

Wu Hui-han, chairman of the chamber, called on the ROC government to negotiate with the Philippine government for a bilateral investment protection agreement and an agreement to avoid double taxation. He also expressed hope that the ROC government will encourage more Taiwan investors to invest in the Philippines.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN, SOUTH KOREA TRADE PROMOTION AGENCIES SIGN AGREEMENT
DOC.DATELINE: Seoul, Aug. 22 (CNA) (By Chiang Yuan-chen and Elisa Kao)

TEXT.P: The Taipei-based China External Trade Development Council (CETRA) and the Korean Trade Promotion Corporation (KOTRA) signed a cooperation agreement Wednesday, resuming a trade cooperation mechanism interrupted in 1992.
CETRA Secretary-General Huang Chih-peng and KOTRA Chairman Oh Ying-kyo signed the agreement at the eighth joint KOTRA-CETRA meeting.
CETRA signed a cooperative agreement with KOTRA Aug. 10, 1984 and the two sides held seven joint meetings until Taipei severed diplomatic ties with Seoul in 1992.
After several reciprocal visits, CETRA and KOTRA decided to resume the joint meetings to promote bilateral economic and trade relations.
Huang and his delegation were scheduled Thursday to visit the Korea Foreign Trade Association, the Korea Chamber of Commerce and Industry and the Taipei mission in Korea.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP KEEPS DOOR OPEN FOR COALITION WITH `ANY PARTY' AFTER ELECTIONS

TEXT.P: The opposition People First Party (PFP) will cooperate with whichever party controls the most legislative seats after the year-end election, despite its "spiritual" attachment to the Kuomintang, PFP Chairman James Soong said Wednesday.
However, Soong went on, the PFP will not give up its principles and stances on some important issues purely for the sake of cooperation.

He urged the leaders of Taiwan's ruling and opposition parties to work out a "gentleman's agreement" on the formation of a coalition that would command majority support in the legislature and thereby maintain the stability of the government.

The former Taiwan provincial governor said it would be preferable for leaders of the political parties to negotiate the ground rules of a coalition prior to the election, so that they will not be influenced by their parties' performance in the election.

The PFP is in no position to join any coalition before the election owing to the paltry 17 seats it holds in the 220-seat legislature, and will determine its strategy as to which party it will cooperate with according to the number of seats it occupies in the new legislature after the year-end election, Soong said at a tea party with local journalists.

Although the coalition can only be formed after the election, it would be preferable to have it in place before February -- when the new legislature is set to meet -- because the stricken economy cannot wait that long for help, according to Soong.
He also confirmed that he and Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan will meet Thursday.

Soong said they will continue their negotiations on cooperation in the year-end elections and exchange views on how to stabilize the government after the Economic Development Advisory Conference (EDAC) ends Sunday.
Soong said he owes a definite answer to some PFP members who are aspiring to run for magistrateships in counties around the island, as the final window for announcing their candidacy is approaching.
If there is no chance of the two parties fielding a candidate supported by both in several critical counties, there is no reason to keep those PFP hopefuls in agony any more, Soong said.
Also on their agenda is a discussion of ways to translate the EDAC conclusions into concrete policy, Soong added.
As an advisory group, the EDAC's conclusions are not legally binding before going through the legislative process and that is where cooperation between parties will come to play, Soong said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI TO HOST 2002 INTERNATIONAL CHILDREN'S GAMES

TEXT.P: Tapei City has earned the right Wednesday in Budapest to host the 2002 International Children's Games, sources with the city hall said.
Taipei City, which applied to join the game for the first time last November, is fielding a delegation to the 2001 games presently under way in Budapest, Hungary from Aug. 21-24.

During a meeting of the games' organizers in Budapest, the Taipei delegation, led by Taipei City Deputy Mayor Pai Hsiu-hsiung, bid to host the next games, slated to take place from Aug. 30-Sept. 3, 2002.
After 90 minutes of deliberation, the games' regulators awarded Taipei the right to host the games.
The games, for children aged 12-15, consist of six events -- track and field, table tennis, badminton, tennis, basketball and swimming.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC SCORES SIXTH CONSECUTIVE WIN IN WILLIAM JONES BASKETBALL SERIES

TEXT.P: Host Chinese Taipei beat Russia 87-77 Wednesday to take its sixth consecutive victory in the 24th William Jones Cup Basketball Invitational presently under way in Fengshan City, Kaohsiung County.
The home team employed one-on-one defense tactics to contain the attacks of the taller Russian team.
The Russians have so far won four victories and suffered one defeat in the elimination round of the competition which began Aug. 16.
In another two games that day, Honduras defeated Mongolia 92-81 and Canada beat South Africa 85-60.
Score standings as of Wednesday were:
Team W. L. Chinese Taipei 6 0 Russia 4 1 South Korea 5 0 Philippines 3 2 Honduras 2 3 Canada 2 4 Mongolia 0 5 South Africa 0 6

DOC.HEADLINE: SALOMON TAIWAN DONATES NT$3.5 MILLION TO PROMOTE ONLINE LEARNING

TEXT.P: Salomon Smith Barney Securities Taiwan Limited, a part of the Citibank Group, donated NT$3.5 million (US$100,000) Wednesday to an educational Internet Web site known as Educity to help promote online learning for the people of Taiwan.
Educity, an Internet virtual city supported by the Ministry of Education and the National Science Council, provides plentiful free resources online to encourage citizens to never stop learning.

Tu Ing-tzung, president of Salomon Taiwan, Minister of Education Ovid Tzeng, and the president of Academia Sinica, Lee Yuan-tzeh, -- who is the honorary mayor of Educity -- took part in the donation ceremony held at the Fubon Life Insurance building in Taipei Wednesday.

At the ceremony, Lee praised Salomon Taiwan which he said has always donated generously to charity. An business must shoulder some social responsibility, and Solomon Taiwan is a model in this aspect, Lee said.
In addition, Tzeng also encouraged teachers to be devoted to online teaching.

DOC.HEADLINE: POWERFUL U.S. CONGRESSIONAL DELEGATION VISITS TAIWAN

TEXT.P: A powerful U.S. congressional delegation led by House International Relations Committee Chairman Henry Hyde arrived in Taipei Wednesday for a three-day visit.

Hyde and his 34-member delegation were greeted by Vice Foreign Affairs Minister Chiu Jung-nan and Raymond Burghardt, director of the Taipei Office of the American Institute in Taiwan, the de facto U.S. embassy in Taipei, upon their arrival.

This is the first trip for Hyde, a Republican from Illinois, to the Asian-Pacific region since he took the post as head of House International Committee in January and his first visit to Taiwan since the Republic of China and the United States severed their diplomatic relations in 1979. Hyde, who was first elected to the U.S. House of Representatives in 1974, is one of a handful of surviving members of the Congress who took part in the drafting of the Taiwan Relations Act in 1978-1979 which regulates unofficial exchanges between Taipei and Washington in the absence of formal ties. During his stay here, Hyde will call on President Chen Shui-bian, Former President Lee Teng-hui, Premier Chang Chun-hsiung and Foreign Affairs Minister Tien Hung-mao in addition to giving a speech on "the future of democracy in China."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies on Thursday are as follows:
The China Times:
The two sides of the Taiwan Strait will be admitted to the World Trade Organization (WTO) in November, says mainland deputy trade minister.
The United Daily News:
Both sides of the Taiwan Strait set to enter WTO in November, says mainland deputy trade chief.

The Central Daily News:
KMT Chairman Lien Chan says every party member should be subject to party rules.
The China Post:
