The Taiwan News:
U.S. reviewing military policy with Taiwan.
The Taipei Times:
President chen urges Japan to accept past.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, Aug. 23, or the fifth day of the seventh month of the Year of the Snake according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
93AD: Julius Gnaeus Agricola, Roman general renowned for his conquests in Britain, dies in Rome at the age of 53.
410: Alaric, king of the Visigoths, orders his men to storm Rome after Honorius, emperor of the West Roman Empire, refused to agree to his terms.
1305: Sir William Wallace, Scottish patriot who demanded independence for his country, is hung, drawn and quartered in London.
1754: Louis XVI, king of France at the time of the outbreak of the French Revolution, is born.
1818: The first steamship service opens on the Great Lakes in North America.
1821: Mexico gains its independence.
1912: Gene Kelly, American dancer, choreographer, singer, actor and director, is born. He starred in Hollywood musicals, including "Anchors Aweigh," "Singin' in the Rain" and his "Invitation to Dance."
1914: Japan declares war on Germany.
1926: Screen actor Rudoph Valentino, the idol of millions, dies of peritonitis in New York's Polyclinic Hospital. He was 31. The Italian-born American actor was known for his romantic leading roles in silent films such as "The Sheik" and "Blood and Sand."
1927: In one of the most controversial cases in American legal history, Nicola Sacco and Bartolomeo Vanzetti are sent to the electric chair. In July 1921, a jury found the two Italian political anarchists and immigrants guilty of the murder of a factory paymaster and a guard during a robbery in South Braintree, Massachusetts.
1928: Chinese Communist Party leaders, including Mao Tse-tung and Chu Teh, and their troops flee to Chingkangshan in Kiangsi Province after being outflanked and besieged by government forces from both the provinces of Hunan and Kiangsi.
1933: Gandhi is released from Poona jail after his hunger strike almost kills him.
1939: The USSR and Germany sign the Molotov-Ribbentropp Non-Aggression Pact, a terrible shock to the Western European leaders.
1940: German bombers begin night raids on London.
1945: Soviet troops occupy Manchuria.
1945: Chiang Kai-shek sends a third invitation to Mao Tse-tung after inviting him Aug. 14 to come to Chungking for a conference and the again Aug. 20.
1958: The Battle of the Taiwan Strait begins with Communist China firing 57,000 rounds in 2 hours at the islands of Kinmen. Many defenders are killed, including Gen. Chi Sing-wen, deputy commander of the Kinmen Garrison Command.
1963: Ambassador to the United States Tsiang Ting-fu signs the nuclear test ban treaty on behalf of the Republic of China.
1981: One hundred and ten people die in the crash of a Far Eastern Air Transport plane. The incident represents Taiwan's worst air disaster.
1990: East and West Germany choose October 3 as the date for reunification.
1990: Amenia declares its independence from Moscow.
1992: The Republic of China severs diplomatic relations with South Korea.
1998: Russian President Boris Yeltsin sacks his government and names former premier Viktor Chernomyrdin as acting prime minister.
1999: ROC Premier Vincent Siew is awarded an honorary doctorate in public service by Ohio State University.
2000: Eight mountaineers from Taiwan successfully climb to the 3,776-meter peak of Mount Fuji, thus writing a new page in climbing history.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "The Emperor Shun might perhaps be considered in the highest sense of the word a pious man. In moral qualities, he was a saint. In dignity of office, he was the ruler of the empire. In wealth, all that the wide world contained belonged to him."

DOC.HEADLINE: PILOT DIES IN ARMY HELICOPTER CRASH

TEXT.P: A Republic of China Army OH-58D helicopter crashed during a routine training flight over northwestern Taiwan early Thursday, killing the pilot and injuring the co-pilot, military sources said.
A spokesman for the ROC Army 602 Airborne Brigade said the ill-fated helicopter took off from an air base in Hsinshe in the central county of Taichung at 7:38 a.m. for a routine training mission.
The No. 613 chopper crashed into a ditch in hilly terrain near Sanyi, Miaoli County at 7:48 a.m. for unknown reasons, the spokesman said, adding that thick smoke was seen following the crash.

The plane's pilot, Major Chen Yao-cheng, was killed in the crash, while the co-pilot, Captain Wei Ya-teh, only sustained minor injuries, the spokesman said, adding that Wei had been rushed to a nearby hospital for treatment.
The spokesman further said army authorities have launched a probe into the cause of the tragic mishap.
Local cable TV news reports said the helicopter might have hit a power line before crashing.
Military sources said the OH-58D helicopter specialized in reconnaissance, search, communications, command and supervisory missions.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC BIOTECH DELEGATION TO VISIT U.S. AND SEEK PARTNERSHIPS

TEXT.P: A high-level Republic of China delegation will travel in September to Pennsylvania, New Jersey, Delaware, Maryland and Virginia for a mid-Atlantic biotechnology initiative, the U.S.-ROC (Taiwan) Business Council announced Tuesday.

The delegation will be led by Shih Yen-shiang , director-general of the Industrial Development Bureau of the Ministry of Economic Affairs, to seek partnerships for biotechnology development and explore investment opportunities.
"This is a remarkable opportunity for the United States' biotechnology sector," said Rupert J. Hammond-Chambers, president of the U.S.-ROC Business Council.

He said the ROC delegation represents "the core of Taiwan's emerging biotech community -- senior private sector leaders who have already enjoyed success, and senior government officials who will play a proactive role in ensuring that entrepreneurs and businesses receive the support they need to do business with Taiwan."

The ROC government recently announced that it is committing itself to biotech, one of the fastest growing industries in Taiwan. This commitment is evident in Taiwan's US$1.5 billion appropriation of government funds for research, development and promotion over the next five years.

The delegation will begin with a two-day summit in Philadelphia hosted by the University of Pennsylvania's School of Medicine and School of Applied Engineering and organized by the American Institute in Taiwan and the United States Trade and Development Agency.
Topics for discussion will include how to integrate Taiwan with a globalizing U.S. biotechnology industry.

The delegation will also learn about specific business opportunities in the United States. Following the summit, the delegation will tour pharmaceutical and educational research facilities in Pennsylvania, New Jersey, Delaware, Maryland and Virginia.
The tour will precede the 25th annual Joint Business Conference of the U.S.-ROC and ROC-USA Business Councils to be held in Boston, Sept. 17-19, 2001.
For the past 25 years, the two councils have hosted the Annual Joint Business Conference to bring together all those who have an interest in business relations between the United States and Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK PRICES DOWN BY 27.76 POINTS

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) lost ground on Thursday, with the benchmark weighted price index moving down 27.76 points to close at 4,459.76.
Market turnover amounted to NT$43.29 billion (US$1.25 billion).

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN FIRM UNVEILS WORLD'S FIRST DNA-BASED ANTI-COUNTERFEIT CHIP

TEXT.P: The world's first DNA-based anti-counterfeit chip has been successfully developed by a Taiwan biotechnology company and is now ready to be mass produced for commercial applications, the chairman of the company said Wednesday.

The DNA-based anti-counterfeit chip, a combination of biotechnology and micro-electrical engineering, was unveiled by Biowell Technology Co. at a news conference Wednesday. Government officials and representatives from leading business conglomerates in Taiwan who are potential users of the DNA chip attended the event.

The DNA chips, with their almost unlimited variations, could be the best and cheapest device to deter counterfeiting and forgery that current technologies are unable to detect, according to Dr. Hsu Chun-chieh, chairman of Biowell and head of its research and development department. Hsu was formerly a researcher at the Academia Sinica, Taiwan's top research institute, but left two years ago to help start Biowell.
The DNA chips, each with individual DNA developed using biosynthesis technology developed by Biowell, can be affixed to any object that needs to be protected from counterfeiting and forgery.
It can be placed on credit cards, cash cards, membership cards, ID cards, and electronic door locks and passes.

It takes only two seconds to identify or detect a card mounted with the DNA-based anti-counterfeit chip, and the users, such as stores, do not need to change their machines to enable them to read cards carrying the DNA-based anti-counterfeit chips. All they need to do is to add on a portable DNA chip reader to their cash machine, Hsu noted.

In addition, the DNA chips are waterproof and resistant to pressure. Their polymer encasement, which contains a central processing unit that is one-sixth the size of an adult's fingernail, protects them from damage. Even strong ultraviolet rays will not harm the chips, Hsu said.
Currently the company says that the chips are expected to have a lifespan of only five years, but in the future, when technologies improve, the chips should last for at least 10 years, he said.

The end result of biotechnological research should not only be applied to pharmaceutical products, Hsu said, adding that other applications could be quite useful if used in consumer goods to help better the lives of average citizens.

Currently the company has a monthly production capacity of 2.5 million DNA-based anti-counterfeit chips, which can be tailor-made to meet different demands from different customers. For example, the DNA chips that would be used by a credit card issuing company would be different from that to be used by Pfizer for its Viagra packages, Hsu said.

Buyers of each major batch of the DNA chips would have their own data bases to control and detect the chips to help them find out whether the DNA chip-mounted cards or products have been counterfeited, he said.

While feeling comfortable and confident with the marketing prospects of the DNA chips, Biowell researchers are planning to expand their product line -- to develop edible anti-counterfeit DNA-coated materials and sprays to be used in expensive medicines and high-priced food products, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIT TAIPEI OFFICE CHIEF NOMINATED NEW U.S. AMBASSADOR TO VIETNAM
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Aug. 22 (CNA) (By Herman Pan and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The White House announced Wednesday that President George W. Bush intends to nominate Raymond Burghardt, current top U.S. representative to the Republic of China, to be new U.S. ambassador to Vietnam.

Burghardt's appointment will require Senate confirmation. Burghardt, if confirmed, would succeed Douglas Peterson, a former prisoner of war in Vietnam who came to Hanoi as the first U.S. post-Vietnam War ambassador to the Indochinese nation in May 1997.

A career member of the U.S. Senior Foreign Service, Burghardt has served as director of the Taipei office of the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) since 1999. The AIT Taipei office represents U.S. interests in Taiwan in the absence of formal diplomatic ties between the two countries.

The White House news release said Burghardt served as principal officer in Shanghai from 1997 to 1999, deputy chief of mission in Manila from 1993 to 1996 and deputy chief of mission in Seoul from 1990 to 1993.

He has also held numerous other positions overseas, including political officer in Beijing, Tegucigalpa, Hong Kong, Guatemala and Saigon, the news release said, adding that Burghardt's Washington assignments included service in a variety of capacities in the Bureau of East Asian and Pacific Affairs.

ROC President Chen Shui-bian decorated Burghardt with the Order of Brilliant Star with Grand Cordon Monday in recognition of his contribution to promoting substantive Taipei-Washington relations during his two-year stint as the de facto U.S. ambassador to Taiwan. The Order symbolizes the highest honor the ROC presents to a foreign national.

It remains unclear who will succeed Burghardt as the top U.S. representative to Taipei. Many China affairs experts in Washington, D.C. said Douglas Paal, a former senior Asian affairs director with the White House National Security Council, is the most likely candidate for the post.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Shares prices opened high but closed lower on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) on Thursday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 27.76 points to close at 4,459.76.

Encouraged by a rise in U.S. stock prices, the bourse opened at 4,491.23, and began to go down due to a prevailing wait-and-see atmosphere. The index fluctuated between 4,506.92 and 4,435.97 during trading.

A total of 1.8 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$43.29 billion (US$1.25 billion), a decrease from the previous trading session which saw 1.98 billion stocks change hands on a market turnover of NT$46.93 billion (US$1.36 billion).
Only two of the eight major stock categories gained ground as construction stocks and pulp and paper issues both moved up 0.4 percent.

The other major categories posted losses, with plastics and chemical shares moving down the most at 1 percent, followed by textile issues at 0.9 percent, electrical shares at 0.8 percent, cement stocks at 0.4 percent, foodstuffs stocks and bank and insurance shares, both at 0.2 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 247 to 236, with 108 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES MIXED ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock index futures market reported mixed results on Thursday, as Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index futures for September moved up 8 points to close at 4,468, with 11,043 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for October fell 25 points to finish at 4,450, with 16 contracts traded. No transactions were reported for other months.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Thursday at 4,460 for September, 4,475 for October, 4,431 for December, 4,445 for next March, and 4,411 for next June.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were lower.
September TE futures moved down 2 points to close at 224.5, with 2,047 contract transactions, while October TE futures decreased 1.5 points to finish at 224.5, with 11 contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for other months.
September TF futures lost 0.2 points to finish at 584.8, with 896 contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: EUROPE CAN PROVIDE MODEL FOR ACADEMIC AND INDUSTRY INTEGRATION: NSC HEAD

TEXT.P: Taiwan should look to the entrepreneurship programs of many innovative universities in Europe as a model to promote interactions between academic circles and industry, Huang Wen-hsiung, vice chairman of the National Science Council, said Thursday.

Huang has recently concluded a tour to Europe. He said that during his visits to several science parks in Europe, he was impressed to learn about the success of university programs to support the establishment of spin-off companies.
Accompanied by the council's director of humanities and social sciences and director of international programs, Huang visited Sweden, Finland and Britain in the past two weeks.

He said that the science parks in Scandinavia are mostly research and development-oriented, and universities are supporting industrial companies which usually are small in scale. University professors offer consultative services to these companies.
While Taiwan is planning for the establishment of biotechnology parks, Huang said that Taiwan can learn from the Scandinavian models.

Many innovative universities in Europe have developed successful models of collaboration between academic circles and industry, and these universities in Denmark, Portugal, Spain, Germany, Sweden, Finland, the United Kingdom, the Netherlands and France have formed a continental-wide network -- the European Consortium of Innovative Universities.
Huang said that Taiwan's production-oriented science-based industrial park is also recognized internationally as a successful model with an annual production value amounting to US$3 billion.

Many of the IC (integrated circuits), IT (information technology) and communications companies based in the Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park were spin-offs of the Industrial Technology Research Institute (ITRI), a national research institute which transfers some 3,000 technologies to companies in various industrial sectors every year.
Taiwan's hi-tech sectors -- electronics, optoelectronics, automation, pharmaceuticals, aerospace, energy and environment protection -- have benefited greatly from ITRI's technology transfer programs.

In recent years, leading enterprises in Taiwan are cooperating with local universities by sponsoring research and development centers on university campuses. Huang said that the National Science Council is promoting cooperation programs to encourage professors and research personnel in universities to offer on-site consultancy to industrial companies in science parks.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP CHAIR WANTS SPEEDY OPENING OF DIRECT CROSS-STRAIT TRAVEL LINKS

TEXT.P: Chairman of the opposition People First Party (PFP) James Soong spoke out Thursday in favor of a speedy opening of direct air and shipping links across the Taiwan Strait -- the first time the party leader has made such a declaration.

Soong, formerly the provincial governor of Taiwan who defied Kuomintang party regulations and ran for president in 2000 and failed, stressed that the PFP is willing to help accelerate direct cross-strait travel links under the framework of the Republic of China Constitution.

Spelling out the PFP's latest policies of seeking stability across the Taiwan Strait, Soong called for resumption of cross-strait negotiations based on the National Unification Guidelines and the "1992 consensus" that allows both sides of the Strait to have separate interpretations on the "one China" concept.

Soong added that Taiwan should shelve disputes over the thorny "unification or independence" issue and begin talks with mainland Chinese authorities over technical issues to first achieve economic and functional integration across the Taiwan Strait.

He said the major differences across the Taiwan Strait is that people in Taiwan enjoy systems of freedom and democracy while their mainland counterparts do not. He said he keenly hopes to enable the Beijing leadership to understand that Taiwan is more than willing to seek peaceful unification and long-term political integration, with the Taiwan population feeling confident about their future.

As for the PFP, Soong noted that the party would by no means be obstinate -- instead, it is more than willing to cooperate with any other party to jointly work out solutions to help stabilize domestic politics and accelerate cross-strait reconciliation.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN JOBLESS RATE HITS NEW HIGH IN JULY

TEXT.P: Taiwan's unemployment rate hit a new high of 4.92 percent in July as a result of global and domestic economic sluggishness, sources from the Cabinet-level Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) reported Thursday.

July's soaring jobless rate was the tenth monthly rise in a row and marked the longest consecutive period of rising unemployment in Taiwan's history, said Chen Chin-cheng, a DGBAS deputy bureau chief.
Chen attributed the soaring unemployment rate mainly to the contraction of Taiwan's job market.

The number of people who lost their jobs because of business closings or layoffs in July marked the eleventh consecutive month the figure has risen. On average, 17,000 more people became unemployed month-on-month between April and July, according to Chen.
In July, 480,500 people were out of a job or looking for employment, an increase of 43,000 from June, marking an unemployment rate of 4.92 percent, a single-month record, Chen noted.
Increased numbers of newly graduated students pouring into the job market and former white-collar employees turning to blue-collar work also contributed to the unemployment rate in July, he said.

Cumulatively, Taiwan posted an average jobless rate of 4.08 percent in the first seven months of this year, Chen said, adding that the unemployment rate is expected to hit an average of 4.3 percent for the entire year.
Chen forecast that the island's jobless rate will break the 5 percent mark in August with no sign of immediate recovery in sight.
Meanwhile, the first group of 50 "employment boomers," trained by the Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) to help reinvigorate the sluggish job situation, hit the market for the first time Thursday.
The job boomers, said CLA officials, will go out with a "tough salesman's spirit" to help job seekers to sort out their needs, get access to useful resources and eventually find work.

DOC.HEADLINE: AMCHAM URGES TAIWAN TO FIND SOLUTIONS TO CROSS-STRAIT IMPASSE

TEXT.P: The American Chamber of Commerce in Taipei (AmCham) urged the Republic of China government Thursday to actively seek a breakthrough to the deadlocked relations across the Taiwan Strait.

The largest foreign trade association in Taiwan made the call on the eve of the opening of a much-anticipated national economic development conference aimed at revitalizing the island's faltering economy.
Both incumbent AmCham President Richard Henson and his predecessor, Paul Cassingham, said they have high expectations for the Economic Development Advisory Conference scheduled for Aug. 24-26.
Henson said Taiwan should take advantage of the conference to craft innovative measures to break the lingering cross-strait limbo to revive public confidence in Taiwan's economic prospects.
In his view, Henson said, Taiwan is now at a critical juncture and needs wisdom and vision to cope with the challenges it faces.

Noting that Taiwan's present economic woes lie in a lack of public confidence, Henson said he is convinced that boosting cross-strait trade and economic relations would help enhance consumer and investor confidence.

In particular, Henson said, if the two sides of the Taiwan Strait can open direct trade, mail and transportation links, commonly known as "three links," in the near future, it would certainly have a positive impact on Taiwan's economic development.

For his part, Cassingham said Taiwan should define its own role under the current wave of economic globalization. As both sides of the Taiwan Strait will soon be admitted into the World Trade Organization (WTO), Taiwan should formulate new development strategies to deal with new challenges following its WTO accession.

Meanwhile, Henson suggested that Taiwan allow its low-end manufacturing and assembling industries to relocate to mainland China and focus its energy on developing such high value-added services as resourcing, management, designing, and research and development.
Henson further said Taiwan should cash in on its strategic geographic location, management expertise and international trade experience to sustain its economic growth in the midst of globalization.

As the people of Taiwan have forged a consensus on economic and political reforms, Henson said the ROC government should redouble its efforts to push for transparency and globalization of its financial and banking services to attract foreign investors and sharpen its competitive edge in the global market.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2001 TAIPEI CHINESE FOOD FAIR OPENS

TEXT.P: The 12th Taipei Chinese Food Fair, featuring various kinds of Chinese noodles and delicacies, opened with lively performances Thursday at the Taipei World Trade Center.

Minister of Transportation and Communications Yeh Chu-lan, Chairman of Chunghwa Telecom Co. Mao Chi-kuo, Chairman of the China External Trade Development Council Shea Jia-dong, and the event's chief organizer, Stanley C. Yen, took part in the opening ceremony Thursday morning.

The food fair is one of the most popular ways to bring Taiwanese products to the world and this year the organizers invited chefs from mainland China and famous TV cooking program host Martin Yan to present their outstanding skills, Yen said.
Chunghwa Telecom issued a set of five telephone cards Thursday with different designs depicting Taiwanese traditional foods such as Hsinchu meatballs and rice noodles to commemorate the fair.
There are 59 booths at this year's food fair showcasing various Chinese dishes and cooking skills. The fair is scheduled to close on Aug. 26.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC BEATS MACAU IN WOMEN'S TABLE TENNIS GROUP EVENT AT UNIVERSIADE
DOC.DATELINE: Beijing, Aug. 23 (CNA) (By Lee An-tung and Ed Chen)

TEXT.P: Chinese Taipei blanked Macau 3-0 Thursday in the women's table tennis group event at the 21st Universiade presently under way in Beijing.
Chinese Taipei will take on Moldova Thursday night and play against host mainland China Friday.
A total of 18 teams are taking part in the competition. Chinese Taipei, Macau, Moldova and mainland China are in Group A.
Chinese Taipei's Chen Chiu-dan, Tsui Hsiu-li and Chuang Wen-chuan took part in Thursday's Chinese Taipei-Macau match.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S SALARY GROWTH POSTS 20-YEAR LOW

TEXT.P: Taiwan's average monthly salary reached NT$34,140 (US$987) in the first six months of this year, representing an increase of 1.22 percent over the same period of last year and the lowest growth in 20 years.

Statistics published Thursday by the Cabinet-level Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) show that average monthly salaries in June totaled NT$34,244, a growth of only 0.36 percent over May.
The DGBAS attributed the tiny growth to the reduction of weekly working hours implemented from the beginning of January this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: REVENUE OF HSINCHU SCIENCE-BASED INDUSTRIAL PARK FALL 13%

TEXT.P: The business revenue of the Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park in the first half of the year totaled NT$364.2 billion (US$11.24 billion), a drop of 13 percent compared with the year-earlier level, according to statistics released Thursday by the Cabinet-level National Science Council (NSC).
An official from the industrial park administration attributed the fall to the global stagnation of the semiconductor and computer industries.

However, Yen Tsung-ming, a section chief at the Science-based Industrial Park Administration under control of the NSC, said that the communications, precision machine and bio-tech industries grew 25 percent, 21 percent and 47 percent, respectively.
He predicted that the park's whole year revenue will reach NT$800 billion (US$23.4 billion).
Yen disclosed the statistics at a press conference jointly sponsored by the NSC and the Science-based Industrial Park Administration.
He noted that the park yielded revenue of NT$929.3 billion (US$27.1 billion) in 2000, a record in its 20-year existence.
In June, Yen went on, global trading in the semiconductor industry reached US$11.6 billion, a decrease of 30.7 percent in comparison with the same month of the previous year.

According to a prediction made by the International Semiconductor Equipment and Material Association, revenue of the global semiconductor equipment sector will suffer a 35 percent cut, or US$31 billion, the largest cut this years.

Revenue of the computer and peripherals sector in the year's first six months totaled NT$86 billion, a decrease of 22 percent from the year-earlier level. Revenue of the IC industry reached NT$21.04 billion, a decrease of 15 percent compared with the like period of a year ago, while revenue of the optoelectronic industry totaled NT$36 billion, down 5 percent from the year-earlier level.

Revenue of the bio-tech industry grew 47 percent to reach NT$620 million, while that of the precision machinery industry grew 21 percent to total NT$2.5 billion and the communication sector posted a growth rate of 25 percent to reach NT$28.2 billion.
In terms of the park's labor force, the 12,840 personnel employed as of the end of 2000 had been cut to 10,510 employees as of the end of this June, Yen said.
He added that 24 new companies with a total capital of NT$10.6 billion were approved to set up in the park, with some 30 companies still in the process of applying for approval.

DOC.HEADLINE: BLADDER CANCER 23 TIMES MORE PREVALENT IN SOUTHWESTERN TAIWAN: STUDY
DOC.DATELINE: Tainan County, southern Taiwan, Aug. 23 (CNA) (By Fang Wen-hung)

TEXT.P: A recent study to be published Saturday shows that bladder cancer is 23 times more likely to occur in southwestern Taiwan coastal regions in patients aged 50-60 than in other areas of Taiwan.

The study was jointly conducted by Chiu Wen-hsiang, director of the Chih Mei Foundation Medical Center's Department of Urology, and professors Chen Chien-jen and Hsu Ling-i of National Taiwan University's Graduate Institute of Epidemiology.

Chiu said that the study focused on the villages located at the mouth of Pachang River in Tainan County, where many residents have been drinking underground water over a long period of time, accumulating large quantities of arsenic in their bodies.
He added that many of the residents in these villages are also afflicted with the "blackfoot disease," an endemic form of vascular thrombosis.
According to the study, the occurrence of bladder cancer in the same region was already 20 times that of other regions 10 years ago.
During these 10 years, the occurrence of bladder cancer in these coastal villages has gone up by 30 percent for women and 15 percent for men.
Chiu said that bladder cancer is caused by many factors other than arsenic. Smoking and ingestion of dyes are other possible factors.
The complete results of the study will be announced Saturday at a meeting of the Urological Association of the Republic of China.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT TO ATTEND EDAC PLENARY SESSION

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian will attend the plenary session of the Economic Development Advisory Conference (EDAC), slated to be held Aug. 24-26, his chief of staff said Thursday.

Presidential Office Secretary-General Yu Shyi-kun said Chen has managed to take the three-day session into his schedule to underline the emphasis he places on the conference, which he himself ordered to be set up.

In addition to the discussion, Chen will also preside over the plenary session's opening and closing ceremonies, as well as a post-conference news briefing Aug. 26, barring unforeseen emergencies, Yu went on.
The five preliminary EDAC panels have put forward 314 consensus, 38 majority opinions and 39 other opinions, all of which will be discussed in the plenary session, Yu continued.

Instead of resolving the issues through voting, the meeting will come up with consensus, which will be non-binding, although Chen has promised to abide by the consensus reached to the best of his ability.

In order to translate the conference's conclusions into government policy, Premier Chang Chun-hsiung ordered Wednesday the related government agencies to list the current regulations that will have to be revised or the new regulations that will need to be enacted in order to implement the conclusions.
Unless the conference demands otherwise, Chang said, the list should be presented to his office by Sept. 3 for Cabinet approval by Sept. 13 and remittance to the legislature by Sept. 18.

Chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development Chen Po-chih said Thursday that his council has been charged by Chang to monitor the implementation of the conference's conclusions every week and to report its progress to EDAC members every quarter.

As to the extra budget, estimated at about NT$100 billion (US$2.94 billion), that would be required to put the 18 conference proposals into action, Yu said the government will present a financial feasibility study about the proposals to the conference at the plenary session, but claimed that the government will be in "no position to reject them."
Chen said the government might raise the money through the privatization of state-run enterprises, or else might raise the cap on government loans.
He noted that there is room for the cap on government loans -- 30 percent of the government's whole year budget -- given the 60 percent cap in "all developed countries."

DOC.HEADLINE: `GO SLOW' POLICY ADJUSTMENT WILL NOT AFFECT DIPLOMATIC WORK: OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: Minister of Foreign Affairs Tien Hung-mao said Thursday that the government's plan to ease the "go slow, be patient" policy on mainland China-bound investment will not affect the nation's diplomatic work.

Tien was responding to press reports that some of the Republic of China's diplomatic allies have told relevant ROC government authorities that they will step up efforts to tap the mainland Chinese market once Taiwan eases its curbs on investment across the Taiwan Strait.
He noted that the reports are not new and that congressmen and parliamentarians from some countries that recognize the ROC have paid visits to mainland China in recent years.
Tien said the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) has consistently worked very hard to maintain cordial relations with ROC allies.

"Nevertheless, in the face of the changing global environment, we can no longer ask our allies to avoid any contact with mainland China," Tien said, adding that MOFA should still ask ROC diplomatic allies to minimize their engagements with the mainland.
Noting that relations with other countries involve wide-ranging aspects, Tien said mainland visits by parliamentarians will not be enough to easily turn the tables.
In his view, Tien said, long-term friendships between top leaders of the ROC and its allies are critical to sustained bilateral diplomatic ties.
Tien went on to say that the government's planned relaxation of the "go slow" cross-strait investment policy may add new perspectives to Taiwan's diplomatic work.
To cope with all possible new challenges, Tien said, MOFA staff will exercise even more prudence and caution in handling relations with ROC allies.

Tien further said he has ordered relevant MOFA officials to evaluate the possible impact of easing cross-strait investment restrictions on the ROC's diplomatic relations with its allies. "We'll heighten alert, identify core problems and make necessary adjustments of our strategies to cement relations with our allies and address issues that may arise in the wake of the relaxation of mainland investment curbs," he added.
Tien was speaking after a luncheon he hosted in honor of a visiting U.S. congressional delegation led by House International Relations Committee Chairman Henry Hyde.
Tien said he exchanged views with Hyde on a broad range of matters of mutual concern during the lunch meeting.

He said the ROC has consistently maintained close friendly ties with the two main U.S. parties -- the Republican Party and the Democratic Party. "Our cordial relationships with both parties will never change," he stressed.
Hyde, a Republican from Illinois, and his 34-member delegation arrived in Taipei Wednesday for a three-day visit.

This is Hyde's first trip to the Asian-Pacific region since he took the post as head of House International Committee in January and his first visit to Taiwan since the Republic of China and the United States severed their diplomatic relations in 1979.

DOC.HEADLINE: SECOND TAIWAN SCHOOL SET UP IN MAINLAND CHINA

TEXT.P: A second school for the children of Taiwanese businessmen in mainland China will be completed in early September, according to a report in Thursday's People's Daily, a mainland newspaper.

With more and more Taiwan businessmen coming to mainland China in search of trade and investment opportunities, the first school for their children was set up last year in Tonguan City, Guangdong Province.
The report said that construction of the school, located in Kunshan City, Jiangsu Province, is almost complete and that classes can begin next month.
The school, which was paid for entirely by Taiwanese businessmen, will mainly serve Taiwanese students scattered throughout eastern mainland China.

To date, there are more than 240 Taiwanese students registered to attend the school. More than 50 will come from Shanghai and Kunshan, while others will mainly come from Beijing, Tianjin and Hangzhou.

The construction cost of the initial stage of the school project exceeded US$2 million. The school, which is expected to receive some 500 students, has already hired 30 teachers, 17 of which will come from Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: PILOT DIES IN ARMY HELICOPTER CRASH

TEXT.P: A Republic of China Army OH-58D Kiowa Warrior helicopter crashed during a routine training flight in northwestern Taiwan early Thursday, killing the pilot and injuring the co-pilot.

An army spokesman said that Maj. Chen Yao-cheng, 31, was piloting the reconnaissance helicopter on a training mission with Capt. Wei Ya-teh, 25, when it crashed into a ditch in hilly terrain in Sanyi Township at 7:48 a.m.
Military sources said that Chen and Wei had radioed in a report of abnormal dashboard instrument readings shortly before the chopper snagged a high-voltage power line and crashed into the hillside.
Chen was killed by an impact to his neck, while Wei sustained multiple fractures and other non-fatal injuries.
Wei, who has logged 365 flying hours, was reported to be in stable condition after receiving treatment at a nearby hospital.
Chen had just celebrated his birthday on Sunday. He is survived by his wife, his parents and a five-year-old child.

Col. Chen Ming-tung, staff director for the 602nd Airborne Brigade -- which only recently won the honor of being a model unit in the ROC Armed Forces -- said that the pilot of the ill-fated helicopter was an instructor for the brigade with 1,300 flying hours under his belt.

Chen said that the crash was the first of its kind since the OH-58Ds were incorporated into the army in 1993. He added that the Army General Headquarters has already established an ad hoc investigation team to determine the factors that led to the fatal accident.
The army bought a total of 26 OH-58D helicopters from the United States in 1992. Each helicopter cost US$6.7 million.
Observation helicopters like the Kiowa frequently fly at extremely low levels, hugging the ground during maneuvers, due to the special nature of their missions.

They serve as the eyes and ears of the attack helicopters in the brigade, flying just above the treeline to provide a sweeping view of the battlefield and targeting information for attack choppers like the army's AH-1W Super Cobra.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC, EL SALVADOR TO SIGN TEMPORARY ADMISSION PACT

TEXT.P: Officials of the Republic of China and El Salvador will sign an agreement on temporary admission Friday to further strengthen bilateral trade.

ROC Vice Economics Minister Chen Ruey-long and his Salvadoran counterpart, Eduardo Ayala, will sign the agreement, under the terms of which samples and exhibition products will receive rapid customs clearance and be tax-exempt.
The agreement is expected to help local enterprises to promote their products in South America, according to an official of the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA).
The ROC government proposed the agreement idea during the first meeting for vice economics ministers of the ROC and five Central American countries held in August last year.

Bilateral trade between Taiwan and El Salvador reached US$87.6 million last year, with Taiwan exporting products worth US$87.1 million to El Salvador, while importing US$532,000-worth of products from the Central American country.

DOC.HEADLINE: WOMEN'S CONTRIBUTIONS TO LABOR UNDERESTIMATED: ROC MINISTER
DOC.DATELINE: Beijing, Aug. 22 (CNA) (By Lee An-tung and Elisa Kao)

TEXT.P: Republic of China Interior Minister Chang Po-ya said Thursday that most countries have made the pursuit of gender equality their "main goal," as the contributions made by women are "usually underestimated."
Chang made the remarks at the 2001 Women Leaders Meeting under the framework of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum, which is presently under way in Beijing.
In a panel discussion on women's participation in economic activities, Chang said the treatment of women in the workplace still lags behind that of men, whether in advanced or developing countries.

She went on to say that Taiwan has begun to compile statistics among men and women in various aspects, including personal security, health, employment, education and insurance, social and political participation, media, marriage and family and culture and entertainment, to serve as reference for the government when it draws up its policies.
The statistics, which were compiled according to APEC regulations, are expected to be completed in 2004.
The minister indicated that through the statistics, the government will be able to easily notice gender differences in society and take steps to amend the situation.
Meanwhile, that day, there were also panel discussions on small- and medium-sized enterprises, science and technology and manpower resources.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRAYER CEREMONY HELD ON ANNIVERSARY OF AUG. 23 ARTILLERY WAR

TEXT.P: A Buddhist ceremony was held on the frontline Republic of China island of Kinmen Thursday to "appease the souls" of the military and civilian victims of the Aug. 23 Artillery War that took place over four decades ago.
Twelve dharma masters from Taiwan's Fuokuangshan Temple led some 300 members of the public, soldiers and veterans in saying Buddhist prayers that honored the fallen.
The Artillery War was a key moment in ROC history because the war made mainland China realize that it did not have the power to invade Taiwan.

On Aug. 23, 1958 -- nine years after the Chinese communists forced the Kuomintang government to retreat to Taiwan -- the world watched in alarm as the Aug. 23 Artillery War broke out in Kinmen, the nearest ROC territory to the mainland.

At the crack of dawn, concentrated fire from over 300 artillery pieces blanketed the tiny island just off the coast of the mainland. The communists were determined to shell the ROC troops into submission.
Artillery shells hammered the ground like torrential rain, plowing up everything in their path.
Kinmen was ravaged by more than 57,500 shells in the span of just two hours.

Both sides threw their navies and air forces into the fray. On Aug. 25, the communists set up a blockade of Kinmen and stepped up their artillery offensive. Kinmen responded with its own counterattack.
The two sides traded shots back and forth until Oct. 6, when the communists announced a cease-fire.
The official tally put the estimated number of shots fired by the mainland Chinese at 479,554.

During the 44-day confrontation, each square kilometer of Kinmen's landscape was dotted by an unprecedented world record average of 3,197 shells, which translates into roughly three hits per square meter.

The troops on Kinmen were able to force the communists to halt their bombardments for several reasons, including the high morale on the part of the garrison forces and the support of the United States, England, France, the Philippines, Argentina and South Korea.

The United States and the Republic of China at that time were still diplomatic allies, and the two shared a mutual defense pact that proved important at the time of the Aug. 23 Artillery War because the Seventh Fleet moved into position to prepare for any possible escalation of the conflict and even began escorting ROC supply ships.

In 1960, two years after the Artillery War, the communists began their artillery onslaughts anew, with the first of two periods of lesser bombardment. Shelling on alternate days, the mainland artillery attacks continued until 1978, when a formal declaration to end the shelling was made.

After the end of the Aug. 23 Artillery War, the ROC military crafted several tunnels out of granite cliffs for the use of mechanized landing ships as well as personnel and vehicle landing ships to make supply runs to Kinmen.
The tunnels protected the waterway entry of the ships, allowing them to carry out their missions despite the persistent bombardments.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CALLS FOR TALKS WITH BEIJING UNDER DEMOCRATIC PRINCIPLES

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian told a visiting U.S. congressional delegation Thursday that he has been pushing for the normalization of Taipei-Beijing relations, but principles of democracy, parity and peace must be upheld during bilateral interaction.
Chen told U.S. House International Relations Committee Chairman Henry Hyde and his bipartisan delegation that cross-Taiwan Strait issues must be resolved through dialogue and negotiations.
However, he added that the will and the right of choice of the 23 million people of Taiwan must be respected in the process, safeguarding the principle of democracy.
Chen went on to say that the principle of parity means the relationship between Taiwan and mainland China must not be that of a local government and a central government.
The principle of peace dictates that the mainland should not resort to the use of force or military intimidation, but should instead embrace dialogue, he added.

Chen said that his integration theory, the opening of the "mini three links," preparations to open Taiwan to mainland tourists and plans to ease restrictions on Taiwanese investment in mainland China are all concrete actions that serve to show Taiwan's sincerity in improving bilateral relations.

However, he lamented that Beijing has not only failed to respond kindly to these goodwill gestures, it has even attempted to use divisive means to affect Taiwan's internal unity and create cross-strait tension by deploying more missiles across the strait from Taiwan.

Not only are these actions not conducive to a breakthrough in the current impasse in bilateral ties, he continued, they run against global expectations of a peaceful resolution to cross-strait issues.
Chen reiterated that the issues must be resolved in accordance with the principles of the ROC Constitution.

Only then can bilateral differences be resolved, and only then can the government and people of both sides of the strait determine the content and meaning of a mutually acceptable "one China," he added.
Chen said that the ROC government will not give up any possible opportunity that would be helpful to restarting bilateral dialogue and reconciliation.

He reaffirmed his willingness to attend the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation forum's Shanghai summit in October, adding that it could provide the occasion for the leaders of both sides of the strait to meet, shake hands and talk.

He went on to say that the summit could set the stage for and be the bridge to the resumption of bilateral dialogue and that the ROC government will not have any predetermined stance or set any limits to possible issues of discussion.

Chen claimed that "a lack of confidence" is the reason that the leaders in Beijing will not talk to Taiwan, but he added that he will continue to rely on wisdom, innovation and patience while waiting for the "stubborn rock" to give the nod.
Hyde later called on former ROC President Lee Teng-hui for a closed door meeting. They reportedly exchanged opinions on Taiwan's current political situation and the state of ROC-U.S. relations.

ROC Minister of Foreign Affairs Tien Hung-mao said during a lunch banquet held in Hyde's honor that the ROC government has always shared friendly ties with both the U.S. Republican and Democratic parties, and that such ties will remain cordial in the future.

Hyde's 34-member delegation includes Rep. Michael Bilirakis, a Republican from Florida; Paul Gillmor, an Ohio Republican; Mel Watt, a Democrat from North Carolina; and Darrell Issa, a California Democrat.

This is the first trip for Hyde -- a Republican from Illinois -- to the Asia Pacific region since he took the post of House International Relations Committee chairman in January. This is also his first visit to Taiwan since the ROC and the United States severed diplomatic relations in 1979.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL LITTLE LEAGUE: CHINESE TAIPEI BLANKS PERU
DOC.DATELINE: Mexico, Aug. 22 (CNA) (By Chen Chang-hui & Ed Chen)

TEXT.P: The Chinese Taipei nine blanked Peru 11-0 Wednesday in the International Little League Championship Tournament presently under way in Mexico.
Chinese Taipei overwhelmed the Peruvians from start to finish, scoring three points in the second half of the first inning and three more in the second half of the second inning.

The game finished ahead of schedule at the fifth inning after Chinese Taipei collected five more points in the second half of the third, earning a place in the quarter finals with six wins and one loss.
Chinese Taipei will take on Venezuela Friday and play against Brazil Saturday.

DOC.HEADLINE: MIXED RESULTS FOR TAIWAN ATHLETES AT BEIJING UNIVERSIADE
DOC.DATELINE: Beijing, Aug. 23 (CNA) (By Lee An-tung & Ed Chen)

TEXT.P: Mainland China delivered a crushing 119-65 defeat to Chinese Taipei Thursday in the women's basketball event at the 21st Universiade presently under way in Beijing.
The trouncing meant that Chinese Taipei, which ranked third in the Group B preliminary round after chalking up one win and two losses, would not advance to the quarter-finals.
In swimming, meanwhile, eight Chinese Taipei swimmers were eliminated in the preliminary round of the competition.
Lin Chi-tsang was eliminated in the women's 800-meter freestyle and Chinese Taipei was also eliminated in the men's 800-meter freestyle relay.
Lin and her team-mate Lin Chien-ju were knocked out of the women's 100-meter freestyle, while Wu Nien-ping was eliminated in the men's 100-meter backstroke.
Hung Chien-chih and Huang Chih-yung were knocked out of the men's 50-meter butterfly, while Lee Tsung-chieh failed to make it through in the men's 200-meter breaststroke.
One of the few bright spots in an otherwise dismal day was in women's volleyball, when Chinese Taipei blanked Ukraine 3-0. Chinese Taipei will take on Russia Friday and play against Mexico Saturday.
A total of 16 teams, divided into four groups, are taking part in the volleyball preliminary rounds.
Chinese Taipei, Ukraine, Russia and Mexico are in Group B and Chinese Taipei will advance to the quarter-finals if they win against either Russia or Mexico.
Meanwhile, Lu Yen-shuen of Chinese Taipei came through in men's tennis, blanking his Spanish rival 2-0 to advance to 32nd place.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP LEADER DISAPPOINTED WITH KMT OVER COOPERATION

TEXT.P: Opposition People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong expressed disappointment Thursday that the Kuomintang cannot publicly endorse any PFP candidates in the year-end county chief elections.

"To my great disappointment and regret, the KMT cannot support any PFP candidates in any of the 21 counties and cities around the island, owing to difficulties of its own." said Soong, without elaborating.
He made the remarks after a two-hour meeting with KMT Chairman Lien Chan in a last-ditch effort to work out plans to field joint candidates.
The two parties had planned to throw their weight behind a single candidate in at least six crucial counties to increase their chances of winning.

Lien took the impasse in his stride, saying that difficulties are inherent in cooperation between parties in local elections. According to Lien, of greater account is the determination on the part of both parties to set up a mechanism for cooperation.
Although the cooperation is on the verge of collapse, Lien said his party will not give up efforts to sort out its differences with the PFP.
Both Lien and Soong said in a joint statement released after their meeting that their disagreement would not deter them from working together on other issues.
They reconfirmed their parties' commitment to support whatever consensus emerges from the upcoming Economic Development Advisory Conference (EDAC).

According to the statement, Soong supported Lien's idea of calling for negotiations among different political parties to work out rules on the formation of a coalition government after the legislative election also scheduled for the year-end.

In a press conference later in the day at the KMT headquarters, Lien called on President Chen Shui-bian not to hog the right of forming a Cabinet, but rather follow the Constitution and ask whichever party enjoys the majority or can strike up an alliance with majority support at the legislature to form the Cabinet.
He also said his party will set forth "ten proposals" and make a pitch for "three reforms" at the EDAC plenary session to be opened Friday.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER URGES BELARUS TO SET UP REPRESENTATIVE OFFICE IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: Premier Chang Chun-hsiung urged Belorussia to set up a representative office in Taipei Thursday while receiving a group of visitors from Minsk.
Chang told Belarus First Vice Minister of Finance Rumus F. Nikolai that Taipei looks forward to Minsk living up to a 1996 protocol with Taipei to open an office in Taipei.
Taipei's representative office in Minsk was inaugurated July 1, 1996, six months after the protocol was concluded, and the Republic of China extended a US$35 million loan to Belarus.
Rumus expressed thanks for the ROC aid to his country in the last five years and asked for new loans to help the cash-strapped country.
He pointed out that the collapse of the Soviet Union in 1991 took a heavy toll on the defense industry, which used to be the economic lifeline of the republic.

He also said that the country is forced to earmark almost 10 percent of its gross national product every year to pay for decontamination of the radioactive fallout from the 1986 Chernobyl nuclear disaster.
He urged Taiwan to keep providing aid to his country to help bail it out of the economic crisis.
Rumus previously visited Taiwan in 1996, when he took part in the negotiations on the exchange of representative offices.

DOC.HEADLINE: COAST GUARD ADMINISTRATION TO SET UP AIR RECONNAISSANCE FORCE

TEXT.P: The National Coast Guard Administration (NCGA) is making efforts to establish an air reconnaissance force to further strengthen its patrol and rescue missions, NCGA Administrator Wang Chun said Thursday.
Wang said at a regular press conference that the Executive Yuan has already approved the plan, which will see the NCGA renting helicopters from the civil sector in the initial stages.

Wang said that as the NCGA has to patrol very large areas and also handle marine ecology protection and disaster rescue, it does not have nearly enough patrol boats, which makes the formation of an air arm all the more important.
He added that night flying will be the priority training item for the pilots of the air reconnaissance force.

Wang also said that the NCGA will hold a joint air-land-sea drill at Shalun Beach in northern Taiwan's Taipei County Aug. 31, to test the capability of NCGA personnel in stopping cargo and human smuggling and disaster rescue.

DOC.HEADLINE: KOREA BEATS RUSSIA IN 24TH WILLIAM JONES CUP BASKETBALL INVITATIONAL

TEXT.P: South Korea beat Russia 83-80 Thursday at the 24th William Jones Cup Basketball Invitational presently under way in Fengshan City, Kaohsiung.
South Korea has so far chalked up six wins without any losses, paralleling the fortunes of Chinese Taipei.
Chinese Taipei will take on South Korea Saturday in the finals of the competition.
Meanwhile that day, Mongolia defeated South Africa 93-87 and the Philippines edged out Honduras 90-85.
Standings as of Thursday were:
Team W L Chinese Taipei 6 0 South Korea 6 0 Russia 4 2 Philippines 4 2 Honduras 3 3 Canada 2 4 Mongolia 1 6 South Africa 0 7

DOC.HEADLINE: EDAC TO BE FOUNDATION FOR ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian told visiting Japanese guests Thursday that reform cannot be accomplished without bitterness.

Chen said that all the financial and economic issues facing Taiwan will be resolved after all the conclusions from the Economic Development Advisory Conference (EDAC) scheduled to open Friday have been thoroughly implemented.
These conclusions will lay the foundation for Taiwan's future economic development, he added.

Chen made the remarks while receiving members of the Japan-Taiwan Parliamentarians Amity Federation set up in May by Japan's ruling Liberal Democratic Party (LDP) parliamentarians and scheduled to be inaugurated Friday.
Chen said the federation will greatly help promote cooperation and exchange of parliamentarians between the two countries.

"I have attached much importance to relations between Taiwan and Japan since I assumed the presidency," Chen went on, adding that in addition to setting up an ad hoc committee on Japan to be presided over by Presidential Office Secretary-General Yu Shyi-kun, former secretary-general of the National Security Council, Adm. (retired) Chuang Ming-yao has been nominated to chair the Association of East Asian Relations.
This, said Chen, indicates that the ROC government and the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) attach much importance to developing relations with Japan.
Koki Kobayashi, head of the federation, agreed that the federation will help further promote relations between Taiwan and Japan.

He expressed hope that Japan will strengthen cooperation and exchanges with Taiwan and said Chen's farsighted viewpoint on relations with Japan will have a positive impact on Japan and the whole of Asia.

DOC.HEADLINE: NETHERLANDS REAFFIRMS ITS VISA REFUSAL FOR ROC OFFICIALS
DOC.DATELINE: Brussels, Aug. 23 (CNA) (By Tang Ping-chun & Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: The Dutch Foreign Ministry reconfirmed Thursday its refusal to grant visas to five leaders of the Republic of China.

In a July 19 letter to the Parliamentarian Foreign Relations Committee, the ministry said it has followed the practice of European Union states in denying visas to the ROC president, vice president, premier, foreign minister and defense minister, because their trips are often "politically charged."
As for ordinary ROC citizens, they can still obtain visas from The Hague's trade office in Taipei.
The ministry reconfirmed what the July 19 letter said adding that the country's practices are in line with those of the other Schengen convention signatories.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, Aug. 24, or the sixth day of the seventh month of the Year of the Snake according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
79AD: Mount Vesuvius erupts and destroys Pompeii, Herculaneum, Stabiae, and a number of smaller settlements in Italy.
1770: British poet Thomas Chatterton becomes depressed and fatally poisons himself with arsenic in London at age 18. He duped scholars by ascribing his poetry to a 15th-century monk, Thomas Rowley.
1814: The small but very bitter war being fought between Britain and the United States continues, with British forces razing many Washington, D.C. landmarks, including the White House.
1923: A "Dr. Sun Yat-sen mission" led by Chiang Kai-shek leaves Harbin for Moscow on a fact-finding tour.
1945: Chiang Kai-shek, chairman of China's Nationalist government, signs the ratification instrument of the U.N. Charter.
1945: The Legislative Yuan of the Republic of China ratifies the Sino-Soviet Treaty of Friendship and Alliance.
1950: Communist China sends troops into Tibet.
1954: U.S. President Dwight D. Eisenhower signs into law the Communist Control Act, outlawing the Communist Party.
1954: Brazilian President Getulio Vargas shoots himself to avoid scandal as well as demands that he relinquish power. He was 71.
1968: Taichung's Golden Dragons baseball team defeats the U.S. West team 5A-0 to win the 23rd Little League World Championship.
1981: A Manhattan Supreme Court judge jails Mark David Chapman for 20 years to life for shooting dead John Lennon the previous December.
1983: The auditorium of Fengyuan High School in Taichung County collapses, killing 27 students and injuring 83 others.
1983: Communist Chinese pilot Lt. Col. Sun Tien-chin, who flew to South Korea from mainland China in a MiG-21 jet fighter Aug. 7, arrives in Taiwan.
1985: Communist Chinese pilot Hsiao Tien-jun, 33, flies an H-5 torpedo attack bomber to South Korea and requests political asylum in the ROC.
1986: The ROC Little League baseball team "Kungyuan" defeats Tucson, Arizona, and recaptures the Little League World Series title after four years.
1991: The Ukraine declares independence from Moscow.
1991: Mikhail Gorbachev resigns as head of the Soviet Communist Party and urges its leadership to disband the party.
1992: Communist China and South Korea establish diplomatic relations.
1995: President Juan Carlos Wasmosy of Paraguay leads a delegation to Taipei for a four-day visit.
1995: Beijing expels Chinese-American human rights activist Harry Wu shortly after he was sentenced to a 15-year prison term for spying and leaking state secrets.
1996: The ROC wins the 1996 Little League World Series in the U.S. city of Williamsport, Pennsylvania.
1999: A UNI Air plane from Taipei crash-lands at Hualien Airport in flames, injuring 28 passengers.
1999: Ever Decent, a Panamanian-flagged container ship owned by Taiwan's Evergreen Marine Corp., is hit by Norwegian Dream, a Bahamas-registered cruise ship, injuring three people aboard the cruise ship.
2000: ROC President Chen Shui-bian wraps up his visit to Chad ahead of schedule after issuing a joint communique with Chadian President Idriss Deby.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "He who possesses great moral qualities will certainly attain a corresponding high position, a corresponding great prosperity, a corresponding great name, and a corresponding great age."

DOC.HEADLINE: UNITED STATES AND ROC SIGN GOVERNMENT PROCUREMENT AGREEMENT

TEXT.P: The Republic of China and the United States signed a memorandum of understanding on Thursday, clarifying Taiwan's commitments to the World Trade Organization's Government Procurement Agreement (GPA) following Taiwan's accession to the WTO.

The signing ceremony was held at American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) headquarters. Richard C. Bush, chairman and managing director of AIT and C. J. Chen, representative of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Representative Office in the United States, signed on both governments' behalf.
Bush said during the ceremony that the agreement clarifies and updates Taiwan's commitments under the WTO GPA and addresses U.S. bilateral market concerns in this specific area.

He said this agreement has turned a "lose-lose" situation into a "win-win" one, adding that Taiwan will also benefit from enhanced access to the U.S. government procurement market by virtue of its anticipated accession to the WTO GPA in the near future.
Chen said the agreement addresses the concerns of the U.S. and, most importantly, demonstrates Taiwan's efforts to liberalize the government procurement market.
According to U.S. official estimates, Taiwan's commitments cover over US$15 billion over the next 10 years in infrastructure projects and procurement of a wide range of other goods and services.

Linda S. Droker, director for Korea and Taiwan affairs with the U.S. Department of Commerce, said this understanding is the last agreement within the bilateral WTO accession package signed by the U.S. and Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORTUNE DEBUTS BILL POWELL'S 'CHINA DIARY' COLUMN

TEXT.P: Fortune magazine announced Wednesday that Bill Powell, its bureau chief in Beijing, will write a weekly column which will appear on the Fortune Web site -- www.fortune.com.

Titled "China Diary," the column will not only focus on economics and business in mainland China, but will take a wide-ranging look at a variety of subjects pertaining to that area and Asia in general, covering the gamut of contemporary culture, history and politics.

In his debut column, "Japan or China? It ain't easy," currently available on the Web site, Powell looks at how China and Japan are becoming more integrated economically than they have ever been in the postwar era. "Yet at the same time," says Powell, "that integration is contributing significantly to a marked increase in tension between these two. That tension is deeply rooted, extends well beyond economics, and isn't going away anytime soon."

"China Diary" is a strong addition to Fortune's roster of online columns, including Andy Serwer's "Street Life" and Justin Fox's "London Calling," said Fortune international editor Robert Friedman. "This is part of our ongoing commitment to international business news coverage, in addition to what we cover in the magazine every two weeks."
Powell joined Fortune in July 2000. Previously, he was at Newsweek, where he worked in a number of foreign bureaus, including Moscow, Berlin and Tokyo, in addition to working in the New York office.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN OFFICIATES AT ECONOMIC ADVISORY CONFERENCE OPENING

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian officiated at the opening of the plenary session of the much-anticipated Economic Development Advisory Conference Friday, a series of meetings and discussions designed to invigorate Taiwan's floundering economy.

Addressing participants at the opening ceremony, Chen vowed to use the conference as a vehicle to chart a new direction for Taiwan that takes into account both economic development and social justice. Chen said that Taiwan stands at a historically critical juncture and is at the beginning of the second phase of a program he advocated last year he termed, "The third way for Taiwan: a new political perspective."

Chen said the nation "will not be defeated by recession as long as we retain our courage to conquer adversities," adding that "for our country we have no right to be pessimistic, but only have inescapable duties and responsibilities."

The president reiterated that consensus of opinions and suggestions that are reached during the conference, albeit non-binding, should be carried out by all ministerial-level officials and Cabinet-level agencies.
He said that conclusions regarding policies would be addressed immediately following the end of the conference.

Chen assured the nation that the administration will carry out the recommendations of the participants of the conference to the best of its ability with "three determinations, an integrated implementation program and a guarantee."

Chen stressed that the administration is determined to put Taiwan, the economy and the investment climate as priorities on the list of policy implementation; determined to reconcile differences between the administration and the Legislature; and determined to better cooperation between the ruling Democratic Progressive Party and opposition parties. The president also said that he would not attach preconditions or bottomlines to the implementation of the conclusions reached during the conference.

The five preliminary conference panels have put forward 314 consensus opinions, 38 majority opinions and 39 other proposals, all of which will be discussed during the Aug. 24-26 plenary sessions, according to Presidential Office Secretary-General Yu Shyi-kun.
President Chen will take part in the three-day session to underline the emphasis he places on the conference, which he himself ordered to convene, Yu said.
In addition to the discussions, Chen will also preside over the plenary session closing ceremony, as well as a post-conference news briefing Aug. 26, barring unforeseen emergencies, Yu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: BROKERAGE HOUSES FEELING THE HEAT FROM ASIAN MELTDOWN

TEXT.P: The brokerage industry's downsizing in Asia is another sign of the region's economic slump, and Asia's economies will be the big losers, Asiaweek magazine reports in its current issue.

What's worse, according to senior editor Tim Healy of the Hong Kong-based magazine, there's little prospect for a rebound. The big Western banks that rushed into Asia, looking for big returns in risky emerging markets, have finally lost patience, he adds.

Asiaweek finds that while the most immediate reasons for the cuts can be linked to sluggish markets and lower stock trading volume, more general investor flight from emerging markets is the real problem.

Asia is no longer seen as a sure bet, the magazine warns. It quotes Chia Teck Yew with PricewaterhouseCoopers in Singapore as claiming that international banks "no longer look at Asia as a place where they can make money," and are returning to the more stable markets in the West.

The constant flow of new lay-off announcements from blue-chip financial institutions such as Credit Suisse First Boston, Prudential Securities and J.P. Morgan represents "wrenching structural changes," according to Healy. The real crux of the situation is that "some of the lost jobs currently twirling down the drain won't come back."

The brokerage houses that didn't reap the fruits of the traditional model of "greater risk, greater reward" in Asia are leaving in droves, Asiaweek says, adding that brokerage houses around the region are shrinking and that every major city is feeling the pinch.

Investment banks in Asia, which probably employed more than 100,000 people four years ago, have slashed their workforce by as much as one-quarter, it says. A prime example is Jakarta, where the 16 foreign brokerages during that time have shrunk to five this year, with two more on the way out.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Shares prices opened low and closed even lower on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) on Friday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 149.44 points to close at 4,310.32.
The bourse opened at 4,430.42, and continued to go down due to a plunge in electrical shares. The index fluctuated between 4,430.42 and 4,303.34 during trading.

A total of 2.1 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$44.97 billion (US$1.3 billion), an increase from the previous trading session which saw 1.8 billion stocks change hands on a market turnover of NT$43.29 billion (US$1.25 billion).

All of the eight major stock categories lost ground, with electrical shares moving down the most at 4 percent, followed by textile issues at 3.4 percent, plastics and chemical shares at 3.1 percent, construction stocks at 3 percent, foodstuffs shares at 2.6 percent, bank and insurance stocks at 2.3 percent, cement stocks at 1.4 percent, and pulp and paper issues at 1 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 452 to 81, with 56 stocks remaining unchanged.
