DOC.HEADLINE: UNEMPLOYMENT INFECTS URBAN AREAS AND HI-TECH INDUSTRIES

TEXT.P: Newly released unemployment statistics show that jobless rates are continuing to rise in urban areas and those affected include not only workers in traditional industries but also white-collar employees in the hi-tech sector.
The Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) reported Thursday that Taiwan's unemployed population reached 485,000 at the end of July, with the jobless rate at 4.92 percent.

The jobless rate has been on the rise for 10 consecutive months and officials say more employed people are likely to lose their jobs in the coming months because layoffs are becoming more commonplace in traditional industries as well as in the hi-tech sector due to the economic recession.

Hi-tech companies in the Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park have laid off or pensioned more than 4,000 workers since early this year. Sluggish business performance suffered by many industrial companies in the park has had an effect on satellite factories of these companies in neighboring areas.
The jobless rate in Hsinchu City in July was 4.82 percent and that of Hsinchu County was 4.19 percent, according to government statistics.

At the end of June, there were 305 industrial companies based in the Hsinchu industrial park, with seven new establishments to begin operations soon. There are 101,511 employees at these companies, a decrease of 1,330 from last year's level. According to a DGBAS official, more factories but fewer workers seems to indicate that companies are trying to cut down on personnel expenses.

Kaohsiung city and county, which houses most of the traditional industries such as petrochemicals, iron, steel and cement, continue to lead the list of areas with high unemployment rates. The jobless rate in Kaohsiung City in July was 5.31 percent; Kaohsiung County stood at 5.15 percent.
However, as more employees of the hi-tech sector and service industries have lost their jobs in the past months, the problem of urban unemployment is surging, the official said.

In July, the jobless rates in Taipei County, Keelung City and Ilan County surrounding metropolitan Taipei all exceeded 5 percent. Many residents in Taipei's neighboring counties are commuters working in Taipei. Urban unemployment is a problem shared by the neighboring regions, he added.

He said that prospects of an improved job market are not good and the jobless rate in August may surpass 5 percent. In April, there were 124 job opportunities for every 100 persons. In July, however, the ratio fell to 73 openings for every 100 persons, according the official.

What worries authorities is that an increasing number of unemployed workers are the primary wage earner for their family. Although there are an estimated 485,000 people out of work, nearly 1.16 million have been affected because the person that they had relied on for financial support had been made redundant, the official said.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECONOMIC CONFERENCE PANEL PRESENTS 'INDUSTRIAL COMPETITIVENESS' PLAN

TEXT.P: A preparatory panel under the ongoing Economic Development Advisory Conference unveiled a 10-point program Friday on upgrading Taiwan's industrial competitiveness.

Addressing a conference plenary session, Vice Premier Lai Ing-jaw, also a co-convener of the industrial competitiveness panel, said the panel had held seven seminars between July 22 and Aug. 13 to discuss a number of issues related to the transformation of traditional industries and the upgrading of their competitiveness.

"All panel members have agreed on major reform principles and come up with many concrete proposals," Lai said, adding that some panelists have also presented special opinions on certain reform issues.

Lai said the panel had extensive discussions on measures to enhance competitiveness of various traditional and high-tech industries, promote research and development, expand the high-tech talent pool, boost the development of the knowledge-based economy, revise corporate management statutes and upgrade agricultural technologies and management in preparation for Taiwan's imminent accession to the World Trade Organization.

Lai further outlined the consensus reached by all panelists, including offering incentives to attract more foreign and mainland Chinese professionals to work in Taiwan; allowing more conscripts to work at private high-tech companies as an alternative to compulsory military services; and easing restrictions on issuing corporate bonds and the public listing of venture capital firms.

The panel also forged a consensus on the need to integrate the resources of the government, academic and industrial circles to establish a new research and development mechanism, revise the existing corporate law to facilitate mergers and acquisitions, open a single-stop service counter to offer convenient business information services, develop recreational agriculture and fishery industries to buoy economic development in rural areas and promote strategic agricultural alliances to uplift operational efficiency and competitiveness.
All the consensuses, resolutions and proposals presented by the panel were to be discussed at the plenary session of the three-day conference, which opened Friday.
The much-anticipated conference will focus on proposals presented by the industrial competitiveness and investment climate panels on its first day.

On Saturday, discussions will be centered around proposals presented by the financial reform and employment panels. The final day of the meeting will focus on proposals initiated by the panel in charge of affairs related to relations across the Taiwan Strait.
President Chen Shui-bian, who concurrently serves as chairman of the 120-member conference, has pledged to fully implement suggestions that have been fully agreed to by all participants.

DOC.HEADLINE: SURVEY FINDS MANY MARRIED COUPLES LIVE UNHAPPILY EVER AFTER

TEXT.P: A majority of married couples in Taiwan are not happy and most of them do not think that their marriages are right, results of a recent poll show.

Conducted by the Taipei Christian Academy just days before the first Chinese Valentine's Day of the 21st century, the survey questioned married adults islandwide. The academy found that 93 percent felt unhappy in marriage and 90 percent did not think they made the right decision to get married. The survey also showed that 90 percent do not feel right about their marriage.

A total of 88 percent of the respondents felt that their spouses do not dote on them or do not love them dearly enough and only 16.3 percent of them consider themselves happier now than before they got married, the survey found.

The survey also showed that 67 percent of the respondents think their spouses are garrulous or complaining, and 53 percent of them worry that their spouses may have had or are having an extramarital affair.
Less than one-third of the respondents say their spouses understand their feelings and thoughts and only 26.2 percent say they could share secrets with their spouses, according to the poll.

Chang Kun-chih, director of the academy, a charitable organization committed to social welfare, said Taiwan's marital relationships need repair as the number of marriages is falling while the divorce rate is climbing.

Chang quoted tallies compiled by the Ministry of the Interior as indicating that marriages in Taiwan fell year-on-year to a low in 1998 where only an average of 6.69 people in every thousand got married.

In 2000, according to the tallies, 180,000 couples married while 50,000 couples ended their relationship with divorce -- an annual rise of 6.4 percent in the number of people seeking divorce in Taiwan.
The Taipei Christian Academy conducted the recent poll via family education and consultation centers islandwide which obtained 368 valid questionnaires for the survey.

DOC.HEADLINE: N.T. DOLLAR UP ON TAIPEI FOREX MARKET

TEXT.P: The new Taiwan dollar rose NT$0.004 against the U.S. dollar on the Taipei foreign exchange market Friday, closing at 34.625.
The local currency opened Friday at 34.612 and was traded between 34.596 and 34.635.
Interbank U.S. dollar trading totaled US$327 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: POLL FINDS 58% BACK OPENING OF DIRECT CROSS-STRAIT '3 LINKS'

TEXT.P: A majority of the people of Taiwan support the proposal to open direct trade, mail and transportation links across the Taiwan Strait, more commonly known as "three links," according to the results of an opinion poll released Friday.

The telephone poll of 1,069 randomly chosen adult residents, conducted by the 21st Century Foundation Aug. 9, found that 57.8 percent of the respondents gave a thumbs-up to the proposal to open direct cross-strait "three links." Only 19.3 percent said they oppose the proposal.

According to the survey, 31.7 percent said they feel that the current Democratic Progressive Party-led administration's reluctance to open direct "three links" mainly results from its pro-independence ideology, while 22.1 percent said they think that the government's main consideration should be its worries about Taiwan's increasing economic reliance on mainland China.

Asked if the government fails to make a resolution on opening direct "three links" in the near future, 27.2 percent said they support the proposal to hold a plebiscite to decide whether the new opening measure should be implemented, but 45.8 percent gave a thumbs-down to the "referendum" proposal.

If the government continues to drag its foot on opening direct "three links," 35.3 percent said the Legislative Yuan should be authorized to make a decision; 20.2 percent said cross-party consultations should be held to discuss the issue; and only 7.5 percent said the current Economic Development Advisory Conference should be authorized to address the issue.

Analyzing the survey findings, Lin Yu-fang, an opposition People First Party candidate for the year-end legislative elections, said opening direct cross-strait "three links" complies with Taiwan's general public opinion.
Lin said some pro-independence diehards' opposition to any proposal to expand cross-strait commercial exchanges apparently violates prevailing public opinion.

DOC.HEADLINE: MARKETING, LOGISTICS IMPORTANT TO COMPETITIVENESS: CONFERENCE ADVISERS

TEXT.P: Wang Chung-yu, former chairman of the China Steel Corp., said Friday at the Economic Development Advisory Conference that the government should help Taiwan's traditional industries develop international marketing channels and ease their tax burden.

At the panel discussions on improving the competitiveness of traditional industries, Wang said that traditional industries used to be Taiwan's principle industries. In recent years, however, comparatively higher labor costs and land prices have driven up the production costs of Taiwan's traditional industries and weakened their competitiveness.

According to Wang, Taiwan's manufacturing industries have been weak in streamlining their overseas sales channels. He suggested that the government play an active role in helping manufacturers develop international marketing networks.
Legislator Lai Shyh-bao supported Wang's viewpoint, saying that Taiwan's traditional industries should put more emphasis on marketing and logistics to improve their competitiveness.

In the past years, Taiwan's traditional industries have sought to move their production facilities to Southeast Asia or mainland China where the personnel as operational costs are much lower than those in Taiwan. Legislator Chu Li-lung said that the government should face the reality of business migration and design practices to regulate it.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN OVERSEAS TOURISTS CONTINUE TO OUTNUMBER INCOMING VISITORS

TEXT.P: Taiwan tourists traveling abroad far outspent foreign travelers who came to visit Taiwan last year, according a report by the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) Friday.
Travelers from Taiwan spent an estimated US$8.1 billion overseas in 2000, while those coming to visit Taiwan only spent an estimated US$3.7 billion -- a difference of some US$4.37 billion.
The gap between outgoing money and incoming tourist dollars grew 14 percent compared with 1999, the latest statistics showed.
MOTC officials said that the trend for greater spending by Taiwan tourists abroad compared to their counterparts visiting the island has been ongoing for the last decade.
The number of outbound travelers increased from 3.36 million in 1991 to 7.32 million in 2000, while inbound visitors only increased 770,000 from 1.85 million in 1991 to 2.62 million in 2000.

DOC.HEADLINE: GREEK PARLIAMENTARY MISSION TO VISIT ROC

TEXT.P: A group of four Greek parliamentarians is scheduled to arrive in Taipei Sunday for a weeklong visit to the Republic of China, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs said Friday.
They are Georgios Tsournos, Anna Manta-Tsournou, Athineos Florinis and Gerakina Florini.
While in Taipei, they will call on Vice President of the Legislative Yuan Yao Eng-chi, Vice Minister of Foreign Affairs Chiou Jong-nan and other ROC government officials.
They will also visit economic and cultural establishments, including the Taipei World Trade Center and the National Palace Museum before leaving Sept. 2.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWANESE JUST LOVE TO USE IVS

TEXT.P: Taiwanese people -- even those not necessarily seriously ill -- believe so much in the efficacy of IVs that they consumed some 33.6 million bottles of IV fluid last year, mainly to "regain their strength."

Those 33.6 million bottles cost the nation NT$1.1 billion (US$31.88 million) in National Health Insurance bills, Huang Fu-yuan, deputy director-general of the Cabinet-level Department of Health (DOH), said Friday.

Huang quoted a recent DOH survey as indicating that about half of the local people who responded to the survey believe that a cold or a dose of 'flu will not be cured unless medicine and injections are administered by doctors.
The DOH survey also found that some 10.12 percent of the population do not think rest and drinking lots of water will help strengthen immunity against disease.

According to another recent survey conducted by the National Health Insurance Bureau (NHIB), county hospitals administer the most IVs -- administering 22.75 percent of their patients with an IV -- followed by local-level clinics, with an IV administration rate of 11.35 percent.
Medical centers islandwide have the lowest IV administration rate, but still at a relatively high rate of 6 percent as compared with those in advanced countries.

According to Huang, seniors with lower education backgrounds are most likely to request IV treatment when they go to the doctor. In southern Taiwan, some hospitals and clinics have even opened an "IV Zone" exclusively for patients receiving IV treatment, he added.

Huang called for the Taiwan public not to become "addicted" to IVs, particularly at a time when the economy is contracting, as it costs about NT$500-700 for each bottle of IV liquid, even though the fluid -- usually saline or glucose -- is cheaper than a sports drink to prepare.
He pointed out that eating two bowls of rice would provide the same benefits as a 500cc IV of glucose.
He said he is even more disapproving of those people who talk, walk around and even shop in the hospital complex trailing their IV racks around with them.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND CHINESE TOURISTS EXPECTED IN TAIWAN EARLY 2002

TEXT.P: As Taiwan is preparing to open up to tourists from mainland China in January 2002, travel businesses islandwide have decided to set up a joint federation in September to handle relevant issues, industry sources said Friday.

Wu Pao-shun, chairman of the Kaohsiung Travel Association, said at a news conference that it was decided in a meeting with industry representatives from across the island the previous evening that a joint federation for the local industry will be established Sept. 17 in a move to prepare for the opening up to mainland tourists.

The planned federation will serve as a "counter" in cross-Taiwan Strait travel exchanges and take charge of transferring applications by mainland tourists to the relevant government authorities, Wu said, adding that the mainland side has also started similar preparations.
According to Wu, around 300 local travel agencies are qualified to deal with mainland tourist package tours following initial screening by the government, with 50 of them based in Kaohsiung.

He noted that the first group of mainland tourists is expected to be given permission to travel to Taiwan in January at the earliest and that applying for a Taiwan entry permit will take around five days for mainland visitors.

Based on government assessments, as many as 365,000 mainland tourists will be allowed to visit Taiwan per year, a situation which it is estimated will help create 200,000 job opportunities in related businesses worth more than NT$100 billion (US$2.9 billion) annually, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: GUATEMALA CONGRESS PASSES RESOLUTION TO SUPPORT ROC'S U.N. ENTRY
DOC.DATELINE: Panama City, Aug. 23 (CNA) (By Oscar Chung and Elisa Kao)

TEXT.P: The National Congress of Guatemala passed a resolution Aug. 21 to show support of the Republic of China's entry to United Nations and other international organizations.
The resolution notes that the ROC, established in 1912, is the first democracy in Asia and one of the U.N. founders.

However, the resolution adds, Taiwan's 23 million people have been excluded from participation in international issues regarding public health, education, environmental protection and cultural affairs during the past 30 years because of Resolution No. 2758, which gave the ROC's seat in the U.N. to mainland China.

The resolution emphasizes that the ROC is a sovereign country that pursues democracy and peace and can serve as example to all developing countries. However, the ROC's exclusion from the U.N. and its affiliate - the World Health Organization - deprives Taiwan's people the opportunity to participate in international quarantine efforts.
Despite this, the resolution adds, Taiwan still offers technology and capital to help developing countries in public health promotion.
Guatemalan congressmen said they firmly support the return of ROC to the U.N., the WHO and other world organizations.
The congressmen also urged other Central American countries to help ROC join the U.N. and the WHO.
The Guatemalan Congress will send the resolution to the Central American Parliament to push for joint efforts in this regard.
The congressmen said they will also send the resolution to U.N. Secretary-General Kofi Annan and to the ROC Legislative Yuan.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN-JAPAN PARLIAMENTARIANS AMITY ALLIANCE SET UP

TEXT.P: A Taiwan-Japan Parliamentarians Amity Alliance was formally established Friday to help promote economic and cultural relations between the Republic of China and Japan.
Legislator Lin Chung-mo of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) was elected to chair the newly founded organization.
The alliance's Japanese counterpart -- the Japan-Taiwan Parliamentarians Amity Federation initiated by parliamentarians of Japan's ruling Liberal Democratic Party (LDP) -- was founded in May.
The alliance will also try to push the governments of the two countries to jointly safeguard the Asian-Pacific regional peace and security, Lin said in a speech at the founding ceremony.

Lin and Koki Kobayashi, chairman of the Japan-Taiwan Parliamentarians Amity Federation, signed a joint statement stressing that the main purpose of the organizations is to promote closer relations between Taiwan and Japan.

Vice Foreign Minister Wu Tzu-dan said that the ROC and Japan attach great importance to democracy and human rights and are also partners in strategic security and interest. Respect, understanding and support are the key factor to upgrade relations between the two countries, Wu said.
Chuang Ming-yao, chairman of the Association of East Asia Relations, confirmed the newly established parliamentary organization's importance to promoting Taiwan-Japan ties.
The alliance is comprised of 44 Taiwan legislators and 28 LDP dietmen.

However, only three legislators -- Chou Ching-yu (DPP), Chen Hung-chi (Kuomintang) and Chao Yung-ching (independent) attended the founding ceremony. A 10-member Japanese delegation led by Kobayashi witnessed the founding ceremony.

DOC.HEADLINE: VIOLENT BREAK-UPS RAMPANT AMONG LOCAL LOVERS: REPORT

TEXT.P: A total of 254 cases of violence arising from lovers' break-ups were reported in Taiwan between the beginning of 2000 and the end of July this year, according to a study released Friday by the Awakening Foundation.
"The number could be translated into an average of one violent break-up of lovers every two days," said Chen Chun-fen, director of the non-profit foundation's research department.

Chen said the foundation's study also found that three cases of death involving lovers' break-ups were reported per month during the period and that one case of love affair-related suicide was reported every two weeks.

Of the 57 cases of homicide following break-ups, women accounted for about 80 percent of the victims, Chen said, adding that the foundation based its study on reports collected from databanks of two local major newspapers -- the China Times and the United Daily News.
Chen said that as the National Police Administration has not compiled relevant data, the actual number of cases should be higher than the figures provided by the foundation.
The forms of violence used in the cases studied by the foundation included rape, beating, inflicting injury, intimidation or emotional blackmail, and murder, Chen said.
In 24 cases, Chen said, the women involved had nude pictures or videotapes taken of them without their consent.

The study further showed that the numbers of men and women who committed suicide over a conflict or break-up with their lovers during the period were roughly equal, Chen said, adding that suicide over soured love affairs usually resulted from a lack of extensive social support networks.

Meanwhile, the study found that women were more prone than their male counterparts to fall victim to violence resulting from lovers' break-ups, with a ratio of three to one. Moreover, about 60 percent of the attackers in cases with male victims were men.

The study also found that retaliatory measures taken by embittered lovers have become more likely to offend public safety, including arson and throwing Molotov cocktails or home-made bombs. Seven such dangerous cases were reported in 2000 and the number increased to nine in the first seven months of this year.

Chen said the foundation unveiled its study on the eve of Chinese Valentine's Day with a view to promoting the development of a new "love culture" that favors peaceful break-ups after love turns sour.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. CONGRESSMAN CALLS FOR WASHINGTON TO VOICE PROTECTION OF TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Visiting U.S. House International Relations Committee Chairman Henry J. Hyde said Friday that the United States must publicly state that it will never allow Beijing to subvert or destroy "the world's only functioning Chinese democracy" in Taiwan.

At a lunch meeting of the Chinese National Association of Industry and Commerce, Hyde told a group of local political leaders and scholars, as well as foreign diplomats, that "instead of backing away from Taiwan," the United States should hold the island's democracy up as an inspiring example to mainland China.

The Illinois Republican praised Taiwan for the "historic accomplishment" of having the first-ever democratically elected government in five millennia of recorded Chinese history in 1996, and for the first peaceful transfer of political power from one party to another last year.
Hyde said: "Elections are rare enough in this world, but peaceful transfers of power are rarer still and are the indisputable mark of the establishment of a genuine democracy and political freedom."

He went on to say that democracy brings with it a "dynamism" that is sometimes mistaken as instability. He called the political realignments currently taking place in Taiwan "a sign of strength, an indication that change and adaptation are possible, that the political system is responding to the ever-changing demands of society."

Hyde said that Taiwan's economic success is essential in convincing Beijing that a Western, market-oriented economic model would work in mainland China. He called for increasing economic links and dialogue across the Taiwan Strait.
He also criticized the Beijing government for apparently being determined to bring about Taiwan's subordination and seemingly willing to risk an armed confrontation to achieve that end.

However, he suggested that the United States should not break its ties with Beijing or impose any sanctions, but should instead continue to deepen bilateral economic ties and convince the Chinese people that an authoritarian regime is destined to fade.
The United States must help mainland China to become fully integrated into the world, he added.

Hyde's 34-member delegation includes Rep. Michael Bilirakis, a Republican from Florida; Paul Gillmor, an Ohio Republican; Mel Watt, a Democrat from North Carolina; and Darrell Issa, a California Democrat.
This is the first trip for Hyde to the Asia Pacific region since he took the post of House International Relations Committee chairman in January.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAJOR MONEY SUPPLY LEVELS REBOUND IN JULY

TEXT.P: Taiwan's three major indicators of the money supply -- M1A, M1B and M2 -- all rebounded in July, the Central Bank of China (CBC) announced Friday.

According to statistics compiled by the CBC, the narrowly defined M1A money supply (notes and coins issued by the central bank and bank deposit money) posted a minus 5.97 percent growth rate in July, up 0.79 percentage points from June, while the July M1B level (M1A plus pass-book saving deposits) posted a minus 2.92 percent growth rate, up 1.49 percentage points from a month ago.

In July, the annual growth rate of the more broadly defined M2 money supply (notes, coins held by the public, all private-sector current accounts at commercial banks, post offices and trustee savings banks, as well as private-sector deposit accounts with deposit banks, finance firms, discount houses and dealers in the money market) rose to 6.34 percent, up 0.33 percentage points from June and the third consecutive monthly increase, CBC tallies show.

CBC officials attributed the increase in July's M2 level to a rise in bank loans, investment and net value of overseas assets. The increased rate of the M2 levels averaged 5.87 percent during the January-July period, still within the growth range of between 5 percent and 10 percent targeted by the CBC.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC FOREIGN MINISTER TO VISIT GRENADA

TEXT.P: Republic of China Foreign Minister Tien Hung-mao will depart Taipei Aug. 27 for Grenada, where he will attend a meeting with his counterparts of four ROC diplomatic allies in the eastern Caribbean.

Tien is scheduled to make transit stops in New York and Boston en route to and on his return from Grenada. In New York, he will have a chance to exchange opinions with members of various U.S. think tanks, while in Boston, he will deliver a speech at Harvard University.

Tien said Friday that as there has been some criticism from U.S. Democrats of U.S. policy toward the Asia-Pacific region and as many influential analysts are highly critical of the Bush administration's foreign policy, his stays in New York and Boston will allow him to exchange opinions with some of these people so that they might develop a less negative view of Taiwan.

Concerning his meeting in Grenada, Tien said the ROC and its four diplomatic allies in the eastern Caribbean -- Commonwealth of Dominica, Grenada, St. Kitts and Nevis, and St. Vincent and Grenadines -- convened the first annual meeting of their foreign ministers in 1997.
Through these meetings, he said, the countries have expanded cooperation in political, economic, trade, cultural and various other aspects.
During the last four years, the meetings have been held alternately in the capitals of the Caribbean countries and in Taipei.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN LOSES TO VENEZUELA AT LITTLE LEAGUE CHAMPIONSHIP
DOC.DATELINE: Mexico, Aug. 23 (CNA) (By Chen Chang-hui and Ed Chen)

TEXT.P: Chinese Taipei suffered its second defeat Thursday in a battle with Venezuela, 2-6, at the International Little League Championship Tournament presently under way in Mexico City.
Because the Chinese Taipei team was guaranteed to advance to the semifinals, the team did not use its best pitcher, Chinese Taipei coach Cheng Chun-hsiang said.
The Chinese Taipei team will take on Brazil Friday, the last leg of the preliminary round.

Chinese Taipei has so far chalked up six wins and two losses in the preliminary round. The Chinese Taipei-Brazil match will not affect the Chinese Taipei position in the semifinal and Chinese Taipei, therefore, will use the same strategy when playing against Brazil.
In addition to Chinese Taipei, Venezuela, Mexico and Brazil have also been confirmed to advance to the semifinals.

DOC.HEADLINE: LABOR, ENVIRONMENTAL GROUPS PROTEST OUTSIDE EDAC SITE

TEXT.P: With the curtain finally rising on the much-anticipated Economic Development Advisory Conference (EDAC), many labor rights and environmental protection groups converged outside the meeting site Friday to promote their causes.

The demonstrators included foreign laborers, local labor rights activists and environmentalists. They had different appeals and the presence of a large crowd of unexpected petitioners added to the workload of police officers mobilized to maintain law and order in the area.
Among the petitioners were about 100 foreign workers organized by a local Catholic alliance aimed at protecting the legal rights of alien laborers in Taiwan.

The foreign demonstrators asked the Republic of China government to heed their contributions to Taiwan's economic development and not to cut wages and benefits for alien workers in the midst of the island's current economic slowdown.

The foreign petitioners said they oppose any proposal to lower their wages on the grounds that Taiwan's minimum wages for foreign workers are higher than those offered in Singapore and Hong Kong. They claimed that Singapore and Hong Kong offer better social welfare and lower brokerage fees for foreign workers. Moreover, they added, Singapore and Hong Kong do not impose time limits for foreign workers and put up less red tape for those wishing to change employers.
Major local labor rights organizations also mobilized their members to demonstrate outside the Taipei International Convention Center, site of the three-day EDAC plenary session.

Local labor rights activists urged the government not to yield to pressure from major business groups by slashing stock transaction tax and land value increment tax because such tax cuts would only benefit the wealthy and would violate taxation fairness and social justice.

The labor groups also urged the government not to ease the existing "go slow, be patient" policy on mainland China-bound investment, warning that if the government lifts curbs on cross-Taiwan Strait investment without adopting any effective support measures, Taiwan's unemployment rate will soon shoot up to 10 percent.

Meanwhile, several environmental groups, including the Taiwan Environment Protection Alliance, the Green Civil Action Alliance and the Wildlife Conservation Alliance, demonstrated against several investment projects that they claim will damage Taiwan's natural ecology and living environment. They urged the government not to heed business groups' demands at the expense of Taiwan's natural environment.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN DESERVES RECOGNITION: CANADIAN MP

TEXT.P: A Canadian member of parliament urged his government Friday to rethink its "one China" policy that recognizes Beijing.

John McKay, chairman of the Canada-Taiwan Parliamentary Association, said Canada officially adheres to a one-China policy "that says we support the Chinese government's claim that Taiwan is an inalienable part of the territory of the People's Republic of China."
In other words, Canada's relationship to Taiwan is dictated by Beijing, he wrote in The National Post, a Canadian newspaper. "It is time to rethink Canada's one-China policy," he suggested.

He pointed out that Taiwan, the island nation of 23 million, is Canada's fourth-largest trading partner in Asia and 13th-largest overall. Major Canadian companies have significant business interests there and Taiwanese visitors contribute C$300 million (US$200 million) annually to Canada's tourist industry.
And yet, he went on, this is a country Canada does not recognize because it does not want to offend Beijing.

While Taiwan's isolation could be contributed, in part, to the "monumentally stupid decision" by Chiang Kai-shek to leave the United Nations in 1971, much has changed in Taiwan since Chiang died in 1975, he said.
Taiwan no longer claims to be the government of mainland China and it has thrown off Chiang's dictatorship and fully embraced democracy, he noted.

He said Beijing's unwillingness to recognize the obvious -- that Taiwan is a separate country -- is built upon its "dubious version of reality" which reaches back to the 18th century to find what can only be described as a remote claim to Taiwan.
Canada has nevertheless followed the Beijing line and in turn has complicated relations with Taiwan. "What China might think" has driven Canada's policy with Taiwan for too long, McKay stressed.

Based upon recent evidence in other spheres, mainland China could care less what others think -- be it the Falun Gong, Tibet or legitimate democratic rights, he continued. "China is indifferent to the opinions of others, least of all ours," he said.

"The Kyoto Protocol serves as a good example of how our one-China policy impairs our national self-interest," he wrote. Taiwan has expressed its support for the protocol and has shown a willingness to voluntarily comply with specific emissions standards.

Taiwan, however, cannot sign the Kyoto Protocol because of its lack of legal status and therefore it is reduced to non-binding arrangements and memoranda of understanding. Canadian governments and companies will be legally bound by the protocol, but Taiwan and Taiwanese companies will not. The costs of compliance will go directly to the Canadian bottom line, but the Taiwanese will not be under such similar stricture, creating a potential commercial disadvantage to Canada, he reasoned.

During a recent visit to Taiwan, McKay and other Canadian MP's met with President Chen Shui-bian. Chen raised the issue of Taiwan joining the World Health Organization, McKay said. Taiwan wishes to be a good global citizen and Chen wanted Canada's support. "What could be more obvious than having this dynamic island nation join a worldwide organization dedicated to improving world health?" he asked.

Mainland China, however, pressures nations like Canada to resist the application, he pointed out. The one China policy means that Taiwan has no legal status and therefore cannot participate in world health initiatives. "How sensible is it to jeopardize health because of PRC pressure? Is that in our national or international self-interest?" he asked.

He said that every time a Taiwanese official expresses a desire to come to Canada for meetings at the ministerial level, the Canadian government goes through its elaborate calibration of the "offense quotient" to Beijing. The merits of a meeting with a Taiwanese minister or even the president of one of our largest trading partners is of secondary concern.

"In Canada we like to reward our friends, encourage robust democracy, rules-based trade and respect for human rights. Similarly, we are critical of countries that abuse human rights, ignore the rule of law and remain a one-party state. In the case of Taiwan, we are punishing those who espouse the values we hold dear," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: ARSON INCREASES SIGNIFICANTLY IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Cases of arson are mounting in Taiwan, with willful fire-raising in the first six months of this year increasing by 33.9 percent over the same period of last year, according to government statistics released Friday.
Interior Ministry statistics show that 7,141 fires were reported in Taiwan in the first six months, with arson cases totaling 620.
Southern Taiwan's Kaohsiung County suffered the largest number of fires, with 734 cases, followed by Yunlin County, with 544 cases and Tainan County, with 531 cases.

Interior Ministry officials attributed the main causes of fires to the burning of weeds and garbage, accounting for 2,551 cases, followed by fires caused by faulty electric equipment, with 1,012 cases, fire caused by cigarette butts, with 750 cases and arson, with 620 cases.
The statistics also show that the fires killed 106 people and injured 461 people in the same period.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN MINISTER `OPTIMISTIC' U.S. WILL NOT THWART ROC U.N. BID

TEXT.P: Republic of China Minister of Foreign Affairs Tien Hung-mao said Friday that he is "cautiously optimistic" that the United States will not thwart Taipei's bid to join the United Nations this year.

Tien expressed his hope that the United States will not make any comments which might affect Taipei's efforts to join the U.N. this year and revealed that "we have reason to believe that the United States will not do so this year, according to the information we have received."
The foreign affairs minister made the remarks during a tea party with local reporters prior to his imminent departure for four of the ROC's diplomatic allies in the Caribbean.

To the U.S. State Department, Taiwan's bid to join the U.N. is not a pressing issue, he claimed, adding his hope that the Bush administration, unlike the Clinton administration of the past two years, will refrain from making negative comments about Taiwan's bid to enter the international organization.

Tien, however, pointed out that it will not be clear until the last minute how the matter will develop, although he noted that Washington voiced its support this year for Taiwan's membership of the World Health Organization as an observer.

Should the United States change its approach and attitude regarding Taiwan's U.N. bid, it will certainly have some leverage in France and Britain -- something Taiwan cannot achieve by itself -- Tien said.

DOC.HEADLINE: MORE THAN 7,000 PEOPLE TRAVEL UNDER `MINI THREE LINKS': MAC

TEXT.P: A total of 7,653 people had traveled directly between Taiwan and mainland China this year as of Aug. 15 under the "mini three links" framework, the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) reported Friday.

According to the MAC, 7,346 Taiwan residents and 307 mainland Chinese people have traveled during the period on a total of 97 round trips -- 84 and 13, respectively -- between the Republic of China-held Kinmen and Matsu islands and Xiamen and Fuzhou ports in mainland China's Fujian Province.
No travelers sailed between Matsu and Fuzhou during the first seven months of this year, but a trade and culture promotion delegation from Fuzhou made a voyage to Matsu in August.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP ALTERS YEAR-END ELECTION STRATEGY

TEXT.P: People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong said his party will withdraw from the year-end election of county chiefs in two crucial counties and refocus its energy on the legislative elections.

Claiming that "the PFP will not engage in any battle it has no chance of winning," Soong announced the withdrawal of party candidate Chin Chin-sheng from the election for the Taipei County magistrateship and candidate Chung Shao-ho from the race for Kaohsiung County magistrateship.
However, he went on, the party will back to the hilt its candidates for the county halls in Nantou, Hualien, Lienchiang, Kinmen, Taitung and Changhua.
Soong asked for his supporters' forgiveness because of the party's abrupt change in policy.
He made the announcement one day after the collapse of cooperation talks between his party and the Kuomintang (KMT).

Since the PFP has re-calibrated its election campaign to try and expand its presence in the legislature, Soong said his party will ask Chung, who is a legislator, to run for re-election, while Chin will help with the party's day-to-day work.

Chung, who was informed of Soong's decision just five minutes before Soong broke the news at a press conference, said in Kaohsiung County that he felt "shock and regret" and complained that the party authorities bowed to the KMT too readily.

He said he will ask the party authorities to reconsider the decision and take into account the political fallout from the withdrawal decision, which concerns not only himself but also the party and the party's credibility among its supporters.

Meanwhile, a KMT chief for the party's Kaohsiung County branch expressed thanks for Soong's decision, saying that it will help the KMT and its allies to win the Democratic Progressive Party's power base in the year-end election.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI WINS 16 GOLD MEDALS IN INTERNATIONAL CHILDREN'S GAMES

TEXT.P: Republic of China child athletes did well in the 2001 International Children's Games in Budapest, Hungary, gaining 16 gold medals, four silvers and two bronzes, according to sporting sources in Taipei.

The ROC's 45-member delegation, led by officials of the Cabinet-level Council on Physical Fitness and Sports and Taipei City Deputy Mayor Pai Hsiu-hsiung, also earned the right to host the 2002 International Children's Games in Taipei.

A farewell party was celebrated at the end of the games Aug. 23, with children of every competing country performing shows dressed in national costume. After exchanging gifts, the children promised to see each other in Taipei next year.
The games, for children aged 12-15, consist of six events -- track and field, table tennis, badminton, tennis, basketball and swimming.
The delegation is scheduled to return to Taipei Aug. 28.

DOC.HEADLINE: INDUSTRIAL COMPETITIVENESS PANEL OF EDAC REACHES 139 CONCLUSIONS

TEXT.P: The industrial competitiveness panel of the Economic Development Advisory Conference (EDAC) reached 139 conclusions Friday at a panel meeting of the EDAC formal session that will last until Sunday.
The major points of the 139 conclusions include:
-- Broaden the channels through which enterprises can attract overseas talent to work in Taiwan;
-- Enable enterprises to gain capital more easily;
-- Strengthen the internationalization of Taiwan's industries;
-- Establish a mechanism for industry and academics to join efforts in research and development;
-- Amend corporate law to assist enterprises to promote competitiveness;
-- Set up a "one-stop window" to provide information services to industries;
-- Develop high technology-based agriculture;
-- Allow five-year multiple entry for mainland Chinese and foreign hi-tech personnel;
-- Expand trade opportunities with mainland China; and
-- Assist agriculture and fishery villages to transform to tourism-oriented villages in order to cope with the island's entry into the World Trade Organization, probably later this year.

Speaking at a post-session press conference, Wang Yung-ching, chairman of the Formosa Plastics Group and EDAC vice chairman, described the panel meeting as "fairly smooth" and said that through the implementation of the conclusions, Taiwan's industries will make great strides towards pluralization and rationalization.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIT CHIEF OPTIMISTIC ABOUT WTO MEMBERSHIP FOR TAIPEI, BEIJING
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 23 (CNA) (By Herman Pan and Bear Lee)

TEXT.P: The head of the American Institute in Taiwan said Thursday that he is happy to see the removal of the last barrier to mainland China's entry to the World Trade Organization (WTO) and that it will also benefit Taiwan.

Richard Bush made the remarks when asked to comment on a statement by Long Yongtu -- chief mainland Chinese WTO negotiator -- several days ago that both Taiwan and mainland China will be admitted into the organization at a ministerial meeting of the WTO to be held in Qatar in November.

"We understand that there is one issue with respect to the PRC's accession. We are pleased that it can be resolved in a satisfactory way, so that the PRC and Taiwan's accession can proceed in the next couple of months," said Bush, whose agency is charged with handling exchanges with Taiwan in the absence of official relations between the United States and Taiwan.
"I think it's good for Taiwan, good for the PRC and good for the international trading system," he added.

However, U.S. trade officials who asked to remain anonymous said that Lung's remarks seemed to lack accuracy, as the adoption of entry documents by the upcoming WTO ministerial meeting will not necessarily ensure immediate WTO admission of Taiwan and mainland China.

They said that the two economies' entry protocols will have to be approved by their respective congresses first and then their government will have to officially notify the WTO that they will accept WTO norms, before they are formally admitted.
The officials pointed out that it will take time for all these processes, and estimated that the admission of Taiwan and mainland China will only be possible in next January at the earliest.

Membership for Taiwan, which has completed all its bilateral talks with WTO members on entry terms, has been tied to that of mainland China because of a tacit understanding among WTO members that it should be admitted just one step behind mainland China.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN WINS 2 GOLD MEDALS, 1 SILVER, 1 BRONZE AT WORLD GAMES
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Aug. 24 (CNA) (By Mike Chang & Ed Chen)

TEXT.P: Chinese Taipei won two gold medals, one silver and one bronze in the women's skating event Friday at the Sixth World Games now taking place at Akita City, Japan.

Pan Li-ling captured Taiwan's first gold of the games in the women's 300-meter speed skating, finishing with a time of 26.978 seconds. Her team-mate Pan I-chin finished third, with a time of 27.597 seconds, to take bronze.
Later in the day, Pan Li-ling gained another gold in the women's 500-meter speed skating event, while Pan I-chin captured silver.

Meanwhile, in the pool-billiards event, Yang Ching-shuen advanced to the men's semi-finals Friday after defeating his U.S. rival Cecil Hall 11-7, while Chen Tsun-tsen made the semi-finals of the women's competition after beating her German competitor Franziska Stark 9-6.
Liu Hsin-mei, another local player, was eliminated after losing to Ireland's Julie Kelly.
Yang will vie for a place in the final Saturday when he plays Germany's Thomas Engert.
The Chinese Taipei delegation has so far chalked up two golds, three silvers and three bronzes since the games opened Aug. 16.
A total of 2,266 athletes from 91 countries and regions around the world are taking part in the 11-day competition, which will close Aug. 26.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. CONGRESSMAN TO VISIT TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Peter T. King (R-NY), a member of the U.S. House of Representatives, will arrive in Taipei Aug. 27 for a four-day visit.

While in Taipei, King will call on President Chen Shui-bian, Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng, Premier Chang Chun-hsiung, Minister of National Defense Wu Shih-wen, Mainland Affairs Council Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen and Deputy Minister of Foreign Affairs Wu Tzu-dan.
He will also visit several cultural and economic establishments of the Republic of China.
The main purpose of King's trip is to better acquaint himself with cross-Taiwan Strait relations, Taiwan's foreign policy and the country's defense needs.
He also intends to seek to strengthen bilateral cooperation on investment and trade between the State of New York and Taiwan.
King presently serves on the House International Relations Committee and the Financial Services Committee.
A good friend of Taiwan, King has fully supported several House bills and resolutions, including the recently passed Resolution No. 428 on Taiwan's WHO bid this year.
He is scheduled to leave Taipei Aug. 30.

DOC.HEADLINE: 75 CONSENSUS ON INVESTMENT REACHED IN ECONOMIC CONFERENCE

TEXT.P: The plenary session of the Economic Development Advisory Conference (EDAC) Friday cut 83 consensus reached by an earlier panel discussion to 75.
-- Establish norms for environmental impact assessment, making it a transparent, rapid and systematized process;

-- Speed up the release of land in industrial zones delineated by the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) by easing restrictions on use of such land, adjusting prices in accordance with market demand, buying the land with government budget and leasing it out;
-- Follow the MOEA's plans on the development of water sources to stabilize water supplies;
-- Push ahead with government reform; and
-- Encourage the establishment of venture capital to invest in the high technology industry;
The consensus reached by the panel but downgraded to "majority opinion" at the plenary session because of objections by some EDAC members included:
-- Encourage the development of high technology industry by copying the tax breaks offered by other countries to this industry;

-- Open the island to mainland Chinese investors -- as long as it does not compromise the national security and interest -- and push for mergers between local firms to attract foreign investment and mainland Chinese investment;
-- Oppose a referendum on the fourth nuclear plant because of its negative influence on investment;
-- Allow banks to give a preferable appraisals to stock prices in the traditional industry sector and extended loans to them accordingly; and
-- Cut by half tariffs on raw materials and machinery for "vital" industries.

DOC.HEADLINE: ANOTHER BAD DAY FOR CHINESE TAIPEI AT 21ST UNIVERSIADE
DOC.DATELINE: Beijing, Aug. 24 (CNA) (By Lee An-tung & Ed Chen)

TEXT.P: The Chinese Taipei delegation to the 21st Universiade continued its run of poor performance Friday as the competition entered its fifth day.
In addition to Hsieh Su-tze, seven others were eliminated in the first heat of the women's 50-meter breaststroke swimming event.
Hsieh was advanced to quasi-final after finishing 29.63 seconds.
In the women's table tennis event, mainland China defeated Chinese Taipei 3-0, but with second place overall, Chinese Taipei had already qualified for the Group 5 quarter-finals.

In women's judo, Liu Su-yun lost to her Polish rival in the 63-70 kg category, while in volleyball, Chinese Taipei's men's and women's teams both lost, to South Korea and Russia, respectively. The men's defeat put them out of the competition, but the women still have the chance to advance to the quarter-finals if they can beat Mexico Saturday.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC TAKES WILLIAM JONES CUP FOR FIRST TIME IN 26 YEARS

TEXT.P: For local basketball fans, Aug. 24 is a day to celebrate since the home team captured the William Jones Cup Basketball Invitational for the first time in its 26-year history Friday by edging out South Korea 69-58.

Eight teams -- South Korea, Russia, South Africa, Honduras, Mongolia, Canada, the Philippines and Chinese Taipei -- took part in the nine-day competition held at the Fengshan Stadium in southern Taiwan's Kaohsiung County.
Both Chinese Taipei and South Korea had advanced to the finals with six wins and no losses in the preliminary rounds.
The stadium was packed with fans who saw Chinese Taipei come from behind to beat Korea 21-16 in the first set.
In the second set, Chinese Taipei then employed a one-on-one defense strategy instead of the expanded defense method of the first set, eventually trouncing Korea 69-58.
In the two games played that day, Russia beat the Philippines 81-71 to win third place and Honduras edged out Canada 70-67 for fifth place.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, Aug. 25, or the seventh day of the seventh month of the Year of the Snake according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1530: Ivan IV, known as "Ivan the Terrible," the Russian Tsar who executed more than 3,000 people, including the royal heir, is born.
1819: James Watt, English engineer and inventor of the steam engine, dies at the age of 83.
1270: Louis IX, known as "Saint Louis," the king of France who led the Seventh Crusade against Egypt in 1248, dies in a subsequent crusade to Tunisia at the age of 56.
1718: The city of New Orleans, named in honor of the Duke of Orleans of France, is founded.
1822: Sir William Herschel, the German-born English astronomer who discovered the planet Uranus in 1781, dies at the age of 84. He also cataloged more than 800 double stars and 2,500 nebulae.
1825: Uruguay declares independence from Spain.
1867: Michael Faraday, the English chemist and physicist who invented the first electrical cell (battery), dies at the age of 76.
1875: Englishman Matthew Webb makes history by becoming the first person to swim the English Channel. The 27-year-old master mariner covers the 34-kilometer stretch from Dover to Calais in 21 hours 45 minutes.
1900: Friedrich Wilhelm Nietzsche, the German philosopher whose written works include "Thus Spake Zarathustra," dies at the age of 55. He reasons that Christianity's emphasis on the afterlife makes its believers less able to cope with earthly life.
1912: The Chung-kuo ke-ming tung-meng hui (Society of the Common Cause) is reorganized as the Kuomintang (Nationalist Party) and holds its inauguration meeting in Beijing.
1917: Dr. Sun Yat-sen forms a military government in Canton, southern China.
1930: Sean Connery, the Scottish actor who played the leading role as "007" in seven James Bond movies and won an Oscar for best supporting actor in "The Untouchables," is born.
1940: Latvia, Estonia and Lithuania are incorporated into the Soviet Union.
1943: Lord Louis Mountbatten is appointed Supreme Allied Commander in Southeast Asia.
1944: Paris is liberated when the local German commander, General von Choltitz, surrenders to the Allies, ending a four-year ordeal that Paris and her citizens suffered at the hands of the Nazis.
1945: Vietnamese communist leader Ho Chi Minh announces the formation of the Democratic Republic of Vietnam (DRV).
1989: The spacecraft Voyager 2 beams back to earth pictures of Neptune.
1960: The Republic of China Olympic team carries a large sign reading "Under Protest" in the opening procession of the Olympic Games in Rome to protest the International Olympic Committee's ruling compelling ROC athletes to compete under the name of "Taiwan" instead of the "Republic of China."
1968: Lesotho Premier Leabua Jonathan arrives in the ROC for an official visit.
1986: ROC-US trade talks on wine and tobacco imports open in Taipei. Both sides failed to settle disagreements on pricing and advertising for American products during the nine-day talks, and a new round of negotiations was planned.
1991: Byelorussia declares independence from the Soviet Union.
1992: Niger's Prime Minister Amadou Cheiffou arrives in the ROC to advance mutual understanding between the two countries.
1999: One day after former Taiwan Provincial Governor James Soong said that he has crossed the Rubicon in his presidential bid, ruling Kuomintang Secretary-General John Chang rules out any possibility that Soong could be recruited as the running mate of KMT presidential candidate Lien Chan.
1999: Taiwan's Acer Group and the Cisco Corp., the world's largest network manufacturer, jointly announce that they have established a strategic alliance.
2000: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. Chairman Morris Chang donates NT$150 million (US$4.83 million) to National Tsinghua University to establish the first technology managing college in Taiwan.
2000: The Opposition People First Party unveils the theme of "respect for history, acknowledgment of reality and joint efforts for peace" as the guidelines of its mainland policy.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "For God in giving life to all created things is surely bountiful to them according to their qualities. Hence the tree that is full of life, he fosters and sustains, while that which is ready to fall he cuts down and destroys."

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY (Aug. 26)
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, Aug. 26, or the eighth day of the seventh month of the Year of the Snake according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1346: An English army under Edward III wins an overwhelming and unexpected victory by defeating Philip VI's larger French force in the battle of Crecy.
1789: The French Assembly adopts the Declaration of the Rights of Man.
1858: Britain and Japan sign the Treaty of Edo (Tokyo), opening up Japan to British trade.
1873: Lee De Forest, American radio and television pioneer and inventor of the Audion vacuum tube, which made broadcasting possible, is born.
1906: Albert Bruce Sabin, American microbiologist and physician, is born in Poland. He developed a live-virus vaccine against polio in 1957, replacing the dead-virus vaccine invented by Jonas Salk.
1910: American physicians verify that the X-ray, discovered in 1895 by German physicist Wilhelm C. Roentgen, can help detect lung disease.
1920: The United States legislature ratifies the 19th Amendment, giving American women the right to vote.
1926: Warner Brothers, an American movie company, is successful with its premiere sound picture.
1936: Egypt and Great Britain agree to a treaty that reaffirms Egypt's independence. This treaty also reduces the number of British troops stationed in Egypt and restricts them to the Suez Canal region.
1952: The Soviet Union announces that the first successful Intercontinental Ballistic Missile (ICBM) tests have taken place.
1961: Burma becomes the world's first Buddhist republic.
1972: Sir Francis Chichester, English yachtsman who was the first senior citizen to sail around the world alone in his 53-foot yacht in 1966, dies at the age of 71.
1974: Charles Lindbergh, American aviator who made the first solo non-stop flight across Atlantic in 1927, dies at the age of 72.
1977: Premier Chiang Ching-kuo receives Richard Holbrooke, U.S. assistant secretary of state for Asian and Pacific affairs, at the Executive Yuan for a briefing on Secretary of State Cyrus Vance's trip to Peking.
1978: Cardinal Albino Luciani of Venice is elected as Pope John Paul I. He died of a heart attack on Sept. 28.
1978: President Chiang Ching-kuo decorates visiting vice president of the Republic of Costa Rica Jose Miguel Alfaro Rodriguez with the Order of the Brilliant Star with Special Grand Cordon.
1987: A sex-crazed elephant "urgently in search of a mate" runs amuck in Bangkok, killing two people and flattening a radio center.
1993: Russian President Boris Yeltsin signs a friendship treaty with the Czech Republic after condemning the 1968 Soviet-led invasion of Czechoslovakia.
1996: Prince Charles, the heir to the British throne, formally divorces Princess Diana Frances Spencer, ending 15 years of marriage.
1996: A court in Seoul sentences former President Chun Doo-hwan to death on charges of masterminding a 1979 coup and his successor, Roh Tae-woo, is sentenced to 22 years and six months in prison for playing a supporting role. Their prison terms were reduced later.
1999: A group of local legislators set up the Taiwan-Sweden Parliamentarians Association, the first time an association of this kind has been set up without using the name the Republic of China.
1999: The ROC Army unveils its Sky Bow surface-to-air missile base in Linyuan in southern Taiwan amid escalation of tension in the Taiwan Strait.
2000: Premier Tang Fei says that the government has a hard time making ends meet because the existing budget law has failed to achieve desired efficacy since its enforcement.
2000: Jan Jyh-horng, director of the Research and Planning Department of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council, says that mainland China should not impose any political barrier to the proposed opening of direct "three links" across the Taiwan Strait.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "He who possesses exceedingly great moral qualities will certainly receive the divine call to the Imperial throne."
