DOC.HEADLINE: CEPD HEAD URGES GOVERNMENT TO RAISE UPPER LIMIT FOR FUND-RAISING

TEXT.P: An economic official urged the government Saturday to raise the upper limit for fund-raising in a bid to pour more money into domestic public construction.
Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) Chairman Chen Po-chih made the call on the second day of the plenary session of the Economic Development Advisory Conference (EDAC).
The EDAC is a provisional task force set up by the Presidential Office to provide the government with suggestions on how to reinvigorate the island's sluggish economy.
He said that presently, Taiwan lags behind many developing countries in public construction and urged the government to borrow money to pave the way for the island's future development.

Chen said the CEPD is mapping out a "NT$100 billion (US$2.89 billion) a year, NT$500 billion (US$14.45 billion) in five years" public construction plan in the hope that the government will raise the upper limit for fund-raising to meet with the planned expenditure.
He noted that many advanced countries' upper limits for fund-raising exceed 40 percent, much higher than that of Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S., MAINLAND CHINA TO DISCUSS AIR, SEA ACCIDENTS

TEXT.P: The United States and mainland China will hold a special meeting next month to discuss ways to prevent accidents involving warships and aircraft of the two countries, as a result of an April 1 collision between a U.S. reconnaissance plane and a mainland jet fighter.

Lt. Cmdr. Jeff Davis, a Pentagon spokesman, said Friday that the two sides have agreed to hold the special round of talks under the 1998 Military Maritime Consultative Agreement (MMCA) in Guam Sept. 13-14.

It will be the first MMCA meeting since the incident, in which a U.S. Navy EP-3 surveillance plane collided with a mainland Chinese F-8 fighter jet, killing the fighter pilot and causing a major standoff between the two countries.

The objective of the meeting is to discuss principles of safe flight and navigation for military activities conducted on the high seas, in international airspace and in exclusive economic zones, said Davis.
"We view this meeting as an important step in working past the EP-3 incident," he said. "It will provide a proper forum for both sides to discuss the issue of avoiding future incidents."
The U.S. delegation will be led by Rear Adm. Stephen Smith, director for strategic planning and policy at the U.S Pacific Command in Honolulu.

The MMCA was signed in January 1998 during a trip to Beijing by then-U.S. Secretary of Defense William Cohen and his Chinese counterpart, Chi Hao-tien. It created a consultation mechanism to strengthen military maritime safety.
The agreement calls for plenary meetings led by two-star flag officers, preceded by working group meetings. Special meetings can also be held as needed.
There have been two plenary meetings since 1998. The meeting next month will be the first special session to be convened.

DOC.HEADLINE: LAWMAKER CALLS FOR SWEEPING TAX REFORMS

TEXT.P: Opposition New Party Legislator Lai Shyh-pao said Saturday that the government should form a tax reform committee after the ongoing Economic Development Advisory Conference (EDAC) to review the country's overall taxation system.
Lai, also an EDAC member, said that many tax reduction proposals have been put up for discussion at the current EDAC plenary session in the midst of the domestic economic slowdown.

"Even I myself support the proposal to cancel commodity taxes on certain products. But if we only cut taxes without adding new taxation sources, the government's financial difficulties will worsen further," Lai said.

Noting that all the tax adjustment proposals presented to the EDAC tend to reduce the tax burden on the wealthy while increasing taxes for poor people, Lai said tax adjustments must adopt a "two-way" approach -- slashing certain taxes while levying new taxes or raising tax rates.

Lai said that Taiwan's overall taxation system contains many problems and flaws. "Our taxation system needs a comprehensive review and sweeping reforms," Lai said, adding that the government should set up a special committee to craft tax reform measures that will update the nation's taxation system.

EDAC members from business and industry circles have suggested that the current stock transaction tax be suspended for a year and that the land value increment tax be halved for two years. Critics say the proposals favor the rich at the expense of the poor.

Both proposals were discussed at the EDAC plenary session held Saturday. Because of strong opposition from government officials and representatives of the academic community, the EDAC had yet to decide as of press time whether the two proposals would be listed as "common opinions" of all EDAC members. President Chen Shui-bian has said on many occasions that his administration will fully implement all EDAC "common opinions."

Meanwhile, Lee Tung-hao, a National Chengchi University professor and also an EDAC member, suggested that the government implement a one-third income tax cut for 2001 and 2002 to induce a domestic recovery by boosting private consumption.

Lee said private consumption tends to account for 60 percent of Taiwan's gross domestic product. "Stimulating private consumption would help revive consumer confidence and thus contribute to the domestic economic recovery," Lee explained.
As the proposed income tax cut could result in a NT$160 billion decrease in government tax revenues, Lee continued, the government should be authorized to float state bonds to help make ends meet.
Moreover, he went on, the long-established income tax exemption privilege for military servicemen and elementary and junior high school teachers should be canceled from 2003.

DOC.HEADLINE: A 268-HOUR CONTINUOUS VIGIL BY FALUN GONG

TEXT.P: About 30 Falun Gong practitioners held a demonstration and press conference Friday in front of the mainland Chinese consulate in Los Angeles to call for urgent support for Falun Gong practitioners held in the Masanjia Labor Camp in mainland China.

The press conference marked the start of a seven-day hunger strike by three local Falun Gong practitioners and a continuous 268-hour vigil representing the 268 practitioners said to have died as a result of persecution.

The hunger strike is in support of around 130 practitioners who have been on hunger strike for over three weeks in the Masanjia camp in protest over their continued detention despite their sentences having ended.

It is reportedly very common for mainland detention facilities to not release Falun Gong practitioners until they renounce the practice, despite their sentences having ended. There are also widespread reports of torture at the Masanjia camp.
Local practitioners from Southern California and Los Angeles County will take turns to keeps the round-the-clock vigil that will last about 11 days.
Similar hunger strikes are taking place at many mainland Chinese consulates and embassies in the United States, Canada, Europe and Australia.
Ten practitioners in front of the mainland Chinese embassy in Washington, D.C. were reported to be on day eight of their water fast.

DOC.HEADLINE: EDITOR'S NOTE: KINMEN SERIES
DOC.TEXT: A series of five articles on Kinmen, a frontline island of the Republic of China, will be filed beginning this weekend. The first and second articles will be filed today (Saturday), and the third will be filed tomorrow (Sunday). The remaining articles will be filed in the coming weeks. Related photos are available on the CNA Web site (client.cna.com.tw/cnaphoto). Type "kinmen" in the keyword search field on the upper left of the screen to find the photos. The relevant captions will appear in English.

DOC.HEADLINE: FEATURE (1/5): KINMEN -- BEATING SWORDS INTO PLOWSHARES

TEXT.P: When life gives you lemons, make lemonade. But when your arch-enemy tries to obliterate your beaches, houses and military installations with 479,554 artillery shells of various calibers, what can you do? The residents of Kinmen, a small but strategic frontline outpost of the Republic of China, called upon the entrepreneurial spirit they share with their Taiwan cousins -- and made kitchen knives out of the steel shell casings.
Beating the proverbial swords into plowshares can be quite a profitable business.
Tourists from Taiwan -- and the local government is hoping soon from mainland China and other places as well -- have almost without exception heard about the famous Kinmen-made cutlery.

In fact, it is one of the most well-known things about Kinmen, in addition to its extensive military history, its labyrinth of interconnected underground air raid shelters, its well-preserved traditional architecture and its fiery sorghum spirit called "kaoliang."
Nowadays, Kinmen is also known among international birdwatchers as a haven for migratory birds -- well over 200 species of them.

It is also the focus of what some would call an experiment and a litmus test in Taipei-Beijing relations since the Jan. 1 establishment of the "mini three links" -- the first-ever direct transport, trade and postal links between ROC-controlled areas and mainland China in over five decades.

According to Kinmen County Commissioner Chen Shui-tsai, the mini links were meant to serve as a gesture of goodwill to Beijing and to become a model for the possible opening of the "big three links" between Taiwan-proper and mainland China in the future.
However, judging from the lack of success of the mini links so far, Chen says that he is not optimistic about the establishment of the "big three links" anytime soon.
He puts the blame squarely on Beijing, which has been adamant that Taiwan must embrace the "one China" principle before anything else can be opened to discussion.

The mini links, then, have become a unilateral gesture. Over 5,000 people have already traveled the short distance directly from Kinmen to mainland China's coastal city of Xiamen since January, but fewer than 300 people from Xiamen have made the journey to Kinmen -- all of them either former Kinmen residents who were unable to return after the communists took over the mainland after World War II, or members of a performance troupe invited to put on their show in Kinmen.
Seven shipments of sand, gravel and granite have made their way from Xiamen to Kinmen since Jan. 1, but no Kinmen products have been shipped to the mainland during the same period.

The ROC government had also been hoping that with the opening of the mini three links, mainland tourists would make the short hop across the narrow distance between Kinmen and Xiamen, thereby stimulating the local tourism industry.

However, mainland officials have not allowed such sightseeing groups to travel to Kinmen and there is no way to know for sure just how many mainland Chinese would be interested in touring the island should the ban be lifted.
Regardless, the county commissioner is planning ahead. He wants to build a bridge linking Kinmen with Xiamen, which is only a stone's throw away.

With NT$34 billion (US$982 million) lying dormant in Kinmen banks and waiting to be invested in the fast-growing coastal region of Fujian Province, he said that he is waiting for the political issue of "one China" to be resolved so that what he terms a "mutually beneficial economic relationship" between Kinmen and Xiamen can start to bloom.

Meanwhile, Kinmen is vigorously upgrading its infrastructure -- with a new commercial port nearing completion, a bridge linking Kinmen-proper with the isle of "Little Kinmen" to begin construction in December and plans for a larger airport undergoing feasibility studies.

With the number of soldiers on the island likely to be reduced further because the military and the local population apparently believe that Kinmen will not be the target of a future Chinese communist attack, Kinmen has transformed itself into a tourism-based economy from an economy that used to center around the vast number of military personnel stationed on the island.

With its idyllic natural setting, its historic military attractions and its picturesque folk villages, Kinmen -- which literally means "golden gate" -- stands poised to become truly a gateway through which tourists will be able to find a wealth of local culture and history.

DOC.HEADLINE: FEATURE (2/5): KINMEN -- THE IMPREGNABLE GATEWAY

TEXT.P: Despite the deadly summer heat, would-be frogmen training to become the elite of the army's local garrison forces relentlessly continue their drills on the sandy beaches of Kinmen, apparently unperturbed by the fact that the Chinese mainland is only kilometers away.
The "tadpoles," as they are called before they complete their three-month basic training, belong to the Republic of China's only amphibious reconnaissance battalion.

They are the army's equivalent of the marines -- trained in the martial arts, capable of fighting and disarming enemies barehanded, taught to swim over 5,000 meters in the sea before basic training is completed and skilled in diving, intelligence gathering, demolition and other military specialties.

According to a first master sergeant who has been serving with the amphibious battalion for nearly 17 years, although many soldiers volunteer to serve in the prestigious unit, only about 70 percent of the tadpoles make it past the rigorous basic training.
On another part of the island, meanwhile, an artillery company is undergoing basic gunnery drill on an eight-inch howitzer.

Situated in a tunnel carved out of the granite hills and shielded from prying eyes with camouflage netting, the howitzer -- with "U.S.A. 1944" stamped on the breechblock -- is manned by eight soldiers who practice daily, aiming at several predetermined targets on the Chinese mainland.
Further along the coast at Mashan Observatory, the northernmost tip of Kinmen, two soldiers stand sentry at a post known throughout the ROC military as "the world's No. 1 guard post."

It is the closest point to mainland China manned by the ROC Armed Forces. At high tide, the distance from Mashan to Chiaoyu -- the nearest mainland island -- is only 2,200 meters. At low tide, the distance shrinks to 1,800 meters.
While the "speaker wall" at Mashan blasts music and propaganda across the narrow strait toward the mainland, a mainland Chinese fishing boat glides past the guard post only a few hundred meters away.
The deputy commander of the company stationed in Mashan admits that even mainland sightseeing boats often draw close to the post so that the tourists can wave at the sentries and take pictures.

Maj. Gen. Chen Chin-chih, director of Kinmen Defense Command's political warfare department, says that although mainland China is creating "a false sense of peace," the ROC military remains highly alert and ready to face any possible contingencies.
The soldiers are taught the concept of "peacetime self-defense, wartime offensive strike" and understand they are fighting for the security of the nation and the welfare of the people, he adds.
IMPREGNABLE GATEWAY TO THE SEA
Kinmen and its surrounding islands are naturally and artificially fortified, facilitating its defense while impeding any attacks from the sea or air.

As early as the 14th century, during the Ming Dynasty, the residents of Kinmen built walls and moats around their settlements as a measure of protection against marauding pirates who roamed the mainland Chinese coastal regions.
These fortifications earned the island its present-day name. Literally, Kinmen means "golden gate," an abbreviation for a phrase that roughly means the "impregnable gateway to the sea."

As a frontline ROC garrison for the past five decades, it has successfully repelled a surprise attack by mainland troops in 1949 and was the target of a massive-scale bombardment in 1958 that became known all over the world as the Aug. 23 Artillery War.
Kinmen was struck by an estimated 479,554 shells, establishing a world record of sorts as each square meter of the island took the brunt of an average of three hits.

For the two decades following the 1958 bombardment, until Washington switched diplomatic recognition from Taipei to Beijing, Kinmen was the continual target of bombardment by mainland China on alternate days.
Non-explosive shells containing communist propaganda rained down on the island, but Kinmen stuck true to its name and remained an impregnable gateway.
FROM MILITARY TO CIVILIAN RULE
Because of the delicate frontline nature of Kinmen, the island remained under military rule until 1992, when control reverted back to the local civilian government.
However, a strong military presence can be felt in almost every aspect of life on the island, pervading the local economy and local society.
At the Kinmen Shangyi Airport, groups of soldiers on leave -- still dressed in their camouflage fatigues -- can be seen waiting in the departure lobby for their flights back to Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATIVE YUAN TO REVISE INTERNAL REGULATIONS

TEXT.P: The Office of Legislative Counsel of the Legislative Yuan has drafted a bill to revise the internal regulations of the legislative organ to improve legislative efficiency.

During the fifth session of the fourth legislature between last February and June, only 42 bills were approved by the Legislative Yuan and an extraordinary session had to be called in late June to deliberate six financial bills. Insufficient internal regulations and a lack of communication between the administration and the legislature are believed to be the major problems.

Some legislators have been blamed for taking advantage of the loose internal regulations and the Office of Legislative Counsel is trying to revise the regulations to avoid such maneuvers by individual legislators.

Under the existing internal regulations, five legislators can form a caucus which is entitled to attend negotiations between the administration and the legislature. Many bills failed to be deliberated during the spring session because boycotts by individual legislators.

A majority of legislators support a revision of the internal regulations, according to Legislator Shen Fu-hsiung of the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP). He added that the DPP, Kuomingtang (KMT) and People First Party (PFP) have agreed that the hurdle for forming parliamentarian caucus should be raised to around 13 legislators, representing 5 percent of the 225 parliamentary seats.

He said that the three parties are also in agreement that the hurdle provision should be adopted before a November recess of the autumn session. The autumn session -- from September till December -- will have a recess in November due to the year-end legislative and county chief elections.

The hurdle provision will definitely face resistance from legislators of small parties and political groups. However, the three leading political parties are determined to push it through so as to streamline the operations of the legislature, said Shen.

DOC.HEADLINE: PROTESTERS TO URGE UNITED NATIONS TO ALLOW TAIWAN'S ENTRY
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Aug. 24 (CNA) (By Eric C.Y. Tseng and Fang Wen-hung)

TEXT.P: About 1,000 protesters to be led by local overseas Chinese community members and supporters of the Republic of China's ruling and opposition parties are expected to gather in front of U.N. Headquarters Sept. 11 to show their support for Taiwan's latest bid to rejoin the United Nations.
The demonstration is scheduled to coincide with the opening of the 56th plenary session of the U.N. General Assembly.

According to the organizers of the protest, this year will mark the first time that the ruling Democratic Progressive Party and the opposition Kuomintang, People First Party and New Party will join hands to lend support to Taiwan's cause.

The organizers said that a formal announcement on the series of demonstration activities will be made public Wednesday and that they have already decided that the ROC flag will be prominently displayed while political party flags will have a lower profile.
Last year, at the opening of the 55th plenary session of the U.N. General Assembly on Sept. 5, over 1,000 protesters showed up to rally for Taiwan's re-admittance into the United Nations.

The Republic of China is seeking to rejoin the United Nations for the ninth time. Ten of its diplomatic allies have jointly submitted a proposal asking the world body to reconsider Taiwan's representation.
The Republic of China was a founding member of the United Nations until it left the body in 1971, when its seat was occupied by mainland China.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOST SECURITIES HOUSES PLAN TO DOWNGRADE FINANCIAL FORECAST

TEXT.P: Shrinking trading volume and falling stock prices have driven down revenues as well as profits of local securities houses and most of them are planning to adjust downwards their financial forecast for this year.

Sources of the Taiwan Stock Exchange Corp. said Saturday that except for China Trust Securities -- whose NT$1.45 billion pre-tax profit in the first seven months has already exceeded the NT$1.27 billion target set for the whole year -- most securities houses are under pressure to downgrade their financial forecasts.
In order to save on personnel as well as operational costs, many local securities houses have laid off large numbers of employees since late last year.
Yuan Ta Core Pacific, a market leader topping the profit-making list, has reduced its branch offices around the island from 90 to 72 and cut its personnel from 3,100 to 2,800.
Fubon Securities, having laid off 100 workers recently, is planning to lay off another 300 and cut the payroll total to 2,000.

Polaris Securities prided itself as a pioneer when it invested heavily in e-commerce last year. In less than a year, the securities house -- frustrated by the Internet bubble and the depressed stock market -- has decided to wind up its e-commerce department.
According to market sources, the prospects for the stock and securities market will remain gloomy until such time as clear signs of a global economic recovery are seen.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP CANDIDATE INSISTS ON RUNNING FOR KAOHSIUNG MAGISTRATE
DOC.DATELINE: Kaohsiung, southern Taiwan, Aug. 25 (CNA) (By David Hsu)

TEXT.P: The opposition People First Party (PFP) was in a dilemma Saturday when one of its members insisted on running for the magistrateship of Kaohsiung County against the wishes of the party.

PFP Vice Chairman Chang Chao-hsiung met with Legislator Chung Shao-ho and some of his supporters in an attempt to persuade him to abandon the Kaohsiung magistrate election, but Chang's efforts were reported afterward to have been in vain.
Chung said that he made the decision to run for Kaohsiung magistrate because, he said, he has the support of mainstream opinion.
The PFP had originally nominated its Deputy Secretary-General Chin Chin-sheng to run for Taipei County magistrate and Chung to run for Kaohsiung magistrate.

However, PFP Chairman James Soong announced Friday at a press conference that the party would not contest the two posts on the grounds that Chairman Lien Chan of the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) was unable to guarantee KMT support for the PFP candidates because of a failure to agree on cooperating in the year-end legislative and local government head elections.

Chang said that Chin will keep his post as PFP deputy secretary-general and that the party will continue its efforts to persuade Chung to change his mind and accept the party's arrangement to run for re-election as a legislator.
The PFP has adjusted its election strategy to place the emphasis on striving for more seats in the Legislative Yuan.

DOC.HEADLINE: EDAC FAILS TO REACH CONSENSUS ON TAX CUT PROPOSALS

TEXT.P: The ongoing Economic Development Advisory Conference (EDAC) failed to reach consensus Saturday on two tax cut proposals but agreed to list them as "majority opinions" and refer them to the government for reference in future policy formulation.

Commerce and industry representatives to the conference came up with the proposals during preparatory panel sessions that the government suspend the stock transaction tax for one year and halve the land value increment tax for two years in the midst of the lingering domestic economic doldrums.

Because of opposition from other EDAC members, however -- particularly those from relevant government agencies and the academic community -- the two proposals failed to receive unanimous support at Saturday's EDAC plenary session.

President Chen Shui-bian, who concurrently serves as EDAC chairman, has promised that his administration will fully implement proposals unanimously agreed upon by the 120 conference attendees. In comparison, the government will have discretion to decide whether or not to implement proposals that do not receive unanimous support.

Several other proposals, including raising the ceiling on public debts, were also listed as "majority opinions," although the government had originally hoped that the proposal to raise the cap on public debts could receive unanimous support to allow it to float more state bonds to ease its financial straits.

At Saturday's EDAC plenary session, the participants managed to forge 17 "common opinions" or "unanimous opinions" and 19 "majority opinions" on government restructuring, tax reforms, and other relevant financial and banking issues.

One of the unanimous opinions concerns the much-anticipated government restructuring with a view to upgrading administrative efficiency and slashing government expenditure. The proposal requires the government to present a draft revision bill on the current Executive Yuan organization law to the first session of the new Legislative Yuan that will be elected Dec. 1.

Another unanimous opinion is that the government should come up with a comprehensive tax reform plan and present relevant legal revision bills to the new legislature for screening during its first session.

Other major unanimous opinions include that the government should promote the privatization of state-owned enterprises in line with general global trends and viable market terms and that the government should work out a plan to balance its budget in five to 10 years.

The unanimous opinions also require the government to take concrete steps to expand the scale of Taiwan's securities market, respect stock market mechanisms and push for greater transparency and higher efficiency in the management of four major government-run funds in stock investment.
The government should also forge a mechanism to facilitate the restructuring and merger of local financial institutions and should offer more incentives to encourage mergers of local banks.
The EDAC opened Friday and is scheduled to close Sunday. Discussions Saturday focused on financial reforms and employment issues.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP CHAIR REGRETS KMT RELUCTANCE TO COOPERATE ON ELECTIONS
DOC.DATELINE: San Francisco, Aug. 24 (CNA) (By Neil Lu and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Opposition People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong expressed regret here Friday over the opposition Kuomintang's (KMT's) reluctance to cooperate with his party in Taiwan's year-end elections for local government chiefs.

Soong said after his arrival in San Francisco for a brief visit that the KMT's grassroots members have been reluctant to support the PFP's cooperation proposals, even though KMT Chairman Lien Chan has shown a sincere desire to field joint tickets for local government chief elections in certain cities and counties.
Soong said he has maintained a cordial friendship and smooth contacts with Lien. "We often exchange views on major policy issues," he said.

Nevertheless, Soong said he was saddened by KMT grassroots party workers' reluctance to throw their support behind any of the PFP-proposed candidates for mayoral and magistrate elections scheduled for Dec. 1.

Against this backdrop, Soong said, the PFP has finally decided not to enter candidates for the Taipei and Kaohsiung county magistrate elections. "It's a difficult decision to make," he said, adding: "In view of our party's limited resources, we can't engage in any battle that we have no chance of winning."

Soong said the PFP will refocus its energy on the legislative elections in the two counties and other areas around Taiwan. As for the local government chief elections, Soong said the PFP will concentrate its campaign efforts in Taitung, Miaoli and Nantou counties, where he said the party stands good chances of winning.

He also said he had urged President Chen Shui-bian during a recent meeting to push the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) to adjust its pro-independence ideology in order to seek a breakthrough to the deadlocked relations across the Taiwan Strait.

Soong said the KMT made a wrong assessment of mainland China's economic development potential in the latter years of its rule of Taiwan. "The KMT's underestimation of mainland China's development potential has had a serious adverse impact on Taiwan's current political and economic development," he claimed.

Against this background, Soong went on, he reminded Chen, a DPP stalwart, that the DPP must revise its pro-independence party charter to facilitate the development of cross-strait relations. Otherwise, he went on, Taiwan's economic prospects will remain gloomy.

DOC.HEADLINE: LAWMAKER QUESTIONS COURT RULING ON LEAKING OF CLASSIFIED INFORMATION

TEXT.P: Legislator Diane Lee said Saturday that a military court ruling which claims that an army officer was guilty of leaking classified information to the press was questionable and "a blow to the freedom of speech."
Lee said in a press conference that Maj. Liu Chih-chung's case should have been handled more fairly, justly and openly.

Liu -- who provided a local reporter with information that mainland Chinese warships were seen in waters close to Taiwan before the presidential inauguration last May -- was sentenced to nine years in prison for leaking military secrets, corruption and theft.

Lee said that the information Liu disclosed did not fit the military's definition of classified information and that the judge's ruling that Liu's disclosure illegally benefited the reporter was questionable because the information did not help the reporter receive any monetary rewards from his newspaper for his exclusive report.

On the ruling of theft, Lee said that the court believed Liu stole dissertation reports from a military seminar on joint service warfare, whereas she believed that in fact, such information presented at academic seminars is in the public domain.

DOC.HEADLINE: INVESTIGATION INTO MAGAZINE ATTACK GETS UNDERWAY: OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: Republic of China law enforcement authorities have launched investigation into the recent attack on the office of a local magazine, a Presidential Office spokeswoman said Saturday.

Kuo Yao-chi, director of the Public Affairs Office under the Presidential Office, made the remarks after a U.S.-based organization sent a letter to ROC President Chen Shui-bian expressing its concern about the recent attack on the office of "Taiwan Next" weekly.

The New York-based Committee to Protect Journalists (CPJ) said in its letter to President Chen that the ROC government should ensure that police investigation into the attack is thorough and professional.

Around midday of Aug. 22, a group of men wielding baseball bats charged into the downtown Taipei office of Taiwan Next, a tabloid-style magazine, and smashed windows, computers, and office furniture. No one was injured in the attack.

"As an organization of journalists dedicated to the defense of press freedom around the world, CPJ is alarmed by this criminal attack on Taiwan Next," the organization said in its letter, adding that ROC authorities must ensure that those involved in the attack are prosecuted to the fullest extent of the law, thereby sending a clear message that attacks against the press will not be tolerated.

In response to the CPJ's concern, Kuo said ROC law enforcement authorities have been dealing with the case. "As the case has already entered judicial procedures, the Presidential Office will respect judicial ruling on the criminal attack case," she added.

"Taiwan Next," owned by Hong Kong tycoon Jimmy Lai, is known for its paparazzi-style coverage of public figures, and it has been defendants in at least three lawsuits since its May 30 launch in Taiwan.

A "Next" editor said magazine staffers had received many threatening phone calls in the past as a result of its coverage of scandals involving politicians, criminals and celebrities. "We have no idea who did this," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAPANESE LAWMAKER TO HELP FORMER ROC PRESIDENT REVISIT JAPAN

TEXT.P: Japanese Lower House member Koki Kobayashi has said that he would do his best to help former Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui to revisit Japan for medical treatment this fall.
Kobayashi was in Taipei at the head of a 28-member Japanese parliamentarian mission to attend the inauguration of the Taiwan-Japanese Parliamentarians Goodwill Alliance Friday.
The Japanese government allowed Lee to visit Japan for a heart operation last April amid protest from mainland China.
Lee hinted to reporters a few days ago that he hopes to make a post-operation examination in Japan this fall, and his remarks triggered mixed reactions in Japan.

Some friendly Japanese politicians have voiced their support for Lee's Japan visit, while some others, including pro-Beijing Foreign Minister Makiko Tanaka, are against Lee's visit, fearing that it might affect Japan's friendly relations with mainland China.

Kobayashi told reporters that despite the mixed reactions in Japan, he would do his best to help realize Lee's plan to revisit Japan this fall to further improve friendly relations between the two countries.
Beijing has regarded Lee as a promoter of Taiwan independence and has taken all-out efforts to block his plans for foreign trips.
Nevertheless, the U.S. government ignored protest from Beijing and allowed him to visit his alma mater, Cornell University, several weeks ago.

DOC.HEADLINE: MORE JAPANESE ENTERPRISES CONSIDER MOVING TO MAINLAND CHINA
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Aug. 25 (CNA) (By Mike Chang & Victor Lai)

TEXT.P: The results of a recent survey by the Japan External Trade Organization indicate that more than 40 percent of Japanese enterprises are considering shifting their production lines to mainland China.
The survey was conducted among 2,700 major manufacturers, trading houses, wholesalers and retailers in April, with 38 percent of these firms responding to the survey.
Forty-two percent of the responding firms said that they were considering shifting production lines or supply bases at home and abroad to mainland China.
The main reason is that the production cost in Japan is too high.

DOC.TEXT:

DOC.HEADLINE: FEATURE (3/5): KINMEN -- A VERDANT SANCTUARY FOR MIGRATORY BIRDS

TEXT.P: The pristine environment of Kinmen -- a Republic of China island located off the southeastern coast of mainland China and just north of the Tropic of Cancer -- provides an ideal sanctuary for a diverse population of migratory birds and is a testament to the government's success in bringing lushness back to the once-barren island.
Although Kinmen covers only 150 square kilometers, birdwatchers have already spotted 287 species of birds on the island, approximately 75 percent of which are migratory.

The large number of birds that grace the crystal-clear ponds throughout the different seasons makes it all the more difficult to imagine that Kinmen used to be an arid, hilly island covered with granite, sandy soil and red loam where only drought-resistant crops like sorghum, corn, peanuts and sweet potatoes could survive.

According to historical records, Kinmen was once covered in lush forest. Since the 13th century, however, woodcutting to boil seawater for salt, tree felling for shipbuilding and other over-logging practices gradually denuded the island.
This exposed the sandy soil to the wind, leading to dust storms and erosion.
Local villagers turned to "wind lion" gods for help, but the government stepped in with some concrete measures to rein in the desertification.
Since 1950, the government has embarked on an ambitious reforestation program to make Kinmen into the lush tropical island it once was.
Local legend has it that Gen. Hu Lien, who served as the commanding general of the local garrison forces from 1949 to 1957, ordered each soldier to be responsible for the well-being of 10 trees.
If any of the saplings withered as a result of mistreatment or neglect, so the popular story goes, the soldier assigned to care for it would be held accountable and disciplined.

Meanwhile, another regulation banned residents from raising goats to prevent the animals from chewing up seedlings, illustrating the government and the military's determination to bring the lush, green environment back to Kinmen.

To counter recurrent droughts, late ROC President Chiang Kai-shek instructed during a 1965 autumn visit to Kinmen to dig wells, build dams, develop water sources and provide for tap water to tackle the hardships faced by the people and the soldiers who lacked fresh water.
A bay was enclosed and dams were constructed to create artificial lakes. Soon birds began to flock to the island.
Kinmen National Park Superintendent Hsu Wun-long says that Kinmen is a small island whose delicate ecosystem could be easily upset.
Therefore, a national park was established in October 1995 to help preserve what reforestation has brought back to Kinmen, and also to preserve the island's history and culture.

Hsu says that the diversity of local fauna and flora could be attributed partly to the success of the military's reforestation efforts. The trees have helped lock in moisture and provide shade which has generally lowered ground temperatures, allowing fish and other animal life to flourish in the cooler environment.
Otters and horseshoe crabs can also be found in Kinmen, illustrating the low level of pollution on the island.
However, the environment must be continually monitored to ensure that such factors as water quality and pollution levels are kept within standards, Hsu said.
Some of the recommended bird watching spots in Kinmen include Lake Tzu, the mouth of the Wu River, the Kinsha Reservoir and Lake Linshui on Little Kinmen.

DOC.HEADLINE: DISCUSSIONS FOCUS ON `1992 CONSENSUS' AT ECONOMIC CONFERENCE

TEXT.P: The so-called "1992 consensus" of "one China, where Taipei and Beijing can make their own interpretations" became the focus of discussions Sunday, the final day of the ongoing Economic Development Advisory Conference.

Almost half of the 120 conference participants signed up to voice their opinions on cross-Taiwan Strait issues at the session, which was presided over by Koo Chen-fu, Taipei's top negotiator with Beijing and chairman of the Straits Exchange Foundation.

Koo said that because Taipei's direct control over certain cross-strait affairs is limited, any conclusions arrived at the conference on related issues must still rely on Beijing's cooperation, otherwise they would be difficult to implement.
Opposition New Party delegates proposed to include the acceptance of the 1992 consensus in the final conclusions of the conference to ease cross-strait tensions.
Legislative Yuan Vice President Yao Eng-chi, a member of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT), seconded the proposal to return to the 1992 consensus that was embraced by the previous KMT administration.

However, the proposal was opposed by a delegate of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, who warned that Taiwan would be putting restrictions on itself by accepting the 1992 consensus. He suggested that if the opposition parties insist on the consensus, another conference should be held to deal specifically with that issue.
The proposal did not receive approval from the 120 conference members to be included in the final conclusions.

Consensus was reached on 36 cross-strait issues, including a change in the government's policy toward local business investments in mainland China from "no haste, be patient" to the less restrictive "active liberalization, effective management."

The conference participants also agreed to urge the government to seek to resolve the partisan differences in regard to the "1992 consensus" while defining cross-strait relations in accordance with the Republic of China Constitution.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL FORUM ON BIOTECHNOLOGY TO OPEN IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: The 2001 Taipei International Master Forum on Biotechnology is scheduled to open Monday, bringing together industry and academic leaders from around the world to discuss the future of biochips, bioinformatics and biopharmaceuticals.

A total of 24 papers will be presented at the three-day conference, which is organized by the Biomedical Engineering Center of the Industrial Technology Research Institute and GeneMaster Lifesciences Co.

Minister of Economics Affairs Lin Hsin-yi, Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou and officials from the National Science Council, the Department of Health and other government agencies are slated to attend the conference.

David Flores, president of BioCentury, which specializes in providing business intelligence on the biotechnology industry, is scheduled to speak at the conference on the current paradigm of the industry.

DOC.HEADLINE: MEXICO WIN OVER CHINESE TAIPEI RELEGATES TAIWAN TO POSSIBLE THIRD FINISH

TEXT.P: Mexico rallied early to beat Chinese Taipei Saturday in the first game of the semifinal at the International Little League Championship Tournament in Mexico City.
Chinese Taipei scored first in the third inning, but Mexico came back strong in the bottom of the inning with two runs.
The hosts got another run in the fifth and held on to win.
One of the coaches of the team from Taiwan, Cheng Chun-hsiang, blamed the loss on what he said was an obvious bias by an umpire in Mexico's favor.
Cheng said that the plate umpire was not calling balls and strikes fairly for the Taiwan team and the only way his pitchers could get strikes was to throw nothing but fast balls.
The Brazilian umpire ignored Chinese Taipei's protests, Cheng said.

Lee Cheng-ta, the manager of the Chinese Taipei squad, also complained that the baseball field was bigger than what his players were used to and long fly balls that would have been home runs in other parks were caught by the Mexican players.

Chinese Taipei will face Brazil next on Sunday. Brazil was also defeated in the first round of the semifinals. The two will compete for third place in the tournament. Lee predicted that Chinese Taipei should win easily.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOTC UNAWARE OF NEW PARTY LAWMAKER'S PLANNED MAINLAND TRIP

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) is unaware of a planned mainland trip by New Party lawmaker Elmer Feng for talks on postal and transportation links with the mainalnd, vice minister Ho Cheng-tan said Sunday.
Ho said he has heard nothing about such a trip and pointed out that the issue regarding the establishment of the "three links" is beyond the power of the MOTC.

Ho said although many enthusiastic people have offered different proposals to the government on the issue, the government cannot accept them all. Ho said that even though he was unaware of Feng's plans, he felt that the lawmaker had the best intentions in mind.

Feng announced at a gathering with local residents of Taipei City's Ta-an district earlier the same day that he will lead a delegation to mainland China in mid-September for discussions on postal and transportation links across the Taiwan Strait.

According to Feng, he has informed the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) and the MOTC of his planned trip and that he will travel to the mainland as long as the two governments' authorities approve his plans.

The lawmaker said he will visit the mainland in his capacity as chief of the "Cross-Strait People's Service Center" and voiced his hope that the MAC and the MOTC would send relevant officials to serve as private advisers for his delegation.
Feng predicted that if he could make the trip, the mainland Chinese side would agree to set up postal and express delivery links and exchanges of remittances of small amounts of money with Taiwan.

Criticizing the ongoing Economic Development Advisory Conference as being fraught with "masked acts," he said the government's decision to shift to the "proactive openness and effective management" policy from its previous stance of "no haste" is just a hollow slogan.

Feng said he knew that the "1992 consensus" would not be approved by the economic conference and that the easing of the "no haste, be patient" policy is only aimed at reducing pressure from the private sector.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER'S TRANSIT STOPS IN U.S. NO CAUSE FOR CONCERN: FOREIGN MINISTRY

TEXT.P: A spokeswoman for the Ministry of Foreign Affairs Sunday denied media reports that Premier Chang Chun-hsiung's transit stops in the United States will cause waves between Taipei and Washington.
Chang Siao-yue said that her ministry has not heard of any US concerns over the premier's planned stopovers in four US cities.
On the contrary, the spokeswomen said, the United States was "more than willingly" to agree to the premier's request for transit stops on the basis of "safety, comfort and convenience."

The minister's spokeswoman made the comments in response to media reports that the premier's stops in the United States are "unnecessary" and have caused concern in Washington and could negatively affect ties between Washington and Taipei.
Chang Siao-yue said that there is mutual trust between Taipei and Washington. She said that Washington understands that Taipei will not "play any tricks" regarding the stopovers.
"We will certainly not destroy the rules we have taken pains to establish," she said.
Premier Chang will stop in four U.S. cities in four nights and is not expected to do anything that will disappoint his U.S. hosts, Chang Siao-yue said.
The premier intends to stop in Los Angeles and Honolulu and will meet with ethnic Chinese living there, Chang Siao-yue said.
Premier Chang is slated to visit four Caribbean countries between Aug. 31 and Sept. 12. and will transit through New York, Miami, Los Angeles and Honolulu.

DOC.HEADLINE: WORLD TAIWAN BENEVOLENT ASSOCIATION OPENS IN SEATTLE
DOC.DATELINE: Seattle, Aug. 25 (CNA) (By Yen Ning-ju and Ed Chen)

TEXT.P: The World Taiwan Benevolent Association, which is an extention of the Taiwan Benevolent Association in America (TBAA), was formally founded Saturday in Seattle with Minister of the Cabinet-level Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission (OCAC) Chang Fu-mei and Republic of China Representative to the United States Chen Chien-jen witnessing.
More than 100 delegates from TBAA chapters the United States, Taiwan, and Europe took part in the founding ceremony, which also marked the 24th annual convention of the TBAA.

The TBAA, founded in the 1970s under the initiation of the Kuomintang's Overseas Chinese Affairs Department, has gradually de-emphasized the political purpose of the group and focused instead on social interactions and service.
The gathering was considered significant enough that Chang attended the TBAA annual convention for the first time since the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) assumed power over a year ago.

Addressing those assembled at the ceremony, Chang highly praised members of the TBAA for their patriotism. "You have always put yourselves forward in the fight against Beijing when Beijing has put pressure on Taiwan during the past years," Chang said.

"You generously donated cash and materials to Taiwan when a killer earthquake jolted the central part of the island on Sept. 21, 1999, claiming more than 2,000 lives and when we suffered heavy damage and loss of life due to Typhoon Toraji, which swept through Taiwan recently, " Chang added.

Chang told the overseas Chinese that they should ignore the entreaties by Beijing to turn their back on a democratic Taiwan. He said that it should be clear that Beijing was only scheming to subvert the causes of the government of the Republic of China.

ROC Representative to the United States Chen Chien-jen spoke highly of the patriotism and dedication to their homeland during the past 24 years that the supporters of Taiwan have shown. He also lauded their contributions to help ROC diplomatic missions abroad promote relations with the ROC.

ROC President Chen Shui-bian, U.S. President George W. Bush and Vice President Dick Cheney, Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan, People First Party Chairman James Soong, ROC Premier Chang Chun-hsiung, President of the Legislative Yuan Wang Jin-pyng, President of the Examination Yuan Hsu Shui-teh, President of the Judicial Yuan Weng Yueh-sheng, President of the Control Yuan Fredrick Chien, U.S. Secretary of Labor Affairs Elaine Chao and others have sent congratulatory messages to the group.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINESE TAIPEI WINS 3 GOLDS, 3 SILVERS AND 5 BRONZES AT WORLD GAMES
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Aug. 26 (CNA) (By Mike Chang and Ed Chen)

TEXT.P: Chinese Taipei won gold and bronze Sunday on the last day of the Sixth World Games held at Akita City, Japan.
Yang Ching-shuen of the Chinese Taipei delegation picked up a gold medal after edging out his German rival, 11-8, in the men's billiard event.
Chinese Taipei inline skater Pan I-chin won a bronze medal in the women's 15,000-meter race.
Chinese Taipei has chalked up three golds, three silvers and five bronzes from the Games which ended the 11-day competition Sunday.

Inline skater Pan Li-ling won two gold medals in the women's 300-meter and 500-meter races Aug. 24 while Pan's teammate, Pan I-chin, won two silvers and two bronzes. She won a bronze in the women's 15,000-meter skating event, a silver medal each from the women's 10,000-meter event and the 500-meter race. She won another bronze in the women's 300-meter skating race.
Chinese Taipei's Chen Kuan-ting won a silver medal in the women's lightweight class of the power lifting, while her teammate, Chao Chen-yeh, grabbed a bronze from the women's heavyweight class.

Chinese Taipei's Chen Tsun-chen won a bronze medal in the women's pool-billiard contest and Chinese Taipei also won a bronze medal in the korfball event. In addition, Chinese Taipei also won a silver in gateball, a Japanese version of croquet.
More than 2,000 athletes from 92 countries around the world took part in the quadrennial Games.
The Chinese Taipei delegation is expected to return to Taipei Monday.

DOC.HEADLINE: EDAC AGREES ON 36 CROSS-STRAIT TRADE ISSUES

TEXT.P: Participants of the Economic Development Advisory Conference (EDAC) reached consensus on 36 issues on Taiwan-mainland trade ties Sunday, while deciding to refer their different viewpoints about the "1992 consensus" to the government.

More than 100 prominent representatives from the local business community, the academic and the government sectors, although holding differing stances, agreed on 36 issues linked to the improvement in trade ties between Taiwan and mainland China in a package vote.

But the participants decided to submit various opinions on the "1992 consensus" -- which refers to the disputed "one China, respective interpretations" principle -- to the government to put aside differences between the political parties on the matter.

By doing so, they voiced the hope that the government can quickly forge a national consensus on the critical issue to be able to give a definition to cross-strait relations in accordance with the Republic of China Constitution and to start negotiations with the mainalnd on the establishment of the "three links" and on other issues which may benefit the people on both sides.
Key conclusions reached during the meeting include:

-- Establish direct trade, transportation and postal links across the Strait and allow limited imports of mainland-made products in line with the two sides' entry into the World Trade Organization; and
-- Under the principle of national security, open up the local tourist market to mainland Chinese visitors.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, Aug. 27, or the ninth day of the seventh month of the Year of the Snake according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1642: Cheng Cheng-kung, a Ming dynasty general better known to Westerners as Koxinga, is born in Japan. He sailed his troops to Taiwan in 1661 with the hope of fighting his way back to mainland China after the fall of the mainland to invading Manchu troops. Although he never realized his dream, he succeeded in opening up Taiwan for Chinese settlement.
1770: George Wilhelm Friedrich Hegel, the German philosopher who proposed that truth is reached by a continuing dialectic, is born.
1813: France's Napoleon Bonaparte, with a force of 130,000, wins his last great battle at Dresden, Germany, against a superior Austrian, Prussian and Russian allied force of 200,000.
1859: The world's first oil well is drilled by Edwin L. Drake at Titusville, Pennsylvania.
1883: The 1,800-meter volcano Krakatoa on the Indonesian island of Rakata erupts with a fury that is heard in Australia, more than 3,541 kilometers away, and gigantic tidal waves of up to 36 meters devastate the coastal towns of Java and Sumatra, leaving an estimated 36,000 people dead, and making the eruption the most catastrophic volcanic event ever recorded.
1908: Lyndon B. Johnson, the 36th president of the United States, is born. He succeeded to the office after John F. Kennedy was assassinated. He won the 1964 election but faced increasing criticism over the mounting US involvement in Vietnam and did not stand for reelection in 1968.
1910: Thomas Alva Edison, the American inventor who patented more than a thousand inventions, shows his "talking picture" for the first time at his New Jersey laboratory.
1910: Mother Teresa of Calcutta, the Yugoslavian-born Albanian nun dedicated to the poor and sick, particularly in India, is born. She won the Nobel Peace Prize in 1979.
1913: Yuan Shih-kai, in an attempt to impose dictatorial rule after assuming the provisional presidency in Beijing in March, 1912, orders the arrest of eight members of a constitution-drafting committee.
1916: Italy declares war on Germany.
1916: Romania declares war on Austro-Hungary, thus entering World War I.
1928: The Kellogg-Briant Pact, or Pact of Paris, an international agreement to condemn all war as a means of settling dispute, is signed by representatives of 15 nations.
1939: The world's first jet-propelled aircraft, the He-178 developed by German manufacturer Ernst Heinkel, makes its first flight at Marienehe, in northern Germany.
1946: France and Laos conclude an agreement establishing a kingdom under French domination.
1952: Israel and West Germany reach agreement in their negotiations on Nazi war crime indemnity. Under the agreement, the West German government will pay 3 billion Reichsmarks over 12 years to compensate Israeli people for their loss of lives and property caused by the Nazi regime during World War II.
1962: The International Amateur Athletic Federation issues a statement revoking its ratification for Indonesia to hold the Fourth Asian Games following the southeast Asian country's rejection of the Republic of China delegation to the Games.
1972: The Taipei Little League baseball team wins the world title.
1977: The ROC's Lih Teh Little League baseball team wins the world title. Both Senior League and Big League baseball teams from Taiwan also won the 1977 world titles in earlier competitions.
1979: Lord Louis Mountbatten, former admiral and viceroy of India, is murdered by a bomb planted by the Irish Republican Army as he and members of his family enjoy an outing on his 30-ft. fishing boat off Mullaghmore, County Sligo in the Irish Republic. He was 79.
1986: The ROC Ministry of Finance decides to lower the highest tariff rate to 57.5 percent and reduce duty rates on products with high import tariffs but limited import volume.
1987: A 13-year-old Chinese girl who was left to live with a family of pigs returns to normal life after three years of special training.
1991: Moldova declares independence from the Soviet Union.
1995: Israel and the Palestine Liberation Organization sign an agreement in Cairo to expand Palestinian autonomy from Gaza to the West Bank.
2000: Board Chairman Yeh Ming-hsun of Shih Hsin University is elected as new chairman of the National Press Council of the Republic of China, replacing Pan Huan-kun who died in May at age 83.
2000: A highway bridge linking Kaohsiung and Pingtung Counties in southern Taiwan collapse suddenly, leaving at least 20 people injured as five vehicles plunged into the river.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK PRICES UP BY 74.23 POINTS

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) gained ground on Monday, with the benchmark weighted price index moving up 74.23 points to close at 4,384.55.
Market turnover amounted to NT$47.67 billion (US$1.38 billion).

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW COMMITTEE WILL SCREEN MAINLAND-BOUND INVESTMENT

TEXT.P: Minister of Economic Affairs Lin Hsin-yi said Monday that his ministry will form a committee to craft new rules for mainland China-bound investment.

Lin said the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) must formulate new rules of the game now that the government has decided to relax restrictions on investment in mainland China in line with a recommendation reached by consensus at the Economic Development Advisory Conference.

The just-concluded, 120-member conference passed a proposal that requires the government to replace the "no haste, be patient" cross-Taiwan Strait investment policy with "active opening, effective management."

Lin said the MOEA will form a new committee, to be composed of government officials, industry executives and academics, to screen items to be allowed for mainland China-bound investment under the new policy.

In preparation for the formation of the new working group, Lin said the MOEA will consult with relevant government agencies, including the Ministry of Finance, the Mainland Affairs Council and the Council for Economic Planning and Development.
Lin pointed out that even under the "no haste, be patient" policy, restrictions on mainland investment have been confined to only a few lines of business.

Under the policy, Lin said, Taiwan entrepreneurs can freely invest in 62 percent of industries. Meanwhile, 90 percent of cross-strait investment projects in the 34 percent of categories subject to case-by-case scrutiny have been approved.

"In all, the 'no haste' policy has affected only about 7 percent of cross-strait investment applications, mainly those for infrastructure construction and cutting-edge and capital-intensive industries," Lin explained.

After the "no haste, be patient" policy is eased, Lin said, the soon-to-be-formed committee will decide whether up-stream petrochemical and wafer industries and several other high-tech concerns will be opened for cross-strait investment.

Lin added that he personally hopes that local enterprises will still refrain from investing in certain high-tech industries and infrastructure construction projects, such as power plants and railroads.

"I look forward to seeing local enterprises adopt a 'Taiwan first' investment policy," Lin said, adding that the MOEA will actively assist Taiwan firms in making overseas investments while keeping their business roots at home.

Under the "no haste, be patient" policy, mainland investment projects worth more than US$50 million each are subject to case-by-case scrutiny. In the future, Lin said, the Taiwan-mainland China investment ratio will be NT$100 to NT$20 or NT$30. "It means that local companies must invest at least NT$100 (US$2.90) in Taiwan before they are allowed to invest NT$20 to NT$30 in mainland China," he explained.

He further reminded local enterprises to fulfill their duties to protect their employees' legal rights and interests before launching new ventures on the mainland. "Local companies should also not leave their debts in Taiwan and then relocating to the mainland," he stressed.
The minister further said the "no haste, be patient" policy has had positive effects on Taiwan's economic development in the past years, particularly in helping maintain domestic economic stability.
"The 'no haste' policy should not be blamed for rising domestic unemployment and other current economic woes," Lin added.
