DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Shares prices opened high and closed even higher on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) on Monday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 74.23 points to close at 4,384.55.

Encouraged by a rebound in the NASDAQ index over the weekend and the historic consensuses reached on Sunday at the Economic Development Advisory Conference, the bourse opened at 4,352.34, and continued to go up due to a rise in electrical shares. The bourse fluctuated between 4,407.82 and 4,333.2 during trading.

A total of 1.9 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$47.67 billion (US$1.38 billion), compared with the previous trading session which saw 2.1 billion stocks change hands on a market turnover of NT$44.97 billion (US$1.3 billion).

Half of the eight major stock categories lost ground, with pulp and paper issues moving down the most at 3.2 percent, followed by construction stocks at 1.2 percent, textile issues at 0.8 percent, and cement stocks at 0.1 percent.

The other major categories posted gains, with bank and insurance shares moving up the most at 3.5 percent, followed by electrical stocks at 1.8 percent, plastics and chemical shares at 1.1 percent, and foodstuffs stocks at 0.2 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 276 to 233, with 76 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock index futures market were higher on Monday, as Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index futures for September moved up 38 points to close at 4,341, with 11,706 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for October rose 54 points to finish at 4,355, with 25 contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for other months.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Monday at 4,303 for September, 4,301 for October, 4,370 for December, 4,351 for next March, and 4,370 for next June.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were also higher.
September TE futures moved up 2.6 points to close at 217.2, with 2,430 contract transactions, while October TE futures increased 2.6 points to finish at 217.6, with 23 contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for other months.
September TF futures rose 15.2 points to finish at 586.2, with 1,828 contract transactions, while October TF futures gained 29.2 points to close at 593, with three contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: TSMC READY FOR DEPLOYMENT IN MAINLAND CHINA: MORRIS CHANG
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 27 (CNA) (By Ben Wu) (By Lillian Lin)

TEXT.P: Taipei, Aug. 27 (CNA): Morris Chang, chairman of the Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Corp. (TSMC), said Sunday that the leading semiconductor foundry is ready to open operations in mainland China as part of the corporation's global strategy.

Chang said at the plenary meeting on the last day of the three-day Economic Development Advisory Conference (EDAC) that he must acknowledge the importance of the global market, while advocating the principle of "priority to Taiwan."

TSMC cannot afford to ignore the investment incentives and advantages offered by the Beijing authorities, said Chang, although he has said many times in the past that TSMC was not preparing to begin operations in mainland China.

A number of TSMC's local competitors have sought to invest in mainland China by using whatever means possible before the government lifts the restrictions on the semiconductor sector, but TSMC insists on abiding by the regulations.

An industry source said that Chang is aware that his integrity may cause the company to lose its competitiveness in the long run, and the advisor to the economic conference used the meeting to speak of the problems encountered by his company.
At the conference panel discussions, Chang urged the government to take the initiative and be open-minded in its cross-Taiwan Strait economic and trade policies.
Although TSMC has no immediate plans to investment in mainland China, the semiconductor foundry cannot go against the tide, according to Chang.
A world leader in the manufacture of integrated circuits, TSMC has over 14,500 employees in Taiwan, Japan, the United States and Europe. In 2000, the company's annual sales was US$5.3 billion.
The semiconductor sector worldwide is suffering from an unprecedented slump in sales and TSMC's sales in the past few months has also dropped considerably from last year's level.
Company spokesman K.C. Chen announced recently that TSMC's net sales for July totaled NT$8.6 billion, down 42.7 percent from the level of the same month last year.

Chen said that the net sales value in July increased by one percent from that of the previous month. The market has been showing signs of gradual recovery since early July and the prospects for the second half of this year are expected to improve, she added.

DOC.HEADLINE: N.T. DOLLAR UP ON TAIPEI FOREX MARKET

TEXT.P: The new Taiwan dollar rose NT$0.016 against the U.S. dollar on the Taipei foreign exchange market Monday, closing at 34.609.
The local currency opened Monday at 34.619 and was traded between 34.576 and 34.620.
Interbank U.S. dollar trading totaled US$455 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: POLL SHOWS MORE MANUFACTURERS OPTIMISTIC ABOUT ECONOMIC PROSPECTS

TEXT.P: A survey conducted by the Taiwan Institute of Economic Research (TIER) in July showed that more local manufacturers are optimistic about the economic prospects for the second half of this year than they were the month before.

Among the manufacturers polled in July, 30.2 percent said that they were optimistic about the economic prospects in the second half of this year, and 26.5 percent were pessimistic. A similar survey in June showed that only 26.6 percent of those replying to the questionnaires said that they believed there would be an economic recovery in the second half, and 27.5 percent were negative about the prospects.

While 10.6 percent of those polled considered the economic climate in July "good" and 53.4 percent thought it "normal," the TIER report pointed out that the manufacturers were more positive about the market because traditionally the second half was a brisk season for orders.

TIER President Wu Rong-I said that a fully-fledged domestic economic recovery will rely on the improvement of the international economic climate and effective implementation of the government's public investment and reconstruction projects. While prospects for the key industry -- the semiconductor sector -- remains gloomy, a quick economic recovery is unlikely.

DOC.HEADLINE: ASIA-PACIFIC ANTI-CHILD PROSTITUTION MEETING OPENS IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: Anti-child prostitution activists from major Asia-Pacific countries met in Taipei Monday to discuss effective measures to fight commercial sexual abuse of children.

This is the first time that a regional meeting of its kind has been held in the Republic of China. Representatives from Japan, India, Sri Lanka, Thailand, Australia, New Zealand and the host ROC are taking part in the two-day conference.

Addressing the opening ceremony, Kao-Lee Li-chen, president of the End Child Prostitution Association (Taiwan), said child prostitution has been drawing increasing concern in the international community along with globalization.
For instance, Kao-Lee said, calls for cross-border cooperation have become louder to crack down on pornographic child photos on the Internet and sex-oriented tours.
Noting that the Asia-Pacific area encompasses a wide range of diverse cultures, Kao-Lee said Asia-Pacific countries have different ways to cope with child prostitution issues.
"We hope that the current conference provides a forum for countries in the region to exchange views and experiences in their efforts to end child prostitution," said Kao-Lee.
The conference will focus discussions on measures to curb commercial sexual abuse of children, pleasure trips targeted at child prostitutes and Internet child pornography.

Speaking on the same occasion, Ron O. Grady, honorary chairman of the international End Child Prostitution Association, said that the phenomenon of sex-oriented pleasure trips has been growing rapidly in Asia.
Grady said many Japanese and American men have joined so-called "sex tours," with the Philippines and Thailand as main destinations for their "sexual adventures."

Meanwhile, Grady said that since communist regimes collapsed in eastern Europe, criminal rings in the region have found that kidnapping children to sell into prostitution is a lucrative trade, resulting in a sharp increase in the number of child prostitutes in eastern Europe.

Noting that stopping both Internet child pornography and cross-border smuggling of children who may be sold into prostitution needs international cooperation, Grady said all countries around the world should join forces to combat these criminal activities.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE ECONOMICS MINISTER HEADS FOR SHANGHAI TO ATTEND APEC MEETING

TEXT.P: Vice Minister of Economic Affairs Lin Yi-fu went to Shanghai Monday morning to attend a ministerial meeting on small- and medium-sized enterprises of the eighth Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum which will begin Aug. 29.
The main topic of the meeting is the development and innovation of small- and medium-sized enterprises and how to upgrade their techniques and environment for development.

While at the meeting, the participants will exchange opinions and experiences with each other in the hopes of building networks to strengthen cooperation. Lin is also scheduled to speak on technique innovation.

Members of Lin's delegation include Board of Foreign Trade officials, Director-General Lai Sun-kuei of the Small and Medium Enterprise Administration and representatives from Taiwan's private enterprises.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER TO LEAVE SEPT. 1 FOR EAST CARIBBEAN VISIT

TEXT.P: Premier Chang Chun-hsiung is scheduled to leave Taipei Sept. 1 for official visits to the Republic of China's four allies in the eastern Caribbean region, a Cabinet spokesman said Monday.
Chang will visit Saint Kitts and Nevis Sept. 3, the Commonwealth of Dominica Sept. 4, Saint Vincent and the Grenadines Sept. 5-6, and Grenada Sept. 7, the spokesman said.
It will be Chang's first overseas trip since he assumed office last October.

The spokesman said the four East Caribbean nations are staunch allies of the ROC. "They have consistently supported the ROC's bids to join the United Nations and other major international organizations," he added.
Since Chang took the premiership, the spokesman went on, senior officials of the four Caribbean nations have visited Taiwan and invited him to tour their countries.
"We believe that Chang's upcoming diplomatic tour will further boost our cordial relationships with the four countries," the spokesman said.

As the U.N. General Assembly will open its annual plenary session Sept. 11, the spokesman said, Chang will take advantage of his tour to solicit the four allies' continued support for the ROC's U.N. bid.
Chang will make a transit stop in New York en route to the eastern Caribbean and will also make brief stopovers in Los Angeles and Hawaii on his way home, the spokesman went on.

The premier will be accompanied by an entourage of government officials and senior business executives, including Minister of Transportation and Communications Yeh Chu-lan, Government Information Office Director-General Su Tzeng-ping, Vice Minister of Economic Affairs Lin Yi-fu and Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission Minister Chang Fu-mei.
Chang and his 10-plus-member entourage are scheduled to return to Taipei Sept. 12.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT SHOULD DO MORE IN PROMOTING CLEAN POLITICS: POLL

TEXT.P: Public evaluation of the government's performance in promoting clean politics has declined slightly from last year's level, according to the results of an opinion poll released Monday.
The Ministry of Justice (MOJ) has commissioned National Chengchi University to survey public opinions about the government's efforts to promote clean politics annually in recent years.
The latest survey found that the government has managed to receive a "passing grade" this year, but the score fell below last year's level by a small margin and failed to reach 65 points.

Vice Minister of Justice Hsieh Wen-ting said the mild decline might result from public misperception. "As law enforcement authorities have endeavored to crack down on official corruption and vote-buying over the past year, local people might have misperceived that political graft remains rampant in Taiwan," Hsieh explained, adding that many suspected corruption cases under investigation were committed sometimes ago.

Hsieh said the MOJ will not be daunted by the decline in public rating of its anti-corruption operations. "We'll instead redouble our efforts to wipe out corruption and establish clean politics," he added.
Poll results showed that survey respondents were particularly dissatisfied with the current government's indecisiveness toward certain major public issues.
The poll also found that the respondents were also very dissatisfied with the performances of elected representatives, including legislators and members of city and county councils.
Meanwhile, a majority of survey respondents said they have no confidence in the effects of reporting suspected corruption cases to relevant law enforcement authorities.

According to the poll, the respondents said they thought that government officials in charge of procurement and construction administration affairs are most likely to take bribes or get involved in kickback scandals.

The poll further found that the majority of respondents are aware that the current Democratic Progressive Party-led government has pledged to eradicate "black gold" politics, or shady links between politics and organized crime, and official corruption. Most of those interviewed also threw support behind the proposal to set up an independent anti-corruption agency.
A total of 1,086 adults were questioned in this year's poll.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER PREMIER HAILS SUCCESS OF EDAC

TEXT.P: Former Premier Vincent Siew hailed Monday the Economic Development Advisory Conference (EDAC) initiated by President Chen Shui-bian.
Siew, who served as one of the five deputy conveners of the just-concluded EDAC, offered high praise for the fruitful results accomplished by the EDAC.
Siew made the remarks during an interview with the Broadcasting Corporation of China (BCC).

He pointed out that one of the achievements of the three-day EDAC was the consensus that the government's "no haste, be patient" policy that restrict local investment in mainland China should be adjusted.
This adjustment will be a great step forward, Siew said, adding that in the rapidly changing world, cross-Taiwan Strait economic policy should also be readjusted to meet the challenges.

However, he added that the "no haste, be patient" policy adopted by the government in 1996 was the correct one in its day. Taiwan's information technology industry had just began to develop when the government implemented the policy, Siew went on, adding that no-one could have predicted the outcome of Taiwan's economic development if adequate control measures had not been adopted.

The policy was very useful in helping Taiwan's economic development at that time, Siew said, adding that in the face of the new century and the new economic situation at home and abroad, the adjustment of the policy is essential.

Asked why Chen mentioned his "new middle way" line at the EDAC, Siew said that Chen was apparently telling the fundamentalists in the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) that the "new middle way" is the only possible way forward.
He called on the DPP and the Chen administration to readjust the nation's economic policy in a timely manner.
Siew also denied news reports that Chen had asked his five deputies to propose at the EDAC plenary session Sunday a revision of the land value-added tax and the cap on government debts.
Siew also dismissed news reports that he will be renamed premier of the ROC. He called on both the government and people to concentrate their efforts on promoting Taiwan's economic development.

DOC.HEADLINE: TSU NOT TO BE INVITED TO CROSS-PARTY CONSULTATION MEETING

TEXT.P: The opposition Kuomintang (KMT) said Monday that it will not invite the newly formed Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) to a cross-party consulation meeting that the KMT will host in two weeks.

Participating in the meeting, which will focus on working out ways to implement the agreements reached at the just-concluded Economic Development Advisory Conference, will be leaders of the four major political parties -- the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, and the oppositon KMT, the People First Party and the New Party, all of which hold seats in the Legislative Yuan, said Wang Chih-kang, director-general of the KMT's Cultural Communication Commiteee.
Wang said that as the TSU does not have any seats in the legislature, it will not be invited to the consultation meeting.
Wang also expressed the party's affirmation to the convening of the EDAC, an idea of Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian to boost the sluggish economy.

The nation's major political parties, economic and industrial experts, as well as business leaders, had a wide exchange of views on Taiwan's economic problems through the EDAC and reached many conclusions in the three-day meeting that ended Sunday.

Wang said that the KMT is glad that most of its suggestions presented at the EDAC were accepted and that Chen has also given its support to the idea of a political consultation meeting initiated by KMT Chairman Lien Chan.

Meanwhile, Tsai Chia-fu of the KMT caucus in the Legislative Yuan said that it would be better if the political consultation meeting is organized by the KMT as it is the largest party in the legislature. Tsai was responding to a proposal of Tsai Huang-liang -- the DPP caucus leader in the legislature -- who said the meeting should be convened by the president.

He also suggested that the political consultation meeting should focus on cross-strait ties, a ceiling on government debt, tax reductions and other "crucial topics," and that the president should attend the meeting.
The KMT will invite secretaries-generals of the major political parties to meet Friday to prepare for the meeting.

DOC.HEADLINE: BIOTECH FORUM OPENS IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: A three-day forum aimed at promoting information exchanges among Taiwan's biotechnological firms opened in Taipei Monday.

The 2001 Taipei International Master Forum on Biotechnology has been organized by the Industrial Technology Research Institute and brings together 24 speakers from the United States, Australia, Japan, Hong Kong, mainland China and Taiwan.

Chintay Shih, president of the Industrial Technology Research Institute, said the purpose of the forum is to harness Taiwan's well-developed information technology to the development of biotechnology, with the focus on biochips, bioinformation and biopharmaceuticals.
David P. Flores, president of the world's leading biotechnological intelligence providers -- BioCentury Publishing Company -- gave a speech at the opening ceremony.
He urged technological firms to ensure their survival and prosperity through joint ventures, industrial alliances and technology transfers.
After the bursting of the optimistic bubble with regard to dotcom firms, Flores said, the public should give a cautious appraisal to biotechnological firms.

Taipei City Mayor Ma Ying-jeou was also invited to attend the opening ceremony. He touted Taipei -- which hosts seven of the country's 12 medical centers -- as an ideal base for technological firms because of its huge population of technologists and the soft loans available from the Taipei Bank for biotechnological firms.
He promised to relax city zoning restrictions to accommodate the establishment of pharmaceutical companies in Taipei.
Meanwhile, GeneMaster, a local biochemical firm, unveiled a biochip called the Galaxy Chip at the forum.

The chip, purported to be the first "live" chip in the world, is the brainchild of GeneMaster and the Tri Service General Hospital in Taipei, according to its inventor Chang Jung-sen, a professor from the National Central University.
Chang said the chip can diagnose meningitis and identify the strain of bacterium causing it within 24 hours.
There are twenty to thirty bacterium which can cause the disease, which is common in Taiwan and Japan. The Galaxy chip can detect about 80 percent to 90 percent of them, according to its inventor.

The current method of diagnosing meningitis is through examination of the cerebrospinal fluid, a process that takes between three days and one week. It is not unusual for patients to die before the test results become available, said Chang.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN FLASHES BLUE RECESSION LIGHT FOR 8TH STRAIGHT MONTH

TEXT.P: Taiwan's economy in July flashed a blue light, representing recession in the country's official rating system, an official of the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) said Monday.
It was the eighth consecutive month that the island's economy had flashed a blue light, the rating system's worst situation.

In the CEPD-devised five-color system, a red light signifies an overheated economy, yellow-red indicates that the economy is heating up, green reflects steady growth, yellow-blue signals economic sluggishness, and blue represents recession.
In applying the system, the CEPD measures nine major areas of economic activity, including exports, industrial production, stock index and orders placed in the manufacturing field.
The CEPD official said that all nine areas registered blue lights in July, indicating that the prospects of an early economic recovery remain bleak.
Meanwhile, the official noted that Taiwan's leading economic index for July stood at 92.8, up a 0.1 percentage point over the preceding month.

He said that the decline in some areas of the index have slowed down, creating a better chance for recovery, but added that the movement in the next few months will be key to predicting the economy's future.

DOC.HEADLINE: REPORTED PLA EXERCISES `ROUTINE': MND

TEXT.P: Reported imminent exercises to be held by the People's Liberation Army (PLA) along the coast of eastern Guangdong Province will be routine annual drills, Taiwan's Ministry of National Defense (MND) said Monday.

The MND made the remark in response to a Hong Kong-based newspaper's report that the PLA's Guangzhou Military Region will probably hold a military exercises in Shantou, on a scale similar to that of an exercise held recently on Dongshan Island off the coast of Fujian Province.

The Wen Wei Pao daily said the exercise will be characterized by drills relating to anti-landing, anti-air raid, electronic interference and anti-electronic interference, satellite reconnaissance and anti-blockade.
MND officials noted that Beijing often exaggerates the scale of mainland Chinese military exercises in an attempt to attain its propaganda goals.
For example, they said, the scale of the just-ended Dongshan Island exercise was "not large," but Beijing media reported that 100,000 troops took part.
The officials urged the people of Taiwan to heighten their "psychological defenses" and not be affected by exaggerated mainland reports.

DOC.HEADLINE: CROSS-STRAIT TRADE POSTS DOUBLE-DIGIT DECREASE IN JUNE

TEXT.P: Taiwan's exports to mainland China registered a 12.4 percent decrease in June from the same period of last year, according to statistics released Monday by the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA).

An official of the Board of Foreign Trade (BOFT) under the MOEA attributed the slump in mainland-bound exports -- the second in as many months -- to the global economic slowdown that has began to produce a negative impact on mainland China's economy.

The statistics also show that two-way trade between Taiwan and the mainland totaled US$14.4 billion in the first six months of this year, which also represents a fall of 5.8 percent over the same period of last year.

Of the figure, Taiwan's exports to the mainland reached US$11.5 billion, a decrease of 6 percent, while imports from the mainland totaled US$2.8 billion, a fall of 5.2 percent, giving Taiwan a trade surplus of US$8.6 billion, also a decrease of 6.2 percent over the same period of last year.

DOC.HEADLINE: FIRST LEGALLY IMPORTED MAINLAND CHINESE COMMODITIES ARRIVE ON KINMEN

TEXT.P: The first shipment of legally approved imported mainland China-made commodities arrived in Kinmen's Liaolo Port directly from Fujian's Weitou Port Monday.

The trade, postal and transport links between the Republic of China-controlled offshore islands of Kinmen and Matsu and the mainland ports of Xiamen and Mawei were unilaterally inaugurated Jan. 1 this year by the ROC authorities.

An official of the Kinmen County government said that the shipment not only marks the first batch of products made by mainland China to be legally imported to Kinmen but also lays a new milestone in that commodities rather than people have made the crossing.

This goods will be displayed at the First Jinjiang Best Product Expo scheduled to be held at the Kinmen Stadium Aug. 31-Sept. 2 under the joint sponsorship of Kinmen County Chamber of Commerce (KCCC) and Jinjiang General Chamber of Commerce.
A total of 52 companies from the mainland city of Jinjiang will take part in the exposition.
Monday's 10-ton shipment included footwear, furniture, toys, construction materials, hardware, garments and electronic goods.
Hsu Chun-min, president of the Kinmen County Chamber of Commerce, said that the KCCC will serve as a bridge between Kinmen and Jinjiang to promote commercial exchanges.

Kinmen County Magistrate Chen Shui-chai said that holding the expo on Kinmen will promote commercial exchanges between the two regions. He added that the Kinmen government is planning to set up an exposition hall to permanently display the mainland China-made products.
The deputy mayor of Jinjiang City is expected to arrive on Kinmen Tuesday at the head of a 120-member delegation to take part in the expo.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEXUAL OFFENDER OFFERS TO UNDERGO CASTRATION PAROLE

TEXT.P: In an attempt to dispel opposition to his parole, a jailed sexual offender has offered to undergo treatment to reduce his libido, a prison instructor said Monday.

The offender made headlines earlier this month for passing the Joint University Entrance Examination and gaining admittance to National Taiwan University, which is the first choice of most high school students.

However, the possible release on parole of the sexual offender, who was convicted of dozens of sexual attacks against female university students, caused hot debate over the appropriateness of releasing a serial sexual offender back among the people upon whom he used to prey.
The offender, whose name has been withheld by the Ministry of Justice (MOJ), has served six years of a 16-year jail term and is therefore eligible for parole, said a MOJ official.

But the public concern over his past offenses has put a lot of pressure on the MOJ, which is due to deliberate the offender's parole before local universities begin their autumn semesters in September.

An official at the Taipei Prison, where the man is incarcerated, said Monday that the convict has expressed his strong desire to study at National Taiwan University and has offered to undergo "any treatment" to suppress his sexual desire if it would help allay public concern.

DOC.HEADLINE: LOCAL TYCOON FIGURES AMONG `100 EXCELLENT CHINESE'
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, Aug. 27 (CNA) (By Semy Chen and Elisa Kao)

TEXT.P: Taiwan petrochemical tycoon Y.C. Wang was chosen as one of the "100 outstanding Chinese in the world" by a book sponsored by the United Nations and Beijing's State Council and published Monday.

The U.N. Conference on Trade and Development (UNCTAD) and the Leading Group for Poverty Relief under mainland China's State Council announced the list of 100 excellent Chinese from Taiwan, mainland China and Hong Kong at a press conference in Hong Kong.
Hong Kong tycoon Li Ka Shing also made the list.

Many Beijing officials stationed in Hong Kong, as well as UNCTAD Representative Maclod Nyrongo, attended the conference and conferred awards on the people on the list, although neither Li nor Wang attended.
The 100 figures come from various spheres of society and were chosen for their tremendous contributions to and influence on economic development and social progress.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT URGED TO RESPECT BIGGEST PARTY WHEN FORMING COALITION

TEXT.P: The spokesman for the opposition Kuomintang (KMT), Taiwan's largest political party, said Monday that President Chen Shui-bian should respect the views of the KMT when he forms a coalition government.

Chen pledged at the end of the Economic Development Advisory Conference (EDAC) Sunday that regardless of the results of December's legislative elections, he will form a coalition government to stabilize the political situation.

KMT spokesman Wang Chih-kang told reporters that his party affirmed Chen's remarks, but added that the president must respect the largest party in the Legislative Yuan when forming the coalition government.
Otherwise, Wang noted, "disputes between the government and the Legislative Yuan will arise frequently."
In order to resolve the problems relating to political instability, he went on, "respecting the majority in the Legislative Yuan is a prerequisite for forming a coalition government."
Regarding the form of the proposed coalition government, Wang said that "it must be decided through negotiations of all parties."
In this connection, ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairman Frank Hsieh said in Kaohsiung that the successful convening of the EDAC provided a good model for future party cooperation.
Commenting on Chen's statement about forming a coalition government, he said that the DPP "would not exclude such a possibility."
However, he pointed out that "whether the coalition government can be formed and what form it should take will depend on the results of the year-end legislative elections."
"Party cooperation is the precondition for the successful formation of a coalition government," Hsieh said, adding that without such a precondition, talk of a coalition would be no more than hot air.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC BEATS JAPAN, R.P. AT PACIFIC JUNIOR LEAGUE BASEBALL EVENT
DOC.DATELINE: Manila, Aug. 27 (CNA) (By Philip Liu & Ed Chen)

TEXT.P: Chinese Taipei blanked Japan 5-0 Monday in its debut game at the first Pan Pacific Cup Junior League Baseball Championship Tournament presently under way in the Philippines.
The game actually began the previous day but was rained off in the fourth inning, by which point Chinese Taipei was leading 4-0.
The game resumed Monday, when the Chinese Taipei nine beat their Japanese rivals 5-0 before going on to trounce host the Philippines A team 9-4.
Chinese Taipei will take on Singapore Tuesday.

A total of 11 teams representing the United States, Mexico, Australia, Japan, South Korea, Singapore, the Republic of China, Malaysia and Indonesia, with the Philippines fielding two teams, are taking part in the tourney under the sponsorship of the Philippine Pony Baseball and Softball Association. The games are being held at the Subic Bay Softball Diamond.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT REGRETS EDAC'S FAILURE TO ENDORSE `1992 CONSENSUS'

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) spokesman Wang Chih-kang expressed regret Monday that the Economic Development Advisory Conference (EDAC) failed to endorse the so-called "1992 consensus" on the "one China" issue.
The "1992 consensus" allows both sides of the Taiwan Strait to make their own interpretations as to the meaning of "one China."

It formed the basis for quasi-official dialogue between Taipei's Straits Exchange Foundation and Beijing's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait until bilateral negotiations came to a complete standstill in July 1999.

Wang said at a press conference that the KMT affirmed the convening of the EDAC and its success in reaching consensus on 322 items, including a relaxation of the "go slow, be patient" policy, which regulates Taiwan's trade with and investment in mainland China.
However, the KMT spokesman stated that his party regrets that the "1992 consensus" was not listed as a consensus by the tree-day EDAC that ended Sunday.
Regarding the easing of the "go slow, be patient" policy, Wang said that it is designed to cope with Taiwan's entry into the World Trade Organization (WTO) later this year.
"As Taiwan is going to face a severe challenge after its accession to the WTO, the KMT highly affirms the easing of the `go slow, be patient' policy," he said.
Wang added that "at present the government should put more effort into strengthening the development of economic and trade relations across the Taiwan Strait."

DOC.HEADLINE: H.K. CHIEF HAILS DIRECT CROSS-TAIWAN STRAIT LINKS
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, Aug. 27 (CNA) (By Mandy Wong & Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's opening to direct transportation links with mainland China will have a negative short term but a positive long term influence on Hong Kong's economy, Hong Kong Chief Executive Tung Chee-hwa said Monday.

One day after the Taiwan authorities declared their readiness to open direct transport links with mainland China and lift long-standing curbs on trade with and investment in the mainland, Tung said Hong Kong will suffer as a result, but only in the short term.

However, Tung said, Taiwan's dismantling of the barriers to trade with mainland China will facilitate reunification of the "homeland," and Hong Kong will support whatever measures are conducive to national reunification.

Meanwhile, Hong Kong Financial Secretary Antony Leung Kam-chung said he is pleased to see Taiwan changing tack and added that the new measures will promote economic and cultural exchanges between the two sides of Taiwan Strait, which, he said, is in the interest of all Chinese.

Leung admitted that local land and air carriers will bear the brunt of the impact, since Hong Kong will lose its importance as the gateway to and from mainland China for millions Taiwan visitors every year in the absence of direct links between the mainland and Taiwan.
However, Hong Kong's status as the financial center for the whole of Asia, especially for mainland China and Taiwan, will be strengthened in the long term, Leung went on.
The closer economic integration of mainland China, Taiwan and Hong Kong will boost the prosperity in the Greater Chinese area, Leung said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN WINS TABLE TENNIS BRONZE AT UNIVERSIADE
DOC.DATELINE: Beijing, Aug. 27 (CNA) (By Lee An-tung & Ed Chen)

TEXT.P: South Korea beat Chinese Taipei 2-0 Monday in the table tennis mixed doubles semi-finals, leaving the Taiwan pair to settle for the bronze medal at the 21st World Universiade Games presently under way in Beijing.

Chiang Peng-lung and Chen Chiu-dan had advanced to the semi-finals earlier in the day after blanking their North Korean rivals 2-0, while another Chinese Taipei team comprising Chang Su-yen and Tsui Hsiu-li were beaten 2-0 by mainland China.
In the men's table tennis singles, Chuang Chih-yen blanked Daisuke Ishida of Japan to advance to 32nd position, while Chiang Peng-lung was eliminated by his mainland Chinese rival.

In tennis, Lee Hui-tze and Weng Tse-ting of Chinese Taipei edged out their Japanese rivals in the women's doubles to advance to the semi-finals, making at least a bronze medal a certainty for the Chinese Taipei delegation, which has so far not performed well at the Universiade.
Lee and Weng will take on South Korea Tuesday.

In the women's singles, first-seeded Lee Hui-tze of Chinese Taipei advanced to the quarter-finals after eliminating her South Korean rival 7-5, 7-5. She will take on Liu Nan-nan of mainland China Tuesday.
Her team-mate Wang I-ting also advanced to the quarter-finals after eliminating her German rival 7-6, 6-4. She will take on Li Na of mainland China Tuesday.

In the men's single, Cheng Wei-jen was eliminated by his Slovakian rival, while Lu Yen-hsuen defeated Zhang Yu of mainland China to advance to the quarter-finals. He will take on his British rival Tuesday.
In track and field, meanwhile, Chinese Taipei's Lin Chung-chieh was eliminated in the first heat of the men's 110-meters hurdles.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PRESIDENT RECEIVES U.S. COMPANY PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian met Monday with David Peterson, president of the U.S.-based NRG Energy, Inc., at the Presidential Office.

NRG Energy Inc. and Hsin Yu Cogeneration Co., Ltd., a local company based at the Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park entered into an agreement under which NRG will provide NT$5 billion (US$143 million) in capital investment to build a cogeneration plant at the park and another at the Tainan Science-based Industrial Park to supply electricity for Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Corp., United Microelectronics Co. and other major electronic companies.

Peterson told Chen that the semiconductor industry in Taiwan will continue to lead the world and that a stable power supply is essential for a nation seeking economic development. Peterson also expressed the hope that Taiwan will open up more of its power market to foreign investors.

NRG Energy Inc. is the second-largest private power supplier in the United States and the fifth-largest in the world. Its current capacity is capable of producing 22 megawatts -- almost equal to Taiwan's total consumption.

Hsin Yu already has one cogeneration plant at the Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park. Construction of the second plant is scheduled to begin at the end of this year and is expected to begin supplying power in January 2004. The Hsinchu and the Tainan cogenerating plants together will cost a total of NT$17 billion (US$487 million).

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT TO CONSIDER WHETHER TO REPRIMAND FORMER PARTY CHAIRMAN

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Secretary-General Lin Fong-cheng said Monday that the party's Evaluation and Discipline Committee has been authorized to handle former Chairman Lee Teng-hui's violation of party discipline.

Lee has been the target of criticism within the party for his open support for prospective candidates of the newly formed Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU). Some have demanded Lee's expulsion from the party.
After hearing a report on Lee's case at the party's central work meeting, Lin said it will be handled by the Evaluation and Discipline Committee in line with party regulations.
Chen Keng-chin, chairman of the committee, told reporters that the party has no timetable for handling Lee's case.
He noted that the basic principle will be to exercise as much damage control on the case as possible.
As Lee plans to begin campaigning for TSU candidates in southern Taiwan Sept. 1, Chen said that the party will monitor his words and actions closely to decide how to deal with the case.

DOC.HEADLINE: FM HEADS FOR GRENADA

TEXT.P: Foreign Minister Tien Hung-mao left Taipei Monday for Grenada to attend a meeting with his counterparts from the Republic of China's four allies in the eastern Caribbean region.

Although it was not reported where he will make his stopover en route to the Caribbean, he will visit New York and Boston on his way home and will give a speech Sept. 9 at Harvard University's Kennedy Government School.

DOC.HEADLINE: HONG KONG TOURIST ARRIVALS FROM TAIWAN GROW SLIGHTLY
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, Aug. 27 (CNA) (By Mandy Wong and David Hsu)

TEXT.P: Hong Kong's tourist arrivals from Taiwan registered a year-on-year increase of 2.4 percent in July, according statistics released Monday by the Hong Kong Tourism Board (HKTB).
There were 221,048 tourist arrivals in Hong Kong in July from Taiwan, down from the last several months.
For the January-July period this year, Hong Kong's tourist arrivals from Taiwan registered a cumulative growth of 5.6 percent, the statistics reveal.
The HKTB attributed the drop in tourist arrivals from Taiwan mainly to the recession and the effect of Typhoon Toraji on Taiwan.
But Hong Kong's tourist arrivals from mainland China grew significantly by 20.3 percent in the same month compared with the same month of last year, according to statistics.

Hong Kong's tourist arrivals rose 7 percent in July to 1.17 million, with cumulative tourist arrivals in the first seven months recording an increase of 7.4 percent, roughly in line with HKTB's prediction of 7.8 percent growth for 2001.
For the first seven months of this year, tourist arrivals in Hong Kong from mainland China grew by 12.7 percent, compared with the same period of last year.

The HKTB attributed the sharp increase of tourist arrivals from mainland China to the significant growth of mainland China's economy and Beijing's loosening of its policy toward mainland people traveling abroad.
But Hong Kong's tourist arrivals from mainland China grew significantly by 20.3 percent in the same month compared with the same month of last year, according to statistics.

Hong Kong's tourist arrivals rose 7 percent in July to 1.17 million, with cumulative tourist arrivals in the first seven months recording an increase of 7.4 percent, roughly in line with HKTB's prediction of 7.8 percent growth for 2001.
For the first seven months of this year, tourist arrivals in Hong Kong from mainland China grew by 12.7 percent, compared with the same period of last year.

The HKTB attributed the sharp increase of tourist arrivals from mainland China to the significant growth of mainland China's economy and Beijing's loosening of its policy toward mainland people traveling abroad.
The HKTB statistics also show that from January to June, visitors' spending created a year-on-year growth of 7.7 percent to HK$31.26 billion (US$4 billion).

In the first half of this year, mainland visitors spent more than HK$10 billion, up 13.3 percent from the same period of last year, while Taiwan tourists spent some HK$60 million, a year-on-year increase of 1.6 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, Aug. 28, or the 10th day of the seventh month of the Year of the Snake according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1640: The Scots defeat royalist English forces at the Battle of Newburn, near Newcastle.
1774: Elizabeth Ann Seton, American educator and religious leader who founded the Sisters of St. Joseph, is born. She was canonized as the first US-born saint in 1975.
1828: Lev Nikolayevich Tolstoy, also known as Count Leo Tolstoi, Russian writer and philosopher, is born. His great novels "War and Peace" and "Anna Karenina" offer extraordinary detail and profound psychological insights. His later theories of ethics and morality recommended non-participation in and passive resistance to evil.
1830: Peter Cooper, American inventor who built the first American locomotive, displays his latest creation, a steam-driven locomotive called Tom Thumb.
1884: Peter Fraser, prime minister of New Zealand from 1940 to 1949, is born in Scotland.
1910: Montenegro proclaims independence from the Ottoman empire.
1916: Germany declares war on Romania.
1919: Sir Godfrey Hounsfield, British inventor of the EMI medical scanner, is born. He was winner of the Nobel Prize for psychology in 1979.
1927: The Eighth Far East Games is held in Shanghai.
1929: The Kuomintang (KMT) branch in Shanghai asks the Nanking government to punish Professor Hu Shih, a former student of John Dewey, for publishing an article criticizing Dr. Sun Yat-sen and the KMT.
1931: The Mexican government orders all ethnic Chinese to leave Mexico before Sept. 2.
1945: Mao Tse-tung, accompanied by U.S. Ambassador Patrick Hurley, arrives in Chungking from Yenan to hold a meeting with the KMT to discuss such issues as national unity.
1963: U.S. civil rights leader Martin Luther King Jr. delivers his "I have a dream" speech to some 200,000 people after an interracial march on Washington, a peaceful demonstration in favor of furthering the cause of civil rights.
1973: Princess Anne arrives in Kiev for an equestrian event, becoming the first member of the British royal family to visit the Soviet Union.
1974: The Republic of China and Thailand conclude a maize trade agreement.
1976: ROC President Yen Chia-kan receives Bolivian Vice Foreign Minister Hernando Garcia Vespa and his wife.
1980: ROC Premier Y.S. Sun leaves for Costa Rica, Panama and the Dominican Republic for official visits.
1983: Menachem Begin resigns as prime minister of Israel.
1988: Three jet planes belonging to an Italian Air Force aeronautics display team collide during an exhibition in front of a crowd of 300,000 at the U.S. Air Force base at Ramstein in West Germany, killing 47 people and injuring some 500 others.
1990: Iraq declares Kuwait the 19th province of Iraq.
1993: Ong Teng Cheong, chairman of the ruling People's Action Party, is elected president of Singapore.
1996: El Salvador President Armando Calderon Sol visits the Republic of China.
1999: The ruling Kuomintang convenes the second plenary session of its 15th National Congress to formally approve Lien Chan and Vincent Siew as the party's nominees for the 2000 presidential election of the Republic of China.
2000: Buddhist leaders from Taiwan are taking part in the Millennium World Peace Summit of world religious leaders that opens in New York.
2000: Opposition Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan says that he would like to meet President Chen Shui-bian at the Presidential Office to exchange opinions about the nation's major issues.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Like the rush of mighty waters, the presence of unseen powers is felt -- sometimes above us, sometimes around us. Such is the evidence of things invisible that it is impossible to doubt the spiritual nature of man."

DOC.TEXT:

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. WELCOMES TAIWAN'S POLICY ADJUSTMENT ON CROSS-STRAIT INVESTMENT

TEXT.P: The United States on Monday welcomed the decision of President Chen Shui-bian's government to ease restrictions on cross-strait investment in mainland China and to adopt a more aggressive policy, which is favored by most Taiwan business leaders.

"We believe improving cross-strait economic ties serves the interest of both Taiwan and the People's Republic of China and is conducive to peace and security in the region," a State Department official said.
"With that in mind, we welcome recent proposals by Taiwan's economic advisory conference to expand cross-strait economic ties," he said.

"Our abiding interest is a peaceful resolution of differences in a manner acceptable to the people on both sides of the Strait," the official said, adding that Washington believes dialogue is the best way to achieve such a resolution.

On Sunday, President Chen promised to formulate new policies within two weeks based on the recommendations offered by the Economic Development Advisory Conference, which included lifting the US$50 million ceiling on any single Taiwanese investment in mainland China and allowing investment from mainland China in Taiwan's real estate and stock markets.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER CHANG VOWS TO ERADICATE VOTE-BUYING IN YEAR-END ELECTIONS

TEXT.P: Premier Chang Chun-hsiung pledged Tuesday to fight vote-buying in the elections for legislators, city mayors and county magistrates scheduled for Dec. 1.
Chang made the vow during an inspection tour of the Central Election Commission.

Noting that the year-end elections are the most important national elections since Taiwan's historic democratic transition of power between different political parties in May 2000, Chang said the government is determined to ensure that the elections are not sullied by what has become commonplace in Taiwan politics -- gifts of money or goods in exchange for votes.

"We are determined to make every possible effort to wipe out vote-buying in the December elections. We'll investigate any suspected vote-buying case regardless of party affiliation and social status of those involved," Chang said.

The premier further said open, fair and clean elections are critical to instilling public confidence in the results of the elections. He also said that a transparent election process is important in maintaining social stability and establishing a solid foundation for democratic development.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK PRICES DOWN BY 16.17 POINTS

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) lost ground on Tuesday, with the benchmark weighted price index moving down 16.17 points to close at 4,368.38.
Market turnover amounted to NT$36.41 billion (US$1.05 billion).

DOC.HEADLINE: 50,000-PLUS PIRATED VCD CRUSHED IN DISPLAY AGAINST COUNTERFEITING

TEXT.P: More than 50,000 counterfeit VCDs and other products were crushed in a public ceremony Tuesday to signify the Republic of China government's determination to eradicate commercial piracy and protect intellectual property rights (IPR.)
The ceremony, presided over by Vice Minister of Economic Affairs Chen Ruey-long, was held to honor outstanding police units in anti-commercial piracy operations over the past year.

The Ministry of Economic Affairs also invited members of the diplomatic corps and representatives from the de facto U.S. and Japanese embassies in Taipei -- the American Institute in Taiwan and the Japanese Interchange Association -- as well as officials from relevant ROC government agencies, including the Ministry of the Interior, the Ministry of Justice, and the Public Prosecutors' Office of the Taiwan High Court, to witness the ceremony.

The crushed counterfeit goods, with a market value of NT$8.36 billion (US$242.32 million), were confiscated by Taipei, Shihlin and Panchiao prosecutors' offices and all people involved those cases have been convicted of commercial counterfeiting.
Watching a steamroller running over the fake products, Chen said the move underscores the government's drive to eliminate commercial piracy and strengthen IPR protection.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock index futures market were lower on Tuesday, as Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index futures for September moved down 30 points to close at 4,311, with 10,190 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for October fell 37 points to finish at 4,318, with 27 contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for other months.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Tuesday at 4,341 for September, 4,355 for October, 4,408 for December, 4,389 for next March, and 4,408 for next June.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, reported mixed results.
September TE futures moved down 2.8 points to close at 214.4, with 1,966 contract transactions, while October TE futures decreased 3.8 points to finish at 213.8, with 19 contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for other months.
September TF futures rose 1.4 points to finish at 587.6, with 1,275 contract transactions, while October TF futures gained 1.4 points to close at 594.4, with only one contract traded.
December TF futures increased 12.8 points to finish at 595, with one contract traded. No transactions were recorded for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECONOMIC PROCESSING ZONES TO CONCENTRATE ON VALUE-ADDED INDUSTRIES

TEXT.P: The government is planning to develop the economic processing zones (EPZs) in Kaohsiung and Taichung into industrial parks for high value-added manufacturing and services, according to EPZ administration director Chou Yen.

Chou said that manufacturing industrial companies now account for less than 40 percent of the businesses in the EPZs, as compared with 51 percent in 1998. Increasing numbers of companies involved in international trade, services, high-technology, logistics and the warehousing and transportation sectors are headquartered in the EPZs, he added.

At the Economic Development Advisory Conference last week, the participants reached recommendations by consensus to promote direct transportation links between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait and to develop Kaohsiung Harbor into a transshipment center.

Related government agencies, including the Ministry of Finance, the Ministry of Economic Affairs, the Council for Economic Planning and Development and the Ministry of Transportation and Communications all support the proposal of the Kaohsiung City Government to have the Kaohsiung Nantze and Chungtao EPZs included into the Kaohsiung transshipment center project.
Under the plan, imported products, including those directly from mainland China, can be processed at the warehouses at the EPZs and re-exported or distributed from the transshipment center.

An official of the Kaohsiung Harbor Bureau pointed out that the transshipment center project will help the EPZs attracting more warehousing and transportation businesses and will benefit the international harbor in boosting its transshipment businesses.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Shares prices opened high but closed lower on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) on Tuesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 16.17 points to close at 4,368.38.
The bourse opened at 4,405.22, and fluctuated between 4,406.97 and 4,340.65 during trading.

A total of 1.67 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$36.41 billion (US$1.05 billion), a decrease from the previous trading session which saw 1.9 billion stocks change hands on a market turnover of NT$47.67 billion (US$1.38 billion).
Three of the eight major stock categories lost ground, with foodstuff shares moving down the most at 1 percent, followed by electrical stocks at 0.7 percent, and cement stocks at 0.3 percent.

The other major categories posted gains, with construction stocks moving up the most at 3.6 percent, followed by plastics and chemical shares at 0.5 percent, bank and insurance stocks at 0.3 percent, textile issues and pulp and paper issues, both at 0.1 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 243 to 238, with 105 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: HANCOCK GRAHAM SUGGESTS POSSIBLE LOST CIVILIZATION NEAR PENGHU

TEXT.P: Hancock Graham, author of the bestsellers "The Sign and the Seal" and "Fingerprints of the Gods," said Monday in Taipei that he believes the undersea stone walls near Penghu are relics of a lost civilization that flourished at least 10,000 years ago.

The British writer has been looking for relics of lost civilizations on land and under the sea in the Mediterranean, India and Japan. He learned about the undersea stone walls near Penghu from a Japanese television program. With the help of local divers, he conducted a diving expedition near Penghu to see the structures under the sea first hand.

Graham said that judging from the appearance of the walls, he believes they are relics of a lost civilization. As a writer, he said that he can only do so much to inspire authorities and academics to look further into the walls to determine their history.

DOC.HEADLINE: LARGE MAINLAND GROUP MAKES DIRECT VOYAGE TO KINMEN FOR TRADE FAIR

TEXT.P: A 112-member mainland Chinese trade delegation, headed by Deputy Mayor of Jinjiang City Wang Yuandong, arrived at the Republic of China's frontline island of Kinmen via a direct voyage Tuesday to preside over the opening of a trade fair.

This was the largest mainland group to sail directly across the short distance in the Taiwan Strait since the ROC government opened direct trade, mail and shipping links between its two offshore defense outposts of Kinmen and Matsu and mainland China's Xiamen and Mawei ports in Fujian province, commonly known as the "mini three links," at the beginning of this year.
The mission followed the arrival of a shipment of mainland Chinese consumer products Monday to be displayed at the First Jinjiang Trade Fair scheduled to open at the Kinmen Stadium Friday.

The shipment comprised 138 categories of consumer products manufactured by 52 blue-chip firms in the Jinjiang area in Fujian province which lies opposite Taiwan. It was the first batch of mainland consumer goods to be legally imported to Kinmen since the opening of the "mini three links."
Wang said upon his arrival in Kinmen that he is very pleased to see the "mini three links" enter a new stage of legal merchandise trade.
"We hope the upcoming trade fair will help boost commercial and civilian exchanges between Kinmen and Jinjiang for the benefits of residents in both regions," Wang said.

For his part, Kinmen Deputy Magistrate Yen Ta-jen said the county government has long hoped to legally import mainland consumer goods. "We hope the Aug. 31-Sept. 2 Jinjiang trade fair will set a model for future cross-strait commercial exchanges," he added.
As Kinmen lies far closer to Fujian than to Taiwan, many mainland products have been smuggled into Kinmen over the past years, despite intensive coast guard patrols.

A second trade delegation from Jinjiang, to be held by Zheng Zungjie, director of the external trade and economic cooperation department under the Fujian provincial government, is scheduled to arrive in Kinmen Thursday to attend the grand opening of the trade fair.
Mainland products to be displayed in the show will include footwear, furniture, toys, garments, consumer electronics and construction materials and interior decorations.

As mainland China has been reluctant to throw its full support behind the Taiwan-initiated "mini three links," it still does not allow regular direct Kinmen-Xiamen and Matsu-Mawei shipping services and instead reviews such applications on a case-by-case basis.
Kinmen County Government sources said the forthcoming Jinjiang trade fair may mark a change in mainland China's attitude toward the "mini three links."

"Anyway, we hope that the 'mini three links' can make headway after the trade fair to help pave the way for opening of full-fledged trade, communication and transportation links across the Taiwan Strait," said Kinmen Deputy Magistrate Yen.
