DOC.HEADLINE: N.T. DOLLAR UP ON TAIPEI FOREX MARKET

TEXT.P: The new Taiwan dollar rose NT$0.007 against the U.S. dollar on the Taipei foreign exchange market Tuesday, closing at 34.602.
The local currency opened Tuesday at 34.592 and was traded between 34.571 and 34.610.
Interbank U.S. dollar trading totaled US$257 million.
Dealers analyzed that basically, the N.T. dollar will not go bearish in the near term because of the weakness of the greenback on international markets.
However, dealers predicted that the local unit will appreciate against the U.S. dollar at a slow pace in the light of the island's general economic climate.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN IMPORTS OF U.S. AGRICULTURAL PRODUCTS IN DECLINE

TEXT.P: Taiwan was the sixth-biggest market for U.S. agricultural products during the first half of the year, with total purchases of US$986 million, according to the latest statistics released by the U.S Department of Agriculture.

The statistics show that the total export value of U.S. agricultural products in the first sixth months of 2001 reached US$26.29 billion, an increase of 5 percent compared with the same period of 2000.

Taiwan purchases of U.S. agricultural products in the first two quarters of this year declined 8.2 percent in value compared with the figure registered for the same period of 2000, while mainland China's agricultural purchases from the United States hit US$1.1 billion -- an increase of 40.3 percent -- to make it the fifth-biggest importer of U.S. agricultural products in the same period.
Taiwan ranked the fifth-biggest market for U.S. agricultural products in 2000. The latest figures represent the first decrease in three years.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN RESIDENTS GENERATING LESS GARBAGE: DOH

TEXT.P: Thanks to a recycling campaign, the people of Taiwan are now producing less garbage, with per capita garbage production falling from 1.07 kilograms per day in 1999 to 0.939 kilograms in 2000, the Cabinet-level Department of Health (DOH) reported Tuesday.
DOH officials said the nearly 10 percent fall was the first negative growth of its kind in a decade and they attributed the progress to the recycling efforts of local governments across the island.

According to the officials, garbage generation was largely reduced in Taipei, Kaohsiung and Taichung cities, thanks to a series of measures, including garbage recycling and classification, carried out in Taiwan's three largest cities. They added that Taiwan's garbage will be further reduced after all counties and cities on the island begin promoting similar complementary measures.

About 8.45 million metric tons of garbage were collected in Taiwan in 1999, 219,000 metric tons of which, or 2.6 percent of the total, were recycled. With the implementation of the recycling campaign at the beginning of 2000, Taiwan cleaned up 7.88 million metric tons of garbage last year, with the recycling rate rising to 6.5 percent, or 470,000 metric tons, according to DOH tallies.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC DEFENSE MINISTRY MUM ON SUBMARINE REPORT

TEXT.P: The Ministry of National Defense (MND) declined to comment Tuesday on a U.S. magazine report that Taiwan can build diesel-powered submarines on its own, so long as it can acquire certain sophisticated components and parts.
MND officials said it is the ministry's established policy to refrain from talking about weaponry acquisition affairs in public.

A report carried in the latest issue of Defense News weekly quoted former Taiwan defense officials as having said that if Taiwan can receive certain technical assistance and precision components and parts, it would be able to build diesel-fueled submarines.
The report further said that the U.S. military has formed a special task force to study how to help the Republic of China acquire new diesel submarines.

The U.S. government approved a US$4 billion arms sales package to Taiwan earlier this year, including 12 P-3C Orion reconnaissance aircraft, four Kidd-class frigates and eight diesel submarines. However, the United States has not produced diesel submarines for many years and countries that still produce this kind of warship, including Germany and the Netherlands, have rejected proposals to cooperate with the United States in providing Taiwan with the submarines.

Responding to the report, military sources said that although Taiwan's defense technology has reached a certain level and its state-owned China Shipbuilding Corp. (CSBC) is capable of building warships, Taiwan would still have to obtain foreign technology transfers and would have to import certain sophisticated components and parts, if it wants to build submarines on its own.
A military expert, who preferred anonymity, also said that although the CSBC has experience in building warships for the ROC Navy, its warship-building capabilities still need upgrading.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT, NP TIE-UP FOR YEAR-END ELECTIONS

TEXT.P: The opposition Kuomintang (KMT) and its ally, the New Party (NP), entered a cooperation pact Tuesday by agreeing to jointly field a candidate in the Taipei County magistrate election -- expected to be one of the most hotly contested battlefields in Taiwan's year-end elections.

KMT Chairman Lien Chan met with NP head Hsieh Chi-tah Tuesday after months of seeking an integration of members and supporters of the KMT and its two splinter parties -- the People First Party (PFP) and the NP -- to form a so-called "pan-blue force" that will cooperate rather than compete against each other in the year-end legislative, mayoral and county chief elections.

PFP Chairman James Soong announced last Friday that the PFP will not enter candidates for the Taipei and Kaohsiung County magistrate elections as a result of the KMT's reluctance to cooperate with his party with regard to candidate selection.

Soong, formerly a Taiwan provincial governor and a KMT secretary-general, said he was saddened by the KMT grassroots party workers' reluctance to throw their support behind any of the PFP-proposed candidates for the mayoral and magistrate elections scheduled for Dec. 1.

On Tuesday, Lien and Hsieh reached a consensus that the KMT and the NP will jointly decide by conducting a public opinion poll on which candidate from the "pan-blue force" will be fielded to run for the seat of the Taipei county chief.
The poll results will be used to gauge which candidate -- either the KMT's Lin Chih-chia or the NP's Wang Chien-shuan -- has the best chance of winning.
After the meeting, Hsieh said the KMT-NP cooperative formula can be applied to all cities and counties around the island to choose the best possible candidates from the "pan-blue force."

According to Wang Chih-kang, a KMT spokesman, Lien still pegs high expectations on the scenario that the KMT, the PFP and the NP will cooperate to as to allow them to compete shoulder-to-shoulder against the ruling Democratic Progressive Party in the crucial elections.

Both Lin and Wang support the idea of finalizing the candidate through an opinion poll of KMT and NP supporters, but they ruled out the possibility of teaming up with someone else to run for deputy Taipei county chief if they were both rejected as county chief material by the poll respondents.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN DELEGATION INVITED TO INTERNATIONAL LABOR MEET
DOC.DATELINE: Bangkok, Aug. 28 (CNA) (By Kuo Fang-chi and Elisa Kao)

TEXT.P: The Taipei-based Chinese Federation of Labor (CFL) attended the Asian regional meeting of the International Labor Organization (ILO) held Tuesday in Bangkok, mainly because of its work to protect foreign laborers in Taiwan.

CFL President Lin Hui-kuan led the Taiwan delegation to the meeting in the name of observer of the International Confederation of Free Trade Union (ICFTU). It was the first time that a Taiwan labor group has been invited to participate in a meeting of the ILO, which is an affiliate of the United Nations.

The CFL's participation in the meeting did not meet with any objection from Beijing, as it attended as an observer of a non-U.N. organization. Beijing opposes Taiwan's participation in any international organization in which sovereignty is a prerequisite.
Lin told CNA that the CFL gained high appraisal in its efforts to protect the rights of Thai, Filipino, Indonesian and Vietnamese workers in Taiwan.
Taiwan is the only country in Asia that allows foreign laborers to enjoy the same salary levels as their local counterparts, which elevates its image in international society, Lin added.
He indicated that although Taiwan is not a U.N. member, it has signed two international agreements related to labor affairs and abides by all the regulations stipulated by the ILO.

Recently, Lin added, the Republic of China government was about to eliminate the minimum wage requirement for foreign workers mainly due to pressure from the business sector. However, through the protests of local labor groups, foreign laborers' working rights were protected, bringing extra attention to the power of Taiwan labor groups.
Lin noted that Taiwan is one of the ICFTU founders and that its participation in the ILO can serve as a model for Taiwan to take part in international activities.
Lin and his delegation are scheduled to return home Sept. 1 after the quadrennial meeting.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC BEATS SINGAPORE AT PAN PACIFIC JUNIOR LEAGUE BASEBALL TOURNEY
DOC.DATELINE: Manila, Aug. 28 (CNA) (By Philip Liu & Ed Chen)

TEXT.P: Chinese Taipei blanked Singapore 3-0 Tuesday at the first Pan Pacific Cup Junior League Baseball Championship Tournament presently under way in the Philippines.
The Chinese Taipei nine's victory took them through to the semi-finals and they will take on the winner of a Japan-Philippines game Wednesday.
In another game played that day, the Philippines edged out Japan 3-2. The Philippines is fielding two teams at the competition.

The tourney, which is being held at the Subic Bay Softball Diamond, was originally to have been attended by 11 teams representing Japan, the Republic of China, Australia, Mexico, the United States, South Korea, Singapore, Malaysia, Indonesia and the Philippines.
However, only the ROC, Japan, Singapore and the host Philippines made the four-day competition.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINESE TAIPEI WINS TENNIS BRONZE IN WOMEN'S DOUBLES AT UNIVERSIADE
DOC.DATELINE: Beijing, Aug. 28 (CNA) (By Lee An-tung & Ed Chen)

TEXT.P: Chinese Taipei's Lee Hui-tze and Weng Tze-ting were beaten 2-0 by South Korea Tuesday in the women's tennis doubles semi-finals at the World Universiade Games presently under way in Beijing.
The loss meant they had to settle for a bronze medal, shared with a French team.
In the women's singles, Universiade gold medallist Lee Hui-tze advanced to the semi-finals after blanking Liu Nan-nan of mainland China 6-2, 6-2. Lee will take on a British rival Wednesday.
Her team-mate Wang I-ting was not so successful, however, falling to a 2-0 defeat by Li Na of mainland China.
In men's table tennis, Chiang Peng-lung and Chang Yen-su advanced to the semi-finals in the men's doubles after eliminating their Dutch and Bosnian rivals.
The Chinese Taipei delegation has so far chalked up one silver and two bronze medals.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC, VIETNAM COOPERATE TO BUST CROSS-BORDER DRUG TRAFFICKING RING

TEXT.P: Law enforcement officers in the Republic of China and Vietnam have recently cooperated in breaking a cross-border drug trafficking ring, the Criminal Investigation Bureau (CIB) said Tuesday.
According to the bureau, a mastermind of the ring, identified as Liu Kuo-hsing, was arrested in Ho Chi Minh City by Vietnamese police authorities early this month.

Quoting Vietnamese sources, a CIB official said Liu had extensive connections with drug trafficking rings and dealers in Vietnam. "Vietnamese police have detained Liu for further questioning and they have agreed to repatriate him to Taiwan after they finish their questioning," said the official.

Acting on tips from international sources, local police managed to nab several drug traffickers from Vietnam earlier this month. Initial investigations show that the drug traffickers were commissioned by Liu to smuggle contraband narcotics into Taiwan.

In the past, drug trafficking rings used to smuggle illegal drugs from the Golden Triangle to Taiwan via Thailand and mainland China, but as police now monitor this trafficking channel closely, the CIB official said, Liu's ring had moved its operation center to Vietnam in recent years and had changed its transport route.

"The ring first secured narcotics in mainland China's Yunan province and then transported the goods to Vietnam by land for airlifting to Taiwan via Hong Kong and Macau," the official explained, adding that the ring had commissioned Taiwan tourists to smuggle drugs into Taiwan in small installments by hiding them in specially designed footwear and suits.
CIB investigations show that the ring had used this new trafficking formula to smuggle drugs into Taiwan more than 10 times.

The official said Vietnam apparently has become a new springboard for Taiwan-destined drug trafficking. "As criminal rings tend to use individual tourists to help smuggle drugs into Taiwan in small installments, it's not easy to bust them without tip-offs," he admitted.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPOWER TO BUY COAL FROM MAINLAND CHINA THROUGH LONG-TERM CONTRACTS

TEXT.P: Taiwan Power Company (Taipower) will benefit from a relaxed mainland investment policy, as the state-run firm has gained approval from the Republic of China government to purchase coal from mainland China to fuel its electricity generators.

Taipower President Wu Ching-chi said the company has been allowed to purchase more than one million tons of coal from the mainland for power generation after having recently signed two year-long contracts with mainland Chinese state-owned coal enterprises.
It was the first time that Taipower had inked long-term contracts for purchasing coal from the mainland, as it had previously only been able to buy mainland coal on an order-by-order basis, he noted.
Wu pointed out that transport costs from the mainland are cheaper than those from Australia, which has long been a major supplier of coal for Taiwan.

He added that mainland Chinese coal will be more competitive after direct transport links are set up between Taiwan and the mainland and revealed that Taipower is considering new contracts with the mainland side should their deliveries prove stable and timely.

Wu pointed out, however, that the ratio of mainland Chinese coal cannot surpass 20 percent of the company's total consumption as fuel diversification rules stipulate that the percentage of coal purchased from other countries cannot exceed 35 percent of the total, which has recently been revised downward from the previous level of 40 percent.
Taipower currently needs 22 million tons of coal for power generation per year, so the company can buy three million tons of coal from mainland China based on the 20 percent ceiling, he explained.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. CONGRESSMAN ARRIVES IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: U.S. Republican Party whip in the House of Representatives Tom Delay arrived in Taipei Tuesday for a three-day visit.

Delay (R-Texas) met President Chen Shui-bian and entertained him with dining and baseball during Chen's transit stop in Houston on his way home from a visit to the Republic of China's diplomatic allies in Central America in May.

Delay and his delegation will meet Chen Wednesday, after which Chen will accompany them to the National Palace Museum -- the first time that Chen will have accompanied official guests on visits to tourist spots and a demonstration of the importance that Chen attaches to Delay's visit.
Delay will also listen to a brief report from the American Institute in Taiwan and will lunch with ROC ambassador-at-large Jeffrey Koo.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PRESIDENT SUPPORTS KMT-INITIATED CROSS-PARTY NEGOTIATIONS

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian is happy to see the convening of cross-party negotiations initiated by opposition Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan, Presidential Secretary-General You Hsi-kun said Tuesday.
"The president is not only happy to see the convening of the inter-party negotiations to be attended by the chiefs of all parties, but he will also extend his all-out support," You told reporters.
You said that the consensus reached at the just-concluded Economic Development Advisory Conference (EDAC) proved far better than originally expected.
"It has not only established a new strategy for the development of the country's economy, but has also laid the foundation for cooperation between the parties," he noted.
You said that he understood Lien and People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong want to convene cross-party negotiations after the EDAC, and added that Chen "is happy to support the plan."
However, he went on, the Presidential Office could not make a "concrete response" to the proposal at present as it "does not understand the concept" of the inter-party talks.

If the nature of the talks is defined as inter-party negotiations, You said that they would be better represented by party leaders because Chen is not a member of the Democratic Progressive Party Central Standing Committee.

He went on to point out that if the talks are designed to implement the agreements reached at the EDAC, it seems appropriate to consider the participation of the premier, vice premier and relevant Cabinet ministers, as they will be responsible for the implementation of the EDAC-approved proposals.

In this regard, Kuo Yao-chi, director of the Public Affairs Office under the Presidential Office, said that the president is glad to see the development of all matters which are helpful to the harmony of the parties and the country's economic development.
"If the president's presence at the inter-party negotiations will produce constructive significance, he will be happy to attend," Kuo stated.
KMT spokesman Wang Chih-kang said a day earlier that his party hopes that the cross-party negotiations can be held within two weeks to discuss the implementation of the proposals reached at the EDAC.

The KMT's idea is to bring together the chiefs of the KMT, the PFP, the DPP and the New Party to the inter-party talks, while excluding the participation of the newly established Taiwan Solidarity Union, which is not represented at the Legislative Yuan.

As DPP Chairman Frank Hsieh is slated to leave Taiwan Sept. 1 for a week-long foreign trip and PFP Chairman Soong is presently in the United States, the inter-party talks are likely to be held in the middle of September.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC ROLLER SKATERS TO COMPETE IN WORLD CUP

TEXT.P: Pan Li-ling and Pan I-chin, who won two gold medals, two silvers and two bronzes in roller skating at the just-concluded Sixth World Games, are scheduled to leave Taipei Thursday to train for a week in France before taking part in the roller skating world cup in France Sept. 8-16.
Although they bear the same surname, the two skaters are not related but have been friends since kindergarten.

They will also take part in the first Asian Cup Roller Skating Competition scheduled to be held in the southeastern Taiwan city of Taitung at the end of September, bringing together competitors from mainland China, Japan and South Korea, as well as Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRC STEPS UP DEPLOYMENT OF MISSILES TARGETING TAIWAN: PENTAGON
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Aug. 28 (CNA) (By Jay Chen and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Mainland China has stepped up its deployments of short-range missiles opposite Taiwan, with the latest number of missiles within range of Taiwan exceeding 350, the Washington Times reported Tuesday.
U.S. Deputy Defense Secretary Paul Wolfowitz was quoted by the paper as describing the mainland Chinese missile buildup as "destabilizing."

New missile deployments were discovered recently by U.S. intelligence agencies at Yongan in Fujian Province and at Jiangshan, located about 384 kilometers southwest of Shanghai. Yongan is the base used by mainland Chinese military forces to test-fire missiles, while Jiangshan is an existing base disclosed for the first time as a missile site, according to the Washington Times report.
The U.S. intelligence agencies discovered that mainland China added more than 30 new CSS-6 and CSS-7 missiles within range of Taiwan recently, according to the report.
The mainland military is adding 50 new missiles a year at the current rate, the report indicated.
"They (the PRC military) have been doing that steadily for a number of years now," Wolfowitz said in an interview with the Washington Times.

The missile deployments contradict mainland China's commitment to a 1982 communique with the United States that says Beijing's fundamental policy is a "peaceful resolution" of its differences with Taiwan, Wolfowitz said.
"And I don't see that building up your missiles is part of a fundamental policy of peaceful unification," he added.
Any attempt by mainland China to intimidate Taiwan will fail, he continued, because the United States is firmly resolved to prevent the forcible reunification of the island with the mainland.
The latest deployments put the total number of short-range missile within range of Taiwan at 350, an increase of 50 missiles since the spring, the Washington Times report said.

The PRC has three other short-range missile bases within range of Taiwan. They include the missile brigade headquarters at Leping and one at Nanping, about 368 kilometers from Taiwan, the Washington Times quoted a U.S. military intelligence agency as stating.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CHAIRMAN: U.S. ARMS SALES SHOULD NOT BECOME ISSUE-MAKING LICENSE

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan said here Tuesday that U.S. arms sales to Taiwan "should not become an issue-making license."

Lien also said that the two sides of Taiwan Strait should open consultations on the basis of the so-called "1992 consensus" to restart dialogue and exchanges so as to secure a stable cross-strait situation.
Lien made the remarks while meeting members of the Asian fact-finding Mission of the U.S. Conservative Caucus, a U.S. think tank.

Lien also called on the United States to avoid being biased to either side in its relations with Taipei and Beijing, and he noted that positive cross-strait dialogue and exchanges correspond to U.S. policy.

Lien said that the Taiwan Strait and the Korean peninsula have become two major potential flashpoints in Northeast Asia. This situation, he went on, not only affects the security and safety of Taiwan but also that of the Asian region and even the whole world.

Touching on the rapid economic development in mainland China, Lien said that Taiwan should deal with this problem realistically. He added that although mainland China has maintained rapid economic growth in past years, the situation there is very complicated because Beijing faces daily-widening gaps between rich and poor and between coastal and inland areas, as well as increasing unemployment.

He further pointed out that this situation provides Taiwan, the United States and other Asian countries with a chance to help the mainland China transform itself into a stable nation through economic, cultural and social exchanges.
Lien stressed that peace across the Taiwan Strait cannot be built on military confrontation and that the cross-strait problem stems chiefly from differences in the social systems on either side.

He noted that Taiwan has always purchased U.S. arms for defensive purposes and added that the arms are used to maintain the security of the Taiwan Strait, not to provoke Beijing. He stressed that the KMT treasures greatly the U.S.-Taiwan relationship.
Lien also reiterated that the "eventual goal" of the KMT's mainland China policy is to build a democratic, free and equal unified China.

He also said that Taiwan's peaceful transition of power has successfully exploded the myth that democracy is unsuitable for Asian people. It has also proved that democratic values are universal and that time is on the side of the Chinese people.

DOC.HEADLINE: LABOR COUNCIL TO DETER MASS LAYOFFS BY MANUFACTURERS

TEXT.P: Domestic manufacturers who lay their laborers off illegally and en masse might face government administrative penalties, including a ban on leaving the country, sources from the Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) said Tuesday.

Manufacturers who dismiss their workers en masse in contravention of government regulations will be dealt with under the terms of a CLA-initiated anti-mass layoff bill, which is expected to be approved by the Executive Yuan next month, CLA officials said.

According to the terms of the bill, violators will be liable to penalties ranging from a ban on leaving the country, sanctions on the manufacturers' schedules to become a listed company or an over-the-counter company, new restrictions on applications for hiring foreign workers from abroad, and harsher demands for their applications to invest in or relocate their operations to mainland China.

The bill, which will be part of the Republic of China Administrative Process Law, stipulates that manufacturers should inform their labor unions or employee representatives 90 days before any mass layoff takes effect.

The manufacturers should also inform the relevant local government at the same time and should provide a comprehensive layoff plan indicating reasons, timetable, number of people involved and criteria of the layoff, according to the anti-mass layoff bill.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN, MAINLAND CHINA MAY COOPERATE IN OIL EXPLORATION

TEXT.P: Oil companies in Taiwan and mainland China are evaluating the viability of joint exploration of potential oil reserves in the Taiwan Strait, a Taiwan oil official said Tuesday.

Chiu Chi-hsiung, vice president of Taiwan's state-run Chinese Petroleum Corp. (CPC), confirmed that CPC and mainland China's China National Offshore Oil Co. (CNOOC) have been cooperating for years in geological oil research in maritime areas close to Chaozhou and Shantou districts, Guangdong Province, and in Taiwan's southern Tainan Basin.
Chiu added that as the geological research shows that there are potential oil reserves there, the two companies are considering expending more capital to do real exploration.
According to the official, exploring for a single well costs around US$10 million.

Since the Republic of China government still has not relaxed its "no haste, be patient" policy that restricts local investment in mainland China, the two companies may set up a new company in a third place such as Singapore to handle the exploration work.
Chiu said the project will be sent to the Cabinet for approval, after which, the two companies might sign a contract to undertake further exploration.
The CPC official said the new contract will be signed on the basis of equality and mutual benefit and will not involve issues of sovereignty.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIT OFFICIAL: WISDOM REQUIRED TO HANDLE `1992 CONSENSUS'

TEXT.P: Raymond Burghardt, director of the Taipei Office of the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT), said Tuesday that "wisdom is required" for both Taiwan and mainland China to handle the problem regarding the so-called "1992 consensus."
The consensus said by some to have been reached in 1992 discussions allows both sides of the Taiwan Strait to make their own interpretations as to the meaning of "one China."

It formed the basis for Taipei's Straits Exchange Foundation and Beijing's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait to engage in quasi-official negotiations until July 1999, when bilateral dialogue came to a complete standstill.

Burghardt, a veteran diplomat who was about to assume a new post as U.S. ambassador to Vietnam, was asked his opinions on the development of cross-strait relations during a meeting with members of the American Chamber of Commerce in Taipei.
He said that the so-called "1992 consensus" was not a "consensus," but an "agreement" reached by the two sides.

As Taiwan and the mainland were able to discuss pragmatic issues by shelving their controversies through the 1992 interactions, Burghardt pointed out that "the two sides of the Taiwan Strait need wisdom to reopen negotiations based on that foundation."

Talking about the mainland's military threat to Taiwan, the AIT official noted that the mainland is unlikely to take military action against Taiwan, saying that such action would hurt the mainland's international image and that Beijing is aware that the United States is obliged to provide Taiwan with defensive arms required for the island's security.

DOC.HEADLINE: HONING ENGLISH SKILLS TOPS WISH-LISTS OF TAIWAN OFFICE WORKERS

TEXT.P: Honing their English skills is top of the wish-list of Taiwan office workers, according to the results of a recent online public opinion poll released Tuesday.

The poll, conducted by Jardine Fleming Taiwan Investment and Trust, found that some 66 percent of the office workers polled in Taiwan most want to improve their command of English, while 56 percent most want to learn about financial investment and 44 percent most want to improve their computer skills and knowledge.

According to the poll, which secured 1,836 valid responses, 28 percent of Internet surfers who are also office workers say their major monthly expenses are buying funds or securities, followed by 23 percent who spend most of their money on their mortgages.

The poll also found that 51 percent of the respondents choose to buy funds as their number one financial investment tool, followed by 47.4 percent who invest in the stock market and 47.3 percent who put their money into time-deposit savings.

DOC.HEADLINE: 7 FOREIGN TEAMS FOR ASIAN CUP BIG LEAGUE BASEBALL ARRIVE IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: Seven foreign baseball teams arrived in Taipei Tuesday for the 2001 Asian Cup Big League Baseball Tournament that will be held in Taipei Aug. 30-Sept. 4.
The preliminary rounds of the competition will be held at the Hsinchuang and the Tienmu baseball stadiums.
The teams in Group A are Chinese Taipei, Japan, South Korea and Australia, while the teams in Group B are India, Indonesia, Thailand and the Philippines.
Eiichiro Yamamoto, president of the Asian Baseball Association, will preside over an executive meeting of the association and hold a press conference Wednesday.
Chen Hsien-jung, chief coach of the Chinese Taipei team, will also meet the media Wednesday to report on the training of the host team.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINESE TAIPEI WINS TABLE TENNIS BRONZE AT UNIVERSIADE
DOC.DATELINE: Beijing, Aug. 28 (CNA) (By Lee An-tung & Ed Chen)

TEXT.P: Mainland China's Liu Giozheng and Zhang Yung beat Chinese Taipei's Chiang Peng-lung and Chang Yen-su 2-1 Tuesday in the men's table tennis doubles at the World Universiade Games now being held in Beijing.
The defeat meant that the Taiwan players had to settle for a bronze medal in the event, share with Japan.
In women's table tennis, meanwhile, Chen Chiu-dan and Tsui Hsiu-li blanked their Russian rivals 2-0, while Liu Feng-yun and Pan Li-chun edged out Brazil 2-0, propelling both pairs to the final 16.
In the men's table tennis singles, Chuang Chih-yen and Yang Meng-suen advanced to the final 16, while Chang Yen-su was eliminated.
In the women's table tennis singles, Tsui Hsiu-li was thwarted in her bid to reach the semi-final by mainland China's Tieh Yana.
In volleyball, Chinese Taipei edged out Portugal 3-1 in a consolation game to take 21st place overall.
Chinese Taipei will take on Canada Wednesday to vie for seventh place in women's volleyball competition.
In women's basketball, Chinese Taipei will vie for ninth place Wednesday in a game against Sweden.
Chinese Taipei has so far chalked up one silver medal and three bronzes at the games.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOTC DENIES MAINLAND CHINESE TOURISTS TO ARRIVE IN OCTOBER

TEXT.P: A Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) official denied a legislator's claim Tuesday that the first batch of mainland Chinese tourists is expected to arrive in Taiwan in October under a pilot plan to open the island to mainland tourists.

Vice Minister of Transportation and Communications Ho Cheng-tan said that presently there is no concrete timetable to open the island's tourism market to mainland people, contradicting Legislator Chang Ching-fang.
Ho also expressed opposition to a suggestion in the mainland Chinese media that cross-Taiwan Strait private organizations should hold talks on the matter.

He pointed out that the MOTC has indeed completed preparations for opening Taiwan's tourism market to mainland Chinese people, but stressed that talks on the issue should be conducted between Taipei's quasi-official Straits Exchange Foundation and its Beijing counterpart, the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait.

Meanwhile, the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) denied a report that it has tacitly consented to talks between privately run local tourist associations and the Taiwan Affairs Office of mainland China's State Council on measures related to visits to Taiwan by mainland tourists.
MAC officials also denied telling Chang that it was going to implement the pilot plan.

The officials further said that the MAC will respect the consensus on the plan reached at the plenary session of the Economic Development Advisory Conference and that it will map out related measures on the issue according to the Executive Yuan's instructions.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOTC TO EASE LIMIT ON FOREIGN CAPITAL IN TELECOMMUNICATIONS

TEXT.P: Minister of Transport and Communications Yeh Chu-lan said Tuesday that the current 20 percent ceiling on the proportional ratio of direct foreign capital in the telecommunications industry will be inncreased to 49 percent.
Yeh's made he remarks at an MOTC meeting to discuss how to ease limitations on the foreign capital in the telecommunications industry.

According to the current telecommunications statute, direct foreign investment in the telecommunications industry cannot surpass 20 percent, while direct and indirect foreign investment combined cannot surpass 60 percent.

The MOTC's Department of Post and Telecommunications had offered Yeh a choice of three increases -- 10 percent, 20 percent and 29 percent -- and Yeh selected the highest in order to lure more foreign investment to the local telecommunications industry.
The MOTC will submit a draft of an amendment bill to the Cabinet for approval and will also try to win support from the Legislative Yuan to amend the statute by the end of this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies on Wednesday are as follows:
The China Times:
The Cabinet is expected to approve the land value increment tax cut at its weekly meeting today.
The United Daily News:
The Cabinet is likely to pass the proposal to halve the land value increment tax.
The Liberty Times:
Water disputes escalates between Taipei City and Taipei County governments.
The Taiwan Daily:
President Chen is scheduled to pay visits to top leaders of various parties in the near future, says a close aide.
The Central Daily News:
Kuomintang and New Party agree to hold a public opinion poll in selection of a common candidate for Taipei County chief election.
The China Post:
Premier angered over policy remarks.
The Taiwan News:
Taipei County's Su asks for agreed water quota.
The Taipei Times:
Cabinet to take on property taxation.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, Aug. 29, or the 11th day of the seventh month of the Year of the Snake according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1475: The Truce of Picquigny is signed, under which King Edward IV of England agrees to withdraw his invading troops from France in return for gold and a yearly pension.
1831: Michael Faraday, British physicist and chemist, successfully demonstrates the first electrical transformer in London. He also proposed the field theory later developed by Maxwell and Einstein.
1842: The Treaty of Nanking is signed by Britain and the Ching Court, ending the Opium War. Among the treaty's stipulations were the opening of five ports to British trade and the ceding of Hong Kong to England.
1835: John Batman and associates buy land from Australian Aborigines and officially establish Melbourne.
1885: The first motorcycle is patented in Germany by Gottlieb Daimler, German engineer and pioneer automobile manufacturer who produced the first high-speed internal-combustion engine.
1910: Japan takes complete control of Korea and begins governing it as a colony to benefit its own interests.
1926: Nepal abolishes slavery, freeing some 55,000 slaves.
1929: The giant airship Graf Zeppelin returns to Lakehurst, New Jersey, after completing a 21-day trip around the world.
1932: A Chinese volunteer army in northeast China launches a surprise attack at Shenyang (Mukden), capital of Liaoning province, during the night. They burned the airport and destroyed 27 Japanese military aircraft.
1945: Allied forces land in Japan following Japan's surrender.
1945: The Nationalist government appoints Chen Yi as governor of Taiwan following the island's retrocession to China after 50 years of Japanese occupation.
1945: Chiang Kai-shek, chairman of the Nationalist government, receives Chinese Communist Party leader Mao Tse-tung to discuss such issues as national unity and reconstruction.
1948: Thailand expels some 5,000 ethnic Chinese.
1949: The Soviet Union tests its first atomic bomb.
1958: Michael Jackson, American pop mega-star, is born. His hit albums such as "Thriller" and "Bad" are backed by equally successful videos.
1962: A sword belonging to Lee Siu-cheng, one of the leaders who launched the Taiping Rebellion against the Ching court 97 years ago, is returned to mainland authorities by a Briton.
1969: Chiang Cheng-Tao, a mainland Chinese musician who defected to France, arrives in Taipei.
1974: The Republic of China and Haiti conclude a trade agreement.
1975: A nova in the Cygnus constellation is discovered by the Taipei Observatory.
1982: Ingrid Bergman, Swedish star of stage and screen who won Oscars for both "Gaslight" and "Anastasia," dies on her 67th birthday at her London home.
1987: The ROC Little League baseball team wins the world title by beating the US West team, 21-1.
1998: A Cubana de Aviacion Tupolev airplane crashes after taking off from Ecuador's international airport in Quito, killing 81 people.
1999: The New Party formally recruits writer-critic Li Ao as the party's candidate for the 2000 presidential election in a meeting of party officials.
2000: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. Chairman Morris Chang is ranked as the most investment-worthy entrepreneur of the year in the latest issue of Smart Magazine, a local financial publication.
2000: ROC Premier Tang Fei meets with a visiting delegation of Democratic Party dietmen from Japan and expresses hope that they will try to promote peace in Asia.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "The intelligence which comes from the direct apprehension of truth is intuition. The apprehension of truth which comes from the exercise of intelligence is the result of education."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK PRICES UP BY 140.31 POINTS

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) gained ground on Wednesday with the benchmark weighted price index moving up 140.31 points to close at 4,508.69.
Market turnover amounted to NT$65.22 billion (US$1.89 billion).

DOC.HEADLINE: CABINET APPROVES PROPOSAL TO HALVE LAND VALUE INCREMENT TAX

TEXT.P: The Cabinet approved a proposal Wednesday to halve the land value increment tax, a capital gains tax for property transactions, for two years.
The Cabinet passed the proposal, strongly advocated by major commerce and industry associations amid the lingering domestic economic doldrums, at its weekly meeting.

The proposal is pending approval by the Legislative Yuan. Premier Chang Chun-hsiung directed the Ministry of Finance (MOF) and the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) to consult with the legislature to facilitate the implementation of the tax-cut proposal.

As the land value increment tax is basically a local tax, Premier Chang said the central government will reimburse local-level governments for their financial losses resulting from the proposed two-year tax cut.
Meanwhile, Chang ordered the MOF and the DGBAS to draft revisions to the existing law to authorize the government to float state bonds to raise funds to compensate local-level governments.
Chang pointed out that the two-year reduction of the land value increment tax was a "majority opinion" adopted at the just-concluded Economic Development Advisory Conference.

Quoting an MOF analysis, the premier said although the proposed tax reduction may result in a decrease in government tax revenues, the move is expected to help buoy the recession-hit local property market and stimulate overall economic development.
Against this backdrop, Chang said, the Cabinet has decided to accept the proposal to slash the land value increment tax by 50 percent for two years.

The Cabinet's decision immediately drew mixed reaction from various social quarters. While bankers and business executives generally welcomed the proposal, some opposition lawmakers claimed that the proposal was an expedient measure in favor of large business groups at the expense of ordinary people.
The main opposition Kuomintang (KMT), which controls a majority in the current legislature, generally supports the two-year, 50-percent cut in the land value increment tax.
KMT Vice Chairman Vincent Siew, also a former premier, said the tax reduction would help stimulate the slumping property market and help local banks resolve serious bad debts issues.

"We believe that it could be an effective measure to cope with our current economic woes," Siew said, adding that in the long run, the government should take advantage of the "two-year reprieve" to overhaul Taiwan's taxation system.

Meanwhile, the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) legislative caucus said it basically backs the proposal. But the caucus' secretary-general, Tsai Huang-lan, said some DPP lawmakers still oppose the proposal. "We hope that MOF and DGBAS official will explain whether it is suitable to issue state bonds to make up for financial losses from the proposed tax cut," he noted.

Liu Tai-ying, chairman of China Development Industrial Bank, said he fully supports the tax reduction proposal because it would boost property transactions and thus help local banks lower their non-performing loan ratios.
Chuang Meng-han, an associate professor at Tamkang University, said Taiwan is the only country in the world that has implemented the land value increment tax system.
"It's an unreasonable taxation system," Chuang said, adding that the government should replace the tax with a "property transaction income tax."
In contrast, the tiny opposition New Party voiced it strong opposition to the tax-cut proposal.
New Party legislative caucus whip Ying Chih-hung said at a news conference that the tax-cut proposal was just a "majority opinion" of the Aug. 24-26 economic conference, not a "consensus opinion."

"I simply can't understand why the Cabinet should want to rush the decision to put the proposal into practice," Ying said, adding that the quick move signified that the current Democratic Progressive Party-led administration is leaning toward large business groups at the expense of social justice.

Ying said Taiwan needs a sweeping taxation reform, not a biased tax cut. He said the New Party will do its utmost to block the passage of the proposal in the legislature, which will open its new session in mid-September.

DOC.HEADLINE: LESSONS FROM SWISSAIR FLIGHT 111 TRAGEDY: IMPROVE WIRING SYSTEMS

TEXT.P: Canada's Transportation Safety Board looking into the crash of Swissair flight 111 three years ago issued three recommendations Tuesday to improve airline safety, saying current fire prevention systems are not good enough.

The jet went down on Sept. 2, 1998 in the Atlantic Ocean near Peggy's Cove, Nova Scotia, killing all 229 people on the flight. The board found evidence of fire in the ceiling of the plane, near the cockpit. One possible source could have been damaged wires in the aircraft's in-flight entertainment system, according to investigators.
The Canadian investigators' recommendations include toughening the flammability standards for all materials used in airplanes, not just walls and seat cushions as is currently the case.

"Often in places where there are few, if any, defenses in terms of fire detection and suppression, you can find various materials that can sustain a fire. And these materials don't just burn; they can also emit toxic gases and excessive amounts of smoke," said board chairperson Benoit Bouchard.
The board also called for a more stringent certification standard for electrical wires. It said standards should include more realistic testing covering all the ways wires can fail.

Lastly, the board recommended that all systems be evaluated in terms of their impact on an in-flight fire. It noted current systems can aggravate fires in progress, turning a minor scare into a full-blown tragedy.

DOC.HEADLINE: HUMAN RIGHTS WATCH CALLS FOR PROGRAMS TO COMBAT RACIAL DISCRIMINATION

TEXT.P: Human Rights Watch said Tuesday that it expects the upcoming U.N.-sponsored World Conference against Racism to lead to concrete programs to combat racial discrimination around the world.
The U.N. World Conference against Racism will be held in the South African eastern city of Durban from Aug. 31 to Sept. 7.

Human Rights Watch said "racism today is a pervasive problem which affects every society. The organization expects governments to commit to concrete national and global programs to stamp out racism in all its forms."
The human rights organization said "victims of racism around the world expect more than empty talk -- they expect action."

Reed Brody, advocacy director of Human Rights Watch, said in Durban "this meeting needs to offer something to the refugee in Europe who is beaten up simply because he is a 'foreigner,' to the scavenger in India whose low caste prevents him from rising in life, to the Tibetan tortured by (Communist) Chinese police, to the Palestinian under Israeli occupation, and to the African-American child who is three times as likely to live in poverty as her white counterpart."

Human Rights Watch called on the government of India to drop its insistence that the issue of caste discrimination be kept out of the meeting's final declaration, despite an unprecedented international mobilization around the issue.

"More than 250 million people worldwide suffer under a hidden apartheid of segregation, modern-day slavery, and other extreme forms of discrimination because they were born into a marginalized caste," said Smita Narula, senior researcher with Human Rights Watch. "Caste discrimination has been a shameful secret for too long, but an emerging global movement will not let it be hidden any longer."
Human Rights Watch also said it hoped that the conference would:

-- Call for reparations to address the continuing effects of slavery, segregation, and other extreme forms of racism. Human Rights Watch has proposed the creation of truth commissions to examine how a government's past racist practices contribute to contemporary deprivation and to propose methods of redress;

-- Recognize discrimination against refugees, asylum seekers, migrants, and internally displaced persons as a contemporary form of racism and call on governments to reverse practices that discriminate against refugees, asylum seekers, and migrants and to reaffirm their commitment to the U.N. Refugee Convention;
-- Address the issue of racial discrimination in the conferring, denying and stripping of citizenship;
-- Recommend measures to identify and to remedy the racist effect of law or practice in the administration of justice, even in the absence of racist intent.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN ABORIGINES TAKE PART IN UN INDIGENOUS PEOPLE MEETING

TEXT.P: A Taiwan Aboriginal group took part in a United Nation meeting on indigenous peoples and affairs held recently in Geneva, marking the first time that Taiwan indigenous people had attended such a UN gathering.

Six Taiwan Aboriginal people, headed by Yang Chih-wei, chairman of the Association for Taiwan Indigenous People's Policies, participated in the meeting of the UN Working Group of Indigenous People (UNWGIP) held July 25-28.
Yang said his group was able to take part in the UNWGIP meeting by saying that they were from "Formosa," rather than Taiwan.
Over the past four year, Yang said, Taiwan Aboriginal groups have been barred from the annual UNWGIP meeting because of Beijing's intervention.
Yang held a news conference Tuesday to explain the messages that his group delivered at the four-day UNWGIP meeting.
The six Taiwan delegates are from the indigenous tribes of Tsou, Paiwan, Amis, Pazeh and Saidek.

This year's UNWGIP meeting, according to Yang, focused on marginalization, racism, poverty and other pressing problems faced by the estimated 300 million members of indigenous groups throughout the world.
Yang said he found that Taiwan Aboriginal people are different from their counterparts in the rest of the world in how they go about securing their rights and protecting their interests.
In Taiwan, indigenous people rely on the government for their welfare, while indigenous people around the world fight from the grassroots up for their rights and interests.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN REITERATES DESIRE TO ATTEND APEC SUMMIT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian reiterated his desire Wednesday to personally attend this year's informal leadership meeting of the Asia-Pacific Economic cooperation (APEC) forum to be held in Shanghai in late October.
Chen expressed his desire during a meeting with two visiting U.S. congressmen -- Rep. Joseph M. Hoeffel and Rep. Peter King.

Noting that the annual APEC informal leadership meeting could be a "window on opportunity," Chen said it could provide a good setting for the top leaders of the two sides of the Taiwan Strait to sit don to talk.

"I earnestly hopes to attend the meeting in person," Chen said, adding that the Republic of China should enjoy the same rights and should fulfill the same obligations as other APEC members based on the principles of equality.
Chen further said that as a member of the international community and the Global Village, the ROC should be given the opportunity to fulfill its obligations and duties.

APEC, a regional forum dedicated to promote free trade, investment and economic cooperation, is one of the few multilateral organizations that simultaneously admits Taiwan and mainland China. However, due to Beijing's opposition, the ROC president has been barred from attend the annual APEC summit in person and has instead had to name a proxy to attend the meeting on his behalf.

President Chen has on many occasion expressed his strong desire to travel to Shanghai to attend this year's APEC summit, but mainland Chinese authorities have so far turned a cold shoulder to the proposal.

During his talks with the American lawmakers, Chen also said that the just-concluded Economic Development Advisory Conference was the first cross-party conference on national affairs since he assumed office in the ROC's historic transition of power between different political parties in May 2000.

"The Aug. 24-26 conference has managed to reached 322 'consensus proposals' on Taiwan's future economic development and financial reform," Chen said, adding that he was satisfied with the results of the meeting.

Chen told his guests that the meeting has reached consensus on adjusting Taiwan's policies on trade and investment in mainland China. "The meeting marks an important watershed in our national economic development and trade ties with mainland China," he stressed.
Chen said he is convinced that the conference will contribute to the upgrading of Taiwan's industrial development, financial reform, job market and cross-strait relations.
"My administration is now working on concrete measures to implement proposals reached at the conference," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S.: PLA MISSILE DEPLOYMENT A FACTOR IN CROSS-STRAIT BALANCE

TEXT.P: The U.S. government indicated on Tuesday that mainland China's missile threat against Taiwan will be taken into account as the United States evaluates the military balance across the Taiwan Strait.
"China's deployments obviously have an effect on how we see the balance and stability of the situation there," said Richard Boucher, spokesman for the State Department.

Observers say that these remarks seem to indicate that the United States will keep the missile threat in mind when decisions are made on what type of security assistance to provide to Taiwan or on whether to transfer missile defense technology to Taiwan.
Last week, Assistant Secretary of Defense Peter Rodman made a more explicit linkage between the two.
"A reasonable answer to make to them [Beijing] is, 'Well, the missile defense is prompted by the fact that there are missiles,'" he said.
Beijing has expressed their strong objection to U.S. plans for missile defense, and particularly to a shield that would cover Taiwan.

Boucher said that he was restating what U.S. officials had told Beijing on many occasions, including the meetings held between Secretary of State Colin Powell and mainland Chinese leaders during Powell's trip to Beijing in July.

His comments came after the Washington Times reported that the People's Liberation Army has stepped up deployments of short-range missiles opposite Taiwan, with the number of missiles able to reach the island totaling over 350.
The spokesman would not discuss the details of any information that the United States may have on these deployments.

DOC.HEADLINE: INDIGENOUS ACTRESS ANNOUNCES BID TO RUN FOR LEGISLATIVE SEAT

TEXT.P: Comely local movie and television actress Chin Su-mei announced Wednesday her bid to run for a seat in the Legislative Yuan representing indigenous people of Taiwan.

Attired in a traditional ceremonial Atayal costume for women, Chin said at a news conference marking the launch of her campaign that she will run as an independent, rather than representing the opposition People First Party as observers had previously speculated.

Chin said she would add her Atayal mother's maiden surname of Kao to her name for the election, which she described as a "gateway" for her to fight for the rights and interests of her indigenous people.
She will be the first indigenous woman to enter the legislative elections in Taiwan history.
The news conference kicked off a series of campaign drive activities, which include the drinking of millet wine -- a traditional drink for all indigenous people around the island.
Chin was accompanied by her sister and members of the Taiwan Entertainment Business Association during the news conference.

Chin would become a Republic of China legislator representing Aboriginal people if she wins 12,000 votes or more to beat seven other rivals. Altogether, 11 Aboriginal people have entered the December legislative elections, which have four seats up for grasps exclusively for Aborigines.

Chin gained fame as an actress eight years ago when she was cast as the leading man's girlfriend in Oscar-winning director Ang Lee's feature film "The Wedding Banquet," which won a top award at the Berlin Film Festival in 1993.
Chin once ran her own wedding studio in Taipei. The studio, located on Chungshan North Road, was destroyed by fire several years ago. She never reopened the business.
Earlier this year, after recovering from cancer surgery, she started a cancer relief foundation to help cancer patients and their families.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Shares prices opened low but closed higher on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Wednesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 140.31 points to close at 4,508.69.

Affected by a plunge in U.S. stock prices, the bourse opened at 4,350.91, but began to go up later due to reports on a Cabinet decision to halve the land value increment tax for two years. The index fluctuated between 4,508.69 and 4,342.01 during trading.

A total of 2.96 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$65.22 billion (US$1.89 billion), an increase from the previous trading session which saw 1.67 billion stocks change hands on a market turnover of NT$36.41 billion (US$1.05 billion).

All of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with bank and insurance shares moving up the most at 5.7 percent, followed by construction stocks and plastics and chemical shares, both at 5.6 percent, textile issues and foodstuffs shares, both at 4.8 percent, cement stocks at 4.3 percent, pulp and paper issues at 3.4 percent, and electrical shares at 2.2 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 481 to 65, with 51 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock index futures market were higher on Wednesday, as Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index futures for September moved up 174 points to close at 4,485, with 16,524 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for October rose 172 points to finish at 4,490, with 66 contract transactions, while December futures gained 72 points to close at 4,450, with two contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for other months.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Wednesday at 4,311 for September, 4,318 for October, 4,378 for December, 4,359 for next March, and 4,378 for next June.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were also higher.
September TE futures moved up 6.35 points to close at 220.75, with 3,238 contract transactions, while October TE futures increased 5 points to finish at 218.8, with 28 contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for other months.
September TF futures surged 41 points to finish at 628.6, with 2,893 contract transactions, while October TF futures gained 41.2 points to close at 635.6, with 13 contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN COMFORTABLY LEADS IN POLL OF SUPPORT RATING

TEXT.P: A survey shows that President Chen Shui-bian still enjoys the highest support rating among Taiwan voters compared to other political figures.

The islandwide poll of eligible Taiwan voters, conducted by Open Magazine between Aug. 17 and 23, found that 31.3 percent of the respondents would vote for Chen if a presidential election were held the next day.

Just over 26 percent said they would vote for People First Party Chairman James Soong, formerly Taiwan provincial governor and secretary-general of the Kuomintang (KMT), if the election were held the next day.
Chen and Soong were trailed by Ma Ying-jeou, mayor of Taipei City and a KMT stalwart, with a support rating of 12.5 percent, according to the poll.
KMT Chairman Lien Chan and former President Lee Teng-hui had support ratings of 10.1 percent and 2.9 percent, respectively, the poll results showed.
KMT legislator Pan Wei-kang said that it is still too early to speculate who will win the next presidential election since the election is two years away.
Open Magazine conducted the poll by telephone, obtaining 949 valid responses with a margin of error of 3.18 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: WEB SITE OF CHINESE ASTROLOGY SETS UP PROFIT-MAKING MODEL

TEXT.P: While most Internet content providers and Web site managers are complaining about the difficulties in making their sites profitable, a low-cost site featuring Chinese astrology, lucky names in particular, is pulling in good revenues.
Astrology remains one of the most popular sections of Chinese portal sites and there are at least 200 Chinese Web sites dedicated to astrology and Chinese horoscopes.

Established one-and-half years ago, www.veryname.com started with only NT$10 million. Now its monthly revenue amounts to NT$1 million. Paying customers by the end of this year are expected to reach 150,000 and the monthly income to reach NT$3 million, according to David Lin, founder of the Web site.
Lin said that the Taiwan market for Internet content related to astrology is estimated at NT$100 million and market potential in overseas Chinese communities is equally large.

The Internet business in general is still struggling to find profit-making models, be it Internet content providers or service providers. Applying mysticism in an entertaining approach through fortune-telling and astrology Web sites is one of the few winning ideas in the Internet business.

The local currency opened Wednesday at 34.590 and was traded between 34.570 and 34.601.

DOC.HEADLINE: CPC EYEING HUGE MAINLAND CHINESE OIL MARKET

TEXT.P: The state-run Chinese Petroleum Corp. (CPC) is planning to make inroads into mainland China by relocating part of its distribution and sales operations across the Taiwan Strait, CPC sources said Wednesday.
CPC management is now working first to open gas stations and oil storage tanks in port cities along the Yangtze River, the longest river on the Chinese mainland, according to CPC officials.

Under cut-throat competition at home after the Formosa Plastics Group edged into Taiwan's oil market last September -- a move which ended CPC's five-decade monopoly -- the CPC decided recently to "move out," initially targeting mainland China's diesel oil markets, CPC officials said.
Before CPC actually branches out, however, the company will have to obtain export permits from the Energy Commission under the Ministry of Economic Affairs, CPC officials said.

CPC's announcement that it will seek to open operations in mainland China was made known now only after the Republic of China government began recently to ponder reviewing the "no haste, be patient" policy devised years ago to curb rapidly expanding Taiwan trade with and investment in mainland China.

Actually CPC has already sold some 2,000 metric tons of liquefied national gas (LNG) to Guangdong province earlier this year on a trial basis via a Hong Kong-based agent, and CPC has "quietly" sold diesel oil to mainland China over the last two years, also on a trial basis, according to CPC officials.

Last week, CPC struck a tentative accord with mainland China's flagship petroleum company, the Beijing-based China National Offshore Oil Corporation (CNOOC), to jointly explore for oil reserves in the Taiwan Strait.

The agreement, only revived recently after a five-year hiatus, features joint oil exploration in waters located southeast of the mouth of mainland China's Zhujiang (Pearl River), according to CPC sources.
Encompassing 15,400 square kilometers, the targeted area straddles the imaginary demarcation mid-line in the Taiwan Strait that has been tacitly accepted by both Taipei and Beijing for decades.

If everything goes smoothly, a formal pact on the cross-strait cooperation is expected to be signed by the end of this year, paving the way for the two companies to launch formal exploratory drilling, probably in 2002, CPC officials added.

Under the initial contract, CPC and CNOOC will each contribute US$500,000 for oil and LNG exploration in the targeted area, which lies 250 kilometers south of the city of Swatow in the mainland Chinese province of Guangdong.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW FIGURES SHOW DENSE POPULATION IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Population density in metropolitan Taipei stood at 9,717 persons per square kilometer at the end of June, and that of the port city Kaohsiung in southern Taiwan was even higher at 9,728, according to statistics compiled by the Environmental Protection Administration under the Executive Yuan.

Dense population poses a heavy burden to the urban areas in Taiwan. While the population density of the island at the end of June was 619 persons per square kilometer, the population densities in Taipei, Kaohsiung and 10 cities and counties in Taiwan were far above 1,000 per square kilometer.

In general, the population densities in cities and counties along the island's west coast were high, between 1,500 and 4,500 per square kilometer, while in Taitung and Hualien counties in eastern Taiwan the population densities were only 69 and 76 per square kilometer respectively. The mountainous Nantou County's population density was also comparatively lower, at 132 per square kilometer.

In Taipei, as of the end of June there were 1,635,769 motor vehicles on the streets, of which automobiles totaled 672,942 and the rest were mostly motorcycles. In Kaohsiung, the number of motor vehicles totaled 1,355,430, of which automobiles totaled 376,788.
The numerous manufacturing factories around the island have helped boost Taiwan's economy. However, they have become a major burden to the environment.

Though not many factories chose to locate in the cities, the suburban areas surrounding such metropolitans as Taipei, Kaohsiung and Taichung are favored as factory sites. At the end of June, there were 26,858 factories in Taipei County and 10,706 in Taoyuan County neighboring Taipei City. Surrounding Kaohsiung City, Kaohsiung County had 4,874 factories and Tainan County 6,740. Taichung County and Taichung City in central Taiwan combined had 17,841 factories.
The government statistics showed that at the end of June there were 97,500 factories in Taiwan, nearly three in every square kilometer.

DOC.HEADLINE: BUSINESS TURNOVER OF HSIP DROPS 13 PERCENT IN FIRST HALF-YEAR

TEXT.P: Business volume at the Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park (HSIP) in the first half of this year totaled NT$364.2 billion (US$10.3 billion), down 13 percent on a year-on-year basis, according to statistics released recently by the HSIP Administration.
The administration attributed the fall to a global recession of the IC industry, which is the backbone of the northern Taiwan hi-tech industrial park.

In terms of industry categories, the computer, IC, and optoelectronics industries all registered decreases in their business volume during the first six months, while the biotech, telecommunications and precision machinery sectors posted noticeable rises of 47 percent, 25 percent and 21 percent, respectively, administration tallies show.

The administration, however, pointed out that 59 firms based in the HSIP still applied for capital increments in the first half, channeling in NT$211.3 billion, up 2.1 percentage points from a year ago. During the same period, 24 new companies with a combined capital of NT$10.6 billion were established, a four-fold increase over the year-earlier level.

It forecast that the park's business turnover for the whole of 2001 will reach NT$800 billion based on the optimistic prediction that the IC industry will regain momentum in the fourth quarter of this year.

In the other hand, the annual business volume of the biotech companies headquartered in the HSIP is expected to grow by 100 percent for 2001, as the government has plans to invest NT$17.2 billion to promote the industry in the coming year, an official with the park administration said.

From the beginning of this year to the end of June, there were 305 firms based in the park, with a labor force of 101,510 workers, a decrease of 1,330 workers from the year-earlier level, according to administration tallies.

DOC.HEADLINE: POLICE RAID NETS LARGEST-EVER ECSTASY HAUL

TEXT.P: Taipei police discovered more than 40,000 MDMA pills, commonly known as ecstasy, at the Chiang Kai-shek International Airport Tuesday night.
Taipei police authorities said the more-than 10 kilograms of the illicit drug, the largest amount ever found at any of Taiwan's airports, had a street value of NT$28 million (US$800,000).

A task force of Taipei City Police Headquarters led by Prosecutor Hsu Ming-chu arrested five Taiwan women -- Huang Lee-ching, 25; Lee Hsin-hsin, 21; Kao Tsu-ying, 21; Hung Yu-ting, 21; and Lin Chun-ping, 24 -- upon their arrival on flight SR 166 from Switzerland when they were found to have the class 2 drugs strapped to their legs and abdomens with bandages.

The initial police investigation revealed that the five young women -- none of whom has a criminal record -- left Taiwan Aug. 21 for Belgium to serve as couriers for a local drug dealer surnamed "Ah Fu."

The five women confessed that they agreed to carry the very pure MDMA from Europe for "Ah Fu" for NT$100,000 each. Police suspected that international drug lords might be responsible for the smuggling plan.
Police later also arrested a female drug dealer surnamed Hsu within the airport who was seeking to contact the women. Hsu was found to be the girlfriend of "Ah Fu," who remained at large.

DOC.HEADLINE: DRIVERS REMINDED ABOUT NEW RULES ON SEAT BELTS, MOBILE PHONES

TEXT.P: The Taipei city government reminded city drivers Tuesday that from Sept. 1, they will be fined if their front-seat passengers are caught not wearing a seat belt.
Drivers and motorcycle riders will also be fined from the same day if they are caught using hand-held mobile phones when driving or riding.

In an activity to remind the drivers and riders about the new road-safety regulations, Minister of Transportation and Communications Yeh Chu-lan and Chung Hwa Telecom Chairman Mao Chih-kuo will appear Thursday in a demonstration show.
Under the new regulations approved early this year, front-seat passengers of sedans, taxis and even buses, are required to wear seat belts or the driver will face a fine of NT$1,500.
The fines for using hand-held cellular phones while on the road or at traffic lights will be NT$3,000 for drivers and NT$1,000 for motorcyclists.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING PROTESTS AGAINST ROC LABOR LEADER'S SPEECH AT ILO MEETING
DOC.DATELINE: Bangkok, Aug. 29 (CNA) (By Kuo Feng-chi & Ed Chen)

TEXT.P: The leader of the Taipei-based Chinese Federation of Labor (CFL) said Wednesday at a conference that the CFL protects the rights and interests of foreign workers working in the Republic of China, drawing a protest from the mainland Chinese delegate.

CFL Chairman Lin Hui-kuan also called on labor union leaders from the Philippines, Thailand, Indonesia and Vietnam to make joint efforts to protect the rights and interest of their workers so that they are not exploited by their employers in Taiwan.
Some 300,000 workers from these Southeast Asian countries currently work in Taiwan.
Lin made the appeal at the 13th Asian Regional Meeting of the International Labor Organizations (ILO) presently under way in Bangkok.
The mainland Chinese delegate lodged a protest over Lin's speech, as Lin mentioned the official name of the Republic of China on several occasions.
Lin and two other labor unions leaders from Taiwan are taking part in the current meeting as representatives of the International Confederation of Free Trade Unions (ICFTU).

Lin also briefed the more-than 500 participants on the current labor situation in Taiwan and on the local labor unions' efforts at the just-concluded Economic Development Advisory Conference to ensure equal working opportunities and preserve the rights and interests of foreign workers as well as local workers.
Delegates from more than 30 countries and regions in Asia are taking part in the five-day conference at which Taiwan is being represented for the first time.

DOC.HEADLINE: 8 FISHERMEN ABOARD TAIWAN FISHING BOAT RESCUED BY U.S. WARSHIP
DOC.DATELINE: San Francisco, Aug. 28 (CNA) (By Neil Lu and David Hsu)

TEXT.P: One Taiwan skipper and seven mainland Chinese crewmen aboard a Taiwan fishing boat were rescued by a U.S. Navy warship after their vessel caught fire and sank in the Pacific Ocean, a spokesman for the U.S. Pacific Fleet said Tuesday.

The Chih Man Chun No. 21 sent out a distress signal last Saturday night from waters 1,030 km east of Guam when it caught fire. They were rescued a short time later by a helicopter from USS Boxer, which was 200 km away.
The spokesman said the eight men were still aboard the USS Boxer and in good condition. They will be sent back to their home countries after the warship reaches Pearl Harbor in Hawaii, he added.

The Pacific Fleet is presently arranging the men's repatriation with the U.S. State Department and Immigration and Naturalization Service, the spokesman said, adding that the fleet will also inform the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in Honolulu and the relevant mainland Chinese authorities in the United States on the matter.

The USS Boxer is an amphibious assault ship with a complement of 2,500 navy and marine personnel. The spokesman did not disclose when the ship will arrive in Hawaii, but it is expected to make a port call there before its return to San Diego Sept. 14.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, Aug. 30, or the 12th day of the seventh month of the Year of the Snake according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
30B.C.: Mark Antony, the ruler of the eastern part of the Roman Empire, commits suicide at the court of his lover, Cleopatra, queen of Egypt, who later commits suicide by allowing an asp to bite her breast.
1483: Louis XI, king of France who was responsible for the unification of his country after the Hundred Years War, dies and is succeeded by his son, Charles VIII.
1862: Thomas Jonathan Jackson, known as "Stonewall," American Confederate general, leads his forces to victory against the Union Army at the Second Battle of Bull Run in Virginia. He was accidentally killed by his own troops at Chancellorvile in 1863.
1916: Turkey declares war on Romania.
1918: Vladimir Ilich Lenin, known as "Nikolai Lenin," first head of the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics, is shot and wounded by Fanya Kaplan and her sister Dora in Moscow.
1928: Jawaharlal Nehru founds the Independence of India League.
1932: Hermann Wilhelm Goering, German Nazi politician and military leader, is elected president of the German Reichstag. He was responsible for the buildup of the German air force, directed Germany's wartime economy and was designated Hitler's successor in 1939.
1937: American boxer Joe Louis flattens Britain's Tommy Farr to win the heavyweight title at Madison Square Garden in New York.
1940: Sir Joseph John Thomson, British physicist, dies at the age of 84. He won a Nobel Prize in 1906 for investigating the electrical conductivity of gases.
1945: Hong Kong is liberated when the British Navy under Rear Adm. Cecil Harcourt sails into Victoria harbor to accept the Japanese surrender.
1949: The Southeast China Governor's Office, which was established in Taipei on Aug. 15, appoints Gen. Sun Li-jen as commander-in-chief of the Taiwan Garrison Command.
1958: Mainland China's Resolution Concerning the Establishment of People's Communes in the Rural Areas is promulgated. In a period of less then three months, 26,578 people's communes involving 127 million peasant household were established all over the mainland.
1963: The "hot line," a direct telephone line between the White House and the Kremlin linking the U.S. president with the Soviet leader, becomes operational.
1974: A bomb planted by leftist guerrillas explodes in the main office of Mitsubishi Heavy Industries at Marunouchi in Tokyo, killing eight people and injuring 376 others.
1979: Ding Mou-shih, former vice minister of Foreign Affairs, leaves for Seoul to assume his post as ROC ambassador to the Republic of Korea.
1981: Muhammad Ali Rajai, president of Iran, and his prime minister, Mohammed Javad Bahonar, become victims of a bomb planted in the premier's office in Teheran.
1981: President Chiang Ching-kuo receives U.S. Senator John Glenn.
1988: Republic of China-U.S. talks on finance and banking open in Washington. The ROC negotiators agree to open the Taiwan market to credit card companies and to expand credit for foreign banks.
1989: Guatemalan President Marco Vincicio Cerezo Arevalo arrives in Taipei for a six-day visit.
1990: Chien Mu, a great master in the study of Chinese classics, dies in Taipei at the age of 96.
1991: Azerbaijan declares independence from the Soviet Union.
1999: New Salvadoran Ambassador Francisco Ricardo Santana Berrios presents his credentials to President Lee Teng-hui.
1999: Premier Vincent Siew leaves Taipei for Los Angeles en route to Panama to attend the inauguration of President-elect Mireya Moscoso on Sept. 1 as the special envoy of President Lee Teng-hui.
2000: A six-day joint seminar of college professors and students from Hong Kong, mainland China, and Taiwan opens on the campus of Tunghai University.
2000: President Chen Shui-bian receives Brisbane Mayor Jim Soorley, and welcome his visit aimed at strengthening exchanges between the ROC and Australia and seeking intercity exchanges.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Where there is truth, there is intelligence; where there is intelligence, there is truth."

DOC.HEADLINE: KISSINGER SAYS MAINLAND CHINA COULD BECOME ENEMY OF UNITED STATES

TEXT.P: Former U.S. Secretary of State Henry Kissinger is convinced that Communist China could become America's enemy, but "it should not happen as a result of our actions."
In his view, the United States must defend itself against whoever has missiles that would threaten America.

In an exclusive interview published by NewsMax.com on its Web site Wednesday, the 78-year-old Nobel Peace Prize winner said, "I don't think we have any one [enemy] anymore. We have a plethora of issues before us. I think the emergence of China as a major country is a challenge to America and to the international system.

"It is a test for us: whether we can live in a world in which we are the most powerful country, but in which we do not insist on dominating. [Otherwise] we will use more and more of our resources and expend our energy, as we have recently, by turning foreign policy into a series of domestic issues. And we will lose our relevance," noted Kissinger.
About who he would define as America's main enemy now, he said, "It could happen that China becomes our enemy. But it is not foreordained. And it should not happen as a result of our actions."

Asked about the development of a U.S. "Star Wars"-type program which he supports but Beijing finds extremely threatening, Kissinger replied that, "I know it's an axiomatic view of the left around the world that missile defense is sinful, and that it's desirable to keep each nation as vulnerable as possible. But that's a debatable premise. The U.S. must defend itself against whoever has missiles that would threaten the United States. And you don't have to be able to name an enemy."

As to President George W. Bush's first few months on the foreign affairs front, the former Secretary of State said, "He has been amazingly sure-footed. And I agree with the main lines of his foreign policy. Probably it would have been wiser to renegotiate the Kyoto Protocol [adopted by the Clinton administration, agreeing to reduce emissions of greenhouse gases, but rejected 95-0 by the Senate], rather than abrogate it. But the main line of the foreign policy I support."
