DOC.HEADLINE: TRAFFIC SAFETY GETS BOOST WITH NEW 'BUCKLE UP, NO CELL PHONES' LAW

TEXT.P: Minister of Transportation and Communications Yeh Chu-lan asked all drivers in Taiwan Thursday to support the two new road-safety regulations to take effect Saturday -- buckling up and leaving cell phones off while behind the wheel.

Beginning Sept. 1, car drivers and front-seat passengers will be required to wear seat belts and those driving motorcycles and cars will be prohibited from using hand-held mobile phones while their vehicles are in motion. Pillion passengers are not subject to the restrictions.

Under the two new regulations, approved by the government early this year, car drivers and front-seat passengers will be fined NT$1,500 if they are caught not wearing seat belts when the vehicle is in motion. The fine applies to both individuals, but the ticket will be written out to the driver of the vehicle.

Automobile drivers will be fined NT$3,000 if they are caught using hand-held cellular phones when driving, while motorcycle drivers will face a fine of NT$1,000 if they are caught using hand-held phones when riding, according to the new regulations.
Yeh quoted tallies from Taipei's Wanfang General Hospital as indicating that 47 percent of people who died in traffic accidents in Taipei could have survived if they were wearing seat belts.
In Japan, Yeh added, the death ratio of people who were not wearing seat belts is seven times higher than that among people who had buckled up.

She also said that in the United States, statistics show that lives of some 25,000 people were saved annually after vehicles were equipped with seat belts, and some 125,000 others suffered lighter injuries than would have been expected if they had not been wearing seat belts.

In Taiwan, the number of deaths from freeway traffic mishaps declined by one-third from 1985 compared with 2000 when a new road-safety regulation -- requiring car drivers to wear a seat belt while driving on expressways or risk a fine of NT$1,500 -- was passed by the Legislative Yuan and put into force, Yeh noted.
Moreover, she said that it has been scientifically proven that speaking on a hand-held mobile phone while driving can distract a driver and can lead to an increased risk of traffic accidents.
Traffic accidents cost Taiwan some NT$3 billion each year. The losses include medical bills, decreased productivity and expenses incurred during rehabilitation.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK PRICES DOWN BY 4.83 POINTS

TAIEX Index futures for October lost 39 points to finish at 4,448, with 49 contract transactions, while next June futures decreased 50 points to close at 4,502, with one contract traded.

Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, reported mixed results.

DOC.HEADLINE: OFFICIAL REAFFIRMS STANCE ON OPENING TO MAINLAND TOURISTS

TEXT.P: A senior official reaffirmed the government's commitment Thursday to opening the door to mainland Chinese tourists, saying the policy will be substantiated in the foreseeable future.
Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Vice Chairman Chen Ming-tung made the reaffirmation during a breakfast meeting with opposition People First Party (PFP) legislators.

At the meeting, many PFP lawmakers asked Chen how the government will implement a consensus reached at the just-concluded Economic Development Advisory Conference to allow mainland Chinese people to visit Taiwan for sightseeing purposes.
In response, Chen said the MAC, which charts Taiwan's policy toward mainland China, already finalized planning work for the new open-door policy in early July.

"The policy has so far not been substantiated mainly because certain critical issues have yet to be resolved," Chen said, adding that time is needed for the two sides of the Taiwan Strait discuss measures to prevent overstaying of mainland Chinese tourists and upgrade quality of cross-strait travel services.

Since the Aug. 24-26 economic conference has reached a consensus on opening Taiwan's door to mainland Chinese tourists, Chen said, the government will put the policy into practice on an experimental basis as soon as possible.
Nevertheless, Chen refrained from giving a definite timetable for implementing the measure. "It would be a disrespect to mainland China if we unilaterally set a timetable at the moment," he stressed.
Noting that mutual respect is crucial to cross-strait interaction, Chen said the new open-door policy will be implemented when cross-strait engagement proceeds smoothly.

Although Beijing still refuses to resume the long-stalled cross-strait dialogue, Chen said he is convinced that all hurdles can be removed gradually and that mainland tourists will be able to come to Taiwan in the foreseeable future.

Touching on the direct "three links" issue, chen said both sides of the Taiwan Strait attach great importance to the topic related to the opening of direct bilateral trade, mail and transportation links.

"As the 'three links' involve exercise of public authority, the issue cannot be negotiated by unauthorized private organizations," Chen said, adding that since Taiwan is a democratic country ruled by law, the "three links" issue must be handled by the government in accordance with existing law and regulations.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER CHANG DESIGNATES SEPT. 21 NEW ARBOR DAY

TEXT.P: Premier Chang Chun-hsiung on Thursday designated Sept. 21 a new Arbor Day in Taiwan and called for the public to contribute to the "one person, one tree" campaign to help with re-forestation on the island.

Chang urged everyone in Taiwan to support the "one person, one tree" drive with a spirit of community by planting great numbers of trees to enable residents on the island to "grasp firmly the land of Taiwan with roots."

The premier made the call when he took part in the 10th meeting of the Cabinet-authorized 921 Earthquake Post-Disaster Recovery Commission held at the headquarters of the now much-downsized Taiwan Provincial Government located in Chunghsing New Village, central Taiwan.

Taiwan was hit by a devastating earthquake of magnitude 7.3 on Sept. 21, 1999, the deadliest in four decades which claimed some 2,400 lives. Since then, Chang said, roads, bridges, tourism and agricultural in the affected areas have clearly recovered from the disaster.

However, Taiwan, particularly eastern and central parts, suffered a new major blow when Typhoon Toraji wreaked havoc on the island in late July, resulting in great losses in human lives and immeasurable property damages, Chang noted.
He said Sept. 21 (921) will be remembered as a watershed in Taiwan's conservation rehabilitation and the day will be a new Arbor Day on the island for re-forestation.

DOC.HEADLINE: STUDENTS OF MAINLAND CHINA FLOCKING TO MACAU

TEXT.P: The number of mainland students studying in Macau will soar almost ninefold this academic year from 180 to nearly 1,600, the South China Morning Post reported Thursday.
It quoted Macau's education officials as saying that the rise is due to a push by the Macau government to encourage mainland and overseas students to study in the former Portuguese colony.
An official of Macau's Higher Education Bureau reportedly said that the exact number of mainland students enrolling at Macau's four tertiary institutions in the new term would be released soon.
"We know so far that about 1,500 mainland students are planning to study here in the next academic term," the official was quoted as saying.
Hong Kong has 400 mainland students studying at the undergraduate level, all on Jockey Club scholarships, but universities are also trying to recruit paying students from China. (Stanley Cheung)

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Shares prices opened low and fluctuated on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Thursday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 4.83 points to close at 4,503.86.

The bourse opened at 4,495.92, and began to go up despite a decline in U.S. stock prices, but profit-taking selling pressure drove the prices down later. The index fluctuated between 4,576.33 and 4,469.59 during trading.

A total of 3.21 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$62.97 billion (US$1.83 billion), compared with the previous trading session which saw 2.96 billion stocks change hands on a market turnover of NT$65.22 billion (US$1.89 billion).
Only one of the eight major stock categories lost ground, with electrical shares moving down 1.6 percent.

The other major categories posted gains, with textile issues moving up the most at 4.5 percent, followed by plastics and chemical shares at 3.2 percent, cement stocks at 3.1 percent, foodstuffs shares at 2.7 percent, pulp and paper issues at 2.2 percent, bank and insurance shares at 1.8 percent, and construction stocks at 1.4 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 284 to 212, with 95 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: CABINET CUTTING UNIFORM TAX REVENUE APPROPRIATION TO TAIPEI CITY

TEXT.P: Premier Chang Chun-hsiung approved a revision Thursday of the formula for the allocation of uniform tax revenues which will result in a nearly NT$1.4 billion shortfall for the Taipei City Government's fiscal 2002 revenues as compared with the city government's projections based on the old formula.

By changing the composition of reference factors of the formula, the Cabinet is giving the Kaohsiung City Government a larger share of the appropriations in fiscal 2002. The reference factors include business revenues, population, area and financially sustaining abilities.

At a news conference Thursday, Minister without Portfolio Hu Sheng-cheng said that in fiscal 2002, the Taipei City Government will receive an appropriation of NT$47.9 billion, and the Kaohsiung City Government NT$19.1 billion.

Both Taipei and Kaohsiung cities have equal status within Taiwan province. The two special municipalities take 43 percent of uniform tax revenue appropriations, counties and provincial municipalities 39 percent, rural and urban townships 12 percent, and 6 percent goes for special purposes.

Considering that the Taipei City Government may have immediate problems with less appropriations from tax revenues, the Cabinet will create a special fund of NT$1 billion for the city government, according to government spokesman Su Tzen-ping.

Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou, frustrated and disappointed upon learning of the Cabinet decision, said that the city government has submitted its fiscal 2002 budget plan to the city council, and the shortage will cause difficulties for the city government's budget planning. He expects that the Cabinet will make up the difference of NT$1.4 billion, he added.

In Kaohsiung, Mayor Frank Hsieh said that an increase of NT$1.4 billion in its tax revenue appropriations from the central government will help ease the port city's financial difficulties. The Cabinet's decision signified an advancement of the central government in promoting balanced development of the north (Taipei) and the south (Kaohsiung).

Refuting political opinions, the Kaohsiung mayor who is concurrently chairman of the Democratic Progressive Party, said that it was groundless to say that the Cabinet decision meant to embarrass Mayor Ma, a member of the opposition Kuomintang.

Hsieh said that Taipei City is far more advanced than other cities in Taiwan in terms of basic infrastructure. He called upon the Taipei City Government to be more generous in allowing a more balanced development in different parts of the island.

The Kaohsiung City Government said that the additional sum from the central government will be mainly used to raise the payments to various insurance programs, including public health, and those for laborers, farmers, fishermen and the handicapped.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S CAL POISED TO BUY INTO MAINLAND CHINA AIR CARGO OPERATOR

TEXT.P: The Taipei-based China Airlines (CAL) is planning to buy into mainland China's China Cargo as a shareholder of the air cargo operator which is an affiliate of China Eastern Air (China East) sources from Hong Kong reported Thursday.

CAL is currently negotiating with China East for a 25 percent stake in China Cargo's stocks to become a new partner of the air cargo operator, according to Hong Kong's Wen Wei Po daily. CAL is offering cash for the shares.
Exactly how much CAL will spend for the shares of China Cargo remains to be seen as the assets of China Cargo are still under assessment, the report said.
China East Chairman Yeh Yigan said his company is expected to forge an agreement with CAL sometime in September for the buy-in, the paper reported.
CAL authorities were quoted by the daily newspaper as being "very pleased to learn about the development."

China Cargo, the first air cargo operator on the Chinese mainland, is a joint venture between China East and China Ocean Shipping (Group) Co., with the two holding 70 percent and 30 percent, respectively, of the company's shares.
With the joining of CAL, the three-way shareholding of China Cargo will become 55 percent (China East), 20 percent (China Ocean Shipping) and 25 percent (CAL), the daily said.

The report indicated that CAL and China East personnel have been in negotiations for years concerning the buy-in plan, but that talks were suspended after Democratic Progressive Party's Chen Shui-bian was elected the Republic of China president last year.
Yeh said the talks resumed only in recent months, adding that the CAL-China East cooperation is purely a business relationship and has no "direct relations" with politics, according to the report.

The report added that it is evident that both CAL and China East are trying to secure their positions, paving the way for the opening of direct travel and transportation links across the Taiwan Strait which is expected in the near future.
Meanwhile, the Tai Kung Po daily (Hong Kong) also reported Thursday about the CAL-China East tie-up.

The paper quoted China East Chairman Yeh as saying that China East is eyeing an imminent Taiwan-Hong Kong-Shanghai route for cargo traffic in hopes that China Cargo will become a key carrier of cargoes from Taiwan to Shanghai. From Shanghai, more cargoes originating from Taiwan will be delivered to other major cities in mainland China.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DEPUTY DEFENSE SECRETARY RESTATES COMMITMENT TO TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Calling Taiwan "a model of both economic and democratic reform," U.S. Deputy Secretary of Defense Paul Wolfowitz said that the United States remains committed to the defense of the island and to the principle of peaceful resolution of cross-strait differences.

"We can more than adequately back up the commitments that are enshrined in the Taiwan Relations Act and which the president affirmed," Wolfowitz said in an interview published in Wednesday's edition of the Washington Times.

The United States is firmly committed to seeing the issue resolved without force, he said. "So the Chinese would be making a great mistake if they thought they could settle this thing on their terms by using force," said the No. 2 Pentagon official.

Wolfowitz reaffirmed the U.S. position after President George W. Bush said in April that the United States would do "whatever it took" to help Taiwan defend itself from an attack by mainland China under the 1979 Taiwan Relations Act.
On the future of U.S relations with mainland China, he suggested that the United States should be vigilant.
"I don't think China has to be a threat," he said, "but I think if we're complacent, then we could actually contribute to the opposite effect."

A former assistant Secretary of State for East Asia during the Reagan era, Wolfowitz predicted that mainland China is "almost certain to become a superpower in the next half-century, and maybe in the next quarter-century."

The question, he said, is whether the emerging superpower will live at peace with its neighbors "or will it go the way of traditional power diplomacy," which he said would be "a tragic mistake for everybody" because of the weapons available today.
Asked about the prospects of Beijing's leaders making political reforms, Wolfowitz said, "Over the long run the Chinese political system is going to have to change.

"Does that mean it will quickly or overnight? Absolutely not," he said. "And I don't particularly like being associated with theories of economic inevitability because so many of them have been wrong in the past."

DOC.HEADLINE: LOCAL PILOTS PROTEST PLAN TO ALLOW HIRING OF FOREIGN CO-PILOTS

TEXT.P: Local civil aviation pilots voiced strong opposition Thursday to a Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) plan to allow Taiwan carriers to hire foreign nationals as co-pilots.
Representatives from major civil aviation pilots associations aired their views at a public hearing organized by opposition People First Party (PFP) Legislator Liu Wen-hsiung at the Legislative Yuan.

Liu said the MOTC has drafted revisions to the existing regulations governing employment of foreign pilots by local carriers. According to the amendment bill, local carriers will be allowed to employ foreign nationals to serve as co-pilots.

Liu further said the revised regulations do not require foreign applicants to present certificates proving that they have experience in operating the same types of aircraft they will fly for local carriers.

Liu said the MOTC plan to ease restrictions on employment of foreign pilots does not comply with a consensus reached at the Aug. 24-26 Economic Development Advisory Conference that requires domestic employers not to violate local workers' rights while recruiting foreign laborers.
Under the existing regulations, Taiwan carriers can only hire foreign nationals as pilots.

Speaking on the same occasion, Liu Li-chung, a flight instructor with a local pilot's association, said that as of the end of June, local carriers hired a total of 707 local pilots and 518 foreign pilots.

Liu Li-chung said foreign pilots do not necessarily outpace their local counterparts in flight skills. He also claimed that the influx of pilots from Third World countries in recent years has affected the quality of flight safety .

Moreover, he went on, some foreign pilots are unwilling to cooperate in investigations of flight mishaps. He recalled that a Mandarin Airlines plane committed a mishap at Hong Kong's Kai Tak Airport two years ago. Its Italian pilot declined to accept Taiwan's investigations and returned to Italy directly from Hong Kong. A Canadian pilot also rejected a probe and returned to his home country after he mistakenly flew a Taipei-bound plane to Taiwan's outlying island of Penghu.

As pilots from Third World countries usually settle for lower salaries, Liu said he is worried that the MOTC's planned lifting of the ban on hiring foreign co-pilots would affect their local counterparts' job opportunities.

He urged the MOTC to gradually reduce the ratio of foreign pilots to protect local pilots' working rights. "The MOTC should also impose stricter professional requirements on foreign pilots to ensure flight safety," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECONOMICS MINISTER HOPING TO LURE INVESTMENT FROM EUROPE

TEXT.P: Minister of Economic Affairs Lin Hsin-yi will leave for Germany and France Sept. 1 in a bid to attract more investment from Europe's high-tech industries, ministry sources said Thursday.

Lin will be focusing on enterprises with operations in electronics, biotechnology, aerospace and environmental protection. While there, he will also attend economic cooperation conferences organized by various civic organizations.

Lin's visit will follow a recent trade-promotion tour of Europe by Finance Minister Yen Ching-chang and a tour of the United States by Vice Economics Minister Lin Yi-fu in late June, which brought to Taiwan potential investment worth US$155 million from American biotech and telecommunications industries.

A ministry official said that at a time when Taiwan is mired in an economic slowdown, the island needs more foreign capital and that communication with specific foreign enterprises is the best way to attract investment.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S ELEMENTARY SCHOOLS LACK ENGLISH TEACHERS

TEXT.P: Taiwan's elementary schools do not have enough English teachers, especially in remote regions such as areas of Nantou and Hualien counties, according to the latest survey conducted by the Ministry of Education (MOE).

The survey results show that at present, 2,200 elementary school English teachers are needed, but the MOE has trained only 1,615 people as elementary school English teachers. So far only 1,138 passed qulification tests and become formal teachers.

In Nantou, for example, 159 elementary school English teachers are required, but only 15 MOE-trained teachers had registered to take the test in the area. All 15 passed, but only six would agree to teach in Nantou.
MOE Director of Education Liu Yi-chaun said the ministry is working out ways to solve the shortage problem.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2ND MAINLAND TRADE MISSION ARRIVES IN KINMEN FOR TRADE FAIR

TEXT.P: A mainland Chinese trade delegation, led by Zheng Zungjie, head of the foreign trade department of the Fujian provincial government, arrived in the Republic of China's frontline island of Kinmen Thursday to attend a special trade fair.

The 56-member group included senior Fujian officials in charge of Taiwan affairs and trade affairs. Also among the members was Kang Uni, deputy director of the Department of Taiwan, Hong Kong and Macau Affairs under mainland China's Ministry of Foreign Trade and Economic Cooperation.
Kang's presence indicated that mainalnd Chinese authorities attach importance to the trade fair scheduled to open Friday, local observers said.
The trade fair will feature consumer products manufactured by 52 blue-chip firms in the Jinjiang area in Fujian province which lies opposite Taiwan.

The 10-ton goods to be displayed in the Aug. 31-Sept. 2 trade fair were shipped directly from Xiamen to Kinmen Monday. It was the first batch of mainland consumer goods to be legally imported to Kinmen since the ROC government opened direct trade, mail and shipping links between its two offshore defense outposts of Kinmen and Matsu and mainland China's Xiamen and Mawei ports in Fujian province, commonly known as the "mini three links," at the beginning of this year.
In preparation for the trend-setting trade fair, a 112-member mainland delegation, headed by Deputy Mayor of Jinjiang City Wang Yuandong, already arrived in Kinmen Tuesday.
Kinmen County Magistrate Chen Shui-tsai said he is very pleased to see the arrivals of the two mainland trade delegations and the opening of the trade fair.

"The trade fair marks the start of a new stage in the Kinmen-Xiamen commercial and civilian exchanges and is also expected to turn a new page for the 'mini three links,'" Chen said, adding that he also hopes the trade fair can set a new model for cross-strait commercial exchanges.
As Kinmen lies far closer to Fujian than to Taiwan, many mainland products have been smuggled into Kinmen over the past years, despite intensive coast guard patrols.
Mainland products to be displayed in the show will include footwear, furniture, toys, garments, consumer electronics and construction materials and interior decorations.

As mainland China has been reluctant to throw its full support behind the Taiwan-initiated "mini three links," it still does not allow regular direct Kinmen-Xiamen and Matsu-Mawei shipping services and instead reviews such applications on a case-by-case basis.
Kinmen County Government sources said the forthcoming Jinjiang trade fair may mark a change in mainland China's attitude toward the "mini three links."

"Anyway, we hope that the 'mini three links' can make headway after the trade fair to help pave the way for opening of full-fledged trade, communication and transportation links across the Taiwan Strait," said Kinmen Magistrate Chen.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT INSPECTS POST-TYPHOON RECONSTRUCTION WORK IN PENGHU

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian visited Penghu Thursday morning to inspect post-typhoon reconstruction work on the island which suffered heavy damage in the wake of last June's typhoon.
He heard a briefing from Penghu Magistrate Lai Feng-wei on the damage caused by Typhoon Chebi June 23 and the progress of the reconstruction work.
Regarding the local request that the central government extend assistance for reconstruction of damaged offices and roads, the president promised that relevant agencies will provide necessary help.

Stressing the importance of promoting development on Taiwan's nearby islands and improving the local residents' living environment, Chen said that the government is determined to strive for a balanced development throughout every corner of the country.
He told local officials that the special task force under the Executive Yuan has decided to appropriate funds for 14 of the 20 projects submitted to the task force for review.

Chen said that Taiwan is an island vulnerable to natural disasters, and added that heavy casualties and property losses were registered in southern Kaohsiung, eastern Hualien and central Nantou during a short time this summer.
He called on the affected people to rise again and work with the government to build a new life.
The president toured Penghu, accompanied by Deputy Presidential Secretary-General Chen Che-nan, Minister of National Defense Wu Shih-wen and Minister without Portfolio Chen Chin-huang.

DOC.HEADLINE: HONG KONG AMITY ASSOCIATION CALLS ON TAIPEI MAYOR

TEXT.P: A 30-member delegation from the Hong Kong Amity Association called on Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou Thursday to exchange views on ways to strengthen relations and exchanges between Taiwan and Hong Kong.

An advisor to the delegation, Xing Qeishan, who is director of the Taiwan Affairs Department of the Beijing Liaison Office in Hong Kong, traveled to Taiwan with the delegation but was not present at the meeting.
Several association members who are concurrently members of the Chinese People's Political Consultative Conference (CPPCC) were among the members of the delegation.

Ma told his guests that relations between Taiwan and Hong Kong are very close and added that although the Republic of China government will relax the current "no haste, be patient" policy on local investment in the mainland, open the local tourism market for mainland visitors and negotiate with Beijing on postal, trade and transport links after Beijing and Taiwan enter the World Trade Organization (WTO), these moves will not affect Taiwan-Hong Kong relations.

He also said that Taipei officials are considering whether the mainland city of Shanghai should be invited to take part in the Third Taipei-Hong Kong City Forum to be sponsored by Taipei next year. If Shanghai is unable to make preparations to attend in time, Ma said, Shanghai should attend the forum as an observer so that it can discuss issues related to culture, education and environmental protection.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN REMAINS 4TH-LARGEST HOLDER OF U.S.-APPROVED PATENTS IN 2000

TEXT.P: Taiwan remained in fourth place in 2000 in terms of patents approved in the U.S., behind the United States, Japan and Germany, according to statistics released Thursday by the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS).
Taiwan was granted 5,806 patent rights by the United States in 2000, an increase of 1,280 from the previous year's level, the DGBAS figures show.
DGBAS officials said Taiwan approved a total of 42,241 patent rights in 2000, among which, 17,503, or 41.4 percent, were "creative" in nature, up 2.7 percent from the 1999 level.

Meanwhile, Taiwan published 9,203 scientific papers in major science periodicals in 2000, an increase of 259 from the number published in 1999 but still putting the country in 19th place in this regard. In 2000, Taiwan filed 4,878 engineering papers in the world's major periodicals, ranking in 10th place.

DOC.HEADLINE: RUSSIA UNDER THREAT FROM MAINLAND TRADE INTEGRATION: ACADEMIC

TEXT.P: Growing economic integration between mainland China and Russia's Far East will pose a "real threat" to Russia's territorial integrity, a Russian academic said Thursday.

Despite the fact that bilateral mainland China-Russia ties are good at present, Alexander Sharavin, a military expert and strategist who has conducted in-depth studies on the matter, said territorial disputes between the two countries remain unresolved.

Sharavin made the remarks while giving a keynote speech titled "Mainland-Russia Relations in the New Era" on the closing day of the Third Asia-Pacific Security Forum, which was sponsored by the National Policy Institute and the Washington-based Center for Strategic and International Studies (CSIS).

Scores of experts and think-tank members from Taiwan, the United States, France, Germany, Japan, Australia, Russia, Singapore, India and India took part in the gathering for talks on Asia-Pacific security and exchanges.

According to Sharavin, mainland China has been carrying out creeping expansion in Russia over the past decade. Although Russia has firmly upheld the "one China" policy which regards Taiwan as part of mainland China, he said that the mainland has not yet abandoned its territorial claims toward Russia.

In Russia's Far East and Siberia, the number of mainland Chinese migrants (mostly illegal immigrants) outnumbers the local populations, he noted, adding that the economic dependence of those Russian regions on mainland China in recent years has led to deeper integration between those regions and the mainland. "That is a big threat to Russia's territorial integrity," he pointed out.

The two-day seminar held in Taipei formed part of a series of activities initiated by the CSIS and the France-based IFRI in 1997 with an aim of promoting strategic exchanges and security talks in the Asia-Pacific region. Four large-scale international conferences or roundtable forums have been held since then.

DOC.HEADLINE: OVERSEAS CHINESE PROMOTE ROC'S U.N. BID
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Aug. 29 (CNA) (By Eric Tseng and Elisa Kao)

TEXT.P: Overseas Chinese leaders and representatives from the Republic of China's major political parties issued a declaration Wednesday in New York in support of the ROC's entry into the United Nations.

As the ROC is about to launch its ninth consecutive bid to rejoin the U.N., which will convene its General Assembly Sept. 11, the Chinese communities in New York and representatives from Taiwan's ruling Democratic Progressive Party, opposition Kuomintang and People First Party urged the international community to respect Taiwan people's rights and accept the ROC as a U.N. member.

They said at a press conference that although they embrace different political ideals, their support and love for Taiwan are the same and they feel deep regret over the unfair treatment that ROC has received from the world community for decades.

The declaration emphasizes that the U.N. has changed its way of thinking since the end of the Cold War and now pays more attention to issues concerning human survival and development, such as disease, environmental protection, human rights, trade, women and children, and housing.

Because Taiwan's 23 million people are excluded from the U.N., they are deprived of their basic rights and cannot participate in discussions organized by the U.N. Consequently, they cannot share in the results of such discussions, the declaration says, adding that this situation violates completely the basic principle and spirit of the U.N. Chapter, and goes against the world trend.

The declaration continues that the disputes between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait should be resolved through negotiations. Until that time, it goes on, no one can represent Taiwan's people except the democratically elected ROC government.

The fact that mainland China claims in the world community that it can represent Taiwan is far from reality, the declaration continues. "Beijing has no right to represent Taiwan's 23 million people," it says.
The declaration also urges the Beijing authorities to face the reality of the existence of the ROC and urges the international community to respect Taiwan people's basic rights.

DOC.HEADLINE: KAOHSIUNG CITY HOUSES MOST OBESE PEOPLE IN TAIWAN: SURVEY

TEXT.P: Kaohsiung City leads the island's 19 counties and cities in terms of the number of overweight people living there, according to the results of a survey released Thursday by a local publication.
Offshore Penghu County and eastern Taitung County came in second and third places in the survey by Health monthly.
An alarming discovery of the survey is that most of people in the three areas have no idea that they are overweight, said the magazine.

The survey was based on telephone interviews with 3,520 people across the island. The respondents gave their weight and height and the interviewers calculated their body mass index (BMI) with computers.
BMI is an easy way of measuring a person's health. It is calculated by dividing one's weight in kilograms by the square of one's height in meters.

A BMI of 19 to 24.9 is considered healthy. A BMI of 25 to 29.9 is considered overweight, 30 to 39.9 is obese, and 40 or more is very obese. A BMI of less than 19.0 is deemed unhealthy and may indicate malnourishment.
Keelung City is the most healthy city. according to the survey results, with 60 percent of its residents having a healthy BMI. Only 32 percent of them are overweight or obese.
Following behind are Taipei County, Hsinchu City, Taichung City and Kaohsiung County, according to the survey.
In contrast, people in Kaohsiung City, Penghu County, Taitung County, Pingtung County and Chiayi County registered the lowest rate of healthy BMI, ranging from 42 percent to 45 percent.

Since low vigilance against obesity is believed to be a contributory factor, it is not surprising that Penghu County has the highest rate -- 22 percent -- of people who said they are not alert to obesity, followed by those in Chiayi County, Pingtung County, Taitung County, Tainan County and Hualien County. More than 10 percent of the respondents in the four counties said they do not consider themselves overweight.
However, people in Hsinchu City, Taipei County, Hsinchu County, Taipei City and Taichung City "usually consider themselves overweight."
Lee Se, the editor-in-chief of the magazine, told a news conference called to release the survey results that obesity, which involves many health risks, is a worldwide problem.

The lack of a mass transportation system has bearing on people's weight, he went on, since it encourages people to resort to personal transportation vehicles such as cars and motorcycles and therefore increases the health risks caused by air pollution, traffic accidents.
The cities and counties which have the most obese residents in the survey are also those with less efficient mass transportation systems and those with higher numbers of personal vehicles, said Lee.

DOC.HEADLINE: VISA-FREE TREATMENT URGED FOR VISITORS FROM NEIGHBORING COUNTRIES

TEXT.P: The Republic of China government should consider granting visa-free treatment to visitors from neighboring countries such as South Korea in line with its plan to open its doors to mainland Chinese tourists, a local industry leader said Thursday.

Stanley C. Yen, chairman of the Taiwan Tourism Association, told CNA in an exclusive interview that the government should consider making the move step-by-step, as it will take some time for the "open door" policy to mainland Chinese tourists to be implemented.

Citing statistics compiled by the Tourism Bureau under the Ministry of Transportation and Communications, Yen said the number of tourists from Japan, Hong Kong and Macao account for more than half of the 2.5 million tourist arrivals to Taiwan per year and that recent tallies show that Japanese tourist arrivals have rebounded to the previous levels posted before the Sept. 21 earthquake of 1999.

Since the government has also recently begun offering landing-visa privileges to visitors from Hong Kong and Macao, Yen contended that visa regulations should be further eased and more fully opened in order to attract more tourists.

As to the long-awaited two-way tourist exchanges across the Taiwan Strait, the noted hotelier said that politics should not interfere in the matter and called on the government to promote mutually beneficial measures to help boost Taiwan's economy as long as the nation's security is maintained. "Overemphasis on ideology will only complicate the issue," he stressed.

DOC.HEADLINE: SPEAKER OF PHILIPPINES LOWER HOUSE ARRIVES FOR VISIT
DOC.DATELINE: Manila, Aug. 30 (CNA) (By Philip Liu & Ed Chen)

TEXT.P: Jose de Venecia, speaker of the House of Representatives of the Philippines, left Manila Thursday for a visit to Taipei.

While in Taiwan, De Venecia will preside over the first Dialogue between Christians and Buddhists in Taipei and will also attend the inaugural ceremony in a Taipei suburb of the world's largest Buddhist temple.
De Venecia expressed hope that the First Dialogues between Christians and Buddhists in Taipei will help promote peace and cooperation in the Asian region.
He will proceed to Bangkok from Taipei to attend the 22nd meeting of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations.

DOC.HEADLINE: BUDDHIST MASTER PROMOTES `TAIWAN GOOD DEED MONTH'

TEXT.P: Local media chiefs issued a joint declaration Thursday vowing to build Taiwan into a better place to live by "doing good deeds."
They were responding to the "Taiwan Good Deed Month" movement promoted by Master Sheng Yen, founder of the Dharma Drum Mountain Buddhist Foundation.
Sheng Yen teaches that "if everyone in Taiwan says or does a little good thing every day, those 23 million little good things will accumulate into a single large good thing."
The media chiefs said in the joint declaration that "we will exhort each other and encourage all the people of Taiwan to say and do good things."
They also promised to broadcast news of at least one good deed in their newscasts.

Sheng Yen explained that everyone in every corner of Taiwan has the power to say and do something good, irrespective of their wealth and that everyone should pay more attention to the people around them.
The promotion will begin Sept. 1 and end Sept. 30. A gala party and a gathering of 10,000 meditating people will be held in the plaza in front of Taipei City Hall Sept 29.
Sheng Yen will also invite eight major newspapers in Taiwan to join the drive.

DOC.HEADLINE: JANET LEE TAKES SILVER IN WOMEN'S TENNIS SINGLES AT UNIVERSIADE
DOC.DATELINE: Beijing, Aug. 30 (CNA) (By Lee An-tung & Ed Chen)

TEXT.P: Mainland China's Li Na beat Chinese Taipei's Janet Lee 2-1 to take the gold medal in the women's singles tennis finals Thursday at the World University Games in Beijing.
The loss meant that Lee, the defending champion, had to settle for the silver medal.

In track and field, Chiang Wan-tsun was eliminated in the javelin and Tsai Meng-lin was eliminated in the men's 200-meter sprint, while Chen Tien-wen advanced to the finals in the men's 400-meter hurdles.
In women's basketball, Yugoslavia defeated Chinese Taipei 86-67 in the consolation round. Chinese Taipei will take on Mexico Friday for 11th place.
Chinese Taipei has so far chalked up three silver medals and four bronzes.

DOC.HEADLINE: OFFICIAL TO ATTEND SAO TOME AND PRINCIPE PRESIDENTIAL INAUGURATION

TEXT.P: Republic of China Vice Foreign Minister Wu Tzu-dan left Taipei Thursday as a special envoy of President Chen Shui-bian to attend the Sept. 3 inauguration of Sao Tome and Principe President-elect Fradique de Menezes.
Members of the delegation accompanying Wu include ROC Ambassador to Sao Tome and Principe Hsiang Yen-chu and officials from the Ministry of Foreign Affairs.
Menezes won his country's July 29 presidential election for a five-year term, gaining 54.36 percent of the popular vote.
The president-elect has previously served as a member of parliament, Sao Tome and Principe's ambassador to many countries, foreign minister, as well as being a successful businessman.
After winning the election, he vowed to continue strengthening his country's relations with Taiwan.

Since the establishment of formal relations between the two countries in 1997, Taiwan has extended assistance to Sao Tome and Principe through a combination of infrastructure projects and through the stationing of medical and technical missions there.

During his stay in the ROC's West African diplomatic ally, Wu will hold talks with the new president and other government leaders. He will also visit the ROC medical and technical missions stationed there.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT JUGGLES PRESS FREEDOM WITH NATIONAL SECURITY

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bien warned Thursday that press freedom is not a pretext for obliterating the division between "the enemy and ourselves."

In a meeting with local journalists on the Presidential Office beat, the president said that as head of state, he has an obligation to protect press freedom, but this freedom should not take precedence over national security, because no freedom could be guaranteed if the country were to cease to exist.

As a pro-democracy activist in his earlier career, Chen said, he himself was the publisher of a political magazine and was jailed for articles carried by the magazine, and therefore he understands journalistic convictions and principles.
But as president, he went on, he has to defend both the security of the state and the freedom of the press, which itself is dependent on national security.

He urged the journalists to keep the idea of national security in the backs of their minds, especially in the face of the Beijing regime. "We should remain alert to disasters, risks and Beijing's hostility," he said.

Cautioning that national security is no laughing matter, the president said reporters who poke fun at national security might not mean any harm, but their readers might not be able to realize the humor in the stories and misunderstand their meaning.
He noted bitterly that from reading their stories, he can hardly tell if some of Taiwan's journalists are reporters from the Republic of China or from the People's Republic of China.
He urged the reporters to "brush up on their loyalty to the country," to keep in mind the interests of the 23 million people on the island and heighten their guard against "the enemy."
Throwing all this to the wind under the pretext of press freedom would be an inappropriate judgment for a journalist, according to Chen.
The president made the remarks after being asked about criminal cases against government officials who have recently been accused of passing out "secrets" to newspapers.
At least one military officer and one government official have been convicted and sentenced to jail terms to date, with two more cases pending in the judicial system.

DOC.HEADLINE: HSIEH YU-SHU TAKES FIRST-DAY LEAD IN 2001 ACER TAIWAN GOLF OPEN

TEXT.P: Local veteran golfer Hsieh Yu-shu shot a nine-under-par 63 Thursday to take the first-day lead in the US$300,000 Taiwan Golf Open at the Sunrise Golf and Country Club in suburban Taipei.

Scott Hoch of the United States, winner of the US PGA tour at the Greater Greenboro Chrysler Classics and the Avil Western Open and the tournament's star attraction, carded a three-under-par 69 as of the 16th hole before being rained off the course.
One stroke behind Hsieh was Andrew Pitts of the United States, who shot an eight-under-par 64. India's Arjun Atwal, who ranked third, finished with a seven-under-par 65.
Gary Rusnak of the United States, who recorded an eight-under-par at the 16th before poor visibility stopped play, was the only player with a chance of catching Hsieh.
Hsieh birdied the 12th to the 16th, took an eagle at the sixth hole and birdies at the third and eighth.
Unfortunately, he scored a bogey at the fifth and took a par at the 18th, dashing his hopes of breaking the course record.
Rainy weather stopped 42 of the players, who will have to complete their rounds early Friday morning.
The leading scores from the uncompleted first round of the 300,000 dollar Taiwan Open Thursday are as follows:
Hsieh Yu-shu (ROC) 63
Andrew Pitts (USA) 64
Arjun ATwal (Ind) 65
Thongchai Jaidee(Tha) 66
Ho Chia-feng (ROC) 67
Kao Bo-song (ROC A) 68
Scott Taylor (USA) 68
Ted Oh (Kor) 68
Jyoti Randhawa (Ind) 68
Thammanoon Sriroj (Tha) 68

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CALLS FOR MILITARY MODERNIZATION AND COMBAT READINESS

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian urged the nation's armed forces Thursday to further strengthen its training and combat readiness in order to fully safeguard the country.

Stressing that the ROC troops must be an army capable of protecting the nation and its people from any outside attack, Chen said the ROC's military buildup is being carried out to secure the country's continued development and ensure the safety and well-being of its people, and is by no means an arms race with other countries or a move to provoke tension.

As the situation surrounding Taiwan's offshore islands has changed markedly since Taiwan's implementation of the "mini three links" with certain ports in mainland China's Fujian Province at the beginning of this year, he appealed to all ROC troops to heighten their alert in order to prevent sudden attack or infiltration from the mainland.

Only a capable military force with a strong determination will be able to help the nation deter threats from other countries and avoid war, especially at a time when mainland Chinese troops are conducting amphibious military exercises on Dongshan Island designed to simulate an attack on ROC-held Penghu Island, he said.

As current world trends do not allow Taiwan and mainland China to devote their energy and limited sources to a mutual standoff, Chen urged the two sides of the Taiwan Strait to engage in mutually beneficial trade and cultural exchanges and cooperation with mutual trust in order to forge a "win-win" situation as a foundation toward achieving eternal peace.

The president made the remarks during an inspection tour of troops stationed on the offshore Penghu Island. He was accompanied by Minister of National Defense Wu Shih-wen and Chief of the General Staff Tang Yao-ming.

Emphasizing that the armed forces are an indispensable element for a country's persistent survival, Chen thanked all ranking military officers and their troops for their remarkable contributions to Taiwan's safety and prosperity.

During a dinner party later the same day in Taipei with ranking military chiefs, the president wished all the military servicemen a happy "Armed Forces Day," which falls Sept. 3, and promised to continue with the military modernization program.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI MAYOR PROPOSES STUDENT EXCHANGE WITH MOSCOW

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou met Thursday with the new Russian representative to Taiwan, Vladislav N. Verchenko, and proposed student exchanges between Taipei and Moscow.
He also raised the idea of inviting Russian artists to spend sabbaticals in Taipei to promote cultural exchanges between the two countries.

Verchenko, who assumed his new duties recently, told Ma that he lived in mainland China for 14 years and found that Taipei possesses some "unique characteristics" compared with mainland Chinese cities.
He also expressed the hope that civilian exchanges between Russia and Taiwan will be further strengthened.
For his part, Ma explained the city government's plan to establish an "international village of arts."
He said that some 30 foreign cities have agreed to support his plan to exchange artists, and that he hoped Moscow will be able to join the plan.
The Russian representative noted that a student exchange plan is already being carried out between his country and Tamkang University in suburban Taipei.
As to the plan for artist exchanges, Verchenko said he will study the plan carefully when he receives details from city government officials.

DOC.HEADLINE: RP, THAILAND ADVANCE ON OPENING DAY OF 4TH ASIAN YOUTH BASEBALL

TEXT.P: Thailand trounced Indonesia 21-13 and the Philippines beat India 9-2 Thursday, the opening day of the Fourth Asian Youth Baseball Championship.

Eight teams representing Japan, South Korea, Australia, India, Thailand, Indonesia, the Philippines and the Republic of China are taking part in the six-day competition taking place at the Tienmu Diamond and at Hsinchuang Stadium.
Meanwhile, a Japan-Australia game and an ROC-Korea game were rained off and postponed to Friday morning.

DOC.HEADLINE: NTU STUDENTS OPPOSE SEX OFFENDER'S UNCONDITIONAL RELEASE ON PAROLE

TEXT.P: A National Taiwan University student organization has launched a petition drive on campus to oppose a sex offender's unconditional release on parole lest he should become an NTU freshman.
The sex offender, who committed more than 30 sex assaults, was permitted to attend national joint college entrance examinations, which he passed, qualifying him to attend NTU this summer.
The Ministry of Justice was to hold a special meeting Friday to decide whether to release him on parole to enable him to enter the campus.

Besides launching the petition drive, the Alliance for the Self-Defense of Student Security also urged the university administration to compile and distribute handbooks on campus security to students and to boost campus security in a bid to provide students with a safe study environment.

An NTU Social Science Department student said the department is now busy sponsoring a series of activities to welcome freshmen and the issue of whether the offender will enter the department has naturally become a focus of concern.
The student said that students' parents have expressed hope that the university will deal with the issue carefully.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S ELECTRONIC INDUSTRY OUTPUT WILL DECLINE IN 2001: CEPD

TEXT.P: The output of Taiwan's electronic industry will decline in value this year, according to a report commissioned by the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD).

The report forecast that dynamic random access memory (DRAM) manufacturers will suffer losses of NT$30 billion (US$882.35 million) as a whole, while thin-film transistor liquid crystal display (TFT-LCD) manufacturers will suffer losses of NT$16 billion (US$470.58 million), with small- and medium-sized firms bearing the brunt.

Citing the slim world growth of 2.4 percent for this year and the negative expansion for the United States in the second quarter, the report predicted a worldwide decline of 53 percent, the second biggest plunge in history, in DRAM sales.
The report estimated that the world's semiconductor market will shrink by 35 percent this year, before expanding by 12 percent next year and 23 percent in 2003.

As for Taiwan, the wafer foundry market will be cut by 32 percent this year, with the capacity factor -- the percentage of utilized capacity to installed capacity -- declining from 97 percent last year to 54 percent this year, translating into a loss of NT$30 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC OFFICIAL MEETS WITH MAINLAND CHINESE OFFICIAL FROM HONG KONG

TEXT.P: Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Vice Chairman Chen Ming-tung hosted a dinner in honor of Xing Kuishan, a Beijing official in charge of Taiwan affairs in Hong Kong, in Taipei Wednesday.
Xing is in Taipei for a five-day visit in his capacity as advisor to a 32-member mission organized by the Hong Kong Goodwill Association.
Chen told reporters Thursday that because it was their first meeting, they just chatted over dinner without raising any "sensitive" political topics.
Other guests invited to the dinner included the MAC's Hong Kong and Macau Affairs Department Director Chang Liang-jen and Straits Exchange Foundation Deputy Secretary-General Yen Wan-chin.

When members of the visiting mission visited the Cabinet-level MAC earlier that day, Chen said that the Taipei's policy toward Hong Kong and Macau is in line with the principles set forth by President Chen Shui-bian in his inaugural speech last year.
The spirit of the principle, he noted, is based on "goodwill and reconciliation, positive cooperation and everlasting peace."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies on Friday are as follows:
The China Times:
The allocation formula for the tax redistribution fund will be overhauled next year.
The United Daily News:
Kaohsiung's share of the tax redistribution fund will be raised gradually while Taipei's will be lowered.
The Liberty Times:
Starting Saturday, leaving cellular phones off while behind the wheel.
The Taiwan Daily:
President Chen says media should refrain from 'making a joke of national security.'
The Central Daily News:
Tax change has Taipei mayor feeling cold.
The China Post:
Taipei Mayor Ma cries foul as Kaohsiung gains greater tax share.
The Taiwan News:
Cabinet decides to take NT$1.39 billion from Taipei City.
The Taipei Times:
Outcry grows over parole of the 'Wolf'.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, Aug. 31, or the 13th day of the seventh month of the Year of the Snake according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
12AD: Caligula, originally Gaius Caesar, Roman emperor remembered for his murderous reign, is born. He succeeded his adopted father Tiberius. After a severe illness, he displayed the ruthlessness, extravagance and megalomania that led to his assassination.
1422: Henry V, King of England, who reopened the Hundred Years' War, defeating the French at Agincourt in 1415 and capturing all of Normandy by 1419, dies of dysentery in France at the age of 35. His son Henry VI accedes to the throne at the age of nine months.
1907: The Anglo-Russian Convention is signed in St. Petersburg, settling differences between the two over Tibet, Afghanistan and Persia.
1907: Ramon Magsaysay, president of the Philippines from 1953 to 1957, is born.
1939: Adolf Hitler announces the invasion of Poland. Three days later, both Britain and France declared war on Germany, marking the outbreak of World War II.
1945: The Nationalist government divides the three northeastern provinces in Manchuria into nine provinces.
1957: Malaysia achieves independence from Britain with Tengku Abdul Rahman as its first president.
1961: President Chiang Kai-shek tells 70 visiting American reporters that Kinmen and Matsu "are as important as West Berlin."
1962: The former British possessions of Trinidad and Tobago become an independent nation.
1962: The Republic of China recognizes the Republic of Trinidad and Tobago.
1965: Pakistan and India threaten war over Kashmir.
1968: A strong earthquake rocks northeastern Iran, killing 12,000 people and injuring over 100,000 others.
1974: The first plant to produce high-density polyethylene resins in the Republic of China is dedicated at Toufen in Miaoli County.
1976: Little League, Big League and Senior League teams return to Taipei after winning world titles in the United States.
1980: The ROC Mulan soccer team wins the championship at the first International Women's Soccer Tournament held in the United States.
1989: Buckingham Palace officially confirms that the marriage of Queen Elizabeth II's daughter, Anne, and Captain Mark Phillips is on the rocks.
1990: Premier Hau Pei-tsun advises the Legislative Yuan that ROC relations with mainland China will operate under the concept of "one country, two areas."
1992: Former British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher expresses support for the ROC's entry into the GATT during her visit to Taipei.
1993: Beijing makes public a white paper reiterating its position of solving the Taiwan problem by "peaceful reunification" and "one country, two systems," while refusing to renounce the use of force against Taiwan.
1994: Russian President Boris Yeltsin and German Chancellor Helmut Kohl jointly preside over a farewell ceremony marking an end to half a century of military presence on German soil by troops of the former Soviet Union.
1994: The IRA declares an unconditional end to its 25-year armed struggle for a united Ireland and its war against British rule of Northern Ireland.
1995: The ruling Kuomintang nominates incumbent President Lee Teng-hui as its presidential candidate.
1997: Britain's Princess Diana and her millionaire companion Dodi Al Fayed are killed in a Paris car crash.
1999: Raymond F. Burghardt, the newly appointed director of the Taipei office of the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT), arrives in Taipei to assume his post.
2000: U.S. President Bill Clinton emphasizes that America must consider the impact on Asian security of a decision to deploy a National Missile Defense system in Asia.
2000: ROC Minister of National Defense Wu Shih-wen says that the military will continue to try to obtain an early warning system after recent war games revealed Taiwan's limited means to counter mainland Chinese missile attack.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "It is only he, in the world, who possesses absolute truth who can get to the bottom of the law of his being. He who can get to the bottom of the law of his being will be able to get to the bottom of the law of being of other men."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN, CHINA WTO BIDS MAY BE APPROVED IN NOVEMBER: U.S. OFFICIAL
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Aug. 30 (CNA) (By Herman Pan and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Taiwan and mainland China's bids to join the World Trade Organization (WTO) are on track to be approved in November when the world trade regulatory body holds a ministerial-level meeting in Qatar, sources from the U.S. Trade Representative (USTR) office said Thursday.

U.S. Trade Representative Robert Zoellick said that as the current process is moving along in a very constructive way, there certainly is a real prospect of this happening at the Nov. 9-13 WTO meeting in Doha, Qatar.

Mainland China has reached bilateral agreements on WTO accession with 37 members countries, and the process for it to join the global trading club will soon be concluded, Zoellick said, adding that Taiwan is expected to join at about the same time.

However, Zoellick, answering a CNA reporter's questions during a news briefing, declined to further clarify whether the accessions of mainland China and Taiwan will occur back-to-back or one day apart.

According to USTR officials, even if WTO admission for both Taiwan and mainland China is approved in November, actual accession is not expected to happen until January, 2002, as the legislatures of Taiwan and mainland China will first have to formally consent to the conditions attached to admission.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK PRICES UP BY 5.58 POINTS

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) gained ground on Friday, with the benchmark weighted price index moving up 5.58 points to close at 4,509.44.
Market turnover amounted to NT$51.83 billion (US$1.5 billion).

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Shares prices opened low but closed higher on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Friday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 5.58 points to close at 4,509.44.

Affected by a decline in U.S. stock prices, the bourse opened at 4,450.2 but began to go up due to the good performance of financial shares. The index fluctuated between 4,513.26 and 4,430.43 during trading.

A total of 2.51 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$51.83 billion (US$1.5 billion), a decrease from the previous trading session which saw 3.21 billion stocks change hands on a market turnover of NT$62.97 billion (US$1.83 billion).
Only one of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with bank and insurance shares moving up 1.9 percent. Electrical stocks remained unchanged.

The other major categories posted losses, with construction stocks moving down the most at 4 percent, followed by textile issues at 1.8 percent, pulp and paper issues at 1.5 percent, plastics and chemical stocks at 1.3 percent, foodstuff shares at 0.7 percent, and cement stocks at 0.4 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 353 to 165, with 69 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAPAN FIRMLY OPPOSES TO FORCE TO SETTLE TAIWAN ISSUE: LEGISLATOR

TEXT.P: The Japanese government has repeatedly conveyed messages to mainland Chinese authorities that Japan firmly opposes Beijing using force against Taiwan to settle the so-called "Taiwan issue," an influential Japanese parliamentarian said Thursday.

Koichi Kato, Japan's former chief Cabinet secretary, who is currently visiting Taipei at the invitation of the private politics think-tank Nanhai Foundation, said leaders on both sides of the Taiwan Strait should "sit down and talk" to narrow down their differences, rather than resort to military confrontation.

In a speech delivered Thursday, Kato said that Japan forged diplomatic relations with mainland China in 1972 based on Japan's national policies and that since then, Japan has clearly stated its position regarding Beijing-Taipei-Tokyo triangular relations.
He added that the current Japan-China diplomatic framework is in line with Japan's interests and is conducive to stability in the Taiwan Strait.
Kato pointed out, however, that the international community should spare no efforts in helping bolster cross-Taiwan Strait stability.

At the same time, he said, both sides of the Taiwan Strait should return to the negotiating table as soon as possible and work toward reconciliation, adding that whichever side causes cross-strait relations to deteriorate will fail to obtain approval from members of the international community.
Kato, a member of the lower house of the Japanese Diet who has for a long time been known as pro-Beijing, stressed that regional economic prosperity closely hinges on stability in the Taiwan Strait.
He warned that based on the experience of history, any regional conflict that remains stalemated for a prolonged period of time creates a powder-keg situation that can easily lead to bloodshed.

He said he keenly expects that conflict will never break out across the Taiwan Strait, calling on both sides to sit down and engage in talks on political, economic and diplomatic issues and never resort to force to solve disputes.

DOC.HEADLINE: DIRECT LINKS TALKS MUST BE CONDUCTED BY AUTHORIZED OFFICIAL REPS: MAC

TEXT.P: Engagements between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait that involve the exercise of public authority should be negotiated by government agencies or officially authorized organizations, a senior official said Friday.

Mainland Affairs Council Vice Chairman Lin Chong-pin made the remarks in response to a mainland Chinese official's recent statement that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait can negotiate direct "three links" issues through private organizations.

Wang Zaixi, deputy director of the Taiwan Affairs Office under mainland China's State Council or Cabinet, said in a speech delivered in Singapore Thursday that so long as Taiwan regards the direct cross-strait "three links" as a domestic matter, technical details regarding the opening of such links could be negotiated through civic groups, private corporations, or industry and trade associations.
Commenting on Wang's overture, Lin said government-to-government talks are needed for any cross-strait engagements that involve the exercise of public authority.

"This is our established policy and position," Lin said, adding that as the opening of direct trade, postal and transportation links, commonly known as the "three links," involves many critical issues, relevant government agencies or officially authorized intermediary bodies on both sides must sit down to talk to lay down certain basic rules and operational guidelines.

As the just-concluded Economic Development Advisory Conference reached a consensus on easing restrictions on cross-strait trade and investment, the timing for opening the direct "three links" has become a hot topic on both sides of the Taiwan Strait in recent days.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock index futures market were lower on Friday, as Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index futures for September moved down 15 points to close at 4,442, with 11,832 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for October lost 2 points to finish at 4,449, with 55 contract transactions, while next June futures decreased 97 points to close at 4,405, with two contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for other months.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Friday at 4,457 for September, 4,451 for October, 4,459 for December, 4,505 for next March, and 4,502 for next June.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, reported mixed results.
September TE futures edged down 0.15 points to close at 216.5, with 3,004 contract transactions, while October TE futures increased 1.4 points to finish at 217, with 38 contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for other months.
September TF futures rose 8 points to finish at 644.6, with 2,818 contract transactions, while October TF futures gained 4.4 points to close at 644, with 6 contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: WHICH PORTS TO BE USED FOR DIRECT SHIPPING STILL UNDECIDED: OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: A Cabinet official said Friday that it is still too early to react to speculation on whether Taichung Harbor in central Taiwan will be authorized as one of the Taiwan seaports to engage in direct shipping with mainland China.

Chen Ming-tong, vice chairman of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), Taiwan's highest government agency in charge of formulating policies toward mainland China, called on the Taiwan public not to engage in meaningless speculation, saying that the questions of which seaports and how many will be designated as appointed ports for direct cross-strait shipping is still in the planning stage.
Chen said he is bewildered by rumors that Taichung Harbor has been excluded from the list, which have stirred up swipes against the government from among the people in central Taiwan.
As for the official opening of Taiwan to mainland Chinese tourists, Chen said the MAC will announce the implementation date "at the appropriate time."

He made the remarks during a forum held at Feng Chia University that was participated in by Taichung Mayor Chang Wen-ying; Lin Chia-cheng, chairman of the Cabinet-level Research, Development and Evaluation Commission; and Liu An-chih, president of Feng Chia University.

Chen said he clearly understands that people from central Taiwan, particularly those in the tourism sector, have attached great expectations on the opening of Taiwan to mainland Chinese tourists for leisure trips as this is expected to be an important shot in the arm for central Taiwan, whose tourism industry has been sluggish since the devastating 921 earthquake in 1999.

He added that although the Cabinet has given the green light to the plan in July regarding the opening of Taiwan to mainland Chinese tourists, the exact time it will formally take effect has not yet been decided as bilateral negotiations on technical issues remain unsettled.

DOC.HEADLINE: ENGLISH BECOMES COMPULSORY COURSE IN TAIWAN'S ELEMENTARY SCHOOLS

TEXT.P: Schoolchildren in Taiwan are to start learning English at the fifth grade in elementary school as part of the education authorities' push for an "the earlier, the better" policy in English teaching.
The Ministry of Education has instructed all elementary schools to include English in the curricula of the fifth and sixth grades in the semester beginning early September.

As foreign language ability becomes more and more important in academic as well as career pursuits in Taiwan, the education authorities have sought to create a better environment for the younger generation to master English, which is the most popular foreign language in Taiwan.

In the past few years, several elementary schools, mostly private ones, have started to give English lessons to their pupils. English courses have become attractions of these schools and many parents try very hard to have their children registered at these schools.

It is not unusual to find urban children starting to learn English at kindergarten or bilingual cram schools as early as four years of age. Before the educational authorities announced that English would be a compulsory course in elementary school curricula, children's English-learning cram schools and bilingual kindergartens were already mushrooming in metropolitan Taipei and other big cities on the island.

Many children in urban areas have already learned English basics before starting courses in elementary school, according to an educational official. With better resources, children in the cities usually have a head-start, he added.

While the Ministry of Education is expecting that compulsory English will provide all children with equal opportunities in school, the first syndrome of the urban-rural difference is already apparent, as many elementary schools in remote areas are already having difficulty recruiting qualified English teachers.

With the new semester beginning within the next few days, schools in Hualien and Taitung counties on the eastern coast, southern Pingtung County, and the offshore islands of Penghu, Kinmen and Matsu are still waiting for applicants for posts as English teachers, the official said.
He added that at least 600 more English teachers are needed by the 2,557 registered elementary schools.

The Ministry of Education is very disappointed about the situation, because not many of the 1,138 elementary English teachers trained by the ministry under a special program last year are interested in posts in remote areas, according to the official.

DOC.HEADLINE: N.T. DOLLAR UP ON TAIPEI FOREX MARKET

TEXT.P: The new Taiwan dollar rose NT$0.028 against the U.S. dollar on the Taipei foreign exchange market Friday, closing at 34.554.
