DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND-BASED TAIWAN BUSINESSMEN FAVOR EASED TRADE POLICIES

TEXT.P: A Shanghai-based businessman from Taiwan said recently that phasing out the government's "no haste, be patient" policy restricting local investment in mainland China will help bolster competitiveness on both sides of the Taiwan Strait.

The businessman claimed that in any case, the policy is only symbolic rather than an effective means of holding back Taiwan trade with and investment in mainland China, adding that Taiwan investment in the mainland has never stopped, despite government regulations.

Officials from the Taiwan Electrical and Electronic Manufacturers Association claimed meanwhile that Taiwan has "no choice" but to opt for relaxed restrictions on trade with the mainland, particularly in the face of mainland China's World Trade Organization (TWO) entry, when major manufacturers and traders from the United States, Japan and South Korea are expected to jump into the huge mainland market to take advantage of the freer trade environment after China's WTO accession.

Another Taiwan businessman, based in Guangzhou, said relaxed trade regulations toward the mainland will benefit both sides of the Taiwan Strait, which can jointly explore mainland and world markets using Taiwan's technology, management and expertise in international trade and mainland China's cheap workforce and immense market potential.

Yet another Shanghai-based Taiwan businessman lauded Taiwan's recent decision to phase out the "no haste, be patient" policy, saying that replacing policies of containment with measures based on "positive opening and efficient control" will eventually benefit Taiwan.
He added that Taiwan will become richer and stronger after Taiwan businesses harvest gains from mainland China's rising economy, in which Taiwan capital and manpower are helping a lot.

Hsu Ming-yi, a researcher from the National Policy Research Foundation in Taiwan, said that in accordance with the theory of international investment, the more investment a company makes abroad, the more returns the company will secure from its overseas operations, underlining the current situation of Taiwan investment in mainland China.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRODUCTION FACILITIES OF TAIWAN'S IC FOUNDRIES LYING IDLE: CEPD

TEXT.P: The production utility rate of Taiwan's semiconductor foundries this year is estimated at only 54 percent of their manufacturing capability, as compared with 97 percent last year, according to a report by the Council for Economic Planning and Development.
The report, released Friday, says that production value of Taiwan's electronic industry as a whole is expected to drop considerably this year.
The DRAM (dynamic random-access memory) sector will suffer the most, with the yearly loss amounting to NT$30 billion, while the TFT-LCD sector is estimated to lose NT$16 billion.

As prospects for the semiconductor sector worldwide remain sluggish, the report forecast that the market for Taiwan semiconductor manufacturers this year will shrink by 35 percent from the level of the previous year.

The two leading semiconductor manufacturers in Taiwan -- Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Corp. (TSMC) and United Microelectronics Corp. (UMC) -- both suffered sales declines in the first half of this year.

In July, TSMC managed to achieve a 1 percent sales growth over last month, thanks to the gradual sales recovery of components for PCs and IA products. UMC, on the other hand, continued to suffer a sales drop due to heavy inventories of telecommunications products.
The report says that the downstream packing and testing factories are suffering greatly as a consequence, with most of their production facilities lying idle.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC SHOULD HAVE PLACE IN ASIA-PACIFIC SECURITY COOPERATION: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Friday that the Republic of China should not be excluded from an Asia-Pacific security cooperation mechanism.
Chen said Asia-Pacific military cooperation should not be confined to the United States and Japan, but should include other Asian countries.
"Even though Taiwan does not maintain formal diplomatic ties with the United States or Japan, it should not be shut out of a regional defense cooperation agreement," he said.
The president further said that peace in the Taiwan Strait is the basis of Asia-Pacific security and is in the common interests of European Union nations with interests in the Asia-Pacific region.

Chen made the remarks while meeting with participants in the 2001 Taipei Roundtable of the Asia-Pacific Security Forum, jointly organized by Taipei's Institute for National Policy Research, the Washington-based Center for Strategic and International Studies (CSIS), the Institute for Strategic and Development Studies (ISDS) in the Philippines and the French Institute Francais des Relations Internationales (IFRI).
He told his guests that he has consistently adopted a positive and supportive attitude toward any mechanism that would contribute to Taiwan Strait peace and Asia-Pacific security.

Chen went on that since he assumed office in the ROC's first democratic transfer of power between different political parties in May 2000, he has on many occasions reiterated his desire to resume cross-strait dialogue and normalize cross-strait relations for the well-being of the people on both sides.
"Moreover, we have outlined our basic principles for handling cross-strait affairs -- goodwill reconciliation, active cooperation and permanent peace," Chen continued.

As for the controversial "one China" issue, Chen said he has repeatedly suggested that the top leaders on both sides use their wisdom to find a mutually acceptable definition of "one China" under the principles of "democracy, parity and peace."
Chen said he firmly believes that normalization of trade and economic ties will be the first step toward normalizing cross-strait relations.

In his previous major policy speeches, Chen went on, he has advocated cross-strait economic and cultural integration as a basis for forging a new framework to maintain permanent peace in the Taiwan Strait.

Touching on the just-concluded Economic Development Advisory Conference (EDAC), the president said the meeting marked the first time since the inauguration of his administration that the ruling and opposition parties have sat down to discuss major national issues.

"It was no easy task for the 120 EDAC members to forge consensus on a number of public issues, including the sensitive cross-strait relations," Chen said, adding that one consensus reached at the Aug. 24-26 meeting was that the "no haste, be patient" policy on cross-strait investment will be replaced by a policy based on "active opening, effective management."
He also said he agrees with a conclusion reached at the 2001 Taipei Roundtable that Taiwan politicians should refrain from "taking domestic partisan disputes" to Beijing.

During the meeting, CSIS Pacific Forum Director Ralph Cossa told Chen that mainland Chinese officials and scholars told him and several other CSIS researchers during a recent visit to Beijing that some Taiwan opposition politicians had advised mainland authorities not to forge contacts with the Chen administration.

The unidentified Taiwan opposition politicians were quoted as having told Beijing officials that if Beijing resumes cross-strait dialogue during Chen's tenure, Chen would stand a better chance of winning re-election three years hence. Chen was Beijing's least-liked candidate in Taiwan's 2000 presidential election due to his party's pro-independence stance.

Cossa said he was not sure whether any Taiwan politician had really offered such advice to Beijing. "I just want to remind Taiwan politicians that Beijing officials and scholars have made such a claim," he added.

For his part, Chen said he hopes that local politicians can refrain from trying to block Beijing from developing contacts with his administration. "Such action would not only allow Beijing to get involved in Taiwan's domestic political disputes but it also violates the democratic spirit and rational inter-party competition," he stressed.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC EDGES OUT KOREA IN DEBUT AT 4TH ASIAN YOUTH BASEBALL TOURNEY

TEXT.P: Chinese Taipei edged out South Korea 2-1 Friday in its debut game at the Fourth Asian Youth Baseball Championship tournament in suburban Taipei.
South Korea scored the first point at the first half of the fourth innings, while Chinese Taipei gained the first point in the second half of the sixth.
The Chinese Taipei nine obtained another point in the second half of the eighth.
Eight teams representing Japan, Korea, Australia, India, Thailand, Indonesia, the Philippines and the Republic of China are taking part in the six-day competition.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINESE TAIPEI TAKES 11TH PLACE IN WOMEN'S BASKETBALL AT UNIVERSIADE
DOC.DATELINE: Beijing, Aug. 31 (CNA) (By Lee An-tung & Ed Chen)

TEXT.P: Chinese Taipei beat Mexico 80-75 Friday to place 11th in the consolation games in the women's basketball event at the 21st World University Games in Beijing.
Chinese Taipei ranked sixth at the last Universiade.
Chinese Taipei has so far chalked up three silver medals and four bronzes.

DOC.HEADLINE: TSMC GEARING UP TO OPEN OFFICES IN MAINLAND CHINA

TEXT.P: An executive of the Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Corporation (TSMC) -- Taiwan's top chip maker -- said Friday that his company is preparing to send officials to mainland China to study the feasibility of setting up strongholds there.

From the viewpoint of a global management strategy, mainland China is a market TSMC cannot afford to lose because of its market potential, and the company is planning to dispatch officials to collect information regarding trade and investment opportunities in major mainland Chinese cities, according to TSMC Chief Executive Officer F.C. Tseng.

Tseng said that TSMC has not yet decided whether it should set up offices in Beijing, Shanghai or Shenzhen, despite the fact that the company already has mainland Chinese clients. He reiterated that TSMC will not cast any investment into the mainland in the near future.

Tseng's remarks echoed those of TSMC Chairman Morris Chang, who said at the recent Economic Development Advisory Conference that the time has come for his company to make a move in order to edge into the mainland Chinese market.
